This study aims to understand the psychosocial factors (defense and psychological processes) and personality traits that may underlie NP, focusing on the role of early and adulthood traumatic experiences in predicting the onset and maintenance of NP, and the effects of NP on life, emotions, social relationships and the quality of life of the subjects. Thus the investigators will examine the psychosocial predictors of the onset and progression of Chronic Migraine (CM), Fibromyalgia (FM) and Vulvodynia (VU), in an effort to identify a common core of psychosocial characteristics in individuals who suffer from these disorders, despite showing quite different pain behavior. Given the heterogeneity of the three pathologies expressed by NP, it is necessary to investigate the characteristics that may differentiate them with reference to the type of personality, defense mechanisms, childhood traumatic events, and central sensitization. Ultimately, the study aims to identify subgroups of individuals who suffer from NP, based on similarities and differences in psychological variables, in order to tailor the best therapeutic practices for each patient.

<|assistant|>
Pressure injuries, also known as pressure sores, are a medical condition that affects elderly or bedridden patients. The formation of these wounds occurs for several reasons, such as long periods of sitting or lying down without adequate tissue perfusion. The goal of this study is to investigate the prevention effect of a modern mattress system compared to a standard mattress system. The standard mattress system is a viscoelastic mattress with an orthopedic foam system. In the experimental group, a modern mattress system with a support surface with vibration (massage) features, a cube/block system, and a ventilation system is used. To determine the risk of pressure ulcers, the patients' Braden Scores are calculated daily upon admission. The patients are then followed for four weeks, and their pressure ulcer risk is recorded on a daily basis. The pressure ulcer area is calculated with a square centimeter ruler using the Pressure Ulcer Observation Form. The number of patients without pressure ulcers is monitored in both groups, and the number of patients with a Braden Score of 13 or higher is compared statistically between the two groups. The investigators predict that bedridden patients using a mattress system with a support surface that reduces the pressure, vibration, and air exchange will have less pressure ulcer formation. These mattresses with cube/block systems have a greater area of low pressure that offers lower pressure to the patient, which may have a positive effect on prevention of pressure ulcers. The mattresses with cube/block systems are more expensive and cost approximately 400 more euros than the standard mattress, but the prevention of pressure ulcers and subsequent complications may lead to cost savings within a short time.

Children with type 1 diabetes (T1DM) aged 10-12 will be included in the study. The children will be randomized into 2 groups as the experimental group and the control group 2 days a week by a cardiologist who is not involved in the study. The experimental group will perform moderate exercise for a total of 60 minutes for 12 weeks with AR glasses. The control group will not receive any intervention. The exercise group, consisting of 30 children, will be given a single session of AR games, followed by a session of exercise in the first session. At the end of the first 4 weeks, another control session will be given, followed by another exercise session. In the second 4 weeks, the control session will be replaced by a single AR game session and then a new session of 7 days. In the third 4-week period, a control session will be held on the 1st, 3rd and 5th days, and each period will end with an exercise session. This process will be continued for 12 weeks in total. Anthropometric measurements such as body weight, height, subcutaneous fat mass, body composition analysis, and blood biochemistry values will be taken from the children at the beginning of the study, during the progress of the study in the 3rd, 6th, 9th and 12th weeks, and after the completion of the study. The quality of life scale will be applied to the children at the beginning of the study, at the end of the 4th and 8th weeks of the study, and after the completion of the study. By dividing the children into two groups and including them randomly, an experiment will be organized for the 12-week period where 30 children with type 1 diabetes will have different exercise applications. The exercise to be applied by the children in the first 4 weeks after the initial application will be evaluated in the study with AR glasses. The application will be changed in the second 4-week period and continued. This change will be made as follows: In the 6th week of the application, 1 control session will be held on the first day and the application will be changed on the second day. This sequence will be repeated for the 7th day. On the 5th day, a control session will be held in the 1st week, a single AR exercise session will be held in the 2nd week, a control session will be held on the 3rd day, and a single exercise session will be held on the 4th day. Thus, the children in the exercise arm will have a total of 10 exercise sessions and 6 control sessions during the 12-week period. By this method, it will be tried to prevent adaptation and increase motivation, and it will be ensured that the exercise is not boring for the children..

The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of virtual reality on anxiety management before abdominal surgery. For this purpose, a total of 64 patients aged 18-70 who will undergo different types of abdominal surgery under general anesthesia in the operating room of Trakya University Selcuk Ertegun Medical Research and Education Hospital, General Surgery Surgical Outpatient Clinic will be divided into three randomized groups with each patient included in the study. After the preoperative evaluation of the patients, the VAS-A anxiety scale will be applied to the patients, and if the anxiety level of the patient is detected as above 40 in the VAS-A scale, one of the glasses groups will be included in the study, and the data of the remaining patients will be recorded in the control group. In the experimental group, the 12-minute application will be made 15-20 minutes before the patients will be taken to the operating room. The experimental group will also have video viewing at this time. The smart wristband will be worn and preoperative patient measurements will be taken at this time. The patient will be taken to the operating room from that moment on. Anxiety control will be done by the researcher for the control group. In the control group, preoperative patient measurements will also be taken by the researcher. The stress of the patient will be measured by the smart wristband after entering the patient into the operating room. At the time of the intervention (before and after the video application), the measurements of the patients will be recorded.

A prospective, single arm, non-controlled, open label investigation is initiated to evaluate the outcome of laparotomy closures performed with Suture-TOOL as compared to non-instrumented technique in terms of stitch count and incision length/wound length (SL/WL) ratio. This will be the first comprehensive evaluation of Suture-TOOL for abdominal closure at 4 sites in Europe.
The Suture-TOOL is a fast and standardized device for closure of the abdominal fascia. 
The primary aim of the investigation is to compare the performance of Suture-TOOL for abdominal closure by evaluating stitch count and incision length/wound length ratio. Stitch count and SL/WL-ratio will be calculated.
A total of 100 consecutive patients will be enrolled in the study. 
Patients will undergo scheduled open abdominal surgery (for benign or malignant colorectal disease), through a midline incision ≥ 120 mm. Abdominal closure with Suture-TOOL is performed immediately after surgery by trained personnel. Stitch count, incision length, SL/WL-ratio, incision closure time, surgeons´ comfort with device during closure, surgical wound infection within 7 days of surgery, postoperative pain score, scar appearance within 1 month and one year after surgery as well as length of hospital stay will be assessed.

- Immune matrix of the immune cells (eg. T- lymphocyte, cytotoxic T-cells, antigen-presenting cells)
- Tumor- tissue- matrix in the blood (systemic) and the affected salivary gland tissue (intratumoral) as well as the presence of tumor cells and tumor-specific antigens.
- Monitoring of immune cells and messenger substances in the blood/serum
- Measurement of cytokines in peripheral blood and their change by cytokine networks and immune responses (eg. Interferon, Interleukins)
- Examination of the metabolic state in blood and serum of the patients through untargeted liquid mass-spectrometry to determine the overall cellular, as well as the tumor-specific cellular metabolism
- Determination of the microbiome of patients using 16S rRNA deep sequencing of saliva, tumor and stool samples
- Collection of stool, saliva, blood and tumor tissue of the patients for long-term storage
- Comparability of the groups for their immune characteristics (immune matrix, immunophenotyping, cytokine network, metabolic state, microbiome)

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the nervous system. In our study, we aim to investigate the relationship between the Mediterranean diet and the walking habits of individuals with MS. The purpose of the study is also to evaluate the walking-related problems and quality of life of individuals with MS over time. The study will include 50 individuals with MS who are physically inactive (sedentary) or slightly active. During the study period, the compliance of the Mediterranean diet, the walking status of individuals (walking distance, ability to carry out daily living activities) and the self-perceived quality of life of individuals will be investigated. As a result of the study; It is aimed to determine the level of individuals' compliance with the Mediterranean diet and the tendency to use various nutritional supplements. In conclusion, the study aims to identify the effects of adherence to the Mediterranean diet on individuals with MS and the quality of life, walk ability and gait ability of individuals with MS.

This project is a multi-centre, randomized, controlled, prospective clinical study. A total of 187 subjects diagnosed with Crohn's disease according to the clinical criteria were selected and enrolled. Randomization was conducted in the ratio of 1:1. The selective intensive induction regimen group (SIIT group), which included 95 subjects, adopted the combined dosing scheme for SIIT regimen. After intravenous infusion, the patients were randomly divided into different subgroups and received intravenous or subcutaneous standard induction regimen according to the UST-CDST evaluation of CRP standard. The control group adopted the standard induction regimen: routine intravenous infusion at week 0, 160mg of UST at week 8, and then a total of 480mg (80mg/week) standard subcutaneous injection regimen. The two groups were statistically analysed according to the intention-to-treat principle. In addition, the two groups were also evaluated for differences in response rate, safety, remission rate and other clinical outcomes. This study provides important data for the evaluation of clinical decision-making tools in guiding the treatment of Crohn's disease.

<|assistant|>
This study is conducted to investigate the patients' preferences for the treatment options of overactive bladder. In Australia, where a third of the population is born overseas, diversity in treatment preference can be seen. The aim of this study is to evaluate the importance of treatment-related characteristics and their impact on patient preference for treatment. Therefore, a discrete choice experiment is designed. The participants will be asked to choose between two therapeutic options, each option comes with its own characteristics. The characteristics represent the different features of the therapies, such as cost, effectiveness, treatment frequency, recovery time after treatment or its side effects. Participants will be randomised and offered two options in two rounds. The primary outcome measure will be the proportion of participants choosing either option. The differences in mean characteristics rated between groups will also be evaluated. The data will be anonymized and encrypted and stored in a central database. The statistical analysis of the discrete choice experiment will utilise the R software package, the gnnet2 package and the mlogit package for the calculation of the parameters. This study will provide the first data on the preferences of a diverse OAB patient population towards different treatment options.

Background: Despite being able to continuously monitor blood glucose (BG) levels, people living with type 1 diabetes (T1D) are unable to effectively utilise this technology due to the lack of access to and affordability of Continuous Glucose Monitors (CGM).
Objective: The main objective of this study is to generate evidence to inform policy and decision makers on the potential benefits of use of CGM in South Africa.
Study Design: A three-arm pragmatic randomised controlled study (RCT) design will be used to assess effectiveness of continuous and intermittent CGM use from baseline to the end of intervention period (15 months).
Study arms: 1. Participants will be randomised to continuous use of CGM from enrolment to the end of intervention period.
2. Participants will be randomised to intermittent use of CGM (use for 2 weeks once every three months) from enrolment to the end of intervention period.
3. Participants will receive the standard of care.
Quality of life (QoL) and costing surveys will be conducted using mixed methods design. Focus group discussions (FGDs) will be held among recipients of care and their caregivers and among health care providers (HCPs) involved in clinical practice. Semi-structured interviews (SSI) will be held among HCPs involved in clinical care at the study sites.
Expected outcome: This evidence will have an impact on policy decisions regarding the access to and utilisation of CGM technology in South Africa.

Prostate cancer has a high rate of biochemical relapse, especially in patients with a positive mpMRI and Dynamic Contrast Enhancement (DCE). Treatment is still a challenge since it must provide a balance between oncological outcomes and acceptable toxicity. The aim of this study is to evaluate the oncological efficacy of SBRT with mpMRI focal dose escalation on dominant lesion (DIL for dose escalation) compared to standard SBRT in patients with localized PCa.

The aim of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of the combined action of a serious game (SG) system and a specific aerobic training in improving the respiratory and physical fitness of young people with asthma or chronic lung diseases compared to the same training alone. It is estimated that the SG system will contribute to improve self-care, self-awareness and compliance with therapy.

Additionally, in Smokers, the investigators will investigate the relationship between specific and general PIT effects and both questionnaire-assessed chronic and acute stress. The investigators hypothesise that general PIT effect found in the single-lever PIT task is more strongly associated with the general PIT and less strongly associated with the outcome-specific PIT effect in the full PIT task. The investigators also hypothesise that increased chronic stress enhances effects of both general and outcome-specific PIT. However, if there are significant stress-induced effects, the investigators will conduct an additional post-hoc power analysis that will determine the necessary sample sizes to observe significant stress-induced differences across the three study arms. These additional sample sizes should be added. We will calculate the needed sample size for this exploratory analysis based on the power analysis. The investigators will include sufficient participants for the exploratory analysis in each study arm. These additional sample sizes (approximately 60) will be added to both the AUD and HC study arms.

The purpose of this study is to determine if it is possible to increase CPAP support beyond the typical 4-week course and reduce the adverse outcomes in preterm infants. The investigators will apply a structured maintenance/weaning CPAP protocol and compare it to standard of care.

The purpose of this Phase 3 study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Frexalimab compared to placebo in adults with nonrelapsing secondary progressive MS (SPMS).

Cleft lip and palate are the most prevalent congenital defect of the head and neck. When the palatal shelves and the medial nasal process fail to fuse together between the fourth and eighth weeks of development, unilateral cleft lip and palate results. Lip muscles are disrupted and abnormally inserted to the columellar base on the non-cleft side and from the alar base on the cleft side. The nasal floor and alveolus on the cleft side may be deficient or absent. Several approaches, including quadrangular flaps, triangular flaps, and rotation-advancement procedures, were established in the middle of the twentieth century. The most popular triangular technique which relies on mathematical calculations to lessen vertical lip contracture is the Tennison-triangular Randall's approach. The Cupid's bow is distorted, the white roll up is pulled up by scar contracture and the philtral column is vertically situated, which is modified Millard's technique. To restore the natural facial appearance and functional structure, the objectives of the cleft lip repair are to create a symmetrical lip without any scar and vertical lip contracture. Anthropometric Evaluation of surgical technique and comparison of cleft and non-cleft sides are two benefits of measuring surgical outcome The anthropometric measurements which are evaluated is Lip height, Lip length, Philtral length, Lipsub Nasal length, Columelldistance which measures the difference between the base of the nose and the labial commisure. The qualitative evaluations is to analyzed facial aesthetics and appearance impairment using scales, indices, scoring systems and rankings. Both direct and indirect technique can be used to perform the measurements and qualitative evaluations. To evaluate the anthropometric measurements of the Cleft lip patients 21 patient of unilateral cleft lip had mishra technique repair and 21 patient of unilateral cleft lip had modified Millard technique repair using the Skelettal class I normative standard values. The measurements are taken on the non-cleft side of the patient and will be compared with the cleft side. Both direct and indirect technique will be used. The qualitative evaluations are measured by comparing it with its opposite non-cleft side, skeletal class I normative standard values, and the control group.

Background: Diverticular disease is a common condition in western countries with relatively uncommon complications, fistulae, complicating diverticular disease occurs in 4-23% of patients hospitalized for diverticular disease. Herein we describe a case of a single-digest fistula (sDF) due to sigmoid diverticulitis, a long-standing problem in which there are more questions than answers. Intra-cavity endoscopy of sDF was performed by one of us (NK) to help define the extent of pathology and its effect on short bowel syndrome.. Aim: The aim of this study was to assess the effectiveness of endoscopic treatment of sDF by using endostitches and clips . Research question: Is Endoscopic Management Of Controlled Colo-cutaneous Fistula As A complication of Acute Sigmoid Diverticulitis Effective? Hypothesis: Yes The Endoscopic Management Of Low Output Recurrent Colonic Fistula After Anterior Resection For Rectal Cancer Is Effective. Design: All consecutive patients with the symptoms of sDF and confirmed by preoperative radiological studies (CT scan) were approached. After endoscopic evaluation patient was randomised into two groups treatment group and no treatment group with the aid of random numbers table method. The random allocation was made independently by the clinical research fellow who did not take part in patient care. Statistical analysis: The data were expressed as number (percent), mean (standard deviation), median (minimum,maximum) or mode as appropriate. The data collected was subjected to statistical analysis using chi square / fisher exact / T- test, and Mann Whitney test. P<0.05 was considered statistically significant. Results: One hundred and ten patients who attended the general surgery outpatients clinic and satisfied the above criteria were approached. One patient refused to participate. One patient didn't have radiological support . The remaining 102 patients were randomized.. A fistula between a sigmoid loop diverticular point and the ileocecal valve was found endoscopically in 86 patients, while the fistula was between the sigmoid diverticular point and the caecum in 16 patients. There were no statistically significant difference between sDF and iDF in relation to age and gender. There were no significant difference with respect to underlying disease factors and the site of the fistula in both groups. Sixty-four patients were managed after 3 weeks of intravenous antibiotics. Twenty-eight (43.8 %) patients were managed conservatively out of which 24 (40.3%) responded well to conservative measures. Six (9.7%) patients in the no treatment group required immediate surgery. One patient had perforation of the jejunum and the presence of a high output fistula that was not able to heal conservatively. Five patients developed recurrent symptoms in the form of sepsis during the early period after discharge, and they required emergency laparotomy . All fifty-six patients who submitted endoscopic management had a decrease in volume of drain (61 +/ - 12 versus 395 +/ - 13.3 mL; p< 0 .005) and white cells count of drain (257 +/ - 112 versus 124 +/ - 40.8 mm3/ h; p< 0.005). During the follow up period, nine patients who submitted endoscopic management develop recurrent symptoms in the form of sepsis and required emergency laparotomy, but no patient has developed recurrence of the fistula. The recurrence of fistula was also evaluated one month after operation in the treatment group. No recurrence of the fistula was seen in the treatment group during the follow up period. A high recurrence rate of the fistula (64.3%) was observed in the conservative group and it was statistically higher than that of the treatment group (40.3%; Chi square test: p< 0.001). No significant morbidity was recorded in the treatment group. The overall mean duration of hospital stay in the treatment group was significantly lower than that of conservation group (12 +/ - 3.1 versus 18.3 +/ - 10.3 days; p< 0.005). Patients will receive letermovir at a dose of 480 mg, orally once daily, for up to 365 days.

To propose the PHYSIOSCORE as the most reliable instrument to evaluate the care complexity level for physical therapists working in the hospital with emphasis on postoperative and/or postacute cardiac patients (with or without heart failure). The purpose of this study is to identify patients where observation is feasible after a diagnosis of oropharyngeal cancer with HPV + status that warrants adjuvant therapy following transoral surgery. The investigators hypothesize that patients who are clinically selected to receive observation after treatment with transoral robotic surgery can be observed with the understanding that salvage would be pursued in the case of recurrence. The investigators aim to enroll 120 patients. Patients on the experimental arm will be under observation only. Patients enrolled in this arm will be monitored for toxicity, Quality of Life (QoL) and outcomes evaluation. Suspected locoregional recurrence based on physical examination, imaging or increasing ctDNA will undergo completion of workup at the discretion of the University of Maryland Head and Neck tumor board. LRR will be offered salvage treatment based on recommendations from multi-disciplinary discussion. Salvage therapy (surgery and/or radiation with or without chemotherapy) could be offered. Salvage therapy will not be given if local failure or recurrence were demonstrated due to the presence of the disease. Treatment-related toxicities are known and well characterized, but the extent of short and long-term complications associated with observation following TORS is not yet known. Patients on the experimental arm of the study will serve as a control group and will receive the standard of care. Patients in this arm will undergo adjuvant treatment per standard of care (Radiation with or without chemotherapy). Radiation therapy alone usually will be given and chemotherapy will be given as determined by the treating physician. Patients will be offered the option of concurrent chemotherapy if deemed appropriate by the physician. Chemotherapy options include weekly carboplatin AUC2 and paclitaxel 50mg/m2, every 3 weeks. Radiation therapy will consist of 60 gray in 30 fractions over 6 weeks. Chemoradiation therapy can be administered concurrently or sequentially as deemed appropriate by the treating physician. Blood and tissue samples will be collected. Blood and tissue sample tests include ctDNA test (blood test for diagnostic and surveillance purposes measuring expression of Cell free HPV tumor DNA (ctDNA) in the blood, Circulating Tumor DNA (ctDNA) test.

The purpose of this randomized phase II trial is to compare hypofractionated breast radiotherapy with a short and high (26Gy) dose per fraction (ultra-hypofractionation) versus a standard fractionation regimen, either partial breast irradiation (PBI) or whole breast irradiation (WBI, also called APBI). PBI is a hypo-fractionated treatment regimen for early breast cancer with a reduced treatment time of approximately one week. Recent evidence from randomized prospective trials is in favor of PBI as it allows better quality of life with no decrease in oncologic outcomes. However, some concern about the risk of local recurrence has persisted since no meta-analysis has been able to establish the risk due to the heterogeneity of the included studies and the impossibility of comparing PBI and WBI. The investigators believe that the reduction in treatment time and the low toxicity rate of daily fractionation allow the hypofractionated regimen to be safely compared with the standard fractionation regimen. The main hypothesis of this trial is that ultra-hypofractionated radiotherapy in either PBI or WBI is as effective in terms of oncologic control with less acute and late toxicity compared to the standard fractionation regimen. Specifically, the investigators aim to demonstrate that ultra-hypofractionated PBI and WBI are as effective as the standard fractionation regimen (26 Gy/50 Gy) with less toxicity and less financial burden on the health care system. Additionally, the investigators will assess patient-reported outcomes (PRO) (quality of life, body image, psychosocial burden and satisfaction with treatment), complication rates and late toxicities. After 5 years of follow-up, the investigators' hypothesis is that ultra-hypofractionated radiotherapy in either PBI or WBI is as effective as the standard fractionation regimen (26 Gy/50 Gy) with less toxicity and can be offered after breast-conserving surgery and adequate nodal staging in all patients with early operable breast cancer.

Relapsed/refractory (R/R) multiple myeloma (MM) patients have a high symptom burden, poor health-related quality of life (HRQoL), and significant risk for toxicities. Currently, there are limited programs available to address these issues. 
The goal of this study is to explore the use of symptom monitoring and digital life coaching (DLC) to inform a more complete understanding of the impact of MM on symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and financial, physiologic, and psychosocial well-being among a diverse U.S.-based, contemporary sample.

Humans consume too little fibre. Especially patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), i.e. ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease, suffer from a low intake of dietary fibre, while fibre is known to have beneficial effects on their health. However, IBD patients have difficulties with accepting (large) amounts of dietary fibre. Fibre-rich dried vegetable supplements as a source of food-derived prebiotic fibres (FDF) may provide a suitable option for IBD patients. In this study, IBD patients will receive dried chicory root. This intervention will be performed as a pilot study.
Primary research question: In patients with inflammatory bowel disease, what is the effect of a 4-week intervention with 10-20 gram of additional dietary chicory root fibre intake?
Secondary research question: In patients with inflammatory bowel disease, What is the difference in effect between patients with ulcerative colitis and patients with Crohn’s disease regarding changes in fecal calprotectin, gut microbiota composition, and stool frequency and consistency?

This study will be an exploratory multicenter randomized clinical trial conducted to evaluate the use of a porcine acellular dermal matrix for the treatment of RT1 gingival recessions. This will be done in parallel to the periodontal plastic procedure performed with the coronally advanced flap. 74 patients will participate, who will be randomized into two experimental groups. For a six-month follow-up, intraoral and extraoral pictures will be taken; intraoral photographs will be evaluated through a clinical analysis, using a digital image calibrator, the same evaluators will evaluate gingival tissue thickness, probing depth, gingival index and plaque index. During the surgical procedure, the use of local anesthesia will be performed, and sub epithelial connective tissue graft will be harvested from the palate, and coronally advanced flap will be performed with or without acellular dermal graft application. The use of antibiotics will be done for all patients.

There is accumulating evidence from experimental studies and clinical trials, indicating that physical exercise promotes physiological, functional, and neuropsychiatric benefits. Physical exercise can change health conditions such as cardio-respiratory fitness, blood pressure and heart rate. Physical exercise can reduce the expression of chronic diseases, increase life expectancy, increase the resistance of the body to infections, improve bone development, improve motor, cognitive, and emotional functions, promote improvement in brain blood flow and improvement in brain neurochemicals, increasing the production of neurotrophic factors.
Physical exercise during hemodialysis is being shown to improve the quality of life of these patients, reduce some cardio-neurological risks, and influence the hemodynamic responses of patients, making the intervention with physical exercise very promising for chronic renal patients. However, many patients on hemodialysis are subjected to a variety of difficulties, which may prevent exercise.
This research project aims to carry out a Longitudinal Cross-over Clinical Trial, considering a sample of 32 chronic renal patients, to observe physiological changes, which can be measured during a virtual game environment, compared to the effects of physical exercise in the usual format in these patients, while dialyzing. The main objective is to understand the impact of virtual reality games on various variables of interest in the management of Chronic Renal Disease (Chronic Kidney Disease - CKD). In this context, there is a hypothesis that virtual reality games have a greater effect on the modulation of heart rate variability than conventional physical exercise. The study will be done from January 2021 to December 2021.

The objectives of this study are to determine whether ventilatory variability and intensity of dyspnea can predict the success of a weaning test (synchronization test) performed in 28-day ventilated patients. Therefore, the study will involve 50 patients whose weaning test will be carried out during the course of their stay in the intensive care unit. In these patients, the measurement of ventilatory variability will be carried out in addition to the usual observations and protocols for weaning. Non-communicative patients will be deprived of the subjective evaluation of dyspnea. In addition, in case of failure of the synchronization test, the patient will be put back on the ventilator and the reasons of the failure determined. On the other hand, the study will not provide information on the duration of ventilatory dependence, since this information will be routinely collected in the medical record by the physician in charge of the patient.

Episiotomy is a planned surgical episiotomy incision to the perineum and posterior wall of the vagina during the second stage of labor. Vulvar pain is important issue for sexual health in patients. It can cause a wide range of problems from vulva infection to sexual dysfunction. Although there are several treatments in the literature, it still affects woman's sex life. Er:YAG laser has shown its efficacy for vulvar pain and vulvar scar healing. However, no study has evaluated the effect of Er:YAG laser on the tissue healing of the episiotomy scars and the vulvar pain. In this study, the investigators evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of Er:YAG laser on the tissue healing of the episiotomy scars and the reduction of vulvar pain in postpartum patients with mediolateral episiotomy in a 6 months follow-up.

How has somatosensory deficits impacted children and adolescents with spastic unilateral cerebral palsy and what has been done to address this?
There is a growing body of evidence highlighting somatosensory deficits and their potential therapeutic value in individuals with spastic unilateral cerebral palsy. In a recent systematic review, the authors concluded that somatosensory therapy can lead to improved functional performance in children and adolescents with unilateral cerebral palsy. Yet, the full clinical potential and long-term effects of somatosensory therapy still remain to be explored. Therefore, the proposed study will focus on evaluating the effect of somatosensory therapy on upper limb somatosensory outcomes in 50 children and adolescents aged 7 to 15 years old with spastic unilateral cerebral palsy.

<|assistant|>
Synopsis: The gut microbiome has been implicated in several medical disorders including type 2 diabetes (T2DM), cardiovascular disease, ulcerative colitis, gastro-oesophageal reflux and gallstone disease. Gut microbes may either promote or impede the progression of many disorders and therefore have significant clinical implications for patients affected by them. There is increasing evidence suggesting differences in the gut microbiome of patients with gallstone disease compared to those without but there are only a handful of small scale studies linking these differences with the development of gallstone disease complications and patient outcomes to date. Preliminary results from these studies suggest an association between gut microbiome diversity (the richness of the number of species present in the gut) and gallstone disease and that specific species may confer risk for symptomatic gallstone disease. Researchers are currently unaware of what these microbes are and whether these differences have any effect on the progression of gallstone disease or its complications. Therefore, this study aims to understand the profile of the gut microbiome in adult patients diagnosed with gallstone disease and its relationship with patient outcomes including those who develop complications following diagnosis and those who develop complications following cholecystectomy. It is intended that this work will help to identify the differences in gut microbiome in patients with gallstone disease compared to controls and link this to the development of complications. The knowledge gained from this study will allow researchers to devise strategies to reduce the number and severity of complications in patients with gallstone disease and ultimately result in a better patient experience and reduced use of NHS resources. This study is crucial in the first step in understanding differences in the gut microbiome that are linked to gallstone disease. The findings from this study will provide the evidence to support future larger scale studies or trials to determine interventions which can be used to reduce the development of complications in patients with this disorder.

Inclusion criteria: All adults (age >18 years of age) patients diagnosed with gallstone disease following confirmatory imaging at an East Kent University Foundation Trust Hospital. Patients of any gender, ethnicity or socio-economic background are eligible as well as pregnant women. Patients undergoing both open and laparoscopic cholecystectomy will be included.

Exclusion criteria: Patients less than 18 years of age and patients who do not have capacity to consent to involvement in the study.

Study design: 2 cohorts, consisting of sepsis patients with and without SALD, were selected for the investigators to further compare and analyze the patients' clinical data, characteristics, outcomes, and biochemical markers.
Objectives: This study is an observational, retrospective cohort study, focusing on evaluating correlation between APRI and SALD in adult patients with sepsis.
Study population/sample: The MIMIC IV database for sepsis patients was downloaded from physionet. We performed a review, after which we selected the cases most relevant to our study. Inclusion criteria in the MIMIC IV database for sepsis patients included the following: 1) adult sepsis patients (≥18 years) and 2) first hospitalization and first ICU admission. Exclusion criteria were: 1) all types of chronic liver disease; 2) viral hepatitis; 3) primary acute cholangiopathies; 4) cholecystitis; 5) hepatic infarction; 6) liver necrosis; 7) liver trauma; 8) length of ICU stay< 24 hours; 9) Patients without simultaneous AST and PLT data in the first 24 hours after ICU admission.
There were 87 234 patients in our database. Ultimately, 326 patients with APRI data and simultaneous AST and PLT data were enrolled.
Data collection and extraction: The database(MIMIC IV), which contains patient demographics, characteristics, and hospital data, was used. The biochemical markers were also assessed, both in the database and by additional laboratory testing. The extracted indicators include age, weight, gender, comorbidities, infection site, disease severity scores, vital signs, treatment received, blood parameters and clinical endpoints.
The MIMIC IV database for sepsis patients was downloaded from physionet (http://www.physionet.org) at 19:06 on Jan. 7, 2019. It contains detailed, longitudinal EMR data for sepsis patients in three adult ICUs from 2008 through 2012 in the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston.
Data analysis: APRI and incidence of SALD will be evaluated using logistic regression analyses. We will use 0.5 of APRI as a cut-off to discriminate the association between APRI and SALD. The APRI and clinical indices were dichotomized into a high APRI group (APRI > 0.5) and low APRI group (APRI ≤ 0.5). The SALD group is used for comparison, and the non-SALD group is used as the control group. Risk differences will be calculated, along with 95% confidence intervals for differences.
Logistic regression will be performed to evaluate the association between incidence of SALD with APRI, after adjusting for age, gender, comorbidity, infection site, disease severity scores, APACHE II, and initial serum hemoglobin levels. Odds ratios, along with 95% confidence intervals for differences, will be calculated.
Expected results: APRI is a simple, inexpensive, and widely available marker of liver disease. It is calculated by (AST(IU/L)/ upper limits of normal)/PLT(k/uL)×100. We hypothesized that APRI will be elevated in patients with SALD, regardless of etiology. In the current study, patients with higher APRI values will be more likely to develop SALD as compared to those with lower APRI values. Additionally, APRI > 0.5, which we set in our study, will be predictive of SALD. Finally, patients with elevated APRI levels will experience higher mortality rates compared to those with low APRI levels.

This trial focuses on assessing the immunogenicity of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine in subjects with different immunization programs to provide data on the clinical development of Omicron BA.4/5-Delta recombinant humanized SARS-CoV-2 protein vaccine at the same time as the Omicron variant circulates in the United States and Europe. This trial consists of two parts: a 0-1-month study group and a 0-6-month study group. Participants aged 18 and above who agree to the terms and conditions of the study will first receive two doses of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine, and the researchers will observe and record adverse reactions and the production of COVID-19 protective antibodies. If they decide to continue participating in the study, a blood sample will be taken 3 months after the final vaccination. If the number of participants reaching this stage meets the requirements, the blood will be collected and tested at 6 months after the final vaccination.

The trauma of birth can increase the risk of physical, psychological and social complications for mother and baby. In order to minimize the trauma of birth, skin-to-skin contact, which means putting the newborn naked to the mother's chest for the first hours after birth, is one of the practices recommended by the World Health Organization since 1991. Although it was stated that skin to skin contact between baby and mother affects the mother's bonding to the child and the mother's attachment, there are conflicting studies on the subject. In this study, we aimed to examine the impact of early skin-to-skin contact on the perception of traumatic birth of mothers.
In addition, skin-to-skin contact and face-to-face breastfeeding practices, which are thought to affect the bond between mother and baby positively, are expected to increase. In this study, the hypothesis that early skin-to-skin contact has a positive effect on the bond between mother and baby and the perception of birth trauma will be investigated.

The incidence of chronic low back pain following lumbar discectomy is approximately 35%, and the use of intraoperative analgesia is one of the most important treatment strategies for this problem. The sacral erector spinae plane block is an ultrasound-guided block technique that allows the administration of local anesthetic to the sacral nerve roots adjacent to the spine. The aim of the present study was to evaluate the effect of sacral erector spinae plane block on opioid consumption and post-operative pain in patients undergoing lumbar disc hernia surgery. The patients were divided into two groups randomly. Fifty-four patients underwent lumbar disc hernia surgery under general anesthesia. Following completion of the surgery, patients in the first group received sacral ESPB, while patients in the control group received local anesthetic 10% solution into subcutaneous tissue. The patient satisfaction and total tramadol consumption were recorded 24 hours after surgery. The groups were comparable regarding to age, weight, and durations of surgery. It was found that the erector spinae plane block reduced intraoperative and post-operative pain and significantly reduced opioid consumption.

Development and validation of a multimodal imaging measure of lumbar myofascial pain (MP) as a useful clinical tool and a sensitive predictor of the myofascial pain response to treatment. Our goal is to develop a practical and inexpensive portable device consisting of a single multimodal ultrasound scan that determines the degree of myofascial pain as a composite of trigger point (TP) echogenicity, thoracolumbar fascia (TLF) and multifidus muscle (MF) stresses, and MF dynamic strain tensor and tissue viscoelasticity. During this project, the researchers will gather baseline MP data from 200 enrolled patients with cLBP and conduct a 16-week outcome period involving 15 home exercises and active management education.
Study Participant Group/Arm: 200 patients will be enrolled in the study: 40 Healthy Normal individuals, 120 individuals with chronic low back pain who meet the NIH definition of myofascial pain without TPs, 120 individuals with chronic low back pain who meet the NIH definition of myofascial pain with latent TPs, and 120 individuals with chronic low back pain who present with active trigger points.
Study Intervention/Treatment: Standardized clinical examination to classify the participant into MP-related categories (normal, MP without TPs, MP with latent TPs, and MP with active TPs).

Neuro-Linguistic Programming (NLP) techniques have been used in various contexts, including education. Some educators and practitioners believe that NLP can help children develop their communication skills, self confidence, and self awareness and improve their learning outcomes. Some NLP techniques adapted for children include: (1) Anchoring involves linking a particular emotional or sensory state with a physical stimulus, such as a touch or a visual cue. For example, a teacher might use a specific gesture or word to help a child feel more confident before a test. (2) Reframing: This technique involves helping a child see a situation or problem differently. For example, a teacher might help a child reframe a difficult math problem as a fun challenge. And (3) Meta-modeling: This technique involves helping children become more aware of their language patterns and the language patterns of others, which can improve communication skills and self awareness. The study aimed to evaluate whether NLP techniques enhanced schoolchildren's performance at school, concentration, and attention, and decrease hyperactivity in ADHD children.
The study involved 120 children divided into two groups, the experimental and the control groups. Both groups received training on how to study. The children in the intervention group additionally received training on how to use NLP techniques.

Structured clinical examination is a key part of medical students' training, and it is widely acknowledged as a means of assessing the knowledge and ability of students in terms of decision-making. However, despite the efforts made to standardise the OSCE process, it still has several flaws, such as the variability of the trainers and students, the lack of standardisation between the OSCE evaluators, the time constraints due to the large number of ECOS per exam, and the need to cover a large number of subjects in a short time.
The aim of this research project is to optimise the performance of students during the emergency department (ED) internship, and to improve the final grade for OSCEs at the end of their studies by creating an OSCE-oriented ECOS training module in the ED.

Methods: 
The first step of the study will be to carry out a pre-test survey within 4 emergency departments in Paris. This will be followed by the creation of the ECOX module, the evaluation of the quality of it and the assessment of the students' mastery of the content in terms of know-how and psychological status. The ECOX module is made up of a box filled with ECOX grids (a series of clinical scenarios and a time limit), a poster outlining the main elements of the emergency department and essential patient data, post-it notes to facilitate the application of the ECOX method and improve patient follow-up, a booklet summarizing the main criteria of each emergency unit, and a checklist indicating the main items to be included in the ECOS by service or unit.
The ECOX module will be evaluated by using the SIRS questionnaire to gather student feedback on usability and user experience. A survey of the ED trainers will also be conducted to determine whether the implementation of the ECOX box has enhanced their own work. During the ECOS, the evaluators will also check in with the students to assess their mood as part of the psychological status, based on their STAI- Y scores.

Expected results: 
By completing this course, the research project aims to obtain results that show whether the ECOX module can be considered a useful tool for training medical students in the ED. It will assess its success based on improvement in the final OSCE rate and on feedback from students and teachers.
If the ECOX method proves relevant and effective, it could be used for the training of other categories of students, such as nurse practitioners and interns.

The purpose of this research is to design a web-based health care program based on patient-reported needs and identify the effectiveness of this program on social support, patient self-care ability, activity tolerance, symptom distress, anxiety, depression, and quality of life.
We aimed to: 
1. Design a web-based care program based on participants' feedback and recommendations.
2. Conduct a parallel-group, double blind, and block randomization experimental design study in the second and third years to explore the effects of self-care ability support and care in the Internet era based on patient autonomy, patients' self-consciousness, and support in the web-based health care program.

Background : Motor Neuron Disease (MND) is a rare neurodegenerative disorder with high morbidity. It is considered a medical emergency that is progressive, severe and life threatening. The diagnosis of MND is made on a combination of clinical findings including signs and symptoms related to dysfunction of the motor system, and supported by neurophysiological investigations and imaging techniques that do not show any other abnormalities attributable to other diseases causing motor impairment. Most people with MND die from respiratory failure, and this can be a slow process that can last from a few months to years. Non-invasive ventilation (NIV) has been shown to improve exercise capacity, sleep quality, and quality of life in some cases, and has been implemented as a standard treatment for MND in adults. Intriguingly, however, the effect of ventilation and the decision to offer it in the outset has not been systematically studied in MND. Patients and their families suffer from the physical, psychological and social changes that occur both with the disease itself and as a consequence of the decision about long term ventilation. Currently, the decision about the treatment with long term ventilation is made in a non - standardized way in clinical practice, with the focus on preventing respiratory failure. When patients and their families experience respiratory failure or discomfort, it can become a medical emergency that requires acute medical support and, possibly, intubation and mechanical ventilation that has both short and long term consequences for the patients and their partners and children. In most cases, however, the decision for ventilation is made because of a deteriorating quality of life, and before this can happen, the patients and their partners should be informed about the pros and cons of this treatment.
Objective : To examine objectively the effects of long-term ventilation support and the support of health care professionals on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families and to explore reasons for their decision making with regards to the treatment.
Methods : Long-term ventilation support will be defined as ventilation that is not intended to be used temporarily (e.g. during acute respiratory insufficiency), but planned to be used continuously and for an extended period of time. Patients with or without such treatments will be included in an active clinical intervention cohort study. Inclusion criteria for patients: A clinical diagnosis of probable ALS according to the revised El Escorial criteria. Progression of the illness leading the consulting physician to offer NIV or NPPV in the outset of the disease. Can communicate in Norwegian. Inclusion criteria for partners of ALS patients: Partner of a patient that suffers from ALS with progression of the illness leading the consulting physician to offer NIV or NPPV in the outset of the illness. Can communicate in Norwegian. Inclusion criteria for children: Children from 8 years and older having a parent who suffers from ALS with progression of the illness leading the consulting physician to offer NIV or NPPV in the outset of the illness. Can communicate in Norwegian. Exclusion criteria for patients, partners and children of ALS patients: 1.Potential participants with cognitive impairment or dementia.
The following outcome measures will be used in the study: The primary outcome is the change in overall quality of life, measured by the Quality of Life Scale, which will be completed by the patient, his/her partner, and his/her children. Other outcome measures include quality of life measured by the Severe Respiratory Insufficiency Questionnaire, health-related quality of life measured by the Kidsscreen-27 and self-reported measures of health perceptions, psychological distress and burden of caregiving. In addition, patients' symptoms and survival will be recorded up to 2 years. Discussion: This project will contribute to the knowledge about the effect of long-term ventilation support in MND and the effect of this treatment with respect to quality of life, psychological distress and burden of caregiving. It will contribute to the knowledge base on patient care and decision-making in ALS and improve the quality of care in ALS. This in turn may improve the well-being of patients and help them to decide, based on more information, whether or not they wish to start with long-term mechanical ventilation, and how these decisions will affect them and their family. If ventilation has a positive effect of the quality of life, but not the symptom burden, it is possible that ventilation support can be a useful treatment for both patients and their families. If mechanical ventilation has a negative impact on the quality of life, it is reasonable to consider other methods of treatment, or to discontinue treatment if symptom burden increases.
This project will contribute to the quality of care

Chronic subdural hematomas (cSDH), due to head trauma, have an estimated annual incidence of 1 per 1000 population. Though most cases will resolve following surgical evacuation of the hematoma, post-operative degradation in clinical status is common and it is often a challenging clinical dilemma in regard to optimal management.
Studying EEG signatures may help predict post-operative neurologic function. In general, post-traumatic spreading depolarization (SD) events are associated with post-operative worsening in patients with a cSDH. The primary goal of this study is to use EEG measures to differentiate between SD and non-SD associated cSDH.
Specifically, we will compare three EEG measures of SD associated cSDH: 1) frequency of SD, 2) duration of SD, and 3) volume of brain tissue involved with SD. These measurements will be compared to neurological outcomes (disability, cognitive function, and health related quality of life). The secondary outcome of this study is to assess the association of EEG SD events, when present, with clinical outcomes in patients undergoing surgical evacuation of cSDH.
By correlating EEG-related characteristics of SD in cSDH with outcomes as assessed by functional and cognitive measures post operatively and longer term outcomes, this study will provide insights into post-operative neurologic status and may impact clinical decision making and rehabilitation planning. Since EEG will be employed, our study will not impact the current standard of care. The proposed study aims to provide fundamental knowledge on the mechanisms of neurologic deterioration in patients with cSDH. The proposed study has several advantages: 
1. This study aims to provide important information to aid in clinical decision-making. SD events may be associated with deleterious neurological outcomes in patients with cSDH, and elucidating this may influence the decision to either observe or proceed with surgical drainage. Thus, this study will contribute to patient care and outcomes.
2. Because EEG monitoring is an easy and relatively inexpensive method, this study will provide a valuable tool for future studies investigating this same question.
3. This research is focused on patients with acute, as well as chronic, subdural hematomas. This is important as most studies have used only patients with chronic cSDH.
4. This study is relevant to most neurosurgical practices in the United States, where cSDH is a common occurrence in patients seen in the emergency room.
5. This study will be the first to directly relate clinical outcomes and patient-centered measures in patients undergoing surgical evacuation of cSDH.
6. Results of this study will be immediately implementable.

Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a chronic pathology characterized by relapses of neurological symptoms and a progressive worsening of neurological impairment leading to physical and cognitive disability. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is a valuable tool to monitor the disease and to assess the therapeutic efficacy of MS treatments. In our routine practice at the Toulouse Neurology Hospital, we prescribe regular follow-up MRI in patients with MS.
Ocrelizumab, an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody, was designed as an interferon-β re-evaluation treatment in MS and more especially in Relapsing Remitting MS. Clinical trials have proven its efficacy in treating MS and its role in slowing down the cognitive decline and the physical disability.
This anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody has been distributed for more than 5 years in France for the treatment of MS. The ocrelizumab injection is a continuous treatment with initial 3 treatments per year, followed by one injection per year for two more years in patients with active MS.
Since its introduction in 2017, we have noted that the initial treatment was effective, but in some cases, clinical deterioration was observed after a year of follow up. These progressive diseases, which occur despite treatment with ocrelizumab, pose new concerns for the patient and the neurologist.
Consequent to this observation, the manufacturer has been contacted to allow an earlier intervention, with the option to inject again every 6 months. 
For the patient and the neurologist, the use of less than 3 annual administrations would be preferable to a monthly injection on one hand and to a weekly injection during 4 years on the other hand. For the patient, the treatment of MS has a significant impact not only on their physical and cognitive impairment but also on their family and social life. This impact can have several consequences such as an inability to work and travel and a substantial psychological impact. The medical treatment of MS must therefore be as effective as possible as well as well tolerated and accessible to all patients.
The aims of this study include:
To compare the evolution of two different frequency regimens of ocrelizumab for maintaining the absence of clinical relapses
To compare the treatment efficacy, the appearance and persistence of new T2 active lesions and new gadolinium-enhanced lesions on MRI after 2 years of treatment
To study the long-term impact of a semestrial treatment on clinical and biological activity in MS.
The primary purpose of this study is to determine the non-inferiority of the semestrial administration of ocrelizumab to the annual administration to maintain the absence of clinical relapses and avoid the formation of new MRI lesions on cerebrospinal MRI. Non-inferiority is defined as the absence of new active MRI lesions in 30 % of patients treated with the semestrical administration.
All patients included in this cohort are followed in the MS department of the CHU de Toulouse. They can benefit from MRI with a dedicated 3T device in the MRI center of the CHU de Toulouse.
The primary outcome will be the comparison of the absence of radiological disease activity at 2 years.
The second outcome will be the comparison of the absence of clinical relapses at 2 years.

Colorectal cancer has the second leading position among the major cancer types and remains the third most common of cancer diagnosis in our country, with the highest occurrence in men. The main treatment for the radical resection of tumors in the colon is a segmental resection where the section of the section of colon is removed together with tumor. This resection is performed according to the rules of the oncologists - oncologic principles (CRC principles).
The primary objective of radical resection is to obtain a tumor-free margin, which should be more than 1 mm, in terms of clinical oncology terminology is called "R0", i.e., resection for cure or complete remission.
For small non-invasive colonic adenocarcinomas, there are discussions for the use of minimal invasive procedures, which can be performed without removing full sections of the colon. This type of procedure is called Organ Sparing, Organ Preserving or non-standard procedures, e.g. endoscopic submucous dissection (ESD). In our study, we describe a minimal invasive procedure called the Combined Endoscopic Laparoscopic Surgery (CELS) which provides endoscopic and laparoscopic methods for performing a minimally invasive procedure for small colonic adenocarcinomas. In this study we will evaluate if it can be used in patients who are frail and over 75 years old.
The investigators hypothesize that CELS can be performed with regard to oncological principles and lead to increased patient-reported recovery. The investigators also need to determine whether the new technique has a higher risk of cancer recurrence compared with the traditional colonic resection with an intact mesenter.
PATIENTS AND METHODS: 
74 patients will be included in a two-armed prospective randomized controlled trial at the Dept. of surgery, Rigshospitalet, Copenhagen. Patients above 75 years of age or otherwise judged frail and fit to undergo elective colon resection for small (T1N0) colonic adenocarcinoma located in the proximal colon. Patients will be screened and examined pre-operatively by an oncologic MTD. Eligible patients will be randomized to either the CELS or the standard colonic resection group. In both the CELS and the standard colonic resection procedures, all procedures will be performed under general anesthesia and according to current oncological principles. The CELS group will undergo the hybrid endoscopic laparoscopic procedure, whereas the standard surgery group will have the colonic section removed using oncological principles. Assessment of postoperative morbidity and mortality, change in patients' functional capacity and quality of life, and assessment of histopathological risk factors and long-term oncological outcomes will be performed.
The investigators believe that the study design follows the criteria of good clinical practice. All patients will receive comprehensive information and provide informed consent. The trial has been approved by the Regional Ethical Committee and the Danish Data Protection Agency and is supported by grants from The Danish Cancer Society and the Copenhagen University Hospital Research and Innovation Team. It is registered in the Danish Clinical Trial Registry.

Rationale

Background:
Neuromuscular diseases (NMDs) are a heterogeneous group of over 70 disorders resulting from a defect in a specific type of muscle protein, such as neurofilaments, dystrophin, laminin, potassium channels, collagen proteins, troponin or creatine kinase. People with neuromuscular diseases may have difficulty in breathing. Spinocerebellar ataxias, the most common inherited ataxias, are another cause of neurogenic lung weakness. People with neurogenic lung weakness are more likely to have infections, lung damage leading to scarring or bronchial dilatation, and eventually require ventilatory support or are at risk of dying from respiratory-related cause. The treatment of lung damage is based on removal of secretions through airway clearance techniques and drugs to reduce infection and inflammation in the airway. The airway clearance techniques employed consist of simple cough techniques and chest physiotherapy, like percussion, forced expiration, and postural drainage. Aerosol delivery, that is, the delivery of drug into the airway during breathing, is often used. Aerosol delivery can be in the form of inhalation or nebulisation. Nebulisation involves turning a liquid medication into a fine mist that can be breathed in with regular breathing. Nebulised saline can help to clear secretions in the lungs and reduce the risk of infections by acting like a natural expectorant to thin secretions. People with neuromuscular diseases are at risk of breathing in too much salt into their lungs. This is called hypertonic saline poisoning, and requires admission to hospital for treatment with intravenous fluids and close monitoring. It is not known whether more frequent nebulisation of saline may lead to more salt in the lungs of people with neuromuscular diseases. This is likely to depend upon how much is breathed in, and the balance between the beneficial effects of nebulised saline and the risks of breathing in too much salt.

Objectives:
The objective of this study is to determine the amount of salt in the airway of people with NMD or neurodisability, following nebulisation of saline using different concentrations.

Gliomas are the most common tumors of the central nervous system, accounting for 20% of all brain tumors. Despite the many advancements, therapy remains challenging in many patients, particularly those with malignant, "high-grade" gliomas. Because of their invasive nature, these tumors are not able to be completely removed by surgery. For this and other reasons, radiation and chemotherapy are often given after tumor removal in an effort to eradicate any remaining tumor cells. Tumors are metabolically active, and use more energy from the food consumed, compared to normal brain. This increased activity can be visualized by a standard metabolic imaging approach, ¹⁸FDG Positron Emission Tomography (PET). However, there are only a few PET scanners, and many patients do not have access to them. This means that patients often have to wait months or years after their tumor removal for their first PET scan. This is usually not enough time for clinicians to make decisions on the effectiveness of radiation and chemotherapy. This problem is particularly important in young or elderly patients who may have difficulty undergoing MRI scans or in those with medical conditions that are worsened by lying in the MRI scanner. They may need surgery, radiation or chemotherapy to be started as quickly as possible, leading to potential overtreatment in some cases and delay in therapy in others. The investigators believe that a new metabolic imaging approach using an MRI based approach, "aMRI" may offer advantages to both patients and physicians. The investigators have developed a powerful new metabolic measurement technique (named kᵢₒ*V) that can be used during MRI scans, in the same device used for structural MRI scans. This has been successfully used in animals to differentiate benign and malignant brain tumors in normal brains, but has never been evaluated in human subjects. The investigators first need to confirm that this method is robust and reproducible in human subjects, and compare it with the current standard of care, PET.
Based on its promising results in the above mentioned studies, the investigators have developed an MRI based approach to measure brain activity at 3 tesla in various disease states and in normal subjects. This includes:
- Patients with gliomas
- Metabolic profile before brain surgery
- Metabolic profile after brain surgery
- Metabolic profile in different conditions of the brain in which glucose metabolism is altered (normal subjects, diabetic patients, acute stroke patients) and
- Metabolic profile in different brain diseases (seizures, neurocutaneous syndromes, autism, etc.) and normal subjects.
For gliomas, the investigators will measure brain activity using the new aMRI approach in comparison to the current gold standard of PET. In patients with glioma, a tumor or "lesion" is an abnormal mass or area, detected on standard brain images, that is likely to be due to tumor. Surrounding healthy brain tissues normally show increased metabolic activity (shining bright in ¹⁸FDG PET) in response to the tumor, and this is thought to be due to the tumor cells "feeding". However, while the tumor is metabolically active, many of the normal-appearing, surrounding tissues which are thought to have the potential to eventually form tumor are still able to maintain good blood flow and provide nutrition. In addition, some normal-appearing tissues may not provide enough nutrition to maintain normal function and can therefore undergo some degree of damage, which can lead to problems with memory and thinking. The investigators will test their hypothesis that the MRI based approach, aMRI, can differentiate between the normal appearing tissues in the brain that are good and those that are bad, and thereby, identify new treatment targets in brain cancers. The investigators will also test whether the activity difference between the tumor and normal-appearing tissues is different in different forms of the disease, including benign and malignant types, and the type that is more or less likely to be sensitive to the standard chemotherapeutic drugs that are used currently in patients with brain cancer.
The investigators believe that this research project will make important contributions to improving the evaluation of brain cancer and development of new treatment strategies by directly comparing the MRI based approach to the current standard PET scans.

Heart failure (HF) is a major global health problem affecting approximately 64.3 million patients worldwide. HF and its chronic symptoms and progressive symptoms are associated with an estimated annual healthcare expenditure of $30.7 billion in the United States alone. Despite advances in pharmacological and device therapy, heart failure continues to have a poor prognosis with 50% risk of hospitalization or death within the first 6 mo after diagnosis, and average 5-year mortality remains at 50%. Guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) that maximizes evidence-based pharmacotherapy, including use of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin II receptor blockers (ACEI/ARB), beta-blockers (BB), aldosterone antagonists (AA), and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRA), reduces morbidity and mortality in HF patients. Patients with HF with reduced EF (HFrEF) have the most consistent and prominent benefit when GDMT is optimized. A key issue surrounding GDMT underutilization is the recognition that in primary care practice, the number of guideline-specified pharmacotherapy doses that require an up-titration, addition of a new class of treatment, or discontinuation of contraindicated medications can be substantial due to patient heterogeneity. Further, although current heart failure therapies (eg, ACEI, BB) help patients with HFrEF, there are recent developments in novel therapies including SGLT2i and ARNI. ARNI provides benefit over ACEi/ARB in terms of reducing the combined endpoint of death from any cause and hospitalization for heart failure. However, there is limited evidence on the use of novel GDMT therapies in real world settings especially in HFrEF population, when compared to ACEi/ARB. It is increasingly clear that multi-prong approaches (combination of strategies) are needed to further optimize GDMT among patients with HFrEF in primary care settings.
The purpose of this intervention study is to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving GDMT in patients with chronic HFrEF seen in primary care practices. We hypothesize that the addition of (1) multiprong clinical decision support (CDS); (2) focused education; and (3) physician and pharmacist referral options, (4) enhanced by electronic patient note reminders and patient portal messages to enhance clinician and patient awareness of key HF guidelines, and (5) targeted at different primary care practitioners' (PCPs) behaviors and preferences will lead to GDMT intensification in patients with chronic HFrEF receiving primary care. The investigators are also interested in identifying specific combinations of interventions that result in the best improvement in guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) in these settings.
This study is a single-blinded randomized parallel group study with a non-randomized factor (education versus delayed education) and will be conducted on 6 outpatient cardiology clinics within the Geisinger Clinic system. Approximately 4000 (1600 per practice clinic) patients with chronic HFrEF ≥ 18 years of age will be allocated via a stratified block randomized design into no intervention (control), multiprong CDS, multiprong CDS with pharmacist referral, and focused education at the clinic level. Patients in these four study arms will not interact with each other and will follow their individual study arms' randomization over a 12-month period.
To achieve balanced allocation of practices by cardiologist preference for pharmacist referral (P = 0.40) and cardiologist preference for electronic patient note reminders/patient portal messages (P = 0.70), the investigators will stratify by specialty (cardiologist or non-cardiologist) and by cardiologist referral habits over the previous 12-month period to estimate a 45%/45%/10% proportional distribution of clinics within these categories to the following arms (intervention/control, respectively): (1) no intervention, (2) multiprong CDS, (3) multiprong CDS+referral, (4) education.
Clinics will be randomized to one of the four study arms, after which each 24-month period within a clinic will be randomized to either early or delayed education rollout.
Clinical decision support-intervention
The intervention will involve adding multiple forms of BPAs in the electronic medical record (EMR). One will be an interruptive BPA that includes a GDMT order set

The prevalence of urologic stones is about 10-12% in the general population which causes ureterocolic junction obstruction in about 1/3 in the course of time. When endourologic procedures fail to fragment this stone completely or it fragments the other segment of ureter obstructing the other side or is completely dislodged into one collecting system which then obstructs the whole urethra. In patients who have developed ureteric stone for the first time the possibility of spontaneous passage of these stones is about 40-50%. In cases where the stone is less than 6 mm chances of spontaneous passage is about 80% but in larger stones chance of spontaneous passage is about 30-40% of patients.
Stone clearance by extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) has improved significantly in the last two decades, with success rate and stone‐ free rates reaching 95% with new generation lithotriptors. However in patients with upper ureteric stone size ranging from 6-15 mm, despite the success rate, there is still 25-50% residual stone volume in the ureter after ESWL only. It is believed that alpha blockers play an important role in the treatment of ureteric stones, by augmentation of ureteric blood flow, relaxation of the peri ureteric fibrous tissue and hence facilitate stone fragment dislodgment and spontaneous passage.
Hence the investigators hypothesize that in patients with upper ureteric stones of size ranging from 6-15 mm the addition of tamsulosin therapy to the ESWL treatment protocol would lead to higher stone clearance by ESWL after one week of procedure as compared to ESWL alone.

Tracheal stenosis following a percutaneous tracheotomy is quite common and the surgical treatment of tracheal stenosis is usually successful. However, it is often associated with significant postoperative morbidity. The aim of this study is to evaluate the new non-invasive interventional treatment strategy with the cryoprobe and the Argon Plasma Coagulation (APC). 17 patients (17 women, mean age 60.7 ± 16.7 years) with a tracheal stenosis after percutaneous tracheotomy underwent a transarterial cryoprobe ablation plus APC. During or after the intervention, a self-retracting tracheal dilator (self-retainer) was inserted in the trachea. The stenotic site was examined endoscopically (directly after the intervention by a laryngologist and one month later during fiber optic bronchoscopy by a thoracic surgeon). The laryngeal-tracheal area was then imaged using computed tomography (CT). In all cases, the self-retainer was kept in place for about 6 months, up to tracheal and tube removal. All patients underwent decannulation after intervention, with a maximum follow-up period of 12 months. In all of the 17 patients enrolled in the study, the self-retainer was positioned correctly and retained its position, enabling complete decannulation with no complications after the intervention. One patient died from cardiac arrest at 3 months (no direct involvement of the technique). There was no significant deterioration in glottis morphology during the follow-up period. All patients were successfully decannulated. In conclusion, transarterial cryosurgery combined with APC plus the insertion of the self-retainer in the trachea appears to be an effective and safe treatment for tracheal stenoses resulting from a previous tracheotomy.

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) frequently involves comorbid psychoneurotic symptoms such as anxiety, depression, borderline personality characteristics, obsessive-compulsive symptoms, and other issues that affect a large proportion of the autistic population. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of psychiatric medication for psychoneurotic symptoms in patients with ASD, after establishing a therapeutic environment through psychoanalysis and other behavioral interventions. The study is divided into two groups, where one includes participants undergoing psychoanalysis and the other is a control group for comparison. Participants in the psychoanalysis group receive a 6-month-long weekly treatment of sertraline, duloxetine, and cognitive/behavioral therapies. The control group receives only medication treatments. Based on the results of our study, we anticipate improvement in the quality of life for those individuals with ASD who experience comorbid psychoneurotic symptoms after completion of medication and psychodynamic psychoanalytic treatments.
