Contraception counseling is a critical component of family planning services with an emphasis on both clients’ experiences and providers’ quality of care. Evidence of poor contraceptive counseling is widespread, with multiple methods for measurement and many different aspects to consider. Conventional clinical measures for assessing quality of family planning counseling and its determinants could be used to support reproductive health. In 2017, Holt, Dehlendorf, and Langer created a framework for contraceptive counseling quality grounded in quality of care and human rights principles and research in healthcare communication. Based on this framework, Holt et al. developed and validated the Quality of Contraceptive Counseling (QCC) Scale, which covers three interrelated aspects of counseling quality: information exchange, interpersonal relationship, and disrespect and abuse . The scale comprehensively measures aspects of the counseling process related not only to information receipt but also individuals' experiences having the opportunity to participate in the method selection process and the degree to which they had positive and trusting experiences with the provider . Associations between quality of contraceptive counseling and characteristics of clients, such as age, education, and reproductive status, could represent significant health disparities and indicate the need for research. This study will seek to understand quality of family planning counseling utilizing the validated and client-centered based QCC Scale as experienced by reproductive aged women in El-Dakhla District, New Valley. Furthermore, it will investigate their associated factors either client, provider, or visit factors. Data will be collected through a semi-structured interview administered questionnaire which includes: Socio-demographic characteristics of women Family planning practice: This will include number of living children, current use of FP method and its type, and suggested causes of discontinuation of FP, previous contraceptive use, and reason for the visit 3-Facility factors such as gender of providers, qualification of providers, type of the health facility (mobile clinics???) 4-Quality of contraceptive counseling (QCC) scale: it is a 22-item scale which measures the quality of care received by women during family planning visits. It includes : 1) information exchange, 2) interpersonal relations, and 3) disrespect and abuse in contraceptive counseling. The information exchange subscale consists of ten items, the interpersonal relationship subscale consists of seven items, and the disrespect and abuse subscale consists of five items. Item responses were given on four-point Likert scales. Response categories for positively worded items were completely agree (4), agree (3), disagree (2), and completely disagree (1). Response categories for negatively worded items were yes (1), yes with doubts (2), no with doubts (3), and no (4). Composite subscale and total scores were calculated as mean scores . Items of QCC scale: Information exchange factor During the contraception consultation, I was able to give my opinion about what I needed. I received complete information about my options for contraceptive methods. The provider knew how to explain contraception clearly. I had the opportunity to participate in the selection of a method. I received information about how to protect myself from sexually transmitted infections. I received information about what to do if a method fails (e.g., broken condom, forget a pill, feel an IUD is poorly placed). I could understand how my body might react to using contraception. I could understand how to use the method(s) we talked about during the consultation. I received information about what to do if I wanted to stop using a method. The provider explained to me what to do if I had a reaction to a method (e.g., allergies, nausea, pains, menstrual changes). Interpersonal relationship factor I felt the information I shared with the provider was going to stay between us. The provider gave me the time I needed to consider the contraceptive options we discussed. The provider was friendly during the contraception consultation. I felt the health care provider had sufficient knowledge about contraceptive methods. The provider showed interest in my health while we talked about contraception. The provider was interested in my opinions. I felt listened to by the provider Response Options: Completely agree - 4 Agree - 3 Disagree - 2 Completely disagree - 1 Disrespect and abuse factor The provider pressured me to use the method they wanted me to use. I felt the provider treated me poorly because they tend to judge people. I felt scolded because of my age. The provider looked at me or touched me in a way that made me feel uncomfortable. Response Options: Yes - 1 Yes with doubts

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease associated with significant morbidity and mortality, affecting young to middle-aged individuals with a devastating impact on their quality of life. Standard medical management aims at symptom control and the identification of potential triggers for fluctuations. In spite of various disease progression models, the identification of suitable therapeutic targets in order to personalize therapies is hampered by the variable course of the disease and incomplete understanding of the biological pathways associated with MSA. As a consequence, the optimal management of individuals with MSA is still defined by a multidisciplinary approach, but its implementation can be demanding, particularly in geographically dispersed populations. The impact of the disease, including autonomic, motor, and cognitive dysfunction can affect the quality of life of the patients, as well as the caregivers of the patients. The burden of caregiving is associated with physical and psychological morbidity.
The aim of this study is to evaluate the feasibility of a multidisciplinary, personalized treatment plan, based on a predefined standardized operational protocol and adapted to individual needs, in order to improve quality of life and reduce caregiver burden in individuals with MSA. With the advancement of technological solutions, this study will integrate telemedicine components with mobile palliative solutions, to improve access and continuity of care in an aging population. We plan to recruit 46 individuals with MSA fulfilling all the inclusion and none of the exclusion criteria for this trial. The study will follow a randomized, parallel design. At baseline, 6, 12 and 18 months after the baseline visit, the individuals with MSA will undergo a comprehensive clinical, psychological and neuro-rehabilitation assessment. The individualized treatment plan, including telemedicine and mobile palliative care offer, and therapy adaptations will be made based on the individualized assessment of therapeutic needs and healthcare preferences, and monitored throughout the 18 months study period. Twenty-three patients will be randomized to receive additional monthly and on-demand neurological, psychological, physio-, occupational and speech therapy telemedicine visits (based on individual needs). The therapeutic interventions will be documented, and the monthly follow-up visits will allow for the monitoring of caregiver burden and the identification of barriers to compliance. The study will be evaluated in terms of effect on the baseline to 18 months-change in the EQ-5D-5L score, the MSA-QoL score and subscores, UMSARS (video-based, rater-blinded assessment of the UMSARS motor score and Hoehn & Yahr changes over the study period), and the individual healthcare preferences of individuals with MSA and their informal caregivers. Based on our previous work on telemedicine in MSA, we expect to improve the coordination of care, adherence to the therapeutic plan and the overall quality of life within the 18 months of this study, to be eventually integrated as a standard component into the management of the disease. Successful management of the disease associated with improvements in quality of live and support in the informal caregivers will have a direct impact on the daily practice of healthcare professionals involved in the care of people with MSA. The proposed clinical trial will contribute to a comprehensive approach for the development of a new, patient-centered, evidence-based model of management in individuals with MSA.

The primary objective of the study is to identify molecular mechanisms and genetic profiles that contribute to growth response to growth hormone (GH) therapy in children with idiopathic short stature (ISS). ISS is a common condition, affecting approximately 2-3% of the paediatric population. Clinicians face the challenge of having to assess the likelihood of response to GH therapy among children with ISS before starting the treatment. The main consequence of a non-responder (poor responder) outcome is the withdrawal of an ineffective therapy, associated with significant costs, both personal and system-based.
The hypothesis to be tested in this study is that ISS has a partly, but nevertheless, genetic basis. However, this genetic basis might be heterogeneous and thus may vary among children with the same condition/phenotype. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the molecular profile (measured through genetic variants) will provide additional information for clinicians to predict treatment response after initiation of GH therapy.
We will compare the genetic profiles between good responders and poor responders to identify the differences in the frequency and count of genetic variants per gene/pathway that contribute to the different response to GH. The study expects to enrol 600 children with ISS, 300 good responders and 300 poor responder. Each participant will provide one non-invasive biological sample. The main outcome measure is the frequency and count of genetic variants per gene/pathway, which will be determined by a panel of genetic panels and the ISSomics® test (R&O Genetics GmbH).
To facilitate the dissemination of the study results, the participants will be asked to allow the use of data and bio-samples for future research purposes in anonymized and de-identified format.

Patients status post aneurysm coiling are prone to sleep disturbances, and sedative drugs given to improve sleep quality may cause complications such as respiratory depression, delirium, and prolonged ventilator dependence. The presence of the neurocheck (standard of care neurological examination) is an important cause of sleep disturbances by waking patients frequently during the night. This study will determine if adjusting the timing of the neurocheck has a significant impact on sleep quality as well as the incidence of acute neurological sequelae post aneurysm coiling. Informed consent will be obtained after recruitment on the inpatient medicine or neurology service. This study will enroll 29 patients. Based on past data, an expected median of 18 hours will be required for participants in the study.
The hypothesis is that decreasing the frequency of routine neurochecks from every hour to every other hour will result in an improvement in sleep quality and no significant change in the incidence of neurological sequelae.

Oropharyngeal and laryngeal carcinomas account for 90% of newly diagnosed head and neck cancer (HNC) in Denmark. In the United Kingdom in 2018, 3800 new HNC patients were diagnosed and 1940 died. In the US in 2018, 64,670 new cases were diagnosed and 13,780 died. A main risk factor for HNC is tobacco smoking, along with alcohol consumption and diet. Recently, the human papilloma virus (HPV) has emerged as a significant risk factor for oropharyngeal squamous cell cancer (OPSCC). OPSCC is highly curable if treated, while laryngeal, hypopharyngeal, and oral cavity HNC are generally of a more advanced and poorer prognosis.
To improve patient outcome, accurate and reliable staging of HNC is crucial. Tumor extent at presentation is important for treatment decision-making, prediction of clinical outcome, and can also affect quality of life. Several risk groups and staging systems have been developed and are widely accepted. For HNC, staging of the neck is primarily based on clinical and endoscopic examinations of the patient.
Despite the availability of clinical and endoscopic staging, the diagnosis of HNC is frequently dependent on imaging, specifically CT and/or MRI scans of the head and neck. The radiologists use the scans to evaluate the primary tumor location, lymph node involvement, and presence of extranodal tumor extension (ENE). The radiologists assess the ENE on the CTs by looking for "loss of circumscribed demarcation" between the primary tumor and the lymph node. This is based on the assumption that the normal lymphatics are demarcated and therefore normal lymphatics should not cross. Thus, the presence of ENE relates to the loss of circumscribed demarcation of the lymphatic architecture.
This is the first multicenter study evaluating the diagnostic accuracy of radiologists' assessments of ENE compared with the gold standard obtained via histopathology (the presence of ENE on the neck specimen, pathologic ENE [pENe])), as well as analyzing the prognostic significance of ENE. This study will serve as the basis for the development of a standardized reporting system for ENE.
For the purpose of this project, the investigators will define ENE as a tumor extension which appears to extrude the capsule of a lymph node or anatomical barrier. Radiologically, this is identified as "loss of circumscribed demarcation" between the tumor and the lymph node. The presence of this radiological finding will be defined as radiologic extranodal extension (rENE).
This is a retrospective, multi-institutional, international study based on data from consecutive patients treated for head and neck cancer. All patients eligible for inclusion must have sufficient imaging and clinical data available; this includes neck scans with or without contrast and either histopathology or clinical follow-up. The investigators will identify data from consecutive patients treated for oral cavity, oropharyngeal, carcinoma of unknown primary, laryngeal, or hypopharyngeal cancer and be over the age of 18. All patients who meet the inclusion criteria must be treated with curative intent via surgery, radiotherapy, or chemoradiotherapy or a combination within the study inclusion period (1/1/1999-12/31/2020). Radiologic and clinical data available within a 3-month timeframe before the start of treatment must be available.
The investigators will only include HNC for this study if data of the imaging and the histopathology (primary or metastatic lesions) are available and if they could be traced back to a report of pENE. All patients should have at least two years of follow-up, or death. It is not necessary that all patients included in the study have ENE on the neck specimen (pENE) as only patients with sufficient imaging and clinical data can be included in the study. The study will include patients with pENE and patients without pENE in one single cohort. Patients treated palliatively at first presentation and patients presenting with recurrent disease will not be included.
Follow-up data will be requested from the participating centers and include data on recurrence, localization of recurrence, overall survival, and disease-specific survival.
This is a multicenter international study

Bone biopsy (BB) is the gold standard for diagnosing osteomyelitis in diabetic foot osteomyelitis (DFO)1. However, its use remains underused for various reasons. These include availability in some centers, high costs, and delays for conventional bone biopsies (conventional BB: surgical or radiological) which could lead to the loss of limb. In a few years, we have set up a simple blind biopsy procedure (Bedside BB) that involves a physician performing a biopsy through healthy skin at the bedside of the patient with DFU suspected of DFO. This procedure is effective, safe and has already been developed in more than 200 patients with DFO in the university departments of diabetology of Lariboisiere Hospital and Bichat Hospital (Paris). Since its inception, more than 60 publications have studied the effectiveness of this new procedure in DFO: its safety, its equivalence to conventional biopsies, its sensitivity and its specificity in microbiological results. In order to extend the results of these preliminary and observational studies and to make Bedside BB a standard, the investigators have recently evaluated the feasibility of an randomised controlled trial comparing the safety and effectiveness of Bedside BB versus conventional biopsies. To evaluate the effectiveness, they have designed a multicentre open-label controlled non-inferiority trial. Its primary purpose is to demonstrate the equivalence in treatment outcomes between Bedside BB and surgical conventional bone biopsy in patients with DFO. The investigators will recruit 200 patients with diabetes and DFO. The main endpoint (primary endpoint) is the remission of DFO without the need for surgery. The investigators aim to demonstrate non-inferiority of Bedside BB vs surgical conventional bone biopsy. The other secondary endpoints include clinical efficacy, microbiological results including sensitivity to antibiotics, costs evaluation, and quality of life evaluation.

African Americans (AA) are less likely to receive quality end-of-life (EoL) care. For example, goals of care conversations, which are critical discussions between clinicians, patients, and families near the end of life, are less likely to occur for AAs than for Whites, and preferences are less likely to be followed when they do occur. Instead, families are more likely to be labeled as difficult if their decisions are incongruent with clinicians' recommendations. EoL decisions for many AA persons are rooted in both culture and a lifetime of experiences of structural racism. Efforts to address disparities need to address multiple factors such as patient-level cultural identity and EoL care values, interpersonal- and community-level norms for EoL communication and treatment, and healthcare institutional contexts for delivering EoL care in a setting affected by institutional racism. Our research group began to address this need with 'African American Community Speaks', a proof-of-concept prototype of a community-developed training program for clinicians caring for AA older adults with serious illnesses. The program originally focused on rural Southern older AAs and is not broadly generalizable across the US due to geographic differences in culture, attitudes, and communication preferences among AA persons in the US. Thus, we propose to adapt our prototype program to urban-dwelling Southern and Northern older AA adults using our established platform of Community-Based Participatory Research (CBPR) in two geographically diverse regions: Birmingham, Alabama, and the Bronx, New York. To create the new training program called 'Caring for Older African Americans', our team of experts in CBPR, medical sociology, and clinical trials will work with local Community Advisory Boards to: 1. Conduct a comparative ethnographic study of urban dwelling AAs in the North and South to describe AA community values and preferences related to EoL care; 2. Adaptation of our prior community-developed training program by integrating community-developed storytelling videos for empathizing with experiences of racism in EoL care, guidelines for culturally concordant EoL care delivery, and adapting an existing implicit bias management program to goals of care communication; and 3. Conduct a cluster randomized trial in which we will randomize training times to 1 of 4 start dates using a stepped wedge design to accommodate the training of all clinicians and to mitigate the effect of secular trends. Patients' personal experience of racism will be measured using the discrimination subscale of the Group Based Mistrust Scale. The primary outcome will be patient/family's perception of therapeutic alliance using The Human Connection Scale. Secondary outcomes will be family-reported goal-concordant care, and clinicians' knowledge of cultural values, awareness of implicit bias, and confidence to change practice. This innovative effort will be the first training program that: 1. addresses culturally concordant care, systemic racism, and implicit bias management, the three key elements in enhancing the provision of equitable care; and 2. is designed and implemented in full partnership with two distinct AA communities in the South and the North of the US.

Head and neck cancers are the sixth most common cancer common worldwide causing more than 380,000 deaths each year. More than 90% of these cancers are carcinomas epidermoids arising from the mucosal surfaces of the cavity oral cavity, oropharynx and larynx. Squamous cell cancers of the head and neck are classically correlated with risk factors linked to excessive consumption of alcohol and tobacco and have a rather poor prognosis (mainly HPV negative patients). However, the incidence of Head and Neck cancers in patients without alcohol-smoking risk factor has continued to increase in recent years, in relation to more and more frequent HPV contamination. Evolution of oral sexual practices seems to be one of the explanations for the progression of these cases of oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma and oral cavity HPV positive.

2. an overall survival of 1 year after surgery

The prevalence of chronic diseases in developed countries is increasing, and their economic impact on the healthcare system is high. Chronic diseases have a high prevalence in Western countries. Healthcare costs in the United States of America alone are 7.8 million dollars, and the prevalence of chronic health conditions in England costs over 71 billion pounds a year. In France, an epidemiological study found that 60% of the population has several chronic diseases, some of which require regular medical appointments. In addition, these sick patients often have jobs that require them to meet deadlines and targets or are subject to a hierarchical regime, which can lead to burnout, defined as a chronic loss of motivation and an increase in job dissatisfaction, particularly if there is a discontinuity between efforts and rewards. Healthcare professionals are also part of these sick patients, and the effects of their job and burnout are increasingly recognized, especially among physicians with professional qualification. The economic cost of work burnout is considerable for the company, which is forced to retrain employees. Workers who are frequently absent from work because of burnout often lead to low productivity and less quality care for patients. Anxiety or depression is not uncommon in healthcare professionals, with a prevalence ranging from 5% to 29%. Chronic health conditions can also have an impact on employees' emotional state. Psychological burnout can lead to depression, anxiety or substance abuse, thus influencing a workers' quality of life and productivity.
There is an urgent need to assess a sick employee's health status and psychological quality. Some tools exist today to evaluate the emotional state of a person but often rely on self-declarations which may alter the results. In addition, some questionnaires are very exhaustive and long, making it difficult for patients to answer them. An alternative would be to introduce more visual tools that avoid the tediousness of a long questionnaire, the patient answers being less subjective. Visual analog scales have proven reliable in a few studies. These scales are easy to use, they do not require a lot of education of patients and often patients do not have to answer to open questions. This scale could quickly assess and track the evolution of the patient's well-being. Visual analog scales, if they can be validated, could be used as a complement to the regular questionnaire of healthcare professionals. The investigator aims to implement a questionnaire assessing the emotional state of the employee to better understand whether the company should provide more psychological support, thus preventing burnout. The investigator does not aim to redo existing questionnaires or to create a new tool to assess psychological state. The main goal is to create a simple, visual and understandable tool to quickly assess well-being. In addition, the investigator does not aim to assess a sick employee's physical state (other questionnaires can already exist for this) but to focus on their emotional one and their relationship with their job, in order to prevent burnout and decrease the risks of an emotional disturbance that may worsen their quality of life.

Background: Alveolar ridge augmentation procedures are performed for the regeneration of the alveolar process. The aim of our study is to evaluate and compare the soft and hard tissue dimensions of alveolar ridge augmentation procedures with the use of different barrier membranes in the presence of different grafting materials.
Inclusion criteria: To be included, participants need to be older than 20 years old, without any contraindication for invasive dental procedures, indicated for dental implants if needed, having healthy oral soft and hard tissue (probing bleeding index <20%, and plaque index <20%), a minimum keratinized tissue height, and not needing a simultaneous bone augmentation surgery. All participants need to be willing and sign the consent form.
Exclusion criteria: Poor oral hygiene maintenance, uncontrolled periodontal disease, heavy smoking (smokes >20 cigarettes per day), uncontrolled diabetes, and alcohol abuse are all considered exclusion criteria.

For this split-mouth study, 80 patients with mandibular bilateral tooth extraction will be randomized in three groups:
Group 1: tooth extraction with an alveolar ridge preservation.
Group 2: two-stage alveolar ridge preservation with vascularized connective tissue graft in combination with autologous bone particle.
Group 3: one-stage alveolar ridge preservation with vascularized connective tissue graft in combination with autologous bone particle.
All participants will undergo an intraoral CT-scan at baseline, 4, and 8 weeks, and 6 and 12 months postoperative. In addition, the soft tissue dimensions will be assessed using STereoLithography files are superimposed and recorded by Cone-Beam Computed Tomography data at baseline and after 6 and 12 months.
The main hypothesis is that two-stage alveolar ridge preservation procedures with vascularized connective tissue graft in combination with autologous bone particle results in smaller alveolar bone and soft tissue dimensions in comparison to one-stage alveolar ridge preservation with vascularized connective tissue graft in combination with autologous bone particle.
The secondary hypothesis is that the soft tissue dimension of alveolar ridge preservation groups differs at different time points in comparison to the spontaneous healing group.

Official Title
-----------------

This study will compare the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in women who have had removal of Essure® contraceptive implants and in control patients who have had benign laparoscopic gynecological surgery. The pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-8, IL-1B, IFN-gamma, IL-17A) will be analyzed in the peritoneal fluid withdrawn. The levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines will be compared in the three groups of patients: Essure group (patient who underwent removal of the Essure® contraceptive implant), Control group with no endometriosis/adenomyosis (patient who underwent benign laparoscopic gynecological surgery and with no diagnosis of endometriosis or adenomyosis) and Control group with endometriosis/adenomyosis (patient who underwent benign laparoscopic gynecological surgery and with diagnosis of endometriosis or adenomyosis). For the first time, this study should bring new evidence concerning possible inflammatory processes in patients who have a removal of Essure® and it may help to understand the causes of adverse health effects observed by some women after the implantation of these devices.

INTRODUCTION AND RATIONALE: The COVID-19 pandemic has hit the world hard, and older and vulnerable persons are more likely to get very ill when infected, and have the highest morbidity and mortality. The majority of patients that are admitted to the hospital are older (>70 years), and some of them have been, or are being, admitted to Intensive Care Units. Many patients stay on the ICU/hospital for weeks. To get back to the highest state of functional independence, these patients will need specialised care and treatment, therefore geriatric rehabilitation will be very likely required.
Geriatric Rehabilitation (GR) is defined as a multidimensional approach of diagnostic and therapeutic interventions, the purpose of which is to optimise functional capacity, promote activity and preserve functional reserve and social participation in older people with disabling impairments.
OBJECTIVES: The primary objective of this study to get insight into the course of functional and medical recovery in (geriatric) rehabilitation patients affected by COVID-19 in Europe.
The secondary objective is to get insight into the treatment modalities employed and the organisation of geriatric rehabilitation that post-COVID patients in Europe receive.
STUDY DESIGN: The study follows a pragmatic and observational design, and study-related data will be collected via a web-based data collection system on routine healthcare information from rehabilitation patients, which has no effect on their treatment and care in rehabilitation.
PARTICIPANTS: This pan-European study involves cooperation between several countries across the world. Participants are patients with a diagnosis of COVID-19 infection that recovered from their infection and are admitted to geriatric rehabilitation for a rehabilitation treatment.
DATA COLLECTION PROCEDURES: The information about demographics (age), gender and diagnoses will be collected from the patients’ own charts or from medical records of their referring general practitioner or hospital records. The information collected from their own charts will only include existing data, no additional procedures need to be performed to collect these data.
The following data will be collected at admission: demographics (year of birth/age, gender, premorbid residency), and if routinely collected data is available: level of ADL functioning (using the Barthel Index (BI) scale 0-20), quality of life (EQ-5D-5L scale 0-1), frailty (mMSE/SNAQ/NRS/MUST/Clinical Frailty Scale), cognition (MMSE/Demtect/ MOCA), mood/anxiety (/GDS/HADS), muscle strength (MRC biceps/quadriceps), fatigue (VAS scale), dyspnoea (VAS scale) and pain (NRS scale). Additional information that we receive in anonymised or descriptive way is the number of hospital readmissions, the length of stay in GR, discharge destination and ADL, quality of life, frailty, BMI, nutrition, cognition, mood/anxiety, fatigue, dyspnoea, pain, mobility/balance, muscle strength, and comorbidity/diagnostics will be documented at discharge.
In case of follow-up data, data will be collected for quality of life, fatigue, dyspnoea, nutritional status, frailty, post-traumatic stress syndrome and comorbidity and diagnostics.
All patient data are anonymised.
POTENTIAL BENEFITS: Rehabilitation care is designed to improve the overall situation of the patient in the short and longer run. By optimising the rehabilitation care for COVID-19 patients the quality and speed of their recovery can be improved.
In conclusion, the results of this study will lead to better insights in the course of recovery of post-COVID-19 patients and can give more insight in the treatment modalities employed, and can lead to better and more targeted rehabilitation care for this group. In 2019, the European Union developed the Joint Programming Platfora 2 ‘Preventing Mobility Disability and Promoting Mobility in Older Adults’. The goal of the platform is to coordinate and improve intersectorial cooperation, which is of paramount importance to improve the outcome of rehabilitation. We hope this study will contribute to this effort that seeks to improve the evidence base for the benefits of rehabilitation in the European Union.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to pose a health threat worldwide, with high morbidity and mortality among kidney transplant recipients. Vaccination against SARS-CoV-2 is currently available in most countries. Immunogenicity against SARS-CoV-2, however, is suboptimal in kidney transplant recipients. This impaired immune response is related to the use of immunosuppressive agents. Studies have demonstrated that patients that use everolimus instead of mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) have a higher immune response after vaccination. Vaccine response against Varicella Zoster Vaccine (VZV) is also impaired in patients that use everolimus instead of MMF. Both the COVID-19 vaccine and the VZV require an optimal immune response to be fully effective. Therefore, we hypothesize that kidney transplant recipients who replace their MMF by everolimus, have an increased capacity to mount a specific immune response to both vaccines. The purpose of the "PREPARE-iVAC" trial is to evaluate replacement of MMF by everolimus in kidney transplant recipients on immunosuppression after vaccination. The main focus will be COVID-19 vaccination and vaccination against herpes zoster, but we will also investigate humoral and cellular immunity against varicella zoster. Moreover, we will evaluate safety of using everolimus instead of MMF in kidney transplant recipients. The hypothesis is that those who receive everolimus achieve better vaccine response, as measured by specific antibody concentrations and virus neutralising capacity, as compared to the MMF/MPA group.

Patients with chronic cervical spondylosis or neck pain are commonly prescribed with non-specific treatment approaches, such as local heat treatment and neck/shoulder strengthening exercises. Nevertheless, despite common implementation, evidence of the efficacy and effectiveness of these interventions is uncertain, given the small number of low-quality studies in the literature. Some studies have demonstrated the efficacy of neck stretching in reducing neck pain and improving neck range of motion in this population. However, there is little information on the efficacy of stretching specific upper fibers of the trapezius muscle. Consequently, this study is designed to determine if stretching the upper fibers of the trapezius muscle (specific group), in addition to neck stretching, neck strengthening and heat treatment, is more efficacious than standard physical therapy (neck muscle strengthening and heat treatment) in reducing pain intensity and improving neck range of motion, and reducing neck disability in patients with chronic cervical spondylosis.

The physiological effects of this type of physiotherapy are generated by the application of an electromagnetic field with frequency of approximately 0.5 MHz to the human body. The effects attributed to this technique include increased deep and superficial blood circulation, vasodilatation, increased temperature, removal of excess fluid and increased cell proliferation. It is also true that this increase in tissue temperature, generated through the application of the device, is a physical reaction to the passage of current (Joule effect). While there is already clinical literature supporting this mechanism, the amount of energy and current that must be transferred to obtain the desired temperature rise is unknown. It is expected that the research team will find that the performance variables improve after receiving the treatment by means of the Tecartherapy. In addition, this study, the first of its kind on its subject, may be of interest to other sports entities to apply these techniques in their therapeutic routines, as well as in new rehabilitation protocols in sports practice. At the same time, the design of the protocol does not allow for biomarker analysis in blood samples, so no sample has been included for their collection, and therefore no blood tests will be carried out.

Background: Endometriosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that can cause infertility due to the presence of chronic inflammation and oxidative stress. It is also associated with changes in the microenvironment of the ovary as well as alterations in oocyte quality. In addition, Endometriosis is associated with the presence in the blood of a cell free DNA, it is therefore considered as a marker of inflammation. Objective: The main objective of this study is to evaluate the role of cell free DNA as a marker of oocyte maturation, fertilization, and implantation in patients with endometriosis.

The purpose of this study is to compare treatment outcomes of fully edentulous patients with maxillary IODs secured by bars or Locators. The primary outcome is the change in peri-implant marginal bone level 10 years after placing the overdenture. Other outcome measures will include implant and overdenture survival, peri-implant mucosa health and patients' satisfaction.

Maxillary IOD are a reliable alternative to a conventional denture and provide good retention, stability and esthetics. Several retention systems are available including bars and Locators. Bar-retained IODs are considered the gold standard, but are expensive and require a high degree of patient compliance. Solitary attachments or Locators serve as an alternative. However, these attachments are more economical, but they often need replacement and may not be as durable as bars.

This study will include 74 patients who were treated with IOD supported by four implants 10 years ago. The primary outcome measure will be peri-implant bone level. Additionally, implant and overdenture survival, peri-implant mucosa condition and patient satisfaction assessed with a questionnaire will be evaluated. These variables are of great importance when comparing outcomes of treatment with different IOD attachment systems.

This is a non-randomized study with no masking. The sample size calculation resulted in at least 74 patients being required for sufficient power. No interventions are planned.

The results of this study will contribute to the choice and use of IOD attachment systems, which will result in better treatment for patients.

Seniors with mild to moderate dementia have a poor prognosis. There is no treatment or cure for dementia. Family and community support are limited, but an innovative non-pharmacological intervention may help.
This research project (R01AG067388) studies the effectiveness of Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (CST) for individuals living with dementia. CST is a low cost and highly disseminable intervention that has been demonstrated to be feasible and efficacious in several RCTs and randomized controlled open trials across the globe. The study investigators have demonstrated it can be offered effectively in the USA. CST has been well-received by people with dementia, their caregivers, and clinicians and is the preferred therapy by Canadians and Americans with cognitive impairment.
The study investigators will implement this therapy in a clinical randomized controlled trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to either receive CST or maintain with usual care. The investigators hypothesize that CST will improve cognitive and other functional status of individuals living with dementia.
Those enrolled into the study will receive a referral from their health care providers for 14 weeks of CST. The CST classes will be led by physicians and other health care professionals in their neighborhood clinics. The intervention classes will be tailored to the specific needs of each participant while utilizing the CST manual. CST manual has been highly standardized across 32 countries. The investigators will closely monitor study progress and report the number of participants recruited, reasons for recruitment failure, and any adverse events associated with the treatments. Primary Outcome Measure: Baseline and 6 months cognitive assessments by study investigators using the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), Saint Louis University Mental Status (SLUMS) exam, or the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE).
Secondary Outcome Measures: Patient Acceptance (measured by participant recruitment acceptance rate, attendance rate, and attrition rate). The investigators will also track adverse events and monitor participant satisfaction.
This research project is expected to last 5 years and will involve 1000 participants.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is one of the most common gastroenterological disorders with a reported prevalence of 10% to 20% percent in Europe and the USA and less than 5% in Asia. It manifests as heartburn, regurgitation, retrosternal pain, cough, and in some cases dysphagia and holds the possible complication of a Barrett´s esophagus. GERD can appear as non-erosive (NERD) or erosive (ERD). In the diagnosis of the reflux disease the DeMeester score is used as a measure of esophageal acid exposure time. Important differential diagnosis are benign functional disorders of the esophagus such as is functional heartburn or functional dysphagia. Comorbid symptoms of anxiety and depression are common: The association between anxiety or depression and reflux symptoms has been investigated in previous studies under the aspects of whether existing reflux symptomatology leads to increased anxiety and depression or whether anxiety and depression lead to more severe reflux symptoms. The results are inconsistent: In younger patients (18 - 40 years) with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) the prevalence of anxiety and depression is higher than in those without GERD. There is an independent association between GERD, anxiety and current depression. Patients with anxiety are more likely to experience GERD symptoms and these symptoms seem to be more severe in anxious patients. Anxiety and depression intensify symptom perception. Patients with GERD have a higher incidence of anxiety, depression and sleep disturbances than those without GERD, and there is an association between psychosocial disorders and an increased risk of anxiety. Thus, there is a an interaction between GERD and psychosocial disorders, which has been discussed as the psychoemotional effects of GERD. GERD is considered to be an independent source of stress.

In the present study the hypothesis is that anxiety is significantly associated with positive DeMeester scores indicating pathologic reflux disease. We conducted a prospective observational cohort study with one measurement time on admission for patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease referred to the Reflux and swallowing problems center of the Clinic for General and Visceral Surgery of the University Hospital Cologne, Germany, between January 2020 and July 2021. All patients were screened for anxiety and depression using the HADS questionnaire.

The HADS questionnaire is completed to assess anxiety and depression levels of patients with physiological as well as with pathological DeMeester scores. Furthermore, the modulation of anxiety on the severity of reflux symptoms such as fullness, heartburn and dysphagia is examined.

Objective: 
The diagnostic system based on ColonCAD - EYE (CAD-EYE) developed by Artificial Solution for a better detection of colorectal lesions (previously adenomas and suspected later ones; hereafter called colonic lesions) during the colonic examination. CAD-EYE improves the quality of colonic lesions detection by a 30% increase in the adenoma detection rate (ADR).
The goal of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of CAD-EYE compared to colonoscopy in screening for neoplastic lesions in Lynch syndrome.
Inclusion and exclusion criteria: 
Eligible patients will be included if they have a confirmed mutation for Lynch syndrome and a colonoscopy.
Exclusion criteria of the study: 
Patients undergoing total colectomy with ileoanal or ileosigmoid anastomosis, those with a history of Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis, patients with allergy or intolerance to PEG et Ascorbyl, and those unable to undergo fractionated colonic preparation are excluded.
Methods: 
A prospective randomized study will be conducted, including 8 centers, including 4 academic, 2 private and 2 university hospitals. 420 eligible patients will be enrolled and randomized to one of 2 study arms: 
o The CAD EYE group will undergo a colonic examination by a CAD-EYE-equipped colonoscope, under white light vision, with the CAD-EYE system switched on throughout the procedure. The physician's and CAD-EYE's predictions of histologic pathology of the colonic lesions will be reported separately;
o The CE group will undergo a colonic examination by chromo-colonoscopy with indigo carmine (IC) under white light. The physician's predictions of histologic pathology for the removed polyps will be reported. 
In the CAD EYE group, when polyps are detected, these will be identified with the DOT mode of the colonoscope, and photographs taken and reported. Polyp location, size with and without biopsy, will be reported by the physician. The endoscopist will remove all adenomas or suspected later lesions immediately by snare polypectomy.
Polyp location, size with and without biopsy, will be reported by the physician. The endoscopist will remove all adenomas or suspected later lesions immediately by snare polypectomy. 
Results: 
The primary objective of the study is to compare the detection rate of adenomas and serrated lesions in the 2 study arms (CAD-EYE vs. CE). 
The study also aims to evaluate CAD-EYE and CE predictive abilities for specific lesions and resect and discard strategy by comparing CAD-EYE histologists prediction to the physician's histologists prediction and the histological anatomopathological report. The performance of the CAD-EYE automated detection system assessed by its sensitivity, negative predictive value and positive predictive value will be compared to its automated prediction in comparison to colonoscopy indigo carmin chromo-colonoscopy. 
Colonoscopy time will be analyzed under the 2 study arms as well. 
The study should provide proof of the effectiveness of CAD EYE in the detection of colonic adenomas and serrated lesions in Lynch syndrome patients. The implementation of CAD EYE will also improve the predictive ability of the physician for this lesion. 
CAD EYE is expected to facilitate the adoption of a resect and discard strategy during colonoscopies in Lynch syndrome patients by improving the diagnostic specificity of the procedure. 
Finally, the system has a potential to reduce colonoscopy average procedure time. 
Expected results: 
Results of this study will provide a new tool to better detect colonic lesions in Lynch syndrome patients, while reducing the colonoscopy duration and the number of lesions taken care off.

<|assistant|> Our primary objective is to demonstrate that use of enteral contrast in the diagnosis and monitoring of patients with adhesive small bowel (ASBO) obstruction is associated with a lower rate of operative lysis of obstruction (operative LYO) compared with those who do not receive contrast. To assess the efficacy of our primary outcome measure, we will conduct a prospective observational study of patients admitted to the hospital with a working diagnosis of ASBO. The study will be conducted at five members of the Western Pediatric Surgical Research Consortium. The study will examine 314 patients with a diagnosis of ASBO and a trial of non-operative management (NOM) at discharge in order to prospectively compare the outcomes between these two groups. The primary study outcome measure is the operative LYO of ASBO. The primary endpoint will be the number of patients undergoing operative LYO based on contrast use during the hospital stay. We will also compare the length of hospital stay between the two groups. This study will provide information to guide future decisions regarding the use of contrast in the management of ASBO. Our study design will enroll patients who present with ASBO, a trial of NOM on admission, and enteral contrast will be given with a repeat contrast study at 8-12 hours. For this study, an attending pediatric surgeon will diagnose an ASBO and choose to manage this patient by trial of NOM, a treatment decision we believe is most appropriate for young patients with suspected ASBO. All of the enrolled patients will be included as part of an outcome measure comparison. In order to assess the efficacy of the contrast protocol based on contrast use in the management of ASBO, we will compare the outcomes between patients who were enrolled in a study for early use of contrast and patients who were not. All of the enrolled patients will be included as part of the outcome measure comparison. The primary study outcome measure will be operative LYO, defined as the need for surgery due to the failure of non-operative management. This study is important to determine which patients with ASBO are best managed through a trial of NOM, and which patients are better managed by immediate operative LYO. The impact will be direct with an anticipated shift in the management of ASBO. This prospective, multi-center, observational study will determine the relative efficacy of enteral contrast use and non-operative management in the pediatric population. While we do not anticipate any adverse outcomes from contrast administration being utilized at the six participating sites at the current time, we will monitor adverse events related to contrast administration prospectively to gather more evidence to guide the use of contrast in this setting. The purpose of this study to characterize key pharmacokinetics parameters of itepekimab (SAR440377) following administration of single subcutaneous dose of itepekimab using autoinjector (AI) or prefilled syringe (PFS) in healthy young male/female subjects.

Inclusion Criteria: Subjects of both sexes greater than 18 years and less than 65 years.

Method: This will be a single center, randomized, open label, single dose pilot study in health participants. Two cohorts of subjects (n=8/cohort) will be randomized (AI versus PFS) for the administration of a single dose of itepekimab in the form of autoinjector or prefilled syringe. The pharmacokinetics of itepekimab concentrations in serum will be observed over a period up to approximately 141 days post dose.

Design: This will be a randomized open label study and each participant will be given only one treatment. There will be no masking.

Bronchiectasis is a chronic disease characterized by thickening of the bronchial walls, chronic cough, sputum production and prone to recurrent infections. Many factors can be associated with bronchiectasis: congenital abnormalities can affect the bronchial development, immune inborn deficiencies cause chronic infections and lung damage, while external insults can cause the inflammatory changes that lead to bronchial wall destruction. Patients with bronchiectasis present with non-reversible airway obstruction. However, in contrast to asthma, the improvement in airway obstruction in response to bronchodilators in bronchiectasis is less clear. Bronchodilators are still among the most common therapies used in bronchiectasis despite the lack of a clear effect on disease progression and treatment of airway obstruction. The goal of this study is to determine if bronchodilator response in bronchiectasis might be influenced by other factors apart from the direct effect of bronchodilators. Evidence for this assumption can be seen in that respiratory therapy in terms if positive expiratory pressure (PEP) therapy can improve various parameters of lung function when tested again closely after the therapy. Theoretically, in bronchiectasis, the forced expiration maneuver used in spirometry testing can potentially cause changes in lung function for example by inducing cough and mobilization of sputum. The primary objective of this study is to determine whether bronchodilator response is influenced by the time between spirometry and bronchodilator inhalation. This will be determined by performing bronchodilator response test (BDT) in the following order: 1) 30 minutes of regular spirometry followed by 4 puffs of salbutamol; 2) 30 minutes later the same procedure with placebo will be performed. The secondary objectives are: a. To determine if bronchodilator response in various specific subset of bronchiectasis (cystic fibrosis, primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), primary immune deficiency (PID), idiopathic bronchiectasis) differ from each other. b. To determine if bronchodilator response in patients with higher degree of bronchiectasis severity differ from patients with less severe bronchiectasis disease. c. To determine if bronchodilator response is influenced by age and gender of the participant. d. To determine if bronchodilator response in specific subset of bronchiectasis (cystic fibrosis, PCD, PID) is influenced by FEV1 level (FEV1 >80 versus <80) as measured by best FEV1 measured in the 6 months prior to the day of the study. e. To determine if bronchodilator response is influenced by the history of pseudomonas (positive or negative as determined by sputum cultures). f. To determine if bronchodilator response is influenced by personal history of allergy. g. To determine if bronchodilator response is influenced by baseline FEV1 (FEV1 >80 versus <80) as measured by all FEV1 scores obtained in the 6 months prior to the day of the study. 80 is the established cutoff as the difference between age adjusted predicted values to distinguish severe COPD.

Sex has long been a predictor of various physiological responses, including pain sensitivity. Studies have demonstrated that males and females differ in pain sensitivity, response to nociceptive stimuli, nociceptive processing in the central nervous system and the effect of hormones on pain perception. Gender identity is an important social determinant of health, shaping personal experience of the world, exposure to stressors and the impact of these on various physiological processes including pain modulation. Despite this, transgender individuals continue to experience more pain and poorer quality of life as compared to gender majority individuals. This is especially relevant to the health care system with transgender patients reporting difficulty accessing healthcare, often being misgendered, subject to discrimination and facing a multitude of mental health challenges. The aim of the proposed study is to study the effects of sex, gender identity and hormones on pain perception.

The aim of this research is to test the feasibility of providing an inpatient, stroke multidisciplinary technology enriched rehabilitation programme. The multidisciplinary rehabilitation programme will test the feasibility and appropriateness of using a technology enriched space within the hospital stroke unit. This will examine the acceptability and appropriateness of increasing time spent in rehabilitation activity delivered to inpatients in the acute/sub acute stage of their rehabilitation from an average of 1.6 hours a day, to around 4 hours a day, within a specially designed room which contains, wearable/mobile technology equipment, such as robotic devices, adapted treadmills, virtual reality, smartphones and tablet computers. The study will measure the dose and time spent in rehabilitation activity using wearable activity monitors. Semi-structured interviews will be completed with hospital staff and participants to assess the acceptability of the intervention. It is hoped that the work completed in this study will provide a method of delivering the recommended 4 hours of therapy a day, which should be achievable within a hospital stroke unit. This is essential given the current staffing shortfall of 30% in stroke rehabilitation. Results of the project will determine the potential for wider implementation of technology enriched rehabilitation within acute and sub acute hospital stroke units.

<|assistant|> Background: Dyspnea induced by Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis is a major determinant of suffering in ALS patients. The only palliative treatment for respiratory failure is non-invasive ventilation (NIV), which compensates for failing respiratory muscles and relieves dyspnea. The persistence of dyspnea outside of NIV sessions has highlighted the need for therapeutic alternatives in the treatment of persistent dyspnea, including immersive virtual reality (IVR) and auditory distraction through music (music therapy). To date, several studies have evaluated the effect of IVR on dyspnea in respiratory patients. However, studies conducted in populations other than ALS have demonstrated the therapeutic potential of IVR. Several studies have shown the interest of auditory distraction through music on dyspnea. Objective: The objective of this study is to evaluate the effect of IVR on respiratory discomfort (scale A1 of the Multidimensional Dyspnea Profile (MDP) questionnaire) of patients with ALS at the stage of respiratory failure treated by NIV. Method: This will be an open-label, monocentric, randomized, controlled cross-over clinical study. ALS patients will be recruited during their respiratory evaluation carried out as part of their usual care provided in an ambulatory setting (day care hospital) in the Pneumology Department of Pitié Salpêtrière Hospital. The study consists of two sessions, each of 15 minutes, separated by a 30-minute break. The IVR session will be based on medical hypnosis, with a tablet (Samsung) equipped with Healthy Mind software, a virtual reality headset (GAMIDA), and headphones (Bose). The music therapy session will be based on the choice of music that the patient likes. The Random Order software (CleanWeb) will be used to determine the order of the intervention at the inclusion stage. Urinary tract infection (UTI) is the most frequent bacterial infection among women, and antibiotic treatment, most of the time broad-spectrum, is associated with an increase in the risk of resistance. Since the majority of women with lower urinary tract infection (UTI) are managed by general practitioners (GPs), this study aims to promote the use of susceptibility testings (ST) among GPs, by providing a new report that recommends a targeted antibiotic therapy, and thereby reduce the consumption of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
Since the early 2000s, the use of specific antimicrobials targeted at susceptibility profiles in GPs practices has been shown to lead to a reduction in the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics (Bronner et al., 2006). More recently, the same approach, involving the use of selective reportings (SR) to promote ST in GP practices, was associated with a significant reduction in antibiotic prescribing in French primary care (Berenger et al., 2012). This SR approach is implemented from 2013 in all laboratories in France thanks to an inter-professional consortium in charge of its production (Consortium Interprofessionnel de Délai de Livraison des Rapports de Résistance). Indeed, the implementation of standardized targeted reporting by all clinical laboratories could be a major milestone to reduce the unnecessary use of broad-spectrum antibiotics in French primary care settings.
We hypothesize that a selective reporting among general practitioners would further reduce the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotics prescribed among patients with E. coli UTI. We plan to compare four levels of treatment of E. coli UTI based on E. coli susceptibility, and their impact on the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic use. Furthermore, given that the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic consumption may vary according to practice and patient characteristics, we plan to identify potential modifiers and mediators of this impact. Finally, we plan to measure the effect of this intervention on the rate of directed antibiotic de-escalation.
We will carry out a randomized controlled clinical trial among all GPs who receive ST from the LabOuest network (a public laboratory), and among women with E. coli UTI for which ST is performed in these laboratories over a one-year period. The sample size is estimated to 20 000 women.
This study is innovative in that it aims to optimize the use of ST by providing physicians with a recommendation that can lead directly to prescription of narrower-spectrum antibiotics.

Ischemic stroke is one of the leading causes of disability and mortality worldwide, which imposes a huge burden on families and society. Currently, the effective treatment strategies of ischemic stroke are limited. It is of great clinical value and significance to explore effective neuroprotective medications besides reperfusion therapy. Sodium valproate is widely used in clinical practice, and its safety and tolerability has been confirmed. It is mainly used in the treatment of epilepsy, bipolar disorder, neuropathic pain and other diseases. In recent years, a number of preclinical studies have found that valproic acid has a potential neuroprotective effect in acute ischemic brain injury, which can decrease infarct volume, reduce blood-brain barrier damage, and improve neurological function. However, the neuroprotective mechanism of sodium valproate has not been fully revealed, and there is still a lack of clinical studies to clarify the neuroprotective effect of sodium valproate in patients with ischemic stroke. The goal of this study is to test whether sodium valproate could become a new therapeutic approach to improve the functional outcome after ischemic stroke. This prospective pilot study is intended to clarify whether the use of sodium valproate in patients with acute ischemic stroke can improve clinical outcomes, and to explore the mechanism: whether valproate could increase peripheral anti-inflammatory CD177+ neutrophils levels to reduce neuroinflammation caused by the infiltrated peripheral immune cells. Patients with acute ischemic stroke included in the study will be randomly assigned to low-dose sodium valproate group, high-dose sodium valproate group and placebo group. Besides receiving conventional treatment for stroke, 10mg/kg sodium valproate, 20mg/kg sodium valproate or normal saline were given intravenously for 3 consecutive days, respectively. The investigators evaluate whether sodium valproate can improve clinical outcomes and increase peripheral CD177+ neutrophil levels.

The purpose of this study is to determine if the use of a MyChart enabled virtual weight loss coach can be superior or have an equal impact to existing standard weight loss tools. Our initial hypothesis is that this type of virtual coach can help in achieving a faster rate of weight reduction and may even improve quality of life. Additionally, we hope that the virtual coach may increase patient satisfaction. As there are no published, peer-reviewed articles on the use of virtual coaches in a surgical preoperative weight loss regime for obese patients, this study will provide the first insights into the use of virtual coaches in this population and add to the literature of aiding weight loss through digital resources.

Endodontic treatment failure remains one of the most common challenges for dentists even in the era of advanced materials and technologies. The root canal treatment protocol of the Vietnamese Dental Association, which requires sealing the root canal system after root canal preparation, resulted in a higher pain relief rate than the previous method by the Vietnam Ministry of Health, which does not seal the root canal system after root canal preparation. However, pain is still an issue that affects the patients' quality of life. The root canal sealer was used to reduce the number of visits for root canal treatment and to reduce the discomfort for the patients, thus reducing the treatment cost and the patients' inconvenience, which is one of the goals of the new national oral health strategy 2015-2020. The root canal sealer is expected to reduce or eliminate bacterial infections that trigger inflammation in tooth tissue. Currently, both calcium silicate-based sealer and epoxy resin-based sealer are clinically effective in the control of pain and in reducing complications from root canal treatment such as swelling, fistula, etc. Moreover, the application of the root canal sealer could provide a stronger and more resistant seal, preventing the occurrence of cracks in the root canal system. The purpose of this clinical trial is to compare the effectiveness in term of pain control and treatment outcomes of calcium silicate-based sealer versus epoxy resin-based sealer used for root canal obturation with the same endodontic treatment protocol with the support of an electronic operating microscope in a single visit.

This study was designed to evaluate the immunogenicity of two domestically-produced bivalent HPV vaccines (Wozehui® and Cecolin®) compared to imported HPV vaccines in adolescent females aged 13-14 years. A total of 3,000 subjects were recruited and divided into three groups, including domestic bivalent vaccine group, domestic bivalent vaccine group and imported vaccine group. Vaccines were administered in a 0, 2, 6 months schedule in both the domestic bivalent vaccine group and imported HPV vaccine group. Three immuneogenic blood were collected. A window period ± 1 month for each follow-up visit was set. The aim of this study was to provide a direct and relevant reference for the selection of domestically-produced HPV vaccines and provide information for clinical decision making.

<|assistant|> Background: Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CIM) is a popular supportive approach among cancer patients. It has become necessary to integrate CIM modalities in cancer care. The use of homeopathy may be particularly beneficial for symptom management. Aims: The aim of this study is to evaluate the feasibility of the process of integrating homeopathy as a supportive approach to improve symptoms of cancer patients on an outpatient basis. Methods: Adults with cancer who are 18 years and older, who will undergo an integrative oncology consultation at the Division of Oncology and Hematology, Rambam Health Campus, will be invited to participate in the study. They will be invited to complete an interview that will focus on exploring the reasons for their interest in homeopathic treatment, as well as validated questionnaires to assess their quality of life. Patients that agreed to the interview will further be offered the integration of homeopathic remedies to their care. They will be followed up one month after integration. The question of the retention rate of patients in the follow up visit will serve as a measure of outcome and feasibility of the approach. The main endpoint of the study will be feasibility of homeopathic support as a supportive approach according to the completion of the questionnaire and retention rate of participants at the one month follow up visit. In addition, the main changes in the quality of life questionnaire will be recorded. Qualitative analysis of the interviews will be performed in order to better understand the reasons and experience of the patients. Thrombophlebitis remains a major complication of vascular catheterization, whether central or peripheral. Septic form in particular represents 25% to 30% of catheter infections and 5% to 20% of catheter failures, leading to catheter removal and, consequently, an increase in the number of invasive procedures required during antibiotic treatment. The diagnosis of thrombophlebitis, and in particular septic thrombophlebitis, requires a combination of clinical, biological and ultrasonographic signs. Doppler, usually performed during hospitalization, is the most relevant and recommended imaging examination to confirm the presence of thrombosis. However, it has never been specifically evaluated in the diagnosis of septic thrombophlebitis. Our primary goal is to determine the proportion of patients with septic thrombophlebitis with a positive venous Doppler ultrasound on days 8, 15, 30, 45, 60 and 90. Our second objective is to assess the predictive factors for 30-day septic thrombophlebitis and for the disappearance of venous Doppler ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis at 1 month.

Background: Relapsed/refractory (r/r) classical Hodgkin lymphoma (cHL) remains a significant clinical challenge with a need for novel treatment options. Achieving deep responses or a cure is more challenging in patients with r/r cHL. CD30 targeted therapies have improved the treatment of r/r cHL. In the past year, an anti-CD30 bispecific antibody (bsAb), Odronextamab (ODX), has been used in combination with lenalidomide (RDx) in patients with r/r CHL. RDx produced deep, durable, single-agent responses in patients with r/r cHL, and the addition of ODX to the regimen has resulted in a more favorable response compared to the standard of care RDx-based regimens (RR10, RD13, ORR of 83% vs 30%; median PFS of 44 vs 4 months) in the ongoing TEMPO2 study (NCT03503279). This study has generated interest in testing the safety and efficacy of ODX in combination with lenalidomide for r/r indolent lymphomas.
Objective: To perform a pivotal Phase III randomized clinical trial to further explore the safety and efficacy of ODX in comparison to R2 in patients with r/r indolent lymphomas.
Design: This study was initiated based on the ODX development plan and rationale for RDx treatment in r/r indolent lymphomas (FL/MZL) and its potential to provide a new treatment option for patients with these conditions. This study is designed as a two arm, Phase III, randomized, open-label, multicenter study. The study arms will contain an experimental arm with odronextamab + lenalidomide (ODX), and the R2 arm, consisting of two consecutive blocks of R2 (rituximab and lenalidomide) followed by lenalidomide monotherapy until progression or end of study (EoS). Dosing for the study will be based on previous reports of ODX in Phase I trials. Data supporting the dosing and schedules for lenalidomide and rituximab in both study arms are well known.
Specific studies have been designed to better understand the pharmacokinetics of ODX in this setting of r/r FL/MZL.
The primary objective of this study is to determine whether ODX in combination with lenalidomide (ODX+LD) is superior to rituximab in combination with lenalidomide followed by lenalidomide monotherapy (R2/LD, R-blocks followed by lenalidomide; R2) with regard to the best overall response rate according to the 2018 Lugano classification for follicular lymphoma at end of study (EoS) visit, in patients with R/R indolent lymphoma (FL and MZL).
Inclusion Criteria:
1 Age 18 to ≤ 90 years, male or female
2 Patients with r/r follicular or marginal zone lymphoma (FL/MZL)
3 Patients must be refractory or have progression after at least 2 prior lines of systemic treatment
4 Patients must have measurable disease on cross sectional imaging

Gingivitis and periodontitis are inflammatory diseases affecting the soft tissues and the underlying bone and periodontal ligament, which support the teeth. Periodontitis is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by gingival inflammation, periodontal breakdown, and bone resorption in the periodontal tissues. Ozone has antibacterial, antifungal and anti-inflammatory properties that have been suggested to be effective in the treatment of gingival and periodontal diseases. Ozone treatment has been recommended not only for the prevention and management of periodontitis, but also to reduce bleeding on probing and gingivitis in healthy patients. Although ozone therapy could improve periodontal health, the available literature is still not clear about the mechanism of action and the extent of ozone antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory effects. Moreover, there is a lack of evidence for the treatment of periodontitis with ozone alone. Therefore, the aim of the present study is to evaluate the effect of immediate ozone application on the reduction of the gingival inflammation and the severity of periodontal breakdown, the reduction of the amounts of Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Porphyromonas gingivalis, Prevotella intermedia and Tannerella forsythia counts as compared to the levels seen after non-surgical periodontal treatment alone. The present clinical randomized controlled trial involves 24 patients for each study group divided into 2 groups: an Ozone group and a control group. All the patients will be evaluated for plaque index, gingival index, bleeding on probing, periodontal probing pocket depths, and the amounts of Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Porphyromonas gingivalis, Prevotella intermedia and Tannerella forsythia counts in gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) at different study time points (baseline, after non-surgical periodontal treatment, 1st and 3rd months after treatment). The ozone group will receive 3 times of gaseous ozone immediately after non-surgical periodontal treatment. The control group will receive non-surgical periodontal treatment only.  This study will provide a better understanding for the treatment of periodontitis with ozone alone, based on the current and potential future practice.

Pterygium is a benign degenerative disease of conjunctival tissue. The aim of this study is to identify cell proliferation markers (CD44, PCNA and E-cadherin) in surgically removed pterygia compared to conjunctival tissue from normal control patients. The researchers hypothesized that pterygium cells express different cell proliferation markers compared to normal conjunctival tissue. Conjunctival samples will be taken from patients with pterygium and normal conjunctiva samples from 30 healthy individuals. The immunohistochemical and histopathological staining findings will be reported using a light microscope and an image analysis system. The study will contribute to better understanding of the pathogenesis of pterygium and help in developing new therapeutic strategies for treating the disease.

Respiratory tract infections (RTIs) account for 5-15% visits to primary care, 3-15% hospital admissions and 4-11% deaths. Both young healthy adults as well as frail vulnerable elderly suffer from RTIs. The former are known to have a stronger immune response to vaccinations, leading to high protection rates. In contrast, the latter have been reported to carry a high burden of RTI-related mortality despite being vaccinated with RTI-preventing vaccinations. A likely reason for this is their severely weakened immune system, even after RTI vaccination, allowing RTI-induced immune suppression to develop to such an extent that vaccination is no longer effective. The nose/nasal cavity is recognized as the main site of RTI development, as the majority of RTI-causing pathogens enter the respiratory tract through the nose. Thus, the immune response in the nose is the first line of defense against RTI-causing pathogens. CD8+ T cells are the main cell type mediating clearance of RTI-causing pathogens in the nose. In the last years, we have performed several pilot projects showing a marked decrease in CD8 T cell frequency in the nose of healthy aging adults. Our most recent pilot studies indicate that this decrease is even more profound in frail older adults and even more so after RTI development. We here propose a longitudinal controlled study aiming 1) To unravel the underlying mechanisms and consequences of the loss of T cells and/or other immune cell populations that is responsible for the increased RTI susceptibility in older individuals; 2) to assess the added value of repeated (seasonal) sampling during 5 months to assess immune response dynamics to SARS-CoV-2, a well-known respiratory pathogen that is also responsible for large numbers of nosocomial infections, and; 3) to dissect the role of sex-differences in RTI susceptibility in both young healthy adults and frail older adults. The data obtained in our proposed project will contribute to designing more effective RTI prevention strategies in older adults.

Background: Liver cirrhosis is the most important cause of ascites in clinic. Cirrhosis can progress by development of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).  SBP leads to development of portal hypertension in addition to development of portal systemic shunt with progression of the disease until the patient develops terminal hepatic outcome. 
The diagnosis of SBP relies on laboratory test that includes presence ≥250 polymorphonuclear leukocyte (PMNL)/mm3 in the ascetic fluid in absence of surgical and treatable causes of intra-abdominal infections. However SBP  is associated with several predictive factor of poor outcomes of SBP. 
Methods: The study will include fifty cirrhotic patients with ascites. In the study there are two parts and two study arms. Study arm 1 will include 25 cirrhotics with ascites who will be treated with ceftriaxone intravenously for 5 days. The second study arm will be another 25 cirrhotic patients with ascites who will not receive ceftriaxone for 5 days. 
Blood samples from all participants will be taken in the first and fifth day of starting treatment and also on the fifth day if not developed SBP symptoms. The labs studies include platelets to lymphocytes ratio (PLR) and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio (MLR). This research will be conducted in the Tanta University Hospital, Hepatology and gastroenterology department. 
Analysis will be done on both groups (treated and untreated) to evaluate the effect of ceftriaxone treatment on survival rate of the cirrhotic patient with ascites. 
Expected Results: The results will be expressed in percentage and mean (standard deviation). 
Comparison between the groups in each time ( first day and fifth day) will be made using the student t-test. Also we will compare the difference between the last day (after five days from starting treatment) in the treated arm and the untreated. 
This study will help in predicting the response to treatment in cirrhotic patients with SBP.
