Detailed Description
-----------------
Nearly 30 million people worldwide suffer from chronic heart failure (HF), a condition for which effective long-term treatment options are greatly needed. While the pathogenesis of HF is multifactorial, one of the key underlying mechanisms is the disruption of the endocalyx, a glycocalyx layer that lines the blood vessels and regulates the exchange of water and electrolytes between blood and the cardiovascular system. This mechanism occurs even in patients with HF who have otherwise normal kidney function. The key consequence is fluid excess which results in symptoms like peripheral edema and shortness of breath. This fluid excess is typically managed by diuretic treatment, but excessive use of diuretics often leads to electrolyte depletion and worsening of kidney function. Therefore, a non-diuretic treatment option that will allow patients to be less dependent on diuretics is urgently needed. However, existing non-diuretic treatment options are either not effective or are associated with negative consequences. Thus there is a clear clinical need for finding treatments that will help HF patients deal with the fluid excess without relying on diuretics. The main goal of the current investigation is to determine the efficacy of the food supplement Endocalyx in dealing with the fluid excess of chronic HF. For patients with long-term chronic HF, fluid excess can manifest in a variety of ways. Most patients experience symptoms such as shortness of breath and peripheral edema, while others develop hypertension or may have a worsening of kidney function. Endocalyx is a food supplement that has shown to reduce sodium storage in the small intestine, and as a result increase sodium excretion in healthy volunteers. However, the effect of Endocalyx on patients with long-term chronic HF remains unknown. In the current study we will test whether Endocalyx can decrease sodium and water excess in patients with chronic HF. In an explorative pilot study we have previously demonstrated that Endocalyx also has positive effects on blood pressure control and microcirculation in patients with chronic HF and diabetes mellitus with hypertension. This study was not powered to directly demonstrate these effects. For the current study we will perform a randomized, placebo-controlled trial focused on patients with heart failure and fluid excess, as manifested by elevated NT-proBNP levels or symptoms such as shortness of breath, peripheral edema, hypertension or worsening kidney function. The primary outcome will be the degree of fluid excess or symptom burden based on the change in NT-proBNP levels. Secondary outcomes will include changes in body weight, blood pressure, hemodynamic parameters, total body water and urinary sodium excretion as well as adverse events. We aim to include 50 patients. As many as 1 out of 3 patients will drop out prematurely leading to an estimation of an n = 74, which will give a 80% power to identify a 30% difference in NT-proBNP levels between the two study arms, assuming a significance level of 5%. Sample size calculations were performed using the program G*Power, version 3.1.9.

Chemotherapy combined with immunotherapy has the synergistic effect on tumors, and has emerged as a new breakthrough in tumor treatment. HBsAg loss is an ideal treatment outcome. Studies have shown that tumor immune surveillance has immune dysfunction, which is reflected in defective dendritic cells and dysfunctional T cells. Therefore, activating innate immune system (dendritic cell, NK cells and antiviral CD8+T cells) and adaptive immune system (lymphocyte subsets) play important roles in the anti-tumor effect. This research plan is designed using a triple combined therapy approach (immunotherapy) to aim at the functional cure for chronic Hepatitis B. We select anti-PD-1 antibody, NAs and peginterferon alfa-2a (peg-IFNα) for the treatment of hepatitis B virus (HBV), so as to activate the host's innate and adaptive immune systems, eliminate HBV-infected cells, and maintain a persistently high level of HBsAg-specific T cells that can control HBV replication to reduce the incidence of HBV DNA reappearance. This design of the clinical treatment approach is expected to achieve effective control of HBV replication, maintain HBeAg negative state, and achieve the goal of sustained HBsAg loss, thereby realizing the functional cure of hepatitis B virus.

The purposes of this study aim to detect suture wound loosening in mouth and its related symptoms under experimental conditions with different suture techniques.
Mouth wound loosening is one of the main complications related to periodontal surgery, and it can negatively affect the periodontal therapy. After a full arch alveoplasty, the surgical wound should be closed and sutured at the end of the operation. However, a well-known clinical concern is loosening of the suture material. Since loosening of sutures is related with increased morbidity and discomfort for patients, it is important to investigate suture loosening and its related symptoms.
In several clinical studies, it has been reported that different suture techniques result in different rates of suture loosening. However, due to the lack of similarity and comparison among studies, clear evidence of the influence of different suture techniques on suture loosening has not been found so far. It is known that the time required to knot or suture is longer for the full arch alveoplasty operation. According to the clinical experience in the division of oral surgery in Istanbul Medipol University, the suture wound loosening is more difficult after full arch suturing without interruption.
In this study, the investigators planned to detect early wound healing parameters and suture loosening according to suture techniques between full arch alveoplasty. The null hypothesis for this study is that continuous suture methods should not be different from simple wound closure methods, in terms of suture loosening parameters, and any suturing techniques should not show significant difference in terms of suture loosening parameters. For this purpose, one hundred and eight patients who were candidates for the same full arch alveoplasty treatment in Istanbul Medipol University Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery are included in this study. Patients, aged between 40 and 65, who were candidates for the same full arch alveoplasty are treated under similar conditions.
To detect whether early wound healing score, laundry healing index, suturing time, suture removal difficulty, pain, suture loosening are related to suturing techniques in Istanbul Medipol University, the null hypothesis about there is nothing different about continuous suture methods compared to simple wound closure methods in terms of suture loosening parameters in the full arch suturing in oral surgery is analyzed. If the null hypothesis is proven wrong, the investigators should conclude that the simple suture technique gives less wound loosening related morbidity.

During the last two decades, corneal endothelial replacement (DMEK) has become an established surgical technique for the treatment of cases of Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy. The use of DMEK in the presence of pre-existing retinal surgery, and especially in its absence, remains subject to discussion among corneal surgeons, with opinions ranging from "the treatment is contraindicated" (in the absence of retinal surgery) to "the treatment is not contraindicated and is even recommended" (in the absence of retinal surgery).
The hypothesis of the present study is that DMEK performed in patients with retinal surgery or with a history of anterior segment surgery (cataract, IOL implantation, filtering bleb) presents a serious risk of surgical complication. The investigators hypothesize the opposite in the case of patients with a history of pars plana vitrectomy and / or with an implanted intraocular lens.
This prospective monocentric randomized study will compare the occurrence rate of serious post-operative complications of DMEK in the three groups of patients mentioned above, as well as the improvement in visual acuity from both unaided and corrected eyes one year after surgery.
The main objective is to quantify the occurrence rate of post-operative complications, namely the composite endpoints consisting of corneal detachment requiring graft redressing under air or gas, corneal edema requiring reoperation, corneal stromal graft rejection requiring reoperation, and the development of cystoid macular edema.
The secondary objectives concern the evolution of visual and refractive results of the operated eye, the endothelial density and morphometry of the corneal graft one year after surgery, the evolution of intraocular pressure, the complication rate of phacoemulsification or DMEK combined after one year of surgery, and the analysis of the surgical time.
The analysis of these results will confirm the need for a DMEK surgery in specific patient groups or the need to avoid surgery in others. This analysis will also provide additional data for surgeons wishing to perform DMEK surgery in non-uniform groups, and contribute to defining better indications for DMEK surgery in patients with a history of anterior segment procedure.

The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of stabilization and stabilization-related parameters on shooting performance at the cervical, lumbal and scapular levels in archery athletes. 40 archery athletes aged between 10 and 18, who have been professionally engaged in archery for at least 1 year were included in the study. Demographic information and musculoskeletal system evaluations of the athletes were done. Performance of the athletes via Upper Extremity Closed Kinetic Chain Stability Test, Hand Grip Strength test; presence of scapular dyskinesia was evaluated via the Lateral Scapular Slide Test. Cervical region stabilization was evaluated via Craniocervical Flexion Test, scapular level stabilization was evaluated via Scapular Muscle Endurance Test, lumbar region stabilization was evaluated via Abdominal Drawing-in Test and Sahrmann's Core Stability Test. As the parameters related to stabilization, postures via Corbin Postural Rating Scale; balances via Stork Balance Test, Upper Extremity Y Balance Test; pain was evaluated via the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index. Shooting performances were evaluated with 72 target shootings and a total of 720 points.  There was no significant difference between two groups in terms of total shooting performance (p = 0.13). The two athletes belonging to the upper extremity performance group were scored higher in each session than the other athlete in terms of upper extremity performance with only one clicker test. There were no significant differences between two groups in terms of scapular dyskinesia (p = 0.057). There are significant relationships between upper extremity performance, shooting performance and scapular dyskinesia (r = 0.495, r = 0.448 and r = -0.474) and there is significant relationships between upper extremity closed chain stability test and the presence of scapular dyskinesia (r = 0.403). The study results showed that there was a positive relationship between the muscle strength performance, scapula muscle endurance performance and upper extremity performance. However, there was no difference between the groups in terms of total shooting performance. Our study showed that all stabilization-related parameters measured; muscle strength, muscle endurance, postural stability are related to upper extremity performance and scapular dyskinesia in archery athletes. However; further studies with larger series are needed to clarify the relationship between stabilization performance and the shooting performance of archery athletes.

Background: Sexual and reproductive health concerns often arise, but adolescents may be reluctant to discuss these sensitive topics with their parent or provider. Despite clear benefits to contraception use, adolescents may experience challenges in the quality of communication discussing contraception with their providers that can influence their sexual health outcomes. Mothers and daughters are increasingly accessing primary care. Providers may feel unprepared in discussions around contraception. Although a variety of communication training programs exist for pediatrician trainees and health providers, none are culturally appropriate, family based or designed to address the challenges of adolescent reproductive health. Objectives: To characterize the quality of sexual and reproductive health encounters involving adolescents, mothers and their provider in pediatric primary care settings. To evaluate a conversation skills intervention for providers and assess its impact on communication quality of sexual and reproductive health encounters. To identify communication strategies preferred by adolescents and their family that may be embedded in a chatbot communication training program. Methods: This study will be conducted in three stages. In Stage 1 (formative) (50 encounters), we will characterize the quality of sexual and reproductive health encounters involving adolescents, mothers and their provider in pediatric primary care settings. Through separate post-encounter surveys of each triad member, we will determine ideal, moderate, and poor communication interactions with a 4-point Likert scale to describe the overall quality of the interactions (concordant contraception plans, satisfaction), communication (confidence, comfort, self-efficacy, confidentiality) and decision-making (perceived autonomy, ownership and power) to determine ideal, moderate, and poor communication interactions. In Stage 2 (development), we will use machine learning algorithms to design virtual conversations for providers, adolescents and mothers. In Stage 3 (proof-of-concept), we will test how an AI communication training intervention tool can influence triadic interactions by comparing evaluation results of 50 pre and 50 post training encounters using the same assessments as in Stage 1. The investigators will enroll ten physician learners who will train with the chatbot communication training program as a behavioral intervention. Before the training, the 10 learners will complete 5 sexual health clinical encounters with adolescent-mother dyads (50 total encounters) that will be audio-recorded and post-encounter surveys completed. After training with the tool, the same 10 learners will complete 5 more clinical encounters with adolescent-mother dyads (50 total encounters) in the same format to assess for improvement in communication interactions. Discussion: This study aims to provide innovative approaches to train pediatricians in adolescent sexual health care. This project addresses a critical gap in evidence-based communication training interventions for pediatricians focusing on underserved adolescents. Expected outcome of this project will be a culturally appropriate and family-focused conversation skills training for pediatricians engaging with adolescents and parents.

Background: There is little information about vitiligo which characterises healthcare disparities in vitiligo, despite mounting evidence about the psychological impact of vitiligo. The aim of this study is to assess and characterise mental health and related issues in a vitiligo cohort recruited from a large electronic healthcare database. Healthcare disparities: Mental health conditions; healthcare utilisation including primary care encounters, dermatology referrals and mental health referrals; and work impact (time off work and unemployment) will be assessed for people with vitiligo compared to those without vitiligo.
Design: This will be a retrospective observational cohort study. A large electronic healthcare database, the Optimum Patient Care Record (OPCRD), will be interrogated prospectively to identify people with vitiligo and those without vitiligo, from 2004 to 2020. The endpoints for both cohorts will be examined during the following two years (2020-2021). Patients with vitiligo, compared with those without, will be described demographically and followed up with data on mental health referrals, primary care referrals, time off work, and unemployment. The cumulative lifetime incidence and prevalence of vitiligo will be estimated at age 80 years using survival models and plotted by age, gender, socioeconomic profile and ethnicity.
Outcomes: Primary outcomes will include the frequency of mental health referrals, primary care encounters, time off work and unemployment in people with vitiligo compared with those without disease. Secondary outcomes will include prevalence rates of mental health conditions and time to first mental health referral event in the vitiligo population. The cumulative lifetime risk of vitiligo will be estimated by baseline characteristics age, gender, sex, ethnicity and deprivation.
Study size: The cumulative lifetime risk based on 16 years of follow up, accounting for competing risk of death would identify vitiligo in approximately >350,000 individuals.
Investigative team: A multidisciplinary research team of clinicians, epidemiologists, statisticians, a patient group representative and a patient representative will work closely throughout this project.

The NCCN guidelines for the management of brain metastases recommend localized therapy, including surgery and stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS), in patients with good performance status, no leptomeningeal disease, and controlled extracranial disease. The investigators believe that it is reasonable to include such patients in a study of vinorelbine and trotabresib. Trotabresib is thought to inhibit poly-ADP-ribose-polymerase (PARP), which is commonly altered in HER2-enriched cancers and is also known to function in DNA repair inhibition, and to be particularly effective as a therapeutic agent in breast tumors harboring loss of function mutations that are thought to lead to deficient homologous recombination DNA repair, even in the absence of overt mutations, loss of function or reduced expression in the PARP pathway. There is some evidence that Vinorelbine might enhance the effectiveness of cytotoxic radiotherapy in CNS. This study will investigate the safety and effectiveness of 3-week cycles of vinorelbine (9 mg/m2 intravenous over 10 minutes) along with trotabresib administered orally during the entire week (25 mg/day) immediately after the completion of radiation therapy to brain metastases or leptomeningeal disease. The investigators aim to determine the highest tolerated dose of this combination. The investigators believe that this treatment regimen with radiotherapy, followed by vinorelbine and trotabresib, will provide an effective and well-tolerated therapeutic approach for patients with limited metastatic disease to the central nervous system.

Our primary goal is to develop a culturally-relevant digital health tool for Black women to detect and treat binge eating in Black women with obesity. Our secondary goal is to demonstrate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the digital health program to prevent weight re-gain. A priori sample size calculations indicate we can detect feasibility and preliminary efficacy for the program (based on previous findings). We will use a randomized clinical trial design with 40 participants. This protocol will be the first to focus on preventing weight gain and reducing binge eating among Black women with obesity by implementing a culturally-relevant digital health tool. The program will utilize an approach of "centering" body signals, a cognitive behavioral strategy to better understand and respond to internal eating cues of hunger and satiety. The program's content and design will be informed by a formative process with Black obese women and their primary care providers (PCPs) to optimize engagement and retention in a 6-month study. Intervention Phase: The study will be in two phases: 12-week Feasibility Phase; 6-month Pilot Phase. Phase 1: Feasibility Phase. Aim 1. This formative feasibility phase will include up to 20 participants who, in Phase II, will be randomized to different study arms. Our goal is to recruit 660 Black women over 2 years for Phase 1. The recruitment method will be informed by the results of the formative phase. Aim 1a. Identify the barriers and facilitators to detecting and treating binge eating in Black women with obesity and identify strategies for optimizing digital health tools. Participants will complete individual interviews in Phase I. Interviews will identify strategies for enrolling, retaining and motivating Black women over 6 months and to refine the digital tool. Participants who demonstrate a satisfactory retention rate for Phase 1 (> 90%) will be eligible to participate in Phase II. Aim 1b. Modify and adapt a validated program to be a culturally-relevant digital health tool for binge eating and weight management for Black women.

The purpose of this study is to assess if dietary nitrate (NO3-) supplementation can enhance resistance exercise performance and muscle capacity to generate mechanical work. Specifically, we aim to investigate the effects of different levels of nitrate supplementation on the performance of a single set of heavy resistance exercise. We will explore two different modes of exercise: whole body (e.g., bench press, barbell back squat) and upper body (e.g., barbell bench press, preacher curls) resistance exercise. Investigators will collect data from 30 healthy, male recreational strength-trained individuals between the ages of 18 and 45. Participants will be invited into the study on four separate occasions (one per week), and will be provided (based on a computer-generated sequence) with four different beverages pre-exercise: 4 x 70 ml of nitrate-depleted beetroot juice shots for placebo (PL), 1 x 70 ml of nitrate-rich beetroot juice 3 x 70 ml nitrate-depleted beetroot juice shot for a low dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (BR-LOW; 6.5 mmol of nitrate total), 2 x 70 of nitrate-rich beetroot juice and 2 x 70ml of nitrate depleted beetroot juice shot for a moderate dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (BR-MOD; 13 mmol of nitrate total), and 4 x 70 ml of nitrate-rich beetroot juice for an elevated dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (BR-HIGH; 26 mmol of nitrate total). The 6 conditions will be presented in a fixed, counter-balanced order such that subjects will perform all 3 interventions in a crossover assignment in each muscle group.

Study Overview
=================
A total of 72 patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy will be included from December 2021 to April 2022. All patients recruited will be included in the study if they meet the inclusion criteria. Written and oral information will be obtained from the candidates to be included in the study. All candidates will be informed in writing again before the operation and the consent form will be signed by 2 people by the candidates.
Patients who are not volunteering will be excluded from the study before the operation. Patients who do not consent to the continuation of the study during the operation will be excluded. Patients with ASA 3-4 or patients who do not meet the other inclusion criteria will be excluded from the study. Patients with lung disease, other surgical procedures or anesthetic techniques, pregnant patients, and patients with morbid obesity who cannot tolerate surgery under general anesthesia or have contraindications to the study will be excluded from the study. Patients whose operation is determined to be converted from laparoscopic to laparotomy at any time for any reason after the incision is made will also be excluded. Data will be recorded from the electronic hospital record system. The records of all operations will be inspected and recorded in the study program. Anesthesia data in the operation chart of the patients will be used. If there are errors during data recording, these data will be re-evaluated by 2 experts in the surgical and anesthesia fields to correct the error again. Patients will be included in the groups after the insufflation pressure applied by the surgeon. The group where the insufflation pressure level is determined as 12 mmHg will be kept in group 12, and the group where the insufflation pressure level is determined by the surgeon as 14 mmHg will be kept in group 14. Mechanical power parameters of the patients will be measured using a pressure monitor (Puritan Bennett, Pennsylvania, USA) between December 2021-April 2022. Mechanical power values will be measured for 1 hour after the operation. Statistical power analysis has been performed to determine the number of patients to be included in the study. No statistically significant association was found between mean mechanical power and intraoperative complications in the study literature. In view of the results of the study, a sample size of 36 patients in each group was determined as appropriate to evaluate this relationship in cholecystectomy. The sample size in this study has been determined as sufficient to detect the difference in mechanical power between the 2 groups with at least 90% power at a significance level of 5%. The data recorded will be tabulated by SPSS 22.0. All data will be expressed in numbers, percentages, mean, median and standard deviation. Shapiro Wilk test will be used to evaluate data distribution in each section. Normally distributed data variables in the two groups will be compared using the independent or paired t-test (or Mann Whitney U test respectively). Non-normally distributed data variables; They will be evaluated with the chi-square test after testing the compliance of the data structure with the expected distribution with the Shapiro Wilk test. Correlation will be evaluated between variables in the normal distribution range. A p value below 0.05 will be considered statistically significant. The results obtained will be expressed in text, tables, and graphics in a clear and concise way. The results will be evaluated with statistical packages.

Official Title

Evaluation of the Effect of Two Different Intra-abdominal Pressure Applications on Mechanical Power in Cases Undergoing Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy

Background: Furcation involvement of molars in deep class restorations is a common finding in patients with deep class restorations. Radiographic assessment is the most recommended technique for evaluation of furcation involvement when CBCT is not the method of choice. MRI might be an acceptable alternative to CBCT. Purpose: The main goal of this prospective study is to assess the extent of horizontal and vertical bone loss determined by MRI compared with CBCT in molars with deep class restorations and furcation involvement. We also aim to assess the correlation between MRI and CBCT in the measurement of furcation involvement. Methods: 60 subjects will be included sequentially by the clinical periodontal research group of the Department of Periodontology of the University of Graz. Patients included in the study must have full bone coverage as measured by CBCT (<1.5 mm) in at least one first molar with a deep class II or III restorations and furcation involvement in the apical third (grade II or III, according to Hamp 1975). MRI will be performed with the subject sitting in a fully loaded MRI scanner and with a 3.0 T MRI device (Siemens MAGNETOM Verio, Erlangen, Germany). Data on alveolar bone loss will be extracted for the mesial and distal roots of each molar in both CBCT and MRI examinations. Results and conclusion: If MRI is shown to be an acceptable alternative to CBCT, then further research will be needed for an alternative, non-invasive method. This will be of clinical importance for dentists, since it avoids intra-oral ionization radiation used in CBCT and is cost-effective, compared to regular CBCT assessment. It will also contribute to the development of a new method for evaluation of furcation involvement..

Background: The objective of this clinical research is to evaluate the efficacy of two manual toothbrushes (CS 5460 and Oral-B 123) and two electric toothbrushes (DiamondClean 9000 Philips® and HydroSonic Easy Curaden®) when used daily by pregnant women over a 3-month period.
Objective: Assess the impact of the recommended brushing time (3 minutes minimum) of electric and manual toothbrushes on clinical parameters from baseline during pregnancy.
Methods: Randomized clinical comparative trial in parallel groups with controlled masking. Fifty-two women were recruited when they were in their first trimester of pregnancy and were randomly distributed into groups using sonic or manual toothbrushes or a combination of both. The initial evaluation is made at baseline (T1) and after 1 and 3 months (T2 and T3) by the principal investigator, independent of the randomization groups. The clinical parameters evaluated were: gingival bleeding (BI), number of sites with BI, gingival index (GI), plaque index (PI), clinical attachment (CAL), periodontal pocket (PTRPDEP), and Patient Satisfaction Score (PSS).
Intervention/Treatment: Participants at baseline were included in the trial in four experimental groups: Group 1 (n = 13), patients using a sonic toothbrush; Group 2 (n = 13), patients using manual with 5460 strands; Group 3 (n = 13), patients using manual toothbrush; Group 4 (n = 13), patients using two brushes during baseline.
Analysis: Qualitative and quantitative variables were presented by descriptive statistics: absolute and percentage frequency for qualitative variables; minimum, maximum, mean, median, and standard deviation for quantitative variables. An Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) was performed in the experimental groups, comparing changes from baseline in all parameters before and after treatment between the various groups.
Results: The mean plaque index before treatment (baseline) was similar between all experimental groups (PBS1 = 3.3±2.6; PBS2 = 3.3±2.6; PBS3 = 2.7±2.8; PBS4 = 3.4±2.7), except for the number of teeth (mean: PBS1 = 21.5±4.2; PBS2 = 21.4±4.7; PBS3 = 22.0±4.3; PBS4 = 21.4±4.6, p= 0.010). Over the evaluation period, there was a significant reduction in plaque (P < 0.0001) in all groups. However, no significant differences were observed between the groups using any toothbrush, the only difference being in the GI index with regard to the treatment performed (p= 0.000). The results of the study conclude that the two toothbrushes, sonic and hydrosonic, were as effective as the manual toothbrush to control gingival bleeding, gingival inflammation, and plaque control.
Ethical Considerations: This study is the direct result of the study of its investigators and a clear need to expand knowledge in this field, which was developed with the participation of the research group, taking into account the recommendations of the Declaration of Helsinki and the Research Ethics Board of Clínica São José of CIMO, Campinas, based on the National Law No. 7,194, of 17 December 1984 on the Registry of Clinical Trials, in force since August 18, 1986, in the state of São Paulo, Brazil.

Depression and anxiety disorders are pathological conditions associated with severe economic and social costs. While significant progress has been made in understanding its underlying pathophysiological mechanisms, very few molecular targets for drug development have emerged. Here we identify a number of signaling pathways linking integrin β3, Protocadherin-9 (Pcdh9) and dysfunctional synaptic circuitry in glutamatergic circuits in the brain.
In order to achieve this aim, the following study arms have been designed:
1) Patients with Anxious-Depressive Disorders (Anx-Depr.D) and healthy controls (HC) will be enrolled, and neurofunctional and neurochemical assessments will be conducted, including the measurement of excitatory synaptic markers using structural and functional MRI, 1H-MRS.
Excitatory neurotransmission is critical in the regulation of glutamatergic circuits in cognitive and emotional functions and a dysfunction in this type of transmission has been found in depression and anxiety.
In particular:
- structural brain imaging (e.g., T1-weighted) performed using a 7T-MRI will be used to study the volumetric differences in white and gray matter structures between HC and Anx-Depr.D subjects in the prefrontal-limbic pathway, the area most sensitive to depression and anxiety. This assessment is crucial as the Anx-Depr.D shows significant atrophy of white matter in this specific area, and this atrophy is more severe in patients who have also experienced suicide attempts
- functional brain imaging (e.g., fMRI) will be used to study the functional connectivity differences at rest and during task in the prefrontal-limbic pathway. Since this pathway is frequently impaired in both depression and anxiety disorders, this assessment will help to identify abnormal functional connections.
- proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS) will be performed to study the altered levels of glutamatergic neurotransmitters in the anterior cingulate and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, critical hubs in cognitive-emotional control.
These specific targets are of potential interest in the pathogenesis of depression. Moreover, they help to test the hypothesis that glutamate neurotransmission in the prefrontal-anterior cingulate circuit is altered in depression and anxiety.
2) Mice with Pcdh9 deficits will be investigated for changes in glutamatergic neurotransmission in the prefrontal-limbic pathway, comparing Pcdh9 KO (homozygotes) and control mice (wild type). Pcdh9 was not known to be involved in the regulation of glutamatergic synaptic transmission in the nervous system thus far, but it has a role in maintaining the integrity of synaptic connections in the brain, ensuring they are correctly targeted to and from the developing brain. In fact, it is known that Pcdh9 plays a critical role in controlling how cells communicate throughout the developing brain, by ensuring that neurons and other cell types remain connected to the right nearby structures. Abnormal Pcdh9 expression has been implicated in a number of developmental and neuropsychiatric disorders, such as lissencephaly, schizophrenia, Alzheimer's and Autism Spectrum disorders (ASD). Given the role of Pcdh9 in mediating synaptic connectivity, understanding the dysfunctional circuitry may provide new targets for drug development.
3) In a series of follow-up experiments, the investigators plan to study the interaction between integrin β3 and Protocadherin9 using co-immunoprecipitation analysis from murine brain. If a causal link is established between the two proteins, the investigators will proceed to study compensatory mechanisms of defective Pcdh9 activity in mice. They will assess whether overexpression of integrin β3 or Protocadherin9 compensates for defects in synaptic glutamatergic transmission caused by deficiencies in CAMs. In this case, experiments on murine models will be performed to determine whether overexpression of integrin β3 or protocadherin9 could compensate for defects in synaptic glutamatergic transmission caused by deficiencies in CAMs.
Finally, the investigators will undertake to establish an integrin β3/Protocadherin9 drug discovery program to identify novel compounds that restore glutamatergic syn

A microbial ecosystem is a complex community of interacting bacteria. The potential role of intestinal flora in human health has attracted extensive attention. Imbalances in the gut microbiome have been implicated in a variety of chronic diseases. Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) are the leading cause of morbidity worldwide and are influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. Recent advances have provided scientific evidence that cardiovascular disease may also be attributable to gut microbiota. In many literatures, we have found complex interactions between microorganisms, their metabolites, and potential impacts on the development and progression of cardiovascular disease. The use of intestinal flora in the treatment of cardiovascular diseases is the latest research direction. Gut microbes are likely to be used in the clinical treatment of cardiovascular diseases in the near future.
Gut flora plays an important role in human health and disease transformation. It not only participates in many physiological processes of the host, but also affects the function of the central nervous system (CNS) through the activity of the microbiota - gut - brain axis, which may be closely related to neurotransmitter, immune, endocrine and metabolite pathways. When the intestinal flora is dysfunctional, it can affect the occurrence and development of CNS diseases such as cerebral ischemia, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, multiple sclerosis, hepatic encephalopathy and mental disorders.
Fecal microbial transplantation, exercise training, acupuncture and massage and other therapies can improve intestinal flora disorders, and are expected to become effective measures to treat and prevent some nervous system diseases.
Based on a comprehensive understanding of the microbiome involved in cardiovascular and neurological diseases, explore the relationship between cardiovascular and neurological diseases and intestinal microbiome through clinical sample collection, sequencing technology and machine learning analysis, to provide a new theoretical basis for the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular and neurological diseases.

Pembrolizumab has been approved for first-line locally advanced or metastatic NSCLC with a tumor proportion score (TPS) ≥50% for PDL1, based on the results of KEYNOTE-024. However, even with a positive PDL1 status, only a fraction of patients respond to immunotherapy. In the KEYNOTE-024 study evaluating pembrolizumab versus chemotherapy in first-line advanced NSCLC with PDL1 TPS ≥50%, the response rate in the pembrolizumab arm alone was 45%. This result led to the approval of pembrolizumab for first-line advanced NSCLC with PDL1 TPS ≥ 50%, which nevertheless represents only 22% of patients with stage IIIB/IV NSCLC. Early identification of biomarkers for patients unlikely to benefit from first-line pembrolizumab is therefore a crucial step in selecting suitable candidates. Furthermore, in cancer, genomic alterations in NFE2L2, KEAP1 and CUL3 result in constitutive activation of NRF2-dependent gene transcription, which promotes cellular resistance to oxidative stress, xenobiotic efflux, proliferation and metabolic reprogramming. Somatic mutations in NFE2L2 and KEAP1 are found in 3.5-15% and 12-17% of NSCLC patients respectively. NFE2L2 is a transcription factor that directs the expression of free radical defense genes that may interfere with radiation-induced DNA damage. KEAP1 is an adaptor protein that targets NFE2L2 for ubiquitination and proteasomal destruction as part of normal homeostasis. These new biomarkers are of clinical interest, as KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutations predict radiation resistance in patients with localized NSCLC treated with radiotherapy but not surgery. Some data also suggest a role for the KEAP1/NFE2L2 axis in response to immunotherapy. Establishing a predictive model for the presence of the KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutation would provide a tool for predicting survival (progression-free and overall), even before the patient starts immunotherapy.

Prognostic Value of Combined Approach Based on KEAP1/NFE2L2 Mutations and Pre-therapeutic FDG-PET/CT Radiomic Analysis in Advanced Non-small-cell Lung Cancer PDL1 ≥ 50% Treated With Pembrolizumab.

Thus, the following hypotheses will be tested: Hypothesis 1: Differences will not be found before and after application of the PNF protocol in relation to the drop jump test in professional padel players. Hypothesis 2: Proprioception protocol for ankle dorsiflexion of the PNF improves ankle dorsiflexion range, drop jump test variables and neuromuscular recruitment pattern than the eccentric exercise protocol with electrical stimulation in professional padel players. Hypothesis 3: Differences will be found before and after application of the PNF protocol with the application of the eccentric exercises and electrical stimulation protocol in relation to the drop jump test variables and neuromuscular recruitment pattern of the lower limbs, during the eccentric exercise phase and during the concentric exercise phase. Hypothesis 4: Differences will be found before and after application of the eccentric exercise protocol with the application of the PNF protocol, in the variables of the drop jump test variables and neuromuscular recruitment pattern of the lower limbs, during the eccentric exercise phase and during the concentric exercise phase. For this purpose, a pretest-post-test design and a randomized clinical trial with two parallel-groups were designed, each group receiving one of the following treatments: group 1: Proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation group: Proprioception protocol for ankle dorsiflexion. The purpose of this study is to assess the effectiveness of dietary counselling promoting adherence to the Mediterranean Diet, as an adjuvant treatment of Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) in patients with elevated inflammation biomarkers (CRP, IL-6). To do this, individuals diagnosed with MDD, with elevated inflammatory biomarkers, are randomised to treatment as usual (TAU) for MDD or treatment as usual (TAU) for MDD plus intervention with 6 counselling sessions with a registered nutritionist promoting adherence to the Mediterranean Diet. The study hypothesizes that this intervention can decrease depressive symptoms in adults patients diagnosed with MDD and having elevated inflammatory biomarkers. Specific objectives are: 1.To assess the effectiveness of dietary counselling promoting MedDiet, as an adjuvant treatment of MDD, to decrease depressive symptoms in adults diagnosed with MDD and having elevated inflammation biomarkers (CRP, IL-6). 2.To assess the association between adherence to MedDiet and changes in inflammatory biomarkers. 3.To assess the association between changes in inflammatory biomarkers with symptoms of MDD. 4.To evaluate the association between adherence to MedDiet and effectiveness of psychiatric treatment of MDD. 5.To characterize the association between adherence to MedDiet and changes in health-related quality of life. 6.To evaluate the economic cost-effectiveness of dietary counselling, as an adjuvant treatment in MDD.

In the United States and internationally, refugees are one of the fastest growing demographic groups. In Mexico, tens of thousands of refugees arrived after December 2018, when the previous US administration began the "return-to-Mexico" policy that separated thousands of families. While this policy was temporary, Mexican families continue to arrive to the Tijuana/San Diego border in high numbers. Many stay in large shelters, awaiting adjudication of refugee claims by Mexican authorities. A unique opportunity exists to intervene during the shelter stay to promote parenting skills and strengthen family relationships and overall well-being. While stressors on parents in refugee shelters have been identified in previous research, no studies address effective interventions to address these challenges. This research is proposed to fill these gaps by creating an innovative and culturally-sensitive learning curriculum to build parenting skills in refugee families facing the challenges of the border environment. By involving the host community directly, this approach will enable parents to learn and practice important skills that lead to more positive parent-child interactions, as well as child behaviors and fewer signs of parental stress. Participating mothers, fathers, and children can learn together while also promoting community and culture within the shelter. The aim of this study is to test the effectiveness of teaching parenting skills to refugee families and to involve the larger host community in promoting these skills. This proposed investigation has 4 specific goals: to work with parents and community stakeholders in shelter settings to identify the most important parenting skills that they want for their children. These skills will be prioritized into a concise curriculum. To facilitate the delivery of the curriculum through a learning-by-observing model (LOPI), which increases feelings of ownership and efficacy. To test the effectiveness of this curriculum of parenting skills in improving parent-child interactions and reducing signs of parenting stress compared to a control group waiting to receive the intervention while providing a handout on basic parenting skills. To demonstrate, through qualitative analysis, that parenting skills learned in the shelters may be applicable to life post-shelter after refugees cross the US border. This research proposal presents a framework for adapting parenting interventions for refugee-origin families and involves all groups of people in the shelter in identifying the most important needs and learning together in a supportive community setting. The proposed curriculum aims to be accessible, culturally and linguistically sensitive, and effective in promoting the highest quality care for children of refugee families. This research has the potential to contribute to the development of a community-oriented mental health program that will impact a growing population of refugees awaiting asylum in Mexico.

The main objective of this study is to identify areas for improvement in the health care experiences of those with incurable HNC (head and neck cancer). It is estimated that around 2,500 people a year (up to10 per week) in the North of England are diagnosed with incurable head and neck cancer. The study will be involving both patients/family carers and health care professionals (HCP) in an innovative two-phase process to generate views and opinions about what can be done to improve things for those involved in caring for or having incurable head and neck cancer. By adopting the participatory action research approach throughout all phases of the project we hope to achieve an active partnership between patients/family carers and HCP to provide innovative, creative solutions for improvement. In Phase 1 we are involving patients and family carers through longitudinal qualitative interviews at 4-month intervals following a sampling strategy of purposive maximum variation sampling. All interviews will be conducted via telephone call, video call or online written interviews.

In Phase 2, co-design workshops were be developed using findings from the initial interviews. These workshops will involve patients/family carers and HCP, and aim to identify and prioritise 'stress-points' in the system, where things need to be improved, and generate initial ideas for solutions.

Interviews with patients and family carers will be conducted by an experienced and accredited qualitative interviewer (Dr Emily Mayland). Patients will be approached through a variety of settings and will be recruited in order to ensure a diversity of experiences are captured. Focus Groups with HCP will be facilitated by a multidisciplinary team involving at least 5 HCPs (consultant surgeon, consultant oncologist, clinical nurse specialist, palliative care specialist, allied health professional e.g. dietician, speech and language therapist and specialist nurse). These meetings will be supported by experienced qualitative researchers at the University of Sheffield.

The co-design approach will involve a variety of stakeholders including those with lived experience (patients and family carers) and those who work clinically with or commission services for those with incurable HNC (clinicians, commissioners and service leads) and members of the wider public. This study will use a variety of methods including long term qualitative interviewing and focus groups to provide a comprehensive understanding of the experiences of people with incurable head and neck cancer and the perspectives of health care professionals. This study has been approved by the University of Sheffield Risk Assessment and Ethics Committee (approval number: 6514). It is an important element of our research programme funded by Yorkshire Cancer Research. This study can help improve the quality of life for a large number of individuals with head and neck cancer, their families and also provide guidance for health care decisions.

Endoscopic spinal surgery has become one of the leading minimally invasive surgical methods with rapid recovery, small trauma and fewer complications. Endoscopic spinal surgery is the nerve root decompression based on the preservation of the posterior ligament complex. The accuracy of nerve root identification and protection is of great importance. In response to the increasing attention of minimally invasive spinal surgery, this project will evaluate the clinical application value of near-infrared fluorescence imaging of indocyanine green in the identification of nerve roots in endoscopic spinal surgery.
Fluorescence imaging based on indocyanine green can provide high sensitivity and specificity assistance to the surgeon in identifying the spinal nerve roots. The main factors influencing this process are fluorescence imaging rate of nerve roots, fluorescence imaging time and ICG-related adverse reactions.
This project conducts a prospective randomized clinical study on 90 patients with lumbar disc herniation requiring endoscopic spinal surgery. 
The patients are divided into 1 mg/kg ICG group, 2 mg/kg ICG group, 0.5 mg/kg ICG group and control group(without intervention). The primary evaluation indicators are: the fluorescence imaging rate of nerve roots, the fluorescence imaging signal ratio of nerve root endoscopically, the time taken to find the nerve root endoscopically. The secondary evaluation indicators include: operation-related factors such as imaging method time, amount of bleeding, degree of nerve root protection, visual analogue pain scale, Oswestry disability index and surgical complications. At the same time, 30 patients of the 90 patients in the 1 mg/kg ICG group, 2 mg/kg ICG group are selected and divided into three groups to evaluate safety indexes such as adverse events of ICG.
We hope that this project can provide reliable and effective clinical guidance for the application of indocyanine green fluorescence near-infrared imaging in endoscopic spinal surgery, improving the accuracy of nerve root protection and minimizing surgical risks.

Background: Children with IDDs and their parents often experience social isolation, financial problems, and an increased chance of becoming a victim of child abuse or neglect. Parents who are not well supported could also have low self-esteem that negatively affect how they feel about their parenting abilities. Social services have a duty to identify and provide support for parents when they experience these difficulties. There are several structured evidence-based training programs, but they are mostly delivered in small groups or in the community and they often lack focus on individualized care for families or on practical skills such as household safety. Further, there is an underreported risk for neglect and abuse of young children with IDDs, but structured training programs for supporting those parents are yet to be fully tested. The intervention: For this study, we want to develop a parenting program that has been found to be effective, but that can be delivered in a practical approach suitable for parents with IDDs. The program should be adapted to specific parenting needs and should be provided in the home. The intervention includes support in both practical household tasks as well as skills development in caregiving, based on child's needs, and in parenting skills such as responsiveness and playful engagement with the child. 
Objective: The main objective of the study is to develop a practical home-based training program for parents with intellectual and developmental disabilities, and to evaluate its effect on parental confidence in caregiving and on child wellbeing. We aim to adapt and individualize the program. We will also measure the effects of the intervention compared to treatment as usually provided.
Method: Parents who have children aged 0-6 years living in their own home and who are assessed as in need of individualized care, are included in the study. Each participating parent will be coached and supported to complete structured training tasks, as well as providing data regarding child wellbeing and parent feelings about their own parenting abilities.

This is a research study involving 11 participants with malignancies in the pancreas, lungs and bowels. These subjects will have 68Ga NOTA-H006 intravenous injection to the arm. Images will be obtained by PET/CT (two examinations at least 4 hours apart) within 1 day. Based on the SUVmax of the lesions in the PET scan, we will compare the imaging results with the corresponding pathological specimens (imaging lesions biopsied or surgically resected) and compare the difference. In this way, the investigators will further understand the expression of 5T4 in subjects with these malignancies and the effectiveness of 68Ga-NOTA-H006 in imaging. This study may provide new ideas for the non-invasive diagnosis of tumors.

Heart failure is a common disease with high morbidity and mortality. There are different treatments available and all have a limited effect on reducing heart failure related events and improving survival. Resynchronization therapy, CRT, is a pacemaker with two extra electrodes that stimulates both left and right ventricle simultaneously. A subset of patients respond to CRT with improved heart function, health status and survival. In order to select the best patients for CRT and optimize the treatment, we have started to collect blood samples, heart tissue and clinical data from heart failure patients eligible for CRT and a control group of heart failure patients on medical therapy. Patients will be assessed before CRT implantation and at 3, 6 and 12 months. The samples are stored in the KUHT biobank (Swemno 2012-027) and used for different studies including proteomic and molecular studies in the heart tissue, exosomal miRNAs in blood and analysis of red blood cells. The data collected will be used to increase our knowledge of the mechanisms behind heart failure and resynchronization therapy and to identify biomarkers that could help select patients likely to respond to CRT.
In a subgroup of study eligible patients, a heart biopsy will be performed before CRT to study the biological differences between patients that respond to resynchronization therapy and patients that do not. After a study period of 2-3 years, all the collected data will be analysed and published in different articles from the study.

Heart failure (HF) with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is a chronic progressive disease and currently has no cure. The guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) is the current first-line treatment for patients with HFrEF. The majority of patients with HF are tolerable to all the medications recommended in GDMT. For patients who are intolerable for GDMT, the clinical value of the medications is not well documented. In addition, there is no guideline for the treatment of intolerable patients. This study aims to determine the prognosis of HF patients who are intolerable to GDMT and propose a treatment strategy for these patients. We will include 200 patients with HFrEF and follow-up them for 180 days. The outcome endpoints are all-cause death or worsening heart failure, change of symptoms and signs of heart failure, and changes of Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction (LVEF), Left Ventricular End-Systolic Dimension (LVESD), Left Ventricular End-diastolic Diameter (LVEDD), Left Ventricular Fractional Shortening (LVFS) and N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) level from baseline to endpoint. This study will provide evidence for treatment strategies of patients who are tolerable or intolerable to GDMT.

This will be a cross-sectional prospective study. Potentially eligible patients will be identified by members of the ESC team and will be informed about the study. Interested patients will then discuss the study with the research team and will be invited to participate. After informed consent has been obtained, participants will complete a questionnaire which will cover their level of prognostic awareness, psychological symptoms, and quality of life). The questionnaire will take approximately 20 minutes to complete. The questionnaire can be completed online via RedCap. Endpoints: The primary endpoint of this study is the level of patients' prognostic awareness, which will be assessed by the Prognosis and Treatment Perception Questionnaire. This questionnaire has previously been successfully used in research to assess patients' information preferences, perceptions about their prognosis and the goals of therapy and communication preferences about end-of-life care. Secondary endpoints will be (a) patients' preferences for receiving prognostic information assessed through the Prognosis and Treatment Perception Questionnaire (b) symptoms of depression evaluated through the Patient Health Questionnaire-2 (PHQ-2), (c) symptoms of anxiety evaluated through the Generalized Anxiety Disorder 2-item (GAD-2), (d) quality of life and (d) patients' trust in their medical team and (e) other aspects of perceived quality of care, rated on a visual analogue scale (NRS) from 0-10. Sample size and statistics: The investigators will conduct univariable and multivariable regression analyses to evaluate associations between sociodemographic or clinical variables and outcomes. The investigators aim to include 100 patients. This will give us at least 10 degrees of freedom to assess association of potential risk factors with outcome and to evaluate confounders in a multivariable analysis. Discussion: This will be the first prospective study to assess prognostic awareness among cancer patients referred to ESC services in a British setting. Identifying covariates for prognostic unawareness and psychological burden among patients with advanced cancer will inform the future development of strategies to improve care and communication with this patient group.

<|assistant|> Arterial hypertension remains one of the most important risk factors in developing a cardiovascular disease. Medical treatment is usually necessary, lifestyle modifications should always be included. Besides physical activity and a balanced diet, there are also therapeutic approaches from the so called classical complementary medicine. One very important part in Europe is hydrotherapy, based on ideas of Sebastian Kneipp and his contemporaries. In hydrotherapy there are various therapeutic approaches that can be used additionally to conventional therapy. Because conventional medical therapy is often associated with unwanted side effects, these additional approaches experience increasing popularity. In arterial hypertension, temperature-elevating armbaths, developed by Kneipps contemporaries Hauffe and Schwenninger, are a hydrotherapeutic approach that is highly recommended. Even though hydrotherapy has been a part of complementary medicine for more than a century now some therapeutic approaches lack of scientific evidence - especially when it comes to their effect on arterial hypertension. This randomized-controlled trial aims to evaluate the effect of a temperature-elevating armbath among participants with arterial hypertension. 50 participants will be randomized to either an intervention group or waitlist (treatment as usual). All 50 participants will be monitored with three 24-hours ambulatory blood pressure measurements (24h ABPM) at the beginning of the trial after randomization, at 8 weeks and at 6 months. The intervention group will be advised to perform the armbaths on 5 of 7 days per week for 8 weeks total. Each participant will get a detailed instruction how to perform the armbath and will be handed a diary to document their performance. After 6 months, each participant of the control group will be offered to be instructed on performing the armbaths as well. Within the active period of 8 weeks, participants of both groups will be called regularly to ask about their health and whether they have questions regarding the trial. This study aims to measure and compare the effects of acupuncture or mindfulness on perceived stress and health in military service members and veterans. The study will recruit 21 participants who have a perceived stress score (PSS) ≥ 16, no change in psychiatric and other medications for 3 months, and are willing to participate in group psychotherapy including MBSR. The intervention will consist of four weekly group sessions of Manual Standardized Stress Acupuncture (MSSA) and Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) via Microsoft Teams. The acupuncture will include Auricular (ear) shen men, GV- 20, GV-24.5 (Yin Tang), Bilateral LI-4 (Hegu), and Bilateral LR-3 (Taichong) for 30 minutes per session. MBSR will consist of four 90-minute group sessions followed by three 60-minute weekly sessions. The PSS will be measured using a scale range from 0 to 56 with higher scores indicating higher stress (PSS ≥ 16). The participants will also be measured for Insomnia Severity Index (ISI) and The Short Form (SF) Health Survey. A journal entry will include questions about the perceived benefits of treatment at weeks 2 and 4 after treatments have been completed.

This randomized clinical trial is considered to be the first study that compared the effect of a circumferential and a sectional matrix on tightness of proximal contacts in Class 2 restorations. 62 patients, with compound class 2 cavities (31 teeth- 16 in each group) will be recruited and they will be randomly selected to receive restoration using the sectional matrix.
                Local anesthesia will be administrated, and the whole quadrant containing the offending tooth will be isolated by using a rubber dam. A proper sized wedge will be used to avoid the gingival overhangs. Restorations will be completed according to the manufacturer's instructions. Flossing and a probe will be applied to evaluate and classify the tightness of the proximal contacts after finishing and polishing. Tooth with good general health will be included. Each patient will be selected from patients seeking treatment from the periodontal department of Cairo University. Examination of periodontal and caries status will be done. All restorations in this research will be done by one experienced clinician (S.M.). Tightness of proximal contacts will be evaluated using dental floss. Proximal contact points will be categorized as optimum, open, and tight; if the dental floss passed through the contact area the contact point will be considered optimum. Open contact points will be considered when the dental floss passed through the contact area without resistance. The duration of flossing is less than 5 seconds, according to the FDI recommendations.
                Sample size calculation was based on 80% power and alpha error 0.05 using a software program (Gpower, 2014). Assuming a difference of 0.05 for categorizing tightness of contacts between systems, an effect size of 1.18. 28 cases in each group are required. After a 10% drop out ratio, each group will include 62 cases. Comparison of intergroup difference in tightness of the proximal contacts will be done by using McNemar's test. The significance level is P<0.05.
                The obtained result will help the clinician to choose the best matrix which results in optimum tightness of proximal contact points in Class 2 restorations, leading to longer life span of composite resin restorations..
                The aim of the present study to be the first study comparing the effect of a circumferential and a sectional matrix on tightness of proximal contact in Class II restorations. This study will be the first to report a significant difference in tightness of proximal contacts between the two systems. This study is important for the dental profession because it will provide the evidence base to the clinician in order to choose the optimum matrix for optimum tightness of proximal contacts. Additionally, it adds up to the literature by highlighting the effect of matrix systems on tightness of proximal contacts.

This study seeks to find out whether a pay for performance program can provide more help at a lower cost to frequent users of acute psychiatric services. The purpose is to evaluate whether a pay for performance program, that includes both performance incentives and intensive treatment, can reduce the use of emergency, inpatient, and other high-cost services by persons with severe and persistent mental illness.
The intervention or treatment is an approach that includes intensive case management, individualized assessment and skill building, rehabilitation in the community, peer support, crisis intervention and crisis support, treatment for co-occurring disorders, psychiatric medications, and hospital based care. There are also two financial incentives for providers. The first requires providers to meet certain performance targets by reducing the use of high cost services, with monetary incentives in the form of an 8% bonus if targets are met and a 7% penalty if they are not. The second is a capitated payment system that gives providers a flat amount of money for each client enrolled, but the providers are only paid if clients actually use the services that they pay for.
There was a three-year study period that included an 8-month enrollment period and two years of outcome measures collection. We randomly assigned 114 eligible patients on a 4 to 1 basis to either the pay for performance program or to traditional mental health and psychosocial services, and then followed them over two years. At each follow-up period, we assessed use of emergency services, psychiatric and crisis services, residential care, correctional facility services and other costly programs and services. We also asked a smaller group of participants about their satisfaction with treatment. Finally, we interviewed pay for performance providers and County contract monitors about their experiences with the program.

The trial is designed to assess the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of Culturally adapted Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CaCBT) and Culturally adapted Family Intervention (CulFI) compared to Treatment as Usual (TAU) in reducing overall symptoms of psychosis in individuals with FEP in Pakistan. Participants in CaCBT and CulFI group will receive a 10-weekly and 12-weekly sessions respectively. The primary aims are to 1) estimate the clinical efficacy of the proposed interventions, and 2) examine the health and economic effects of the interventions compared to treatment as usual (TAU) in the local context. The trial will recruit 390 participants at 10 centres of Pakistan. Participants fulfilling DSM-5 criteria for one of the clinical syndromes for schizophrenia, schizophreniform or schizoaffective disorder will be randomised to participate in the trial. Participants randomised in the CaCBT group will be given 12 additional one-to-one sessions; those randomised to the CulFI group will be given an additional 10 additional one-to-one sessions. Intervened group sessions will be conducted via secure video conference. Participants will be given face-to-face sessions. Follow-up assessments will be done at 3 months (baseline) and 6 months. Treatment fidelity and compliance will be assessed every 4 weeks to ensure adherence.

Background: Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR)-modified cell therapies are rapidly emerging as a promising approach for the treatment of relapsed and refractory B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), including Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) and transformed follicular lymphoma (TFL).
While CAR-T cells targeting CD19 represent a significant improvement in therapeutic options for patients with R/R aggressive B-cell NHLs, CAR-T cells targeting B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) which target the CD22 antigen, show even better treatment results. The CD20 antigen is also a valuable surface marker for anti-cancer therapy. CD20 has a high degree of target saturation on the surface of virtually all B-cell lymphomas, even at non-pathological or benign disease stages, including chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Unlike CD19, CD20 is not a cancer-specific marker, but it is very well expressed on the surface of cells. Based on extensive pre-clinical evaluation of bispecific anti-CD19/20 CAR-T cell clones with excellent in in-vitro and in vivo anti-tumor activity, I-Mab has developed a CD19/20 bispecific CAR-T cell product, IMPT-314.
Objectives: This study is designed as a dose finding Phase I/II clinical trial with an expansion phase. The purpose of Phase I is to evaluate the safety of IMPT-314 in a first-inhuman study in adult R/R B-cell aggressive NHL patients and to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of IMPT-314 based on the incidence of dose limiting toxicities (DLTs). The primary objectives of Phase II are to confirm the dose level determined in Phase I, to evaluate the complete response (CR) rate and to estimate the safety of the chosen dose level (either MTD or the highest tolerated dose).
Design: Phase I consists of 2 parts. In Part A a conventional 3+3 design is applied. The MTD of IMPT-314 in adult R/R B-cell aggressive NHL patients will be determined based on the number of participants experiencing dose limiting toxicity (DLTs) within the first 28 days after infusion of IMPT-314. In Part B a response-adapted design is used. Cohort A consists of CAR-naïve patients enrolled at the determined MTD. Cohort B consists of CAR-experienced patients enrolled at the determined MTD.
The Phase II part consists of patients with relapsed/refractory aggressive B-cell NHL who already initiated the study in the expansion phase of Part B. The primary objectives are to confirm the MTD of IMPT-314 established in Phase I, to evaluate the CR rate and to evaluate the safety of the IMPT-314 cohort in the expansion phase of Phase I.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase 1/2 Multi-center Study Evaluating the Safety and Efficacy of IMPT-314, a CD19/20 Bispecific Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) T Cell Therapy in Participants With Relapsed or Refractory Aggressive B-Cell Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma

Conditions
-----------------
Relapsed Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma, Refractory Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma

The purpose of this study is to understand if and how a brief digital intervention can increase vaccine uptake among adults with anxiety or depressive symptoms. We will recruit undervaccinated participants with and without symptoms of anxiety or depression from the CHASING COVID Cohort and randomly assign them to: 1) an attitudinal inoculation intervention; 2), a CBT-informed intervention; or 3) a conventional public health messaging intervention without attitudinal inoculation or CBT-informed content. The participants will be divided into three groups based on the intervention arm they fall into. We will measure vaccine uptake at four weeks and six months post-intervention and will test the effectiveness of the interventions through intent-to-treat comparisons within the study arms.

<|assistant|> Chronic sleep disturbance or poor sleep quality is a common problem in long-term care institutions. However, few interventions have been examined to alleviate the problem. A possible solution, binaural beats (BBs), is a music technology embedded with an audio signal that stimulates brainwaves to produce a relaxing and stress-reducing state. To test the efficacy of BBs in improving sleep quality, depression, heart rate variab;ity (HRV) among older adults with poor sleep quality, a randomised controlled trial was conducted. The participants were screened from older persons, aged 65 and above, in a long-term care institution in Taiwan. A total of 34 participants (age: 65-89, Hz: 15-20) were randomly assigned into BBM group or control group, with approximately matching of age, gender, marital status, and number of visits from family. The BBM group listened to BB music for 20 min and control group listened to the same music without BB for 20 min in three sessions (Monday to Friday) for 2 weeks. The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) and Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS) were used to evaluate sleep quality and depression status, while the HRV analyzer was used to calculate the five markers of HRV. Comparing with the control group, participants in the BBM group showed significant improvement in the total score and seven markers of PSQI, except its subjective item. Besides, the BBM group reported significantly higher depression scores than control group after the two-week intervention. No significant difference of HRV was found between the two groups. This study indicates that listening to BBM music for 20 min thrice a week for two weeks improves sleep quality and self-reported depressive symptoms of older persons with poor sleep quality, however, it does not reduce the actual depressive status in them. Thus, BBM music may be an effective and safe music-therapy intervention in the management of sleep quality in long-term care institutions. To our knowledge, this is the first study that combines the BBM and familiar music in a long run, and examines its effects on sleep quality, HRV, and depressive status among older persons in a long-term care institution. Inclusion criteria: Inclusion criteria were participants who: were aged 65 years and older, had a PSQI score> 7, were able to understand questionnaire contents and communicate in Mandarin or Taiwanese Hokkien, stayed in institution for 1 month and more, and did not receive antidepressant within 3 months prior to and during the intervention. Exclusion Criteria: Exclusion criteria were those with hearing loss, history of bipolar disorder or schizophrenia diagnosed by a physician, and had an acute physiological disease, such as cold, fracture, or trauma. The study aims to develop an understanding of the barriers and facilitators of a high level of fidelity that is sustainable for use by patients and health care providers. It is a mixed methods implementation science study that aims to personalise follow-up for patients with a high risk of recurrence of a head and neck cancer. Central to the construct of ethical research is the prevention of harm, informed consent, and voluntary participation. Participant demographics, treatments, and clinical condition will be purposively sampled for qualitative interviews to provide a range of patient and service provide perspectives. The study will also involve patient and public involvement (PPI) to provide valuable feedback and ensure the findings are relevant to study participants. Patient surveys, service provider surveys, and interviews will be conducted to evaluate patient experience within the personalised follow-up pathway, acceptability to service providers, and sustainability. The study will also examine the safety and feasibility of the pathway by monitoring any recurrences of cancers and any new cancers developed by these patients.

Maternal and fetal well-being is an indispensable requirement for the safe and efficacious conduct of surgery around the puerperium. In recent years, regional anaesthesia (RA) is associated with increasing safety, especially in the obstetric population.
Many drugs were used in RA to combine the anxiolytic, sedative and antidepressant effects with the analgesic effect of local anaesthetics (LA), to improve their quality and safety.
The most widely used agent for this combination is a non-selective, α2 adrenergic receptor agonist, dexmedetomidine (DXM).
Clinical studies on neuro-physiological block characteristics of intrathecal dexmedetomidine with bupivacaine after caesarean section, has not been reported in the English literature.
The objectives of this study are to compare DXM with neostigmine. This comparison will assess the effect on neuro-physiological block characteristics between the DXM anesthesia group and the neostigmine group. Assessments of the onset and duration of sensory and motor anesthesia, quality of operative field, maternal satisfaction and pain scores were also determined.
Patients will be randomized to group 1 which will be receiving 10 μg intrathecal DXM, Group 2 will be receiving 50 μg intrathecal Neostigmine as an adjuvant to hyperbaric bupivacaine. and Group 3 will be receiving hyperbaric bupivacaine as a control group.
DXM, a nonselective, α2 adrenergic receptor agonist, is a potent sympatholytic and it has sedative, anxiolytic and analgesic effects. The sympatholytic action of DXM has positive effects on hemodynamics. The incidence of hypotension in patients receiving DXM anesthesia has been significantly reduced.
Neostigmine is an indirect cholinomimetic agent which acts as an antagonist of the enzyme acetylcholinesterase. Neostigmine is a reversible competitive inhibitor for AChE. It combines reversibly with AChE by the formation of an ester link between the carbonyl group of neostigmine and the ester site on the AChE molecule. The carbonyl group in the neostigmine molecule is attacked by a serine residue on AChE, breaking the ester bond, but only in the presence of ACh, which provides another moiety which can combine with the AChE molecule, thus displacing the ACh-enzyme complex. At doses of neostigmine routinely used as a neuromuscular blocking agent, the duration of effect is short because of rapid hydrolysis of neostigmine by AChE.
In addition, patients and attending anesthetist will be assessed for the onset, duration of sensory and motor block, quality of operative field, maternal satisfaction measured by visual analogue scale (VAS) and post-operative pain scores measured by the same VAS.
Intra-operative hemodynamic monitoring will include heart rate (HR) (beat per minute [bpm]), non-invasive blood pressure (NIBP ) (mean arterial pressure (MAP) ) and pulse oximetry (SpO2) will be also monitored.
At the end of surgery, 25 mg Metoclopramid ® will be administered to the spinal anesthetized patients to assess the post operative nausea and vomiting (PONV) incidence.
It is very important to compare these two adjuvants to bupivacaine to detect their role in improving sensory and motor block, quality of visual field and maternal satisfaction. As the anxiolytic, antidepressant, analgesic efficacy and physiological profile are different the aim of this study is to know which adjuvant can be used safely, easily and better.
                This study will be carried out as a double-mask prospective randomized study. It will take place in the Department of Anaesthesia. The patient's age will be between 18 to 40 years old. The patient's physical condition is American Association of Anesthesiologists (ASA) I and II, and patients with ASA III and high risk will be excluded from the study.
