The mouth is a unique microbial biofilm, and its composition is very much affected by tooth brushing. The effectiveness of tooth brushing relies on the efficiency of mechanical control by the toothbrush on pathogenic bacteria, and a high level of plaque accumulation has been associated with poor oral health and periodontitis. The majority of patients undergoing orthodontic treatment will develop plaque accumulation and gingivitis due to difficulty to brush teeth with fixed braces, and dental plaque and biofilm accumulation can induce significant problems for patients and practitioners during orthodontic treatment. Indeed, gingivitis is the most common oral problem in patients with fixed orthodontic appliances, and its resolution is important for better acceptance of fixed appliances. Additionally, the gingival crevicular fluid is enriched with bacteria and inflammatory markers which will contribute for worsen of the gingiviitis.
In order to assess the efficacy of a new oral care system (Air-Flow) on the incidence of gingivitis, the plaque accumulation and the levels of dental biofilm, gingivitis, plaque accumulation and the levels of biofilm, the host response during orthodontic treatment with fixed braces in patients under 18 years old.
The aim of this study is 1) the evaluation of the effectiveness of the air-polishing system with erythritol in controlling gingivitis and plaque accumulation during orthodontic treatment with fixed braces.
The hypothesis: The null hypothesis tested is that there is no difference between the air-polishing device and the conventional ultrasonic device in preventing WSLs and gingivitis during orthodontic treatment.

Inclusion criteria: Inclusion Criteria: Subjects about to undergo fixed orthodontic treatment will be invited to participate. Age between 12 and 16 years only participants Informed written consent obtained by the parents Exclusion Criteria: Clinically significant concomitant disease states (e.g., renal failure, hepatic dysfunction, cardiovascular disease, etc.), Known or suspected non-compliance, drug or alcohol abuse Inability to follow the procedures of the investigation, e.g. due to language problems, psychological disorders, dementia, etc. of the subject Participation in another investigation with an investigational drug or another MD within the 30 days preceding and during the present investigation Previous enrolment into the current investigation Enrolment of the PI, his/her family members, employees and other dependent persons History of fixed orthodontic treatment Defects on enamel on labial surfaces of the teeth Untreated cavitated lesions Plaque levels >25% Periodontitis Multiple missing teeth Cleft lip and/or palate or other craniofacial anomalies or syndromes Patients taking any regular medication Patients with asthmatic problems.

Focal tissue fibrosis is a dominant characteristic of atrial scar tissue, and key to atrial arrhythmias like atrial fibrillation. It is also present in pulmonary veins and in fibrotic remodelling after myocardial infarction.
Our group has experience in the study of atrial fibrosis, including in relation to different causes of atrial fibrosis. We have discovered new mechanisms by which atrial fibrosis occurs and new pathways by which atrial fibrosis promotes electrical and mechanical abnormalities that underlie AF and other atrial arrhythmias, and cardiac failure.
We now have the opportunity to examine tissue that contains atrial fibrosis and the characteristic atrial driver regions from clinical settings in the field of Thoracic surgery and cardiac surgery. We will study these human atrial tissues, using methods that examine the molecular phenotypes. This pilot study will be the first study to do this.

Parent-based language intervention in early childhood with severe or global developmental delay: a randomized controlled trial with an assessment point at school age.
Background: Children with severe or global developmental delay (DLD) often experience deficits in language development with potential consequences for their later academic, social, and vocational functioning. The current lack of long-term efficacy studies and inconsistently demonstrated effects of language intervention on overall language development require further investigation.
Objectives: 1) To examine whether parent-implemented home-based language intervention applied from childhood to school age with children with severe or global DLD is superior to a less structured control condition with respect to children's spoken language development; 2) To examine whether parent-implemented home-based language intervention applied from childhood to school age is superior to a less structured control condition with respect to children's overall language development; 3) To examine whether parent-implemented home-based language intervention applied from childhood to school age is superior to a less structured control condition with respect to children's communicative participation.
Methods: A randomized controlled trial with 2 parallel groups. Participants (N=178) were children with a diagnosis of non-progressive severe or global DLD, aged 3;6 to 4;7 years. Parents participated in the training condition or the control condition. Parents participating in the training condition were supervised weekly for 12 months by speech- and language pathologists in the application of parent-implemented home-based language intervention including a stimulation element during caregiving activities. The intervention will be conducted from age 3;6 to 4;7 years. The control condition consisted of general behavioral guidance. Children's overall language development will be assessed from age 4;8 to 8;11 years.
Expected results/conclusion: The expected results of this study will enhance the knowledge on the long-term effects of language intervention on the language development and participation of children with severe or global DLD.

Mental illness, specifically schizophrenia spectrum disorders, affects an estimated 3.2 million people in the United States. Schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder often present in early adulthood, with 10% of individuals experiencing their first episode before 18 years of age. Despite the recent identification of first episode psychosis (FEP) clinics and stepped care models, the gap in resources and care between FEP clinics to standard psychiatry outpatient settings is vast for young adults with schizophrenia and related disorders.
The purpose of this study is to assess the barriers and facilitators of integrating Horyzons, a digital intervention for young adults with schizophrenia, as part of standard practice, care or treatment at five established first episode clinics in North Carolina.
This project proposes to conduct formative research within FEP clinics where Horyzons is integrated in the form of focus groups and interviews to qualitatively assess the barriers and facilitators of implementing and integrating a digital intervention with clinical practice. Additionally, a quantitative survey will be conducted to assess the readiness and perspectives of providers on the barriers and facilitators of implementing and integrating a digital intervention at their respective clinic. By understanding the barriers that providers experience when integrating Horyzons into their care, the investigators hope to improve access to evidence-based intervention and improve the quality of services at established FEP clinics, ultimately bridging the gap between first episode care and psychiatry outpatient settings.

Participating in this study involves the following procedures/activities: If you are a provider/peer specialist who works or collaborates with a first episode psychosis clinic in North Carolina, you will be asked to complete an adapted survey on barriers and facilitators of implementing and integrating evidence-based practices at your clinic (e.g., Cognitive Behavioral Therapy). This survey will be completed once at baseline (approximately 4 weeks).
If you are a client diagnosed with schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, schizophreniform disorder, or other psychotic disorders, receiving services from select FEP clinics in North Carolina, you will be asked to participate in qualitative interviews related to your engagement with Horyzons once you complete the effectiveness trial. This qualitative interview will be conducted once, at the end of your involvement in Horyzons for a 12-month period.
If you are a client diagnosed with schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, schizophreniform disorder, or other psychotic disorders, receiving services from select FEP clinics in North Carolina, you will be asked to complete several brief questionnaires at baseline, approximately four (4) weeks post-admission to the platform, 12 months post-admission to the platform, and 3 months post-completion of the platform (for a total of up to 24 months). These questionnaires will include a battery of items that examines your individual experiences and treatment history (for up to 2 times), as well as assessments of loneliness, social support, and overall quality of life.

If you are a client diagnosed with schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, schizophreniform disorder, or other psychotic disorders, receiving services from select FEP clinics in North Carolina, you will be asked to use an online platform, Horyzons, for a period of 12 months. Each time you login and use the platform (e.g., engage with activities, tracks, and online community discussions/interactions), information will be passively collected without the ability to turn off or limit the information being collected. Information collected may include how often you use the platform, the activities you engage in, and your engagement in online discussions.

If you are a provider or peer support specialist at a first episode psychosis clinic in North Carolina, you will be asked to answer questions related to your clinical practice at baseline and once at 12 months. Providers, as well as peers, will also be asked to participate in a small focus group or one-on-one interview if they choose. The qualitative interview will be conducted once at 12 months and focus on your perspectives, experiences, and challenges of integrating and implementing a digital intervention into your day-to-day care.

If you are a client diagnosed with schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, schizophreniform disorder, or other psychotic disorders, receiving services from select FEP clinics in North Carolina, you will be asked to complete a brief battery of measures at baseline and once again as you make the transition from the platform to a follow-up questionnaire.

This is an open, clinical proof-of-concept study to evaluate the safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetics (PK) of two doses of BI 771716 administered via a single intravitreal injection (IVT) and subsequently via five additional IVT injections (total of six IVT injections) into one eye in participants with Geographic Atrophy (GA) secondary to Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD). The study is scheduled as an open-label, non-randomized multi-part study in participants with GA secondary to AMD.

Participants will be enrolled into one of the two cohorts: Part A (single rising dose [SRD] part) or Part B (multiple dose [MD] part) and will receive a single IVT injection at screening and two IVT injections prior initiation of the multiple dose treatment (MD part). SRD part participants will also receive three IVT injections post the MD part. In both treatment cohorts, each participant will receive IVT administered as a per-protocol injection with a topical anaesthetic, followed by a pre-defined ≥10 second interval and a ≥30 second interval. In Parts A and B, BI 771716 will be administered as a solution of 0.01-0.03 mg/mL, either 1.2, 2.5 or 5.0mg in Part A or 2.0mg in Part B. Subjects will have at least one post-injection blood sample collected to measure BI 771716 concentrations one hour after the baseline injection. Participants will be allowed to remain in the treatment cohort for treatment with additional IVT injections up until Week 26.
The primary objectives of the trial are to evaluate the tolerability and safety of intravitreal single rising doses of BI 771716 to determine the maximum tolerated dose, and to assess the pharmacokinetics of intravitreal multiple doses of BI 771716. The secondary objectives include determining the incidence of AEs and Ocular AEs, comparing the PK and PD profiles of BI 771716 and evaluating the long-term safety after dosing with single (Part A) or multiple doses (Part B) with BI 771716.

Cardiac decompensation secondary to volume expansion is a common reason for hospitalization in acute heart failure patients. The primary treatment for this entity is diuresis. Current standards recommend the use of loop diuretics for this indication. A novel technology called Matched Dehydration System (RenalGuard) has been developed to optimize fluid removal in these patients by matching hourly urine output to the infusion of sterile liquid. This technology promises to allow better fluid removal during diuresis therapy while also maintaining optimal blood volume. However, it is not known if the novel technology leads to better outcomes in decompensated heart failure patients compared to standard diuretic therapy. This study proposes the determination of the effects of Matched Dehydration System compared to standard loop diuretic therapy on acute kidney injury episodes and weight loss in decompensated heart failure patients. We further intend to determine the incidence of adverse cardiovascular events in this population, specifically cardiovascular death, worsening heart failure, stroke, myocardial infarction, or re-hospitalization due to heart failure exacerbations.

Chest pain is the most frequent reason for children and adolescents to visit the emergency department (ED) in the United States. Although a majority cases are deemed non-cardiac, a significant portion of these patients undergo unnecessary cardiac testing or are admitted for observation, which carries significant logistical and economic challenges for the healthcare system. Prior research has identified a group of children with chest pain referred to as “idiopathic” chest pain, children with chest pain but no underlying cardiac pathology. Idiopathic chest pain is most commonly seen in adolescents, is typically musculoskeletal in nature, and has been studied extensively in this age group. Despite the high prevalence of idiopathic chest pain in adolescents, there have been no previous studies to evaluate the efficacy of pain-directed interventions in this population.
Research with adult patients with chronic pain syndromes has identified mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs), which focus on increasing awareness of pain and increasing positive emotional states, as effective non-pharmacological approaches to pain management. There have been no published studies of MBIs for children with recurrent chest pain, and yet the same principles of mindfulness may be effective for children as well.
The goal of this study is to determine the feasibility, acceptability, and potential effectiveness of a MB-directed intervention on pain coping strategies in adolescents with idiopathic or musculoskeletal chest pain. If feasible and acceptable, this trial would provide the basis for future studies focused on improving outcomes and decreasing healthcare utilization in this population.

Background:
The COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic has led to a devastated global health crisis. Therefore, millions of individuals are vaccinated against COVID-19 to reduce infection rates. These vaccines also induce a strong antibody response against other coronaviruses, most notably against the coronavirus causing Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS-CoV). COVID-19 vaccine manufacturers are now exploring the possibility of extending the license of their vaccines to cover MERS as well. This goal can be achieved via inclusion of certain antigens of MERS in the vaccine, known as MERS antigens. In parallel, pneumococcal vaccination is recommended by physicians in general and is particularly important for elderly individuals. Pneumococci is a bacteria causing major complications in various age groups and particularly in the elderly, who are especially vulnerable to these complications. This also holds true for individuals with respiratory diseases such as chronic obstructive lung disease. The study aims to investigate whether vaccination with a COVID-19 and a pneumococcal vaccine at the same time causes a reduction in antibodies against Pneumococci in comparison to vaccination with a single or the other vaccine as a comparison.
Inclusion criteria:
Participants, who have received three Covid-19 vaccines, of which the third was a mRNA vaccine (BNT162b2 or mRNA-1273) and at least 16 weeks ago will be included in the study, after giving their consent by signing an informed consent form.
Participation is not possible if
- Use of immunosuppressants
- Congenital or acquired immunodeficiency (e.g. history of HIV infection, hematological disease, current malignancy, or others)
- Chronic condition that may significantly interfere with the immune response in the opinion of the investigator
- History of Covid-19 within 16 weeks before study vaccination
- Previous pneumococcal vaccination
- Contraindication against any ingredient of the NVX or the PCV20 vaccine.
Participants will be randomly distributed into four study arms:
1. Active Comparator: NVX arm. In this arm, participants will receive the NVX vaccine and also a placebo injection administered intramuscularly in the right leg.
2. Active Comparator: PCV20 arm. In this arm, participants will receive the PCV20 vaccine and also a placebo injection administered intramuscularly in the left leg.
3. Experimental: Combination arm. In this arm, participants will receive the NVX vaccine and also the PCV20 vaccine.
4. Placebo Comparator: Placebo arm. Participants in this arm will receive three placebo injections administered intramuscularly to each leg.

The purpose of this study is to show the possible anti-DOMS effects of treatment with the flavonoid diosmin taken 1 day before exercise and 2 days after exercise. This project will be carried out through a randomized, double-blinded and placebo-controlled single-center clinical trial in Paraná State Capital (Curitiba), with a volunteer sample of 39 female athletes. All of them will be subjected to a standardized intense dynamic exercise protocol and will be randomly divided into two experimental groups, as follows: intervention group that will receive supplementation with 750 mg of diosmin (5 tablets, twice a day for 3 days) and the control group that will receive 750 mg placebo (5 tablets, twice a day for 3 days). The effects of diosmin will be assessed immediately after exercise cessation, as well as 24 and 48 hours later. Additionally, evaluations will be carried out at the beginning and end of the experimental period to confirm the absence of alterations in oxidative balance, as well as any adverse effect. In accordance with the study's objectives, the investigators will investigate whether treatment with the flavonoid diosmin reduces muscle pain (primary outcome), in addition to muscle tissue damage, oxidative stress and the impairment caused by DOMS in performance and balance.

Background/rational: Cerebral palsy (CP) is the most common cause of childhood disability, with a prevalence of 2.11 per 1000 live births in high-income countries. CP is attributed to non progressive disturbances that occurred in the developing foetal or infant brain. An advanced treatment option for individuals with severe CP is Intrathecal Baclofen (ITB) treatment. This treatment can be considered when other options, such as oral medication, are insufficient or cause side effects. Previous studies have shown mostly low level evidence for the effect of ITB on spasticity in children with spastic CP. For children with dyskinetic CP, The Amsterdam UMC and Maastricht UMC previously conducted a randomized placebo-controlled trial, which provides evidence for the effect of ITB on attaining personal treatment goals after three months of ITB treatment. It was furthermore found that after one year of ITB treatment, personal treatment goals were at least partially achieved in 97% of children and adolescents. Not all children showed similar response to ITB: some benefit more than others in attaining treatment goals. The investigators previous research on the effect of ITB in children with dyskinetic CP, found that a higher level of dystonia prior to ITB and reduction of pain during ITB were associated, for a small part, with attainment of treatment goals. Sample size was not sufficient to look at specific factors associated with specific types of treatment goals. For example, goals on the level of personal caring could be influenced by other factors than goals related to sitting or transfers. Long-term effects of ITB in a prospective cohort of individuals with spastic and dyskinetic CP have not yet been described in literature. Furthermore, knowing which factors influence outcome on the long term, preferably related to specific types of treatment goals, can be used to inform and select children and adolescents with CP better before initiating ITB. In order to accomplish these goals real life data over a long period of time, and from a large cohort are needed. The Netherlands CP register is an innovative register for data collection which was developed between 2016 and 2020 in a unique collaboration between children with CP, their parents, researchers and health care professionals. The overall aim of the register is to provide personalized, value-based care for children with CP. In the Netherlands CP register, a follow-up registration program is combined with treatment registration. Prospective data collection in the treatment registration will allow us to implement standardized assessment protocols in the two academic medical centres in the Netherlands where baclofen pump implantations are performed, the Amsterdam University Medical Center (Amsterdam UMC) in Amsterdam and Maastricht UMC (MUMC)in Maastricht.

Objectives: The primary research question of this study is: 1. What is the short- (3 months), medium- (1 year) and long-term (2 years) effect of ITB in children with CP on personal treatment goals? Secondary objectives are: What is the association between the effect on personal treatment goals and on spasticity and/or dystonia? Which factors are associated with treatment success of ITB in children with CP?

Study design: A prospective observational study will be conducted in Amsterdam UMC and the MUMC using the Netherlands CP register to collect data over a period of 4,5 years. It is anticipated that in these centres 15 to 20 pumps will be implanted in children and adolescents annually. Over the total study period of 4,5 years, we aim to include a total of 67 to 90 children. The Medical Ethics Review Committee (MEC) of the Amsterdam UMC, location VU University Medical Center (IRB00002991) has stated that the Medical Research Involving Human Subjects Act (WMO) does not apply to the study and that further official approval by the MEC is waived.

Participants: Inclusion criteria: All children with CP Who start ITB treatment in the Netherlands under the age of 16. Exclusion criteria: no consent is given by the patient and/or caregiver for participation.

Subject follow-up schedule: In the investigators previous randomised controlled trial (the IDYS trial) on the effect of ITB in dyskinetic CP, we found that after three months of ITB most goals were, at least partially, attained. Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is a common condition among pregnant women with metabolic implications for both the mother and the offspring. A randomized controlled trial (RCT) is designed to investigate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on GDM development among high risk pregnant women with vitamin D deficiency. Women at risk of GDM with low vitamin D levels will be recruited for RCT and randomly assigned to receive either vitamin D3 supplementation or placebo. The primary outcome is the difference in incidence of GDM according to OGTT 75g. The results are expected to provide valuable insights to inform clinical practice and public health recommendations for vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy.

The PERFORMANCE III study will evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the Neuroguard IEP Direct System for the treatment of carotid artery stenosis in people at very high risk for poor outcomes with carotid endarterectomy (CEA). 
The Neuroguard IEP Direct System is a combination nitinol self-expanding carotid artery stent, an embolic protection filter, and a post dilation balloon used with the Neuroguard Direct Access Kit, which includes the Flow Redirection System to enable the use of direct access and blood flow redirection for carotid stenting. 
The outcomes assessment will focus on a composite Major Adverse Event (MAE) rate 1 month after the index procedure that includes stroke, myocardial infarction (MI) and death.

Our study builds on research demonstrating that participation in traditional exercise does not necessarily translate to better health outcomes for older adults. Additionally, the costs associated with traditional exercise, such as gym memberships or fitness classes, place a strain on the limited resources of older adults. This study aims to investigate the feasibility and safety of a low-cost, structured Nordic Walking (NW) intervention for community-dwelling older adults who are at risk of falling or experience fear of falling.
We will conduct a pilot randomized controlled trial examining the effects of NW on reducing the risk of falls and fear of falling, while also improving balance, mobility, and quality of life for older adults. We hypothesize that NW will result in significant, positive effects in all examined areas. The study aims to determine the effect sizes of the interventions, explore the experiences of the participants regarding the intervention, and inform future sample size calculations. This initial phase of the research will lay the foundation for a full-scale randomized control trial.

Lower gastrointestinal endoscopy is often accompanied by different degrees of discomfort and tension in patients. In recent years, researchers have studied analgesia and anesthesia techniques for colonoscopy. Patent controlled analgesia/sedation (PCAS) is one of the modern anesthesia techniques, which can achieve on-demand analgesia during endoscopy. However, propofol alone can lead to hemodynamic fluctuations and an increase in anesthesia-related complications, such as longer hospital stays after surgery. In recent years, studies show that the use of mixed solution of propofol and remifentanil in endoscopic sedation and anesthesia have obvious advantages. The purpose of this study is to evaluate and compare the sedation and analgesia efficacy and recovery of the two groups using mixed solution of propofol and remifentanil and routine intravenous combined anesthesia in fiber colonoscopy, hoping to provide clinical evidence for the sedation and analgesia technique of fiber colonoscopy.

<|assistant|>
Background: Radiation-induced injury to the gastrointestinal tract occurs in nearly 80% patients undergoing NCRT for rectal cancer. Although most patients recover within 2 months after NCRT, some may develop chronic radiation-induced intestinal injury. There is no effective method for predicting which patients are prone to chronic bowel injury after NCRT. This study is aimed at investigating whether the predictive model of chronic radiation-induced intestinal injury can be constructed using the biomarkers of acute colitis.
Objective: The objective of this study is to construct and validate the predictive model of chronic radiation-induced intestinal injury and determine the accuracy, precision, sensitivity, and specificity of this prediction model.
The prospective, observational and confirmatory clinical study will be conducted by the Department of Radiation Oncology, the Sixth Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University located in Guangzhou, China. The expression levels of immune factors including IL-7, IL-12, IFNgamma, and TNF in 200 pathological tissues after TME, as well as clinical information of these patients will be collected. The follow-up results of these 200 patients will be used for model training and validation.
Methods: Two hundred patients who are diagnosed with locally advanced rectal cancer and meet the inclusion criteria will be recruited for the study. During NCRT, patients will be routinely monitored for radiation-induced injury. Patients who develop grade 2 or above radiation-induced acute intestinal injury during or within 1 month after NCRT will be enrolled in the study. After the completion of NCRT, multidensity TME will be performed for all patients. The expression levels of IL-7, IL-12, IFNgamma, and TNF will be detected in the paraffin sections of these patients. We will evaluate the association between these levels and the chronicization of RAII. The prediction model will be constructed using these levels and the collected clinical information.
The study arm includes radiation therapy and surgery. The patients will receive a total dose of 40-50 Gy in 5-7 fractions of radiotherapy along with 5-fluorouracil and oxaliplatin (FOLFOX), followed by total mesorectal excision (TME). We will compare the differences in immune factor levels between patients without chronic radiation-induced intestinal injury and patients with this injury, as well as the differences between the levels before and after radiotherapy. The correlation between the immune factor levels and the clinical evaluation of the treatment is also observed.
The prediction model will be evaluated by the receiver operating characteristics (ROC) curve for the chronicization of RAII.
The area under the curve (AUC) greater than 0.75 is considered significant in predicting the chronicization. We will analyze the accuracy, precision, and specificity of this model.
Clinical Significance: This study provides a precise prediction of chronic radiation-induced intestinal injury and helps patients choose an appropriate therapy while reducing adverse reactions, providing evidence for clinical efficacy evaluation, and guiding the development of new effective therapies.

The ENDOMATIC SEPIOLA Left Atrial Appendage (LAA) Closure Device is intended for closure of LAA in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation (NVAF). This safety and performance study will enroll 10 patients. The LAA is opened first, then the SEPIOLA device is mounted at the mouth of LAA with a suture. LAA is closed with the SEPIOLA device, by pulling it up through the suture. The SEPIOLA device will completely exclude the LAA. The closure of the LAA is expected to reduce the incidence of atrial fibrillation, thus reducing the need for anticoagulation to prevent blood clots in the heart.

<|assistant|> The primary aim of this study is to investigate whether motivational interviewing can positively influence treatment adherence and therapeutic alliance in the acute inpatient setting and the secondary aim is to investigate whether motivational interviewing can improve symptom severity in the acute inpatient setting. Our pilot study is of randomised controlled, non-blinded design, with a control condition of supportive conversations and a sample size of 60 patients with acute psychosis. Patients will be screened for eligibility on their first ward day and are required to provide written informed consent. Patients meeting the inclusion criteria will be randomly assigned to the experimental group, which undergoes 4 sessions of motivational interviewing, or to the control group, which undergoes 4 sessions of supportive conversations. We will assess symptoms, therapeutic alliance and treatment adherence at baseline, at the end of the intervention and 1 week after intervention. Additionally, at the end of intervention and 1 week after intervention data on motivational level for psychotherapy and self-efficacy are collected. Our results can help us to better understand how MI-based interventions can be adapted to patients with acute psychosis and inform future clinical guidelines regarding the use of MI in this specific patient population. Individuals living with schizophrenia are increasingly impacted by comorbid medical conditions that require attention in the form of medical care. Participants in both study arms will be enrolled in the standard COPSI intervention, which will be delivered to them by trained Community Health Officers over a 12-month period. Participants in the experimental group will have access to an interactive and customizable mobile application (smartphone app), which can be accessed on-demand at any time. Participants in both study arms will be followed for 12 months to evaluate the long-term impact of COPSI and mindLAMP on disability, symptoms, and quality of life of individuals living with schizophrenia. This study will contribute to the knowledge of effective psychosocial interventions for schizophrenia and the role of digital implementation support in achieving sustained and quality service delivery for persons with schizophrenia. Temporomandibular disorder (TMD) is the most common musculoskeletal disorder of the masticatory muscles and preauricular region and the temporomandibular joints. Several studies suggest the participation of cytokines as factors involved in the development of TMD. This study may be of particular importance, especially in the light of the limited success of various therapeutic approaches to TMD. The primary aim is to characterize the levels of cytokines (IL-1beta, IL-13, IL-6, IL-7, IL-8, TNF-alpha) in gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) and peripheral blood (PB) in patients with myalgia, arthralgia, headache attributed to TMP and painful disc displacement (with and without reduction) after stabilization occlusal splint therapy. The second aim is to evaluate the effect of therapy on the levels of inflammatory cytokines in GCF and PB in the same patient population. It has not been tested whether the cytokine levels in GCF or peripheral blood in TMD patients treated with occlusal splint therapy will change in response to therapy compared to the non-specific increase in stress and anxiety. Another interesting question is whether there is a correlation between the levels of cytokines in GCF and PB in TMD patients.

The purpose of the TREAD Study is to assess whether training to counteract perturbations to the trunk during walking can reduce the frequency of falls for people recently undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA). The intervention is a brief (about 45 minutes) perturbation training program that is targeted at counteracting the perturbation response. The perturbation training program is expected to increase the stability of the trunk and improve the ability to respond to a loss of balance. The ability to counteract a perturbation to the trunk is important in maintaining balance and preventing falls during walking. Falls are a leading cause of morbidity and mortality, particularly for people with conditions such as knee osteoarthritis.
The investigators propose that a targeted training program can improve fall outcome after TKA. As such, this study will assess whether the perturbation training program can improve fall outcome after TKA.

The study will include in total 58 patients, 29 patients being treated by the Intensity SL IOL and 29 patients by the PanOptix IOL. Subjects participating in the study are at least 18 years old and have both eyes implanted with a cataract and Trifocal IOL. The duration of the study will be up to 3 months after the second eye operation. Subjects will attend a maximum of 8 study visits with 13 tests and examinations. Patients participating in this study will have the opportunity to have their Trifocal IOL implanted in both eyes. Both eyes can be treated at one or two consecutive days. All patients who would like to take part in the study will receive an information interview and further detailed study information in written form before giving their consent.

Rubella cataract.

Hip fracture is a major burden on individuals, the health service, and economy each year. Surgical treatment reduces death and other poor outcomes, but is not benign as many patients die within a month. Low blood pressure (hypotension) is surprisingly common after hip fracture surgery (> 30%) and is independently associated with a higher risk of death (3% relative rise per 5 mmHg fall in systolic blood pressure). UK guidelines recommend that low doses (< 2mls 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine) are given for spinal anaesthesia to prevent hypotension, but this recommendation is based on data from trials > 40 years old involving younger, fitter patients. There is no observational data describing the blood pressure changes after low dose spinal anaesthesia in older, unfit patients. The investigator provides a retrospective, observational study with outcomes defined by deaths within 30 days of surgery. The investigator aims to analyse the blood pressure changes in the older, unfit patients during and after low dose spinal anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery, using anaesthetic data gathered as part of normal clinical practice. The investigator will describe the haemodynamic changes in the cohort using the latest (2017) European guidelines for measuring and describing blood pressure using the standard ASA definition of hypotension. The investigator will also assess the potential value of a new, more sensitive measure of hypotension (hypotension depth x duration product). Finally, the investigator will use statistical tools to assess whether the frequency of hypotension, and/or the depth/duration product are associated with poor outcomes such as death at 30 days and increased length of hospital stay. By describing the haemodynamic events at a population level, the investigator aims to determine whether lower doses administered using a fascia iliaca block + sedation can prevent hypotension and improve outcome after hip fracture surgery in the older, unfit patients most likely to benefit from surgery.

The prevalence and severity of SARS-CoV-2 infection vary in regions where other infectious diseases are endemic, and malaria-endemic countries are an example of this phenomenon. In Malawi, the burden of COVID-19 remains higher than in Western countries, in part due to the high incidence of HIV and malaria infections, and the low numbers of immunized individuals. This study will explore several hypotheses centered on innate immunity as a factor responsible for the difference in host/pathogen interactions that influence the clinical course and transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in Malawian compared to Western populations. The investigators will examine the relative contribution of innate and adaptive immunity pathways to natural and evoked immunity in individuals in Malawi and compare these with the response in the matched cohort from Sweden.
The study will include 3 cohorts: natural infection, vaccine, and population-based cohorts. Each cohort will be followed-up for 15 months, allowing assessment of the immune memory and protection following infection or vaccination.
The specific aims of this study are to:
1. Determine if the immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 are impaired in Malawians compared to matched controls from Sweden.
2. Identify the innate immune cell subsets, soluble factors, regulatory pathways, and cytokines that differentiate Malawian's innate immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 from that of Swedes.
3. Identify the innate immune parameters that differentiate symptomatic and asymptomatic individuals infected with SARS-CoV-2.
4. Determine the relative importance of innate and adaptive immunity to the generation of neutralizing antibodies and their ability to mediate SARS-CoV-2 clearance in Malawians compared to Swedes.
5. Determine the relative importance of innate and adaptive immunity in mediating antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) following SARS-CoV-2 infection or vaccination.
6. Identify the innate immune parameters that differentiate vaccinees across different age groups in Malawi and Sweden.
Answers derived from this study will help to understand how host-pathogen interaction and malaria and intestinal parasitic co-infection influence COVID-19 transmission, morbidity, and vaccine response in this region.

The aim of this study is to evaluate the effect of hot and cold application to the bladder on the decrease in the probability of the development of postoperative urinary retention in orthopedic surgery patients. With the hot-cold application, no treatment application is made to this area, and the patient is not disturbed. Hot-cold application will be applied 20 seconds of 38 degrees centigrade hot application alternated with 20 seconds of 4 degrees centigrade / 1degree centigrade cool application to the bladder 4 times in 30 minutes. In the control group, standard clinical care will be applied. The intervention will be carried out in the perioperative period in patients who accepted the consent to participate in the study. The first 8 hours postoperatively, all the urine samples of the patients in the same postoperative process will be recorded by urination every 2 hours, and the first 6 hours after the end of the surgery will be taken as a single-blind randomized controlled experimental design. The demographic characteristics of the patients in terms of age, gender, education level, surgery time, and duration of the operation in the postoperative period. The effect of the hot-cold application on the incidence of postoperative urinary retention in orthopedic surgery patients will be evaluated by examining the effect of hot-cold application on the risk of postoperative urinary retention. The data obtained are analyzed by the SPSS 19.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, Illinois, USA) package program. Statistical significance will be accepted as p<0.05. As a result, the contribution to the literature will be made in evaluating the effect of this method. In addition, the reduction of postoperative urinary retention will be positively effective in minimizing postoperative complications in this patient group.

The presence of pancreatic cancer is of great importance in patients with acute pancreatitis, as it may contribute to different disease courses and outcomes compared with those without pancreatic cancer. The primary aim of this study is to establish a radiomic-based model to predict long-term pancreatic cancer (5 years) risk in adult patients who have been discharged from the hospital after acute pancreatitis caused by non-biliary duct obstruction. The model will be established using radiomic features extracted from CT scans performed during hospital stays for initial acute pancreatitis, in addition to clinical data. A secondary aim is to assess short-term predictability of pancreatic cancer. To be eligible for the study, patients must have CT findings consistent with non-biliary duct obstruction (calculi, pancreatic carcinoma, gallstone pancreatitis or biliary injury) and not have the following conditions: active cancer in addition to pancreatic cancer.

Introduction
Sleep apnea and polycythemia, the latter also known as primary arterial hypertension, are very common diseases. It is estimated that 6-7% of the adult population have sleep apnea, and its prevalence increases up to 30% after the age of 50 [1]. In the United States, an estimated 7.5 million women and 15.8 million men suffer from OSA [2].
Polycythemia is characterized by an increase in the proportion of red blood cells, leading to an increase in the proportion of oxygen-transporting hemoglobin [3] which, by altering the blood viscosity, can have deleterious cardiovascular effects [4]. In addition to altering blood viscosity, the increased number and size of red blood cells can promote the development of atherosclerosis [5]. The association of polycythemia with Obstructive sleep apnea has not been extensively studied, although there are case reports and a retrospective report on the prevalence of polycythemia in patients with OSA but not on the possible relationship of treatment with CPAP and the reduction of the polycythemic process in this population.
In 2016, it was estimated that 7-8% of the adult population have polycythemia, with this prevalence increasing with age in men and in pre-menopausal women [6,7]. The prevalence of polycythemia is high in primary care [8]. The relationship of sleep apnea and its treatment (continuous positive airway pressure-CPAP) with polycythemia have been rarely addressed. The aim of this study is to quantify the effect of CPAP treatment on the reduction of hemoglobin and hematocrit in patients with OSA and associated polycythemia.
Methods
Experimental:
To study this association we propose a clinical trial to evaluate the effect of CPAP treatment on reducing hemoglobin and hematocrit in patients with OSA and associated polycythemia. 
Inclusion criteria:
Patients aged between 18 and 80 years without obstructive sleep apnea (apnea hypopnea index < 5/hr), with polycythemia; AHI> 15) and with polycythemia with hematocrit > 49% in men and > 48% in women
Patients who can read and understand informed consent and who agree to sign it.
Patients who can use the CPAP device and are available for the study duration.
Exclusion criteria:
Smokers or former smokers with pack-year index (IPA>30) or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease diagnosed by spirometry (FEV1/FVC post-bronchodilator below the lower limit of normal or z score < 1.645).
Patients with central sleep apnea or periodic breathing
Bariatric surgery
Patients with oxygen saturation (SaO2) <92% or pO2 (Partial Oxygen Pressure)< 60 mmHg at rest during wakefulness, Patients with severe heart failure (LVEF<50) or pulmonary hypertension (PAH).
Patients with the diagnosis of primary polyglobulia (polycythemia vera).

Amputations lead to the loss of muscle activity from a portion of the limb that is lost during amputation surgery. The residual muscles are then repurposed from producing movement to helping to control a prosthesis. The current main method of prosthesis control is through the decoding of electrical signals (myo-electric signals) from the residual limb. These control signals are decoded from the electro-myogram (EMG) activity, and can be used to control various types of prosthesis components. However, traditional myo-electric prosthesis designs require frequent training with both a physical prosthesis and virtual training environments to be effective, both of which make frequent visits to a medical facility and/or therapist necessary for effective prosthetic use.
In our previous research, we demonstrated the feasibility of using virtual reality (VR) for task-specific training in amputees who received a myo-electric prosthesis. The VR training system used a VR headset to provide visual feedback of prosthesis function, and was found to reduce the time for learning to use a new myoelectric prosthesis when compared to the traditional training and a control group.
Our previous research also demonstrated that myoelectric prosthesis users had difficulty controlling multiple movements (2 DoF or more) with the myoelectric controller, which is necessary in order to effectively control more complex prosthetics (for example, a 7 DoF hand prosthesis). As a result, many users of myoelectric control systems have difficulty picking up and transporting objects effectively. As a result, there is a significant need in clinical practice to develop novel training interventions and interfaces that are specific to controlling more complex prostheses.
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of a new virtual prosthesis functional training system (referred to as MyoTrain AR) for the purpose of training novice prosthesis users to control multiple movements during daily tasks (that is, performing multi-joint movements simultaneously over multiple planes including during transport, manipulation, and release of objects). The training system consists of an augmented reality (AR) headset, a desktop computer, and four SteamVR kinematic trackers. The AR headset provides real-time visual feedback of the prosthesis user's performance and allows for the use of more complex training activities and objects.
Up to 10 participants with a unilateral upper limb trans-radial amputation will be selected to receive the MyoTrain AR training system. They will undergo 5 full training sessions with the MyoTrain AR system over 3 weeks in a laboratory setting. During the 5 sessions, the participants will use the MyoTrain AR system to perform the GaMA Cup Transfer task that involves reaching for, grasping, and transporting cups of various volumes that are placed at different locations and heights.
Potential participants may be referred to the study by their rehabilitation physician, therapist, or prosthetist. Eligibility assessment and consent discussions will typically occur remotely. Potential participants will then participate in a one-session pre-screen, where they will undergo an assessment of their muscle function as compared to the muscle function of people with similar limb loss patterns. Those participants who are shown to have sufficient muscle activity from their residual limb to control a pattern recognition-based myoelectric system will then be randomized to either the Experimental (MyoTrain AR) group or to the Control group.

Postoperative ileus is a common and serious complication following major surgery, caused by a temporary paralysis of the intestines. Current treatment options, such as nasogastric decompression and antibiotics are poorly effective. In the past, it has been suggested that temporary, non-invasive pacing of the stomach may accelerate recovery from postoperative ileus, based on data from an animal study. The aim of this international prospective double blinded randomised controlled trial is to evaluate if such gastric pacing, with new developed pacemaker technology, really reduces the time before the first bowel movement after major surgery. We expect the gastric lead to be well tolerated and safe and no serious adverse events is expected as a result of the study.

Background: The purpose of this study is to enroll at least 72 subjects diagnosed with BPPV or migrainous vertigo, who have moderate-to-severe vertigo symptoms measured by the Dizziness Handicap Inventory and to test the effectiveness of the OtoBand as therapy for vertigo. The OtoBand is a medical device that uses mechanical stimulation provided through oscillations to the neck to temporarily alleviate symptoms of vertigo.
Inclusion criteria: Diagnosed as having vestibular vertigo that is caused by one or more of: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) Migraine associated vertigo (MAV, aka vertiginous migraines) Meniere's disease (aka idiopathic endolymphatic hydrops) Uncompensated unilateral vestibulopathy (such as arising from vestibular neuritis and labyrinthitis) Vertigo that has been present for at least 90 days Score greater than 35, and less than 91, on the Dizziness Handicap Inventory (corresponding to moderate to severe vertigo) Smartphone, computer or tablet and access to internet for online enrollment, check-in and wrap-up meetings Willingness to install and use the JotForm ePRO app Residing in the United States Willingness to be paid via Venmo or PayPal. Exclusion criteria: Surgery to the base of the skull within the last 6 months or plans for surgery to the skull during enrollment period Any skull or neck implants such as but not limited to a cochlear implant, vascular stents, bone conduction implant, or deep brain stimulation device History of vitreous detachment (aka floaters) in the last 90 days Superior canal dehiscence (aka third window) or otic capsule dehiscence Hyperacusis (aka hypersensitivity to loud sounds) Currently undergoing vestibular rehabilitation therapy or planning to start vestibular rehabilitation therapy during the study. (People who have completed vestibular rehabilitation therapy, but in whom vertigo persists, will be permitted to enroll)

Study Objective: This pilot study, with a planned enrollment of 24 participants, aims to study the effectiveness of the OtoBand in reducing vertigo symptoms in subjects diagnosed with vestibular vertigo who have moderate to severe vertigo and no other apparent explanation for their vertigo.
Study Design: Decentralized Clinical Trial (DCT) using online meeting software. The intervention will be the OtoBand device and the study will be conducted completely remotely with online video check-ins, e-PRO surveys, and remote monitoring.
Intervention: The investigators intend to enroll up to 120 participants in total. Participants will be randomized into two study arms. One arm will enroll subjects that are determined to have moderate to severe vertigo that requires at least weekly use of the OtoBand to temporarily relieve symptoms of vertigo. The other arm will enroll subjects whose vertigo is less severe and who may use the OtoBand on an as-needed basis (less than weekly).
Study Arms: OtoBand Arm: The investigators intend to enroll up to 80 participants in this arm, and at least 56 enrolled participants will complete the study. In this study arm, the OtoBand will be used as instructed by the clinical coordinator. Participants will be given written instructions and provided a device for the remote monitoring of their OtoBand usage during the treatment phase. Participants will be randomly assigned to use the OtoBand on one of four power settings. The OtoBand will transmit data via Wi-Fi on the frequency of its use, the intensity of its use (power settings), the duration of each therapy session, and the adherence of each subject to OtoBand use. The investigators will record this information via remote monitoring. If a participant's vertigo severity is mild, with a score of less than 35 on the Dizziness Handicap Inventory, they will be re-evaluated by the clinical coordinator at any point in the course of the study to re-designate them to the quality of life arm. Quality of Life Arm: The investigators intend to enroll up to 30 subjects in this arm. In this study arm, the subject's symptoms will be monitored during vertigo episodes using the DHI questionnaire to determine the severity of their vertigo symptoms. Background: Acute upper respiratory tract infections (acute URTI) are a major problem in the elderly. It is a condition that is usually related to colds and flu. This condition is the most recurring in this population. There is a relationship between the increase in the incidence of antibiotics and the lack of immune response due to ageing. It has been recorded that the elderly population is the greatest consumer of antibiotics. Antibiotics have no antiviral efficacy, do not prevent respiratory diseases caused by viruses such as cold and flu, and therefore, in the prevention of respiratory infections for which antibiotics are prescribed, probiotics have proven efficacy in the long term. So far, there have been no studies on the effect of probiotics in the prevention of URTIs in the elderly. The aim of the study is to assess the effectiveness of the multistrain probiotic OMNi-BiOTiC® Active in the prevention of URTIs in the elderly. Methods: This is a randomised, double blind, placebo-controlled, 6-month study. Two independent groups (2:1 allocation) will be examined, the experimental group receiving probiotics and the control group receiving placebo. The sample will consist of 450 participants aged 65 years and older and in good health. They will be enrolled on the basis of self-reported upper respiratory tract infections. Each subject will be provided with a dose of 1 pack of probiotics per day for 6 months. Dosage of probiotics is 10(6) cfu of microorganism per capsule. Questionnaires for the study will be completed monthly and in the event of an acute URTI. Acute infectious URTIs will be diagnosed based on the participant's history of the onset of symptoms, the presence of at least one respiratory symptom (nasal secretion, pharyngeal pain, cough, dyspnoea, headache, myalgia or fever) and the absence of any pre-existent chronic disease. Diagnosis of URTI will be based on the criteria of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The effectiveness of probiotics will be expressed as the incidence and the duration of URTIs for each participant in both groups. In addition, the concentration and changes in concentration of leukocytes (leukocytosis), neutrophils (neutrophilitis), eosinophils (eosinophilia), lymphocytes, monocytes will be compared for each participant between baseline and the end of the study (12 weeks). The same evaluation will be completed for immunoglobulin A (IgA). The difference between the groups on the basis of these parameters will be assessed.

Adhesive Capsulitis is a commonly observed musculoskeletal disorder that leads to shoulder pain and dysfunction. Although the pathophysiology of Adhesive Capsulitis remains poorly understood. The current intervention for Adhesive Capsulitis includes physical therapy sessions which may include the use of different joint manual therapy techniques to decrease pain and improve shoulder range of motion and functional mobility. Among these techniques are Gong's and Kaltenborn's mobilization. Gong's and Kaltenborn's mobilization techniques have both shown promising results in improving pain and shoulder range of motion. However, there are limited studies that provide evidence on their relative effectiveness in improving outcomes for Adhesive Capsulitis patients. The authors therefore seek to conduct a single blind clinical trial to compare Gong's and Kaltenborn's mobilization techniques on functional mobility, pain and shoulder range of motion in patients with adhesive capsulitis. A total of 20 patients with second and third stage of adhesive capsulitis will be included (10 in each group). Participants will be randomized into 2 groups: patients in group A will receive Gong's mobilization and patients in group B will receive Kaltenborn's mobilization. Both groups will receive routine physical therapy sessions in addition to the specific manual therapy techniques of interest (2 sessions a week for 4 weeks, in total 8 sessions). Routine physical therapy sessions include electrical stimulation and heat therapy. The primary purpose of the study is treatment, and the allocation is randomized and the study is conducted as a single-blind randomized clinical trial.

Urothelial carcinoma (UC) accounts for over 90% of bladder cancer and approximately 10% of kidney cancers. Most UC patients are diagnosed with localized disease, for which surgery can be curative. Patients with muscle-invasive disease or those who develop metastatic disease may receive cisplatin-based chemotherapy. In this phase III trial, researchers compare treatment with disitamab vedotin plus the immunotherapy pembrolizumab—targeted therapies known to block cancer cell growth and stimulate the immune system—against the standard chemotherapy option of gemcitabine plus cisplatin or carboplatin. The study will evaluate the safety of this treatment and its effects on disease progression and patient survival. Disitamab vedotin is a monoclonal antibody treatment that works by blocking cancer cell growth and stopping cancer cells from dividing. Pembrolizumab is a type of immunotherapy that works by enhancing the immune system's ability to identify and destroy cancer cells. Gemcitabine and cisplatin or carboplatin are chemotherapy agents that work by stopping cancer cell division. Eligible participants may be enrolled in a post-treatment analysis for the evaluation of long-term survival benefits.

Exclusion Criteria: Patients with other concomitant organic gastrointestinal abnormalities besides Crohn's disease: ano-perineal lesions, extra-intestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease, colorectal history of cancer or abdominal radiotherapy, symptomatic intestinal stenosis, substance dependence history, Patients with significant comorbidities: instable cardiovascular diseases, complicated diabetes, instable thyroid function, Patients receiving non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, steroids, opioids, or narcotic analgesics in the last month before V0, Patients beginning a diet or a specific treatment for functional symptoms (probiotics, prebiotics, anti spasmodic, chelators, anti-depressants, etc.) within one month before V1. In this study, the investigators aim to develop a novel biomarker for detecting residual cancer and recurrence/metastasis for HCC patients after RT. They hypothesize that Human-HBV junctional Chimera DNA (vh-DNA) with high prevalence and specificity in HCC can be used as a highly sensitive and specific biomarker before or after RT. The investigators plan to retrospectively analyze the changes in vh-DNA copy numbers/detection rates between pre- and post-RT serums and prospectively analyze the serial changes of vh-DNA copies within different treatment outcomes. They will correlate the copy number changes of HBV vh-DNA with RT response and prognosis on the pathogenesis and clinical significance of vh-DNA, and support using personalized vh-DNA to evaluate response, to predict prognosis. They plan to identify the HBV integrations by Capture NGS and quantify the specific vh-DNA by ddPCR. Moreover, The investigators will further correlate the clinical response and recurrence/metastasis to serial changes of vh-DNA copy numbers. The investigators hope that vh-DNA will offer a novel method to achieve earlier evaluating response and earlier post-radiotherapy disease monitoring.

Study Overview
=================
Emergent evidence shows that undernutrition is common in patients with amputations, and this can cause complications after surgery. However, undernutrition is often not recognized or acknowledged. The investigators hypothesize that patients who undergo a major LLA have low physical activity levels, low nutritional intakes, and low nutritional status. Aim of this investigational study is to determine the impact of LLA on the dietary intake, physical activity level and nutritional status of patients. Specific secondary outcomes include mortality, wound healing, quality of life, physical functioning, functional level, mobility, exercise capacity, self-efficacy, and healthcare costs.

Methods: 
Patients who undergo a major LLA are asked to participate within 10 days after amputation surgery. Data will be collected before the operation and at 2, 5, and 9 months follow-up. Participants will provide demographic data, provide a dietary recall and accelerometry data, perform a 6-minute walk test, and complete self-report questionnaires on quality of life, physical functioning, physical activity level (in and outside the household) and nutritional status.

Study Population: Eligible patients are 18 years of age or older, undergoing or recently having undergone a major dysvascular (Syme amputation or more proximal) LLA at the Department of Vascular Surgery of Erasmus MC (Rotterdam, The Netherlands) or Wilhelmina hospital (Assen, The Netherlands).

Impact: The results can be used for tailored dietary and physical activity advice, the implementation of a post-amputation care regime, and the development of a nutritional assessment tool.

Diabetes mellitus type 2 and proteinuria increase the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and mortality. Proteinuria and a decrease in estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) are associated with an elevated risk of CVD. Empagliflozin and finerenone are both effective pharmacological therapies for the treatment of diabetes mellitus type 2 with proteinuria. While data from pivotal clinical trials indicate a more potent and sustained renoprotective effect of finerenone compared to empagliflozin, this therapeutic advantage has been observed beyond 44 weeks of treatment only for patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease with a specific phenotype. Since the risk of a non-favoured outcome increases with disease duration and the development of comorbidities, it is reasonable to evaluate the clinical course of patients with diabetes mellitus type 2, proteinuria, comorbidities and an established eGFR of ≥30 ml/min/1.73m2 (CKD stage 3 or 4) after the initiation of empagliflozin, with the possibility to switch to finerenone in case of an insufficient response to reduce the risk of unfavourable outcomes. This protocol aims to provide relevant insights into a personalized use of SGLT2 inhibitors and MRA following an initial open-label monotherapy with empagliflozin as a first-line treatment.
We will conduct a multi-centre, randomized, prospective open-label crossover trial. Patients with type 2 diabetes, albuminuria and an eGFR between 30-60 ml/min/1.73m2 will be recruited in a dedicated research visit at the clinic. Patients will be treated with empagliflozin 10 mg once daily (OAD) for 24 weeks, followed by randomization into two study arms. In group 1, patients will receive either 20 mg finerenone OAD or continue empagliflozine 10 mg OAD for another 24 weeks after which patients will be switched in group 2 and receive 10 mg finerenone OAD or continue empagliflozine 10 mg OAD for another 24 weeks after which patients will be switched again and receive the other drug for the final 24 weeks. The investigators will continue data collection and adherence monitoring until study completion. The primary goal is to investigate whether SGLT2 inhibitors and MRA can be safely and effectively used in patients with diabetes mellitus type 2, proteinuria, comorbidities and a specific phenotype (CKD stage 3 or 4), and to investigate if individual responses regarding albuminuria and eGFR can help tailor the choice of medications.

Through experimental design and quantitative research methods. This experiment will test the effectiveness of the training method by intervening in the selective fitness, skills, and tactical performance of college students using a high-intensity interval training method on the ice. The experiment will use 12 weeks of high-intensity interval training to improve the fitness, skills, and tactical performance of the intervention for ice hockey players. The experiment will use 20 students in the experimental group and 20 students in the control group, to compare the differences between the two groups. The experiment was divided into a discussion group and a general teaching group. The purpose of this experiment is to provide a theoretical basis for the improvement of ice hockey training methods so that college ice hockey players can obtain better competitive performance, especially in physical fitness and technique. The experimental group (1-12 weeks) performed repeated sprint training, sprint interval training (on-ice 45-s shift length conditioning drill), a long-pass tracking drill, and a chase-the-rabbit tracking drill. There are three phases: 1-4 weeks, 5-8 weeks, and 9-12 weeks gradually increasing the intensity of training. Similarly, the control group performed varied-pace skating (1 minute accelerated skating, 2 minutes even pace), dribbling and shooting drill (30 m), passing-catching drill (20 m), and 2 on 1 offensive drill (full rink). As in the experimental group, the same three phases were used to gradually increase the intensity.
Based on the experimental design, the purpose of this study was firstly to assess which training method is more efficient in improving the physical fitness, skills and tactical performance of college male ice hockey players in the high-intensity interval training group than traditional training for college ice hockey players, and to compare the physical fitness, techniques and tactics of elite ice hockey players and high-intensity interval training group.

Pain after accidental injury can be severe and long-lasting. Patients experience chronic pain in up to one third of post-operative injuries requiring hospitalization. For patients with acute injuries, discharge often results in lack of ongoing pain treatment, leading to inadequate pain control and unnecessary overuse of opioids. One explanation for this is that patients fail to access their GP after discharge from the hospital. A growing body of research suggests that collaboration between GP and hospital specialists may significantly impact prescribing of strong painkillers. At present, this collaboration is not common in Norway, where the healthcare system is based on a mix between the public health service and private primary health care. If more patients were to access their GP, and the GP subsequently contacted the hospital specialists, this could potentially reduce unnecessary and inadequate opioid prescribing. The objective of this study is to evaluate if a Pain and Coordination Plan (PAC-plan) for patients after accidental injury can reduce opioid use in the first 6 weeks after discharge. The study also aims to compare the effectiveness of a PAC-plan and conventional care in relation to pain severity, pain interference, insomnia, health-related quality of life, overall satisfaction and adverse outcomes.
66 accidental injuries will be included in the study. Patients will be treated according to a clinical pathway in a comprehensive orthopaedic trauma center, Oslo University Hospital. The patients will be assigned randomly to the PAC-plan or conventional care. Outcomes will be assessed immediately after discharge, at 6 and 52 weeks after the injury.

Background: It is well established that antiplatelet agents decrease the incidence of major ischemic events following stent implantation of intracranial arteries. However, excessive platelet inhibition may cause serious bleeding events. Recently, the optimal antiplatelet regime and the best antiplatelet regimen for patients in different clinical conditions are still controversial. To reduce the risk of ischemic events without increasing bleeding events, antiplatelet dose-guided schemes have been introduced into clinical practice. In view of the lack of such research results in China, this study will be carried out.
Objective: To explore the role of dose-guided antiplatelet drugs in the occurrence of ischemic events after endovascular treatment of intracranial aneurysm and the rate of major bleeding events.
Method: This study is a single-center retrospective controlled cohort study. Participants who underwent endovascular treatment of intracranial aneurysms requiring stent placement between January 2019 and August 2020 in the Department of Neurosurgery, Xijing Hospital of the Fourth Military Medical University will be included. The clinical data of the participants was divided into 2 groups, namely the dose-guided antiplatelet group and the standard antiplatelet group. The participants in the dose-guided antiplatelet group will receive antiplatelet drug testing before stent placement according to the specific requirements of the test results. The dose of antiplatelet drug is adjusted according to the level of platelet function, and the specific drug and its dose are based on the specific requirements of the test results. The participants in the standard antiplatelet group will be treated with conventional antiplatelet drugs before the operation, and the drugs used for antiplatelet drug testing were not involved in the intervention. The ischemic and bleeding events within 4 months after stent placement will be recorded in each participant.
Hypothesis Test: The incidence of postoperative ischemic events and major bleeding events is different between the 2 groups.
Expected Results: It is expected to improve the rational use of antiplatelet drugs in the clinical treatment of intracranial aneurysms, to provide more evidence-based data for the establishment of the treatment guidelines of intracranial aneurysms.

Background: Cerebral Palsy (CP) is primarily a neuromotor disorder that affects the development of movement, muscle tone and posture. The underlying pathophysiology is an injury to the developing brain in the prenatal through neonatal period. Although the initial neuro pathologic lesion is non-progressive, children with cerebral palsy may develop a range of secondary conditions over time that will variably affect their functional abilities. The prevalence of CP varies between 1.5 to more than 4 cases per 1,000 live births worldwide. The motor impairments associated with CP can range from mild to severe, affecting different muscle groups and leading to difficulties in activities of daily living and participation in social and recreational activities. Children with CP often experience motor impairments that affect their gross motor function, leading to limitations in activities and participation. These motor impairments can also have a negative impact on bone health, resulting in reduced bone mineral density (BMD) and increased risk of skeletal complications. Gross motor function (GMF) refers to the ability to perform coordinated movements using large muscle groups, such as walking, running, and jumping. It is a key aspect of physical ability and independence in daily activities for children with CP. Previous research has shown that gross motor function is closely associated with bone health in this population. However, further investigation is needed to explore the specific nature of this correlation and its implications for intervention strategies. Gross motor function is commonly assessed using standardized tools such as the Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) or the Gross Motor Function Measure (GMFM). Quality of life is a multidimensional construct that encompasses physical, psychological, and social well-being. In the context of cerebral palsy, understanding the impact of gross motor function on quality of life is crucial for comprehensive care and intervention planning. Children with CP may face limitations in mobility, participation in activities, and social interactions, which can significantly affect their overall quality of life. Exploring the relationship between gross motor function and quality of life can provide valuable insights into the factors influencing the holistic well-being of children with CP. The quality of life in children with CP is not only influenced by their motor function but also by their overall health and well-being. Bone health plays a crucial role in maintaining the physical abilities and independence of individuals, as well as their overall quality of life. Impaired bone health in children with CP can lead to limitations in mobility, increased pain, and reduced participation in activities, which can have a significant impact on their overall well-being. Bone mineral density, on the other hand, is an important measure of bone strength and overall skeletal health. Children with CP often exhibit lower BMD compared to typically developing peers due to factors such as reduced weight-bearing activities, muscle weakness, altered biomechanics, limited mobility, and hormonal imbalances. This reduced BMD increases their susceptibility to fractures and skeletal deformities, further impacting their functional abilities and quality of life.

Official Title: Relation Between Bone Mineral Density, Gross Motor Function and Quality of Life In Children With Cerebral Palsy

Conditions: Cerebral Palsy, Bone Density, Low, Gross Motor Development Delay

Intervention / Treatment: * Other: Group 1
* Other: Group 2

=================
Eligibility Criteria: 
Inclusion Criteria: Children with CP (spastic diplegia and quadriplegia). Their chronological ages will be ranged from 7 to 10 years. They will be selected from both genders. Their motor function will be at any Level according to GMFCS. Their body mass index (BMI ) will be normal. Exclusion criteria: Children will be excluded from the study if they have any of the following: Underweight, Overweight or Obese. Epilepsy , kidney problems that make them taking hormonal treatments or drugs affect bone density or taking calcium, vitamin D, steroids during 6 months prior to the study. Fracture in the measurement areas. Hip Flexion deformity more than 30° when posed to measure. Internal metallic fixations in the measurement areas (neck of femur and lumber vertebra from L1-L4). Hyperthyroidism or Hypothyroidism. Hypotonia.

This study proposes to develop and validate two new imaging biomarkers, which are measures that reflect the impact of sulpiride on striatal brain regions to assess dopamine function in health and in schizophrenia. These biomarkers will help to understand how changes in dopamine are related to the working of the brain, and to improve the treatment of schizophrenia-related symptoms such as cognitive deficits, negative symptoms and social cognition. This project will contribute to the identification of biomarkers that can help in the development of new antipsychotic medications and treatments in schizophrenia that can specifically target dopamine changes.
Over 50% of all psychiatric patients suffer from symptoms such as poor attention, impaired working memory, cognitive slowness and decreased motivation. Cognitive symptoms are resistant to currently available antipsychotics. The dopamine system plays a crucial role in cognitive functions like working memory and attentional control. Dopamine is a chemical transmitter that helps the brain to select and maintain working memory representations. Drugs that block dopamine at specific cortical and sub-cortical brain structures have been found to improve cognitive deficits when added to standard antipsychotics.
The main objective of this study is to develop and validate new brain imaging biomarkers that will give us a better understanding of the impact of the new drug compound sulpiride on dopamine transmission.
