Current laboratory guidelines recommend measuring serum TSH levels to monitor thyroid hormone status in hypothyroid patients using levothyroxine. This is a widely used indicator to determine the dosage and efficacy of thyroid hormone therapy. However, the interpretation of TSH results in a large group of patients using levothyroxine causes difficulty for their physicians. For hypothyroid patients with Hashimoto's hypothyroidism, it is advised to have TSH values within the reference interval; for patients with hypothyroidism due to total thyroidectomy, a suppressed TSH is required. In patients with hypothyroidism due to Graves' disease, the TSH concentration must be slightly suppressed with a suppressed TSH (i.e. at low concentrations). Despite these different requirements for TSH, fT4 concentrations are often measured in a majority of the patients to ensure treatment efficacy. A higher fT4 level is also seen in the majority of the patients using levothyroxine. These high fT4 levels will only cause treatment problems in patients in which a TSH-guided treatment is impossible (e.g. in patients with hypothyroidism due to central disease). This study investigates whether the treatment efficacy of thyroid hormone therapy can be monitored by measuring other thyroid hormone markers and ratios of these markers. Thyroid hormone markers as total T4 (TT4), total T3 (TT3), rT3, SHBG, acylcarnitines and several amino acids will be assessed and compared to outcomes in healthy controls. This study also includes participants with hypothyroidism using L-T4 with 'normal' TSH to see whether other thyroid hormone markers can indicate thyroid status.

Hip fractures are a common injury in the elderly, especially in the institutionalized population. A large group of patients is not suitable for surgery and benefits more from palliative care. Nonoperative treatment can be the preferred solution for these patients, but little use is currently made of this.
The project aims to improve the treatment decision by shared decision making, which will lead to more nonoperative treatments. Through interviews and a large cohort study in the last 2 years 118 of 193 patients opted for nonoperative treatment. These patients have equal quality of life compared to patients who opted for an operative treatment. Quality of dying was rated as good by the next of kin.
The project team has an extensive network of orthopedic specialists and geriatricians in the Netherlands, which will support the implementation.
In phase 2, the PNOM protocol will be enriched, educational modules will be developed for residents of Orthopedics, information sessions will be organized at scientific conferences and the final PNOM protocol can be put in place. Subsequently, two selected hospitals will be installed as a pilot for an implementation PNOM.
In phase 3, all other hospitals that treat the selected patient group must participate. It is estimated that 1000 patients per year will be approached and that half of these patients will prefer non-operative treatment. This approach leads to a 15% decrease in the number of hip surgeries. This is likely to be a cost saving for the health care system.
In the third and fourth phase, the PNOM project team will support the implementation of the PNOM protocol. The support will range from training sessions, to support in the implementation process, to advice on management. It is expected that this support will lead to an increase in the use of nonoperative treatment for the selected group.
Finally, a process evaluation will be carried out to assess the effectiveness of the implementation process in which all steps from awareness raising and training to successful implementation was documented.
It is expected that this project will result in patients receiving a treatment that meets their needs at the end of their life.
This is a collaborative project of the Zuyderland Medical Center, University Medical Center Groningen and Maastricht UMC+
This is a project of the Top Sector Life Sciences & Health, financed by the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs.
This project is also co-financed by Zuyderland Medical Center, MUMC+, UMCG.

Treatment for patients diagnosed with glioblastoma is sub-optimal because of two main issues: (1) Creating an accurate target volume for radiotherapy, a key aspect of glioblastoma treatment, containing all remaining tumour cells after surgery that is impossible with the conventional CT and MRI imaging techniques currently used and (2) in the follow-up of patients after radiotherapy, conventional MRI is incapable of distinguishing tumour progression from treatment effects. The solution to these issues lies in accurate and non-invasive assessment of physiological processes of tumour cells to enable delineation of the true physiological clinical target volume (CTV) for radiotherapy planning and to allow for early detection of true tumour progression during treatment follow-up. Therefore, the rationale behind this project is to generate proof-of-concept of using a physiological CTV for radiotherapy treatment planning for patients with brain tumours. By extending the clinical standard MRI session used for radiotherapy planning in patients diagnosed with glioblastoma with advanced MRI techniques that assess oxygenation status and cell proliferation, a physiological CTV will be generated for each patient in addition to the standard CTV. Treatment for each patient will be according to the current standard in which the standard CTV is used. Initial analysis will include comparing both CTVs in terms of volume and location. Patients will follow the clinical standard, including the standard MRI scan protocols, for a maximum of 2 years. Pattern-of-failure analysis will be done to compare the standard CTV and physiological CTV. It is hypothesized that the physiological CTV will be smaller than the standard CTV, whilst having the same pattern-of-failure.

Since the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic, immunosuppressive drugs used for treating Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) patients could lead to an increased susceptibility to severe Corona Virus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). The use of Autologous Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (AHSCT) for SSc patients could therefore lead to worsened COVID-19 infections due to severe immunity impairment. It is therefore crucial to assess the incidence and severity of COVID-19 after AHSCT as compared to non-AHSCT SSc patients. The SOLID study will explore the proportion of vaccine refusal in Systemic Sclerosis patients previously treated by AHSCT and in non-transplant controls. It will also assess the cumulative incidence of asymptomatic or symptomatic COVID-19 infection after AHSCT as compared to non AHSCT SSc patients. It will investigate the severity of the disease, measured by the care received by each patient. The study will also describe SARS-CoV-2 specific humoral immunity and the rate and nature of adverse events observed in both populations.

Children and adolescents with overweight and obesity may have unhealthy diet quality. Improving diet quality is essential for treating obesity but time and knowledge can delay access to nutrition recommendations by pediatric providers. Text-based interventions might be able to improve fruit and vegetable intake of adolescents, however, it is unknown if digital interventions are effective for improving diet quality in adolescents with overweight or obesity.

Aims: To show that a digital-based diet quality intervention for adolescents with overweight or obesity is feasible by demonstrating that participants complete study procedures and retention rates are acceptable. Participants will also complete two 24-hr dietary recalls, one for their first morning void, and wear a continuous glucose monitor (CGM). 

Study design: Two-arm pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT). One hundred and forty adolescents between 14-17 y/o who have overweight or obesity and a history of overweight or obesity will be invited to participate. Measurements will be taken in the clinical research center and the home. Participants will be randomized to receive the intervention or no intervention.

For the first aim, the primary hypothesis is that participants randomized to the intervention will achieve a greater overall diet quality than participants randomized to the control group (no intervention) as assessed by change in HEI-2020 between baseline and end of study measurements on primary and secondary outcome measures (24-hr dietary recalls, urine sodium to potassium ratio, and glucose profiles).

For the second aim, an important hypothesis is that participants randomized to the intervention will achieve a greater change in urinary sodium to potassium ratio between baseline and end of study measurements compared to participants randomized to the control group as assessed by change in urine sodium to potassium ratio and HEI dietary components.

Based on prior reports, we anticipate an 11% increase in HEI, and 30% difference in urinary Na to K. To achieve these findings, we will need a total N of 14 to 15 and an estimated retention rate of 81%. This study aligns with the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) Recommendation 10.16 to encourage a 20-50 kg weight loss for children with obesity who are treated in inpatient settings.

Cerebral autoregulation (CA) is the ability of the brain to maintain a stable level of cerebral blood flow (CBF) despite changes in systemic blood pressure (BP). There are two main cerebral autoregulation pathways that have a significant impact on CBF: the myogenic pathway, which acts through the endothelium and smooth muscle of cerebral arteries, and the metabolic pathway, which acts through local CO2 levels and extracellular fluid.
The mechanisms of CA have been studied in the cerebral artery by using techniques such as transcranial Doppler (TCD), transcranial near-infrared spectroscopy (TNS), laser Doppler flowmetry (LDF), and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). These techniques have demonstrated that the myogenic and metabolic autoregulation pathways have opposite response patterns during acute BP changes, which means that the myogenic pathway tends to constrain blood vessels when BP is high, while the metabolic pathway tends to vasodilate blood vessels when BP is low. The metabolic pathway is known to have a rapid response compared to the myogenic pathway, which tends to have a slower response time. CA is also influenced by various diseases and conditions, such as brain tumors, cerebral aneurysms, stroke, trauma, and headache.
Hyperperfusion is an increase in blood flow and pressure associated with a decrease in arteriolar resistance. It is often thought of as an indicator of abnormal autoregulation.
Some studies have indicated increased incidence of CH in carotid revascularisation. These results are related to incomplete restoration of CA after carotid revascularisation. In most previous studies, the incidence of CH varied between 2.8% and 24.8%. The cause may be due to carotid revascularisation-induced cerebral hemodynamics disorder.
For the risk factor that cannot be corrected, the only effective treatment is the early detection and prevention of CA. Therefore, the present study is aimed at improving the early detection and early prevention of CA, thus to reduce the incidence of CH after CAS.
Understanding these mechanisms and determining the most effective autoregulation pathways to regulate CBF, clinicians can optimize cerebral hemodynamics in patients receiving CAS.
In this study, we will try to find the risk factor of CH after carotid revascularisation, the early detection of CA in patients undergoing carotid revascularization, thereby reducing the incidence of CH after carotid revascularisation.
If you have any questions during this study, you can contact the study organizer or the study manager at any time.

A diagnosis of cancer reverberates throughout the family. Family caregivers take on a wide range of responsibilities, such as monitoring medical symptoms, communicating with the patient's medical team, managing insurance claims, providing transportation, and assisting with activities of daily living. Psychological distress is common. Caregivers often feel unprepared for their role, and socially isolated from others. Physical impacts have also been documented, from fatigue to sleep disturbance to immune dysfunction. To alleviate some of these difficult sequelae of cancer caregiving, we propose to test the utility of a brief, low-cost, non-pharmacologic, behavioral intervention for persons providing care for a loved one with cancer. Specifically, we will test the effects of an expressive writing (EW) intervention. The basic paradigm asks participants to write for 20 minutes on four separate occasions about a trauma or stressor. Initial work conducted with undergraduate samples showed benefit of EW. Since then, EW studies have been conducted across a variety of populations including persons coping with chronic illness. Benefits have ranged from better lung function among asthmatics to fewer physical symptoms among women with breast cancer. One meta-analysis of 146 studies across 10,994 participants reported positive effect sizes (mental or physical health benefits) for 102 of the studies (70%). Notable gaps in this literature include testing with cancer caregivers (with some exceptions) and use of novel delivery formats. Specific aims are: (1) To examine the effects of a group-based, videoconference-delivered EW program on emotional, social, and physical well-being among informal caregivers of persons diagnosed with cancer; (2) To identify social and linguistic mechanisms by which participation in the group-based EW intervention may improve distress; and (3) To identify potential moderators of benefit including age, gender identity, relationship to the patient, and baseline social constraints.

The investigators propose a prospective, single surgeon randomized controlled trial that investigates the use of intravenous tranexamic acid (TXA) in patients undergoing gender affirming mastectomy (GAM).
Gender affirming mastectomy is a life-changing and life-saving procedure that is being performed more often and for an increasingly diverse population. It is well documented that GAM improves mental health and decreases the risk for associated cancers in transwomen. As part of gender affirming care, surgical correction of a masculine breast is often the first and only procedure transwomen are willing to undergo. Complications such as hematoma and seroma formation are a significant concern for patients and surgeons post-operatively.
The investigators will randomize patients undergoing gender affirming mastectomy into two groups: an experimental group receiving intravenous TXA and a control group receiving standard care without TXA. The investigators will assess the presence of hematoma, clinical signs of seroma, and total aggregate drain output to determine the effect of TXA on post-operative bleeding, hematoma, and seroma. The investigators will also assess for thromboembolic events and wound complications. These outcomes will be evaluated in the immediate 3-month post-operative period, with a 1-year follow-up review of patient charts to capture long-term complications.
Patient benefit with the use of TXA will be most significant in terms of decreasing the rate of post-operative hematomas, seromas, and delayed drain removal, all of which have been previously demonstrated to improve with the use of TXA in breast surgery. If the investigators' hypothesis is correct, the investigators' data will provide a compelling argument for the routine use of TXA in patients undergoing gender affirming mastectomy.

This trial aims to investigate the efficacy of smell training and trigeminal nerve stimulation for persistent smell loss after COVID infection across a 4-week and 12-week time frame.

Inclusion criteria:
Patients must be treatment-seeking for persistent smell loss, have a normal sense of smell prior to COVID, and be naïve to both smell training and trigeminal nerve stimulation. They must be able to provide informed consent, speak and read English, and not currently use any medications that affect their sense of smell. Participants should have a positive PCR-based test for COVID-19 after the development of smell loss.

Exclusion criteria:
History of head injury, presence of a sinonasal condition, neurological disorder, mental illness, or heavy smoking is grounds for exclusion. Individuals who have used oral or nasal steroids or other intranasal medications within the last month, are pregnant or trying to become pregnant, or are immunomodulated are also excluded.

Participation in this trial will have no adverse effects on participants.

Rituximab is one of the most active agents in the treatment of B-cell lymphoma, including splenic marginal zone lymphoma (SMZL). Rituximab combined with chemotherapy improves outcome (progression-free and overall survival) in patients with follicular lymphoma and B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia. However, there is still uncertainty in the management of patients with SMZL, especially in the presence of high-risk features. This is partly due to the fact that the clinical course of SMZL is very heterogeneous. Previous studies in patients with SMZL have reported 5-year overall survival rates between 43-65% in patients with no specific treatment. Zanubrutinib is a potent and selective Bruton Tyrosine Kinase (BTK) inhibitor with high response rates and favourable safety profile in Mantle Cell Lymphoma. BTK has recently been reported to be expressed in SMZL and also identified as the driver kinase of B-cell receptor (B-cell receptor)- mutated non-follicular non-GCB lymphoma, including SMZL.
This study will evaluate, in a prospective randomized trial, whether treatment with zanubrutinib (with or without rituximab) results in an improvement in Progression-Free Survival (PFS) compared to treatment with rituximab alone in patients with previously untreated symptomatic splenic marginal zone lymphoma. Based on previous data, a superiority in 3-year PFS of 30% of zanubrutinib compared to rituximab alone is hypothesized. The study will include approximately 120 participants. The study will have separate co-primary endpoints defined as 1) PFS defined as the time from randomization to progression (according to Lugano 2014 criteria) or death from any cause; and 2) PFS according to Matutes criteria, which include only splenic MZL. The safety profile of the combination will be described and compared with the standard treatment with rituximab. The trial will be carried out in different European countries.

According to our knowledge, this will be the first randomized controlled trial comparing ultrasound guided SAPB versus thoracic epidural in pain control for thoracotomy. Patients with cancer will be enrolled in our study and will be randomized into two groups. Before induction of anesthesia, the ultrasound image will be obtained with the help of linear transducer probe and an on laying patient with the diseased side of the patient up. The 5th rib is identified in the mid-axillary line. The following muscles are overlying the rib latissimusdorsi ,teres major, and serratus muscle. The needle (22 G, 50-mm Tuohy needle) is introduced in-plane targeting the plane superficial to serratus muscle. Local anesthetic injection is done when the needle is withdrawn back to the subcutaneous layer after injection of local anesthetic, followed by a catheter is threaded subcutaneously. The catheter is secured with sterile gloves and the area of the catheter and skin is covered with sterile dressing and the ends of the dressing are secured with surgical sutures. Intraoperatively, the patients receive general anesthesia with thoracic epidural catheter insertion. Postoperatively, the patients in both groups will be monitored for vital signs while they are transferred to intensive care unit. The same measurements including pain scores, analgesia requirement, and side effects will be done. The investigative plan of the trial is as follows:
Inclusion Criteria: Patients older than 18 years with a diagnosis of pleural or lung cancer undergoing curative surgery (Lobectomy, Pneumonectomy, or Decortification). ASA physical status class II and III. Body mass index (BMI) > 20 kg/m2 and < 40 kg/m2.
Exclusion Criteria: The patient refusal, Known sensitivity or contraindication to local anesthetics. History of psychological disorders. Localized infection at the site of block. Coagulopathies with a platelet count below 50,000 or an INR>1.5: hereditary (e.g. hemophilia, fibrinogen abnormalities & deficiency of factor II) - acquired (e.g. impaired liver functions with PC less than 60 %, vitamin K deficiency &therapeutic anticoagulants drugs),History of unexplained or easy bruising and Prolonged bleeding from small cuts or after dental procedures, patients need prolonged mechanical ventilation postoperatively excluded from our study. failed blocks will be excluded from our study.

<|assistant|> Background: The Pediatric Intensive Care Unit (PICU) serves as the frontline of pediatric healthcare, providing life-supporting medical care for seriously ill patients. While this intense care has led to more children surviving critical illness, it leads to a significant number of adverse events, long-term complications, and a period of time when families are not able to engage with or support their ill child. Research studies have shown that these adverse health outcomes can be significantly decreased when parents are actively engaged in care decisions and the emotional experience of their child’s hospitalization. However, the PICU can be a distressing and overwhelming place for families, and it can be difficult to find ways to engage them in their child’s care. Currently, medical teams do not have a system in place to support parent engagement in their child’s PICU experience. Furthermore, there is a lack of research investigating parent engagement in high-risk, acute care medical settings. The first step in addressing this gap is to work with families during their time in the PICU to create a journal that serves as a tool for parents and pediatric healthcare teams to communicate with one another and support the family's coping, caregiving, and self-care needs. Objectives: 1. Identify parental and child needs that can be met within the PICU to support coping, caregiving, and self-care needs. 2. Creation and evaluation (via pilot trial) of a journal that allows family members to communicate and express emotions to their child's care team. 3. Evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of using this journal with the child's care team. Background: People with Autism Experience Differential Access to Therapy and Research
Those with autism experience different outcomes across the lifespan because many interventions were developed based on White populations. Even interventions targeted at autistic communities have been tested using primarily White participants. The outcomes and effectiveness of these interventions are not generalizable to Hispanic and Latino populations. Understanding cultural and contextual factors that influence the use of and engagement with research is essential to developing effective interventions.
Objectives: The long-term objective of this project is to improve the health and well-being of Hispanic/Latino autistic children by engaging in stakeholder engagement to improve utilization of the evidence based autism intervention Ayres Sensory Integration and to improve stakeholder engagement in the research process from conceptualization to dissemination for effective outcomes. The specific aims of this project are:
1. Compare stakeholder engagement effectiveness of Design Thinking (DT) and Focus Groups (FG) using Stakeholder Engagement Evaluation measures (PCORI areas of stakeholder engagement) in engagement of Hispanic/Latino autistic individuals, parents, caregivers, OTs, teachers, and cultural experts.
2. Adapt two versions of the Ayres Sensory Integration intervention protocols (one based on FG and another based on DT data) to create culturally appropriate information to engage Hispanic/Latino stakeholders in research and treatment for therapeutic services.
3. Evaluate the Acceptability and Feasibility of the adapted intervention manuals using the Acceptability and Feasibility of Intervention Measure (AIM), Intervention Appraisal Measure (IAM), and the Feasibility of Intervention Measure (FIM).

Study Design: The study design is a randomized mixed methods design with two primary aims. The first aim compares the effectiveness of Design Thinking (DT) and Focus Groups (FG) on stakeholder engagement via the PCORI engagement principles, and the second aim compares the acceptability and feasibility of the two versions of the intervention protocols (one based on FG and another based on DT data).

Study Population: The study participants include Hispanic/Latino participants with autism, parents/caregivers, occupational therapists, teachers, and cultural experts.

Intervention: Participants will be invited to participate in either DT or FG to provide input on therapies for Hispanic/Latino autistic individuals. For Phase two of this study, participants will be invited to participate in a follow-up study to evaluate the acceptability and feasibility of the adapted intervention manual for Hispanic/Latino individuals and their families.

Study Procedures: Phase one will consist of a stakeholder engagement session using two methods: Design Thinking (DT) or Focus Group (FG). Participants will learn about the project, provide input using the Stakeholder-Centric Engagement Evaluation (SCEE), and participate in either DT or FG. Phase two will consist of adaption of the information provided to create culturally-appropriate intervention protocols for Hispanic/Latino individuals and their families. Participants will provide input on the acceptability and feasibility of the adapted intervention manual.

Outcomes: Primary Outcome Measure: The study evaluates two measures: Stakeholder-Centric Engagement Evaluation measures using a Likert scale and evaluating the acceptability and feasibility of intervention using the AIM, IAM, and FIM using a Likert response scale. Secondary Outcome Measures include the Demographics and Background Survey (DSBS), the Quality of Life in Autism (QOL-A), and the Occupational Therapy Engagement Scale (OTES) that is completed by participants.

Project Significance: This project addresses significant public health issues in autism treatment delivery and engagement in research and treatment interventions among Hispanic/Latino families. The study may identify strategies for engaging minority stakeholders in research, thereby increasing their utilization of and confidence in the interventions and services provided. The developed therapeutic protocols and intervention manuals will provide culturally-specific guidelines for engaging this underserved and growing population with autism with therapy services and research participation. The results will improve the health of Hispanic/Latino autistic children and guide future clinicians and researchers in effectively engaging minority stakeholders in research and treatment programs that ultimately result in improved health outcomes.

Official Title
-----------------
Testing Design Thinking Methodology to Engage Hispanic and Latino Families of Autistic Children in Research.

Conditions
-----------------
Autism Spectrum Disorder, Patient Engagement

Intervention / Treatment

Adult smokers who are seeking methods to quit smoking that they like can use nicotine replacement therapy, such as a nicotine patch or nicotine gum, or they can switch to e-cigarettes. This study will examine the impact of these approaches by evaluating the effectiveness of these options as first and second line smoking cessation interventions. A total of 500 adult smokers who are unable to quit with 28-days of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) will be randomized to one of four interventions as their second line therapy: a) a nicotine pouch (Bruguiera); b) a nicotine lozenge; c) nicotine gum; and d) a BIDI e-cigarette. It is hypothesized that the nicotine pouch will be superior to the other three options for the treatment of tobacco dependence.

The purpose of this study is to demonstrate that the Remote EEG Monitoring System (REMI) will be able to record EEG data that clinicians can use to identify ictal events over extended periods, and that extended clinical EEG data is valuable in the diagnosis and treatment of seizure related symptoms.

Study Arm: Device
Participants may be prescribed a REMI system, which will be equipped with epilepsy-specific hardware and software to enable clinical EEG data monitoring via electrodes to be transmitted wirelessly to a mobile phone or home WiFi network, thence to a secure cloud-based server. EEG data captured by the REMI system will be transmitted and archived for later review. After a fourteen (14) to twenty-eight (28) day study period, patients will undergo a routine clinical EEG test, and both the REMI data and the clinical EEG data will be evaluated to allow comparison between EEG methods.

Fasting: preoperative fasting remains one of the main rules observed before a surgical procedure. The implementation of this rule limits perioperative fluid and nutrient intake. However, these constraints can cause patient's inconvenience and anxiety as well as discomfort. In the perioperative period, this fasting is associated with a high rate of postoperative complications, with an increase of postoperative nausea and vomiting without any benefit. In practice, the duration of fasting before surgery remains arbitrarily determined, despite a trend to an increase of preoperative fasting. In 2016, the French society of anesthetists and intensive care (Société Française d'Anesthésie et de Réanimation) proposed a guideline about preoperative fasting with a clear indication of solid and liquid oral intake before daytime surgery. However, a retrospective study about preoperative fasting was done before the implementation of this guideline. There are thus no data on the evolution of preoperative fasting after this sensitization campaign, except some retrospective studies in emergency surgery. This study aims to observe (before-after) the duration of fasting (solid or liquid) before daytime surgery in patients admitted to general surgery or gynecology surgery departments in 2 French hospitals. Additionally, the team will investigate the influence of preoperative fasting on patient's anxiety and discomfort and the quality of recovery after surgery.

This community-based randomized controlled trial targets 7th grade students in rural Appalachia to determine the effectiveness of the Mentored Planning to be Active (MPBA) plus Family for physical activity, exercise behaviors, and body composition. Having teens deliver intervention content via structured peer mentoring increases social support and motivation, thereby promoting self-regulation and sustainability to improve health behaviors, especially during adolescence when overweight/obesity in adolescents is rising at an alarming rate. Over the course of two years, 309 children suffering from overweight and obesity will be randomly assigned to receive MPBA+F (n=155) or self-regulation support in both rural and urban Appalachian counties. The long-term goal is to reduce the high rates of overweight and obesity-related diabetes in Appalachia youth.
The study will be conducted during 2019 and 2020 and is composed of 3 data collection phases: the fall (Phase 1), the winter, spring, and summer (Phase 2), and the winter, spring, and summer of the following school year (Phase 3). Phase 1: Children will be recruited during the first 6-1/2 weeks of 7th grade and will undergo one-time data collection to obtain medical histories, height measurements, weight measurements, blood pressure, and blood sample collections. They will also answer questionnaires about their physical activity behaviors. Parents will be asked to provide information about their child's family demographics, home environment, medical history, and family health behaviors. Phase 2: Children will receive either 10 weekly MPBA plus Family sessions or 10 self-regulated health support sessions. Children will be monitored for physical activity minutes (using accelerometers), physical activity behaviors, body composition, blood pressure, and blood samples collected again, as well as answer questionnaires about their behaviors and health. Phase 3: Half of the families will receive a 6-month 'Health and Fitness' rewards-based self-regulation program for child participants. Changes in study outcomes (physical activity, self-efficacy, self-regulation, health behaviors, weight status, and blood pressure) will be measured using interviews, accelerometers, and questionnaires. At the end of the 2-year study period, the investigators compare outcomes for children who received MPBA+F, the comparison condition (self-regulation arm), and usual care (those who do not receive any intervention). Long-term effects on PA outcomes and body composition are explored by analyzing child outcomes between early fall (Phase 1) and the end of child's 8th-grade year (Phase 3), comparing subgroup differences on effects by early fall, later fall, or winter, spring, and summer (child's 1st semester of 7th grade). Comparing the outcomes of peer mentors (intervention condition) and peer mentees (comparison condition) will reveal the effects of the intervention on adolescent health behavior changes. Analyses will also compare children who received the 6-month family reinforcement program to those who did not, with subgroup comparisons by age, biological sex, or baseline weight status. The investigators will also compare child outcomes to those of parents, and compare health outcomes between child participants. The results will provide guidance for future intervention development and the integration of peer mentoring for promoting healthy habits among youth at risk.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common opportunistic infection in China and a major factor leading to liver transplant recipients’ poor prognosis. In order to obtain relevant epidemiology data of CMV and its clinical features in liver transplant recipients, we will evaluate the patients enrolled in this study prospectively. Our results may provide some clinical guidance for clinicians to prevent and control CMV-related diseases in such population. The subjects of the study are liver transplant recipients in seven high volume liver transplantation centers in China. By collecting baseline and clinicopathological features, and laboratory tests when patients are hospitalized, we will observe CMV-related outcomes including the incidence of CMV reactivation, CMV disease, the death risk within the first year after liver transplantation, as well as the rates of graft rejection and other infections. Meanwhile, we will also assess the effects of the different CMV prophylaxis and treatment strategies on CMV outcomes and survival.

Project Summary/Abstract:
Cognitive deficits after right brain stroke, such as impaired spatial cognition and lack of attention to the left side of space, cause significant functional disability, and can be mistaken for inattention or laziness. The principal goal of cognitive rehabilitation is restoration of function to improve quality of life. This project targets the right brain stroke syndrome of spatial neglect (SN), defined as damaged control of left visual space, which accounts for 12-55% of stroke survivors in inpatient rehabilitation units. Individuals with SN are 50% less likely to return home, and half of SN survivors lose their license after stroke. A personalized approach to SN rehabilitation must balance three factors: i) accurate diagnosis of SN (many stroke survivors do not have this diagnosis), ii) efficient administration of effective treatments, iii) cost-efficient care delivery. There is a pressing need for this personalized approach to restore function and independence for Veterans with SN.
The purpose of the research is to determine if a validated clinical predictor of effective SN rehabilitation can be identified from routine clinical data, in order to guide clinical decision-making about which survivors should receive this specialized treatment. The investigators have recently published on the predictive value for recovery of functional independence after rehabilitation of a clinical index (the Existence of Aiming Spatial Neglect) and of neuroimaging, specifically disconnection of dorsolateral frontal and right thalamocortical regions. Here, the researchers have two specific aims. (1) To develop a brain imaging biomarker which indicates the highest likelihood of having SN that affects movement, action and planning, and (2) to determine how these biomarkers can help to predict improvement in daily life function after receiving prism adaptation therapy. Based on our previous work, the investigators predict that this clinical index will be an effective predictor of PAT rehabilitation outcomes, which could translate to improved quality of life after stroke. The investigators have developed PAT for stroke survivors, resulting in the largest collection of PAT outcome data, and have identified a clinical index of PAT outcome prediction based on the presence of Aiming SN. The goal of this proposal is therefore to identify a validated biomarker of the presence of Aiming SN, to determine if including brain imaging biomarkers refines this clinical index of PAT outcome response. The investigators' preliminary findings suggest that subcortical disconnection is the defining attribute of Aiming SN. Thus, the investigators expect to find a strong correlation between Aiming SN and the disconnection of frontal regions with subcortical and parietal regions. These neural biomarkers are needed to support a clinical trial examining the impact of PAT on outcome, to be submitted to the VA National Center for Rehabilitation Trauma and Stressor Related Disorders.

The purpose of this study is to see if blood samples, specifically the free circulating DNA, can be used as a "laboratory biopsy" in patients with brain tumours. This is a pilot study with a maximum of 40 participants to explore the association between the concentration of free circulating DNA in the blood and the tumour in the brain tissue, as well as to establish a reference value for this measurement, taking into account the grade of this tumour (oligodendroglioma or astrocytoma). The blood sample will be obtained through direct puncture or through a peripheral venous cannula with a maximum diameter of 16 gauge in a vein of the right arm, and the analysis will be specifically performed by ddPCR. All patients participating in this study should provide written informed consent.

Background: It has been hypothesized that immune checkpoint blockade could prevent the fibrotic transformation of resected low-risk PDAC, prevent disease progression, and reduce the incidence of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula in BRPC or LAPC patients that undergo a partial pancreatectomy. There is some evidence to suggest that such resections may have less incidence of pancreatic fibrosis than the standard removal of the whole organ (Whipple's Procedure) for LAPC patients. However, this evidence is insufficient to make any definitive conclusions. Additionally, the long-term outcome of patients has been limited to small cohorts. There is a need to further characterize these patients to identify prognostic markers. Therefore, this is a pilot study that aims to provide preliminary efficacy data to support the design of a future larger Phase IIb study to evaluate the role of adjuvant zimberelimab and quemliclustat in patients with borderline resectable or locally advanced pancreatic cancer. Research Design: The study is a Phase Ib, multicenter, open-label single group, pilot study. The study participants will be treated with zimberelimab, a CD73 inhibitor (antigenic CD73 is highly expressed on immature T cells), in combination with intravenous (IV) chemotherapy, including modified FOLFIRINOX (mFFX) comprising fluorouracil, leucovorin calcium, oxaliplatin, and inrinotecan, and with quemliclustat, an inhibitor of α(1,3) glucan. The first 6 patients enrolled in Part A are treated on a lead-in dose escalation of zimberelimab orally, at a starting dose of 80 mg twice a day (BID), and given intravenous (IV) chemotherapy (oxaliplatin, IV leucovorin calcium, and IV fluorouracil). For patients enrolled in Part A, the dose of zimberelimab will be escalated by doubling in successive cohorts, using a Bayesian adaptive cohort design, to obtain a dose to be studied in Part B, which is 160 mg twice a day (BID). In Part B, up to 19 additional patients will be enrolled to receive the recommended phase IIb dose (RP2Bd) of zimberelimab, 160 mg twice a day (BID), in combination with IV chemotherapy. Patients will also undergo biospecimen collections, including blood and tissue samples, for exploratory translational studies. It is expected that all enrolled eligible patients will continue to receive the same dose level of zimberelimab and chemotherapy until disease progression. During the second year of the study, additional 30 to 50 patients with locally advanced PDAC will be enrolled in Part B. Up to 18 additional patients will be enrolled to receive the RP2Bd of zimberelimab and chemotherapy. It is anticipated that all enrolled eligible patients in Part B will continue to receive the same dose level of zimberelimab and chemotherapy until disease progression. During the third year of the study, an additional 36 BRPC patients are enrolled on the combination of zimberelimab, quemliclustat, and chemotherapy over a 3-year period. It is anticipated that during these three years of the study, investigators will collect up to 120 tissue samples.

Cardiovascular diseases (CVD) are the first cause of death in the world. It is well recognized that probiotics are safe and effective in treating several diseases. Several studies supported the use of probiotic for depression, with some studies showing significant improvement. Depression is the most common psychiatric problems among hemodialysis patients, with a high prevalence of over 40%. The purpose of this study is to assess the effect of probiotics on depression syndrome and risk factors of cardiovascular disease in hemodialysis patients.
                This is an interventional study and the patients will be randomized either to probiotics or no probiotics. The patients will take probiotic, MIYAIRI 588, or no probiotics for 3 months.
                The probiotics, MIYAIRI 588, contains B. lactis HN019 and Pediococcus acidilactici PAC 1.0. MIYAIRI 588 has been demonstrated to have neuroprotection and neuropsychotic benefit by inducing the generation of new neurons. The patients in this study are taking MIYAIRI 588 1 packet 3 times daily before dinner.
                Inclusion Criteria. Eligible are subjects who are aged 20 years or over, who are undergoing hemodialysis (more than 3 months, 3 times per week, and ultra-filtration rate ≥65%). Exclusion Criteria are subjects with allergy to the probiotic component or those who have clinically significant cardiovascular comorbidity, infectious complications, active malignancy, psychosis, hypersensitivity or any history of allergy to milk.
                Depression will be assessed by a psychiatrist using the Chinese version of Beck Depression Inventory and Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale. In addition, the presence of hyperlipemia, hypertension, body mass index, level of anxiety, depression, and inflammation will be examined.
                This trial could provide new perspective on the treatment of hemodialysis patients and open new avenue for using probiotics in hemodialysis patients.

We will recruit and retain college-aged adults (age 18-24) to participate in a preliminary clinical trial of a 12-week Internet-delivered CM-PST intervention. The intervention, CM-PST, will integrate positive psychology with CM, and will thus be called CM + Positive.

We will recruit participants with Alcohol Use Disorder between age 18 and 24 years and who have met DSM criteria for AUD in the past year at the entry clinic. Participants will complete written informed consent and, if eligible, an interview with a study psychologist to screen for AUD using the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5.

After screening, participants will be invited to participate in one 30-minute baseline session at the UIC Clinical Lab. In that session, participants will complete baseline self-report measures, consent to a separate MRI session the following week, and receive the standard CM assessment and feedback. Participants will also undergo standard neuroimaging procedures to establish baseline brain activation patterns. Following this baseline session, participants will begin treatment that will entail 8 CM-PST individual sessions over 12 weeks.

Prior to the first CM-PST individual session, participants will attend an orientation-instruction session that will review the CM-PST procedures, including how to participate in videoconferences, how to use the computerized treatment procedures, and the study guidelines and requirements. Subsequent to Orientation-Instruction, participants will participate in 8 CM-PST individual sessions weekly via videoconference. In each of these 8 CM-PST sessions, participants will learn how to solve problems that elicit drinking and how to apply problem-solving skills to other activities that elicit drinking. In CM-PST, participants will receive incentives for alcohol abstinence and submission of urine samples twice per week. For each such sample that the participant does not report consuming alcohol and/or illicit drugs, the participant will earn a $5 gift card toward their incentive total.

To assess feasibility and acceptability of CM-PST, we will collect data on participants’ satisfaction, acceptability, and feasibility of the treatment procedures using a Client Satisfaction Questionnaire.

This research aims to evaluate the effect of high fidelity and virtual reality based simulation applications on simulation-based learning, reflective thinking and therapeutic communication skills in undergraduate nursing students. As a result of the research, it is aimed to determine the effect of virtual reality based simulation applications applied to students on reflection and therapeutic communication skills, by examining the effects of high fidelity and virtual reality based simulation applications that provide experiences similar to practice on students' simulation-based learning skills. To this end, the researchers will apply the Simulation-Based Learning Scale, the Reflective Thinking Skills for Problem Solving Scale and the Therapeutic Communication Skills Scale to the groups who will receive high fidelity simulation and virtual reality-based simulation and to each group separately. They will evaluate the change scores of the application groups by comparing the values obtained on the scale from the pretest and the posttest with a significant level of 0.05.
The researchers hypothesize that virtual reality-based simulation will be more effective than high-fidelity simulation in terms of learning, reflecting and communication skills.
The universe of the research; It will consist of second-year students studying at Hacettepe University Faculty of Nursing in the 2023-2024 academic year. This study is planned to be carried out within the scope of the project called "High Fidelity and Virtual Reality-Based Simulation Applications on the Professional Practice Skills of Undergraduate Nursing Students" (No: I-2022-490) granted by the Scientific Research Projects Coordination Unit of Hacettepe University.
The study is based on the ethical principles determined in the Nuremberg Code and the Helsinki Declaration. The data to be collected in the research will be used exclusively for scientific purposes. In order for the study to take its place without a conflict of rights of the individual, volunteers need to be made before the research. The volunteers in the research will be informed about the research and its procedures and will be given the opportunity to give their consent to participate in the research.

Each patient has a total of 12 dialyses, 2 series of each two air traps as pairs, and is included up to 30 patients to obtain a sufficient number. All bloodlines are used 4 times, with the exception of the arterial line from the arterial filter of the dialyzer of which only one is used.
Each patient is randomized to perform the first HD either with the standard venous chamber air trap in the venous bloodline (F5008) in the first treatment and the air trap Emboless is used within the F5008 venous chamber tubing set in the second treatment and vice versa.
The outlet side probes counts the micro-bubbles that embolize through the air trap into the returning bloodline of which the numbers will be compared between the two air traps with the help of a comparison function.
All micro-bubbles are counted within the timeframe of 30 minutes. An average value of percentages is calculated regarding to outlet versus inlet numbers and size of microbubbles.
If a significant worse outcome appears, the trial will stop immediately and the patient will change back to the standard air trap. Otherwise the trial continues with the new air trap.
A safety committee will decide to proceed with the next patient when less or equal than 30 patients of 12 patients per patient has been performed.
The study is planned for 1 year to ensure that enough patients will be included so that a sufficient number of dialyses are performed on each air trap.

Background: Pancreaticoduodenectomy, or Whipple procedure, is a pancreatectomy surgery to remove the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, the gallbladder, and the first part of the small intestine. In traditional open surgery, most surgeons prefer to disconnect the pancreas neck in the center of the pancreas at the beginning of the surgery. However, with the development of laparoscopic surgery, researchers found that removing the center part of the pancreas neck can lead to pancreatic fistula after the surgery. On the other hand, a few surgeons would conduct extended pancreatic neck transection during laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy, which was proved to be safe and effective by limited randomized controlled trials. 
Methods/Procedure: 180 patients with benign or resectable malignant tumors were enrolled and randomized into extended transection group or conventional transection group. After operation was accomplished, patients were followed-up for 3 months and 1 year. Pancreatic fistula was defined and graded according to 2008 International Study Group of Pancreatic Surgery criteria, and postoperative morbidity was evaluated by the Clavien-Dindo Score. 
Main results: Pancreatic fistula incidence was 26.30% (18/69) in extended transection group, which was similar to the 28.05% (19/68) in conventional transection group (P = 0.797). The location of the pancreatic duct in the pancreatic transverse section showed no difference between two groups. No pancreatic anastomotic leakage was found during the operation and the follow-up after 3 months (P = 1.000). Pancreatic fistula and the pancreatic anastomotic complication were significantly higher in patients with left-side dissection than right-side dissection of the pancreas (P < 0.05). There was no significant difference between the two groups in terms of other morbidity, postoperative mortality and operative time (P > 0.05).
Conclusion: Extended transection group of pancreatic neck cannot reduce the occurrence of pancreatic fistula, but can improve the success rate of laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy by achieving left-side dissection.

Delirium is a common and distressing disturbance in cognitive function among mechanically ventilated patients admitted to an Intensive Care Unit (ICU). The VR-based sensory stimulation (VRS) intervention effectively reduces the incidence and duration of postoperative delirium and hospitalized general psychiatric patients' psychosis. However, its effect on delirium prevention in ICU patients remains uncertain.
Patients in the ICU are usually exposed to sensory stimuli such as mechanical ventilation, frequent invasive monitoring, and unpredictable events that can lead to delirium. A simple and effective way to reduce exposure to these stimuli is VRS, which can also increase the sensory integration among sensory stimuli in daily life.
Aiming to test the effect of VRS on preventing delirium, this pilot clinical trial compares the effectiveness of the VRS intervention to usual care in ICU-patients.
Delirium-free patients (n = 64) are randomized into two groups, the VRS and usual care groups. Delirium incidence, duration, severity, along with ICU memory, post-traumatic stress disorder, ICU quality of life, and clinical outcomes will be compared between groups.

A retrospective study revealed a 1-year mortality rate of 24% after multiple and long fractured ribs, and patients with multiples rib fractures have a high risk of respiratory, cardiac, and acute lung injuries. Early surgical fixation of fractured ribs is associated with lower incidence and mortality of pneumonia, atelectasis, and delayed pulmonary recovery and reduction of time of respiratory assist with mechanical ventilation. To minimize the morbidity after rib fractures, surgical fixation of multiple and long rib fractures is currently considered in patients who are pre ventilatory.
The primary goal of this study is to determine the outcome of surgical rib fixation versus conservative management. As a secondary goal, we would like to study:
a. The length of ICU hospitalization between the two groups.
b. The length of hospitalization between the two groups.
c. The development of acute lung injury between the two groups.
d. The mechanical ventilation between the two groups.
e. Thoracic and overall pain of the two treatment groups.
a. Mechanical ventilation: the need and duration of mechanical ventilation.
b. Thoracic pain: measure severity of pain using pain scale 0 to10.

This project will compare acute psychological stress responses to the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST) and the Mannheim Multicomponent stress test (MMST). While the TSST is the most widely used stressor protocol, recent literature reviews have concluded that, due to some methodological limitations, not all physiological responses to the TSST were consistent with the SNS stress paradigm. Therefore, the aim of this project is to improve the validity of acute psychological stress tests by using the MMST, which can better measure the impact of mental stress by specifically targeting the SNS response.
                Previous studies have reported significant salivary cortisol rise in response to laboratory stressors. This increase is primarily attributed to exposure to social stimulus (e.g., the TSST) accompanied by speech or arithmetic tasks. However, many investigations reported contradictory findings regarding the magnitude of saliva cortisol response induced by these tasks. Therefore, the project will use a standardized laboratory stressor and measure salivary cortisol response from baseline to peak and to recovery, using standard biochemical techniques (ELISA). In addition, we will assess whether differences in acute cortisol response are associated with trait anxiety, as previous studies showed significant links between trait anxiety and physiological response to social stress.
                Cortisol is a biochemical correlate of the stress response. However, salivary alpha-amylase (sAA) can be another biomarker for the acute stress response. It is a human salivary enzyme, whose activity has been used in the diagnosis of pathological stress (such as depression). Previous studies have shown a positive correlation between sAA and salivary cortisol after psychosocial stress tasks. Therefore, the project will examine the association between sAA and salivary cortisol induced by mental stress to clarify the utility of sAA as a biomarker of acute psychological stress.
                Saliva cortisol and sAA will be used to examine the relationship between psychological stress and the immune response after the stress tests. Some studies showed that an acute psychological stress test can down-regulate the cellular immune response (measuring the natural killer cells activity). However, other studies failed to find significant negative effects of psychological stress on immune function. Therefore, the project will combine two specific immune biomarkers (e.g., natural killer cells activity, cellular proliferation) to examine the long-term (7 days) impact of acute psychological stress on immune function.
                Furthermore, we aim to examine the long-term impact (7 days) of acute psychological stress on the cortisol metabolism by measuring the cortisol free fraction. The cortisol free fraction is the amount of free cortisol (unbound to cortisol binding globulin) in the blood. This ratio is commonly used as a measure of glucocorticoid (GC) activity since the unbound fraction has direct access to GC receptors in the target tissues. Additionally, we will examine the association between acute psychological stress and plasma oxytocin levels. Oxytocin is known as a hormone of social bonding and plays a key role in social interactions (e.g., during pregnancy and lactation).
                We hypothesize that participants performing acute psychological stress will exhibit elevated sAA and cortisol levels in response to the tests. However, due to the small number of previous studies, we expect that the association between sAA and/or cortisol and the immune response of cortisol free fraction, natural killer cells activity and cellular proliferation is not clear at this time.

A high yield condition seen in the pediatric emergency department (ED) is acute elbow pain. The majority of evaluations and treatment interventions for acute pediatric elbow pain involve imaging by radiography. While acute elbow pain is often self-limiting and due to either a distal radial fracture or an elbow subluxation, up to one half of all pediatric elbow evaluations will not identify a fracture on radiography, resulting in significant unnecessary radiation exposure. Therefore, it is imperative to be able to differentiate between these two conditions in children as both have different management plans. In addition, acute distal radial fractures have a high probability of being occult (missing on imaging) when visualization is limited by fracture comminution or subtle findings which are seen on a later imaging exam (CT or MRI). Ultrasound has become one of the most commonly utilized imaging techniques due to its cost effectiveness and availability in the ED. Ultrasound has been shown to accurately detect elbow fractures in adults with good sensitivity and specificity. There are currently no studies using ultrasound to address acute distal radius fractures in children.
Despite the availability of ultrasound in the majority of EDs, there is limited literature on using ultrasound for diagnosing pediatric elbow injuries. The pediatric elbow is a complex area of the body with a small amount of fat between tendons and ligaments and is typically difficult to image with traditional ultrasound techniques. Therefore, the main goal of this study is to determine if a novel pocket-sized ultrasound device called Butterfly IQ is capable of imaging the pediatric elbow and can be used by emergency physicians to detect injury. This study will also determine if pocket-sized ultrasound can be used to differentiate between a distal radial fracture and elbow subluxation. This study will be conducted in an Academic Level 1 Pediatric Hospital Emergency Department. 
Additionally, after enrollment in an open-label trial, eligible children will receive a pocket-sized ultrasound exam and be followed up 2 weeks later for presence of fracture on subsequent imaging. The primary aim of the study is to compare initial test performance characteristics of PSUS evaluated by bedside ultrasound provider on initial imaging compared to subsequent blinded radiology readings of the initial or subsequent x-ray images or bedside nursemaid reduction of participants diagnosed with elbow subluxation/dislocation. The secondary aim is to evaluate the accuracy of pocket sized ultrasound elbow exams compared to Xray in suspected fracture or bedside nursemaid reduction in suspected subluxations.

Hallux valgus is a progressive foot disorder involving the great toe and is characterized by a lateral deviation of the first metatarsal (MT1) and the hallux valgus angle (HVA). The HVA is the angle formed by a line connecting the first metatarsal (MT1) and the proximal phalanx of the hallux in the sagittal plane and a horizontal line tangent to the proximal phalanx. A positive HVA angle is defined when the first metatarsal is tilted laterally and the HVA angle is > 15 degrees. Individuals who have a HVA of < 15 degrees and 15-20 degrees are classified as mild to moderate hallux valgus. Individuals with a HVA of 20-40 degrees are classified as moderate to severe. Individuals with a HVA of > 40 degrees are classified as severe. Hallux valgus with a HVA of > 20 degrees is defined as stage 3. Stage 4, hallux valgus with a HVA of > 40 degrees, is treated through surgery and conservative treatment methods are less preferred. Orthotic devices with proven effectiveness are preferred in the conservative treatment of individuals with hallux valgus. The most commonly used hallux valgus orthoses are the finger separator orthosis and the dynamic orthosis. The finger separator orthosis separates the toes to improve the alignment of the first metatarsal to the third metatarsal, while the dynamic orthosis is a device that uses a free joint to prevent hallux valgus deformity and realign the hallux through a lateral force application on it. Although studies have been conducted on the finger separator orthosis, a comparative study between these two orthoses has not been conducted in the literature. In this study, plantar pressure analysis will be done to compare the effectiveness of finger separator orthosis and dynamic orthosis in mild and moderate hallux valgus deformity. To compare the effectiveness of finger separator orthosis and dynamic orthosis on hallux valgus angle and foot pressure distribution will be evaluated by using AOFAS Foot and Ankle Score form, Manchester-Oxford Foot Questionnaire form, Numerical Evaluation form and Socio-Demographic Evaluation Form will be used.

Background: Children born with cleft palate have an opening at the roof of their mouth, which can cause issues with dental eruption, nasal reflux, and speech. An additional issue is velopharyngeal insufficiency. Children with this condition have difficulty speaking, particularly with the letters s, sh, ch, and the sounds of s and z. In fact, the majority of children with cleft palate are considered to be velopharyngeally incompetent. There are several ways to improve velopharyngeal competency, such as speech therapy and surgery.
Objective: To develop two outcome measures to measure speech function in children with isolated or combined cleft palate after surgery. The measures are the Patient and Parent Response Outcome Measurement, Intelligibility in Context Scale, and CLEFT-Q. This is the first study to test these measurements, which could be used in future research into velopharyngeal competency.
Methods: In this study, the speech function of 65 children will be tested before surgery, and one year and 5 years after surgery. In addition, parents will provide feedback about how they communicate with their children. The study will also examine how often children speak, their general health, and the quality of their speech.
Hypothesis: The project hypothesises that (1) the use of these new outcome measures in children with cleft lip and/or palate will be feasible and valuable both for clinical use and for future research.

<|assistant|> Gambling addiction has often been conceptualized as the result of reward processing dysfunction in the brain, particularly in the striatum, a key structure of the reward system. Although a number of studies have provided support for this hypothesis, neuroimaging studies have produced inconsistent results, suggesting either hypo- or hyper-reactivity to rewards in gambling addiction. These inconsistencies have been the subject of intense debate, but remain unexplained to this day, hampering our understanding of the disease and the development of effective therapeutic strategies. The aim of this project is to test a new neurobiological model of gambling addiction that has the potential to reconcile these inconsistencies. A particular feature of this model is that it takes into account inter-individual differences, as well as the multifactorial nature of gaming addiction. Objectives Primary objective: This project will test the hypothesis that there are two opposite brain phenotypes in gambling addiction: striatal hyper-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hypo-reactivity to emotional stimuli, and striatal hypo-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hyper-reactivity to emotional stimuli. The investigators further hypothesize that these two brain phenotypes characterize two distinct subpopulations of gamblers, so-called impulsive vs. emotional, respectively. Secondary objective: This project will also seek to determine whether the brain phenotypes proposed above are capable of predicting gambling behavior outside the laboratory. To do this, the investigators will use Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA), which involves using participants' smartphones to perform repeated, real-time sampling of their gambling behavior and emotions in real life. The investigators hypothesize that a significant difference in reactivity between the striatum and the amygdala will be associated with a strong correlation between 1) gambling behavior and positive emotions in impulsive gamblers, and 2) gambling behavior and negative emotions in emotional gamblers. Obesity is a multi-factorial chronic disease and an important health problem in developed countries. Worldwide there are more than two billion overweight or obese adults and 35% of the world's population suffer from obesity. The economic burden of obesity is overwhelming, with estimated direct and indirect costs for Germany in 2007 being 33.6 billion euros. The main problem of obesity treatment is the lack of effective therapy. This study investigates the effectiveness of different laparoscopic imaging systems, the Olympus and Leica imaging systems, for bariatric surgery and to analyze the impact of different imaging systems on the clinical outcome of the patient compared to each other.
2D 4K and 3D HD cameras are currently the most used camera system in minimal invasive surgery; however, they are not equally available and some countries mainly use the 2D 4K camera system while others mainly use the 3D HD camera system. The investigation focuses on comparing the effectiveness of 2D 4K and 3D HD Laparoscopic imaging systems during Bariatric Surgery.
The evaluation of the primary outcome should be comprehensive enough to evaluate the impact of the surgical image on each clinical outcome parameter. For this purpose, the operation time has been chosen as the primary outcome parameter. This parameter is also the easiest to measure and determine. The workload of the operating surgeon is another secondary outcome parameter. It is also important to document potential intraoperative and postoperative complications, which have a great impact on the success and outcome of bariatric surgery. Since the choice of imaging systems depends on the available resources, and these imaging systems are costly, there is a growing need for evidence and recommendations for a better use of these resources. In Germany, only a few publications exist, which focus on the assessment of different imaging systems.
With the proposed study, a comparison of 2D 4K and 3D HD laparoscopic imaging systems for bariatric surgery will be made using an RCT under real conditions. This will give recommendations for better use of the available resources and provide a comparison between the two imaging systems in a real hospital setting.

Inclusion of subjects into the study
Inclusion Criteria:
Patients with the indication for bariatric surgery (SMOB guidelines: BMI >35,
Age >18), Cumulative two years of controlled conservative dieting without weight loss
Informed Consent
Exclusion Criteria:
Patients with the indication for gastric bypass, BMI >50, Lack of adequate weight loss therapy for two years
Malignant disease, Liver cirrhosis (Child A), Morbus Crohn, Carcinoma patients,
Serious mental illness requiring treatment (not attributable to obesity),
Chronic abuse of drugs, Lack of compliance (missed appointments, inability to cooperate),
Lack of understanding of the requirements and conditions of postoperative therapy and treatment (confirmed by the specialist)
Patient not signing the Informed Consent
The inclusion and exclusion criteria are chosen very carefully and are based on international guidelines and experience from bariatric centers. No gender restrictions apply.

Ovarian cancer has a high recurrence rate and poor prognosis. Many ovarian cancer patients have received standard treatment with surgical resection, chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
The use of Chinese medicine in the treatment of various cancer and other diseases has a long history and has been proved to have certain efficacy and safety in the prevention and treatment of cancer. Huaier Granulated Chinese Medicinal was approved by the State Food and Drug Administration and entered clinical market. It is one of the commonly used TCM in the field of cancer prevention and treatment. Modern pharmacological studies have shown that Huaier Granule can regulate the immune function of patients, inhibit tumors, strengthen the body, and effectively alleviate the symptoms and side effects of chemotherapy, radiation and surgery. Therefore, it is possible to regulate the immune function of patients, improve the quality of life of patients and reduce the adverse effects of chemotherapy.
This study is a retrospective, single-arm study of the efficacy and safety of Huaier Granule in the treatment of stage I primary ovarian cancer, fallopian tube cancer and peritoneal cancer after operation. A total of 92 patients with BRCA mutation and BRCA wild-type ovarian cancer in Zhejiang Cancer Hospital between February 2019 and June 2020 were enrolled as a retrospective study. All patients were treated with Huaier granule after operation.

Introduction: 
Small intestine bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) remains to this day a syndrome that is not fully understood. Initially, it was considered quite rare, but today there are reports suggesting a SIBO prevalence between 6 to 15% of healthy, asymptomatic people and reaching 80% in patients with irritable bowel syndrome. It is often involved in various disorders, such as diarrhea and malabsorption. It is defined as an increase in the number and/or disturbance in the type of bacteria in the upper part of the intestinal tract. SIBO occurs when the homeostatic mechanisms of the small intestine are disturbed. The two main conditions that favor microbial overgrowth in the small intestine are decreased acid secretion from the stomach and small bowel dyskinesia. The literature is scarce concerning the effects of SIBO on critically ill patients. To our knowledge this is the first study investigating the effects of SIBO on mechanically ventilated patients. It is a non-invasive observational study employing a modified technique to obtain exhaled air from the ventilator tubes to perform a standard hydrogen breath test for SIBO diagnosis. Lactulose is used as a substrate. Specifically, each patient is administered 20 g of lactulose diluted in 400 ml of water through the nasogastric tube. Measurements are performed at 0-15-30-45-60-90-120-180 min from lactulose administration. During measurements, a valve attached to a collecting bag at the end of the expiratory limb of the breathing circuit, is kept open and the collecting bag is filled by several patient exhalations. After valve closure and bag isolation, the air is drawn by a 50 ml polyethylene syringe which is connected to the valve system to prevent losses and/or contamination. Then the air is blown into the breath hydrogen monitor and the expired hydrogen measurement is recorded. The hydrogen breath test is repeated at predetermined, protocol-based time intervals for all participants included in the study; 1st/day of admission, 3rd, 5th and 7th day of ICU stay. The 1st day measurement serves as a measure of eligibility, and patients exhibiting abnormal values of hydrogen breath testing at Day 1 are excluded from the study. An increase by more than 20 ppm of eH2 from baseline within 90 min was considered an abnormal measurement suggesting SIBO. Moreover, an increase by more than 12 ppm of eH2 from baseline within the first 30 minutes followed by a second rise within the next 15 minutes (double peak) was also considered an abnormal measurement suggesting SIBO. The primary objective of this study is assessment of the prevalence of SIBO on critically ill mechanically ventilated ICU patients. Secondary outcomes include investigation of the effects of SIBO on ventilator associated pneumonia, as well as ICU length of stay and all-cause in-hospital mortality rate in critically ill patients.
Official Title: 
The Effects of Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth Syndrome in ICU Patients. An Observational Study.

Conditions: 
- Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth
- Critical Illness
- Intensive Care Unit (ICU)

Intervention / Treatment: 
- Diagnostic Test: Modified hydrogen breath test

Participation Criteria: 
- Criteria for patient inclusion and exclusion:
- Participants must be 18years or older 
- Patients are eligible for inclusion in this study if they meet both the following criteria:
1. Admitted to the ICU of Evangelismos Hospital, are at least 18 years of age and meet any of the following criteria:
a. Have been mechanically ventilated by endotracheal intubation during the first 48 hours after ICU admission and require prolonged mechanical ventilation with expected ICU length of stay of 48 hours or more
b. Have been admitted to the ICU and are already on mechanical ventilation for less than 48 hours on the first day of admission with an expected ICU length of stay and expected mechanical ventilation duration of more than 48 hours or
c. Admitted to the ICU, already on mechanical ventilation with the requirement of a second course of mechanical ventilation

The aim of the study was to investigate whether exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH) is present following exercise in patient after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and if so, if it changes with exercise intensity. A repeated measures and single-blinded randomized study were done in thirty-eight patients 24 hours after TKA. Pain severity was assessed by Visual Analog Scale (VAS) (0-10 mm). Pressure pain thresholds (PPTs) were measured over quadriceps and biceps brachii and muscles immediately before and after exercise. The Exercise-Induced Hypoalgesia (EIH) were evaluated on both sides for each patient. Patients were randomly assigned to either high intensity exercises (HIE) group or low intensity exercises (LIE) group. An exercise program consisted of ankle pump exercise (3 sets of 10 repetitions), isometric exercise (3 sets of 10 repetitions), terminal extension exercise (3 sets of 10 repetitions), passive-active assistive-active range of motion exercise (1 set of 10 repetitions) were performed with ankle pumps, isometric exercises, terminal extension exercise, passive-active assistive-active range of motion exercise (2 sets of 8 repetitions) and were performed with the use of continuous passive movement (CPM) device(30 minutes sessions at ankle pumps, isometric exercises, terminal extension exercise and passive-active assistive-active range of motion exercises). Exercise intensity was monitored using the rating of perceived exertion (RPE) scale, which was maintained between 6 and 20 (16) throughout the exercise program. The HIE program was 60 minutes in duration, and LIE program was 30 minutes in duration. PRE< 8 indicates low intensity, PRE>14 indicates high intensity. A difference of pressure pain thresholds between pre and post of exercise for both sides were defined as Exercise-Induced Hypoalgesia (EIH). This study found that there exists a difference in EIH depending on the intensity of the exercises. There was no difference between the PPTs of the exercise side and the other side in both HIE and LIE groups (P>0.05 for all comparisons). It was concluded that the difference of pain severity in pressure algometry (PA) was detected on the exercise side in the 5th day of the participants without EIH on the HIE. There were no differences of Visual analoy scale scores of both exercise legs and non-exercise legs in both groups (HIE and LIE)) except between the non-exercise and exercise legs of LIE (P<0.05). There was no significant difference between HIE and LIE groups for pain (P=0.80) and no significant difference between HIE and LIE groups for both sides were detected for EIH (P=0.62). The conclusion of this study was that there was no EIH following exercises in patients after TKA, and different exercise protocols may be applicable on patients.
