We plan to conduct a three-year prospective study (baseline, 6-month follow up) among first-degree female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwest Nigeria to assess the effects of individualized breast cancer risk assessment and counseling on adherence to breast cancer screening and lifestyle risk reduction recommendations. The specific aims are:
1. To determine the perception and knowledge of familial breast cancer risk among first-degree female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwest Nigeria.
2. To determine the rate of breast screening among first-degree female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwest Nigeria.

To determine the rate of lifestyle risk reduction among first-degree female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwest Nigeria.
4. Determine factors associated with breast screening and lifestyle risk reduction practices among first-degree relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwest Nigeria.
5. Determine the effects of breast cancer risk assessment and counseling on adherence to breast screening and lifestyle risk reduction recommendations among first degree female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwest Nigeria.
6. Determine the independent predictors of breast screening and lifestyle risk reduction among first-degree female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwest Nigeria.
7. To determine the independent predictors of knowledge, perception, and attitude towards breast cancer prevention among first degree female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwest Nigeria.

Inclusion Criteria:
First-degree female relatives of histologically-confirmed cases of breast cancer living in the Southwestern states of Nigeria.
Women aged 20 to 75 years of age.
Willingness for contact for follow-up after six months.

Exclusion Criteria:
Personal history of breast cancer.
Previous exposure to breast cancer risk assessment and counseling.
Absence of intact breasts.

Study Plan:
This will be a randomized controlled trial. Consecutive consenting subjects who met the inclusion criteria will be recruited. In a single-masked study, we would randomize all eligible participants at the baseline visit to receive either standard care or standard care in addition to individualized breast cancer risk assessment and counseling.
Baseline data on all selected participants will be collected to determine age, menopausal status, previous breast screening, lifestyle practices, and socio-demographic characteristics, as well as to assess the perception of familial breast cancer risk. The participants will be interviewed on risk communication, personal beliefs and attitudes, perceived benefits and risks, and willingness to have genetic testing.
All subjects will be recommended to self-assess their breast health once a month using the modified Breast Self-Examination (BSE). Those who were not actively performing monthly BSE will be offered monthly BSE instruction and training. They will also be recommended to have yearly mammogram, clinical breast exam, and breast cytology. They will be instructed on how to obtain assistance with breast screening at no cost if they are unable to pay for this at the nearby health care facilities. All women will be advised to adopt the NCI recommended lifestyle risk reduction practices in addition to mammography, clinical breast exam and cytology.
The primary outcomes of this study will be rates of breast screening and lifestyle risk reduction, and the secondary outcomes will be the perception, knowledge, attitude, and practice regarding breast screening, and the factors determining the performance and timing of these preventive modalities. At the six-month follow-up visit, a clinical breast exam will be performed and participants will be re-interviewed to determine the performance of mammogram, cytology, frequency of BSE and other lifestyle risk reduction practices.

The study objectives include: 
- To determine whether efavirenz (EFV) (also known as Stocrin or Sustiva) induces the metabolic pathway of CYP2B6.
- To evaluate the differences in plasma concentration and pharmacodynamic effects of methadone and tizanidine in the presence and absence of efavirenz and its effects on Caucasian individuals of different CYP2B6 genotypes (normal, intermediate or poor metabolizers).

The study involves 2 visits (pre-entry and follow-up visits), as well as 2 inpatient stays (1 for entry study and 1 for follow-up study). The total duration of the study is 22 days. In the first visit (pre-entry), subjects will have a pre-enrollment screening visit at least 1 week before the start of the study.

In the second visit (entry into the study), subjects will have a baseline study (control) in which the subject will receive a single dose of methadone and tizanidine with blood samples taken every hour for the first 8 hours and multiple blood samples until 72 hours after administration of the drugs.

After a 2 week washout period, subjects will be treated daily for 16 days with efavirenz and will return for a second inpatient stay to receive a second single dose of methadone and tizanidine. Blood samples will be collected at 24 and 48 hours after administration of the drugs, and pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of tizanidine and methadone will be determined. Blood samples collected at baseline (control) and during treatment with efavirenz for 16 days will be available for pharmacokinetic studies on CYP2B6-metabolized drugs, and pharmacodynamics data on tizanidine will be used to assess the functional consequences of the change in these concentrations.

Subjects will be randomized to specific order of receiving methadone alone or methadone and efavirenz treatments for the entry and follow-up inpatient studies. In addition, subjects will be randomized to treatment with efavirenz (or not) for the first 16 days. The order of treatment administration will depend on the study period and the specific protocol for each subject.

<|assistant|> The purpose of this study was to measure the serum magnesium level in adult patients with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus. In total, 65 adult patients with newly diagnosed type 2 DM (cases), and 65 age and sex matched healthy individuals (controls) were subjected. Serum magnesium level of type 2 diabetes mellitus cases, and healthy control subjects were determined by a commercial kit using automated chemistry analyzer. Serum Mg level in type 2 diabetes cases significantly decreases as compared to healthy control subjects with a mean of 85.15 mg/dl and 96.58 mg/dl respectively (p=0.032). The serum Mg level is not only decreased in type 2 diabetes but also decreased according to HbA1c. HbA1c levels were 8.97 and 9.53 percent in patients having serum magnesium level equal to or less than 82 mg/dl and 83.94 and 90.70 percent in groups having serum magnesium level higher than 82 mg/dl. Magnesium supplement was prescribed in the form of Magnesium oxide 400 mg orally twice daily till total duration of 3 months. The mean of Mg level in patients after 1 and 3 months treatment was 94.17mg/dl and 100.09 mg/dl respectively. The conclusion of our study emphasized the fact that serum Mg level is low in type 2 DM patients, and it is related to glycaemic control as well. These studies suggest that magnesium supplementation could improve glycaemic control in type 2 diabetic subjects as well as lowering the cardiovascular risk in high cardiovascular risk patients. Our results suggest that serum magnesium level be examined as a possible marker for screening purposes for cardiovascular risk in DM patients. The goal of this research is to conduct research on the effect of Ophiochepalus striatus extract on the parameters of sarcopenia in elderly patients. The research is an investigational, double-blind, placebo-controlled study in which the intervention group will receive Ophiochepalus striatus extract and the control group will receive a placebo. The intervention group will be given Ophiochepalus striatus extract at a dose of 10 mg/kg BW/day, divided into 2 portions, for 14 days, while the control group will receive the same amount of placebo. The effect of treatment on the level of IL-6 and IGF-1 cytokines (serum) in elderly patients with a low level of muscle mass (sarcopenia) will be assessed.

Malnutrition is a global health issue with negative consequences on quality of life, health, well-being, and survival. A population-based study conducted in the United States indicated that 45% of older adults 60 and older are at risk for malnutrition with rates of malnutrition at 20-47% depending on the risk level used. Malnutrition in older adults has a myriad of consequences, including decreased muscle mass, decreased physical function, delayed recovery from illness, and increased mortality. With aging of our society, it is imperative that innovative solutions to improve malnutrition care delivery be developed and tested in real-world settings, using models of care that are easily and quickly scalable to reduce these consequences and improve health outcomes for those affected.
The goal of this new model is to improve food security and quality of life in persons older than 60 years of age discharged from the hospital with a diagnosis of malnutrition. The study aims to test the feasibility of a patient identification, cross-referral, data reporting, and communication (including data transfer) process from an acute care hospital to a community meal provision organization. Additionally, the study will increase the rate of patients older than 60 years of age with malnutrition receiving care (MNT, MTM) in the community setting by utilizing an MNT care plan developed by an RDN in the hospital. Malnutrition diagnosis will be confirmed by an independent, trained RDN in the community setting.
The study will conduct a cluster-randomized trial with eight sites throughout the United States, specifically recruiting sites with individuals who are Black, Latino, Indigenous, and Native Americans, individuals living in rural areas, and individuals who are food insecure and have low income. These sites will be paired with community meal providers funded through Title III-C1 and C2 funding. Two RDNs per site will participate in the pilot and feasibility study, which will last 18 to 24 months. The investigators will test the new model of malnutrition care delivery and examine the impact of malnutrition management, nutrition care, and meals in the community setting. The study will utilize a stepped wedge cluster-randomized control trial design and have a 7-month study duration consisting of four consecutive 7-month phases. Each phase will randomize two additional sites (8 sites total) to the intervention/treatment. The intervention/treatment will be the new referral and nutrition care and meal delivery model. The new model will be implemented over 5 periods, with each period lasting for 7 months with 21 days of data review at the end of each period. The goal of the study is to enroll a total of 1120 patients, thus allowing for a statistical power of 0.8 to detect a 20 percentage point change. The study outcome will be the percent of patients receiving nutrition care and meals (medical nutrition therapy - MNT, and meals - MTM).

Reduction Mammaplasty is one of the most commonly performed procedures in Plastic Surgery. Adolescent patients undergoing this operation have unique pain management challenges due to the length of their procedures and recovery time. They are also more likely to experience chronic pain if their surgical post-operative pain is not well managed. This study focuses on the use of subpectoral bupivacaine in decreasing post-operative pain in adolescent reduction mammaplasty. We will also evaluate the dose and time frame of the intervention.

A randomized, comparative trial will be utilized, with the participant group/arm and intervention/treatment being as follows:

1.) Participants in the active intervention group will receive 20cc of subpectoral bupivacaine injected into the fascia following the removal of breast tissue.

2.) Participants in the placebo comparator group will receive 20cc of subpectoral saline injected into the fascia following the removal of breast tissue.

The primary endpoint for our study is immediate post-operative pain score on a scale of 1-10. This will be recorded by the PACU nurse upon arrival into the PACU and upon discharge from the PACU. Patients in both groups will be prescribed the same narcotic (Tylenol #3) and will fill out a daily pain log. Additionally, we will utilize chart review to record PACU pain scores from the immediate post-operative time period.

The use of bupivacaine in post-operative pain management in adult procedures has been shown to be effective and our study can help provide insights for pediatric patients undergoing reduction mammaplasty. By examining and comparing the outcomes of the two arms, we can determine if the use of subpectoral bupivacaine can further improve outcomes related to pain management in this population, ultimately addressing the opioid epidemic faced by all patients undergoing surgery.

Background: Ribonucleotide reactivation protein A (RPA) is the most abundantly expressed protein in eukaryotic cells. Among the proteins that bind RPA directly, DNA-PK is unique in that it is regulated on both the DNA and protein replication pathways in response to DNA damage. RPA interacts with a specific domain of DNA-PK called DNA-PKcs and is the cellular protein substrate on which DNA-PKcs is activated. DNA-PK activation is a highly conserved mechanism for controlling DNA damage in response to agents that cause DNA strand breaks including most topoisomerase 2 (TOP2) inhibitors, mitomycin C (MMC), platinum agents, mitotic spindle poison drugs or antimetabolite (chemotherapy) drugs. Recent data suggest that DNA-PKcs is a major target for cancer therapy due to increased activity in many tumors including glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) and leiomyosarcoma (LMS) compared to normal tissues. LMS is a distinct histological subtype of soft tissue sarcoma (STS) that is almost exclusively associated with long segment mutations in the high mobility group box-containing gene (HMGB1) which encodes an architectural/structural chromatin-associated protein. Preclinical genetic and pharmacologic studies with DNA-PK inhibitors show that in HMGB1-mutant LMS and GBMs, inhibition of DNA-PK with NU7026, a potent and selective inhibitor of DNA-PKcs, induced DNA damage, apoptosis and anti-tumor activity in vitro and in vivo. Patients with unselected STS (N=36) treated with the DNA-PKcs inhibitor M3814 (peposertib), an investigational drug that is different than NU7026, showed some signs of anti-tumor activity with less observed adverse events than NU7026 in other tumor types, suggesting the potential benefit/risk profile of this new class of inhibitors that can be further evaluated in specific subsets of STS. Objectives: To determine the Maximum Tolerated Dose (MTD) of the combination of low dose pegylated liposomal doxorubicin (DL) with peposertib (M3814) in patients with STS. To characterize the pharmacokinetics of peposertib when combined with low dose pegylated liposomal doxorubicin. The study will include two sequential cohorts: Cohort I = 2 to 6 patients with LMS or selected STS treated with peposertib (M3814) and low dose pegylated liposomal doxorubicin. Treatment will start with a single dose of peposertib (M3814) on Day 1. A standard 3 + 3 accrual method and an MTD determination method with dose de-escalation will be used to determine the MTD of this combination, which will be the recommended phase II dose that will be used in a larger cohort of patients with LMS or selected STS in cohort II. Cohort II = 20 patients with LMS or selected STS treated with peposertib (M3814) and low dose pegylated liposomal doxorubicin at the MTD from cohort I. In each patient, if appropriate, the biopsy will be performed before treatment is started and periodically at 1 month interval during study treatment. Optional biopsies can be obtained at 1 month interval during study treatment. At study entry, each patient will undergo a comprehensive assessment through medical history, physical exam, laboratory values, chest X-ray and a CT scan of the chest, abdomen and pelvis. Additional imaging studies may be performed depending on patients' symptoms and any abnormal results found during this initial assessment. Patients will be followed until progressive disease is seen or there is an unacceptable level of toxicity. Patients will be also asked to sign a voluntary specimen bank form to allow their stored specimens to be used for future research studies. The overall design of this study enables patients with different subtypes of STS to be treated with a combination of low dose pegylated liposomal doxorubicin and peposertib (M3814). Patients in cohort I will be enrolled as the first group of patients who may or may not benefit from this combination therapy

<|assistant|>
Introduction:
Back pain affects 55 to 60 million Americans every year. Approximately 50% of Americans will experience low back pain in their lives. One study in New York state showed that people with low back pain report about 25% less physical activity on average. A sedentary lifestyle is strongly associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease. Physical activity is safe and can be considered a 'drug' with few side effects. The American College of Physicians guidelines recommend non-pharmacological treatments for treating chronic low back pain. Exercise has been shown to be one of the best strategies for reducing back pain. T'ai chi is one of the simplest and most gentle of all exercise activities and has been shown to be effective in improving low back pain symptoms. It is also effective in reducing symptoms of insomnia. Aims of the study: The aim of this pilot project is to examine the impact (if any) of a 12-week t'ai chi and qigong online exercise program on chronic low back pain and co-morbidities including sleep disturbances and quality of life. Our study offers a free online class taught by a master t'ai chi practitioner. The PI, who is an interventional research fellow at NYMC, has experience using the MindBody Online Program (MBO). The MBO platform allows for classes to be accessed remotely by individuals anywhere in the NYMC service area. Methodology: This study will be conducted in the community to allow easy and convenient access to participants. Participants will be recruited online using NYMC social media platforms and flyers. Interested subjects will complete an initial Survey, then be randomly assigned to either the free t'ai chi and qigong online exercise class held twice weekly or a waitlisted control. Participants who were waitlisted (and who were not injured and could no longer complete the course) received the classes in January 2023 to allow for a cross-over. The study will be a prospective, single-centered, single-blind, parallel design, randomized controlled trial (RCT). Consent for participation in the t'ai chi and qigong exercise (treatment) group and completion of Surveys will be included in the Survey. Participants who were waitlisted received the classes offered on a rolling basis throughout the study. The study will use a pre-post design to track changes within the groups (e.g., Treatment vs. control groups). The PI and the study assistants will remain blinded to the subject assignment, which will be contained on a database protected by a password. The data will be stored on an encrypted, password-protected laptop in a secure space. Data will be transferred by the PI from the laptop to his NYMC-issued computer via a secure portal, then to the project computer. The study will be conducted over a 6-month period using the MindBody Online Platform.

The study will include two groups. Group A will consist of individuals who enrolled in the free online Zoom t'ai chi and qigong exercise program after September 23, 2022 and will be tracked for 3 months after enrollment..

The EMBOL-AF is a multicenter, international, observational study designed as a retrospective re­gistry that will investigate the characteristics of systemic arterial embolic events after treatment of atrial fibrillation by catheter ablation. The registry will gather all clinically relevant data of all cases of arterial embolism that have occurred over the last 5 years in the centers that will participate in the study. Based on these reported cases, the incidence, management and sequelae of embolic events (particularly st­roke and TIA) will be studied. The registry is specially focused on cerebral embolism.
A retrospective survey on the current practices of catheter ablation for AF in the period 1st january 2017 and 31st july 2023 will be performed. The data obtained from this survey will allow to classify centers in tertiles of high, moderate, and low risk.
Each participating center will be requested to provide anonymized data on the total number of patients treated with catheter ablation for AF during the retrospective period, and the number of patients with arterial embolism after ablation, as well as relevant patient characteristics, the details of AF ablation procedure and the consequences of embolic events.
Each participating center will provide data for specific cases following a uniform DCL (data collection logbook). Only the local investigator will be permitted to access the database using a personalized access code. The data collection will follow a standardized and uniform DCL. The DCL has been designed and it is under direct supervision and monitoring by the members of the Executive Committee of EMBOL-AF.
A database will be set up to store information from all participating centers. Confidentiality of data is guaranteed by legal enforcement.
The EMBOL-AF registry is coordinated by the University Hospital of Tor Vergata (Rome, Italy). International collaboration is encouraged. The Executive Committee of the study is being composed by experienced electrophysiologists and researchers in embolic events. This Committee is supported by a steering committee that also includes representatives of the main international scientific societies, such as European Heart Rhythm Association (EHRA), Asia-Pacific Heart Rhythm Society (APHRS), American College of Cardiology (ACC), Latin American Heart Rhythm Association (LAHRA) and Spanish Society of Cardiology (SEC).
The expected results of this study will be the following: 
1. To describe the incidence, management and sequelae of arterial embolism, especially stoke and TIA associated to catheter ablation for AF.
2. To study the acute clinical profile, symptoms, signs and results of brain image techniques of these events.
3. To study the acute therapeutic management of these events.
4. To study the sequelae and clinical consequences at 3 months of follow-up.
5. To study whether the severity of stroke/TIA is associated to any specific ablation techniques.
6. To study other procedure-related aspects as predictors of stroke/TIA.
The EMBOL-AF International Registry is expected to start during the fourth quarter of the year 2023. The maximum time for data collection will be 6 months. The maximum time for data monitoring will be 6 months.

<|assistant|> The objective of this randomized controlled clinical trial is to evaluate the effectiveness of using low-intensity electrical acceleration (ELF-EMF) to accelerate the retraction of anterior teeth using backward traction. The null hypothesis to be tested is that the patients who will undergo the enhanced pulling using the electrical acceleration will perceive no differences in the level of pain, discomfort, and acceptability of the treatment. The alternative hypothesis is that there will be a significant difference between patients subjected to traditional en-masse retraction and those subjected to enhanced pulling using electrical acceleration. To test it, both patients will complete the same questionnaires about pain, discomfort, and acceptability of the procedure before and after the treatment, in addition to other questionnaires about pain intensity and the burning sensation. The sample size will be divided into two subgroups; one will be treated using traditional retraction and the other group will use low intensity electrical acceleration. The data analyzes will use chi-square, Fisher, t-test, and correlational analysis to evaluate the statistical significance. The study will be carried out in accordance with the Statement of Helsinki adopted for the protection of experimental subjects to prevent any damage to human health. Two hundred and eighty-eight patients will be treated, and 282 patients will complete the study. The data collection forms will be distributed among patients at the four-dimensional level (dental, soft tissue alterations, functional changes, and psychological effects) following the retraction of upper anterior teeth, using three instruments: visual analog scale (VAS) and Dental Impaction Questionnaire (DIQ-R) and the short form Health Survey. Inclusion criteria: Adult healthy patients of the both sexes. Age range: 17-25 years. Exclusion criteria: Patients with previous orthodontic treatment. Patients with severe skeletal dysplasia in all three dimensions. Patients who suffer from systemic diseases or syndromes. Patients on medication for systemic disorders, pregnancy, or steroid therapy. Patients' showing any signs of active periodontal disease. Patients who receive ADT are at higher risk for developing AD. AD is linked to cognitive impairment in other disorders, such as Alzheimers disease (AD). Cognitive tests that measure abilities like memory and attention are used to determine whether patients with dementia or cognitive impairments are experiencing memory loss. AD has four stages: no cognitive decline, mild cognitive impairment (MCI), mild dementia, and severe dementia. The number of people suffering from memory loss is rising as the population ages and life expectancies increase. Prostate cancer patients starting hormone therapy are at higher risk for developing cognitive impairments.

This is a single-site, non-randomized prospective observational study of men with prostate cancer. PRIMARY OBJECTIVE: I. To evaluate whether baseline plasma Amyloid-beta 42/40 ratio is associated with cognitive decline in men upon starting ADT. SECONDARY OBJECTIVE: I. To evaluate whether ADT is associated with a decline in plasma Aβ42/40 ratio. II. To evaluate whether intensified ADT (iADT) receipt is associated with greater cognitive decline compared to ADT.

Current or prior diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma based on a pathology report or as documented in a medical oncology, urology, or radiation oncology note. Exclusion Criteria: Patient Participants- Small cell prostate carcinoma (pure or mixed). This study was conducted to determine the validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 years) in Turkish and to evaluate the effect of an educational game developed through the Social Learning Theory on acute complications of diabetes and health literacy in children with type 1 diabetes aged 8-12. It is planned to meet with the groups 3 times in total within the scope of the research. In the first interview, first of all, Diabetes Child Diagnosis Form and Diabetes Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications in Children will be applied. Then the diabetes health literacy board game will be played. For this, groups of 4 will be formed and care will be taken to ensure that children of similar age groups are together while forming groups. In the clinic, they will be asked to play a diabetes health literacy (DISOY) board game in a quiet, bright room, a room with a table and 4 chairs. DISOY board game averages 45-60 minutes. and the first meeting will end here. Each child will be given one game to play with their parents at least twice at home. The second interview will be provided 1 month after the first interview. The third interview will be held in the third month. Data collection forms will be filled out again at each interview. The effect of the educational game applied in the first interview on acute complications of diabetes and health literacy of children will be evaluated by reapplying the same data collection forms.

The effect of puzzles on the ability of first-year nursing students to learn vital signs is examined. Firstly, a questionnaire will be designed by the researcher, to be filled in by students at the beginning of the study, and an experimental group will be formed in such a way as to meet the inclusion criteria. First-year student volunteers who take a course on vital signs for the first time and meet the inclusion criteria will be included in the experimental group. 11 first-year nursing students will be included in the experimental group.
The education method will be applied by providing puzzles to students for two weeks, and the students' course successes will be examined after the puzzle application is over. It will be observed whether the students who were successful in learning the conceptual structure of vital signs were effective in reducing the number of failures they received.
The sample consists of first-year nursing students of Bilecik city, who take a course on vital signs for the first time and meet the inclusion criteria. The education will be carried out as the student course continues. The data in the survey will be collected by the researcher.
The data will be analyzed by SPSS 23.0 software package. In the statistical analysis of the data, descriptive statistics analysis will be used, and then Mann-Whitney U tests will be used for independent sample or Spearman's rho correlation test for independent samples. The study was carried out with a randomized experimental group for all subjects.
The study, which was planned with the students of Bilecik Şeyh Edebali University Nursing Department students, was conducted in 11 students. After the application was completed, it was planned to measure the knowledge of the students, and the results were examined statistically. With the implementation of puzzles in the teaching of the vital signs course, it was found that the successes of the students in the application group were higher than the control group. It can be suggested that both the active structure of the puzzles and the students' motivation to learn can be effective in increasing students' course successes. It should be noted that, in addition to using active learning in vital signs education, using other active learning tools or puzzles in nursing education can positively affect learning processes.

The aim of this research is to determine the effectiveness of an intervention program based on transtheoretical model and motivational interview on smartphone addiction in nursing students and its effects on sleep quality. The effect and effectiveness of the motivational interviewing program based on the transtheoretical model on nursing students participating in the study will be examined. A quasi-experimental study with pre-test and post-test, in which the groups are randomly selected and their levels of smartphone addiction and sleep quality are compared, will be used in the research.
In this research, it will be studied whether motivational interviewing will have an effect on smartphone addiction and sleep quality levels of students participating in the study. The research was planned with the hypothesis that motivational interviewing will be effective in reducing smartphone addiction and improving sleep quality in university students. The research was planned with the intervention group of nursing students and the control group. Smartphone addiction and sleep quality were determined and the levels of anxiety, depression and stress in both groups were examined. The study arms; Motivational interviewing program with transtheoretical model and control group without intervention, were used. Transtheoretical model and motivational interviewing form have been applied to the nursing department participants who scored above the cut-off score in the Smartphone Addiction Scale-Short Form and who agreed to participate in the research. Motivational interviewing program was applied face-to-face using Microsoft teams meeting software. Motivational interviewing was applied with the online training content prepared for smartphone addiction in students. It was tried to determine at which stage of change of transtheoretical model nursing students are and motivational interviewing program was applied according to this. It was planned to repeat the study scales for the students 16 weeks after the end of the motivational interviewing program and to evaluate the effectiveness of the program by comparing their responses with the baseline data. Smartphone addiction levels of the individuals participating in the research, whether motivational interviewing was effective and the effect size in the intervention group was calculated with the chi-square test. It was planned to compare sleep quality between the students in both groups. To determine the effectiveness of the motivational interviewing program and its effect on students' smartphone addiction and sleep quality levels, it is planned to compare the results of both groups with T-test and analysis of variance. It is planned to examine the effects of sleep quality on the academic success of nursing students within the scope of a separate research project. This study will be added to the literature with the hypothesis of the researchers and the data obtained with the study.

Facial erythematous rosacea, as well as mild papulopustular rosacea, are common clinical presentations of rosacea. Both conditions are mainly treated either with topical corticosteroids or systemic tetracyclines. However, the treatment of facial erythematous rosacea with systemic tetracyclines, such as doxycycline and minocycline, can lead to resistance to the drug in a sizable number of patients within one year. Ivermectin is a drug of a different chemical class with a different treatment mechanism, which allows to use it as a rescue therapy in case of tetracycline resistance. Although topical ivermectin has recently been suggested to have an anti-inflammatory effect via the inhibition of the inflammasome, no clinical experience is available so far regarding a combined treatment of rosacea with ivermectin and laser therapy, particularly in cases of refractory erythematous rosacea. Therefore, laser therapy may be an additional effective treatment option for rosacea, possibly reducing the long-term systemic use of tetracyclines or other drugs, associated with low compliance or drug resistance. This study will compare the efficacy of KTP laser therapy and the combination of KTP laser and ivermectin 1% cream topically to the skin on the same patient for the treatment of rosacea.

Cerebral glucose metabolism can be altered in many patients with neurodegenerative disease and head trauma, and the use of functional Positron Emission Tomography (FDG PET-MRI) is essential to detect these alterations. In recent years, a growing body of patients were examined at our institution. This study aims to conduct a retrospective data review of patients included in CARIPLO Project 2016/00422 (study of brain metabolism in patients suffering of neurodegenerative and vascular pathologies) in order to assess the FDG PET features of cerebral glucose metabolism in these patients. This data review will provide a unique opportunity to investigate the variability of FDG PET uptake in different pathologies, to identify the regions of altered brain function and to provide a reference material.

Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is a life-limiting genetic condition which predominately affects the lungs, pancreas and digestive system. The most common cause of death in people with cystic fibrosis (pwCF) is respiratory failure due to chronic lung infection and inflammation. CF affects all age groups and is seen from birth to adulthood. 2017/18 saw the emergence of an infectious disease, Corona Virus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) which is caused by a novel RNA virus, SARS-CoV-2. Early in 2019, COVID-19 spread from the Wuhan region of China to other parts of the world, but from the spring of 2020 in the United Kingdom, the NHS was overwhelmed by COVID-19 resulting in a number of social and economic challenges. COVID-19 disproportionately impacts pwCF. In Italy, there was an estimated 15-20% mortality rate among hospitalised pwCF with COVID-19 with severe respiratory failure. SARS-CoV-2 is an RNA virus which relies on the host's immune system to replicate. Serum antibodies (natural or induced by SARS-CoV-2 vaccination) against SARS-CoV-2 have been shown to have a correlation with severity of COVID-19 disease and with response to vaccination. The development of antibodies in pwCF is particularly important because the lungs are a target for CF complications, including bacterial infection. There is speculation amongst pwCF and healthcare providers that pwCF have lower levels of antibodies following SARS-CoV-2 infection and might respond less well to vaccination due to this underlying condition. However, no studies have directly compared natural infection-induced immune response to vaccination-induced immune response in pwCF. These studies will be critical to informing pwCF and their healthcare providers about the level of protection each method provides and to inform the design of CF-specific SARS-CoV-2 vaccines. To date, there are no studies in the UK that have looked at the antibody responses between natural infection and vaccination, and how this varies over time in pwCF. It is possible that antibody levels from infection and from vaccination will differ between pwCF and the wider population. Understanding the antibody responses will allow healthcare providers to counsel pwCF regarding the level of protection against COVID-19 that they may expect from natural infection and vaccination. This will help to inform vaccination strategies tailored to the needs of pwCF, in particular younger pwCF or those with underlying medical conditions that increase their risk for infection and severe disease. The results of this study will help to define the immune response of pwCF to SARS-CoV-2 infection and vaccination, and inform future care. Moreover, our study data will help identify important markers of immune dysregulation that can have important clinical implications for pwCF in the future. The investigators aim to create a platform for other researchers to study the molecular mechanisms of SARS-CoV-2 infection and to develop targeted therapies and vaccines. 1. To determine the seroprevalence of SARS-CoV-2 infection in pwCF aged < 18 months to 50 years old in the UK over time.
2. To examine the association between SARS-CoV-2 infection and symptoms in pwCF.
3. To determine the factors that influence the severity of COVID-19 in people with CF.
4. To understand the pattern of antibody detection after natural infection with SARS-CoV-2 and after vaccination in pwCF and how this varies between different CF populations (age, genotype, geographical area and time).
5. To identify baseline levels of cytokines, chemokines and immune cells in pwCF and investigate whether they correlate with SARS-CoV-2 infections or vaccination-induced immunity.
6. To identify baseline levels of serum proteomics and cfDNA among pwCF and investigate whether they correlate with SARS-CoV-2 infections or vaccination-induced immunity.
This study will be conducted at participating CF centers over a 3-year period. Study participants will include pediatric and adult pwCF. For the UK section of the study, UK investigators in the European Cystic Fibrosis Society-Clinical Trials Network (ECFS-CTN) will be

Background: May-Thurner syndrome (MTS) is the compression of the left common iliac vein (CIV) at the vena cava confluence, which may result from a narrow right common iliac artery (CIA) in the pelvis. The syndrome can cause symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left leg. There is no widely accepted guideline for MTS treatment. Diagnosing MTS can be challenging but is necessary to consider endovascular management. Duplex ultrasound is the primary modality used to non-invasively evaluate venous compression and diameter of the left CIV when assessing for MTS. The operator of ultrasound scans and the sonographer acquiring the image are not always the same. The effect of inter- and intra-operator variation of the diameter measurement is unknown. Materials and Methods: All the patients who are referred to Hull Royal Infirmary vascular ultrasound service will be invited to a vascular ultrasound examination. In total, two scans of the left CIV (diameter measurement) will be done. The operator of ultrasound scan will scan one (only operator) and a second sonographer will scan the other (operator with sonographer). The operators will perform the scans separately in real-time. The diameter measurement of the left CIV will be made by both operators at each ultrasound scan. Data Collection: The first operator will complete a case report form (CRF). This includes patient demographics, clinical presentations, the results of diagnostic investigations and the results of ultrasound. The second operator will complete the same CRF after scanning. Data Analysis: All the collected CRFs will be entered into the study's electronic database, and the diameter measurement of the left CIV (mm) will be recorded. The inter- and intra-operator variation of the diameter measurements will be examined by a correlation coefficient (Pearson correlation). Data and Results: The diameter measurement of the left CIV (in mm) of all the patients will be collected and entered into the study database. The correlation coefficients between diameter measurements of the first operator and second operator ultrasound scans for the left CIV will be determined. Statistical Analysis: The data will be entered into a database, checked and validated. The data will be entered into the Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS, IBM Corp., Armonk, NY, USA; http://www.IBM.com/software/analytics/spss/) for data analysis. The inter- or intra-operator variation between diameter measurements of the left CIV will be assessed using a correlation coefficient (Pearson correlation). The level of significance (P) will be set as <0.05. The analysis of the correlation coefficient will be done by the second operator, who will be blinded to all patient characteristics.

Background: Currently, the most recommended NMES protocol for evoking torque is the Russian Current with 10% duty cycle. Studies suggest that the Russian Current may be more effective in this context because it produces greater motor recruitment due to a higher affinity between high-frequency stimulation and the properties of motor units. Objectives: The effectiveness of this protocol should be compared to other high frequency and low frequency currents, as well as to the effects of fatigue induced by high frequency stimulation on neuromuscular behavior. Based on the above, the hypothesis is that the Russian Current (10% duty cycle) would present more effectiveness compared to the Aussie Current (10% duty cycle) and pulsed currents (500µs and 200µs phase), as well as produce a lower fatigue level. A better neuromuscular activation for a longer time of stimulation, generating higher torque evoked and a higher intracellular muscle perfusion. Methods: This is a crossover, experimental, randomized, double-blind trial composed of apparently healthy participants. The effects of high and low frequency NMES protocols applied to the triceps surae muscle for evoked torque, muscle fatigue, sensory discomfort, and peripheral oxygen extraction will be evaluated in the same participant by randomizing the sequences of interventions for each visit in the laboratory. The study is considered double-blind, as individuals will not know the sequence of the protocols applied. The evaluator will also not know which protocol will be used at the time of the intervention. It will consist of a total of 5 sessions with seven days between them. In the first session, anthropometry, the maximum intensity level for each electrical stimulation protocol as well as the protocol sequence for each individual will be evaluated. From the second to the fifth session, the following will be considered: voluntary and evoked maximum joint torque of the triceps surae muscle, muscle fatigue through the evaluation of the H-reflex, M-wave, fatigue index, torque-time-integral and recruitment curve, peripheral oxygen extraction, electromyographic signals through RMS (root mean square) and median frequency, and level of sensory discomfort with the Visual Analog Scale (VAS). From the second to the fifth session will be composed by the following evaluation sequence: warm-up with six submaximal contractions with 6 seconds of duration and 10 seconds of rest between them; then the assessment of muscle fatigue; then two maximal isometric contractions, then two maximal evoked contractions; fatigue protocol at 20% of the maximum isometric contraction (this fatigue protocol will use the NMES sequence randomized in the first session; after the fatigue protocol, two maximum evoked contractions will be performed again; then two maximal isometric contractions and at the end, the muscle fatigue evaluation will be performed again. The NMES protocols will be CR10% (Russian Current at 2500 Hz, modulated in 50 Hz bursts, 200 µs and 10% duty cycle - 2 ms of 18 ms bursts and interbusrts), CA10% (Aussie Current with 1000 Hz, modulated in 50 Hz bursts, 500 µs and 10% duty cycle - 2 ms of 18 ms bursts and interbusrts), CP500 (pulsed current with 50 Hz, 500 µs phase) and CP200 (Pulsed current with 50 Hz, 200 µs phase). All protocols will be performed on the triceps surae muscle.

Official Title
-----------------
Effects of Different Modalities of Medium and Low Frequency Electrical Stimulation in the Generation of Evoked Torque, Sensory Discomfort, Muscle Fatigue and Inheritance Peripheral Oxygen Supply in the Triceps Surae Muscle.

Healthy

* Other: Aussie current 10%

The overall objective of this study is to investigate the acute and chronic effects of a 4-week supplementation with a lactate and ketone body ester (Lactate-ketone ester; LaKe) in healthy subjects at risk for metabolic disorders such as insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes (T2DM). During four weeks intervention, we aim to investigate 1) if LaKe can induce a beneficial effect in insulin sensitivity in high-risk populations, 2) if the treatment can alter substrate utilization and gastric function and 3) if LaKe has a favourable effect on lipid metabolism and cardiovascular health. Healthy middle-aged and older adults with a BMI of 30-39.9 kg/m2 and age >30 years will be included. The hypothesis is that one month supplementation with an intravenous lactate-ketone body ester will improve insulin sensitivity, substrate utilization, and health biomarkers.
In total, n=28 (17 women) will be included and randomized to start with the intervention supplemented with LaKe ester or a non-caloric placebo (n=14 in each group), for four weeks, respectively, followed by four week wash-out periods and a subsequent cross-over to the opposite supplementation regime after which all participants enter a 4-week post-supplementation period; the exact order of the two supplementations is randomized. All study days include oral-glucose-tolerance-test (o-GTT) (day 0), a euglycemic hyperinsulinemic-glucose infusion-clamp (M-clamp, day 5), and a 3-hour meal test (day 6), along with cardiac assessments and collection of blood for analyses of glucose-, hormones and metabolic markers. Additionally, in a subsample (n=8), we will determine the effects of the LaKe-supplementation on gastric function by analyzing gastric emptying, cardiac output and gastric biomarkers through blood, urine and stool samples. Finally, we will also collect blood to determine blood lipids and cardiometabolic hormones as well as inflammation markers. This study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. The results will be crucial for the development of new treatment options and dietary recommendations for people who struggle with a poor diet and/or low physical activity. The investigators hope to contribute with new knowledge that may prove beneficial in the fight against obesity, insulin resistance and the development of type 2 diabetes.

The objective of this survey is to study a new ultrasound-guided ilio-psoas tendon tenotomy technique in patients with ilio-psoas conflict after total hip replacement.
The technique will be compared to the open technique (with a 20 mm skin incision at the ilio-psoas level) used in standard practice in patients presenting an ilio-psoas conflict after a total hip replacement.
This comparison will be carried out through a double-blind and placebo-controlled technique (patient and assessor unaware of the technique).
Objectives:
- Assess the success rate of this new ultrasound-guided ilio-psoas tendon tenotomy technique
- Assess the technical difficulty of the surgical procedure
- Assess the operative time
- Assess the number of surgical complications
- Assess the pain experienced by the patient before, during and after the tenotomy, using a numerical scale from 0 to 10
- Assess the quality of life of the patient before, during and after the tenotomy, using the EuroQol five-dimension questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L)
- Assess the satisfaction and forgotten hip sensation in the patient before, during and after the tenotomy
- Assess the early (< 90 days after surgery) and late (> 90 days after surgery) surgical complications related to surgery
- Assess the rate of admission to a rehabilitation center
Study Plan:
This study will be conducted under general anesthesia with an antero-lateral approach.
The study will be divided into 2 phases:
- A preparatory phase: 3 to 6 months before the study begins
- An operative phase: 3 to 6 months after the study begins.
Participants will be evaluated pre-operatively and post-operative in the first consultation at the 15 days, 6 weeks, 3 and 6 months.
Study Population:
Patient with ilio-psoas conflict and having a tenotomy indication (inclusion criteria: patient candidate for total hip replacement, ilio-psoas conflict with a clinical score on Rimand hip index >= 50 without contraindication to surgery, patient affiliation, affiliation of the beneficiary to a French health insurance scheme or equivalent, signature of the written informed consent form by the patient)
- Exclusion criteria: patient with 20° of flexion in extension; pregnant or breast-feeding women (patient will be offered a pregnancy test: urinary test), adult under guardianship or deprived of freedom; allergy to local anesthetics; patient on anticoagulant or antiplatelet agents; contraindication to surgery; Vulnerable persons: pregnant or breast-feeding women (patient will be offered a pregnancy test: urinary test), adult under guardianship or deprived of freedom; Refusal of patient involvement; Patient followed-up or followed-up on clinical and / or imaging study.
Procedure: 
For each patient, 2 identical approaches will be performed: an open tenotomy approach under general anesthesia and a novel ultrasound-guided tenotomy approach under general anesthesia.
The 2 approaches will be randomized and conducted by an independent and blinded surgeon.
The assessment of the technical difficulty of the procedure will be performed at the end of the procedure by a survey of a 4-point likert scale answered by the surgeon from an evaluation of his difficulty.
The clinical examination consists of: pain scales, global score evaluating the ilio-psoas conflict, Rimand hip index, scoring of passive joint mobility, hip function score, score of walking capacity, Harris scores (pain, function, mobility and alignment of the hip), Oxford score of the patient (pain and disability), Oxford score of the patient (hip functioning and discomfort) and Postel score of the patient (pain, mobility, function and alignment).
Patient satisfaction assessment: 4-point likert scale, The forgotten hip sensation will be assessed by the patient himself through the evaluation of a forgotten hip according to the question "Have you forgotten your hip?" for different questionnaires (EQ-5D, Forgotten Hip).

The aim of the study is to evaluate postoperative pain and respiratory function following thoracic paravertebral block application with three different local anesthetic volumes.

Local anesthetic thoracic paravertebral block provides excellent postoperative analgesia in thoracotomy. There are no consensus-based protocols for performing thoracic paravertebral block. In particular, there are no studies comparing postoperative analgesia and patient suitability outcomes in thoracotomy given the same technique using different local anesthetic volumes.

Many of the most serious medical conditions cause fatigue. Fatigue, which is a common symptom, occurs throughout the day and is increased with activity. The purpose of this study is to determine whether muscle vibrations reduce fatigue. Muscle vibration is an active type of stretching that is applied for short periods of time to an individual's muscles. The investigators are comparing muscle vibrations with usual care to see if vibration reduces fatigue.
This study is a phase 2 interventional pilot study. Patients 18 years old or older with MS with fatigue will be recruited through advertisement and referrals from MDs in the outpatient neurosciences clinic. After participants sign an informed consent form, they will be screened with a medical history, neurological exam, and a clinical laboratory test (complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, thyroid study). They will complete questionnaires about their fatigue, mood/emotions/depression, and quality of life. The medical history, neurological exam, and questionnaires will be repeated at the end of the 3-month intervention.

Participants will receive usual care for an initial 3-week period before beginning the intervention. This will help isolate the effect of vibration on fatigue. Each participant will attend 10 training sessions per week over 4 weeks. Sessions last about 90 minutes each. Patients will receive usual care for an additional 3-week period. Participants then will attend 5 training sessions per week over 4 weeks. Session last about 90 minutes each.
The questionnaire takes about 20-40 minutes to complete. Before and after each training session, participants will have muscle and balance function tests. These tests take about 1-2 hours to complete. Patients are paid for their time completing the study. The research team will monitor for any complications or side effects. After the study is completed, participants are given a choice of having their medical charts and study questionnaires either emailed to them or given to them in hard copy.
No one profits or gains from the study, and all costs are covered by grant funding or NMSC Center funds.

Epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors (EGFR-TKIs) are approved as first-line treatment for patients with mutant epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene in NSCLC. The most common mechanism of resistance to EGFR-TKIs is the development of a second EGFR mutation, called the T790M mutation. Some patients may harbor multiple EGFR mutations, including those that confer resistance to EGFR-TKIs. Resistance to EGFR-TKIs may be due to alterations in other genes, such as human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2), which is encoded by the ERBB2 gene. These factors have been associated with decreased response to EGFR-TKIs and poor clinical outcomes in patients with lung cancer.
A Phase I, single-arm, multicentric study (NCT00570481) is currently underway to determine the recommended Phase I dose (RP2D)/maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of tucatinib (OSI-774), a HER2-directed, small-molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in combination with osimertinib and cetuximab (ERBITUX®), an EGFR inhibitor that acts primarily by binding to the extracellular domain of the EGFR receptor. The Phase I portion of this study will enroll a dose-escalation cohort and a dose-expansion cohort. In the expansion cohort, all patients with NSCLC must have: 1) progression on first generation EGFR TKI therapy or progression on osimertinib, and 2) evidence of HER2 alteration (by immunohistochemistry [IHC] and/or fluorescence in situ hybridization [FISH], and/or next generation sequencing [NGS] for HER2 mutation). The goal is to learn the safety profile of the combination therapy and to recommend the next phase of clinical development. The trial consists of two consecutive parts.
Part A (dose-escalation cohort) will determine the RP2D/MTD of tucatinib in combination with osimertinib and cetuximab. The dose-escalation phase of the trial will include a minimum of 6 patients per cohort and a total of about 12 escalation cohorts. The dose will be escalated in a 3+3 design until the MTD is reached or a dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) occurs. Part B (dose-expansion cohort) will confirm the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics (PK), and pharmacodynamics (PD) of tucatinib as a tucatinib and osimertinib combination therapy, and to further explore the anti-tumor activity of the combination therapy in patients with HER2-associated resistance to EGFR TKIs.

Patients after lung transplantation are frequently complicated with lung transplantation rejection. Transbronchial biopsy is one of the most necessary and important methods to diagnose lung transplantation rejection. Traditional transbronchial biopsy mainly relies on tissue biopsy samples obtained through biopsy forceps. Since the acquisition process of traditional transbronchial biopsy is laborious and has a certain level of safety concerns and sampling errors, researchers of University of Hong Kong Shenzhen Hospital proposed the transbronchial cryobiopsy, which can rapidly and safely obtain more and accurate lung tissue samples. This study aims to investigate the diagnostic efficacy of transbronchial cryobiopsy for lung transplantation rejection, and compare with that of traditional transbronchial lung biopsy.

Many gender diverse (GD) youth suffer from poor mental health outcomes as well as social and familial marginalization, leaving them without adequate care. In this pilot randomized clinical trial, we aim to compare the effects of an interactive educational digital platform to usual care among youth aged 15-25 years and their caregivers. The platform will be developed using rigorous human-centered design principles to ensure usability and accessibility. Outcomes of the study include suicidal ideation, depression, anxiety, and overall perceived family support during a 12 month follow-up period. We anticipate at least 80% retention across the follow-up period. If successful, the platform has the potential to be a community-led health intervention that improves the well-being of marginalized populations.

Individuals with substance use disorders have a high prevalence of psychiatric comorbidity, including depression and anxiety disorders. In clinical settings, substance use disorders are often diagnosed and treated separately from comorbid mood and anxiety disorders despite the documented presence and clinical relevance of psychiatric comorbidity. However, there are potential risks of treating psychiatric conditions as separate entities versus in the context of substance use disorders. There is a need to evaluate whether treatment should focus on psychiatric conditions versus targeting substance use as a means of targeting psychiatric symptoms. This study aims to provide a better understanding of the relationship between substance use disorders, substance use treatment, psychiatric symptoms, and treatment outcomes. Participants with AUD and CUD will be screened and treated under existing Integrated Care Pathways for AUD and CUD at the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH). Participants will complete baseline assessments of substance use, psychiatric symptoms, psychiatric history, and neurocognitive function with the PI to assess eligibility for participation in the study. Of the eligible individuals, 60 participants presenting to the AUD program will consist of a treatment-seeking sub-group with a current DSM-5 diagnosis of primary AUD (AUD group). Participants in this arm are currently being treated for AUD in an existing integrated care pathway, but are also being offered CBT for AUD. 60 participants presenting to the CUD program will be screened and those with AUD (i.e., a diagnostic history of AUD in addition to CUD) will be re-screened for CUD. A subset of each of these 2 groups (n=18) will undergo more extensive neuroimaging scans to further examine functional brain changes among the 2 disorders. The investigators estimate a 20% AUD prevalence in individuals with CUD (and therefore a 33% risk of being eligible for inclusion in both the AUD and CUD pathways). If the prevalence is higher, they may include a larger number of participants than originally anticipated (e.g. include up to 36 individuals with the AUD diagnosis). Participants in this arm are current participants in an existing integrated care pathway for CUD but are also being offered CBT for CUD. To summarize, the investigators will recruit and assess 180 participants with AUD and 37 participants with CUD. Both diagnostic groups will be followed with data collection at specific points during standard care treatment for their primary substance use disorder.

Chronic low back pain (CLBP) is a musculoskeletal disorder that is a major cause of disability worldwide. According to the Global Burden of Disease Study 2015, it is the leading cause of years lived with disability (YLDs) worldwide, and it was estimated that 11.9% of all disability worldwide and 72.9% of low back pain morbidity were associated with CLBP. In addition, CLBP is associated with direct and indirect costs, with annual estimated costs worldwide of $103 billion.
Treatment options for CLBP include medication, exercise, education, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), and SMT. Studies of SMT for CLBP have been limited by the use of short-term follow-up (maximum of 13 weeks) and a lack of understanding of the mechanisms of change associated with the treatment. Given the high financial cost of SMT and the unclear effectiveness of this intervention there is a need to improve the effectiveness of SMT as a treatment for CLBP, which is why studies are conducted to identify factors that can contribute to a better effectiveness of this intervention. In addition, investigating these factors can provide information on the effectiveness of SMT treatment for patients, especially those with CLBP.
However, previous studies have not investigated the impact of positive, neutral, and negative expectation speech on pain intensity, disability, and expectations related to SMT in CLBP patients. The aim of this study is to investigate the short-term effect of videos with different expectations regarding SMT, as delivered through positive, neutral, or negative expectation speech content, on pain intensity, perceived disability, expectations related to spinal manipulative therapy (SMT), and perceived qualities of the therapeutic encounter in CLBP patients. It is anticipated that the group submitted to a positive expectation speech about SMT will have lower pain scores, greater perceived improvement and higher expectations regarding SMT than the other groups.

The dorsal and ventral striatum, also known as the nucleus accumbens (NAC), are part of a reward network, a set of brain regions that play an important role in regulating reward- and pleasure seeking. This network is implicated in addiction, gambling, and other disorders related to reward. The activity of the NAC is influenced by the frontal cortex and is linked to both pleasure and pain in the brain. Transcranial focused ultrasound (tFUS) is a developing technology for non-invasively stimulating deep brain regions. Studies have suggested tFUS to be a promising tool for treating neurological and psychiatric disorders, however, as with other brain stimulation techniques, there is not enough knowledge about its safety and effect on the brain. The investigators aim to understand how tFUS applied at the level of the ventral striatum influences the functional connectivity between the ventral striatum and the rest of the brain.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most common cancer in China, but its incidence rate has been increasing in recent years. The risk of CRC increases exponentially after 50 years of age. Therefore, CRC screening is suggested to individuals older than 50 years old. However, more and more CRC cases occur in people younger than 50 years old, so it is possible that some individuals younger than 50 years old may have missed opportunities for cancer prevention. Since gastrointestinal diseases such as Helicobacter pylori, atrophic gastritis/intestinal metaplasia, reflux esophagitis, Barrett's esophagus, and peptic ulcer have been proven to be risk factors for colorectal cancer, colonoscopy can detect colorectal adenomatous polyps, and gastroscopy is valuable for screening for upper gastrointestinal disease. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the incidence of upper gastrointestinal diseases in individuals younger than 50 years old by gastroscopy, to test the hypothesis that these upper gastrointestinal diseases may contribute to the missed opportunities of CRC screening in individuals younger than 50 years old, and to provide guidance for CRC screening in individuals younger than 50 years old.
Inclusion criteria: Patients younger than 50 years old who underwent gastroscopy and colonoscopy simultaneously, including patients with normal colonoscopy examination and patients with colorectal polyps diagnosed by colonoscopy (both serrated and non-serrated polyps were analyzed separately).
Exclusion criteria: Patients without a satisfactory bowel preparation (Boston Bowel Preparation Scale, BBPS score ≥ 6); incomplete gastroscopy or colonoscopy examinations; partial or total gastrointestinal resection; patients who have been diagnosed with gastrointestinal cancer before endoscopy; patients with hereditary polyposis, including Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and patients with familial adenomatous polyposis; a history of inflammatory bowel diseases.
A total of 1114 gastroscopy-colonoscopy cases (1178 patients) were reviewed. The prevalence/occurrence of upper gastrointestinal diseases in individuals younger than 50 years old was 10.2%. For the upper gastrointestinal diseases (except for H. pylori, intestinal metaplasia, reflux esophagitis, and peptic ulcer), the prevalence / occurrence were 2.6% (2.2% without intestinal metaplasia) for esophagitis (non-ulcer), 2.3% for Barrett's esophagus, and 0.6% for gastric adenoma (0.12% for gastric serrated adenoma).

Background: Interferon gamma release assay (IGRA) has been widely used in place of Tuberculin skin testing as a means of detecting active tuberculosis (TB). The presence of interferon gamma (IFN-gamma) producing T-cells is indicative of active disease. IGRA consists of two antigens, one which is active in patients with TB disease and one without activity in patients without the disease. Although IFN-gamma production against each antigen has been used in individual assays, the investigators believe that IGRA may provide better sensitivity and specificity when both antigens are used together. Objective: To evaluate an interferon gamma release assay containing both antigens in a single tube with both T and B cell-dependent responses. To determine if the antigen-specific IFN-gamma response changes between a patient taking TB treatment and subsequently when they are culture negative. Subjects: The investigational team will recruit consecutive cases of newly diagnosed pulmonary tuberculosis. Setting: Plymouth County TB service, Southampton General Hospital, Basildon. Study Groups and Treatment: Healthy individuals (control) and those diagnosed with pulmonary TB (study cases). The investigators will perform an IGRA test in all cases at three time periods: at initiation of TB treatment, at the completion of 60 days therapy, and subsequently at 6 months after the completion of treatment. The investigators will then determine the change in IFN-gamma response between each time period. The investigators will assess the proportion of patients with a positive IFN-gamma response and whether this is related to the development of sputum culture conversion at 2 months and 6 months after initiation of TB therapy. Study Design: The study will consist of a single group assignment with all cases undergoing testing. After completion of the study, the investigators will report the outcomes with respect to the ability to change response profiles between study arms and to identify the relationship between culture conversion and changes in IFN-gamma responses. The investigators will compare patients who become sputum culture negative at day 60 of TB treatment with positive responders with those who have negative response at day 60.

The latency of evoked potentials (EPs) is an objective index of the processing of sensory information in the central nervous system. EPs are measurable electrical potentials in the EEG that are generated by afferent excitation of the central nervous system. In particular, the brain has a marked excitatory response to the activation of a subset of fibers that reach the central nervous system (nociceptors), which evokes EPs that are easily recorded through EEG. While nociceptive EPs have been extensively investigated, no systematic study on mechanical stimuli, such as stimulation with pinprick needles, or of high-frequency stimulation, such as radiofrequency (RF) stimulation, has been described. Thus, the purpose of this project is to carry out a systematic study of the effects of intense acute and prolonged mechanical stimuli and RF stimulation on evoked potentials in the brain. This study will allow to identify, based on different neurophysiological indexes, the differences and similarities between the electrical activation of different stimulus modalities, as well as their reproducibility in different individuals. Thus, the proposed protocol involves the evaluation of brain response to the following stimuli under controlled conditions: RF stimuli that are generated from the electrical stimulation of the dorsum of a foot (radiofrequency electrical stimulation, RFES); and pinprick stimuli, that are produced by an automated device consisting of two needles that penetrate the skin. The RFES consists of stimulation of large nerves (sensory nerves of the foot, median and ulnar nerves of the hand, or cervical nerves) with an electric current in a bipolar configuration that heats the surface of the skin. RF stimulation, like contact heat, evokes a clear and reproducible evoked potential in the brain. RF stimulation has the advantage that the stimulus intensity can be controlled through the power supply of the stimulator, thus allowing the investigation and evaluation of different thresholds of the stimulus. Pinprick stimuli consist of brief mechanical stimuli of the forearm and hand that cause a sensation of sharp pain in the subject. The intensity of this stimulus is also varied by adjusting the force and speed of the needle penetration. Unlike heat stimuli, mechanical stimuli are not painful at high intensity, since these stimuli do not evoke an irritant response in the central nervous system. The evaluation of the brain response to pinprick stimuli and the relationship of the parameters of the response to heat perception and sensation pain thresholds will allow to delimit the mechanisms by which the central nervous system generates the sensory experience of pain and touch.

These measurements will be carried out in healthy subjects and will be carried out in an experimental setting in the Laboratory of Biomedical Signal Processing-Laboratory of Physiotherapy, Faculty of Engineering, National University of Entre Ríos. It should be noted that the tests will not cause pain to the subject. Based on these tests, the response latency will be measured. For this purpose, a series of 10 stimuli will be applied at pain threshold intensity, with a single measurement per subject. After stimulation, a subjective evaluation of the sensitivity to somatosensory stimuli by the subject will be carried out, with a numerical scale of intensity of pain perception.

Study Objectives: We have previously identified a subgroup of trauma victims with mild TBI (MTBI) who have a characteristic finding of enhancement within the outermost layer of the brain's dural covering called the dura mater (meninges) on delayed post gadolinium enhanced MRI (TME). These individuals have been shown to have more complex clinical histories than age- and sex-matched trauma referents without MRI abnormality. MTE affects approximately 15% of MBI patients, and the clinical significance of this finding remains uncertain. The pathogenesis of TME is unknown, and a recent case-control study suggests that TME patients may have an increased risk of subsequent post-concussive problems. It is possible that biomechanical forces experienced by the brain as a result of its natural motion during walking or more common activities of daily living may be a precipitating factor for TME or subsequent post-concussive problems. This project will characterize the local differences in the brain's interaction with its surrounding skull in MTBI patients with and without MTE in order to understand if these biomechanical forces may be a contributing factor to MTE, or its clinical sequelae. We plan to use a technique called magnetic resonance elastography (MRE) to non-invasively quantify the relative rigidity and motion characteristics of the brain and skull in MTBI patients.
Hypotheses: The following hypotheses will be tested: In a subgroup of MTBI patients who have MTE, there is increased local mechanical coupling of motion between brain and skull, as quantified using MRE. This may help explain increased risks of developing persistent brain symptoms in TME patients. Increased mechanical coupling of motion between brain and skull is associated with increased symptoms and impaired function at six month follow-up, as measured using standardized neurobehavioral tests. These findings will be compared to patients with MTBI but no TME.
Study Population: Sixty (60) adults will be recruited for this study, including 25 subjects with a history of mild TBI but no history of TMI, 25 subjects with a history of mild TBI and TMI (TME-positive), and 35 healthy controls.
Study Procedures: Subjects will complete standardized questionnaires regarding demographics, medical history, and prior head trauma injuries. If clinically indicated, they will also undergo a structured neurological exam to determine their medical suitability for MRI. All subjects will then complete standardized neurobehavioral tests to assess their current level of brain function, performed by blinded researchers on a separate day of MRI scanning.
During the MRE portion of the MRI visit, an external device called an MRE driver plate will be placed firmly against the front of the head. The driver plate is attached to the MRI table, which is then vibrated at a precisely controlled frequency. The MRE system uses the MRI scanner to measure the relative motion of brain and skull induced by the vibrations. These measurements can reveal how much the brain and skull move in relation to each other, as well as the timing of that motion in relation to the vibration frequency. In MTBI patients with MTE or controls, the MRE measurements will be used to quantify the local differences in the biomechanical coupling between brain and skull. In MTBI patients with MTE, these measurements will be correlated with clinical history and neurobehavioral test results to determine if differences in biomechanical coupling are associated with the risk for persistent symptoms after TBI.
Official Title: Imaging Characterization of the Biomechanical Coupling of Brain and Skull: An Observational Study

Conditions: Traumatic Meningeal Injury (TME), Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)

Participation Criteria: A person who has been diagnosed with a traumatic brain injury following injury with symptoms such as headache, dizziness, dizziness, or loss of consciousness. A person who has been diagnosed with traumatic meningeal injury following injury during which symptoms occurred at a minimum one hour following injury. A person who has not been diagnosed with a traumatic brain injury, or traumatic meningeal injury.

High blood pressure, or hypertension, is a major public health issue worldwide. Women are among those who may be at an increased risk of developing hypertension. Hypertension is a common and modifiable risk factor for adverse health outcomes including stroke, heart attack, kidney disease, heart failure and dementia. Despite evidence that optimal blood pressure (BP) control decreases the risk of these outcomes, many people with hypertension are not reaching their BP target levels. One approach that has shown promise in improving BP control is through the use and integration of home blood pressure monitoring (HBPM). Patients who have hypertension can use a home blood pressure monitoring device to measure and record their blood pressure at home on a frequent basis and then input their measurements into an electronic database that is accessible to their community pharmacist. The patient's pharmacist can then review the readings and provide their own suggestions for therapy modification to the patient's prescribing clinician. In the absence of HBPM the patient may only have BP readings taken once every few weeks or only when they come into the pharmacy or doctor's office. This can result in suboptimal management and less therapeutic intervention. This pilot project aims to demonstrate the efficacy of combining HBPM and integrated pharmacist care. In addition, the study will explore barriers and facilitators for women using HBPM.
Pilot project hypothesis: Women patients utilizing HBPM and providing blood pressure readings to their community pharmacists who then provides tailored education to the patient and therapy recommendations to the patient's prescribing clinician will result in greater improvements in blood pressure control. In comparison to usual care.
To meet its aim the investigators anticipate recruiting 368 women from Ontario, Canada. In Ontario there are approximately 18 million people and 5000 community pharmacies with approximately 10,000 pharmacists. The investigators plan to implement this pilot project in 50 community pharmacies, aiming to recruit 7-10 women per pharmacy. The sample size of 368 participants will allow for 90% power and allow for a 10% drop-out in participants, thus providing a 23% margin of error.
