<|assistant|> Background: Aesthetic results after dental implant treatment are inseparable from the correct choice of the implant-prosthetic complex. For the achievement in the area of implant crowns, one of the necessary requirements is an adequate soft tissue around implants, which will create the basis for the creation of the correct implant-prosthetic construction. Soft tissue defects are one of the reasons for unsatisfactory aesthetic results. Methods: The aim of the study to compare two soft tissue augmentation methods around dental implants - the use of autogenous (connective tissue) graft and xenobionic (collagen matrix) graft. The investigators planned to conduct a prospective comparative study with one-group assignment and no masking using the patient population of the Department of Oral Implantology, Sechenov University. The investigators planned to include 40 patients in the study in whom inadequate soft tissues would be diagnosed as the reason for the failure of implant crowns. Inclusion criteria included age from 25 to 59 years, sufficient bone volume around a dental implant, and inadequate soft tissues thickness on the vestibular side (<3 mm). Exclusion criteria included patients with hard smoking (>10 cigarettes a day) who could not adhere to postoperative care, patients with medical complications, and patients who could not undergo the entire study protocol. The investigators planned to assess the severity of pain, assess the quality of life using Oral Health Impact Profile - 14 (OHIP-14), determine the amount of soft tissue thickness gain at 90 and 180 days compared to the 0th day (initial value), determine soft tissue aesthetics, determine the severity of collateral edema at 1,3,5,7,180,93 days compared to the 0th day (initial value). Data analysis: The investigators planned to use the Kruskal-Wallis test and Mann-Whitney U test for parametric data, as well as the Student's test for normative data at a significance level of 0.05. The aim of this clinical trial is to improve outcomes in primary care patients with depression. Specifically the study seeks to test whether a precision-guided approach to optimal treatment, based on their personality characteristics, can enhance clinical and functional outcomes. It will test whether those who are optimally treated will be more likely to recover than those who are not. The study is using a well-established, widely used and evidence-based intervention - antidepressant medications along with a brief psychological treatment (known as Activation theory) - as treatment options for depression. By enrolling 360 patients in each group, the investigators aim to detect a 20% difference in recovery rates. Patients recruited to the study will be followed for 12 months and their recovery, functional status, disability, wellbeing and side effects will be tracked. In addition, the investigators will try and identify biomarkers and genetic predictors of recovery in primary care patients with depression. These findings will enhance our understanding of the mechanisms of action of different treatments for depression, the role of the brain in regulating response to depression-specific treatments, and will provide insights into the development of a precision medicine approach to the treatment of depression.

This study seeks to characterize lung inflammatory cell populations, and the composition and functional characteristics of the pulmonary microbiome in moderate-to-severe ARDS compared to none-to-mild ARDS, and identify correlations between these measures and disease severity and 28-day all-cause mortality.

Foot postural index varies from 0 in good posture to 14 in severe flatfoot. Subjects will be recruited based on the Foot postural index from the Taibah University Orthopaedic Outpatient Department from 1 January to 31 October 2020. One hundred and fifty subjects will be recruited. A sample size of 120 is sufficient to demonstrate a 10% difference in pain with a confidence of 95%, assuming a 20% dropout. Subjects with flexible flatfoot who have symptoms of foot and calve pain will be recruited for this study. They will be divided into groups of an equal number of people. Prefabricated insoles will be given to one group and 3D printed insoles to the other. Both groups will use these insoles for 4 weeks. Subjective feedback will be collected at week zero, when the subjects will be given the insoles to wear, and again at week 4. Statistical analysis will be used to determine whether or not there is a significant difference in the responses of the two groups. The results will help us in identifying which insoles are better than the other in terms of parameters described above.

Primary incisional hernia is a common complication of abdominal surgery, which is more common than many people think due to high recurrence rate. Pulmonary function is the only physiological function which has a definite difference between patients with primary and recurrent incisional hernia, according to previous literatures. Pulmonary function includes pulmonary ventilation function and pulmonary diffusion function, which is affected by the defect and repair quality of the abdominal wall, and is a key factor affecting postoperative complications, such as postoperative pain, postoperative pulmonary infection, ileus and postoperative stress. To explore the influence of recurrent incisional hernia on pulmonary ventilation function, and to provide a reliable basis for clinical management and prevention, we have conducted a preliminary study on the influence of recurrence on the change of pulmonary ventilation function. We hope that this study can provide an effective strategy for clinical prevention and treatment of primary and recurrent incisional hernia.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is a major cardiovascular epidemic. It is also a major prognostic factor in patient survival, and its diagnosis is a major public health issue with about 7 million deaths each year.
CAD is due to atherosclerosis. An atheroma develops within the wall of an artery. Deposits lead to foam cells and necrotic nuclei. These atheromas are initially asymptomatic and remain non-obstructive for a long time. They become unstable only later in the course of the disease and can give rise to heart attacks, angina or death by embolism. The major advances observed over the past 20 to 30 years have focused on the prevention of cardiovascular risk factors and the management of secondary prevention. The major innovation lies in the screening of asymptomatic patients that can be carried out by cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), myocardial scintigraphy using 99m Tc sestamibi (Cardiolite Tc 99m) or coronary calcium score (CCS). These assessments make it possible to detect coronary involvement with sub-clinical progression and to monitor its evolution and treatment tolerance. They are often carried out in patients with type 2 diabetes for which it is recommended to screen by echocardiography every two years. The risk of complications for patients carrying silent coronary sclerosis is very low, but the occurrence of acute coronary syndromes is not excluded. Moreover, the screening of asymptomatic patients with an additional risk factor (diabetes, hypertension, obesity, smoking, dyslipidemia...) must be carried out at an earlier life stage. This is all the more necessary considering that the age of the onset of diabetes is becoming younger (childhood) and since patients have been treated for over 10 years with hyperlipidemic agents, which also have an anti-ischemic effect. Screening at an early stage, based on the determination of coronary calcium score (by CT scan), makes it possible to select patients in whom there are sub-clinical and silent coronary lesions to be evaluated for the prescription of a secondary prevention strategy.
The development of cardiovascular diseases is often rapid and difficult to predict before their clinical manifestation. However, with the exception of acute coronary syndromes, there is little information on the frequency of events leading to hospitalization in patients suspected of having coronary involvement. The use of molecular imaging, such as 18 F-NaF PET scanner, seems promising for detecting unstable plaques. Several imaging sequences with FDG and calcium scoring with 125 I-NaF are available for imaging the carotid and coronary arteries. The use of a 18F-labelled NaF and its detection on a PET-CT coupled scanner, and also the calculation of a calcium score is the subject of recent publication.
Calcium score is a simple, non-injected scanner that measures coronary calcifications, a stigmat of healed atheroma plaques and as a rule, non-evolving. The imaging by 18F-NaF PET scanner makes it possible to detect unstable or necrotic plaques in which the cellular composition is modified between necrotic and inflammatory cells to lipid and macrophage contents in macrophage and foam cells. The quantification of these abnormalities is essential because it is believed that it is these plaques that lead to heart attacks. The major advantage of PET scanning is its ability to detect sub-clinical events, to guide anti-necrotic drug treatment, whatever the risk factor of the patient and irrespective of his coronary plaque burden. An initial study in 2009 evaluated the 18F-NaF PET scanner compared to CT without calcium score, in stable patients complaining of chest pain and whose functional and anatomical imaging were negative. In the absence of any symptom, only the 18F-NaF PET scanner made it possible to highlight the presence of 1 or several unstable plaques.
A prospective trial to refine these results and in parallel, to propose a new strategy for the initiation of primary prevention in patients identified with an intermediate and high risk is therefore needed.
There is no reference in the literature to guide the theranostic approach of patients for whom there is no other means of evaluating the unstable plaque status.

<|assistant|> Cerebral small vessel disease (SVD) is associated with cognitive decline and dementia and is mainly manifested on brain MRI as WMH (white matter hyperintensities). These WMH can be subdivided into different forms, but there is no clear consensus about its impact on neuropsychological performance. The aim of this study is (1) to test the hypothesis that certain variations in WMH shape are more strongly associated with cognitive decline and (2) to study the potential relationship between these irregularities in WMH shape and other SVD markers (such as microinfarcts, hemorrhage and white matter integrity). Moreover, the investigators seek to investigate possible relationships between abnormal WMH shape to markers of abnormal CSF-flow around perivascular spaces. As a secondary outcome measure they want to explore these associations further and study whether different 'phenotypes' of WMH can be identified based on their shape. Esophagogastric junctional adenocarcinoma is a common digestive system malignant tumors, and its diagnosis is often difficult. Endoscopic diagnosis is the gold standard and most cost-effective method, but traditional endoscopic image interpretation still faces some limitations, and the diagnosis rate needs to be improved. In recent years, artificial intelligence has been widely applied in various fields, but the application of artificial intelligence in endoscopy diagnosis of esophageal gastric junction adenocarcinoma has not yet been systematically evaluated.
In the past, the research of artificial intelligence in the diagnosis of tumors has been very successful. In addition to the initial diagnosis and recognition of tumors through artificial intelligence, more attention is focused on the detection of lesions and the recognition of tumor states. Artificial intelligence plays an important role in guiding clinical diagnosis by analyzing the changes of internal texture and other characteristics, and has been widely used in the pathway and treatment of various tumors. Artificial intelligence algorithms such as CNN, CapsNet, etc. And combined with deep learning technology that has matured in recent years to mine hidden features through large data analysis, can make accurate predictions of images, thus helping to detect and diagnose tumors. In this study, we plan to use deep learning artificial intelligence algorithms to analyze the endoscopic image features of esophageal gastric junction adenocarcinoma and normal tissue to establish a diagnostic model, and to compare the diagnostic value of artificial intelligence with professional doctors.
Therefore, after preliminary research of the clinical database of the Digestive Endoscopy Center of Changhai Hospital, we propose the following plans:
1. Develop and verify an artificially intelligent endoscopic diagnosis system based on deep learning for esophageal gastric junction adenocarcinoma.
2. After preliminary research of the clinical database of the Digestive Endoscopy Center of Changhai Hospital, we used the data of endoscopic cases in this center to collect and verify the established model.
The specific research plan and methods:
1. Develop an artificially intelligent endoscopic diagnosis system based on deep learning.
2. Develop a training set suitable for modeling.
3. Develop and verify a test set.
4. Develop and verify a verification set.
5. Compare the diagnostic value of artificial intelligence with professionals.

Music therapy has emerged as a complementary treatment in palliative care that is associated with beneficial effects on physical symptoms, psychological well-being, spiritual needs, and quality of life. Music therapy interventions are heterogeneous in that both receptive and active techniques are employed, with varying instruments, durations, and therapeutic approaches. A variety of training backgrounds are found in practicing music therapists. Research has not yet provided unequivocal confirmation of the therapeutic value of various music therapy interventions in palliative care, in that the effects observed have been measured by subjective assessments that rely on rating scales or questionnaires. Few studies to date have utilized objective outcome parameters to assess psychological or autonomic response to music therapy in palliative care populations. It is possible that individual preferences concerning the music employed may be an important variable in the beneficial effects of music therapy in palliative care patients. The present study aims to assess the acceptability of different music interventions, played live or using a pre-recorded track, with objective recordings of human autonomic response using the Corsano wristband 287-2 in addition to subjective assessments of psychological outcome.
This study is designed as a prospective, repeated-measures study at the palliative care ward of the University Hospital Zurich as part of the Integrated Biopsychosocial Laboratory. Healthy research assistants will be trained in music therapy and receive additional training in the use of the 287-2 wristband. The 287-2 wristband is designed for use in autonomic recordings of humans without the need for skin disinfection or abrasion of skin. With the application of a dry electrode on the left wrist, multiple simultaneous biomarkers of autonomic response can be assessed, including skin temperature, heart rate, heart rate variability, electrodermal activity, and Galvanic skin response. The data collected using the 287-2 is stored on a computer system via Bluetooth connection.
The data will be analyzed using non-parametric statistical methods applying the Wilcoxon matched-pairs signed-ranks test to compare pre- and post-therapy data for each biomarker assessed. Descriptive statistics will be obtained for each biomarker with the corresponding time point. Effect sizes will be analyzed by calculating the Hedges' g coefficient and 95% confidence intervals. The investigators will conduct sub-group analyses based on gender and age to assess potential interactions with intervention effect.
At the completion of data collection, patients will be invited to participate in an exit interview regarding the acceptability of the music and the method of delivery (live or recording). The investigators will utilize a modified version of the THETAF-II of the Theoretical Framework of Acceptability (TFA) to assess participants' acceptability of music therapy played live and from a pre-recorded track. Participants will be asked to rate six items on a scale of 1 - 5, with higher values demonstrating increased acceptability of the specific music therapy intervention. The questionnaire was adapted to the specific content of the present study and translations have been verified with the lead author, a musicologist and experienced music therapist. Descriptive statistics will be applied to calculate the mean intervention-specific acceptability questionnaire score of each treatment condition, followed by the Wilcoxon matched-pairs signed-ranks test to analyze differences in intervention-specific acceptability questionnaire scores. Secondary outcome measures are described below.
The investigators will utilize three validated and widely used questionnaires to assess subjective outcome measures. The European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire 15 Palliative Care (EORTC QLQ-C15-PAL) is the validated short-form version of the EORTC QLQ-C30-PAL and will be employed to assess general quality of life. The questionnaire yields subjective ratings of various aspects of quality of life such as physical, emotional, and social functioning. Other measures such as the Edmonton Symptom Assessment System (ESAS) will be employed to assess subjective symptoms such as pain, dyspnea and nausea. Finally, the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) will be used to assess anxiety and depressive symptoms. Qualitative analysis of open questions will be performed to evaluate the subjective experience of patients with regard to the music therapy sessions and the corresponding method of delivery.
The investigators will employ statistical methods to test if these questionnaire parameters differ according to the type of music therapy (live or recording). Descriptive statistics will be obtained for each questionnaire item, followed by the Wilcoxon signed-

Globally, cataract surgery is the most common major operation in ophthalmology, serving millions of patients annually. Nearly half the waste of cataract surgery, as reported by a prospective Malaysian study was recyclable1. Despite the increasing evidence of reusing the operative supplies during cataract surgery in order to cut cost and waste, and in order to lower global warming and climate change, healthcare professionals may be reluctant to consider it due to worries of cross-contamination among patients3. This is mainly because of the risk of intraocular infection, Toxic Anterior Segment Syndrome (TASS) due to contamination of the anterior chamber by micro-organisms3. To date, there is no randomized study in humans to evaluate the effect of reusing of operative supplies during cataract surgery on postoperative complications3. It also means a decrease in the ecological footprint of cataract surgery. 
To date, there is no randomized study in humans to evaluate the effect of reusing of operative supplies during cataract surgery on postoperative complications, especially endophthalmitis and TASS.
The aim of this trial is to show if reusing the operative supplies to reduce financial costs, especially in developing countries, will affect the rate of postoperative endophthalmitis after cataract surgery. In the proposed study, the investigators will assess the risk and the infection rate between:
The routine use of different new gloves, gowns, and tips of the phacoemulsification with hand and gloves sterilization.
The reuse of the same gown, gloves, tips, and operative equipment between selected consecutive cataract patients.
In order to minimize the risk of infection during the reuse of the operative supplies, adequate sterilization and hand hygiene are done:
hand sterilization with alcohol once, each time before and after wearing the next gloves,
changing the tip of the phacoemulsification only and used throughout the operation,
the reuse of keratome, MVR, IOL cartridge, cassette-sac from multiple patients by immersion of them between cases in alcohol, and
the reuse of OVD between multiple surgeries by immersion of them between cases in alcohol.
The irrigation fluid to be used is 3/50 saline solution during 3min.
After each surgery, the conjunctival and corneal wounds were closed with the same 9-0 nylon suture.
All patients received of antibiotic prophylaxis, topical Gatifloxacin (Tymer) and Prednisolone (Optipred) drops one drop per day for the first ten days after the surgery, and a topical combination of Ofloxacin, dexamethasone (Dexaflox), and a lubricant (Systane) three times a day for the next four weeks.
Intraocular antiseptic and topical antibiotics can minimize the risk of ocular infection and the risk of contamination to the corneal stroma.
Topical Gatifloxacin and Prednisolone drops were used for 10 days after the surgery, while a combination of Ofloxacin, dexamethasone (Dexaflox), and a lubricant (Systane) were used three times a day for the next four weeks.

Building on the previous foundation and literature review, we found that ACC is closely related to the core symptoms of AN, and proposed the hypotheses that ACC overactivation and abnormal functional connectivity with other brain regions (anterior frontal lobe, parietal lobe, precuneus, and striatum) is the neuropathological mechanism for the onset of AN. The study is the first time to use dTMS to intervene with ACC in the treatment of adult AN. A randomized controlled study design was adopted, in which patients with AN were divided into the dTMS treatment group and the pseudo-stimulation group by 1:1 randomization, followed by 6-week intervention and half-year follow up, to clarify the near-term and long-term efficacy and safety of the dTMS treatment. Psychometric and fMRI examinations were performed at baseline in both groups. The rest of the time follow-up of symptoms and psychometrics and side-effects questionnaires were performed at week 2, 4, and 6 (during treatment) as well as at week 4, 12, and 24 ( after completion of treatment). Meanwhile, baseline fMRI data were extracted and combined with clinical features to establish an efficacy prediction model. Factors predictive of dTMS efficacy in AN patients of dTMS treatment group, divided into two groups according to whether dTMS was effective or not at the end of treatment (week 6) (effective is defined as BMI increasing by ≥1.2 kg/m2 at the end of treatment), using pre-treatment (baseline) demographic information, psychological assessment questionnaires, and neuroimaging data in the two groups. This will provide theoretical and practical basis for the pioneering ACC-targeted dTMS treatment in China, helping to establish a new type of intervention program for AN, with expected results of innovation.

In France, the only disease being screened in the newborn screening program (NBS) is phenylketonuria. The extension of the NBS has been a long-pursued goal in all the countries and is the subject of numerous studies.
The extension of newborn screening depends on public opinion and its acceptability. However, the results of acceptability studies carried out so far are contradictory, partly due to the use of different definitions of acceptability, but mainly due to the absence of validated multidimensional models of acceptability.
We propose to conduct a prospective, quantitative and qualitative nationwide survey of acceptability among both parents of healthy newborns and parents of a sick child. The aim is first to adapt the multidimensional definition of acceptability and then to use it to measure the acceptability of expanded newborn screening. The survey will also be used to describe parents' expectations and perceptions of expanded newborn screening and to generate hypotheses about the variables associated with positive and negative views on expanded newborn screening.
A second objective of the study is to provide a better understanding of parents who have had to endure a screening/diagnosis/treatment pathway involving the newborn's diseases or close relatives' illnesses (including cancers). These parents may have a different view of expanded newborn screening.
A third objective of the study is to analyze the effects of socio-cultural parameters such as socio-professional category or geographic area on the acceptability of expanded newborn screening.

This is a UK-based observational study that aims to discover novel predictive biomarkers with the potential to guide treatment decision making and prolong PFS and OS in patients with advanced TNBC. Patients will undergo a mandatory, study-specific core needle biopsy or fine needle aspiration of the breast tumour or metastasis before commencing their next line of therapy. The research sample will be run on Pear Bio's test whilst the patient receives therapy as per their physician's choice. This study will not use Pear Bio's tool to inform the choice of treatment, with the treating oncologist being blinded to the test results. Treatment response data will be collected at multiple timepoints to conduct analyses on the study's secondary and tertiary objectives. Fresh tissue resections that arrive at Pear Bio's lab will undergo processing, cell culture and various drug dosing and omics assays (depending on extracted cell numbers). Tumour samples will be processed using a cell isolation kit to retrieve a viable single-cell suspension. A minimum of 100,000 cells (10,000 viable cells per chip) will be used for staining with live and dead cell-tracking dyes. In parallel, blood vials will be processed for PBMCs and further effector cell extraction (flow cytometry, Dynabeads, etc). The remaining cells will be used for sequencing (DNA/RNA), fixed for immunofluorescence characterisation of biomarkers/receptor status or used for further omics assays (if cell numbers allow). The stained cells will be cultured in a biomimetic hydrogel within Pear Bio's organ-on-a-chip to provide a physiological 3D environment for drug dosing experiments. Using a microfluidic device, samples in each chip will be exposed to approved therapies (either as monotherapy or combination therapies, as outlined below) over multiple days. In parallel, PBMCs will be extracted from whole blood, characterised and sorted via flow cytometry and fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) or magnetic beads selection. Cells of interest (e.g. CD8+ T cells) will be used for culture in Pear Bio's chips jointly with cells isolated from the matched tumour sample. To test immunotherapies, tumour cells will be co-cultured with immune cells in a modified organ-on-a-chip architecture. Chips receiving immunotherapies may be tested for tumour mutational burden and/or microsatellite instability. Confocal microscopy will be conducted daily to collect 3D image data of the cells and track their position and behaviour over time. At the end of the assay, the 3D cell cultures will be fixed for further 3D immunofluorescence analyses or used for embedding, sectioning and assessment of spatial transcriptomics. For targeted therapies, RNAseq, IF and other omics data will be integrated to confirm drug MoA and identify other potential therapeutic targets. Concurrently, 3D image data is processed through a computer vision pipeline to measure functional metrics of the ex vivo 3D cell cultures, including cell viability, cell culture width and cell migration, both at a bulk tumour level and at a single-cell resolution. For immunotherapies, additional metrics such as immune cell infiltration and immune cell killing will be recorded. A patient report is then generated to outline an individual patient sample's response to each therapy tested.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to bowel changes, ranging from severe dysplasia to colon cancer. In addition to inflammation in the intestine, IBD causes psychological illness and has a great impact on a person´s well-being and quality of life. IBD patients often need surgery and a long waiting time for surgical procedures can cause significant complications. There is a need to find better ways to treat and follow up IBD patients that reduces the need for surgery. The purpose of the present study is to evaluate if a patient with IBD and a prolonged waiting time for elective surgery differs in both quality of life and socioeconomic status from a patient who has undergone an elective surgery. The study will also focus on the cost of treatment for patients delayed for elective surgery compared to a patient who is operated with elective surgery. Another focus will be if delayed surgery increases complications and the need for reoperation compared to a patient that is operated with elective surgery in a timely manner. A questionnaire will be given to IBD patients, both those who are planned for elective surgery and those who have been operated with elective surgery to investigate the impact of their condition on their quality of life, employment status and socioeconomic situation. A retrospective questionnaire will be given to patients who were operated with elective surgery to investigate their course of disease, complications and needs of re-operation. By doing this, it will be possible to calculate the cost of treatment over time (from the time before surgery to the end of the study) and investigate if delayed surgery leads to increased complications and a need for re-operation. It is well established that early surgery improves the prognosis for patients with IBD, but the decision to delay surgery needs to consider the costs, benefits and risks for each patient affected. By this study we will obtain knowledge that will help us to find better ways of managing the patients and reduce complications and costs in cases where surgery is delayed. By following up on the patients´ condition, including quality of life and socioeconomic status, we will also increase knowledge about what happens with patients with IBD when surgery is delayed. If we find that the patient's condition is negatively affected or if there is a disproportionate risk of complications for the patient, surgery can be performed earlier, and if resources are limited, operations can be prioritised in a better way. The results in this study will allow us to investigate and describe potential societal and patient implications of delayed surgery and thereby develop new strategies in how we handle delayed IBD surgery.

Additionally, added sugars play a significant role in childhood obesity and are also the leading preventable cause of tooth decay. Because added sugars are found in high amounts in flavored sparkling water (SSW), these drinks are the primary drinks that adolescents consume. The proposed study will evaluate whether the substitution of sparkling water has health benefits in adolescents, compared to SSB. In the study, the researchers will compare the effects of a sparkling water intervention that promotes the daily consumption of flavored sparkling water instead of SSB. Adolescents, and their parents, will be provided with enough supplies of the drink each month. The researchers will also provide iPhones with a mobile food recording app. During the study, study staff will regularly communicate with adolescents through the app to encourage them to consume the sparkling water. The investigators hypothesize that by substituting sparkling water for SSB, the adolescents' overall added sugar consumption and energy intake will decline. The decline in added sugar consumption will lead to improved indices of health. Improved health outcomes such as lower waist circumference, increased insulin sensitivity and reduced HgbA1c will occur without changing caloric and macronutrient intake from the American Academy of Pediatrics recommended levels. These positive effects will be sustainable and reproducible over a yearlong intervention. In the first study arm (i.e., Experimental group) adolescents who receive the sparkling water intervention are expected to have declining levels of added sugar and energy intake. In the second study arm, (i.e., Control group), adolescents who do not receive a sparkling water intervention are expected to maintain high levels of added sugars. The study will provide adolescents with a unique opportunity to adopt healthier dietary habits, which they can retain after the study intervention. If these benefits can be maintained, it will provide strong support for the substitution of sparkling water for SSB as a promising dietary pattern for adolescents. Findings have implications for adolescent health, clinical practice and the reduction of disease related to diabetes. This study is feasible, with clear, measurable outcomes, and will provide preliminary data to support research on the effectiveness of interventions that promote the adoption of healthier dietary patterns in adolescent populations at risk for obesity and onset of type 2 diabetes.

Introduction: In resective periodontal surgery suturing has a pivotal role in obtaining a definitive closure of the wound to achieve the best possible postoperative outcome. Several polyglycolic acid (PGA) sutures are available on the market at present. The aim of this clinical study is to evaluate the early wound healing, wound dehiscence, oral candidiasis, dentinal hypersensitivity, angular cheilitis, swelling, bleeding, infection, pain, satisfaction, suture handling and bacterial colonization on the suture.
Material and methods: This is a monocentric, double-blinded, randomized, parallel controlled study. Adult patients undergoing resective periodontal surgery will randomly (1:1 - stratified by study site) receive Novosyn® Quick (control group) or Monosyn® Quick (treatment group). The first 28 patients included in the study will be the run in period. Patients, surgeon, and outcome assessor will be blinded to the type of suture used. The sample size was calculated using the outcome parameter "clinical signs of wound healing" (Early Wound Healing Score) considering the difference between the scores and the pooled standard deviation. The allocation will be randomized (1:1 dynamic allocation) with minimisation algorithm to a suture group. Randomisation will be stratified by study site. Randomisation will be stratified by study site. Data will be analysed using Chi-square test, Student t-test, Mann-Whitney U test and univariate linear regression on continuous variables.
The primary end point in order to evaluate the primary objective of the project (i.e. to assess the early wound healing score, clinical signs of re-epithelization, clinical signs of haemostasis, and clinical signs of inflammation) is defined as the assessment of the Early Wound Healing score in patients undergoing resective periodontal surgery 10 ± 5 days postoperatively. Clinical signs of wound healing will be scored by one investigator blinded to the treatment. The early wound healing score (EHS) is a three parameter score including clinical signs of re-epithelization, clinical signs of haemostasis, and clinical signs of inflammation.

In conclusion, we provide a preliminary treatment for sudden deafness with new ideas and explore more accurate pathways. Objective: To observe the effectiveness and safety of CoenzymeI for injection combined with conventional treatment in the rehabilitation of hearing loss caused by sudden deafness, and to assess the safety of CoenzymeI for injection. Methods: This is a small sample (2 groups), unicenter, double-blind, randomized research. The inclusion criteria were as follows: (1)Age: ≥18yrs. The 2019 American Sudden Deafness Guidelines are for patients with sudden deafness over 18 years of age; (2)Patients diagnosed with sudden deafness, i.e. unexplained sensorineural hearing loss occurred within 72 hours, with hearing threshold≥30 in at least 3 consecutive frequencies, refer to the 2019 American Sudden Deafness Guidelines; (3)Unilateral sudden deafness; (4)Within 1 week of the onset of sudden deafness, no treatment in another hospital/our hospital; (5)No major neurological disease, serious systemic disease, family genetic history, major mental illness; (6)Informed and agreed to join the experiment, no plan to move out or go out within 1 month; (7)If the doctor judged that the patient had no major problems affecting the completion of the study. Exclusion criteria: (1)Other diseases such as acoustic neuroma diagnosed by imaging; (2)Those who cannot tolerate NAD+; (3)Pregnancy. The patients were divided into the treatment group and the observation group. The treatment group was treated with Coenzyme I for injection and conventional treatment, and the observation group was treated with conventional treatment. The main observation indicators are pure tone hearing threshold, tinnitus score and visual analogue scale. Based on a pilot project, we have gathered data on children with nephropathic cystinosis from cysteamine therapy. These pilot data do not provide proof of the benefit of early detection. The transfer to a larger study is hindered by a lack of uniformly agreed upon criteria. A study of the current study size would therefore be too large.
The aim of this study is:
- scientific evaluation of the transferability of the molecular newborn screening for nephropathic cystinosis (screen CST) and
- evaluation of the possible transferability of the genetic newborn screening for primary hyperoxaluria (screens I & II) to other laboratories.
The genetic newborn screenings for cystinosis (screen CST) and the primary hyperoxaluria screening (screen I & II) are carried out without additional costs for the laboratories participating in the study. Participating laboratories can thus not gain economic benefits from it.
Since 2010, the first screening in the DHK has been taking place at the Hannover Medical School (MHH) in about 40% of the births in Lower Saxony with maternal consent. Therefore, this project is mainly limited to the testing period, but the data for the affected children will be collected as usual in the MHH by the parents or physicians. In principle, all newborns whose parents have agreed to participate in the pilot project at HMH will be tested for two mutations in the CTNS gene, and for the cysteamine test, and depending on the test result, for one mutation in the PH1 gene and one mutation in the HOGA1 gene (see design details). The detection rate of both diseases is expected to be >95%.
The follow-up of patients with positive screening results is carried out according to the NBS guidelines of the individual federal states by the competent centers for rare diseases (see design details). In the case of newly diagnosed affected children (Cystinosis) the follow-up will take place in the interdisciplinary cystinosis consultation of the German competence center for cystinosis.
At the age of 10 years, the outcome of the affected children screened for will be evaluated. An extended data will be derived according to a predefined protocol. This extended data is intended to enable an interdisciplinary scientific evaluation.
Parents whose children are to be tested have the opportunity to waive participation in this study. Based on the consent given up to 72 hours after birth or, if not obtained promptly, up to 10 to 14 days after birth, the parents may revoke their consent at any time.
The study is carried out as a non-interventional study with a case-control design without economic benefits. Parents receive the usual care of their children. Screening laboratories are not financially compensated, as their routine NBS is only slightly burdensome through the testing of new mutations.
If the study is negative, no conclusions can be drawn about the future introduction of molecular genetic NBS for Cystinosis and PH in Germany. If the study is positive, its results can be used to scientifically justify a screening of the respective diseases in the future in Germany. In this context, the results on the proportion of heterozygous variants can also be used for the introduction of further variants into the NBS screening. In this way, it is possible to achieve a broad NBS screening, which also covers the detection of heterozygous carriers for the rare diseases. However, in the long term, genetic screening for cystinosis and PH will be necessary to further reduce its costs, to ensure equal distribution of health in Germany and to improve the health of the population overall.

Background: Negative pressure wound therapy is a common practice, but few study shows the effect of placing negative pressure drainage in patients underwent laparoscopic intra-abdominal surgery in surgical wound. Some surgical field, such as gastrointestinal cancer surgery and surgery after the accident of gastrointestinal organ, has high possibility of post operative surgical site infection. Infection at the surgical site can give a big impact to both the patients and health care cost. Aim: To evaluate the effect of placing negative pressure drainage on the post operative surgical site infection rate of clean-contaminated and contaminated surgical wounds from intra-abdominal surgery. We plan to recruit patients who underwent the gastrointestinal surgery. Hypothesis: Place negative pressure drainage on the surgical wound can reduce the postoperative surgical site infection rate of clean-contaminated surgical wound in intra-abdominal surgery. Methods: First, we will conduct a pilot study by using online calculator (Nomogram) to calculate and compare the sample size between two different study model before full scale study. We will recruit 46 patients for each study model. For the control group, we place no drainage in the surgical wound after skin closure. Then we will place negative pressure drainage in the surgical wound after skin closure for the intervention group. We will put out the drainage when the fluid content is less than 20 ml per day. The investigators collect data at the day following the surgery, the second postoperative day, the postoperative third day and the postoperative seventh day. The investigators will follow up on the patients until discharge from the hospital and when discharge, they will evaluate it by 36-Item Short Form Survey Instrument (SF-36) survey according to hospital service at the 7th day after the discharge from hospital. Finally we will compare the rate of surgical site infection between two groups and the comparison will be performed by the Chi-square test, or Fisher exact test at 0.05 level of Significance. Sample Size: To compare the rate of surgical site infection which is considered the primary outcome, our previous study which is the study of negative pressure drainage on open abdominal surgery, the event of surgical site infection occurred in the control group was 6 % while that in the intervention group was 2 %. The sample size of control group that will be recruited is 60 patients and for intervention group is 85 patients. To estimate the incidence of SSI in this study, the total number of patients is a 7:5 ratio (control: intervention). Thus the total patient number is 140 patients (60 controls, 80 intervention). Power: 95% Power was estimated a priori. Based on these calculations, sample sizes of the groups in the pilot study are 12. To detect the difference of a 4% of reduction on the rate of SSI between the two groups. A total of 46 patients for each study groups. To detect the difference in the length of hospital stay with a power level of 80% will require 96 evaluable patients with 48 patients per group.

The 3 FDA-approved CDK4, 6 inhibitors, palbociclib, ribociclib, and abemaciclib, all provided progression-free survival benefits when combined with endocrine therapy in advanced ER+/HER2- breast cancer. But, not all of them provided overall survival benefit in the same setting. One of the proposed mechanisms that influence the overall survival difference is from the different influence of the 3 CDK4, 6 inhibitors on tumor microenvironment and / or immune system. However, there was no head-to-head comparison of the 3 CDK4, 6 inhibitors in the same study. Neoadjuvant therapy provides a window to obtain tissue samples before treatment, during treatment, and after treatment. We aim to compare the immune modulation effects of palbociclib, ribociclib, and abemaciclib with letrozole in neoadjuvant treatment for ER+/HER2- early breast cancer. We will collect tumor tissue, blood, and stool samples prospectively before treatment, at 2 weeks after treatment, and after 12 weeks of treatment at the time of surgery. Immune modulation effects will be compared between 3 treatment groups from breast tumor RNAseq analysis. No randomized clinical trial of CDK4, 6 inhibitors combination with letrozole in neoadjuvant setting has been reported to investigate the immune modulation effects of CDK4, 6 inhibitors. This clinical trial is designed to assess the immune modulation effects (changes of transcriptomic profiles from 3 CDK4, 6 inhibitors) of palbociclib, ribociclib, and abemaciclib compared to letrozole in patients with ER+/HER2- breast cancer treated with neoadjuvant CDK4, 6 inhibitors plus letrozole. Tumor immune microenvironment might be modified by the addition of different CDK4, 6 inhibitors. Our hypothesis is that the different immune modulation effects among palbociclib, ribociclib, and abemaciclib when combined with letrozole will contribute to the overall efficacy. The study population will consist of postmenopausal female patients with ER+/HER2- breast cancer. The investigators will conduct a prospective, randomized study to compare the expression status of immune-related signatures on RNAseq after different CDK4, 6 inhibitors treatments using three different CDK4, 6 inhibitors (palbociclib, ribociclib, abemaciclib) combined with letrozole in each treatment group. By studying the immune modulation difference between the three treatment groups that are currently available as neoadjuvant treatment option, our study can provide evidence of the immune modulation effect of CDK4, 6 inhibitor in neoadjuvant setting of ER+/HER2- breast cancer, which is valuable for the clinical decision and the development of CDK4, 6 inhibitor strategy in precision medicine.
It is an open-label randomized study with parallel assignment.

Official Title
-----------------
A Randomized, Open-label, Parallel-group Study Comparing the Immune Modulation Effect of Ribociclib, Palbociclib, and Abemaciclib in Early ER+/HER2- Breast Cancer

Conditions
-----------------
Breast Cancer, Hormone Receptor-positive Breast Cancer, Hormone Therapy

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Drug: Palbociclib
* Drug: Ribociclib
* Drug: Abemaciclib
* Drug: Letrozole

The study is a randomized controlled trial. New mothers experience postpartum depression after childbirth, which may cause mood swings, crying spells, anxiety, and difficulty sleeping. Postpartum depression mainly begins within two to three days after delivery and may last for up to several weeks or months. Physical activity and mobility have been found to be an integral part of human life, which has significant effects on postnatal depression. This study hypotheses that women in resistance groups will have increased self-efficacy, reduced depression scores and higher maternal quality of life than participants in the flexibility group.
                This study is a cross-sectional research study, conducted at the Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology at Jinnah Hospital, Lahore. After informed consent, the 36 postpartum women will be selected using a purposive sampling method. They will be divided into two groups. The data will be collected after obtaining informed consent from the participants by administering a questionnaire for assessing self-efficacy, depression, and maternal quality of life. Data collection is an interview process. Resistance training group will be given resistance training. Twice per week for 8 weeks. Total 16 sessions will give to both intervention groups. Flexibility training group will be given flexibility training. Twice per week for 8 weeks. Total 16 sessions will give to both intervention groups. To assess self-efficacy, Depression scores will be measured using self-efficacy self-report questionnaire developed by Shumway-Cook & Williams in 1995. Epidemiological studies Depression scale developed by Radloff in 1977. Maternal Postpartum Quality of Life Questionnaire (MAPP-QOL) questionnaire will be administered to measure maternal quality of life during the early postnatal period.
                The study will use a two-group design. Intervention groups will have twenty-five per group. Data analysis will be performed using statistical package for social sciences (SPSS) version 25. Data will be presented in terms of frequencies & percentages and mean & standard deviations. After 4 weeks of intervention, it is hypothesized that women in resistance groups will have increased self-efficacy, reduced depression scores and higher maternal quality of life than participants and control group; also the scores will be different in each group.

Dental wear is one of the most common factors that negatively affect quality of life. For the first time, surface hardness of denture teeth is measured and its correlation with the wear resistance are compared between the prefabricated and CAD/CAM milled dentures in an attempt to increase knowledge of the most appropriate dentures to be used. 2D, Vertical wear were used to characterize the wear on denture teeth. 3D Volumetric wear was measured using a 3D scanner, which provided measurements of wear in the vertical, horizontal and rotational coordinates in a more detailed manner. Predefined inclusion criteria were used for the cross-over clinical trial. All prefabricated artificial teeth of both the conventional acrylic resin base and CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth were measured for surface hardness at the onset of the study and again 6 months later. Vertical wear, 2D, 3D wear were measured when the prefabricated and CAD/CAM milled teeth were used at the onset of the study and again 6 months later. The Vickers's micro indentation tester (Model: HXD-100; Shore Inc. Suzhou, China) was used to evaluate the surface hardness (HV) of the artificial teeth. Two indentations were done separately on the occlusal region of artificial teeth on both sides and its mean value was recorded. The wear resistance of prefabricated and CAD/CAM artificial teeth are significantly correlated (r=0.755, P<0.001). The 2D wear, Vertical wear and 3D Volumetric wear were measured when the prefabricated and CAD/CAM milled teeth were used at the onset of the study and again 6 months later and the difference, p values of the prefabricated and CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth ware studied using T-test. The results show that the 2D, Vertical wear and 3D Volumetric wear of prefabricated and CAD/CAM artificial teeth were non-significant at 0.05 level of P, Pvalue shows no significant difference between the prefabricated and CAD/CAM artificial teeth. The surface hardness of prefabricated and CAD/CAM artificial teeth were significantly correlated (r=0.755, P<0.001). The results show that there is no significant difference in surface hardness and wear resistance between prefabricated and CAD/CAM artificial teeth. Surface hardness, wear resistance were measured with a higher magnification and in three dimensions using 3D scanning. For the first time the surface 3D characteristics of the teeth were demonstrated using the superimposition of the teeth in a 2D and 3D plane. For the first time, surface hardness of denture teeth was measured and its correlation with the wear resistance are compared between the prefabricated and CAD/CAM milled dentures. The results showed that there was no significant difference in surface hardness and wear resistance between prefabricated and CAD/CAM artificial teeth. A further comparison with clinical data for different age groups and dentures usage time is needed. It was concluded that prefabricated and CAD/CAM milled denture teeth have similar surface characteristics and their use is clinically effective. It is recommended that more detailed measurements should be carried out on larger sample size and more age groups. For the first time the surface 3D characteristics of the teeth were demonstrated using surface 3D mapping and scanning. There is need for more measurements of teeth on a larger sample size, and for different age groups. Furthermore, clinical data from patient files using similar tooth types with different usage times and different patient age groups as well as clinical data from the examination of oral mucosal changes for different tooth types should be investigated.

The purpose of this study is to see whether Trastuzumab deruxtecan therapy is more effective than standard neoadjuvant (before surgery) chemotherapy in treating people with HER2-positive breast cancer. It will compare the effectiveness of the trastuzumab deruxtecan regimen with a standard regimen (consisting of docetaxel, carboplatin, trastuzumab and pre-operative hormone therapy for those with hormone receptor positive tumors).
For this study, patients are not required to have specific tests or perform procedures before being eligible to participate. Once the participant is eligible and has agreed to take part in the study, further tests are performed. These tests are to:
- Ensure that the tumor is HER2-positive
- Perform imaging tests, such as positron emission tomography (PET) scans
- Confirm the molecular subtype of the patient's tumor using gene expression profiling (GEP) analysis, known as PAM50.
This study will follow the participants for up to 5 years through regular visits and phone calls. A visit may include:
- Examination
- Blood tests
- Imaging scans
- Biopsies
The study will also see if trastuzumab deruxtecan can be given based on molecular testing in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer.
This study also tries to understand:
- How well patients respond to the study drugs
- Factors such as how breast cancer develops may be related to the treatment success of trastuzumab deruxtecan.

The sevoflurane and propofol groups, both of which were randomized, were included in the study. After the preoperative evaluation, the exclusion and inclusion criteria were met, and the patient, anesthetist, and patient care team and relatives were informed and agreed, were allotted to the two groups. Preoperative evaluators and the anesthetist responsible for general anesthesia in the operating room had no knowledge of the grouping method. There was no discussion or data exchange between the two groups. The participants and data analysts were all blinded. During the operation, the dose of anesthetic drugs (propofol/ fentanyl /remifentanil and sevoflurane/ cisatracurium/ rocuronium) were adjusted to maintain the mean arterial pressure and heartbeat fluctuations within 20% of the baseline value and Entropy (or BIS) value at 40-60in both groups. Postoperative complications within 30 days were assessed by the surgeon or anesthetist. After discharge from the hospital, the patients were followed up by phone or in person every 3 months. The follow-up time was up to 5 years. Clinical follow-up data such as postoperative complications and survival status were recorded every 3 months. The functional capacity score, tumor marker, tumor size, intraoperative blood loss/transfusion, duration of surgery, duration of anesthesia, total opioid (remifentanil/ fentanyl/ propofol) use, postoperative radiation therapy, postoperative chemotherapy, postoperative concurrent chemoradiotherapy, the presence of disease progression, and 90-day, 6-month, 1-year, and 3-year overall survival and Karnofsky performance status score were recorded. The investigators also used the patient's medical records and the electronic medical record system to track the patient's prognosis. Survival follow-up was conducted using telephone follow-up on patients with known survival. When the patients died, the investigator contacted the patient's families to record their survival status.

Physical activity-related health competence is a major factor in health promotion among nursing students. A key factor for the promotion of PAHCO is the transferability of knowledge into one`s own everyday life. Nursing schools, which provide professional training for tomorrow's nurses, play an essential role in promoting health competence in the future. To this end, the present study aims to promote PAHCO among nursing students in the Bavarian region, thereby supporting health-oriented action both during the study and in professional life. Using a cluster randomized controlled trial (cRCT), the study aims to improve PAHCO by disseminating a specific intervention concept, the effect of which depends on the education type (i.e., vocational college: cooperative planning; university of applied sciences: expert-based intervention concept delivered by external physical-activity specialist; university: expert-based intervention concept delivered by teachers). In addition, a co-creation process for the development of intervention concepts will be conducted with the nursing schools. Quantitative and qualitative secondary data analyses of both data collection points (longitudinal) will evaluate the effectiveness of the interventions on the individual-, group- and school-level. The overall objective of the research project is to (a) contribute to the dissemination of PAHCO among nursing students and (b) to provide information for the promotion of health competence in vocational institutions of other occupational fields.

In this study, we aimed to evaluate the effects of Diosmin/Hesperidin combination on the clinical outcomes in patients with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome.
The effects of Diosmin/Hesperidin (Daflon two tablets 500 mg daily), Metformin (Glucophage ® 500 tablets twice daily), and Combined oral contraceptive combination (Yassmin ® film-coated tablets 3 mg of drospirenone and 0.03 mg of ethinyl estradiol once daily) to compare to the standard hormonal contraceptive for the treatment of PCOS.
Participants were randomly assigned to receive Daflon (two tablets 500 mg daily, n= 46) + the standard hormonal contraceptive (Yassmin ® film-coated tablets 3 mg of drospirenone and 0.03 mg of ethinyl estradiol once daily, n= 48), Combined oral contraceptive+Metformin (Glucophage ® 500 tablets twice daily), and Combined oral contraceptive alone (Yassmin ® film-coated tablets 3 mg of drospirenone and 0.03 mg of ethinyl estradiol once daily, n= 48) for 16 weeks. Assessments were done at 0, and 4 months. We found a better improvement in all clinical criteria at month 4 in participants who were treated with Daflon compared to participants who were treated with the standard regimen (Yassmin ® film-coated tablets 3 mg of drospirenone and 0.03 mg of ethinyl estradiol once daily). No statistically significant difference in the improvement of the clinical criteria at month 4 was observed in the comparisons between the Daflon combined with metformin and the standard regimen.

Resectable lung cancer remains the fifth most common cancer, responsible for over 500,000 deaths annually worldwide. With an incidence of around 3% of all cancers, lung cancer accounts for 10.8% of male and 7.8% of female cancer mortality. The 5-year survival rate following the diagnosis is still inferior to 17%, even after surgical treatment. Despite increasing evidence of the efficacy of cancer screening through chest X-ray and low-dose computed tomography, lung cancer detection still occurs in advanced stages. To date, the combination between cancer screening and early-stage lung cancer detection and treatment remains mandatory to improve patient's quality of life, to decrease the rate of death due to lung cancer, and, consequently, to increase life expectancy. On the other hand, the role of non-invasive intra-operative fluorescence imaging using an optical tracking system using NIR tracers can increase the rate of detecting lung nodules located deep in the lung, not visible on the surface of normal, uninvolved tissue.

Our ability to treat cancer patients is limited, especially for patients with previously approved treatment failures. The goal of this study is to assess the efficacy of the combination of Sotorasib and Panitumumab for patients who have a KRAS G12C mutation. 
In our study, patients will receive 960 mg of oral Sotorasib once daily with Panitumumab administered intravenously (IV) at a dose of 6 mg/kg every 14 days, infused over a period of 60 minutes (≤ 1,000 mg) or 90 minutes (> 1,000 mg). The therapy may be repeated for patients with measurable lesions, whose lesions shrink, improve, or stabilize after 1 course of chemotherapy, according to RECIST v1.1. For each new course of chemotherapy, the researchers evaluate treatment response 7-14 days after the first administration.
Patients receive other treatments, including surgery, radiation therapy or radioisotope therapy, if available, before, during or after the treatment, as clinically indicated. If patients have a measurable lesion, the researchers may continue the chemotherapy even if their symptoms improve. When a patient cannot continue Sotorasib and Panitumumab, they will be dropped from the study.
Patients will be interviewed about their cancer history through video conferencing at the end of each course of chemotherapy. If patients develop new lesions, the researchers will assess the treatment response 7-14 days after the first administration.
Additionally, the researchers will periodically conduct blood tests and evaluate each patient once every 3 months to assess their treatment response.

The aim of this study was to compare the effectiveness of the use of two protocols for treating 1 single gingival recession associated with a non-carious cervical lesion partially restored (type RT1 associated with NCCLB+). The first technique was the partial correction of the restoration (PR) with gingival soft and hard tissue alterations only treated with a coronally advanced flap (CAF). The second technique consisted of the association of Partial Restoration (PR) with gingival soft and hard tissue alterations correction, and the use of a volume-stable collagen matrix (VCMX) applied to the gingival margin, associated with CAF. Both groups received antibiotic and anti-inflammatory support during the post-operative period. The procedures used for the correction of gingival recession were the partial restoration (PR) and the coronally advanced flap (CAF). The procedures for the treatment of gingival recession in association with NCCL were evaluated using the Recession Reduction Index, root sensitivity test, visual analogic scale, Patient Related-14 (OHIP-14), patient discomfort diary, and a post-operative diary.
After 6 months, it was found that the average recession reduction was 1.2 mm for both study groups, without significant difference between them. The use of VCMX, associated with CAF, did not provide the hypothesised benefit, as recession reduction was similar for both treatment protocols (PR + CAF and PR + CAF + VCMX). Therefore, the use of VCMX as a treatment adjunct was not significant in the treatment of 1 single gingival recession associated with non-carious cervical lesion partially restored in the context of a 1-year follow-up.

In this study, 302 patients with gastrointestinal tumors were selected from the First Hospital of Shanxi Medical University from July 2021 to June 2023. After nutritional risk screening and follow-up, patients with nutritional risk (PG=SGA≥4, NRS2002≥3) were divided into the intervention group, and patients with no nutritional risk (PG=SGA<4, NRS2002 < 3) were divided into the control group. The nutritional risk screening 2002 score and Patient Generated Subjective Global Assessment (PG-SGA) score in the two groups before and after propensity score matching were compared. It is proposed to give the corresponding intervention. At the same time, the changes of various nutritional indexes of patients before and after nutritional intervention were analyzed. The effects of different nutritional support modes based on nutritional risk screening on postoperative nutritional status were examined. It is expected to provide scientific basis for the rational use of nutritional support in patients with gastrointestinal tumors.

With the recent advances in non-invasive health monitoring, transcranial Doppler (TCD), a ultrasound-based imaging system, has drawn increasing attention for its ability to provide high-resolution images of blood flow and structure of major arteries, veins and cardiac outflow tract. While these advancements have resulted in improved safety and efficacy of the procedure, significant developments are still needed to ensure a comfortable, portable, and affordable imaging system. In this study, the feasibility of employing ultra-miniaturized ultrasound patch will be investigated to measure blood flow in the major cerebral arteries, including the internal carotid artery and vertebral artery, in healthy participants. With a conventional TCD probe, blood flow in the middle cerebral artery, anterior cerebral artery, posterior cerebral artery, ophthalmic artery and basilar artery will be visualized by the investigators. Blood flow measurements for each vessel segment will be recorded with a maximum of 55 minutes for each participant. Participant satisfaction with the comfort and ease-of-use of the wearable patch will be evaluated by a post-procedure questionnaire. Safety will be monitored by the investigators throughout the procedure. A minimum of 60 participants will be recruited from the University Hospital of the University of Alabama at Birmingham. Inclusion and exclusion criteria will include age, gender, ability to operate the device, and provide informed consent. The comparison of the measurements from the compact and wearable ultrasound patch with a conventional TCD probe will be evaluated to determine the performance of the patch for clinical use.

Background: There are two types of HD, conventional HD and hemodiafiltration (HDF), which is also called HFR. Compared with chronic hemodialysis patients with HDD, the survival risk of HFR patients is less, and the quality of life is better. This is because HFR has the function of eliminating a variety of particles with different sizes including the middle molecules and macromolecular uremic toxins. The present research is to evaluate the clearance rate of uremic toxin (especially in the removal of β2-MG, uremic toxins, cytokines, etc.) by HFR, to further study the dialysis replacement effect of HFR and to establish the target of clinical diagnosis and treatment of MHD.
Methods: The study is a randomized controlled single-center interventional study of all cases, and patients treated with blood purification are included in the study. After the patient signed the ICF (Informed consent form) voluntarily, they first went through the HDD treatment and then HFR treatment. The first group of patients (n=57, one day HFR group, with age, gender, disease type, primary disease course, vascular access status matched, the HFR group) underwent a total of two blood purification treatments. The first was an HFR treatment with a blood flow rate of 250 to 400mL/min and a speed of 50-60mL/min, and the second was an HDD treatment with a blood flow rate of 400 mL/min. The β2-MG and λFLC in the HDF treatment were measured. The blood purification treatment of each group was randomly assigned to two treatments (4 times in a month, each time there were two blood purification treatments in a week, and the order of the two treatments varied), with a total of four measurements. The middle molecules and macromolecular uremic toxin (α1-MG, λFLC, Hcy, IL-6, p-cresol, YKL-40, CFD, leptin, hippuric acid, TMAO, ADMA, TNF-α, myoglobin, FGF23 and iPTH) were measured in the fasting serum before and after HFR treatment. The serum albumin, branched chain amino acids and vitamins A, C, E were measured before and after HFR treatment. The comfort of dialysis was evaluated by patients. Dialysis replacement effect of HFR (single-compartment urea clearance index). Statistical analysis.
Expected result: HFR can remove a variety of particles with different sizes, including middle molecules and macromolecular uremic toxins, which can be used to optimize the treatment options provided for MHD patients.

Experimental group: multi-kinase inhibitors in combination with bevacizumab, No Intervention: without adjuvant therapy. This is a phase III, randomized, controlled trial to evaluate the adjuvant efficacy and safety of multi-kinase inhibitors, including sorafenib, lenvatinib, or donafenib, combined with bevacizumab in patients with high-risk recurrence factors after liver transplantation. The objective of this study is to study the effects of 20% human albumin infusions on coagulation parameters in patients with decompensated cirrhosis of the liver. The study aims to look at the effects of albumin on clotting time, clot formation time, maximum clot formation parameters, inflammatory parameters such as ESR, CRP, IL-6 and TNF-α, platelet function studies and endothelial dysfunction studies. Additionally, pulmonary function tests with diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO), albuminome and duration of the hospital stay will be evaluated. This open label randomized control trial will be conducted in 70 patients admitted with decompensated cirrhosis with serum albumin ≤ 2.5 g/dl upon presentation and who will be receiving the standard treatment for their liver cirrhosis. The patients who meet the inclusion criteria will then be put on two different groups. Those randomized to the study arm will receive 20% human albumin infusion if their serum albumin levels are less than 2.5 g/dl. Albumin will only be given to those with serum albumin levels ≤ 3 g/dl to raise and maintain the serum albumin levels above 3 g/dl. The standard treatment group will receive the treatment that the patient would be getting if they were not enrolled in the trial (standard of care). Both groups will be compared for their albumin levels at the time of presentation, 1 week after inclusion in the study, and until 4 weeks unless they are discharged, transfered or die. The effects of albumin on coagulation parameters will be compared.

The clinical trial is a prospective cohort study comparing ciprofol and propofol for sedation in hypotensive ICU patients. The patients in the ciprofol group (group 1) and propofol group (group 2) were sedated by ciprofol and propofol, respectively, during the resuscitation period. The sedation depth of patients in group 1 and group 2 was evaluated by a researcher who is not aware of the grouping. The patient's condition was evaluated by the Numerical Rating Scale of Acute Pain (0-10), Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS), and sedative drugs' dosage. The mean dosage of propofol, ciprofol, and norepinephrine was collected by researchers. The primary endpoint was the proportion of patients who met the RASS sedation state. Secondary endpoints included total dosage and duration of propofol and ciprofol, total dosage and duration of norepinephrine, duration of mechanical ventilation, in-hospital mortality rate, sedation-related complications (pain, delirium, and hypoventilation), and intraoperative time to extubation.

Hypothesis: Laparoscopy reduces the inflammatory reaction in newborns with ECUN.
Objective: to compare the influence of laparoscopy on the short-term evolution of premature newborns with ECUN requiring surgery by evaluating in these newborns the clinical and inflammatory post-operative evolution between two groups: one undergoing laparoscopy and another undergoing only laparotomy.
Methods: this is a randomized controlled trial in single blind, in two parallel arms, in ratio 1:1. Premature infants of <37 weeks of age, presenting with ECUN after medical treatment, will be included. The main outcome will be the blood C reactive protein level evaluated between D0 and D2.

The investigators will perform basic experimental studies designed to quantify the perceptual experiences of retinal and cortical prosthesis patients. The investigators will produce visual percepts in CORTIVIS and Argus II patients either by directly stimulating electrodes (using FDA-approved pulse trains), or by asking them to view a computer or projector screen and using standard stimulation protocols (as is standardly used for their devices) to convert the computer or projector screen image into pulse trains on their electrodes. Informed by psychophysical data and computational models, the investigators will test the ability of different stimulus encoding methods to support simple perceptual and behavioral tasks (e.g., object recognition, navigation). These encoding methods may include computer vision and machine learning methods to highlight important objects in the scene or to highlight nearby obstacles and may be tailored to each individual patient. Performance of prosthesis patients will be compared both across stimulus encoding methods and to performance in normally sighted control subjects viewing stimuli manipulated to match the expected perceptual experience of prosthesis patients.

The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) has identified specific stages for determining treatment for various types of cancer. Stage is determined based on lymph node status. Stage I indicates no regional nodal involvement, Stage IIa represents micrometastatic nodal involvement, Stage IIb represents nodal involvement in which the tumor is > 2cm in diameter with < 6 involved lymph nodes with at most one node > 2cm in diameter, Stage III represents nodal involvement with > 6 involved nodes, while Stage IV represents distant metastasis. High Risk head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) refers to tumors that are T3 in the AJCC staging system. In patients with early disease who are in good health, treatment consists of surgical removal of the primary tumor and dissection of the nearby lymph nodes. In patients with more advanced disease, treatment includes radiation with or without chemotherapy as well as surgical removal of the primary tumor. Immunosuppressed patients are defined as patients who have a transplanted organ or patients with Hematologic Malignancy and are on chronic chemotherapy or other immunosuppressive drugs. The lymph nodes are considered a safe haven for tumor cells, which can metastasize to the lymph nodes even with small primaries. Immunosuppressed patients have additional factors which may increase their risk of developing lymph node metastases such as cancer recurrence. The investigators of this study question the current AJCC staging system for immunosuppressed patients with cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) of the head and neck, and whether ultrasound surveillance of the neck is an effective alternative of surgical removal of the lymph nodes and CT surveillance. The investigators believe that this study could provide valuable evidence to help determine the optimal management of head and neck cSCC in immunosuppressed patients. The hypothesis of this study is that immunosuppressed patients with stage IIa, IIb, and T3 cSCC benefit from ultrasound surveillance. The investigators propose to evaluate the time to nodal metastases, local recurrence, and overall mortality in these patients with ultrasound surveillance compared to a historical control with surgical removal of the lymph nodes. Approximately 200 immunosuppressed patients with high-risk HNSCC will be followed over a 2-year period and prospectively entered into a database. The investigators will compare time to nodal metastases, local recurrence, and overall mortality in participants who undergo ultrasound survey to those who are treated with traditional surgery. All participants are managed with active surveillance with no treatment until there is documentation of nodal metastases. Upon confirmation of nodal metastases, the participants are treated based on the decision of their treating physicians. The study is designed to allow for flexibility in this regard. Once this information has been completed, the investigators will conduct a retrospective review of the outcomes of 200 cSCC patients who received surgical management of the lymph nodes from 2008-2012 at Brigham and Women's Hospital. These data will be used to compare lymph node involvement and disease progression at 1, 2, and 3 years in the prospective cohorts who have undergone ultrasound surveillance with the historical controls who have undergone surgical removal of the lymph nodes. This observational design will help assess the appropriateness of the hypothesis and the potential reduction in complications associated with lymph node dissection. The study results will give insight into the risk of developing distant metastases in immunosuppressed patients. Ultrasound surveillance has the advantage of not requiring treatment for microscopic nodal metastases or small tumors in draining lymph nodes. Ultrasound surveillance offers the theoretical advantage of delaying the need for definitive treatment until later stages of disease progression. Ultrasound survey can help minimize surgical morbidity associated with radical surgical interventions for high-risk cSCC.

Background: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a common disease. Its clinical manifestations are unspecific and, consequently, its diagnosis is not easy, even if medical and dietary guidelines are available.
The diagnosis is supported by the finding of alarm symptoms and/or specific clinical findings (i.e. strictures and ulcers). When suspicion of GERD remains high despite normal MII-pH and endoscopy have returned normal results, the doctor can decide to perform the pH and intraluminal impedance monitoring (MII-pH) or upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsies repeated if it comes to normal results.
Salivary biomarkers for GERD could be useful in diagnosing infants with GERD, helping to perform the necessary diagnostic investigations and identifying the patients who really need the more invasive ones. At present, there are no evidences of the possible presence of salivary markers of GERD or the effectiveness of these markers in diagnosis.
Objectives: Investigated the differences in the salivary protein profile (proton pump-associated intracytoplasmic antigen- pepsinogen A and pepsinogen C; pepsinogen B; gastrin) and, possibly, in the electrolyte content, present in the saliva samples of infants with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux or suspected GERD, in order to search new biomarkers of gastroesophageal reflux disease.
Methods: This study will include a case/control series.
The cases: 40 infants (males and females), aged 2 months to 12 months, hospitalized in the Pediatric Ward of our Institute with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux, performed 24-hour MII-pH and the subsequent evaluation of GERD severity according to the standardized scales. The saliva samples will be collected during the execution of the MII-pH of the esophagus 24 hours, at defined time points, at least 2 hours after the last meal, so as to study the circadian variations of their composition.
