The aim of this randomized clinical trial is to assess the feasibility of surgical exposure of palatally impacted upper canines with open-eruption technique using a surgical template. The secondary purpose of this study is to compare this method with the conventional free-hand surgical exposure. The upper jaw of the patient is scanned using an intraoral scanner and cone beam tomography. The scanning conditions are standardized. OnyxCeph™ software is used to register the digital impression with the digital reconstruction of the pre-operative CBCT scan by surface registration. A surgical template is designed to cover the palate, incisal, and occlusal surfaces of the dentition with an opening that outlines the window to be prepared to expose the impacted canine. Fused deposition modeling is used for the rapid prototyping of the surgical template. During continuous recruiting, sample size calculation is to be carried out to determine the actual number of patients included in this study. Two groups are studied. Patients rinse their oral cavity with 0.2% chlorhexidine solution before surgery and surgical interventions are performed under local anesthesia. Surgery is performed according to the conventional free-hand method in the control group and according to the surgical guide in the test group. The orthodontic wire is attached to the exposed canine after surgery. Patients are instructed to clean the wound with toothpaste and toothbrush and to rinse with 0.2% chlorhexidine solution in the morning and in the evening for a week starting on the day after surgery. Anti-inflammatory drugs (25 mg diclofenac three times a day for 3 days) are prescribed to control postoperative pain. The patients are followed one year after surgery.

Choroidal melanoma is a condition that can lead to metastases as well as tumor progression if not adequately treated. Current treatment recommendations for large tumors in Brazil, which is where the study is being conducted, include plaque brachytheraphy with Iodine 125 or Ruthenium 106. However, plaque brachytheraphy is limited due to the inability to deliver a therapeutically adequate dose of radiation without the risk of retinal detachment or other complications. In order to control intraocular choroidal melanoma and avoid subsequent enucleation, an alternative treatment option to plaque brachytherapy is being explored: Intra-arterial Chemotherapy or IAC, followed by the standard treatment of plaque brachytheraphy.

The investigators hypothesize that intra-arterial chemotherapy will reduce the average tumor thickness in patients with primary choroidal melanoma, allowing subsequent brachytherapy as planned according to standard of care procedures.
The investigators aim to test the hypothesis that selective catheterization of the ophthalmic artery (with administration of 7.5mg of melphalan) and ruthenium 106 brachytherapy will reduce tumor thickness and decrease the risk for enucleation, with acceptable toxicity, in patients with primary choroidal melanomas with a thickness higher than 8 mm on B-scan ultrasound (USG) evaluation, according to a previously developed nomogram.

Knowing the incidence of injures, mechanisms of wounds, approaching strategies, and outcomes is essential to improving prevention and outcomes of trauma patients. In this study the investigators want to register trauma cases admitted to the Emergency Ward in a general rural hospital in Colombia during the first semester of 2023. They want to evaluate the characteristics of the injury mechanism, the severity of the injury, the proportion of patients needing intensive care and those treated in the ICU, the length of stay of patients in the hospital, the incidence of mechanical ventilation in trauma cases, the outcomes during hospitalization, discharge, or death. Lumbosacral spinal stenosis (LSS) is a common cause of disabling leg pain and back pain. It frequently goes untreated and can often negatively alter veterans quality of life. Noninvasive postural therapy (NIPT) is a treatment approach where patients are trained to maintain flexion when standing or walking. Flexion postures are known to limit lumbar stress and pain and improve activity level. We propose a small feasibility study to determine the initial effects of NIPT on mobility and pain in older adults with LSS. This study will recruit 10 older adults with LSS from the VA New Jersey Healthcare System and measure if NIPT can have a positive impact on symptoms and mobility over a six week period.

This study is being conducted to better understand how self-administered nitrous oxide (SANO) can improve the experience of urodynamic study (UDS)--testing to diagnose bladder conditions.
The main goal is to find out if nitrous oxide (N2O), also known as SANO, can make the UDS test more tolerable for people who may be at higher risk of having an uncomfortable experience.
SANO is a gas that is safe to inhale and is commonly used during medical procedures to help people handle pain or anxiety. The study will be conducted in the Urology Clinic in Seattle, Washington.
All eligible participants will be enrolled.
SANO will be used during the UDS test, which includes catheter placement (also called cystoscopy) and two runs of the test. Before the start of the procedure, SANO will be given to the participant through a gas mask. The dose of the gas will be adjusted based on the participant's comfort level but they won't be able to ask for more than allowed. SANO will be used during catheter placement at the start of the UDS. During the two runs, the participant will receive SANO (run 1) and then oxygen (run 2) or oxygen (run 1) and then SANO (run 2).
The study team will talk to the participants after the UDS is started but before it is stopped. Participants will be instructed to breathe out gently in the mask until they no longer smell gas. Participants will then be asked how their pain and anxiety levels were in the UDS test. Participants will also be asked about their overall experience of the procedure as well as issues with pain, anxiety, and bladder dysfunction. Study staff will not be given a copy of the participant's diary.

Background: The incidence of breast cancer in Latin America has become in recent years the most frequent neoplasia among women; in fact, the latest data of the International Agency for Research on Cancer show that its incidence has tripled in the region in the last 30 years. Although there are no known biological criteria for the development of breast cancer, evidence from case-control studies and genetic association shows that early childhood, such as abuse, and inadequate care such as maternal institutionalization, in addition to having the role of modifiable factors (e.g., smoking, obesity), also plays a key role in the genesis of the disease; all these data point to these early experiences of suffering an adverse experience (adverse childhood experience), as one of the possible causes of the increase in hormonal-responsive breast cancers (1).
Aim: The study aims to determine the prevalence of adverse childhood experiences in women recently treated for breast cancer and evaluate the quality of life of women in remission from breast cancer.
Methods: Population: This study will include 227 women treated for breast cancer in the Plenary Health Service of the University Hospital "Dr. Juan A. Fernández" Hospital at the University of San Martín de Porres, during the years 2019 and 2020, by appointment with the Oncology Outpatient Clinic or by phone. The sample will be recruited, through the medical staff, to complete the questionnaire; in addition, patients will be informed about the objectives and the study will be carried out through the voluntary participation of women who agreed to participate.
Instruments: Measures of adverse childhood experiences, quality of life, cancer recurrence fear, anxiety and depression, attachment, resilience, epigenetics and physiological measures.
Expected results: It is expected to increase the knowledge of nursing regarding the psychosocial aspects of breast cancer treatment in the Peruvian population. Thus, the results may allow the development of new psychoeducational intervention strategies aimed at decreasing the incidence of breast cancer.

Pancreatic cancer has a high rate of mortality and a 5-year overall survival (OS) rate less than 10%. The role of neoadjuvant therapy for pancreatic cancer in tumor control and resection remains uncertain. Immunotherapy may represent a new therapeutic approach for local control of tumor. Mesothelin is expressed in about 80% of pancreatic cancers. MSLN targeted CAR-T cells can elicit efficient lysis of cancer cells both in vitro (7, 8, 9, 10) and in vivo (11, 12). In a xeroxial model (Trojan) of pancreatic cancer, MSLN targeted CAR-T cells injection was able to significantly inhibit tumor growth, increase the rate of R0 resection, and improve survival. In the current feasibility study, MSLN-targeted CAR-T cells will be injected into PDAC by endoscopic ultrasonic guidance. The efficacy of neoadjuvant MSLN-targeted CAR-T injection before surgery will be evaluated by radiological changes, tumor volumetric changes measured by CT, rate of R0 resection, PFS, and OS rates.

Dialysis, a treatment for end-stage kidney disease, is performed either peritoneally (PD) or via a surgically created avenous fistula. Peritoneal Dialysis (PD) is preferred by older dialysis patients and is better tolerated than hemodialysis. Although dialysis adequately removes waste products from the blood, it causes dyslipidemia, oxidative stress, and cardiovascular diseases (CVDs). Cardiovascular diseases are the leading cause of mortality and morbidity in dialysis patients. A better lipid profile and less oxidative stress, which lower CVD risk, are needed to improve quality of life and survival in these patients. CVD risk markers include: lipids, glycemic markers, inflammatory markers, and bone metabolism markers. Bone metabolism is negatively affected by dialysis, putting patients at high risk for fractures, bone loss, and osteoporosis. Oxidative stress also contributes to inflammation and CVD. The main objective of this study is to compare the effect of melatonin versus a placebo on these clinical factors in 34 PD patients. The investigators hypothesize that treatment with melatonin for three months will significantly improve the lipid profile, glycemic markers, inflammatory markers and bone metabolism markers in PD patients.
Inclusion Criterion for patients:
Patients with end-stage renal disease in peritoneal dialysis who are willing to take part in the study for three months.

Oxygen delivery (DO2) is defined as the amount of oxygen reaching tissue and is commonly monitored during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). Adequate DO2 is one of the goals of anesthesiology and perfusion management during cardiac surgery. However, the relationship between DO2 and the outcome of patients is unclear. It is essential to provide adequate but not excessive oxygen delivery by balancing the use of oxygen, transfusion of blood, blood products and inotropic infusions. In addition, the optimal management of perioperative DO2 remains a matter of debate with no recommendations on DO2 thresholds. Anesthesia, perioperative blood management strategies, surgical duration and complexity as well as type of cardiopulmonary bypass circuit and postoperative complications impact DO2. In this study the investigators focus on identifying perioperative factors that could influence DO2 to help clinicians in their goal directed optimization of perfusion.

The investigators will collect clinical, biochemical, physiological and procedural data of all patients with DO2 monitoring during CPB in cardiac surgery at the university hospital of Lille, France for 7 consecutive weeks.

Patients who agree to participate will have DO2 measured during CPB as part of their standard care practice. Patients are enrolled after giving their informed consent.
In order to respect the European regulation concerning Clinical Trial and patient right; all patients will undergo DO2 monitoring during cardiopulmonary bypass, whatever their consent choice; patients who are not included will be managed as part of their usual care. The investigators will retrospectively collect data from those patients.
Routine perioperative care, including management of hemodynamic and perfusion goals, anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy, and cardiac surgery itself, will be conducted as per the usual practice at the University hospital of Lille, France.

Pulmonary fluid content, and more specifically subpulmonary fluid content (SPLIF), is a potent predictor of prognosis in patients with acute heart failure (HF). It is a valuable measure in clinical practice and in clinical trials. Remote dielectric sensing (ReDS) is a reliable, non-invasive tool for assessing pulmonary fluid content in patients with HF.
The main objective is to investigate the acute effects of 80 mg intravenously (IV) furosemide on pulmonary fluid content in patients with acute HF in a prospective observational study.
Study Population
Pulmonary fluid content, and more specifically subpulmonary fluid content (SPLIF), is a potent predictor of prognosis in patients with acute heart failure (HF). It is a valuable measure in clinical practice and in clinical trials. Remote dielectric sensing (ReDS) is a reliable, non-invasive tool for assessing pulmonary fluid content in patients with HF.
In this single-center, non-interventional, observational study 200 patients are to be recruited at Copenhagen University Hospital. The inclusion criteria are patients with acute decompensated HF, both acute-on-chronic and new-onset HF. Patients with known chronic obstructive lung disease (COPD) and other conditions with pulmonary alterations will be excluded.
Design and Procedures
An eight-lead (ECG) electrocardiogram will be recorded. All participants undergo a transthoracic echocardiogram with Doppler tissue imaging (TEI) and contrast (color) Doppler. ReDS measurements will be repeated serially after administration of 80 mg IV furosemide. Blood pressure measurements, peripheral oxygen saturation, and oxygen will be measured serially after administration of furosemide. After the initial assessments, a chest x-ray will be performed.
The change (delta) in ReDS values as well as the change (delta) in peripheral capillary refill after 30 minutes relative to the values before (baseline) 80 mg intravenously (IV) administration of furosemide will be used as outcome measures.

The objective of this national randomized study is to evaluate the impact of a smartphone application on university students' daily habits linked to their binge-drinking episodes in particular and their alcohol intake in general. This study will assess the impact of the MyDéfi app on their alcohol consumption over a maximum period of 30 months.

Inclusion criteria:
- Students between 18 and 25 years old
- AUQ score greater than or equal to 24, and AUDIT score greater than or equal to 3 for its first 3 items. Drinking details with the DDQ when necessary.
- BD behavior: at least one occasion with 6 or more drinks in the last 3 months.
- Consent to be included in the study
- Affiliated to social security
Exclusion criteria:
- Not having a smartphone with an Apple or Android system
- Previous use of the MyDéfi smartphone application
- Declaration of a psychiatric / neurologic condition
- Pregnant, parturient or breastfeeding woman
- Subject under guardianship, curators or restricted under public law

The study will be conducted in 2 phases: baseline assessment and intervention.

During the baseline assessment, sociodemographic and personal informations will be collected from the students. Then, a clinical examination including physical examination and medical history will be performed. Screening tools: AUDIT, AUQ, AUDIT-C, DDQ, 12-item Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology (QIDS-12), DASS- 21 will be administered. A blood sample will be drawn for serum Phosphatidylethanol (PEth) measurement.

The smartphone app MyDéfi will be installed at the inclusion meeting. Subjects in the experimental group ('MyDéfi') will also be provided with a smart drink bottle, a breath analyzer and an alcohol drinking calendar.

The main measurements of the study are the change in the number of standard drinks per week over a period of 30 months and the change in PEth concentration at baseline as well as at the follow-up visits 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21 and 27 months.

The smartphone application MyDéfi is based on the scientific literature and was developed by health professionals to meet students' needs and to help them to change their drinking habits. It will provide the users with information regarding the calorie content of each drink, tips to limit their drinking habits. At the beginning of each session, they will be invited to describe their drinking episode since an episode may be identified in time of use. The application will then recommend the user to identify one event in order to improve his / her reflex on control of consumptions.

The assessment team includes psychologists, clinical psychologists, addictologists, psychiatrists, neurology physicians, pharmacists, biologists and statistics experts. The investigators have been trained to use the MyDéfi application. The study will be carried out in compliance with Good Clinical Practices and with European Regulation (2014/53) in the field of data protection.

Background
------ 
Diabetes mellitus type 2 is the most prevalent form of diabetes mellitus. It is characterized by insulin resistance and beta cell failure in the context of low-grade systemic inflammation. Insulin resistance causes hyperglycemia and altered glucose and lipid metabolism, which leads to dyslipidemia, cardiovascular disease and increased morbidity. Nitazoxanide is an antiparasitic drug that has been used for the treatment of helminthic parasites and protozoan orchidiasis. In some cases, beneficial effects with anti-inflammatory properties have been described. The aim of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of nitazoxanide as adjuvant therapy of antidiabetic treatment of type II diabetes mellitus.
Objective
------ 
To evaluate the efficiency of nitazoxanide in patients with type II diabetes mellitus taking metformin and DPP-4 inhibitor.
Eligibility criteria
-----------------
Inclusion criteria: Glycated hemoglobin ( HbA1c ) between 7% and 9%.
Body mass index ≥ 25 kg/m2.
Exclusion criteria: pregnant or nursing women.
Type 1 diabetes mellitus.
Liver disease ( alanine ( Alanine) aminotransferase > 3 upper normal limit )
Kidney disease ( estimated glomerular filtration rate < 60 ml/min/1.73 m2 )
Inflammatory bowel diseases.
History of allergy and/or adverse reactions to the drugs used in the study.

Design
-----------------
Prospective, randomized, open-label, controlled, parallel-group study.
Participants will be randomly allocated into the study and control groups by stratified randomization. In one group (Group 2), participants will take nitazoxanide 500 mg orally twice daily in addition to metformin and DPP-4 inhibitors (such as vildagliptin) and in another group (Group 1), participants will receive metformin and DPP-4 inhibitors (such as vildagliptin). Interventions will be performed for a period of 12 weeks.
Nitazoxanide 5000 mg capsules were manufactured by TAPI Pharmaceutical Industry Co., Ltd. (Drug number: T04-28).
The drugs will be given once daily in the morning for 14 days, one day a week for 8 weeks, and once daily in the evening for 3 weeks. Metformin 1000 mg and DPP-4 inhibitor (Vildagliptin 50 mg) will be taken once daily in the morning.
The treatment duration in each group will be 12 weeks.
After 3 months of treatment, all participants who are not withdrawn during the trial period will be assigned into the efficacy analysis set (EAS) for each group, and the mean change of HbA1c, fasting blood glucose, fasting insulin level, HOMA-IR (homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance), total cholesterol, LDL, HDL, triglycerides and asprosin and A-kinase anchoring protein 1 serum levels will be calculated between the baseline and end-of-treatment visit in each group. The adverse effects in each group will also be assessed between the baseline and end-of-treatment visit in each group. The efficacy visit will be conducted after 3 months of treatment or 12 weeks visit. The follow-up visit will be conducted 24 hours after the 12 weeks treatment. One month (28 days) after the enrolment date, participants of control group will start to take the metformin and DPP-4 inhibitor (Vildagliptin 50 mg) and nitazoxanide 500mg capsules twice daily in addition to metformin and DPP-4 inhibitors (such as vildagliptin). Two months (56 days) after the enrolment date, all participants will make the 12 weeks efficacy visit for the control group and end-of-treatment visit for the nitazoxanide group. Aim of this study is to investigate clinical risk factors of autism and to elucidate the changes in gut microbiome in Egyptian autistic children and their possible correlation with clinical outcomes and the severity of the disease. For the first time, the investigators aims to explore clinical risk factors of autism including genetic factors, prenatal factors, co-morbidities, and demographics factors in Egyptian autistic children. Besides, the investigators will perform a descriptive analysis of the intestinal microbiome composition compared to the unrelated control group to identify the possible correlation between gut microbiome and the severity of the disease. The investigators will also correlate the changes in the microbiome with metabolome profile. This will help to understand the pathogenesis of autism and provide better insight to potential therapeutic targets.

Money is a critical factor for survival. It is especially important for the mental health community who needs to ensure their mental well-being and stability in the future. Even for those who were stable, their families need to pay close attention to their expenses in order to prevent the relapse from their illness. One of the best ways to save money is to manage it properly. Financial problem is a commonly associated factor with relapse of mental disorder and may be a contributing factor to readmission. Financial well-being and stability have become one of the key factors to ensure the continuation of treatment and prevent relapse of mental illness. Money management skills can also prevent the risk of financial scam, which are increasingly common in the aging population.
A recent survey from the Financial Services Authority found that there are about 100,000 scam victims every year in Hong Kong, with the lost amount up to HK $3 billion. With an improving economic situation and an increasing online market, the financial scam problem is on the rise and is expected to increase rapidly. The current treatment from traditional mental health services does not include appropriate training in money management for the vulnerable patients. As a result, even for those who are stable, they are likely to fall into problems when they come into contact with scammers, which may cause relapse of their illness.
There is a growing body of evidence showing the positive effect of money management skills in promoting positive attitude, increasing effective coping strategies, and prevent risky financial behaviour. This research aims to develop an online money management course for the mental health community in Hong Kong to ensure their financial stability, reduce the risk of financial exploitation and prevent relapse of their mental illness. This project is also in response to the increasing financial fraud in Hong Kong. Previous research on money management skill training is mainly conducted through face-to-face interaction. There is a lack of work on internet intervention for this population. This study will provide evidence on the efficacy of an internet-based money management program for the mental health community. This study will also provide evidence for policy makers to implement an online system in helping the mental health community to manage their finances. Based on the findings from this study, a sustainable online course can be developed to reach more individuals in need of financial management skills with minimal cost.

A patient's socioeconomic status (SES) should not predict their post-stroke disability but individuals with low SES are more disabled and have higher mortality rates compared to individuals with high SES. These inequities are not isolated to low- and middle-income countries. In the United States, individuals with low SES are more disabled at 3 months and less likely to be independently ambulatory or discharged to their own homes. There are many factors contributing to these outcomes; however, one critical feature is access to affordable care. Many newly developed rehabilitation therapies and technologies require expensive equipment (e.g. instrumented treadmills, transcranial magnetic stimulation) and extensive training for clinical staff. The extra costs (financial and training) ensure that these state-of-the-art options are only available at metropolitan, well-funded institutions or to individuals who can afford additional healthcare costs. There is an urgent need for accessible, low-cost solutions capable of being delivered at underfunded hospitals and to individuals with no or low insurance coverage. Startle Adjuvant Rehabilitation Therapy (START) represents an accessible and low-cost solution that can be delivered to rural and socioeconomically disadvantaged populations. START is the application of a startling, acoustic stimulus alongside traditional therapy. Distinct from other auditory treatments (e.g. metronome, music), administration of a START represents an endogenous activation of the brainstem (i.e. reticular formation) a phenomenon referred to as startReact. Rather than being a standalone treatment, START is applied within a standard clinical practice to enhance and accelerate skill re-learning through activation of the brainstem. START has been advanced as an adjuvant therapy tool because of the profound way it enhances training outcomes in individuals with stroke, in particular severe stroke. This is particularly compelling given the high degree of difficulty in generating functional changes in individuals with chronic, severe stroke. There is emerging evidence that individuals with stroke strengthen ipsilateral reticulospinal connections during the process of recovery. Thus, START may represent a priming of the nervous system to engage the reticular formation, which is nearly always spared post-stroke, during therapy to enhance both training and long-term outcomes. START's application is a loud, acoustic stimulus timed with planned motor activity and can be administered via headphones. Unlike many new rehabilitation devices/techniques, START represents an extremely safe intervention (the application is a loud sound well beneath OSHA (Occupational Safety and Health Administration) regulations with no reported adverse reactions since its discovery). Thus, clinical staff training and safety protocols are minimal further decreasing application costs. Finally, it is mobile and easily packaged, so it can be administered via the increasing number of telemedicine programs designed for rural populations. Finally, START allows severe stroke survivors to participate in and benefit from therapy. The benefits of START are not contained to severe stroke survivors (e.g. improvement of hand extension in mildly disabled patients) but the capacity of START to work in severe patients significantly increases the potential of this tool to assist patients across all levels of disability.

Endobronchial valves (EBV) can be placed in lobes of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease-COPD to treat hyperinflation and dyspnea. However, there is no data on whether EBV also improve or preserve diaphragmatic function and conformation in these patients.
The investigators plan to undertake a prospective non-randomized controlled monocentric study on hyperinflated COPD patients without collateral ventilation in which all patients have EBV. Eligible patients (FEV1 < 50% of the predicted value, Rv/Tc > 350 and the presence of homogeneous emphysema).
Before and after EBV, the investigators will assess the diaphragm strength and conformation by the measurement of the transdiaphragmatic pressure (Pdi) and diaphragm conformation (diaphragmetric fibers, area and radius of curvature) using high resolution computed tomography.
The hypothesis is that the endoscopic lung volume reduction performed with EBV should improve diaphragmatic strength and conformation in COPD patients.

Carious lesions of teeth can be restored with direct filling of restorative materials. The majority of restorations in the posterior area are prepared using Class I cavity preparation. Two-step resin-based composite restorations were introduced in 1988 as alternative filling materials in direct restoration. However, these resins needed sufficient light-curing intensity and time, and this increased treatment time. Recently, bulk-fill resin composites have been developed to decrease the treatment time significantly. In vitro studies have suggested that both dual- and light-cure bulk-fill resin composites showed no difference in their physical, chemical, and mechanical properties. On the other hand, the clinical performance of the newly developed bulk-fill resin composites was not evaluated so far. The aim of this study was to evaluate and compare the 2-year clinical performance of the tested bulk-fill resin composites using the FDI criteria of esthetic, functional, and biological properties in Class I cavity preparations, compared to conventional dual-cure restorative material.

The NET RETREAT study involves 80 patients with metastatic/unresectable midgut neuroendocrine tumours (NETs), a rare subtype of cancer that originates in the gut. NETs are not normally regarded as curable, but there may be effective alternative treatments that should be tested. The trial compares retreatment with a type of treatment called everolimus to standard treatment using a drug called 177 lumetate DOTATATE (dottoreotide).
Patients on the trial will be randomly assigned to one of two treatment groups, to make sure that both groups have a similar number of people with certain characteristics that could affect the results, such as the type of tumor they have or how far it has spread. One group may receive 3 or 4 cycles of standard 177 Lu DOTATATE. The other group will not be treated with 177 Lu DOTATATE but instead will receive everolimus, a treatment which has recently been approved for NETs.
The 177 Lu DOTATATE will be given to the body (through a drip or a tube) every 8 weeks until the liver, kidney, and bone marrow are able to clear it from the body. This will typically involve 2 repeats of treatment each year and will be given as part of your routine visits. Blood tests will be done at the beginning of each treatment to check the level of the hormone that carries the radiation (thyroid hormone) and the level of protein used to bind the radiation to the tumour (EDTMP).
Over the 18 month (1.5 year) trial period, patients will have additional tests to check how their disease is responding to treatment. These tests include a physical examination, medical history, blood tests and scans. Quality of life questionnaires are filled out at weeks 2, 22, 36 and every 6 weeks (7 times, up to 32 months) from baseline while a diary for patients on everolimus are filled out at weeks 1 and 4 of cycles two to six.
Once patients stop receiving 177 Lu DOTATATE, further blood tests and scans will be done every 3 months for 2 years to look for disease progression, and a further scans may be required if disease progression is suspected. Patients who are not responding to 177 Lu DOTATATE or everolimus may switch to the other treatment option.
Some patients who are on everolimus are able to cross over to 177 Lu DOTATATE after disease progression. This decision will not be determined by the trial team, but the patients can discuss their options with their treating oncologist. For patients who have never received 177 Lu DOTATATE, this cross-over is planned once disease progression has been confirmed by cross-sectional imaging (CT, MRI, PET scan).
The aim of this trial is to improve our knowledge about NETs, to help doctors decide which treatment to offer to patients, to help doctors monitor the progress of the disease, to improve the quality of life of patients and, most importantly, to improve survival for patients.

Chronic mechanical low back pain is common among different age groups and genders, but there is a paucity of controlled trials for its treatment. Evidence has revealed in recent studies that McKenzie method is effective in treating chronic low back pain. However their use still remains debatable.
Methods: A prospective randomized controlled clinical trial is conducted to compare the clinical outcomes of McKenzie techniques with Mulligan techniques in patients with chronic mechanical unilateral radicular low back pain. Thirty two subjects will be recruited at Rehab care Lahore and Jinnah hospital from 1st June - 31st January 2024. Subjects will be divided into two equal groups through a computer-generated random number. Sixteen patients in group A will be treated with Mulligan techniques and Sixteen patients in group B with McKenzie for four weeks at two session per week and single session per day. Visual Analogue Scale, Oswestry Disability Scale and lumbar Range of Motion measurements were used as an assessment tool.  These variables were measured at baseline and at the completion four weeks intervention.
Statistical analysis will be done by statistical package for social sciences SPSS 29.

Achondroplasia is the most common skeletal disorder associated with dwarfism, which causes disproportionate short stature. Approximately 1:25,000 to 1:35,000 of all live births are affected by achondroplasia. Although a rare disorder, achondroplasia represents significant, long-term impacts on the lives of people affected by the disease. Children with achondroplasia are often treated with growth hormone, a treatment that results in improvement in growth, but does not significantly affect overall body proportions, which continues to cause functional limitations and medical complications for these individuals over the course of their lives. The study will investigate an investigational medication called TransCon CNP, which helps to increase the amount of collagen that is produced in the body. This medication may help to increase the growth rate and body proportions of individuals with achondroplasia.

Background: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (PAF) is a rapidly increasing condition that has posed a growing health care problem. People with PAF experience various challenges, which in turn results in significantly impaired quality of life (QOL). However, few studies have specifically focused on the health-related QOL (HRQoL) of patients with PAF. Objective: This study aims to explore the influences of illness perceptions and coping styles among patients with PAF on their HRQoL by using the 12-item Short Form Health Survey (SF-12). Methods: In this observational study, 150 individuals newly diagnosed with PAF will be recruited from the outpatient unit. The data will be collected through an online survey consisting of the 12-item short form health survey (SF-12) (including the physical and mental component summary (PCS and MCS) scores, Brief Illness Perception Questionnaire Revised (B-IPQ-Rev), Coping Orientation to Problem Experiences (COPE), Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), and Socio-demographic questionnaire. We assume that illness perceptions and coping styles have a significant influence on HRQOL. A multiple regression model will be used to determine the mediating effects of self-efficacy, depression and anxiety, and coping on the relationship among illness perceptions, coping styles, and HRQOL among the 150 people newly diagnosed with PAF. Conclusion: Understanding the factors influencing the HRQoL of people with PAF is critical to assessing the holistic benefits of the disease management services provided. This research would contribute to the development of health care delivery models for better supporting the management of PAF.

Inclusion criteria: Age 18-75 years; AF diagnosis, based on a 12-lead ECG and cardiologist-led examination following the 2016 ESC Guidelines for the Management of Atrial Fibrillation; paroxysmal AF diagnosis given by a cardiologist according to the conversion back to the normal sinus rhythm occurs spontaneously within a week; ability to read and write in Chinese.

Exclusion criteria: Severe complications such as unstable coronary artery disease, heart failure with severe systolic dysfunction(ejection fraction≤35%) AF soon after thoracic surgery; malignant disease with a 1-year survival rate or a terminal illness diagnosis; a diagnosed psychiatric condition that interfered with participation (including severe depression, bipolar disorder, psychotic illness of any type, dementia, acute suicidality, severe personality disorder) participation in another study cognitive impairment interfering with their ability to participate in the study.

This study is designed to evaluate the impact of the center volume-outcome relationship and that on mortality which remain poorly understood. A better understanding of the determinants of outcome in patients undergoing surgery could support decision making, aid in the design of service delivery, and improve outcomes for surviving patients who are referred to specialized centers for treatment of aortic disease. Furthermore, the study aims to evaluate outcome predictors in patients undergoing surgery for TAAD, including clinical and perioperative variables as well as to evaluate the incidence of complications beyond 30 days of surgery. Finally, the study will define the long-term clinical course of these patients, including those with a previous aortic surgery, such as Bentall procedure.

Inclusion criteria: Patients aged greater than 18 years, with ascending aortic dissection or intramural hematoma involving the ascending aorta, experiencing a symptom onset within 7 days from surgery, scheduled for a primary surgical repair for acute TAAD, or for any other major cardiac surgical procedure, if concomitant.

Exclusion criteria: Patient aged less than 18 years, onset of symptoms more than 7 days from surgery, concomitant endocarditis or TAAD secondary to blunt or penetrating chest trauma.

Patients will be recruited by the cardiac surgical unit at 14 centers in Europe.
The procedures under evaluation will be:
1. Ascending Aorta Replacement (AAR) with or without Hemiarch Repair
2. Ascending Aorta Replacement (AAR) with Aortic Root Replacement (ARR)
3. Ascending Aorta Replacement (AAR) with Total Arch Replacement (TARP)
4. Root and Ascending Aorta Replacement with Total Arch Replacement

The primary objective of this study is to determine the incidence of operative mortality within 30 days from the procedure and the incidence of mesenteric ischemia beyond 30 days. The secondary objectives include the determination of the incidence of permanent new neurologic deficit within 30 days from the procedure, the incidence of major adverse events, the incidence of perioperative myocardial infarction, the incidence of acute heart failure, the incidence of transient neurologic deficit, the incidence of spinal cord injury, the incidence of acute kidney injury, the incidence of bleeding, the incidence of reoperation for bleeding, the incidence of mechanical circulatory support, the incidence of major pulmonary events, the incidence of need for reintervention, the incidence of late survival rate and the incidence of mortality 30 days from surgery among patients who have had a previous Bentall procedure.

The study will be conducted on a prospective basis. All the enrolling patients will receive routine care. This will include surgical management of dissection or TAAAD, management of their concomitant illnesses, pre-and post-operative care and appropriate medication during and after hospital stay.

The data required for the management of the patients will be collected prior to recruitment as per conventional practice. Further data will be collected at specific time period after hospital admission and discharge, that is 1 month, 3 months, 1 year, 3 years, 5 years, 7 years and 18 years. This approach is appropriate due to the importance of long term follow up and for the completeness of data.

After the 30 days post-operative period, follow-up will be done at specific time period after hospital discharge for survival, re-intervention and complications. The follow-up is crucial and it will ensure the long-term safety of the patients undergoing various procedures described in the current protocol since these procedures are performed only in patients with acute aortic dissection at high risk for early and late mortality.

The aim of this experimental and quasi-experimental clinical trial is to evaluate the effect of virtual reality and traditional meditation method in medical students of the degree of Physiotherapy and Nursing about the academic stress (primary outcome), perceived stress the last month (primary outcome), blood pressure (secondary outcome), maximal heart rate (secondary outcome) and salivary cortisol level just before exams (secondary outcome). Also, between-group differences in qualifications of exams will be registered. It is an experimental and quasi-experimental randomized clinical trial with three groups. Two groups will be submitted to an intervention (EG1 and EG2) and one group will be used as control (CG). The main intervention will be visualizing exams through virtual reality glasses, and the control group will receive the same intervention, but through traditional visualization method. This study will be carried out with students from the 6th and 7th semesters who are enrolled in at least 80% of subjects of an ongoing academic course. Participants will visualize the exam in a specific computer of our University. As the primary outcomes, between-group and intra-group differences in academic stress, which will be registered with the SISCO Inventory version-21, and perceived stress of the last month, which will be registered with the Perceived Stress Scale. As the secondary outcomes, between-group differences in the level of current perceived stress just at the moment prior to start the exam, blood pressure, maximal heart rate and salivary cortisol level just before starting the exam. Finally, as a secondary outcome, between-group differences in qualifications of exams will be registered (it will be pondered by the average qualification of the degree for each student). 140 students will be recruited, and they will be allocated in a 1:1:1 ratio into the three groups (EG1, EG2 and CG) by using a parallel assignment and blocked randomization. No one, at any time, and not even the principal investigator, will be able to know the allocation until the last visit of each participant.

Obesity is now a huge global problem and the number of morbidly obese patients who need surgical treatment, including sleeve gastrectomy, is steadily increasing. Recently, laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) has been actively performed to reduce morbid obesity symptoms, and LSG helps solve obesity and its complications. General anesthesia is required because of the large-scale surgery such as LSG. However, there can be a risk of systemic hemodynamic instability and hypotension according to the anesthetic drugs used during induction of anesthesia of morbidly obese LSG patients.
Remimazolam, a new short-acting benzodiazepine, has been used as an anesthetic induction agent instead of other traditional inhalation anesthetics because of its clinical benefits of stable hemodynamics and faster awakening. Especially, with the recent trend of using remimazolam as an anesthetic induction agent, there is a need for a clinical trial to verify its advantages. On the other hand, propofol is a traditional induction agent as a clinical anesthesia standard, and although it is a potent drug with quick onset of action, it also has the disadvantage of a rapid offset of action (too short to maintain the surgical effect) and rapid awakening compared to remimazolam. The remimazolam group showed lower systemic hemodynamic instability rates without the use of vasoactives, which can be important for rapid postoperative awakening in patients with obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) who maintain upper airway function during surgical intervention.

Recently, remimazolam has been used as an anesthetic induction agent in the cases of both LSG and bariatric obesity surgery, but no related study has been conducted in comparison to propofol. Especially, there are no studies for the rate of hypotension at induction during LSG with Remimazolam. By comparing remimazolam and propofol, we can find the benefits of remimazolam in clinical efficacy and safety. Therefore, we performed randomized controlled experiments to evaluate the efficacy and safety of anesthesia induction drug administration (remimazolam versus propofol) in 80 normal or morbidly obese patients undergoing LSG. It also provides a basis for evaluating remimazolam's advantages in the clinical setting.

The primary purpose of this clinical research is treatment evaluation. In addition, various parameters are measured such as blood pressure, heart rate, and ephedrine doses, and the incidences of adverse events during anesthesia are monitored. The expected outcome of this study is a low incidence of hypotension by comparing the incidence of hypotension during induction between the Remimazolam group and the propofol group.

This is a single-group, phase II study of darolutamide along with leuprolide acetate and exemestane in recurrent adult-type granulosa cell tumor (AGCT). Patients have measurable disease as assessed by Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) 1.1 criteria. Measurable disease is defined as at least one lesion that can be accurately measured in at least one dimension (longest diameter to be recorded). Each lesion must be >= 10 mm when measured by computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Lymph nodes must be >= 15 mm in short axis when measured by CT or MRI. Patients must have had >= 1 treatment regimen.
Safety will be assessed beginning with the initial dose of any treatment. Descriptive statistics, including frequencies of maximum grade of adverse events by term and category will be reported. Patients receive exemestane PO QD and darolutamide PO BID starting on days -14 to -7 prior to C1D1 and then on days 1-28 of each cycle. Patients also receive leuprolide acetate IM on day 1 of each cycle. Cycles repeat every 28 days in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.
Patients must have a prior or concurrent diagnosis of recurrent adult-type ovarian granulosa cell tumor (AGCT). Adequate health must permit completion of the study requirements and required follow-up. Patients must have measurable disease and >= 1 treatment regimen. For example, a prior or concurrent line of treatment with an aromatase inhibitor (letrozole, exemestane, anastrozole). Patients must not be pregnant and must agree to use adequate birth control while on study. Tissue is required. The effects of the combination of darolutamide, leuprolide acetate, and exemestane on the developing human fetus are unknown and androgen receptor inhibitor agents may be teratogenic.

This is a Phase II study aimed at evaluating the safety and efficacy of a new combination chemotherapy consisting of nivolumab, a new anti PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitor, and chemotherapy containing cisplatin and gemcitabine to treat children, adolescents and young adults with newly diagnosed nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
For more information, visit the official study website at the listed resource.
This is a Phase II study.
Study Arms:
Experimental: Treatment (nivolumab, gemcitabine, cisplatin, radiattion)
Participants receive nivolumab intravenously (IV) over 30 minutes on day 1 of each cycle, gemcitabine IV over 30 minutes on days 1 and 8 of each cycle, and cisplatin IV over 3-6 hours on day 1 of each cycle. Treatment repeats every 21 days for 3 cycles in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. For patients with residual disease after cycle 3, patients will receive nivolumab IV over 30 minutes and 37.5 Gy of concurrent radiation therapy on trial, delivered over 7 weeks (50 fr, 1.8 Gy per fr, Monday to Friday). Patients also receive cisplatin IV over 3-6 hours on days 1 and 29 of cycles 1 and 2. Patients also undergo positron emission tomography (PET) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) throughout the trial. Patients may optionally undergo tissue biopsy, blood and stool sample collection during screening and on trial.  After completion of study treatment, patients are followed up every 3 months for 12 months, every 6 months until 24 months off therapy, and then yearly until 5 years off therapy.
How is the study designed?
This is an interventional study.  This study has no masking, so it is an open-label study.  It is a Phase 2 study with a single group assignment.  It is not applicable to compare this study with another procedure, so there is no specific study arm.
What is the study measuring?
The primary outcome measures for this study are:
- Incidence of grade 3 or higher immune-related adverse events (irAE) during induction chemoimmunotherapy (CIT).
- Event-free survival (EFS).

This is an observational cohort study using MRI to measure gastrointestinal (GI) function, lung structure and function and liver endpoints in children with CF aged 6 to 11 years. The study will use a modified version of the protocol used in the GIFT-CF3 study (NCT04618185) to measure GI physiology in addition to MRI measures of lung and liver structure and function. The aim is to identify whether these measures are changed before and after starting ETI. For the CF participants, to be enrolled in the study they must be homozygous or have at least 1 copy of the Phe508del mutation, which would mean they are eligible for ETI treatment. The modified MRI protocol, taken from NCT04618185, has been shortened to include scans that are taken over three timepoints. These timepoints are determined around the ingestion of a test meal which has been previously described. Participants will arrive fasted before having a baseline scan. After their first scan they will eat their first standardised high fat meal followed by a second standardised high fat meal around 240 minutes after. MRI scans to assess GI function will be taken at baseline (fasted), 240 minutes post ingestion of a breakfast meal (T240) and 300 minutes post breakfast (T300). Liver scans will also be taken at baseline and lung scans taken opportunistically at the T240 timepoint. In total, participants will be asked to remain in the MRI scanner for approximately 30 minutes at a time. For comfort, participants will be able to watch multimedia programmes through the use of a specially adapted television while in the scanner. Participants will also be asked to complete validated gastrointestinal questionnaires throughout the study day and recall their GI symptoms over the previous 2 weeks and complete a 3 day food diary. The study will be split into two phases. The first will be a pilot phase where 3 children with CF aged 6 to 11 years and 3 healthy age and gender matched controls undergo MRI scanning. These scans will be assessed to determine whether the scan protocol can be completed by the participants and assess the quality of the images obtained. If successful, the trial will progress onto the main phase. In the main phase, the 12 additional children with CF will be recruited and undergo the above scanning protocol, prior to starting ETI. We will then ask participants to return for a repeat scans approximately 6 months after starting ETI.

Hypospadias repair surgery is an invasive surgery that results in significant postoperative pain. pain alters the quality of life and satisfaction of the patients and results in manipulation of wounds, infection, bleeding, and wound dehiscence leading to unfavorable surgical outcome . As a plan for postoperative pain prophylaxis in children, different analgesic techniques have been used as preemptive analgesia such as local infiltration of anesthesia, penile block, epidural block and caudal block in addition to general anesthesia. Caudal block is found to be one of most succeeded technique in hypospadias repair and decreases the postoperative analgesia consumption. Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic commonly used via caudal epidural route but gives limited duration of analgesia. Therefore, the addition of other drugs in an attempt to improve the quality and duration of analgesia given by bupivacaine has been studied. Examples of additives drugs used in the caudal epidural are opioids, alpha 2 agonist as dexmedtomidine and clonidine which produce prolongation of the duration of the analgesia, but their undesirable effect may limit its use as nausea, vomiting, pruritus, urinary retention and respiratory depression. Epidural corticosteroids have a long history of safe and effective use in the treatment of low back and radicular pain due to their strong anti-inflammatory effect encouraging use in management of acute postoperative pain. In pediatric surgical patients presenting for mainly lower abdominal surgery, a meta-analysis revealed clinically meaningful prolongation of the duration of analgesia from caudal blockade by adjuvant dexamethasone versus placebo. In addition to doubling to tripling the duration of analgesia, adjuvant dexamethasone has a rescue analgesia sparing effect and reduces post postoperative nausea and vomiting. A vast majority of literature supports the efficacy of particulate steroids like methylprednisolone over dexamethasone in providing longer analgesia in management of chronic pain conditions. Aim of the work and hypothesis: To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study that will evaluate the analgesic efficacy and safety of caudal methylprednisolone in pediatric patients. This randomized, double-blind, controlled bi-center study was designed to compare the postoperative analgesic efficacy of dexamethasone and methylprednisolone in caudal block for children undergoing hypospadias surgical repair using the duration of analgesia as the primary outcome. The investigators hypothesize that methylprednisolone will provide superior postoperative analgesia than dexamethasone when added to bupivacaine for caudal block.

Ex-vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) holds great promise as one of the best solutions to expand the donor pool and overcome the donor shortage in lung transplantation. Despite increasing interest in this new technique, the current clinical practice of using EVLP is not without controversy. Although the quality of lungs reconditioned by EVLP is superior to the lungs discarded in standard transplant center, the quality of accepted lungs is still inferior to the lungs accepted in standard practice. 
Our aim is therefore to include an additional device treatment, HDF, in EVLP. This new therapeutic approach could improve the quality of accepted lungs and the outcome of transplanted patients. Currently, the role of dialysis or hemodiafiltration (HDF) in the process of lung reconditioning remains unclear. The addition of a dialyzer and blood-purifying treatment device, HDF, in the lung recovery process could result in improved outcome of transplanted lungs. In our setting, we will assess the impact of HDF on lung regeneration. After exclusion and acceptance of organs on the basis of ISHLT criteria, a subset of lungs will be further evaluated by X-ray and bronchoscopy in the standard setting. The additional step would be the assessment of lung function after 1 hour reconditioning.
Study patients in which the lung function tests are positive, will be randomized to either standard EVLP (without adding a dialyzer) or EVLP plus HDF (an external blood-circulating pump and an additional dialyzer will be added). This will allow us to compare outcomes between the two groups. At the end of the perfusion period, the lungs received by HDF will be compared to controls with standard EVLP. Parameters assessed will be oxygenation, lung compliance, airway secretion volume and cell counts, pH, and inflammatory markers. A subset of donor lungs (tissue biopsies and BAL-samples) will be evaluated for inflammatory markers. We will also perform a complete bronchoscopic evaluation using narrow banded imaging. After completion of the standard perfusion protocol, we can observe any differences that we will expect to find in the tissue markers of this group of lungs.
There are two potential explanations for how EVLP plus HDF works in lung reconditioning. The first explanation is that HDF and reconditioning of cells and matrix may be directly related. The second explanation is that HDF may serve as a lung support therapy that allows the endothelium to recover in vivo and maintain its function (and thus oxygenation), leading to acceptance of lungs which would not been accepted otherwise. By accepting the lungs of older donors with a low functional status, the number of available organs will dramatically increase.
The use of HDF will allow us to investigate the role of plasma clearance and detoxification in lung reconditioning. There are several factors that support this thesis. Our group has shown that in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and in patients with lung cancer, the severity of the illness and the plasma concentration of inflammatory markers like TNF-alpha, IL-6, IL-8 and CRP are correlated with lung function. Moreover, extracorporeal blood purification is known to lower those inflammatory mediators and to be beneficial in ARDS. Another example of EVLP and HDF that support this approach is the report by Kocan et al. Of the 19 lung transplantation patients in this report, 17 received some type of pretransplant EVLP and HDF. In the last transplanted lung of this study (an 80 year old recipient) the lung recovered after 6 hours of EVLP and HDF, which was not possible prior to the addition of HDF. Moreover, the addition of this HDF system seems to be safe. Recently, an increasing number of studies have shown the beneficial effects of HDF in various patient populations. All those studies will contribute to the establishment of an evidence base that supports the introduction of HDF as a method of reconditioning damaged lungs. Based on the evidence, a significant impact of the addition of an HDF system in the lung reconditioning process can be expected and thus the ability to accept organs from a previously underrepresented part of the donor pool may increase.
In the present study we will investigate the impact of HDF on the regeneration of marginal donor lungs after 6 hours of EVLP. Additionally, we will compare the EVLP plus HDF with our current practice of using standard EVLP. Outcome variables that will be measured will include standard lung function tests, microscopic aspects and function of the lung, plasma concentrations of inflammatory mediators

Premature Infant Pain Profile (PIPP) is a validated and widely used tool designed to assess pain in preterm infants. A randomized controlled experimental design was employed, with premature infants as the study participants. The infants were randomly assigned to three groups: the control group, the white noise group, and the multisensorial stimulation group. The white noise group received auditory stimulation through the presentation of white noise, while the multisensorial stimulation group received additional visual and tactile stimuli during the retinopathy examination. The findings of this study have the potential to contribute to the development of effective and well-tolerated (retinopathy) examination protocols for premature infants. By comparing the effects of white noise and multisensorial stimulation, the study aims to provide insights into the most suitable intervention that can optimize the examination process, improve examination success rates, and minimize potential discomfort or distress experienced by infants. It is anticipated that the results of this study will inform healthcare professionals and researchers about the benefits of auditory stimulation (white noise) and the additional advantages of multisensorial stimulation during retinopathy examinations. Ultimately, this research aims to enhance the overall quality of care provided to premature infants, leading to improved visual outcomes and long-term well-being for this vulnerable population.

Meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD) is a common disease contributing to dry eye disease (DED). Several methods used to evaluate and classify MGD have shown limitations.
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a modified calculation formula for MGD grading (modified MG grading) in MGD patients diagnosed with both objective and subjective symptoms. The investigators also aim to evaluate the reproducibility and repeatability of the modified formula.
Participants recruited for the study will be classified using the LipiView (TearScience, Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA) method. 150 patients diagnosed with MGD will be randomly divided into two groups. The first group will be evaluated by the old calculation formula, and the second group will receive evaluation by the modified calculation formula. The following parameters are obtained to calculate MG grading: The area of the MGs and the whole eyelids will be measured by the investigators, and the corneal width from inferior to superior (WTW distance) of the cornea will be measured using the IOLMaster device (Carl Zeiss Meditec AG, Jena, Germany). Corneal WTW distance and the area of the MGs and the whole eyelids calculated by both formulas in each patient will be compared and evaluated by intraclass correlation coefficients (ICC) analysis to determine intraindividual and interindividual reproducibility of the measurement. The investigators also obtain subjective symptoms such as irritation, dryness, burning, and pain. It is expected that a calculation formula with a wider calculation area of the formula, which is more accurate to diagnose the state of the tear film, will be developed, and its reproducibility and repeatability will be investigated.

Oral Mucositis (OM) is a common and severe side-effect of chemoradiation therapy. OM manifests as erythema, mucosal friability/erosion and pain. Oral Mucositis is an important determinant of treatment tolerance and quality of life of patients. Several preventive approaches have been explored, including topical and systemic administration of growth factors and nutrients. Among them, zinc gluconate (ZG), a common dietary supplement, is known to influence immune responses and to exert protective effects against oral mucositis in animal models. Recently, zinc has been administered directly to the oral cavity using a gel-based formulation allowing the local prevention of mucositis in patients undergoing radiotherapy for head and neck cancer. However, so far this approach has never been tested as a randomized controlled trial (RCT), because RCTs are not sufficiently reliable to determine the true effects of such interventions. We propose to test the efficacy of ZG-based oral rinses (or lozenges) vs. standard care in a large multi-center RCT in patients undergoing radiotherapy for malignant lesion of the upper aerodigestive tract. Objectives To evaluate the efficacy of zinc-gluconate gel for prevention of radiation-induced oral mucositis in patients undergoing radiotherapy for head and neck cancer. To evaluate the long-term effects of zinc-gluconate gel in terms of quality of life, adverse events and health economic benefit.

Periodontal Diseases (PD) are not completely controlled. According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), at least 30% of the world's population aged 35-45 years has severe or very severe periodontitis. As of 2017, approximately 15% of the European adult populations suffered from periodontal diseases. The current diagnostic methods are not sufficient to distinguish the level of severity of the disease. With new scientific findings, especially from the area of biomarkers in saliva, the diagnostic of the disease and the progression can be distinguished.
This study has designed 21 biomarker-salivary-analytes to diagnose the severity of the disease in the early period. For inclusion in the study-patient groups, in periodontally healthy, gingiva patient, patients with treated & stable periodontitis, patients with treated & unstable periodontitis, patients with periodontitis stage-I & II and patients with periodontitis stage III and IV is planned.
The total number of participants calculated for each periodontal health status is 360 (3 groups of patients, healthy, periodontitis stage I/II and stage III/IV, all in 3 levels of severity of the disease). The total study population was calculated as 3 x 3 x 3 = 27 participants. Based on the number of people required for the study, the number of patients examined will be based on the inclusion, exclusion and drop-out criteria determined by the study.

The purpose of the study is to determine the effect of white noise, heart sounds, or music that the mother listened to most frequently during pregnancy on reducing neonatal pain during heel lance. It was hypothesized that listening to heart sounds and music can reduce the pain of the infant compared to white noise.
                The design of the study is a randomized controlled experimental design. The sample of the study was chosen as 84 infants with a gestational age of 28-42 weeks. Infants in the first group listened to white noise, while those in the second and third groups listened to heart sounds (at an average rate of 70 beats/min) and music (which the mother listened to most frequently during pregnancy at a rate of 70 beats/min), respectively. The NIAPAS pain score, the duration of the procedure, and the crying time were recorded.
                As a result of the study, it was found that using music that mother listens to most frequently in a heel lance significantly reduced neonatal pain and also crying time. The researchers stated that mothers should be aware of the effect of music, white noise sound, and heart sound and should take this into account, especially while in the hospital.

This retrospective study evaluates the verbal scores of children diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) before and after hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT). Children aged 2 - 17 years diagnosed with ASD by a qualified practitioner who completed a verbal test every six months (either VBMAPP or the ABLLS) were screened for eligibility. Those who elected to receive HBOT received 40 sessions of 60 minutes in an HBOT chamber at 2.0 ATA. Those who did not receive HBOT also received verbal testing every six months. The verbal scores of the treatment group of subjects were compared to those who did not receive treatment and found to be non-significant. The primary outcome measures were change in verbal scores from baseline at 6 months (VBMAPP and ABLLS). The verbal scores were significantly higher for children aged 10 - 12. The VBMAPP scores were significantly higher in the HBOT treatment group subjects. The second outcome measure was safety of hyperbaric oxygen therapy as measured by number of participants with hyperbaric oxygen treatment related adverse events.

Postoperative pain is the most distressing experience for patients undergoing surgery. Improperly managed, pain may cause complications, including decreased wound healing, gastrointestinal tract dysfunction, and other physiologic disturbances (Lee J, Lin T, Ma J and Chiu K, 2006). Nerve blocks are well recognized as an effective method in the management of post-operative pain. To avoid motor block or nerve block associated with neurological defects and to use single injection technique, several peripheral nerve blocks, as saphenous nerve block, femoral nerve block, sciatic nerve block and obturator nerve block, were identified to relieve acute post-operative pain (Mengshiang, 2018). Adductor Canal Block (ACB) is performed in middle third of the medial side of thigh using ultrasound at point of inlet of adductor canal, deep to sartorius muscle, and anterior to femoral artery between the medial head of rectus femoris muscle and adductor longus muscle of femur (Bhattarai, Raju & Sharma, 2017). ACB anesthetizes the branches of femoral nerve which innervate knee and ankle joint and provide sensory innervation to the anterior medial parts of the thigh. Adductor Canal Block is performed safely and effectively with no important adverse effects (Bryant, 2019). An innovative technique was described by Roy R, Agarwal G, et al (2018) called 4-in-1 block technique as a single injection technique to block femoral nerve, sciatic nerve, obturator nerve, saphenous nerve. The technique was reported to cover almost the whole leg distal to knee. In the adductor canal block, some important branches (branches of obturator nerve) are not covered (Eckart, Oderda & Smith, 2012). In the adductor canal block, as 80% of the patients undergoing knee surgery suffer from sciatic nerve block related complications. The adductor canal block may be performed as an alternative to sciatic nerve block (Guerbaa-Cherkaoui Kassou D, Ait-Mellal H, et al, 2008). Also, the 4-in-1 block is less effective than sciatic nerve block and adductor canal block (Roy R, Agarwal G et al, 2018).

Our aim is to compare 4-in-1 block and adductor canal block analgesic efficacy in terms of VAS scores, side effects, motor block, respiratory depression and nausea and vomiting.

Unilateral axillary lymph node dissection is the standard operation for breast cancer patients. It removes several lymph nodes from the axilla, but also causes lymphedema. Lymphedema arises from the fact that it inhibits the drainage of the remaining lymph nodes, causing edema in the upper limb. Research studies indicate that reducing the amount of lymph nodes removed by maintaining the main lymphatic vascular conduit reduces recurrence of lymphedema. 
Immediate postoperative lymphatic reconstruction has been done and has shown that reconstruction surgery can significantly decrease the risk of lymphedema if the procedure is done when lymphatic surgery is done on the same day. It is important to know whether immediate lymphatic reconstruction can reduce the risk of lymphedema in breast cancer surgery. The aim of the current study is therefore to study whether reconstruction lymph node drainage after axillary lymph node dissection can be used as a prophylactic treatment to prevent lymphedema. The investigators propose to conduct a prospective randomized study to determine whether immediate lymphatic reconstruction can actually prevent lymphedema after axillary lymph node dissection. 
In this study, the investigators will evaluate axillary lymph node dissection by the standard surgical technique in 250 women with cT 1 to cT 4a tumors who have not undergone other adjuvant treatments. In this study, patients will be randomized into two groups. 
The immediate lymphatic reconstruction group will receive axillary lymph node dissection and immediate lymphatic reconstruction while the non immediate lymphatic reconstruction group will receive axillary lymph node dissection only. Data will be collected on demographic data, lymphedema symptoms, lymphedema risk factors, drainage amount, lymphatic reconstruction characteristics. If the participant still has lymphedema, clinical photographs will be made and circumference will be measured before and after the operation.

Breast cancer is a very common disease, which now allows patients to have a long-term survival, thanks to the early diagnosis and a better therapeutic protocol. These important results have led to an increasing interest about late effects occurred after cancer, which impact on the quality of life, not only during the treatment period but also during follow-up period. Patients can have the fear of cancer recurrence, the difficulty to relate, to work, to have children and a lack of autonomy. But it is also a question of how to manage the disease and the therapeutic treatments in a complex socio-environmental context. Nowadays, to evaluate the quality of life in the oncologic setting, many questionnaires have been developed . Some of them have already been translated and adapted to the italian culture, while others are still in a phase of development and validation. In this context the aim of this project is to develop a new questionnaire (PRO Survivorship concerns) which represents an evolution of the previous model (FRE-QOL questionnaire) and which is aimed at assessing the problems reported by Italian cancer survivors during their follow-up. The PRO Survivorship concerns is also aimed at assessing the problems reported by Italian cancer survivors during their follow-up. The PRO Survivorship concerns is made up of 17 items which evaluate the problems of survival, the level of concern about problems related to the care of patients, screening, symptom management, family and genetic problems and the fear of disease recurrence, on a scale of 0 to 3. A further aim of the project is to validate this questionnaire in terms of validity, reliability and responsiveness. For these reasons a sample of at least 280 will be enrolled. The recruitment of patients will be conducted in a multicentric, representative way, involving five Italian hospitals. The main goals of this multicentric study are the translation, adaptability and transcultural validation of the PRO questionnaire survivorship concerns to put in evidence rehabilitation needs in breast cancer patients in early stage.

This is a Phase 1 open label, single arm trial to evaluate the safety and tolerability of IBRX-042 and determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and the dose with an acceptable toxicity profile of IBRX-042 in subjects with HPV-associated tumors. Subjects with HPV-associated tumors will receive 3 injections of IBRX-042. The study will also measure the vaccine's impact on specific immune responses and tumor biomarkers. Following enrollment, subjects will be administered IBRX-042 by subcutaneous injection in the abdominal wall every 3 weeks for a total of 3 injections. After the subject completes or withdraws from the study, subjects will attend an end-of-treatment visit 30 days after the last visit. Additionally, subjects will attend a follow-up visit 6 months after last injection administered to collect whole blood for exploratory immune and molecular profiling. Based on the safety and tolerability, the study may expand into a Phase 2 portion at a dose determined in this study.

Inclusion criteria: 
- Subjects must be men or women who are 18-75 years of age and able to understand and sign informed consent.
- Subjects must have a confirmed diagnosis of an HPV- or p16-positive carcinoma. They must have received at least 1 standard-of-care therapy per the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines for their HPV-associated cancer.
- Subjects must meet certain laboratory and performance status criteria.
- Women of child-bearing potential must use effective birth control.
- Subjects must have an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0 or 1 and be able to attend required study visits and return for adequate follow-up.

Exclusion criteria:
- Subjects with a history of autoimmune disease or certain hematologic or hepatic abnormalities will be excluded.
- Subjects with serious medical or psychiatric conditions that could interfere with the study will also be excluded.

Design Details: A study arm design will be utilized to determine the MTD of IBRX-042 vaccine. Subjects will be sequentially enrolled to 1 of 3 dosing cohorts. Dose cohort 1: 1e11 virus particles (VP)/dose Dose cohort 2: 5e11 VP/dose If needed, dose cohort -1 (de-escalation): 5e10 VP/dose

Primary Outcome Measure: 
- Determine the MTD of IBRX-042 to establish safety and tolerability with a maximum of 60 subjects administered IBRX-042. 

Secondary Outcome Measures: 
- Determine the safety profile and reactogenicity of IBRX-042, including solicited and unsolicited adverse events, physical examinations, vital signs, laboratory tests, and ECGs.
- Assess the ability of T-cell biomarkers to predict response to IBRX-042 and progression-free survival.
- Evaluate the immunogenicity and persistence of humoral and cellular immune responses to IBRX-042.

The objective of this study was to compare the effects on pain, functional status and quality of life of connective tissue massage and classical massage in patients with non-specific chronic low back pain. Therefore, participants in the classical group (n=10) received classical massage, and participants in the connective tissue group (n=10) received connective tissue massage. The control group (n=10) received usual physiotherapy practices, including superficial thermal heat, deep transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, and superficial thermal ultrasound.
The mean age of the participants was 46.46±14.92 years, with no significant difference between the groups. There were no significant differences between the groups in terms of height (p=0.262), weight (p=0.365), BMI (p=0.495), duration of low back pain (p=0.982), Visual analog scale (VAS) pain score (p=0.619), Sit and Reach test (p=0.323), Modified Schober test (p=0.265), Back Pain Functional Scale (p=0.864), Roland Morris Disability Score (p=0.883), S-36 physical health (p=0.549), S-36 social functioning score (p=0.502), S-36 bodily pain score (p=0.228), S-36 emotional role score (p=0.552), S-36 mental health score (p=0.753), and S-36 mental health scores (p=0.588). However, the S-36 general health score was found to be significant (p=0.01). Although there was a significant decrease in pain intensity and an increase in functional status in the classical and CTM groups compared to the control group, there was no significant change in body awareness or quality of life after massage treatments. It was concluded that both classical and CTM massage decreased pain intensity, and increased flexibility and functional status in patients with chronic low back pain. Therefore, both classical and CTM massage can be applied as adjuvant therapies. Larger studies are needed to draw more definitive conclusions regarding the effectiveness of connective tissue massage in terms of quality of life.
