Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States. Colonoscopy is a routine screen for the detection of pre-cancerous or malignant polyps and surveillance of participants at high risk. As with all screening tests, compliance is a critical factor in their usefulness. Text messaging has been shown to be effective in improving compliance with other types of medical procedures. The goal of this study is to investigate whether it could improve compliance with colonoscopy, especially among older, minority patients with high rates of non-adherence. In a randomized controlled trial, consecutive veterans due for repeat colonoscopy at the Memphis VAMC are randomized to receive either the Annie text intervention or no intervention control. The Annie is a set of instructional and motivational text messages that helps participants complete the bowel preparation process for the colonoscopy by using real-time reminders to take each dose of laxatives. The text message intervention does not cost money or require any data downloading. This study is the first to use real-time reminders to improve compliance with colorectal cancer screening. If successful, this approach can be easily scaled up to a national level, providing a cost-effective strategy for increasing compliance with colorectal cancer screening. This study will not involve any medical procedures with risk or harm.

<|assistant|> In Europe, there are approximately 150,000 early miscarriages per year. Incomplete early miscarriage is defined as early miscarriage with persistent intrauterine material on ultrasound. Intrauterine retention of trophoblastic debris is not an uncommon phenomenon. These retentions may initially be asymptomatic but are often responsible for persistent metrorrhagia and endometritis. This symptomatology often accentuates the psychological distress of patients mourning the pregnancy. Incomplete miscarriages are mainly managed by the gynecological emergency department. The recommendations of the Collège National des Gynécologues et Obstétriciens Français (CNGOF) suggest as a first line of treatment: either surgical management or expectant care. The choice between the two is left to the discretion of the doctor and the patient. there are no clear recommendations as to the choice between hysteroscopy and aspiration. Within the teams, the choice is often made according to the habits and protocols of the service, according to the equipment available and the skills of the gynaecologists. This study aims to compare the efficacy of management by endo-uterine aspiration versus management by hysteroscopy of trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage, at 6 weeks after surgery, by endovaginal ultrasound. Patients randomized to the hysteroscopy arm will receive misoprostol antibiotic prophylaxis to dilate the cervix before surgery, and anti-adhesion barrier gels will be used, according to routine procedures at each center. In case of intrauterine retention complicated by endometritis, antibiotic treatment for 48 hours (penicillin, metronidazole, fluoroquinolones or a combination of these antibiotics) will be administered according to the standard practice of each center. Evacuated retention product will be sent for pathological examination. Rh-negative women will receive prophylaxis to prevent Rh alloimmunization. | Procedure: hysteroscopy
* The procedure is performed by a gynecologic surgeon under general or spinal anesthesia, depending on the standard practice of the center involved, with the patient in the gynecologic position. Antibiotic prophylaxis may be administered according to the standard practice of the center. The equipment available at each center will be used for operative hysteroscopy. The use of energy is usually unnecessary and saline will be preferred. Before the operation, the appearance of the uterine cavity will be described. The selected design product will be resected from top to bottom using the surgical resector, without electrical energy, as this method is known to be the most protective of the endometrium in previous studies. Electric current should be used only as a last resort, in cases where the selected design cannot be removed without it. If there is active bleeding after the procedure, elective coagulation via the hysteroscope may be performed to stop intrauterine bleeding.
| | Experimental: Arm B: Aspiration
Patients randomized to the aspiration arm will receive misoprostol antibiotic prophylaxis to dilate the cervix before surgery and anti-adhesion barrier gels will be used, according to routine procedures at each center. Evacuated retention product will be sent for pathological examination. Rh-negative women will receive prophylaxis to prevent Rh alloimmunization. | Procedure: Aspiration
* The aspiration will be performed by a gynecological surgeon, according to the center's standard protocol. A flexible or rigid cannula can be used. This project will examine human inference across multi-timescales. We will administer three experiments that each tap the same cognitive process. Our main goal will be to investigate how people use samples of the environment, and then produce inferences about both the near-term environment (the state of that environment after some number of updates, or transitions), and the subsequent environment (the state of that environment after some number of subsequent updates). Using the same set of data (i.e., samples of the environment), people will produce both near and far-term inferences from the same information. Each experiment will be conducted online using Prolific. Our goal with this online approach is to generate a large sample of participants and thereby make powerful statistical inferences. These experiments will be conducted during the COVID pandemic, using secure and well-established online crowdsourcing platforms, and following recommendations for online experimentation under COVID.

The experiments will share the following set-up: Participants must predict an environment state, using samples of that state (e.g. the current configuration of red and blue ball in a jar) and their knowledge of how jars transition. They will complete a pretest before beginning the experiment to ensure that they correctly understand the task at hand. Participants will perform each task in three blocks, each with a different purpose but sharing the same task structure:

1. Short-term Inference: Subjects must identify which of the equally likely jars is currently in use (where "current" is subjective relative to the participant) based on a visual sample of the two jars. The subject will receive feedback on whether their inference was correct. The task repeats many times with different jars. The feedback provided is only a binary statement whether the participant's inference was correct, without explanation..

2. Multi-timescale Inference: Subjects must report the current jar in use, as well as predict the subsequent jar in use on the next trial. Feedback remains binary (accurate or not).

3. Long-term Inference: Subjects must predict the subsequent environment state (i.e., the jar after some number of further updates). Long-term inference differs from the other two tasks in that it cannot rely on visual information about the environment, but must draw from past experience of how transitions between jars occur. Feedback is binary (correct or not), although more informative feedback would likely improve subjects' performance.

In each of the three tasks, the experiment will use different combinations of environmental features. The "red/blue balls" scenario corresponds to environmental features that cannot be updated by the task. We will also use multiple other environmental features that will alternate across participants during each task block, keeping approximately half of the experimental environment constant. These features include the number of red and blue balls (i.e., the size of the environmental feature), the position of the red balls within the jar (i.e., the spatial information), the number of times the jar has been used (i.e., the current history), and the number of red and blue balls to appear on the next trial (i.e., the upcoming history). These last two manipulations are of particular note, as they should provide participants with different sorts of feedback about the environmental transitions, which may in turn influence how participants use the feedback to generate inferences.

While most of the experiments are likely to involve visual stimuli (as is the case with red and blue balls), we also anticipate running control experiments that use different stimuli, such as lines of different widths, tones of different frequencies, or abstract symbols. We will keep the total number of different experimental features roughly fixed between both visual and non-visual versions of the experiment. 

Subjects will complete many trials in each task, and will receive frequent feedback on their performance. We estimate that each task will take approximately 5 minutes if subjects work at a moderate pace. Each task block contains about 125 trials, with at least 25 on each of the five different set of conditions. Participants will be compensated for completing the task, with payments expected to be approximately 5 USD per hour.

Gregory Smith, Nicholas Kyratsis, James McDonnell, Peter Dayan, and John Guckenheimer at Yale University are members of the Inference and Neurodynamics lab.

Black women are two times more likely to suffer a cardiovascular (CV) event. This study is designed to understand risk and protective factors in Black women between 18-49 years old with no diagnosed CV condition. This study aims to answer the following questions:
Q1: What is it like to be a Black woman and live with hypertension-related risk factors such as obesity, diabetes, poor diet and food/drink choice, physical inactivity, poor sleep patterns, tobacco use, socioeconomic adversity (e.g., poverty and neighborhood segregation, and social discrimination/stress)?
Q2: What are the key physiological mechanisms driving CV disease and poor CV health status in Black women across the life course (from adolescence to young adult)?
This multi-method study is designed to answer these questions by collecting information (e.g., behaviors/life experiences) via questionnaires and biological information (e.g., the role of the heart, brain, lungs and key organs) via laboratory assessments using devices. The study findings will provide insights into the relationship between Black women's cardiovascular health and biological measures and other factors.

The aim of this study is to determine if higher doses of tranexamic acid (TXA) given after cardiac surgery are associated with a lower incidence of post-operative delirium (POD). Delirium after cardiac surgery affects one in five patients and is associated with increased mortality, poor functional recovery and reduced health-related quality of life. Although it is possible to identify patients at the highest risk of delirium and POD, currently there is no effective treatment. Tranexamic acid (TXA) is commonly used as a clotting drug to minimise bleeding after surgery and has anti-inflammatory activity, which may protect the nervous system. In recent studies TXA has been associated with less neuro-inflammation and reduced incidence of delirium in other surgical specialties, such as colorectal and vascular surgery. TXA may also protect the brain from blood-brain barrier disruption and improve brain oxygenation during cardiac surgery with deep hypothermic circulatory arrest. Although TXA is routinely used in cardiac surgery, current published guidelines state that there is insufficient evidence to support the use of higher doses of TXA to reduce bleeding or complications after cardiac surgery. However, clinical data demonstrates that increasing doses of TXA improves clotting in patients with haemophilia, suggesting that the dose used is important. A recent trial in abdominal surgery demonstrated that TXA reduced mortality, infection, blood transfusions and delirium when TXA replaced intra-operative blood conservation therapies (Lippi G et al. Tranexamic acid to reduce delirium after gastrointestinal surgery: the TRIGs-D trial. ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier NCT04556056). Inclusion Criteria: All patients undergoing elective or in-house urgent cardiac surgery at RPH between 05/2018 and 08/2022 Exclusion Criteria: Patients undergoing operations involving deep hypothermic circulatory arrest, operations involving thoracic vessels other than the ascending aorta, solid organ transplantation or mechanical assist device implantation, emergency operations The primary aim of this study is to determine if higher doses of tranexamic acid (TXA) given after cardiac surgery are associated with a lower incidence of post-operative delirium (POD). Delirium after cardiac surgery affects approximately one in five patients and is associated with increased mortality, poor functional recovery and reduced health-related quality of life. Currently there is no effective treatment. Tranexamic acid (TXA) is commonly used as a clotting drug to minimise bleeding after surgery and has anti-inflammatory activity, which may protect the nervous system. In recent studies TXA has been associated with less neuro-inflammation and reduced incidence of delirium in other surgical specialties, such as colorectal and vascular surgery. Our hypothesis is that higher doses of TXA can reduce inflammation within the nervous system and improve health outcomes after cardiac surgery. TXA will be associated with lower delirium and other outcomes in adults undergoing cardiac surgery for heart valve and/or coronary artery disease. TXA may protect the brain from blood-brain barrier disruption and improve brain oxygenation during cardiac surgery with deep hypothermic circulatory arrest.

The purpose of this study is to quantify the average therapeutic doses given to the liver during radioembolization using yttrium-90 glass microspheres. There are many challenges facing restorative materials used in dentistry. One of the main challenges facing the dental community is restoring dental caries in patients at high risk for caries. Clinical performance of restorative materials is influenced by several factors including preparation design, application techniques, contour design and restoration technique. Based on above-described concept glass ionomer cements are widely used in dental practice due to its many advantages such as fluoride releasing ability to inhibit demineralization. The most important drawback for using glass ionomer cement is its inferior mechanical and physical properties that cause poor clinical performance. Therefore, many studies were published about improving these properties with using chemically activated glass ionomer cements with application of various techniques such as enhanced by radiant heat or ultrasonic vibration. The purpose of this study was to evaluate clinically the performance of chemically cured conventional glass ionomer cements after enhancement of radiant heat.
This randomized controlled clinical trial investigated the effect of radiant heat enhancement on the clinical performance of chemically cured conventional GICs in first molars.
                Molar teeth were randomly assigned in order to receive chemically cured conventional GICs either with radiant heat enhancement or without enhancement. Restorations were checked at the end of each clinical visit using FDI criteria and evaluating both the biological and functional performance of cement.
                After 12 months of evaluation, the result of this study showed that chemically cured conventional GICs had acceptable clinical performance without evidence of failure. Meanwhile, cement enhanced with radiant heat failed in a higher percentage of the restorations (27.3%) compared to the conventional chemically cured GICs without any enhancement (14.1%). This finding suggests that radiant heat enhancement did not improve the clinical performance of chemically cured conventional glass ionomer cements in this study. However we need further extensive investigations to reveal the role of radiant heat enhancement on clinically acceptable restorations of glass ionomer cements in patients at high risk for caries.

This interventional study was conducted exclusively at the Heart Institute of the Clinics Hospital of the Medical School of the University of São Paulo (InCor - HCFMUSP). It was a single-center study divided into six phases. The first phase involved outpatient preoperative care, where patients underwent a comprehensive anamnesis during the preoperative consultation and were informed about the study. In the second phase, patients were hospitalized and provided with the Informed Consent Form (ICF) if they met the inclusion criteria. Demographic data were collected during this phase. During the surgical phase (third phase), intraoperative data were collected after cardiac surgery. The fourth phase focused on postoperative care, where patients were evaluated, and health measures such as blood pressure (BP), heart rate (HR), electrocardiogram (ECG), and peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2) were collected using the SAMSUNGTM Galaxy Watch5 smartwatch and reference devices. After discharge, the fifth phase involved a 30-day telemonitoring period, where patients were remotely monitored using the smartwatch. Health data, including BP, HR, ECG, and SpO2, were collected three times a day during this phase. The medical team provided clinical interventions when alerts were received via the FAPO SI³ platform. In the final phase, patients returned for an outpatient visit at InCor, where health measures were collected again using the smartwatch and reference devices. Additionally, a World Health Organization Quality of Life (WHOQOL) questionnaire was administered to assess patients' quality of life. ECG reports issued by the smartwatch were also reviewed. The control group consisted of patients with heart disease who underwent surgical procedures and received standard outpatient and post-surgical follow-up according to institutional routines and protocols. Overall, the study aimed to develop and validate an assisted digital telemonitoring platform for patients with postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF). The telemonitored group used the SAMSUNGTM Galaxy Watch5 smartwatch for remote monitoring, while the control group followed standard care protocols.

Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is one of the most prevalent conditions worldwide with around 50 % prevalence in the EU. Moreover, hypertension is the greatest risk factor for cardiovascular diseases, which is the major cause of morbidity and mortality both in Europe and worldwide, accounting for around 48% of all deaths in Europe. Hypertension is an important cause of preventable complications, which are often long before diagnosed due to their silent onset. Furthermore, even if diagnosed in a primary care setting, hypertension remains often uncontrolled. As in all chronic diseases, blood pressure is typically monitored in a longitudinal manner, with measurements performed by the patient outside in between visits to healthcare professionals. This measurement process can lead to over- and undertreatment, with patients visiting the outpatient clinic too often when the condition is well controlled or not often enough when it is not. As such, it is necessary to develop new means for patients to maintain control of their condition, and this, in turn, can enable the healthcare provider to monitor the patients' health and adjust the therapy more precisely. This objective is the main target of the proposed pilot study. The aim of this study is to evaluate the impact of adopting HSMonitor solutions on hypertension management in primary care. According to this aim, two non-competitive, non-commercial solutions have been developed: solutions based on the technology solutions developed in the framework of the EU PCP project HSMonitor. The study falls within the scope of the HSMonitor pre-commercial tender, whose main objective is the development of telematics solutions aimed at optimising patient health status and disease management. This will be a randomised controlled trial where patients with hypertension will be randomised either to one of the two digital solutions or to standard care.

<|assistant|>
Language and learning disorders (LLD) and attention deficit hyperactivity disorders (ADHD) encompass a wide and heterogeneous range of phenotypes with an unknown etiology in most cases and often inadequate treatment or follow-up. The search for a pathogenic mutation can be done with an etiological consultation, which can be carried out by the reference centres. However, they are accessible when a diagnosis has been made and most often when there is already a known dysfunction (e.g. vision, hearing). They are relatively limited in number and time, and it is still possible that they do not explore all the causes envisaged by genetic analyses. The clinical and biological conditions of the child (language delay, learning disability, hyperactivity) are not always the same as that of the parents and the child's relatives. The number and type of dysfunctions may also depend on the developmental phase. In fact, the etiologies of LLD and ADS are heterogeneous with genetic, neurological, and psychological factors. The current treatment options rely on pharmacological products whose efficacy is still uncertain, and non-pharmacological treatments (assistance, education, and rehabilitation measures) that vary significantly within and between geographical areas and are sometimes discontinued by families after the intervention. Genetic techniques such as array CGH (using 300,000 markers) have been used in recent years to identify pathogenic genetic alterations responsible for some LLD phenotypes. In some cases, the presence of a rare cause of etiology allows the patient to benefit from specific and adapted support, and it seems logical to suspect a similar situation for LLD more frequently observed in the general population. The aim of this project is to carry out a whole transcriptome sequencing of index cases whose parents are also sampled and in whom no diagnosis of LLD or ADS exists or has already been rejected. Children will be recruited within participating reference centres. We will include 500 index cases whose blood samples will be screened using genome-wide sequencing to identify at least one pathogenic variant, validated according to the recommendations of the ACMG classification. A clinical and biological description will then be established to check that the pathogenic mutation is causal to the LLD or ADHD described.

The 5 days for health (FDH) is a short behavioral program on healthy nutrition, physical activity and psychological support that is led by endocrinology-diabetes consultants and a multiextended team of nutritionist, psychologist. It is aimed to educate people on lifestyle modification necessary to lose weight.
The program is going to be carried out within 5 days in groups of 7-9 people lead by experienced experts. Participants in groups are adults with the indication of overweight (25-30 kg/m2) or obesity (30-45 kg/m2). During the first day of education the participants will measure their height and weight, waist and hip circumference, and they will get the advice how to measure their body weight regularly. They will also learn how to read food labels and how to estimate the portion size with their hands. There will be a series of interactive lectures and discussions lead by experts who will explain the basics of obesity and metabolic syndrome, cardiovascular consequences, the differences between emotional and physical hunger, identification of personal triggers and how to find alternatives to emotional eating, the effects of body image on mental and physical health, how to have a positive or negative body image and how to improve it, and more. The 5 days of education involves educational lecture, physical activity and discussions, and the participants will wear the accelerometers during these 5 days.
After the program, participants will receive practical guidelines and instructions of how to continue with lifestyle modification at home.
The evaluation will take place during the weight loss program and one month, three month, six month and one year. We will examine the participants' weight change, fat percentage and fat accumulation in the body, blood pressure, metabolic parameters, waist and hip circumference, body height, body mass index, and basal metabolism. Patients will complete questionnaires of eating habits, physical activity and psychological support.

Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP), It is a disease characterized by incomplete vascularization of the retina seen in premature and low birth weight infants, the etiology and pathogenesis of which are unknown, causing vision loss. It is a problem below 32 weeks of gestation in developed countries, but it is reported to develop severely up to 34 weeks of gestation in developing countries. In a multicenter study conducted by the Turkish Neonatology Society in our country, the frequency of ROP in very low birth weight preterm infants was found to be 42%, and the frequency of advanced ROP was 11%. The incidence of ROP was found to be 6.1%, and advanced ROP was 6 per thousand in babies with a birth weight of 1500-2000 grams. The frequency of ROP was found to be 10.3% in babies with a gestational age of 33-35 weeks, and severe ROP was reported in 19 of these babies. Premature babies who developed ROP and underwent ROP inspection experience pain, stress and discomfort.
                Premature newborns are prone to pain during painful stimuli and ROP examination is one of the pain stimuli that may be applied. After this examination, an increase in blood pressure and heart rate, and a decrease in oxygen saturation are observed. Pharmacological and non-pharmacological (non-pharmacological) methods are used to reduce pain. In a study evaluating the effectiveness of sucrose combination with non-nutritive sucking, they reported that pain was moderately reduced and more studies are needed. In another study (2015), it was concluded that topical anesthesia and oral dextrose were not effective in reducing pain in both groups. In a study comparing the effectiveness of breast milk and sucrose, it is recommended to use breast milk because of the rapid recovery of the baby after the ROP examination. In another study, it was stated that the mother's voice as music therapy also showed an analgesic effect and accelerated the recovery after the ROP examination. The study will be conducted in the neonatal intensive care unit of the research hospital. The sample size of the study was calculated as 30, considering the difference in 1 of the PIPP scales. It is aimed to be completed in 6 months.

This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of combined topical 3% Diquafosol and intense pulsed light (IPL) in the management of DE.
Patients with DE were randomized into three groups. Group 1 (IPL+) was administered 3% Diquafosol tetrasodium eye drops 6 times per day for four weeks, along with two sessions of IPL, 2 weeks apart. Group 2 (IPL) received IPL treatment sessions once at 2- weeks interval. Group 3 (DQS) will be administered 3% Diquafosol tetrasodium eye drops six times per day for 4 weeks. After a washout period, groups 1 and 2 will be placed in the same arm with group 3 to complete the treatment for another 16 days. At the end of 28 days, all participants will be in the same arm (DQS). The investigators hope this cross-over design will increase the power in the statistical analysis and reduce the total number of participants involved and the duration of the study.
Each patient was required to visit the clinic on Days 0, 14, and 28 to have outcome measures recorded. The primary outcome measures will be tear breakup time (NIBUT), Ocular Surface Disease Index (OSDI), Fluorescein and lissamine conjunctival and cornea staining (CFS), Meibomian gland function and secretion quality, Tear Film Lipid Layer Score (TFLL), Tear meniscus height (TMH), and Conjunctival hyperemia (RS score). All measurements were obtained at the same visit. Each investigator will be blinded for the participants' group assignment.

This study will compare the efficacy of two different mental health interventions (Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) versus Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT)) to improve mental health outcomes, quality of life, well-being, and functional impairment in autistic adults with co-occurring anxiety and/or depressive disorders. The study aims to contribute to the development of a personalized, integrated treatment approach for mental health problems in the autistic adult population.
Aim 1 will examine the effectiveness of CBT versus MBT for improving patient-centered mental health outcomes, quality of life, well-being, and functional impairment in autistic adults. Researchers will compare the two treatments on the effects of self-reported depressive and anxiety symptoms, well-being, self-acceptance, quality of life, functional impairment, treatment retention and participation, therapeutic alliance, negative side effects, and satisfaction with treatment among participants. Based on prior pilot research on CBT for ASD, the study team predicts that CBT will be more effective than MBT, particularly in the sub-sample of participants with milder expressive and intellectual abilities/skills.
Aim 2 will explore patient characteristics (including clinical, sociodemographic, and patient-mediated variables) that may moderate the effects of CBT or MBT on mental health outcomes in participants with ASD. By identifying individual predictors of response to therapy, the study can inform tailoring of mental health treatments based on patient needs.
Aim 3 will assess the implementation outcomes (i.e., feasibility, acceptability, and sustainability) of CBT versus MBT as reported by therapists and participants. The study team will assess the processes, experiences, and outcomes of engaging in/providing CBT versus MBT. This information can inform strategies for improving access to high quality mental health care for people with ASD.

The overall aim of the study is to determine the differences between general and regional anesthesia on patient sleep quality.
A prospective randomized evaluation of 60 patients will be planned.
Inclusion and exclusion criteria of the patients will be determined. In total, 60 patients included in the study will be divided into two groups by randomization, as the general anesthesia (GA) group and regional anesthesia (RA) group. The PID-20 scale will be used to evaluate the sleep quality of the patients in the two groups. The VAS and Wong Baker Pain Scale will be used to evaluate immediate pain and anxiety levels.
Hemodynamic changes will be recorded in the intraoperative period. If complications develop in the postoperative period, this will be recorded as an immediate complication. Early complications will be evaluated in the postoperative three months. Information will be recorded for mortality (30 days), complication (length of stay in hospital, cardiac and respiratory events, sepsis), and readmission.
Anesthesia management, complication and patient satisfaction scores will be evaluated.
This assessment and comparison can contribute to the development of a new protocol to be applied to patients who will undergo total hip arthroplasty in the future, as well as to determine the impact of general and regional anesthesia on recovery time, hospital days, immediate complications, and the frequency of delirium in postoperative patients.

This clinical trial will evaluate the efficacy of efgartigimod (also known as VYVGART™, a biological treatment for GBS) compared to intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), which is the current standard-of-care treatment, in treating Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). GBS is a debilitating autoimmune condition in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy nerve cells, leading to muscle weakness, and in severe cases, muscle paralysis. The primary efficacy endpoint will be the proportion of patients who had a complete recovery after 12 weeks as assessed by the Guillain-Barre Syndrome Disability Scale (GBS-DS). The proportion of patients reaching a complete recovery on the GBS-DS at 12 weeks as assessed by a blinded Independent Endpoint Review Committee will be compared between the treatment groups. Safety will also be assessed by monitoring the number and seriousness of adverse events. Patients who participate in this study will also undergo quality of life questionnaires, a sensory examination, nerve conduction assessment, and blood tests to evaluate disease progression and the response to treatment.

Inclusion criteria: Inclusion Criteria:
- Provision of signed and dated informed consent form

The addition of Letrozole to the intravenous MTX combined with intra-amniotic MTX and uterine evacuation in cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) leads to less blood loss than traditional therapy with MTX alone. This study tested the hypothesis that the addition of Letrozole would improve clinical results in women with cesarean scar pregnancy.
This randomized, prospective cohort study compared intra-amniotic + intravenous MTX combined with uterine evacuation to intravenous MTX combined with intra-amniotic MTX and uterine evacuation + Letrozole in women with an intrauterine pregnancy in a Cesarean scar (CSP), confirmed on ultrasound, and increasing B-human chorionic gonadotropin (B-hCG) concentrations. Women were treated with a single dose of 100 mg MTX intravenously and 50 mg MTX in intra-amniotic injection (day 0), along with 30 mg potassium chloride in case of positive fetal heartbeat (FH). Women treated with Letrozole received 5 mg orally (from day 0) for 10 days in conjunction with the standard treatment. Blood parameters (B-hCG, hemoglobin, total blood count, creatinine, urea, alanine/aspartate transaminase, gamma-glutamyltransferase, bilirubin) were tested on days 0,4,7, followed by B-hCG concentration measurement every 7 days until POC surgical removal. Intra-amniotic insertions of Letrozole have a progestational effect on decidualized endometrial cells and may contribute to a physiological response to the invasion of the trophoblasts. The investigators aimed to use Letrozole as an add-on in the treatment of CSP. The aim of the study was to compare blood loss parameters and frequency of laparoscopy/laparotomy conversion during removal of POC in women with CSP treated with intravenous MTX combined with intra-amniotic MTX and uterine evacuation with or without adjuvant administration of Letrozol.

During liver transplantation (LT), blood loss is considerable, so that often the intraoperative blood replacement is necessary by means of red blood cell (RBC) transfusions.
Recently, it has opened the possibility of transfusing units of allogeneic RBCs from heart or lung donors with the same ABO-type. RBCs from liver donors offer the unique advantage of being already available during the organ recovery procedure, making the transfusion process more time-sensitive and less likely to have a delay in transfusion support. The first objective is to demonstrate that this procedure is technically feasible, while the second is to prove that it is not associated with an increase in complications and graft failure.

Background: Contrast-enhanced mammography (CEM) is an emerging breast imaging modality that is based on dual-energy mammography and the injection of iodinated contrast agent. A typical CEM study consists of a low-energy image (equal to a FFDM image) and a recombined image (in which areas of contrast enhancement can be appreciated). However, the situation can occur that lesions are visible only on the recombined (contrast) images (in this protocol defined as 'recombined-only lesions' or ROLs). In these cases, we need to perform 'contrast-enhanced stereotactic biopsy' (CESB), in which CEM is used as a targeting modality. However, experiences with CESB are still limited and one of the most urgent questions that need to be answered is the amount of tissue sampling that is required to reach a final diagnosis. Objective: To determine the minimum number of CESB-guided tissue samples needed to establish a final histopathological biopsy diagnosis for ROLs. Study design: Prospective, single center, observational cohort study. Study population: Non-pregnant women (>18 years) able to provide written informed consent and with a ROL recently observed during a regular CEM examination. Intervention: Included subject will undergo CESB, consisting of an intravenous injection of iodinated contrast agent prior to image acquisition. After administration, a contrast-enhanced stereotactic localization will be performed of the ROL to determine the location and depth of the lesion within the breast. After targeting, 18 samples will be acquired using a 9 Gauge vacuum-assistend biopsy (VAB), collected in six separate and numbered cassettes, to be able to determine the chronological order of the tissue sampling. Each specimen will be histologically analyzed in this chronological order and findings will be compared with the final histopathological result after assessment of all 18 specimens. Main study parameters/endpoints: The primary study aim will be to calculate the cumulative diagnostic yield per specimen, enabling us to define a minimum number of biopsies required (or tissue volume needed) to establish a reliable diagnosis using CESB. Secondary study outcomes will be general parameters of the biopsy procedure itself, such as patient characteristics, histopathological results, pain experienced during the procedure, and complication rates (hematoma, infection).

Septum in the uterus is a congenital anomaly, which occurs in in 0.8-0.9% of women with 2-10% incidence per each decade of life. It develops during the second trimester of pregnancy. When the septum enlarges, as a result of menstrual cycle or pregnancy, abnormal uterine bleeding, pregnancy loss or preterm birth may occur. Removal of the septum by hysteroscopic surgery could be an effective therapeutic way in preventing these complications, particularly in preliminary phases of pregnancy. The commonest technique for septum resection is with the use of a monopolar 26 French resectoscope with the collin's knife, and glycine 1.5% as the distension media
However the high fluid deficit may lead to inadequate uterine exposure, impaired ovarian function, decreased ovarian blood flow with increased risk of ectopic pregnancy. On the other hand, the cost of the surgery is higher and require a longer time of learning the technique for the endoscopic surgeon.
The traditional method of septum resection used a scissors to cut the septum. This method has been reported to take long time of operation and relatively lower incidence of complications. Scissors used to cut the septum is easy to handle and is cost effective.
The present study was designed to directly compare scissors with 26 French monopolar resection, with glycine1.5% as the distension media, in all sizes of the septum, under direct vision, regarding the operative time, fluid deficit, operative and post operative complications and need for second intervention.

Current and future pandemics remain a major health issue throughout the world. The main concern is not viral transmission but the severity of the disease and the long-term sequelae. Long COVID, the term used to describe ongoing health issues associated with COVID-19, is defined by the World Health Organization as new or ongoing health problems that appear after the initial recovery of a person who has had COVID-19 infection. To date, no specific treatment for long COVID has been identified. The severity of symptoms and physical de-conditioning suggest an important impact of the disease on the exercise of respiratory muscles, respiratory control and the cardiovascular system. Cardiac coherence (CC) is a method of controlled breathing that has been shown in a previous RCT to be particularly effective in improving respiratory and cardiovascular control and therefore, in improving the recovery of patients with acute myocardial infarction, ischemic diseases or heart failure. The goal of this clinical study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a respiratory control training to CC on reducing the symptoms of long COVID and cardiovascular and respiratory complications in this population. Secondary objectives will be to evaluate the effect of the training on specific symptoms (fatigue, dyspnea, anxiety, depression, posttraumatic stress, cognitive impairment) and on the impact of the disease on Daily life. This study will involve patients at the Reunion University Hospital who will present a clinical profile for long COVID and a positive history of COVID-19. These patients will be randomly assigned to either a CC training group with reinforcement (experimental group) or a CC control group without reinforcement (Control group). Patients will be evaluated at the start of the study (T0) and at different times thereafter (1 month follow up, 2 months follow up, 3 months follow up and 6 months follow up). The primary outcome will be the clinical improvement (scoring on the LCSQ-10 scale) which include 3 parameters (total score, fatigue, anxiety and depression scores). Secondary outcomes: clinical improvement, specific symptoms (dyspnea, fatigue, anxiety and depression, posttraumatic stress, cognitive impairments), impact of diseases on daily life.

Gastrointestinal bleeding is a rare but severe complication of dual antiplatelet drugs including aspirin and thienopyridine (also known as dual antiplatelet therapy or DAPT). Gastrointestinal bleeding tends not to be fatal (40% morbidity, 8.8% in-hospital mortality), but has associated long-term mortality of up to 20%. The high relative risk of gastrointestinal bleeding in patients using DAPT makes it necessary to consider the risk-benefit balance of dual antiplatelet treatment in patients with coronary artery disease. According to a recent expert consensus on DAPT, it is recommended that the use of gastrointestinal protective drugs (proton pump inhibitors or H2RE) should be considered in patients known to have a moderate or high risk for GI bleeding. However, there is no clinical benefit of PPI use with aspirin and clopidogrel in patients with stable coronary disease or PCI. To date, whether PPI-based gastroprotection is necessary at all in those who are at moderate or high risk of bleeding using PPI in everyday clinical practice is unknown.

The aim of this study is to observe whether prospective memory in HIV+ individuals is related with global cognitive profile, hot and cold cognition.
Sixty subjects (30 HIV+ and 30 healthy controls) will be recruited from the Infectious and Tropical Diseases Service and from the HIV Outpatient Service of the Institute of Clinical Sciences, San Raffaele Milan.
In addition to a clinical interview with questionnaires, a neuropsychological battery will be administered, consisting of four tests.
The prospective memory is investigated by means of the Memory for Intentions Screening Test (MIST; Raskin et al., 2010), with the purpose of evaluating the patient's ability to remember and execute a task in the near future. Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA) investigates global cognitive profile, Interpersonal Reactivity Index (IRI) tests cognitive and affective empathy (hot cognition), and the Modified Five Point Test is carried out to assess figurative fluency (cold cognition).
In case of cognitive impairment, patients will be offered for consultation the service of the Clinical Neurosciences and a new neuropsychological assessment.

Intestinal anti-transglutaminase type 2 (anti-TG, IgA and IgG, respectively) antibodies are specific for celiac disease.
The reference standards for celiac disease include serology (i.e. anti-TG (classical antibody test), anti-EMA (enolase immunostatin), plus small intestinal biopsy (normal or abnormal duodenal villi and intra-epithelial lymphocytes of 30/100) or duodenal histology as the reference standard.
Serology of intestinal antibodies (detected on serum) should be performed in every patient with suspected celiac disease, and intestinal biopsy should be performed when serology is strongly positive, equivocal or negative to histology.
Intestinal biopsies involve submitting a small piece of intestine (endoscopy) to histological examination. This must be done under special conditions, and with trained personnel. This often involves a delay in diagnosis of celiac disease, and, when serological tests are negative, histological examination is not necessary.
Recent advances in medicine and gastroenterology have resulted in the development of techniques that can be used at the bedside to detect various biochemical parameters in a blood sample, as well as in a urine sample. These tests can provide diagnostic results in a few hours. Some of these tests do not require highly specialized personnel and some have lower cost and are therefore easy to use.
The present study will evaluate whether a new rapid anti-TG2 diagnostic test, on a blood sample, can make it possible to diagnose celiac disease a little faster. This rapid test, which detects intestinal anti-TG2, could be performed for patients who cannot have an endoscopy.
The current study also aims at comparing with the reference standard (serology + histopathology), the anti-TG2 rapid test on mechanically lysed intestinal biopsy specimens, and in comparison with culture-EMA. This new technique could simplify the diagnosis of celiac disease and avoid the need for intestinal biopsy in some cases.
The investigators also propose to determine whether the anti-TG2 antibodies detected on mechanically lysed intestinal biopsy specimens (ELISTAT method) could help to select patients for whom an early confirmation of celiac disease will be made by a rapid serological test.
The investigators will examine the effectiveness of the anti-TG2 assay performed on mechanically lysed intestinal biopsies, by comparing it with culture EMA, which is currently used in routine practice in France. Based on the literature and our preliminary data, the investigators estimate that the use of the Anti-TG2 assay on mechanically lysed intestinal biopsies is a method that could help to provide a rapid serological diagnosis without the need for intestinal biopsy in some situations.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) increases an individual's risk of stroke, and oral anticoagulation (OAC) reduces stroke risk by 65%. Clinical prediction rules are recommended to assess stroke risk, but rates of risk-discordant stroke prevention therapy persist despite recommendations, representing a major knowledge translation challenge. This RAPID AFib pilot study will evaluate the acceptability of a web-based atrial fibrillation patient decision aid in persons with recent onset AF, and the impact of the decision aid on the process of shared decision making before stroke prevention therapy. This will be a pilot cluster-randomized trial, with a randomized participant stratification by clinic site. The primary outcome will the SDM-Q-9 score, a measure of quality of shared decision-making. This study will be performed at two cardiology clinics in Ottawa, Ontario.

Background: Heart Failure (HF) is associated with poor mortality and recurrent hospitalizations that place an enormous burden on health care costs and systems. Over 3.5 million Ugandans experience HF, and HF-related hospitalizations are common, with over 50% of Ugandan patients hospitalized due to HF within 1 year after diagnosis. The World Health Organization (WHO) has called for innovative health approaches to address the burden of chronic diseases, such as HF. One promising approach is mHealth interventions, which hold promise for reaching patients in diverse, resource-limited settings. Despite this potential, challenges related to scalability, integration with existing health systems, and sustainability have prevented uptake of such interventions into clinical practice. To address these challenges, the investigators' goal is to establish a sustainable implementation package across RRHs that can be integrated with existing clinical care strategies and scaled to meet patients' need for sustained HF care. The proposed approach leverages novel digital health methodologies that are tailored for use in Uganda, and it is driven by engagement of stakeholders, including clinical care providers and patient advocates, to inform iterative program modifications. Methods: The investigators will conduct a cluster-randomized controlled trial with embedded implementation science and cost effectiveness assessments to establish the clinical effectiveness and cost effectiveness of a multi-component implementation strategy for HF care. We will randomize three RRHs in Uganda to intervention and intervention control groups, and we will recruit 2,100 participants with HF to provide core- HF care, including a clinician and patient-facing mobile application intervention. Randomization will be performed using a randomization software. We will apply a Learn-As-You-Go (LAaYG) design at each site that guides iterative modifications of specific implementation components, including mobile applications, and patient-provider communication, using feedback from patients and care providers. The investigators will assess the change in HF self-care, clinical outcomes, patient fidelity to self-care, facility fidelity to implementation strategies, acceptability, and cost effectiveness of the interventions throughout the study. Achieving feasibility requires a careful balance between the depth of the intervention, the pace of implementation, and the acceptability and feasibility of the intervention strategies. Aim 2: Develop and refine the implementation strategy through formative research via an embedded implementation trial.

Official Title
-----------------
ImpleMEntation of a Digital-first Care deLiverY Model for Heart Failure in Uganda

Conditions
-----------------
Heart Failure

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Other: Enhanced HF Clinical Care (Core-HF)
* Other: Digital health intervention (Medly Uganda) plus enhanced HF clinical care (Core-HF)

Languages will include: Lusoga in Jinja, Runyankole in Mbarara, Luganda in Masaka, Rutooro in Fort Portal, Acholi in Gulu, and Alur in Lira in addition to English. Exclusion Criteria: Any individual not meeting the above inclusion criteria Inability to provide informed consent, as determined by the nurse manager Active medical condition requiring hospitalization, such as cardiac ischemia (acute electrocardiographic changes and/or positive biomarkers, if available), syncope, or significant fluid overload Echocardiography findings that do not support a diagnosis of HF as determined during a study visit. This exclusion might occur following enrollment and new patients will be consented and enrolled to compensate for these exclusions.

Aim: This multicentre prospective observational study is to understand the current standards of treatment and care, and the impact (in terms of patient reported outcomes) of apalutamide in mHSPC patients. Methods. Fifty-two UK sites were invited to collaborate and recruit patients into this observational study. Patients meeting the inclusion criteria will undergo a baseline assessment of disease and patient reported outcomes (using validated questionnaires). Follow-up assessments will be done at 12 and 24 months (and as per standard clinical care). Results: We will assess the PSA response rate of mHSPC patients treated with apalutamide and evaluate the feasibility of collecting clinical and patient reported outcomes data. We will then be able to demonstrate the impact of apalutamide in this specific population of patients.

This multidisciplinary sentinel surveillance program, cofunded by the European Union, is aiming to investigate the emergence and spread of viruses with potential to infect humans from animals, identified as zoonotic influenza viruses (ZIV). The program will also develop strategies for control of virus transmission at its source, before it spreads into the general population. It will be performed by a consortium of public health, veterinary and animal/wildlife science services at local, regional and national level and will involve close collaboration with laboratories. The program will involve the following:
1. Surveillance of ZIV within four cohorts of 'people at risk' from animal contact.
- Outbreak workers within outbreak management teams at poultry farms.
- Sentinel population in the selected poultry farms, wildlife rehabilitation centres and pig industry veterinarians.

7. Development of rapid diagnostics to be used at the human-animal interface.

The purpose of this research is to investigate the effect of myofascial release applied in addition to foot core exercises on lower extremity function in young adults with asymptomatic flexible pes planus. 2.4. Sample
This study will be performed with young adults with asymptomatic flexible pes planus and with a navicular drop amount of 10 mm or more. Inclusion Criteria
1. Volunteer to participate in research and continue to the end.
2. A between the ages 18-25 mm.
3. Having a fall amount of 10 mm or more according to the navicular fall test.
4. Having asymptomatic flexible pes planus according to the Jack's finger test.
5. Having stable ankles (According to the talar tilt test and anterior drawer test).
6. Not having musculoskeletal complaints in the lower extremity for the last 6 months.
7. Not being pregnant.
8. Not using physiotherapy and osteopathic services in the last 6 months.
10. Not using orthopedic and podiatric services.
11. Not being a regular participant in sports activities.
12. Exclusion Criteria
1. Having musculoskeletal disorders other than pes planus.
2. Having chronic ankle instability.
3. Having received a treatment related to pes planus in the last 6 months.
4. Having used insoles.
5. Having an orthopedic or neurological history in the lower extremity.

Early pregnancy loss is very common, approximately one in four women will experience a miscarriage in their lifetime. The etiology of pregnancy loss remains largely unknown, although genetic, anatomical, endocrinological and immunological abnormalities have been implicated. It is known that embryonic/fetal chromosomal aberrations contributed to approximately 50% of early pregnancy loss, among which 60-70% were aneuploidies, largely can be detected by the current gold standard karyotyping approach recommended by various international societies.
Besides the well-known karyotyping method commonly used in the clinical practice, the advent of next generation sequencing offers an excellent opportunity to explore the genetic factors that may be involved in the pathogenesis of miscarriage. The proposed study will utilize the non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) approach by low-pass genome sequencing to detect genome-wide copy-number variants, chromosomal mosaicisms, structural rearrangements, absence of heterozygosity (AOH), and single-nucleotide variant (SNV). In other words, the investigators plan to perform low-pass whole genome sequencing of the product of conception (POC) from women who had termination of pregnancy below 13-week gestation. The investigators intend to recruit 10-20 women to undergo the procedure of ultrasound-guided manual vacuum aspiration (USG-MVA) to collect POC samples for genetic testing.
In addition, the investigators hope that this novel approach may provide a better understanding of the complex genetics of early pregnancy loss. The investigators also hope to determine the genetic causes of early pregnancy loss in order to provide more precise and accurate diagnosis for women with recurrent pregnancy loss. The investigators further anticipate that this study could lead to better diagnosis and improved management, which may have the potential to significantly reduce the incidence of early pregnancy loss and bring the significant improvement of women's health.
In this observational study on the role of immunologically-mediated mechanisms in uterine rejection of the preterm fetus, the investigators plan to study the following: 1. the difference of cytokines in the decidual tissue between women with normal pregnancy and those having with early pregnancy loss. The investigators intend to establish a model of immunological rejection in normal decidual tissue with the hypothesis that the activation of immune cells in normal first trimester decidual tissue contribute to fetal demise in women with pregnancy loss. The investigators will also examine the proportion of CD4+ T-cells producing IFN-gamma, Tumor Necrosis Factor (TNF) and interleukin (IL)-12 (Th1 cell) compared with CD4+ T-cells producing IL-4 and IL-10 (Treg cell) in decidual tissue between women with normal pregnancy and those having with early pregnancy loss. The proportion of decidual CD8+ T cells also expressing the Th1-associated cytokine interferon-gamma (INF-gamma) will also be examined. 2. the difference of cytokines in the decidual tissue between women having with pregnancy loss and those with chromosomally normal or aneuploid miscarriages. The investigators will study whether a Th1 dominated cytokine profile in decidual tissue was associated with pregnancy loss. The investigators will also examine whether the chromosomal status of the conceptus influences uterine immunity. 3. the difference of cytokines in the decidual tissue between women having with unsuccessful and successful outcomes of ultrasound-guided manual vacuum aspiration (USG-MVA). The investigators will establish a prospective, randomized, study comparing decidual tissue samples obtained from patients with failed and successful outcomes of USG-MVA.

Seasonal influenza vaccination is the most effective measure to prevent seasonal influenza. Most countries in Europe and North America vaccinate the high-risk groups' elderly, pregnant women, and children. The annual WHO recommendation for offering inactivated influenza vaccine for people aged ≥60 years, pregnant women, and individuals with chronic medical conditions began in 2010. On the contrary, only 14 countries in Africa recommended influenza vaccination for the high-risk groups. Bangladesh is one of those countries, but no comprehensive policies and programs have been developed so far. The seasonal influenza vaccination is an ongoing challenge in developing countries. Most of the high-risk groups' vulnerable populations cannot afford vaccine costs, and as a result, the majority of health facilities do not have the required capacity to deliver vaccines. This study will investigate the acceptability and cost-effectiveness of the facility-based influenza vaccination to vulnerable populations (children six months to 8 years, pregnant women, elderly individuals, and patients with chronic diseases) who were targeted by the government's influenza vaccination policy in Bangladesh. The study will also estimate the needed capacity for a well-functioning seasonal influenza vaccination program in the high-risk group targeted hospital. Finally, the researchers will evaluate the cost associated with healthcare utilization and health outcomes among the high-risk group individuals before and after vaccination. The overall objective is to assess the feasibility and evaluate policy and program options for a well-functioning, cost-effective vaccine delivery and vaccination among Bangladesh's high-risk individuals. The investigators expect that the results of this research will provide insights into improving a well-functioning, cost-effective, facility-based influenza vaccination program in Bangladesh, ultimately saving lives and reducing human suffering from the severe complications of seasonal influenza.

Introduction: The clinical routine in Europe requires that the same duodenoscope is reprocessed and reused after each endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) procedure due to costs and accessibility concerns. However, concerns related to duodenoscope-related cross-contamination and infections have been reported. The purpose of this national multicentre Italian study is to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of single-use duodenoscopes in a real-world setting from an interventional standpoint. The goal of this study is to perform an observational prospective research on a group of patients planned for a duodenoscopic-related procedure involving the use of a single use duodenoscope (DUKE®, Boston Scientific) in a real-world setting to report the outcomes of the technical and procedural performances of the scope.
Objective: This study is an observational prospective research on a group of patients planned for a duodenoscopic-related procedure involving the use of single-use duodenoscopes.
Study design: All patients planned for any procedure involving the use of a single-use duodenoscope will be enrolled in a real-world setting.
Study population and intervention: Patients aged 18 years or older willing to undergo a procedure for which the duodenoscope was the sole endoscopic tool that was indicated for the procedure and a device (Cook-Williams DUKE® Endoscopic System - Boston Scientific, US) that was not commercially available at the time of enrollment was prescribed. After each procedure, the duodenoscope will be discarded. The study duration will be at least 24 months and a minimum of 3000 procedures will be performed.
The main objective will be to determine whether single-use duodenoscopes perform as well as the currently widely used conventional duodenoscopes, and whether they are safe.
The secondary objectives will be:
- to assess the ability of single-use duodenoscopes to provide a diagnostic image of the upper GI tract (sensitivity and specificity)
- to evaluate the technical and procedural performances of single-use duodenoscopes
- to evaluate the ability of single-use duodenoscopes to obtain a pancreatic/biliary ductal cannulation
- to evaluate whether using single-use duodenoscopes may reduce the risk related to contamination/infection in the upper GI tract or cross contamination between procedures
- to evaluate the device usability and patient safety/security during the procedure
- to evaluate the adhesion and clinical outcomes related to duodenoscope use
- to evaluate the impact of single-use duodenoscopes on procedural time, adverse events, technical difficulties and need for additional interventions

Official Title
-----------------
Single-Use Duodenoscopes Performance Characteristics and Technical Outcomes: the SUSPECT Italian Prospective Study

Hybrid Pulmonary Rehabilitation for Patients with COPD: a Feasibility Study (UKCA/CE Class 1-approved and DTAC-certified Active+me REMOTE App)

Objectives: The aim of this feasibility study is to address two key NHS needs for digital health. The first is to generate evidence of the effectiveness of remote Pulmonary Rehabilitation (PR) to support the development of a fully-digital PR programme. The second is to support NHS England to understand the value and benefits (both to the individuals and to wider society) of remote PR, which currently offers very little return on investment (ROI) and only limited savings in health care staff time. The study will use real-world study design, drawing on routinely collected data to compare outcomes for patients recruited to a hybrid PR intervention with a propensity matched control group that has previously received standard PR.

Design: It will test the success of integrating the hybrid PR system (Active+me REMOTE) into routine practice and the ability of the system to overcome barriers to hybrid PR delivery and service implementation. It will also evaluate patient outcomes and identify whether any cost savings can be achieved by implementing the app on a larger scale.
A pragmatic sequential mixed methodology will be employed which includes both quantitative data collected from routine practice, and qualitative data collected via focus groups/interviews with patients and health care professionals. Patients, health care professionals, managers and commissioners, including patients who have self-discharged early from a pulmonary rehabilitation service, will be recruited via an information pack, which will include details of the study. For each arm of the study, participants will be recruited by being referred from their general practitioner (GP) or Hospital Consultant, and being matched according to age, sex, measure of respiratory disability, disease severity, Index of Multiple Deprivation (IMD), location of service (Hospital vs Community), baseline health outcomes, and ability to self-care.
The first phase is a retrospective study to compare the baseline characteristics of patients with COPD who will receive hybrid PR with patients who will receive standard PR to ensure that there are no meaningful differences between groups of patients.

Interventions:
After participants have signed the informed consent, a member of the clinical research team will download the Active+me REMOTE App onto patients' smartphone, providing them with a simple instruction sheet. Participants will be given a preliminary assessment with a member of the Harefield Pulmonary Rehabilitation Team as part of routine care. Participants will then follow the 8-week hybrid PR intervention involving two exercise classes per week. While this is an 8-week programme, additional weeks of in person, online or hybrid classes may be provided for those participants wishing to attend more than 16 sessions. On completion of the programme, participants will be discharged by their clinician.

Main study:
This study will be a hybrid design (randomised, parallel-group, non-inferiority, unmasked, pragmatic control, mixed method, patient level) to compare two modes of delivery of a pulmonary rehabilitation programme (hybrid vs standard) in COPD patients. This study will provide evidence about the effectiveness of hybrid PR with patients with chronic respiratory conditions.
Participants: 60 participants in two arms: hybrid PR intervention and propensity matched control group.
Intervention/Treatment: An onboarding session at the start of the HRB study will be attended by a member of the clinical research team.
Reasoning: To ensure a pragmatic and realistic approach to recruitment, the control group will be recruited to match the participant group/arm in the intervention group.

Study Arms: Arm 1: hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation
Arm 2: Standard pulmonary rehabilitation (retrospective data) collected from routine care practice.

Reasons for designing an observational study with a hybrid design: To overcome the challenges of standard RCTs in digital health, we will use real-world study design. Real-world studies draw largely on routinely collected data, for example from patient health records, to assess outcomes of a digital health intervention in a real-world population. To assess whether the results of this study can be successfully translated into clinical practice, this observational study will include recruitment of patients and gathering of clinical data in real-time. Participating patients will be randomised to either an intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will be recruited to take part in a hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation programme involving technology-based remote PR and two in-person sessions per week. The control group will have participated

A new pre-exposure prophylaxis regimen has been recently approved in Japan which is 2-dose anti-SARS-CoV-2 monoclonal antibody given subcutaneously (SC). Tixagevimab and Cilgavimab, a combination therapy, demonstrated a significant reduction in COVID-19 by 73% (95% CI = 65% - 79%) compared with placebo in the Phase 2 PREVENT trial. Several observational studies have demonstrated the effectiveness and safety of this new therapy as PrEP against COVID-19. However, its effectiveness and safety vary by patient characteristics depending on countries or regions. Due to the different patient populations, and the limited information available on the real-world situation of this therapy in Japan, this observational study will describe baseline demographics and clinical characteristics. To identify the main characteristics that may influence the effectiveness and safety of this therapy, information including medical history, laboratory tests and demographics will be collected.
Participants aged 12 years or more who were administered EVUSHELD as PrEP in Japan between 17th of March, 2022, to 4th of August, 2022, will be identified from the medical databases of the healthcare provider institutions. All baseline demographic and clinical characteristics collected within the 24 months of the medical database will be used for the purpose of baseline description.
The following information will be used for baseline demographic and clinical characteristics: demographic (gender, age), comorbidity (premutually identified diseases including hypertension, diabetes, heart disease, lung disease, kidney disease, liver disease, cancer, HIV and immune suppression), concurrent medication (immunosuppressive drugs, anticoagulant therapy, immunomodulatory drugs), COVID-19 treatment history, and laboratory test results collected prior to the administration of the study therapy. Baseline demographics and characteristics will be described and potential risk factors for COVID-19 associated with treatment failure or breakthrough infection will be identified.
Finally, to understand the real-world efficacy, safety and tolerability of this new therapy as PrEP in Japan. For follow-up period after EVUSHELD administration, data about COVID-19 will be collected from medical databases.
This study is not intended to provide direct benefits to any participant. This study will help to provide real-world information about patients and treatment characteristics of this therapy as PrEP in Japan, and to identify potential indicators for treatment failure or breakthrough infection. This information will be helpful to prevent or minimize treatment failure and/or COVID-19 breakthrough infection.

These deficits may be caused by different pathophysiological mechanisms than impaired handwriting, which is also common in PD. The learning and transfer effects of two weeks of training will also be examined. Postpartum depression and anxiety are frequent, often unrecognized, and underestimated phenomena acknowledged by WHO. Despite a widespread use of psychological questionnaires to diagnose disorders occurring during the first postpartum years, their mechanisms, possible causes, and treatment are still strongly investigated. The present study should establish whether intensified tactile contact between a mother and the newborn should be implemented as an obligatory part of the care program of the newborn during the first week of life (applied in the form of Shantali massage).
This is the pilot phase of a longitudinal research project which should be continued by the project of the Polish Research Grant. The project started in October 2010 and ended in July 2013. The main purpose of the intervention group vs. control group and between the two groups should be tested using the standardized scales (Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale, Self-reports of Anxiety Scale (STAI) and the subscales of the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS). The study will be conducted on a group of 43 randomly selected participants after physiological delivery, their level of happiness will be measured twice before and after the 12th week after delivery. If the results of this phase are satisfactory, the project of the Polish Research Grant will be activated, where the number of subjects should be increased and the study will be carried out in 7 cities, including one metropolis. If the main hypothesis is confirmed, the effects of this simple intervention should be evaluated in a multistage, comprehensive clinical trial.

Persistent symptoms that follow recovery from acute COVID-19 are collectively referred to as "long COVID" or post-acute COVID-19 syndrome (PACS). Despite significant interest in understanding the nature and underlying mechanisms of the PACS, there are no accepted diagnostic criteria or a gold standard treatment approach for it. A growing body of evidence suggests that osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) may have a beneficial effect in some of the patients with chronic musculoskeletal pain and the PACS may have some common features. This pilot RCT was performed to examine the feasibility and safety of OMT for patients with the PACS, and to evaluate its potential effectiveness on symptoms related to PACS. Eligible participants were consecutive and incident patients aged 18 and above who had one or more persistent symptoms following COVID-19 for at least 4 weeks and were recruited by the study investigator. All participants received standard of care that included OMT which was prescribed and performed by a licensed D.O. participants were asked to assess their physical and neurocognitive symptoms, and their global health on questionnaires. The data from this study can be used to inform a larger confirmatory RCT to evaluate the effectiveness of OMT in patients with the PACS.

Inclusion criteria: at least one symptom of post-COVID-19 (eg, fatigue, dyspnea, anosmia, arthralgia, headache, sleep disturbances, anxiety/depression, or other problems related to mental health) which was new after diagnosis with COVID-19 and has persisted for at least 4 weeks after diagnosis.

Exclusion criteria: unable to speak, read and write in English, not mentally competent to give informed consent, inability to complete surveys/questionnaires on-line.

Design: Each enrolled eligible patient has been seen by the PI at least once. On average, each patient was seen ten times within the first four months. For eligible participants, the standard of care may include treatments prescribed by the primary care physician, the neurologist, or other specialists such as physical therapists and occupational therapists. The participants received osteopathic manual treatment based on their response to previous treatments. The total number of OMT sessions were decided by the treating physician with the patient's input. The data from the questionnaires were collected at the first visit, 3 days after every OMT session for up to 4 months after enrollment, and 2 months after the participant's final OMT session.

Outcome measures: Preliminary observations from a similar but smaller study support the feasibility of OMT in patients with PACS. The number of participants who enrolled in the study were assessed. In this study, participants were asked to assess their symptoms using PROMIS and RPCCS questionnaires. We also evaluated global health using PROMIS SF v1.2. The data on the participants' return to work status was obtained from the participants.

This feasibility study is designed to test the feasibility of conducting an RCT in patients with a diverse spectrum of PACS symptoms. It will provide important information on the acceptability of OMT and its role in management of PACS. If the feasibility criteria are met and preliminary evidence of effectiveness is obtained, a larger RCT is warranted. If the larger RCT supports the effectiveness of OMT, it may pave the way for integration of OMT in the standard of care for patients with PACS. OMT may have a role in management of the PACS but its role is not fully understood and requires further research.

Frostbite is a significant source of morbidity and mortality for those in cold climates. As the body cools, ischemia and clotting within the tissue occur, causing significant damage. Upon rewarming, the tissue is assessed to determine the extent of damage and the need for further treatment. The main goal of these assessments is to determine if there is a vascular cutoff causing tissue ischemia. Over the past 20 years, Regions Hospital has used conventional angiography to assess vascular patency and to deliver thrombolytics directly into the affected vessels. Other imaging modalities are being used, but it is unknown how accurately these imaging modalities demonstrate the vasculature.
Indocyanine Green (ICG) microangiography is a promising technology for evaluating tissue perfusion in several diseases. Unlike conventional angiography, ICG does not require ionizing radiation, is easily administered intravenously, and can be repeated as needed. Therefore, the investigators will investigate the ability of ICG microangiography to correlate with conventional angiography in patients with severe frostbite.

Colorectal cancer is a global disease, with a high incidence and mortality rate in older patients. The impact of this pathology is complex, associated with an impact not only on morbidity and mortality but also on the evolution of quality of life. Preventive care, early diagnosis, surgical management are all important issues in the geriatric patient.
We propose to focus on geriatric care of the oldest patients (aged 70 and over) operated on for colorectal cancer. These patients already have an impact on their functionality since the preoperative period.
The study will be conducted in a cohort of 120 patients. Two arms will be compared: patients in the control group will be managed, in all respects, in the hospital's conventional surgical activity. Patients in the second arm will be treated in the Peri-Operative Geriatrics Unit for 10 to15 days prior to surgery (depending on the grade of nutritional status). The objective of the intervention is to improve the preoperative preparation of geriatric patients in order to anticipate complications, optimize the perioperative care and improve the functional status at discharge. In this, the patient in the GPOU is managed differently, in particular with regard to mobilization. Mobilization is the main factor in a global care process and is an essential parameter for the patient to recover his functional status, including the ability to perform daily and instrumental activities, important for autonomy in daily life. Finally, a multidisciplinary meeting will be planned for each patient in the Geriatrics Unit in order to optimize management and organization.
In clinical research in surgery there is little data on the elderly. Very few published studies have evaluated the impact on functional status by using geriatric assessments. The preliminary studies performed locally confirm the interest of an intervention prior to surgery in this patient group.
The proposed study will evaluate the change in functional status between patients treated in the conventional surgery department and patients treated in the Geriatrics Unit with a specific protocol. It will also evaluate the management of surgical care by surgeons and by the anesthesia resuscitation team.
