Background: Metastatic disease is the most common cause of cancer related death and treatment options are limited in patients with metastatic disease. Stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) is an important treatment modality for patients with metastatic disease, especially in cases of oligo-progressive disease, where only a small number of sites are progressing.

Current palliative treatment for metastatic patients involves systemic therapies and radiation therapy to radiated local sites, which may cause tumor regression but rarely complete tumor control. Pembrolizumab, an antibody blocking the interaction between Programmed Death-1 (PD-1) and its ligand PD-L1 has shown impressive results in metastatic solid cancer populations with durable tumor shrinkage and reduced toxicities. The use of Pembrolizumab with radiation therapy may enhance the immune response mediated by pembrolizumab and therefore synergize the treatment mechanism of SBRT.

Objectives: Our hypothesis is that we can enhance the anti-tumor immunity, using a combination of pembrolizumab and SBRT in metastatic cancer patients. With this goal in mind, this Phase I trial aims to establish the safety of giving escalating doses of 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab as measured by dose limiting toxicities (DLTs). This trial will also analyze the changes in 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab uptake as the dose increases to identify the optimal dose for future studies.

Design: We plan to recruit 7-10 patients per dosing cohort. We aim to enroll 2-3 eligible patients into each of 3-4 escalating dose cohorts. Toxicities will be graded according to the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events, version 5.0 (CTCAE v5.0). DLT will be estimated over the first 3 days after administration of study drug. The study duration for each patient, including the pre-screening, screening, PET procedure and SBRT is approximately 6 weeks.

Pilot Trial Using 64Cu-DOTA Pembrolizumab in Patients Receiving Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy for Oligo-Progressive Solid Tumors

Conditions

Metastatic Malignant Solid Neoplasm

Intervention / Treatment

* Drug: Copper Cu 64-DOTA-pembrolizumab
* Procedure: Positron Emission Tomography
* Radiation: Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy

The purpose of this study is to assess the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics (PK) of CSX-1004, an investigational humanized monoclonal antibody designed to block the effects of fentanyl.
In this study, healthy adults will receive a single intravenous dose of CSX-1004 or a placebo. They will also receive three subcutaneous (under the skin) doses of CSX-1004. Subjects will remain in the clinic for the treatment phase of the study and up to 18 days following the end of treatment to monitor safety after release from the treatment unit.
The PK of the drug will be analyzed to determine the maximum serum concentration (Cmax), the area under the curve from time zero to last measurable concentration (AUCLast), the area under the curve from time zero to time of the last quantifiable concentration (AUCtlast), the area under the curve from time zero extrapolated to infinity (AUCinf), and the beta terminal elimination half-life (t1/2).
Safety and tolerability of CSX-1004 will be assessed by treatment emergent adverse events (TEAEs), serious adverse events (SAEs), and TEAEs that lead to discontinuation of the subject. Blood pressure, pulse rate, and vital signs will be monitored throughout the study. ECGs will be obtained from all subjects during the study. Physical examinations, laboratory assessments, and urinalysis will also be performed.
The results of this study will provide valuable data on the safety and pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004 in healthy adults.

Introduction:
Infection remains one of the main causes of secondary functional failure. Its incidence varies between 1 and 5% post-artroplasty . Aseptic loosening (AL) is observed in most patients undergoing revision of the implant, thus the diagnosis of infection is not obvious. FJA is an essential step in the diagnosis and management of patients with an infected prosthesis. It allows for the visualization of the infected synovial fluid, the identification of biomarkers (CRP, Lysozyme, alpha defensing, leukocyte Esterase) and microbiological diagnosis. However, it has some limitations such as the inability to detect the cause in 40 to 60% of patients in the case of negative FJA (0/21 and 0/49) . However, even in the case of positive FJA (100% sensitive), negative perioperative cultures are frequently observed, thus giving a lack of confidence in the prognosis and the treatment of patients.
The use of biomarkers in joint fluid of knee, elbow and shoulder arthroplasty for the diagnosis of infection was tested in a prospective multi-center study and a systematic review . These biomarkers had limited utility for the diagnosis of infection, and the results must be interpreted with caution due to the potential limitations (sample size, heterogeneity of the studied population (primary and secondary arthroplasties), and variability of the biomarkers measured according to the pathology concerned (acute infection, chronic infection, aseptic loosening) .
The purpose of this study is to assess whether the dosage of joint fluid biomarkers (CRP, alpha defensing, leukocyte Esterase and protein) by FJA adds additional information to the antibiotic pre-treatment therapy (APT) and the dosage of CRP in blood. Investigators believe that the use of these biomarkers in association with the clinical, radiological and evolution will improve the diagnosis and the initial treatment.
Secondary objectives:
1. Correlate the results of biomarkers in joint fluid to the bacteria isolated in intraoperative samples (culture, PCR and mass spectrometry) and histological analysis of peri-prosthetic bone biopsies. 2. Characterize the population of patients in each group. 3. Evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the association of joint fluid results to the aseptic or infectious origin of the symptoms of the patients in this cohort. 4. Describe the results of peri-operative cultures and peri-operative histological results. 5. Analyze the incidence of bacteriological contamination during surgery in patients benefiting from APT. 6. Determine the influence of bacteriological contamination during surgery with APT. 7. Describe the functional results after joint prosthesis revision at 3 months for patients in whom joint fluid biomarkers were associated with the diagnosis of infection. 8. Evaluate the influence of joint fluid biomarkers on the evolution of functional results in infected patients. 9. Evaluate the influence of bacteriological contamination during surgery on the evolution of functional results in infected patients. 10. Analyze the correlation between the number of revisions and the long-term evolution of patients in this study.

The purpose of this study is to identify new clinical, structural, and biophysical imaging tools which would help identify early lung dysfunction in CF children, adolescents, and adults.  This is an initial feasibility study to develop and validate in CF.  The study is designed to assess the effectiveness of a gas breathing contrast MRI system used in conjunction with a standard MRI system in healthy controls and individuals with CF.
Participants will undergo a 1 hour 3.0 Tesla combined MRI as part of this study. The MRI will measure their airways ventilation patterns. After that, they will be asked to inhale the contrast gas- PFP- through a valve on a mask worn in the MRI scanning environment.  The subject must hold their breath during the MRI scan, either for five breath hold cycles of increasing duration (5-30 seconds), or during the duration of one shallow tidal breath (5 - 7 seconds). This is a non-invasive procedure, but may cause some discomfort, such as feeling short of breath. We have found that most people are able to complete one of the breath holding tasks, and subjects can choose which breath holding they want to attempt.

The use of double-lumen endobronchial tube (DLT) has become more widespread in thoracic surgery. The DLT is usually placed in a position with the right main bronchus and the left main bronchus being completely occluded to achieve total collapse of one hemithorax or lung lobar selective ventilation for unilateral surgery. However, the DLT can be pulled and kinked in the bronchial channel during the patient's change of position. The use of a conventional ventilation circuit will cause the DLT to be pulled by gravity, the risk of malposition of the DLT will increase, and the possibility of bronchial obstruction will also be increased. There are currently no clinical trials focusing on the prevention of bronchial dislocation with the help of anesthesia breathing circuits to avoid postoperative pulmonary complications.
To improve the safety of DLT patients before and after thoracic surgery, the investigator designed a multi-center, randomized controlled study. The investigator hopes to evaluate the effectiveness of this new method.
The investigators will recruit 380 patients aged 18 to 65 in the Thoracic Surgery Department and the Department of Anesthesia, Anesthesia Assessment, Respiration, Wujin People's Hospital, from August 1, 2018 to January 31, 2021. The investigators divide the subjects into two groups based on the disconnection of the circuit. One is an experimental group (disconnected group), and the other is a control group (connected group). The investigators will evaluate the incidence of double-lumen endotracheal tube malpositions, complications, intraoperative and postoperative patient satisfaction and outcomes. At the same time, the investigator will evaluate the incidence of double-lumen endotracheal tube malpositions, complications, intraoperative and postoperative patient satisfaction and outcomes.

Inclusion criteria: 1. Elective surgery.
2. ASA I-II patients who need postoperative care in the intensive care unit under thoracic surgery.
3. Patients undergoing thoracic surgery requiring a left-sided double-lumen endobronchial tube.
4. Sign the informed consent form for this clinical study.

Exclusion criteria: 
1. Mouth opening ＜3cm.
2. History of previous difficult intubation.
3. Patients with diseases of the upper respiratory tract and main bronchi.
4. Patients with cardiac insufficiency.
5. People with liver dysfunction.
6. Renal insufficiency.
7. Previous stroke.
8. Patients with severe obstructive ventilation dysfunction.
9. Bronchial asthma or airway hyperresponsiveness.
10. Patients who have participated in other clinical studies in the past 3 months.

The design details are as follows:
Primary purpose: prevention
Allocation: parallel randomized two-blind design
Intervention model: parallel assignment
Masking: double

Design details: This is a multi-center, randomized controlled study. Three hundred eighty patients aged 18 to 65 years in the Thoracic Surgery Department and the Department of Anesthesia of Wujin People's Hospital will be recruited from August 1, 2018 to January 31, 2021. The subjects will be divided into two groups based on the disconnection of the circuit. One is an experimental group (disconnected group), and the other is a control group (connected group). The subjects in the control group will undergo thoracic surgery as usual and have the anesthetic breathing circuit connected during the patient's changes in position. During the process of changing the supine position to the lateral decubitus position, the anesthesiologist in the experimental group will disconnect the anesthetic breathing circuit first, and then perform lung collapse and ventilation to the other lung, and connect the anesthetic breathing circuit after lung collapse and ventilation.
The investigators will perform one double-lumen endotracheal tube by random number table method. The investigator will evaluate the incidence of double-lumen endotracheal tube malposition, complications, intraoperative and postoperative patient satisfaction and outcomes. At the same time, the investigator will evaluate each group on the same basis to achieve the purpose of comparison.

Periodontal health may be enhanced by gingival augmentation in patients with thin-gingiva. Gingival recession is more commonly seen in patients with thin gingival phenotype, which may lead to various aetiologies. Gingival recession can be a serious problem for both patients and dentists. Several methodologies for gingival recession have been suggested. One of them is gingival augmentation surgery which is most commonly done using different approaches like free gingival graft (FGG), subepithelial connective tissue graft (SCTG) gingival flap (GF), pedicle graft using mucogingival flap (GMF) and connective tissue graft (CTG). All require surgical techniques that involve tissue manipulation to enhance the blood flow supply which is of importance for the healing process of the surgical site. Hence, there are limitations such as donor site morbidity, lengthy surgical procedures with prolonged healing phases, unpredictable wound healing and patient discomfort.
   In recent years, an alternative, minimally invasive method for achieving gingival augmentation has been the use of microneedles in oral tissue. It offers superior results without causing any pain, postoperative discomfort, inflammation or scarring. Microneedling (MN) involves the creation of microchannels in the oral mucosa using 30 gauge lancet needles at a depth of 1.5 mm with manual and/or mechanical instrumentation. This procedure may cause micro wound-healing response, thereby leading to an increase in the gingival tissue dimension and width of keratinized tissue. 
A recent study proved the advantage of microneedling in gingival recession cases. But many cases of recessions were managed by periodontist, and the gingival phenotype in those cases were not mentioned. Another study showed gingival thickness increase when Microneedling (MN) was performed along with I-PRF in thin gingival phenotype.
   This study will be conducted to comparative evaluation of microneedling alone and along with hyaluronic acid on thin gingival phenotype. The present randomized controlled clinical trial will be conducted in the department of periodontics and oral implantology,Post Graduate Institute of Dental Sciences, Rohtak, India. 20 systematically healthy patients having thin gingival phenotypes will be included in this split-mouth randomized controlled trial. For each patient, each side of the anterior mandible will be randomly allocated to one of the two procedures (MN or MN with Hyaluronic acid)using chit system. In the MN group microneedling will be done 1 mm below the gingival margin with 30-gauze lancet needles. In the HA with MN group, the selected sites of the gingiva will injected with cross-linked HA using a 30-gauge microneedle followed by microneedling. This described procedure will be repeated in both groups three times with intervals of 10 days. The GT, KTW, and periodontal indices: gingival index (GI), bleeding on probing (BOP), and probing depth (PD) will be measured at baseline, 1 month, 6 months and 9 months. To measure gingival thickness (GT) from the apical 1.5 mm of the gingival margin, a No:15 endodontic spreader with a 3-mm-diameter silicone disc will be placed in the centre and will be measured on Vernier caliper, and the distance will be measured from the deepest point of gingival recession on the gingival margin to the crestal interproximal line (KTW) with respect to the midpoint of tooth. A periodontal probe (PCP, Hu-Friedy, Chicago, IL-USA) will be used to measure the PD and it will be recorded from the gingival margin to the deepest point of the sulcus and Bleeding on probing assessed at different time points.

Colon cancer surgery leads to the loss of organs and increased metabolic demand that can trigger a catabolic state, altering adipose tissue function and negatively impacting the body's endocrine system. Previous studies showed that this catabolic condition is associated with the risk of surgical site infection (SSI), anastomotic leakage (AL), and length of stay (LOS). Recent research has demonstrated that surgical site infection and AL are associated with a different distribution of gut microbiota in the inflammatory infiltrate. Oral Impact is an immune-nutrient composition that has been hypothesized to reduce the risk of AL in patients undergoing colorectal surgery by modulating the gut microbiome and altering the metabolic profile of adipose tissue. The main aim of the proposed research is to investigate whether pre-postoperative oral immunonutrition with Impact could lower the incidence of SSI, AL, and LOS and change the tissue distribution of gut microbiota and the adipose tissue function in terms of adipo-dermal markers of inflammation, fibrosis in the tissue, and fat mass in the abdomen. The secondary aim includes the construction of a predictive model for clinical and nutritional variables influencing complications and the assessment of the correlation between the changes in the gut microbiota and the impact on surgical and nutritional outcomes in colorectal surgery for neoplasm.
This is a prospective randomized controlled clinical trial (RCT) with a parallel assignment. 200 patients are randomized to receive Impact or a placebo for 10 days prior to colorectal resection surgery. The surgical approach for resection will remain unchanged. The primary endpoints are the incidence of SSI and AL at 30 days and the length of hospital LOS in days. Secondary endpoints include: the number of inflammatory cells in the subcutaneous and visceral adipose tissues at one month after surgery, the number of fibroblasts at one month after surgery, the number of adipocytes cross-sectional area, the tissue distribution and quantity of gut microbiota, the adipo-dermal inflammatory marker, and the nutritional markers of liver function.

Migraine is a neurological disease/disorder originating in the central nervous system with difficulty modulating responses to common sensory stimuli. It is characterized by being unilateral, frontotemporal, pulsatile, of moderate or severe intensity, nausea and/or vomiting, sensitivity to movement, visual, auditory, and other afferent stimuli may appear. In addition, other symptoms such as fatigue, neck stiffness, decreased concentration, mood swings and yawning may appear, and the headache may be anticipated up to 48 hours.

It has been hypothesized that the possible relationship between the eyes and the pathophysiology of migraine is due to the trigeminal-cervical complex, since if there is an alteration it would be established by a nociceptive impulse that can trigger central sensitization in the trigeminal nuclei.

Today, the quintessential treatment is pharmacological where the excessive use of medications can trigger possible side effects such as depression, anxiety, weight gain, fatigue and drowsiness, among others, causing an alteration in the patient's quality of life more than of the migraine attack.

Several studies show that there are other non-pharmacological treatment options such as manual physiotherapy and therapeutic exercise for migraines, and that it is effective for reducing the intensity and frequency of attacks, the use of medication and improving the quality of life.

Being preventive treatments in order to avoid the frequency and intensity of these attacks.

At present, the role of oculomotricity in headache, although it may be promising, has not been extensively studied. In the literature that the investigators have reviewed, the investigators have found very few studies that investigate manual therapy directly on the eyeball, despite the great relationship of the trigeminal-vascular nerve with migraines and how it influences the different variables.

The main objective of the present study is to investigate the impact and possible additional benefits of adding an oculomotor treatment to a manual therapy protocol of the cervical region in patients with migraine.

Morbidity, mortality, health care cost and loss of patient autonomy for older persons when they are hospitalized are linked to several factors, including the use of drugs. Therefore, the French Agency for Health Safety (HAS) advocates the use of clinical decision support (CDSS) to enhance this population's management.
In particular, the HAS reports a need to provide pharmacists with a CDSS adapted to the hospital environment, able to identify in a preventive way (when a drug is still prescribed) one or other adverse drug reaction like acute renal failure (ARF) or hyperkalemia in older hospitalized patients.

The investigators aim to investigate whether an adapted CDSS that combines CDSS alerts and a dedicated action protocol, applied to older hospitalized patients, would reduce the prevalence of these adverse drug reactions. The investigators intend to study this intervention in 18 hospitals, in order to identify possible factors that explain success or failure of the intervention. An epidemiologist and a pharmaco-economist specialized in CDSS and adverse drug events will join this research program.

First, investigators aim to evaluate how the use of the CDSS alerts with the patient note record of adverse drug reactions (ADRs) influences the rate of adverse drug reactions occurring after hospital admission in older patients.
Second, investigators aim to test the impact of a structured pharmaceutical care intervention including the use of the CDSS alerts on the management of these two adverse drug reactions. In order to achieve the objective, investigators will use a randomized controlled trial design and a stepped-wedge cluster sampling design. A total of 72 hospitals in France will be recruited according to a stepped-wedge design, allowing each recruited hospital to move to the intervention group.
The outcome will be the rate of occurrence of ARF or hyperkalemia in older hospitalized patients.
In order to evaluate the effectiveness of the CDSS alerts, investigators will use a computerized alert generator in the patient record system, which will be operational in approximately one-third of French hospitals. This system has been implemented in the investigators' hospital, and it is already operational. This tool will use a standardized and consistent pharmacist alert generator, with the opportunity for the hospital team to decide the time to receive a new alert.
To reach the goal of increasing the number of ARF or hyperkalemia cases found thanks to alerts generated during the hospitalization, investigators will train all the pharmacists of the participating hospitals on how to generate alerts and also on the specific work organization to ensure the pharmacist's alert management role.
To evaluate the impact on the management of ARF or hyperkalemia after entry into the hospital, investigators will create an alert management system which includes a structured decision-path with a standardized clinical pharmacist's feedback letter given to the physician.
Qualitative system engineering methods will allow investigators to study the impact of the intervention on pharmaceutical care management processes, work environment and professional interactions. Qualitative analysis will be led by a sociologist, and it will aim to highlight the difficulties and opportunities that exist to change these processes.
The cost-effectiveness of the intervention will be evaluated at the end of the study based on health care costs for treating an adverse drug reaction and cost related to alerts generation and management.

The purpose of this trial is to characterize the bacterial translocation in the mesentery of Crohn's patients after a surgical treatment, and to analyze the association between the genetic polymorphism of the innate immunity receptors and the bacterial microbiome. It is an observational study in which two groups of participants who require an ileocecal resection will be included; one with Crohn (group CD) and another without it (control group). DNA will be extracted from the mesentery, ileal tissue and blood in both groups to characterize the bacterial translocation and analyze genes polymorphism related to innate immunity, by Next Generation Sequencing (NGS). We aim to analyze the relationship between these genetic variants and the bacterial microbiome profile in both groups. The main objective is to determine differences in the proportion and abundance of bacterial taxa (defined as total percentage of bacterial DNA sequences) and differences in the function of the bacterial profile (defined as metagenome function analysis) in the mesentery and ileal tissue of CD patients with and without early post-operative disease recurrence. The secondary objective is to identify DNA polymorphisms in innate immunity genes in the blood of CD patients that are related to the profile of the gut bacterial microbiota..

This research registry aims to collect clinical and genetic data on pituitary tumours. Such data can contribute to better understanding of the aggressiveness of these tumours and to improve therapy. The data collected includes clinical data and genetic data to predict the treatment response of tumours.

Inclusion criteria for the registry include patients who have been diagnosed with pituitary tumours, either sporadic or associated with an inherited cancer syndrome. However, patients with non-pituitary tumours, pituitary tumours not associated with RCP and patients under guardianship, curatorship or trusteeship are systematically excluded.

Upon admission to the registry, each patient will benefit from a biological collection of blood and urine. The first visit by a participating endocrine institution is part of the national HYPOcare RCP. The second visit may be carried out according to the needs of the institution and the patient, and will include clinical examination and imaging studies.

Background: 
Preoperative short-course radiation (SCRT) is a simple and safe treatment strategy, which has achieved good oncological outcomes in patients with unresectable locally advanced rectal adenocarcinoma. However, it has no significant effect on the survival rate of patients with MSS type of rectal cancer. Therefore, combined with other drugs such as chemotherapy, targeted therapy or immunotherapy to improve the therapeutic effect is of great significance for patients with MSS-type locally advanced rectal cancer. It is confirmed that PD-L1 monoclonal antibody is expected to play a certain role in adjuvant treatment of colon cancer. But the combined effect for rectal cancer at different stages is still unclear. 
Objectives: 
The purpose of the PRECAM-R study is to evaluate whether the short-course radiotherapy of rectal cancer combined with Envafolimab plus CAPEOX regimen can improve the pCR rate of mid-low rectal cancer patients and compare the long-term survival and surgical safety with the traditional short-course radiotherapy of rectal cancer combined with TME surgery. 
Study population: 
A total of 108 patients with MSS-type advanced middle-low rectal cancer will be enrolled in this clinical trial. 
Intervention/Treatment: 
Patients in Group A and Group B will receive SCRT (25Gy/5F) and TME surgery after neoadjuvant chemotherapy combined with oxaliplatin and capecitabine, respectively. Group A will receive 125mg Envafolimab (ivgtt) 1 week (QW) once a week 4 weeks after the completion of short-course radiation, at the same time, 1000mg capecitabine will be orally daily (d1-14) three weeks after the completion of short-course radiation; Group B will receive the same chemotherapy.

Background: White kidney bean (Phaseolus Vulgaris) is rich in amylase inhibitors which can inhibit starch-digesting enzymes and delay gastric emptying in the gastrointestinal tract. It acts in multiple ways to reduce nutrient absorption, promote satiety, and lower postprandial blood glucose.
Objective: This study attempted to investigate both acute and long-term effects of white kidney bean amylase inhibitors on serum glucose and insulin level.
Methods: Eighteen healthy, male participants (25-45 years), were randomized to one of four diet periods: placebo; oral placebo; oral Phase 1 (day 1) + oral placebo (day 4); and oral Phase 2 (day 4) + oral placebo (day 8). Each period was separated by a 72-hour washout.
Results: Blood glucose levels after glucose loading were significantly reduced by the oral administration of white kidney bean amylase inhibitors. Glucose peak time in Phase 1 was 51 min compared to 169 min in Phase 2 (p<0.05). The oral administration of white kidney bean extracts also reduced glucose absorption (phase 1: p<0.05; phase 2: p<0.01 vs placebo) and improved insulin sensitivity (phase 1: 37.2 ± 10.8 vs 74.4 ± 30.7 p<0.05; phase 2: 29.8 ± 7.3 vs 50.0 ± 10.1 p<0.01 vs placebo). Plasma insulin levels immediately post-meal ingestion and at 120 min were statistically lower when consuming white kidney bean amylase inhibitors. This study also suggested that white kidney bean amylase inhibitor supplementation improves glycemic and insulinemic responses in health individuals. Conclusion: This study shows that white kidney bean amylase inhibitors modulate plasma glucose and insulin levels acutely and the improvement may become greater after repeated oral administration.

Depressive disorders are highly prevalent in primary care and are associated with substantial burden, not only in terms of symptoms but also in terms of healthcare costs and disability. Treatment is still largely inaccessible to the population, due both to a shortage of specialised mental health service centres and to high costs for individuals at risk. This is exacerbated in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) due to the limited availability of trained professionals in this field. Despite advances in treatment (e.g., evidence-based interventions including Cognitive Behavioural Therapy), the majority of individuals living with depression and experiencing symptoms do not receive any treatment at all. Psychological therapies are highly effective for depression. However, it will take a very long time to increase the number of trained specialist mental health workers needed to address the large burden of depression. There is an urgent need for cost-effective and scalable behavioural interventions that do not require any special qualifications in mental health, and can reduce the treatment gap for patients with depression.

The key objective of this study is to understand how an integrated delivery platform can facilitate the provision of a scalable and sustainable model for delivering evidence-based treatment, specifically the Healthy Activity Program (HAP), to individuals with depression in rural, underserved, areas in India. The effectiveness and costs of two different models of delivering HAP, namely facility and community, and the interaction between these two models will be compared.

The HAP has been shown to be effective across multiple randomised trials conducted in different parts of the world. It is also culturally applicable to populations in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) like India and has been shown to be acceptable and effective when conducted by local healthcare workers. These healthcare workers, called counsellors, are already an integral part of the existing primary healthcare system in India. However, the HAP has yet to be tested in a community setting and in a model that combines facility and community-based delivery. The current study, if successful, will provide a platform for scaling up the reach and effectiveness of treatment for depression at a local level in India.
Our goals are to demonstrate how a scalable and sustainable treatment delivery platform can be developed and implemented using existing primary healthcare resources, in a way that is acceptable and accessible to poor rural communities.

The primary objective of this study is to identify acute and chronic effects of BFR protocols combined with low-intensity resistance training on lower-body's blood-flow restriction and dynamic muscle strength endurance, strength and muscle size, as well as the systemic response in terms of catecholamine and inflammatory responses in normoxia and hypoxia conditions. The secondary objective of the study is the identification of physiological and psychological responses to BFR protocols combined with low-intensity resistance training in normoxia and hypoxia conditions. The investigators also aim to compare the effects of different training protocols (low-intensity resistance training, high-intensity resistance training, BFR exercise in normoxia and hypoxia conditions) combined with blood-flow restriction, at different altitude, to see how these are influenced by the conditions, including the comparison to placebo (normoxia and hypoxia without combined with BFR). It is hypothesized that BFR exercise with resistance exercise for low-intensity effort for a prolonged period of time will have similar benefits of traditional high-intensity effort for short duration training sessions.

Rationale: Standard first line treatment for patients with follicular lymphoma and symptomatic disease is immunotherapy with or without chemotherapy. The most commonly used treatment regimens are rituximab plus bendamustin or CHOP (cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine and prednisolone), rituximab plus lenalidomide or rituximab monotherapy. The long-term outcome is similar for these regimens; 75-80% of patients are alive 10 years after initial treatment. A subgroup of 20-40% of patients does not respond to or relapse within 24 months of initial treatment (abbreviated POD24 for progression of disease within 24 months), and they risk poorer effect of second line treatments and shorter survival. Only 30-70% of these patients are alive 5 years after initial treatment, depending on the type of first line treatment, and they are in need of improved treatment options. Mosunetuzumab is a new, bispecific, T-cell engaging antibody that has shown very high response rates and long response duration in B-cell lymphoma patients with multiple relapses or lack of response to standard salvage regimens. It is therefore possible that mosunetuzumab will benefit patients with POD24. The main hypothesis of this trial is that mosunetuzumab is better than standard 2nd line salvage regimens in terms of progression free survival 2 years after the initiation of 2nd line treatment in POD24 patients. Objectives: The main objective is to investigate the efficacy of subcutaneous (SC) mosunetuzumab monotherapy in follicular lymphoma (FL) with POD24. The secondary objectives are to investigate safety of mosunetuzumab in patients with a current POD24 event prognostic significance of 18F-FDG-PET-CT response to mosunetuzumab rate of transformation to higher grade lymphoma following mosunetuzumab patients´ self-reported quality of life during and after mosunetuzumab resource usage related to mosunetuzumab Interventions: Mosunetuzumab is administered SC as described below. Patients are followed for at least 2,5 years and a maximum of 5 years in the trial. Study-specific sampling of peripheral blood for exploratory research amounts to 330-380 mL (depending on the number of treatment cycles) collected over 3 years. Study-specific tumor samples for future research will be collected by fine needle aspiration before the start of treatment and after the third treatment cycle. Ethical considerations: Previous studies have shown that mosunetuzumab is highly effective and well tolerated in heavily treated B-cell lymphoma patients. The safety profile is favourable compared to standard immunochemotherapy. Mosunetuzumab can be safely administered to older patients with co-morbidities, and there is no upper age limit for participation in the trial. The potential beneficial effect of mosunetuzumab in a population of follicular lymphoma patients with POD24 outweighs the risk for rare and undiscovered serious adverse events. The total volume of blood samples is considered acceptable for patients in clinical trials. The extra tumor samples for research purposes will only be collected if deemed safe and not to cause unreasonable discomfort for the participating subject. The extra number of CT scans is 2-3 compared to standard practice and represents a minimal increase in radiation exposure. In total, the benefit to risk balance is deemed positive for this trial.

Musculoskeletal health of adult haematological cancer survivors is poorly understood.  This is particularly important given the ageing UK population and increasing prevalence of lymphoma and leukaemia. This study will address this gap in the literature by gathering data on haematological cancer survivors musculoskeletal health and their experience of musculoskeletal health, care and information provision. The main aims are:
1.  To describe the prevalence of musculoskeletal conditions and musculoskeletal related symptoms experienced by adult lymphoma and leukaemia survivors.
2.  To describe how musculoskeletal health of adult lymphoma and leukaemia survivors changes over time after completing treatment for cancer.
3.  To describe experience of lymphoma and leukaemia survivors on musculoskeletal health, musculoskeletal related care and musculoskeletal health information provision.
4.  To describe the likely risk factors that may be associated with musculoskeletal consequences of adult lymphoma and leukaemia survivors.
5.  To assess likely risks associated with fractures of hip and other major sites in adult lymphoma and leukaemia survivors.
The results of this study will inform development of appropriate support services for haematological cancer survivors.  This in turn will contribute to patients improved long term outcomes and quality of life.

Post-Intensive Care Unit (PICU) Survivors often experience post-intensive care syndrome (PICS), an umbrella term for adverse health conditions that can last months to years, following critical illness. An estimated 100,000 people are admitted to each of the 25 million ICU beds yearly, worldwide. As one of the leading drivers for aging, 5.1 million U.S. adults over 75 years of age are licensed to drive without the need for vision or hearing screenings. The investigators hypothesize that in-vehicle driving assessment and monitoring is a feasible and acceptable approach to assess and address ICU survivor driving safety. The investigators seek to implement novel in-vehicle cloud-data collection technology developed by the investigators' team. The investigators propose to pair neurocognitive assessments with in-vehicle kinematic driving data to conduct essential formative work to develop data-based insights into driving behaviors of older adults with ICU-acquired cognitive declines. The investigators aims to determine protocol feasibility and acceptability of neurocognitive assessments and in-vehicle sensor deployment (Aim 1). The investigators will enroll a cohort of older ICU survivors (n=24) with risk factors for ICU-acquired cognitive impairment to complete neurocognitive measures and participate in driving data collection via in-vehicle sensors over a 6-month post-hospital discharge period. Next, the investigators will evaluate the relationship between neurocognitive assessments and driving behavior and safety in older ICU survivors (Aim 2). Lastly, the investigators will conduct stakeholder advisory panels on the priorities and data presentation needs of driving assessments for older ICU survivors (Aim 3). The stakeholder advisory panel insights will provide scientific justification and protocol feasibility to evaluate recruitment, acceptability and attrition for future full-scale implementation.

Background and Significance: Obesity is a risk factor for mortality and many other chronic and life-limiting health conditions. Psychological interventions that increase self-regulation strategies to approach healthy eating and physical activity show promise for treatment and prevention. This proposal outlines the design for a brief, 4-hour workshop to increase self-regulation strategies related to healthy weight behaviors. Methods: The main objective of this study is to pilot test the development and implementation of an empirically-based workshop for promoting healthy weight behaviors. 70 women (age 40-65; BMI >30 kg/m2) will be randomly assigned to an 8-week weight management workshop that will teach self-regulation skills in the form of an Acceptance and Commitment Therapy-based workshop. Study data will be collected at baseline, 1-week, 1-month (workshop completion) and 2-month post-intervention. Participants will complete surveys assessing dietary habits, physical activity behaviors, body weight, psychological flexibility, weight self-stigma, body image, and emotional eating. Results: Findings will help refine the workshop and will inform an RCT to test efficacy.

GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the gastrointestinal tract. The guidelines recommend that patients at high risk of recurrence should be treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI) such as imatinib for at least 3 years after surgery. Recent studies have reported that some GIST patients who have achieved disease control through long-term use of imatinib can still achieve a long progression-free survival after drug withdrawal, and those who relapse after drug withdrawal can still achieve disease control after re-use of imatinib. These findings suggest that for some selected patients, a treatment mode of drug holiday could be possible. This model, also known as intermittent therapy or on-off therapy, will be observed to observe whether the drug holiday or temporary withdrawal of drug can meet the goal of tumor clearance while reducing the drug's side effects for the patient and improving his or her quality of life. This mode of treatment can only be realized based on MRD detection. Therefore, this one-arm prospective observational clinical study will assist some high-risk GIST patients who have been treated with imatinib for 3 years after surgery and have achieved disease control to adopt the treatment mode of drug holiday based on MRD detection. This study is designed to assist patients to withdraw the oral use of imatinib within 3 years after operation, monitor MRD status and guide drug re-use according to MRD conversion at an early stage, and at the same time observe the occurrence of drug-resistant mutations.

This study is designed to compare the effects of Dohsa Hou therapy with standard treatment protocol on functional mobility in children with Down syndrome. Children with Down syndrome meeting the predetermined inclusion and exclusion criteria will be divided into two groups using a simple random sampling technique. The intervention in both groups consists of three sessions per week for a total of 18 sessions. The active comparator group will receive standard treatment, including soft tissue massage therapy, bicycle training, and aerobic exercises. The experimental group will receive Dohsa hou therapy. Both interventions are administered for an hour during each therapy session. Both TISS and TUG tests will be performed at baseline, 3 weeks and 6th week of follow-up. The primary study objectives for this report are to examine the effects of Dohsa hou therapy on functional mobility before and after the therapy in children with Down syndrome. The results of this study will provide evidence about the efficacy of Dohsa hou therapy in the enhancement of functional mobility in children with Down syndrome.

The purpose of this study is to develop and implement the Rising New York Road Runners (RNYRR) program in under-resourced schools with the goal of increasing children's physical activity (PA), physical literacy (PL), and overall health and well-being. The investigators will recruit 400 3rd through 5th-grade students from 3 elementary schools, assess them on various measures of physical activity and PL, and then randomize 20 schools to either the intervention or the control condition. The intervention will utilize a holistic approach of family engagement to increase children's PA and PL during and after school with the goal of promoting a physically active lifestyle. The control group will receive standard school operating procedures. This study will be the first to test this intervention with 8-10 year old low-income children.

Children with medical complexity (CMC) are increasingly prescribed noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NiPPV) for chronic respiratory failure. NiPPV effectively corrects abnormal gas exchange, improves sleep quality, and reduces symptoms of chronic respiratory failure. The use of NiPPV has been associated with increased survival and improved health-related quality of life (HRQOL). To ensure effectiveness, NiPPV must be used for all periods of sleep and settings must be individually-titrated. Unfortunately, poor adherence results in many CMC being undertreated for chronic respiratory failure. Successful NiPPV initiation is critical because early negative experiences are commonly reported barriers to adherence and early usage predicts longer term use. Standard of care is the initiation and titration of NiPPV during a one-night in-hospital PSG. A PSG is challenging for CMC and families due to their medical fragility and lasting effects of travel and a disrupted routine, the significant amount of equipment and supplies that must be brought to the study as well as the financial implications and additional psychosocial stress for caregivers. Furthermore, negative experiences with NiPPV may be exacerbated by introduction of the therapy in an unfamiliar PSG laboratory with burdensome monitoring. Recent technological advances in remote NiPPV monitoring coupled with a shift to virtual care models has enabled a patient and family centered opportunity to bypass the PSG laboratory and initiate NiPPV at home. Remote NiPPV monitoring extends data collection beyond discrete health care encounters and provides real-time data on adherence and efficacy that can be wirelessly transmitted to facilitate setting adjustment by clinicians. Home NiPPV initiation is increasingly being requested by patients and caregivers. The potential benefits of this innovative care model include increasing patient and family empowerment, improving the delivery of high quality patient-centred care at home, and optimizing NiPPV use. Although there is growing data in the adult population to support home NiPPV initiation via telemonitoring, this cannot be simply extrapolated to CMC. There are key differences in the etiology and manifestation of chronic respiratory failure in CMC compared to adults. Furthermore, family caregivers play an important role in NiPPV acceptance and adherence. Canadian guidelines acknowledge the lack of evidence for the setting in which NiPPV is initiated. Home NiPPV initiation in CMC is a novel model of care that may result in large health system impacts, but requires a feasibility study before embarking on a large-scale trial. This proposal will evaluate the feasibility and safety of an innovative model of care for NiPPV initiation in the home environment utilizing remote telemonitoring compared to usual care which is in-hospital polysomnography (PSG) laboratory-based initiation. The study will be a single-blind, randomized clinical trial. A total of 24 volleyball athletes with latent myofascial trigger points in gastrocnemius on both sides will be recruited. Participants will be randomly assigned to two groups: the intervention group and the control group. The inclusion criteria for participation in this study was being a healthy female volleyball practitioners, without lower limb injury in the last 6 months, and having latent MTPs in gastrocnemius. Exclusion criteria include experiencing needle phobia, presence of active MTPs in the lower limb, pathology that prevents the use of dry needling, and pathology that prevents the performance of vertical jump test.

Both groups will perform a standard warm-up session consisting on continuous running, dynamic lower limb stretching, and vertical jumps for 10 minutes. Then, the principal investigator will apply the dry needling technique to those allocated to the experimental group on the latent trigger points diagnosed on the selection phase. They were allocated according to the presence or absence of even numbers. Subjects in the control group will be asked to wait on the intervention couch for a similar time the ones who received the treatment. The intervention group, along with the control group, will perform three countermovement jumps (CMJ) in each of the study points. CMJ-style jumps will be recorded with an iPhone 15 high-speed camera app.

The primary outcome measure was the counter movement jump (CMJ), which will be measured immediately after the needling technique (T1), 72 h after (T3), and 7 days after the intervention (T4). The difference in flight times between pre and post dry needling and pre and post control was computed for both groups and statistical differences were analyzed using a two-tailed independent t-test. We expect to find an increase in CMJ flight time in the intervention group compared to the control group after dry needling.

The purpose of the ETMS for Stress Project is to conduct a 10-week clinical research trial investigating the safety and efficacy of combining a novel, EEG-guided device called Neuromodulation (NMD) with standard behavior and medication treatments for Chronic Trauma and Stressor Related Disorders (TSRD). 500 Veterans from the Cincinnati Veterans Affairs (VAMC), Dayton, and Cleveland VAMCs and the University of Dayton will participate in the ETMS for Stress Project. Participants will be at least 22 years old; they will have been deployed to Iraq or Afghanistan at least once (or served more than 90 days during Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom) and have a current diagnosis of PTSD, Major Depressive Disorder, Substance Use Disorder, or Chronic Pain Disorder. They may have other psychiatric disorders. To be included in the study, participants must have completed treatment with their primary therapist or psychiatrist. The study will last for 10 weeks, not including screening or follow-up. The study has 3 phases: Phase 1 - 30 days of daily eTMS as an adjunct to standard of care and integrative treatment; Phase 2 - 7 weeks of up to 3 eTMS treatments weekly for a total of up to 21 treatments; and Phase 3 - 8 weeks of a tailored taper schedule to safely reduce eTMS treatments to once weekly.
TMS is a non-invasive procedure that will be conducted at the participating VAMCs and the University of Dayton. Prior to beginning with their study TMS sessions, participants will take an electroencephalogram (EEG) to measure activity of the brain waves. A sensor net will be attached to the head - without any direct contact with the brain - to measure and analyze the brain signals. The session will last up to 45 minutes without the use of any medicinal preparation on the day of the session. Before, during, and after the sessions, participants will be asked to fill out questionnaires to measure their symptoms, assess their depression and anxiety, and record any adverse effects. They will have 6 weeks of up to 3 eTMS treatments weekly plus the 7- and 8- week tapering period during which they may have up to 1 or 2 eTMS treatments weekly. Participants will continue with their standard treatment in the outpatient setting throughout the 10-week study. The investigators will conduct a 10-week study with a 5 year follow-up.

Investigate what effect these new types of Group A Streptococcus may have on patients. The study aims to find out more about the clinical disease caused by infections of the head and neck regions with these new species of Group A Streptococcus, which are being identified for the first time in the United Kingdom.
Inclusion Criteria: Over the age of 18 Suffering with acute head and neck infection of Streptococci. Samples must come from Northampton General Hospital. Consent to participate in research with at least 24 hours of consideration.

Letters of invitation are sent out by the local Public Health Team at NHS East Midlands to potential research participants. If the person is happy to be part of the study, they are contacted by a researcher to make an appointment. If the participant is happy to participate, they will be asked to sign a consent form.
Blood samples and naso-pharyngeal swab samples (of the tissue in the region of the nose and the back of the throat) are taken from the patient and processed in the local diagnostic microbiology laboratory. These will be screened for the presence of Group A Streptococcal DNA by an automated system. They will then be tested for the presence of bacterial markers of certain characteristics of the Group A Streptococci by a specialist laboratory.
After three months of the initial samples being sent, we will write to research participants to ask if they are interested in having repeat blood tests, naso-pharyngeal swabs and throat or blood saliva samples. Any information collected will be treated as strictly confidential. All samples will be given anonymised label (like a bar code) at the stage and information will not be recorded on any documents in a way that can identify the participant. This information will be kept secure by the NHS and the University of Leicester. The participant's General Practitioner (GP) will be informed of their participation. If you need to contact the research team for any reason you will be asked to speak to a member of staff in the research team who has no involvement in the clinical care of your condition.
In some circumstances, this research may change if it appears the original proposal is not working well or is no longer helpful to the patient's treatment or understanding of the reasons for the condition. An independent group of experts will be asked for their advice and help the research team to make improvements.
The University has a legal obligation to protect personal information from unauthorised disclosure. Only NHS staff directly involved in the trial will have access to data gathered during the patient's assessment.
After the research phase is complete, samples which have not been used in the project will be securely destroyed. Any samples from the Public Health Laboratory may have to be kept for up to ten years to show compliance with Public Health England and University guidelines.
You and any other person whose details have been given as emergency contacts will be informed of the result(s) of the research when treatment has improved or when the research team believes the results will help improve their treatment.
You may choose to withdraw from the research at any time. This will not mean the end of your assessment or treatment. You may also receive newsletters relating to the study.
Please be aware that participants in this study will have to be available for up to two follow-up visits. Please also be aware that the follow up visits may need to be undertaken in a hospital other than Northampton General Hospital if this is necessary for the participant's care.

In rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and psoriatic arthritis (PsA), the selection of patients for treatment with synthetic Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drugs (c-DMARDs) and biologic therapy (b-DMARDs) is based on the following criteria:
(i) Disease duration;
(ii) Disease severity;
(iii) Age of the patient;
(iv) Prior treatment with specific anti-arthritic treatment;
(v) Comorbidities;
(vi) Concomitant drugs affecting arthritis progression (NSAIDs);
(vii) Evidence of disease inflammation (DAS/CRP/ESR).
Currently, biologic DMARDs (b-DMARDs) revolutionized the treatment of PsA and RA. b-DMARDs targeting specific pathways of the arthritic process (IL-17, TNF-alfa, IL-12/23, IL-6, IL-23) have been proved efficacious in the management of RA patients. In PsA patients, the selection of b-DMARDs remains a challenge. Indeed, the response to TNF-alfa and IL-17 inhibitors is variable and unpredictable and the risk of developing b-DMARDs-induced arthritis at 6 months of treatment varies from 8,9 to 44% depending on the treatment indication.
In PsO, the role of b-DMARDs is also controversial as well. On one hand, PsO is a chronic inflammatory disease that could be driven by some of the same inflammatory pathways targeted by b-DMARDs. On the other hand, PsO is a multifaceted disease that is characterized by the onset of psoriatic arthritis in a subset of patients (25 to 30%) and the use of b-DMARDs to treat patients with PsO might not be indicated.
There is a need, therefore, to identify the population of PsO patient at risk of developing PsA and the PsO-related biomarkers relevant for differentiation between PsO and PsA patients and the treatment response.
This study focuses on the optimization of patient selection for treatment with b-DMARDs in PsA and RA, and in predicting the treatment response in PsO patients at risk of PsA. The study is conducted in coadjunction with the clinical study EURASA. As there is no consensus on the role of biologics in PsO, the investigators hypothesize that:
(i) The use of non-invasive technology for ultrasound joint assessment could predict the risk of PsA development and treatment response in PsO patients at risk of PsA development and patients with PsA;
(ii) Psoriasis and arthritis biomarkers identified from serum, skin and synovial tissue might provide a more comprehensive tool for the monitoring of biologic response during the treatment with b-DMARDs in PsA, RA and PsO patients.
(iii) The use of new technologies for synovial tissue biopsy analysis, such as single-cell proteomic and transcriptomic studies (CITE-seq and spatial transcriptomics), might identify novel cell population and biomarker relevant for the optimization of treatment in PsA and RA.
To achieve these goals, the investigators will use non-invasive imaging (ultrasound) to predict the risk of PsA development and treatment response in PsO patients at risk of PsA development and patients with PS. PsO lesions and clinical and laboratory parameters of peripheral arthritis will be recorded and correlated to serum inflammatory markers.
To increase the understanding of the role of b-DMARDs in the management of PsA and RA and to explore new treatment protocols for PsA and RA patients, the investigators will monitor the response to bDMARDs in patients in a long-term follow-up and in patients with treatment-induced remission (with or without the withdrawal of b-DMARDs). The investigators will also conduct a pilot study on the use of b-DMARDs in PsO patients to predict the risk of PsA development and treatment response.
Finally, the investigators will analyze the synovial immune and stromal cells of PsO patients at risk of developing PsA

The use of statins to prevent metastatic diseases is an area of intense research in clinical oncology. Data from basic research suggest that high levels of LDL in the blood may promote the growth of cancer and spread of cancer that has already formed. In addition, there is increasing evidence that cholesterol-lowering statins like atorvastatin (lipitor) may have an anti-cancer effect that may prevent the spread of cancer or tumor cell invasion of other tissues. This may be an important step in developing a long-term prevention approach for patients with melanoma. Studies have been performed in laboratory animals where mice and rats were fed statins and given cancer causing chemicals that promote the growth of cancer. In these studies the use of statins prevented the spread of tumors and/or the formation of metastases to other organs. These pre-clinical studies must be confirmed by studies in humans and therefore patients enrolled in this clinical trial will receive either atorvastatin (Lipitor) or matched placebo and will have their outcomes assessed over a period of up to 5 years.
The aims of this trial are focused on several key objectives:
1. Evaluate the ability of statins to prevent the spread of cancer in patients where surgical resection removed the primary cancer and who are at a very high risk of recurrence.
2. Assess whether adjuvant high dose statins impact overall survival in this group of patients.
3. Explore the clinical utility of gene expression profiling in the management of high risk melanomas and its potential association with melanoma spread and recurrence within this specific clinical trial population.
This clinical trial will determine whether high dose atorvastatin therapy will improve recurrence-free survival in patients. Patients will be randomly assigned to a treatment arm with either atorvastatin or placebo and followed for recurrence-free survival over a 5 year period. During this time they will undergo imaging and evaluation of gene expression to see how gene expression may impact on response to treatment.
Recurrence-free survival (RFS) is an important endpoint and refers to time from surgery, in which no new local or distant cancer is detected and there is no cancer tumor related mortality assessed up through year 5. Distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS) refers to the time from the study entry to appearance of cancer in distant locations. Overall survival (OS) is defined as time from the study entry to death due to any cause. DMFS will be assessed using a stratified log-rank test. The median and survival rates at each time point will be derived from the Kaplan-Meier estimate along with their 95% confidence interval. Survival curves for the treatment and placebo groups will be compared using the Log-Rank test and hazard ratios and its 95% confidence interval will be provided. OS will also be assessed using similar methodology. The primary comparison between two treatment groups will be performed using a stratified log-rank test with a 2-sided 0.1 level of significance. Gene expression profiling will be used to develop a predictive model, which can identify high risk for distant recurrence and guide therapeutic management. The gene expression profiles will be correlated with gene pathways that promote melanoma spread and identified targets may be further validated for their impact in melanoma spread..

Hypertension during pregnancy is a leading cause of pregnancy-related death and serious maternal medical complications. Prenatal care is a critical setting for detecting and managing hypertension during pregnancy. This clinical trial will test the effectiveness of three implementation strategies designed to support 20 prenatal care clinics in providing more effective care to pregnant patients with high blood pressure. The three strategies include facilitation (guiding teams towards high-quality improvement and coaching (offering recommendations on ways to improve performance).
Through a multi-component implementation strategy, the clinics will work to deliver timely care to women with high blood pressure. If effective, the results will have significant public health implications for the millions of pregnant women and their babies who receive prenatal care annually. The intervention has the potential to improve maternal and infant health outcomes, decrease costs to the health system, and prevent avoidable maternal deaths. This pragmatic, cluster-randomized trial will build upon a previous study that developed a bundle of evidence-based practices for managing high blood pressure in pregnancy.

One in 5 US adults are age 50 and older and 7 in 50 adults age 65 years and older, which constitutes the world's oldest and most rapidly growing population. Older adults face a higher risk of alcohol-related diseases such as cancer, neurodegenerative disease, cardiovascular disease due to alcohol use. Yet, it is understudied due to social stigma and misconceptions about drinking behavior among older adults. There is an urgent call for effective assessment, prevention, and intervention for older adults to reduce health risk from alcohol and encourage healthy aging. Brief, low-burden, and low-cost digital interventions are an effective solution to overcome barriers such as stigma, access to care, and aging-specific behaviors among older adults. Text-messaging health interventions are an effective way to deliver health behavior interventions, scalable, tailored and cost-effective method of intervention delivery that can promote behavioral change. Contrary to stereotypes, older adults use mobile technology and seek online and mobile interventions, and they often engage longer compared to younger populations. This study will design and evaluate three behavioral interventions based on gain- and loss-framing to reduce hazardous drinking among older adults. This study focuses on gain- and loss-framing of behavior change goals (i.e., the positives of change and the negatives of remaining with the status quo), critical components of behavioral science, and health behavioral interventions. The investigators will design and evaluate three behavioral interventions based on loss-framing, gain-framing, and a combination of loss- and gain-framing to reduce drinking among a sample of 150 older adults with hazardous drinking. Participants will be randomized to one of the three experimental conditions: Experimental: Loss-framed text messaging control condition Experimental: Gain-framed text messaging control condition; Experimental: Combined loss- and gain-framed text messaging control condition. Participants will undergo cross-sectional online assessments before and after the intervention to track drinking behavior, and they will also complete a mobile assessment (via text message) once per week to track drinking over the course of 8 weeks. The effects of the group on drinking behavior will be compared at weeks 4, 8, and 16 months, and attrition will be closely monitored. Finally, the investigators will explore how the effects of condition are impacted by gender and age.

Background: Primary progressive aphasia is a rare clinical syndrome characterized by a progressive language deficit with impairments in listening comprehension and conversation. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a non-invasive technique capable to induce modulation of cortical activity over a specific region by magnetic fields delivered by TMS coil. Neurostimulation in PPA and its potential effects on brain circuits and behavior have not been systematically investigated. Objective: This clinical trial will assess the long-term effects of TMS combined with language training in PPA patients. A multisite study in an inpatient setting will use fMRI and behavioral tests to measure treatment outcomes at the individual and brain level in PPA patients. 
Design: 15 PPA patients will be recruited in two centers. PPA patients will be assigned into two arms, one receiving active and the other sham TMS followed by daily language training using a language and auditory game at home. Each TMS session comprises a single block (30 trains) of theta bursts delivered over the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (i.e., 30 trains of 3 pulses at 80 Hz repeated every 2s, total duration of the train is 6 seconds) and followed by language therapy. TMS and language therapy will be offered five days a week during two weeks, followed by one session per week for 6 months. FDG-PET imaging and behavioral assessment will be performed at baseline and six months.
Analysis: FDG-PET imaging will be conducted using SPM12 to compare the treatment groups on the standard uptake value ratio between baseline and 6-month scan. Changes in brain metabolism will be also related to clinical and behavioral measures.

Malnutrition affects 30% of all hospitalizations, producing important consequences in terms of increased morbidity, prolonged stay in the hospital, treatment costs and mortality. The diagnosis of malnutrition is currently based on the loss of lean body mass (LBM) in 5% or more of the total baseline, or a body mass index less than 20 Kg/m2, measured with bioelectrical impedance analysis. The current diagnostic criteria, based on the loss of muscle mass, do not focus on the factors that cause muscle mass loss. Inflammation is one of the leading causes of muscle mass loss, especially in chronic diseases, affecting up to 70% of patients with malnutrition. Inflammation causes muscle wasting and a decrease in muscle strength in the absence of food restriction, with consequences on functional status and quality of life. This study aims to identify, in patients with malnutrition and chronic inflammation, whether an oral nutritional supplement with anti-inflammatory effect (rich in omega-3 and olive oil polyphenols) and a programme of physical exercise with the intention of decreasing inflammation and muscle mass loss. Secondary objective: To compare the clinical results (albumin, glucose, total cholesterol, total proteins, C-reactive protein, lymphocyte count, platelet count, neutrophil count, glycosylated hemoglobin and creatinine clearance), nutritional status (total energy and macronutrient intake) and quality of life assessed with SF-36 questionnaires in patients in the two groups, at baseline, 1st, 2nd and 3rd month of follow-up. It is suspected that patients included in the study group, will have an improvement in these parameters. Third objective: To identify the main variables of metabolism in relation to dietary habits, nutritional status, functional capacity, clinical status and quality of life. It is hypothesized that the study group may show an improvement in these variables compared to the control group, due to the change in diet to an anti-inflammatory profile and the nutritional rehabilitation promoted. Fourth objective: To compare the weight change, muscle mass and fat mass, as evaluated with bioelectrical impedance at the beginning and end of the study (3 months) in the study group, with the aim of evaluating the feasibility and efficacy of a physical exercise program based on functional activities. It is suspected that patients in the study group will show more weight loss due to an increase in muscle mass and fat mass, without loss of LBM, and a better quality of life compared to the control group. Fifth objective: Describe the nutritional habits, body composition, weight change, physical activity, functional capacity, muscle strength, inflammation status and quality of life in the patients who voluntarily participate in the study, through a two-day dietary survey, bioelectrical impedance analysis and questionnaires used in clinical practice.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether the prolongation of evaporation time of the solvent of two universal adhesives increases its longevity. This will be evaluated by the retention of restorations of Non-Carious Cervical Lesions (NCCL). This is a randomized prospective controlled clinical trial, with double-blind masking of participants, in which participants will be divided into a control group and an experimental group. Both groups will receive two different universal adhesives with different evaporation times of solvents, which will be clinically applied in one surface of a dental lesion located in the cervical part (NCCL). All will receive the same type of resin restorations and be light-cured in the selective enamel etching strategy. The primary end-point will be the number of participants whose restorations have been removed due to fracture during a maximum period of 24 months. Also, secondary end-points will assess retention, marginal adaptation and marginal staining. Statistical analysis will use the chi-square test of independence, to verify changes in retention, marginal adaptation, and marginal staining during the study. The analysis will have 95% confidence, and the significance level will be set up at 0.05. Both groups will be compared with the chi-square test of independence, to verify differences between each other. The sample size will be 140 (70 participants in each arm).

Pancreatic resection has drastically changed in recent years. Likewise, the treatment for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA). In most cases, pancreatic total pancreatectomy (TP) has been recommended as an initial treatment due to the tendency of early recurrence after pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD). However, WOTSA has become popular as a surgical treatment for pancreatic head cancers. Recently, more and more PDA has been performed for leftward extension of pancreatic parenchyma transaction line during Whipple. This case report shows that leftward extension of pancreatic transaction line for pancreatic head cancers is a common finding in the initial pancreatic surgery. In addition, in 2020, leftward extension of parenchyma transaction line occurs in 82.7% of patients who have undergone Whipple in our hospital. 
In that case, TP can be replaced by WOTSA. Therefore, we performed WOTSA for PDCA which abuts or involves both gastroduodenal and splenic arteries and analyzed the efficacy and safety of this technique. 
A total of 40 consecutive patients who underwent Whipple over the splenic artery (WOTSA) for PDCA were compared with 30 patients who underwent total pancreatectomy (TP) between 2008 and 2018. T1DM or severe diabetes developed in 17 WOTSA patients. However, these patients did not show severe hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia after the operation. The remnant pancreatic volume of WOTSA patients became 39% of the total and only one case had a clinically symptomatic postoperative pancreatic fistula or recurrence during the 5 years. The remnant pancreatic volume was similar to that of TP patients at 1 week after the operation. The average tumor burden in WOTSA patients was significantly greater than that in TP patients. The 5 years overall survival rate was 38.5%, which was slightly lower than that of TP patients.
TP could be replaced by WOTSA for PDA. Further studies might be necessary to evaluate the clinical outcomes.

Background: PIK3CA aberrations are common in luminal breast cancers and occur in up to 40% of patients; PI3K inhibitors are available for PIK3CA-mutated patients. The aims of this observational study are to determine the prevalence of PIK3CA mutations in patients with advanced breast cancer, and to describe the molecular characterization of this population. 
Objectives: To determine the prevalence of PIK3CA mutations at the time of advanced breast cancer diagnosis in routine care practice in France. To determine the type and duration of PIK3CA evaluations. To collect patient characteristics by line of treatment. This observational patient registry was conducted in France using medical data collected retrospectively from routine clinical practice charts between 15/01/2015 and 30/06/2020. The study is limited to patients with PIK3CA mutation status information and evaluations were performed only if available and not in case of missing information. 
Methods: All patients with PIK3CA mutation status information will be included. Vasoplegic shock affects one in every four to five patients admitted to intensive care. A rapid and effective reduction in the dose of vasoactive medications, especially catecholamines, in the management of this condition greatly reduces mortality. However, achieving it is problematic as it often requires the use erythrocyte concentrates and hydroxyethylstarch with risks of acute transfusion reaction, haemoglobinuria or acute intrarenal vasoconstrictor syndrome. Blood or plasma purification with hemofilters eliminates catecholamines but cannot remove free hemoglobin released with erythrocyte haemolysis; and vasoactive mediators that accumulate in the renal impairment often seen in this group of patients. Moreover, the risk of transmission of the prion protein increases the more frequent the use of these devices becomes an area for study. In septic shock, inflammation amplifies vasoplegia by producing vasoactive mediators (such as angiotensin II) and causes an overproduction of free hemoglobin and erythrocytes. Free hemoglobin is also toxic for the kidneys, which may further impair their filtration function. The new oXiris membrane developed by BAXTER, with its low permeability to free hemoglobin, may reduce the haemodynamic instability, the inflammatory response and the rate of renal impairment observed with the use of conventional haemodialysis membranes. The oXiris membrane was tested in a small pilot study, in septic shock patients, that suggested improvements in these three parameters. These encouraging results need to be confirmed in a larger cohort. To avoid a potential bias, the study will include patients with or without acute renal impairment. The goal is to determine the influence of oXiris -Prismaflex on the evolution of endothelial permeability, the markers associated with sepsis-induced immunosuppression and the evolution of catecholamine therapy. If the results of this study are positive, the use of the oXiris membrane in these patients could reduce the rate of acute intrarenal vasoconstrictor syndrome and reduce the risk of acute transfusion reaction caused by erythrocyte concentrates. The goal over the medium term is to make a randomized controlled interventional study at the national level, the main difficulty being the organization of this study since oXiris -Prismaflex is now used in most adult intensive care centres in acute renal impairment.
