Hysterectomy is one of the most commonly performed gynecological operations. It is carried out because of a variety of indications, such as presence of dysfunctional uterine bleeding, myoma uteri, adenomyosis and adnexal mass. Hysterectomy can be performed using abdominal, vaginal, laparoscopic or robotically methods. According to the results from a study performed in the United States, the incidence rates for hysterectomies using abdominal, vaginal and laparoscopic methods are 66%, 22% and 12%, respectively. The rate of hysterectomy performed through laparoscopic approach was 28.3% in 2001 and 46.8% in 2009 in Turkey, increasing from 26.1% to 49.9% in Europe, and from 18.6% to 29.7% in USA in 2015. There is still no consensus on which of these approaches is the optimum surgical method for hysterectomy. Abdominal hysterectomy is the most frequently performed approach, but current clinical practice mandates that, when appropriate, the surgical method should be vaginal rather than abdominal, since the former is associated with better outcomes and lower complication rates. Moreover, when vaginal hysterectomy is not feasible or not indicated, the surgical method should be laparoscopic, because total laparoscopic hysterectomy (TLH) provides a faster return to normal activity, shorter hospital stays, lower intraoperative bleeding and fewer wound infections, compared with abdominal hysterectomy. However, longer operating times and higher incidence of urinary system damage are seen in laparoscopic hysterectomies.
Cesarean section (CS) is the most commonly performed surgery on women and has increased significantly in the last 15 years. Various reasons account for the increase in CS, including an increase upon maternal request, changes in maternal demographics (e.g., increasing maternal age), changes in physician practice patterns, more conservative practice guidelines, and mounting legal pressures. Because of the gradually increasing rates of CS (CSs) over the last two decades, the number of hysterectomized patients with previous CS has increased. In a recent review article, previously performed CSs were demonstrated to be an important risk factor for lower urinary tract injuries, and the recommendation that abdominal hysterectomy might be preferable for these patients was emphasized. TLH may be technically difficult in patients with previous CSs, due to surgical adhesions, and is associated with a higher risk of perioperative complications. Mobilization of the urinary bladder off of the cervix is an important step in total laparoscopic hysterectomy, and is always performed before dealing with the uterine pedicle. If the uterus is unscarred, bladder mobilization may not be technically difficult. However, if the uterus is scarred, there can be adhesions not only between the uterus and the bladder but also to the anterior abdominal wall, which can make dissection challenging.
The investigators conduct a prospective randomized control trial in which the efficacy, operative time and the rate of intraoperative and postoperative complications between the central and the lateral dissection techniques will be compared. The investigator hypothesizes that the lateral approach may cause less bladder injury and less surgical trauma.

Asthma is a chronic lung disease. It affects over 250 million people worldwide. A minority of patients will have significant morbidity from their asthma. Despite existing guidelines for treating the condition, there are a large number of patients who continue to have poorly controlled asthma. As asthma treatment has not changed significantly in the last fifteen years, there is an urgent need to identify new treatment targets. Recent studies have shown that the human microbiome can influence immune responses to infectious and inflammatory threats and that disturbances in the microbiome can contribute to chronic inflammatory disease, including asthma. 
The goal of this research is to explore the role of the respiratory microbiome in the maintenance of asthma and its influence on treatment response in asthma patients participating in a standard care clinic. 102 patients aged 18-90 years will be recruited from the Asthma Clinic at St James Hospital, Dublin. Participants for this study will be identified from patients attending the clinic and fulfilling the European Respiratory Society Task Force definition of asthma. Patients will be assigned to different study arms - biologic naïve, or established on biologic therapy - and their asthma severity and treatment will be categorized. Participants will attend for clinic visits over a year, along with providing samples for analysis of their microbiome. The data generated will be used to evaluate the microbiome profile and its impact on disease character.  We aim to identify the microbiome signature associated with different asthma phenotypes, and to determine if this signature correlates with changes in symptom control and treatment response. In addition, we will explore the role of the microbiome in the development of asthma co-morbidities such as rhinitis, rhinosinusitis , nasal polyps and GERD. This information will be used to determine if specific changes in the microbiome have prognostic value in terms of disease progression and response to therapy, helping to improve the early detection of poor treatment outcome.  Understanding the influence of microbiome composition on disease character and response to therapy may help to identify specific microbial interventions to improve the quality of life of patients with asthma.

Inclusion Criteria: - Male cricketers aged 20-30 years

Primary Outcome Measures
-----------------
1. Bench Press Test - This test requires the athlete to push a maximally loaded barbell off their chest from a pause to a fully extended elbow position at approximately eyebrow level. The test will be measured in kilograms.
2. Leg Press Test - This test requires the athlete to complete as many leg presses as possible with no rest. The assistant weighs and records the athlete's weight. The athlete warms up for 10 minutes. The assistant loads the barbell with a weight close to the athlete's one repetition maximum load. The test will be measured in repetitions.
3. 30 Second Sit to Stand Test - Often provides a better picture of the relationship between strength and disability. The test will be measured in repetitions.

Secondary Outcome Measures
-----------------
1. Functional Movement Screen - This test assesses various aspects of mobility, flexibility, movement control & strength which can affect physical performance.

This is a descriptive pilot study of providing cancer care for multiple myeloma care at St. Luke's Hospital, a satellite site, or at the primary Siteman Cancer Center site. The main goal is to compare patient satisfaction, burden from treatment, and financial toxicity in patients who transition their care to a satellite site. We hypothesize 1) that patients who transfer care location will have equal or higher satisfaction with patient-provider relationships, report lower burden of treatment, and less financial toxicity relative to those with care located at the primary Siteman Cancer Center site; 2) that patients who transfer care location will have equal or more care provided by a specialist; and 3) that patients who transition care will not have decreased access to high tech diagnostic and treatment modalities. We aim to enroll approximately 300 patients with multiple myeloma over a total of 18 months. Data collection will occur at the time of transition decision and 2-4 months thereafter or when off study. This study will be conducted in collaboration with the Cancer Care Delivery Program, which is also a site of the Multiple Myeloma Integrated Care Consortium.

This is a prospective, randomized controlled, interventional therapy utilizing virtual reality goggles as a method of distraction. Data will be collected during and after the procedure on the type of behavior displayed and the child's response to standardized questions. Children aged 4-12 years who only require nitrous oxide to complete a painful dental procedure which necessitates anesthesia will be included in this study. These patients exhibit Frankl 2-3 behavior, requiring behavior guidance in order to complete the procedure. Frankl 1 or 4 children, those who do not need behavior guidance at all (Level of cooperation 1=patient accepts or prefers treatment; no difficulty in completing procedures, the patient's usual behavior with minimal guidance) or children with heavy behavior guidance (Level of cooperation 4=patient rejects and refuses all attempts to complete procedure or treatment; not capable of receiving treatment, and child refuses all attempts from parent to cooperate) will be excluded. Participants will be recruited in the clinic, during a new patient exam, routine hygiene or operative dentistry appointment. Following the Frankl behavior score diagnosis, an evaluation of behavior will happen during the beginning of the appointment, specifically watching for acceptance of treatment plan, openness to conversation, and any defiant behaviors or crying. The parent and child being recruited for the study will be informed of the nature of the study, the possible risks benefit and alternatives, and written consent will be obtained from the parent or legal guardian. Assent from child 7 to 12 will also be required as well. The qualifying patient will enter the operatory and be admitted into the study. Participants will be briefed on how the study will proceed, and will be randomized into a control group or treatment group. The groups will be selected at random prior to treatment in the study. Both Groups will use of Faces, Legs, Arms, Crying Consolability(FLACC) Scale, WongBaker FACES, and Houpt Behavior scales to access the pain or discomfort of subjects. Patients will rate their pain using the Wong-Baker FACES Pain Scale by indicating which face best depicts the pain they are experiencing. Each face has a corresponding number: 0 = doesn't hurt at all to 10 = hurts as much as you can imagine. Patients will be observed during injection and assessed by the operator using the Faces, Legs, Arms, Crying Consolability (FLACC) scale. Each category will be rated from 0 to 2. Zero indicating normal positions and no sign of discomfort and 2 indicating discomfort in movements or unable to console/comfort. Patients will be observed during the procedure using the Houpt Behavioral Scale. Each category is scored on the 0-2 scale which results in a total score of 0-10. Assessment of Behavioral Score: 0 = Relaxed and comfortable, 1-3 = Mild discomfort, 4-6 = Moderate pain, 7-10 = Severe discomfort/pain. Patients receiving N2O during their visit will follow the standard of care procedures. The VR goggles will be placed on the head and in front of the eyes. Patients using the goggles are automatically set to start media as soon as the wearer dons them. The patient will be reclined, and placed in an ideal setting, and the goggles will be calibrated to the patient's current view. The dental procedure will then follow. Most procedures require a local anesthetic injection, and if the patient receives this injection, participants will be graded with FLACC score during the injection. At the end of the procedure the child will be evaluated using the Wong-Baker FACES scale, the Houpt Crying and Movement Scales, and a survey will be given to the patient to be completed. Participants will participate in the study during two restorative dental appointments, however, some patients may need more than two visits. Participants who require multiple restorative treatments will only being include in the study during first two visits and no other research activities will occur after. Most appointments are projected to last a maximum of 1 hour. The limiting factor in all treatment in this study, will be the participant's willingness to participate in future appointments.

There is not enough evidence to determine how to prevent or accurately diagnose all health conditions such as malnutrition. Therefore, early detection and monitoring of different kinds of malnutrition is key to increasing understanding of causes and mechanisms that may influence disease conditions. The proposed "Science Against Malnutrition" (SAM) project includes three Work Packages (WP) that are integrated into seven Work Package Areas (WPA). WPA1 focuses on untargeted microRNA expression profile in blood samples; WPA2 focuses on plasmatic extracellular vesicles; WPA3 focuses on metagenomic analysis of faecal samples; WPA4 focuses on metabolomicanalysis of faecal samples; WPA5 focuses on untargeted microRNA expression profile in saliva samples; WPA6 focuses on salivary extracellular vesicles; and WPA7 focuses on metagenomic analysis of salivary samples. All these WPAs have been designed to provide data to validate the existence of biomarkers associated to different kinds of malnutrition. It is expected that the biomarkers will be found at the plasma and saliva level due to the passage of the excretions from the intestinal and respiratory tracts in this compartment before being eliminated. In addition, the project will consider the potential role that extracellular vesicles (EV) will have in the identification of malnutrition types and the quantitation of specific membrane proteins present in them.

Inclusion Criteria:
Caucasian ethnicity
Written informed consent
Both sexes
Age between 0 and 85 years

Stroke is a common cause of adult morbidity and mortality, responsible for up to 20% of disability. Despite recent improvements in acute stroke care, over half of stroke patients will never regain their lost function and one in five stroke patients will die of their stroke. Non-cardiac surgery is a significant trigger of stroke, but current perioperative neuromonitors are unable to detect covert stroke due to spatial limitations and susceptibility to signal contamination from extracerebral tissue. The current study investigates the feasibility of using multi-channel functional near infrared spectroscopy (a non-invasive and bedside neuromonitor) to detect specific regions of the brain at-risk of covert stroke during surgery. To this end, full-head coverage tr-fNIRS will be used to continuously monitor regional differences in cerebral oxygenation and hemodynamics in up to 200 patients undergoing shoulder surgery performed in the beach-chair position under general anesthesia. By having a better understanding of the regional differences in cerebral oxygenation and the temporal relationship between hemodynamic parameters and cerebral oxygenation, the investigators hope to: I. Predict which patients may be at risk of covert stroke, and B. Develop a predictive model based on the perioperative monitoring data to help guide clinical practice for an improvement in patient outcomes after non-cardiac surgery.

The prevalence of moderate or severe functional tricuspid regurgitation is around 19% in patients with heart failure. Despite that there are few medical therapies for functional TR and only loop diuretics are cautiously recommended for relief of congestive symptoms in patients with severe TR and signs of right ventricular failure. In patients with functional TR associated with systolic dysfunction, medical therapy for heart failure with a reduced EF may diminish functional TR by improving LV systolic function. On the other hand, other therapies including digoxin, diuretics, beta-adrenergic blockers and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists may worsen functional TR. Therefore, medical therapy for functional TR has not been well established yet. Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors induce urinary excretion of glucose and sodium by blocking the SGLT2 transporter in the proximal tubule. SGLT2 inhibitor-induced natriuresis lower cardiac preload and reduce pulmonary congestion and systemic edema. SGLT2 inhibitors also restore tubuloglomerular feedback and lower the intraglomerular pressure by vasoconstriction of the afferent arterioles and consequently reduce hyperfiltration-related renal damage. The beneficial effects of SGLT2 inhibitors on the heart and kidneys may halt the vicious cardiorenal cycle in patients with functional TR, which results in deterioration of renal function, hospitalization for heart failure and cardiovascular mortality. Accordingly, the Enavogliflozin Outcome Trial in Functional Tricuspid Regurgitation (EVENT) will test the hypothesis that, compared with placebo, therapy with the SGLT2 inhibitor enavogliflozin for 18 months would improve clinical and echocardiographic outcomes in HF patients with functional TR and preserved LVEF. A total of 700 patients will be randomized into two arms.

There exists a critical time window during which neural and muscular changes are taking place that could have a lasting impact on a person's ability to participate in activities such as walking and ultimately their functional recovery. Researchers have begun to examine this period of time around injury and the possibility that it may be a window of opportunity for improving recovery, yet no clear time frame has been delineated. This study will provide new critical time windows for investigating the possibility of intervention in this window. Specifically, this study aims to identify the critical time window for improvements in mobility, determine if the same improvements can be achieved at different time points post-injury, and determine if the intensity of the intervention will impact improvements in mobility.

Psychosis is a debilitating mental disorder which causes intense anxiety and depression, as well as often disabling symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions. The long-term prognosis for people with psychosis remains poor. People with psychosis are frequently at high risk of becoming homeless or incarcerated, and most die within 20 years of their first onset symptoms on average 10 years earlier than the general population. People at ultra high risk (UHR) of developing psychosis is the name given to young people who have not got psychosis yet but whose thoughts and behaviour indicate that they are at high risk of developing first episode psychosis (first episode of psychosis).
More than 50 scientific studies, including our own in Australia, have now shown that about 30% of young people with such a high risk status convert to psychosis within 2 years. This information has been combined into statistical models to try to predict their future chances of developing psychosis. We are confident that 30% will develop psychosis.
People at ultra high risk of psychosis do, however, have a 70% chance of not developing psychosis. These young people can be described as in clinical high risk (CHR) for psychosis but not at ultra high risk. It is very difficult to predict if this 70% group will never develop psychosis. They may take years before they do. Even when symptoms do later emerge, these people still tend to have a much better outcome than those individuals who first develop psychosis at age 30 or later.
More than 80% of Australian young people with UHR have a condition called schizophrenia. Schizophrenia is a severe and complex brain disorder that affects how you think, feel, and behave. For some people, the first symptoms of schizophrenia appear before adulthood, during the teenage years or earlier. For others, the first symptoms do not appear until the late 20s. It is the second group that are most difficult, and hence most in need of early interventions, to detect.
The long-term prognosis for people with psychosis is poor. People with psychosis are frequently at high risk of becoming homeless or incarcerated, and most die within 20 years of their first onset symptoms on average 10 years earlier than the general population. Early intervention is urgently required to develop effective interventions to prevent this.
At present, doctors know best how to predict the future of young people with UHR who are in clinical high risk (CHR) for psychosis. There are no good tests to identify the remaining 30% of young people at risk of psychosis.
The AMP SCZ program proposes that clinical and biological features in UHR (ultra high risk) subjects and early psychotic disorder (schizophrenia) patients will be characterised and related to disease progression by a multi-modal data analysis (AMP SCZ observations and assessments), data sharing, and data integration (AMP SCZ Data Management, Integration and Coordination Center [DPACC-2]), along with genomic and cell-based approaches (AMP SCZ Cohort Consortium [CC]), including:
Assessing biochemical/cellular abnormalities;
Identifying, correlating, and integrating data from multiple modalities (e.g., brain imaging, electrophysiology, and genetics)
Pursuing mechanistic and functional characterisation of biological and clinical markers;
Using data integration to develop algorithms for predicting psychosis onset and treatment response;
Improving data quality and efficiency using innovative and integrated data systems (e.g., a central data management and integration system);
Identifying potential drug targets (using omics and computational approaches); and
Exploring early interventions, drug development and repurposing, and individualised (personalised) approaches to disease treatment.
Data from multiple centers and patients from Australia, Europe, and Asia in the CHR phase will include:
Structural and functional MRI of the brain;
Psychophysiological (e.g., event-related potentials, pupillometry) measures;
Assessments of mood, anxiety levels, cognition, and symptoms of psychosis;
Computational analysis of speech and facial expression;
Cognitive testing (including neuropsychological and cognitive tests);
Assessments of sleep;
Assessments of personality;
Potential drug target identification using data collected from blood and urine samples using metabolomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, and exosome analyses.
Data from multiple centers and patients from Australia, Europe, and Asia in the psychotic phase will include:

The research findings of this pilot study will provide important information on the feasibility and acceptability of the adapted PM+ intervention in Dutch prisons. These pilot results can be used to inform the design of a larger trial. In addition, the pilot results can help identify any modifications or adjustments needed to successfully implement the intervention in Dutch prisons. The pilot results may inform decisions about the continuation of the intervention during the full clinical trial (RCT2). There are no anticipated financial implications of this study, as the RCT is being conducted as an adjunct to ongoing services and there is no additional risk to individual prisoners to their day-to-day care, nor to their freedom. If PM+ proves to be acceptable to the prison population, the findings of this study will serve to support the integration of evidence-based practices into regular mental health services for this population.

Due to a growing need to treat patients who are not eligible for cisplatin-based concurrent chemoradiotherapy, there is a need for an alternative treatment modality. The objective of this phase I study is to determine the best safe dose of xevinapant combined with carboplatin and paclitaxel when given together with a standard course of radiation therapy. The second goal of this study is to determine the response rate, progression-free survival, and overall survival. This is a phase I, non-randomized sequential assignment (escalation with safety run-in) clinical trial of xevinapant administered in combination with carboplatin/paclitaxel and concurrent radiation therapy. Safety, pharmacokinetics, and biomarker assessments will be performed following treatment with xevinapant. Subjects receiving xevinapant will be enrolled on a dose escalation regimen and will receive xevinapant daily on two days out of three with carboplatin and paclitaxel for 7 weeks, then an additional 3 three week cycles with xevinapant alone. Dosing of xevinapant will be adjusted starting from 150 mg daily on two days out of three. The study will be conducted in the United States.

Background: Depression accounts for 6 years of potential life lost per person, making it the leading cause of disability worldwide, with estimates of 2.8% of the world's adult population living with depression. The need for efficient treatments for depression is paramount, especially for those with treatment resistant depression. This condition accounts for 20-30% of cases seeking help in the healthcare sector and is often refractory to anti-depressant medication and psychotherapies. The goal of this project is to investigate whether psychological treatment, specifically Schema Therapy, can be helpful in people with treatment resistant depression. In a randomized, placebo controlled, double-blind, superiority trial, we aim to evaluate the efficacy of Schema therapy in comparison to treatment as usual.
Objectives: To evaluate the efficacy of Schema Therapy for the treatment of depression in adult patients refractory to anti-depressant medication.
Hypothesis: We expect the Schema therapy to lead to a more substantial reduction in depression symptoms than treatment as usual.
Methods: This is a randomized, placebo controlled, inferiority trial, using a parallel design to evaluate the efficacy of Schema therapy among patients with treatment resistant depression in the healthcare sector in Denmark.
Participants: We include 200 patients with persistent depression, irrespective of type of previous psychiatric treatments.
Intervention/Treatment: Schema therapy, Psychological Treatment as Usual, placebo intervention called Control as Usual, and an option to receive usual psychiatric care at home.
Main Outcome Measure: The primary outcome measure is change on the clinician-rated Hamilton-6 Rating Scale for Depression at 12 months.
Secondary Outcome Measures: The primary endpoint is assessed after 12 months with the clinician-rated Hamilton-6 Rating Scale for Depression. The effect of Schema therapy compared to treatment as usual is evaluated, controlling for age, gender and previous depression history.
Other secondary outcome measures include changes in Work and Social Adjustment - Revised (PSYCHLOPS), Mentalization - Reflection on Feelings Index Questionnaire (REFQ), Metacognitive Anger Processing scale Shor Version (MAP), Quality of life as measured by Euro-QoL-5D (EQ-5D), Health related quality of life, Self efficacy for health-related behaviors, Depression Change Expectancy Scale - pessimistic (DCES-P), Perseverative Avoidance Cognitions Questionnaire (PACQ), Depression Self-efficacy Questionnaire (DSEQ), The Depression Negotiation Scale (DNS), Personal Struggles on Negative Symptoms (PIANO), Social Support Questionnaire, Ways of Coping Index, Quality of Life in Depression Questionnaire (QLDQ), Social Recovery Questionnaire (SRSQ), Brief Symptom Inventory (BSI), Schema Mode Inventory (SMI), Interpersonal Processes in Psycho-therapy-II (IPT-II), Schema Mode Inventory-Short Form (SMI-SF), Young Schema Questionnaire-Short Form (YSQ-S3), Psychological Outcome Profile Questionnaire (PSYCHLOPS), Negative Effects Questionnaire (NEQ) 6 item (NEQ6), Short-Form 36-Item Health Status Survey Version 2.0 (SF-36 V2.0), Quality-of-Life after Chronic Disease (QoL-40), Sheehan Disability Scales - Adult Patient (SDS-IV) and Anger management in therapy scale (AMI).
Design: We use a multi-centre randomized controlled trial design with masked (double-blind) assessment of primary and secondary outcomes. The design is parallel-group assignment with a ratio of 2:1. The study is expected to last 2-3 years and includes recruitment, screening and evaluation procedures to qualify and allocate patients.
Data Analysis: We use a mixed model repeated measures (MMRM) approach to evaluate primary and secondary outcomes over time, controlling for baseline levels, age, gender, previous chronic medical illness and previous depressive treatments.
Expected results: This randomized controlled trial is the first one in the field that includes a systematic approach to the problem of treatment resistant depression and we expect that the study will confirm the efficacy of Schema therapy and demonstrate that treatment resistant depression can be effectively treated with 30-40 weeks of Schema therapy.
Conclusion: This study will be the first randomized controlled trial of Schema therapy in Denmark and the aim is to contribute to a more general knowledge and evidence based health care

The Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) has become the leading cause of death in intensive care medicine. Lung damage has become the most frequent cause of death in intensive care. The incidence of ARDS continues to increase, especially in the elderly population; it is now estimated at 100,000 cases per year in France, with a mortality rate close to 40%. ARDS can appear on several occasions during the course of a severe respiratory tract infection or a major extrapulmonary infection, after a severe trauma or surgery or as a complication for a patient admitted to an intensive care unit. ARDS is characterized by progressive respiratory failure due to a lung injury induced by a number of risk factors. It is characterized by diffuse aeration by pulmonary edema. The treatment of ARDS requires respiratory assistance using mechanical ventilation. In this context, the best clinical condition is associated with a low tidal volume, a high respiratory cycle frequency, the use of positive end-expiratory pressure and low oxygen doses. In addition to limiting ventilatory overdistension during ventilation, it seems to reduce the severity of the disease which decreases mortality and reduces the duration of mechanical ventilation. The care protocols for the use of these modalities of ventilation are numerous and their implementation in the intensive care units varies widely, with the use of large tidal volumes. This heterogeneity of practices has led to the recent publication of international recommendations. The primary endpoint is mortality and days without mechanical ventilation. It consists of the combination of mortality and days without mechanical ventilation, in order to integrate both the ultimate goal, which is the death of the patient, and the severity of ARDS, characterized by a large number of consecutive days and the duration of mechanical ventilation, which is a prognostic criterion and a risk factor for nosocomial respiratory infections and a long stay in the intensive care unit. The secondary endpoints concern various important aspects of care. It is noted that the protocol does not dictate ventilatory management, does not change or modify the management of physicians or other staff caring for ARDS patients, does not change the respiratory secretion management procedure, the use of drugs to reduce lung or systemic inflammation , or the type of ventilation.

HIV-positive adults who migrated from Haiti to the US are among the most underserved groups in the country. Only 49% of Haitian immigrants living with HIV (HILWH) have achieved viral suppression (VS), compared to 60% of US-born HIV-positive patients. Further, 45% of HILWH have never had an undetectable HIV viral load and 58% of those who are VS have stopped taking their medicine, making intervention efforts a critical need. Our primary goal is to develop a health promotion intervention, the Haitian Immigrant Engagement And Retention IN Guided Health (H-iENGAGE). This pilot health intervention is a promising approach to improve health outcomes of HILWH. The pilot will be designed to examine (a) engagement and retention in care, and (b) viral suppression (VS). Mixed methods data collection will provide insights into the perspectives of health care providers as well as the experiences of HILWH related to their engagement in care and their experience with H-iENGAGE, including identification of facilitators and barriers to engaging in care and achieving VS. If preliminary efficacy is obtained, this promising, culturally tailored H-iENGAGE intervention may serve as a model for HILWH in the US, and may help optimize the reach and effectiveness of the US government's global plan to achieve HIV epidemic control by 2030.
This protocol builds on our prior work and will be tested in a prospective quasi-experimental single arm. The goals of this pilot study are to examine HILWH engagement in care (EIC) and viral suppression (VS) during baseline to post-intervention period. Additionally, a process evaluation of the H-iENGAGE intervention and its impact on providers and HILWH post-intervention will be conducted. The proposed protocol consists of a three-armed study. In AIM 1, the pilot portion, HILWH will complete questionnaires, participate in health assessments and intervention. In the second arm, Aim 2 to 4, photovoice sessions will be held with a sample of intervention participants at 3 and 9 months follow-up. If preliminary efficacy for improving engagement in care (EIC) and viral suppression (VS) is obtained, this tailored, culturally and socially relevant health promotion intervention will serve as a model to impact HILWH health outcomes. Aim 1. Mixed methods data collection from health care providers and HILWH to examine barriers and facilitators to VS among HILWH.
This study consists primarily of HILWHs, living with HIV who attended two of the six Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs) that serve the majority of Haitians with HIV in Miami, Florida. A non-probability purposive sample selection method will be used to enroll 60 participants in the study. All new patients, HIV-positive patients who have been undiagnosed or not engaged with care at the clinics, those who are VS will be eligible for enrollment. If preliminary efficacy is achieved, the investigators will identify an additional 6 individuals who have completed the pilot intervention to participate in the photovoice portion of the study. The total time to completion for this study will be 12 months.

The Endoclean device is a novel root canal cleaning device using hydraulic inertial cavitation for effective root canal debridement and preparation. However, it is necessary to demonstrate the effectiveness and safety of using a cavitation device in routine practice. The study aims to compare the effectiveness of the Endoclean device to passive ultrasonic irrigation (PUI), which is the current gold standard, and conventional root canal preparation in the long-term.
The study will be performed using a prospective, randomized, and non-blinded, parallel-group, single-center pivotal study approach. It includes patients presenting ASA1 or ASA2 with symptomatic and/or asymptomatic apical periodontitis, who have no history of analgesic intake in the last 3 days or antibiotics in the last one month. They can present one mandibular and/or maxillary tooth with mature apical with closed apices and an intact tooth structure, which has never been treated with root canal therapy. All participants shall have full-mouth periapical radiographs and full mouth oral-hygiene status assessment with bleeding, gingivitis, and periodontal disease status evaluation and screening.
The primary effectiveness endpoints shall be successful healing of periapical lesion up to 12 months post-operatively and 24 months. Safety endpoint shall be freedom from post-operative pain up to 7 days post-operatively. Secondary effectiveness endpoints shall be successful healing of periapical lesion up to 24 months post-operatively. Safety endpoint shall be the incidence of serious and non-serious adverse events.

Fractures of the skeleton are the most common reason for Emergency Department (EDs) admission, accounting for approximately 15% of attendances. Accurate detection of bone fractures is a key task for radiologists and ED clinicians when reviewing X-rays. When the clinician is uncertain or unsure about the presence of fractures, further imaging may then be required, and referral to Orthopaedics or Trauma for assessment and management. Conversely, inaccurate detection of fractures may lead to undertreatment or failed diagnosis with subsequent adverse clinical outcomes for patients due to missed diagnosis of fractures.
Artificial intelligence (AI) has shown great potential in augmenting radiologist's interpretations of complex images. This potential has been demonstrated in an increasing number of studies across different imaging modalities such as chest radiographs and mammography. However, to date, AI's effect on diagnostic radiology is unclear, and more research is needed before AI algorithms can achieve widespread practical use.
Aims: The main objective of the study is to assess the impact of AI algorithms in augmenting the performance of radiologists' and clinicians' detection of fractures on routinely-obtained X-rays. 
Methodology: A total of 1000 skeletal radiographs depicting fractures and normal findings will be reviewed in a randomised order by all readers twice: with and without AI overlay (Figure 1). The AI algorithm to be used is the Gleamer Boneview algorithm, which predicts the probability of the presence of a bone fracture from each pixel on radiographs. 
The reading will be done remotely via the Report and Image Quality Control site (www.RAIQC.com), an online platform allowing medical imaging viewing and reporting. Participants can work from any location, but the work must be done from a computer with internet access. For avoidance of doubt, the work cannot be performed from a phone or tablet. The project is divided into two phases and participants are required to complete both phases. The estimated total involvement in the project is up to 20-24 hours. Phase 1: Time allowed: 2 weeks - Participants must review 500 X-rays and express a clinical opinion through a structured reporting template (multiple choice, no open text required). Rest/washout period - Time allowed: 4 weeks, to mitigate the effects of recall bias. Phase 2 - Time allowed: 2 weeks - Review 500 X-rays together with an AI report for each case and express their clinical opinion through the same structured reporting template used in Phase 1.<

Specific Learning Disorder (SLD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder in which the individual has difficulties in reading, written expression, and/or mathematics, according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders - 5 (DSM-V). Structural imaging studies in children with SLD have revealed that grey matter is reduced. Poor quality hand grip, fine motor skills and sensory processing, balance and postural control are shown in literature with children with SLD. The aim of this study is to examine fine motor skills, hand and finger strengths and anthropometric measurements in children with SLD compared to healthy children and to examine their relationships with hand grip strength, hand anthropometric measurements and fine motor skills.

The purpose of this study is to determine if dynamic MRI will improve the initial diagnosis of women with symptomatic pelvic endometriosis and to compare the results with those of a group of controls. It is a transversal prospective study. One hundred patients, with suspected pelvic endometriosis, will be recruited from the ENTENDOMOBILE service. One hundred patients will be chosen without pelvic endometriosis from the ENTENDOMOBILE service and the gynecological consultation group. The study is multicentre, with patients recruited from the Rennes site. Dynamic MRI will be obtained for each patient using an MRI cine sequence. MRI cine is a special MRI sequence obtained by taking up to 60 images during the scanning phase. A gynecologist expert in endometriosis diagnosis will independently score the diagnostic MRI at baseline (with 3 to 9 endometriotic lesions in each patient, in reference to the Revised American Fertility Society classification (R-AFS). The images are then scored by two other physicians trained in gynecological imaging to detect endometriotic lesions. The dynamic MRI for patients with pelvic endometriosis will be performed at baseline and at a 6-month interval, while patients who are not diagnosed with pelvic endometriosis (control group) only one dynamic MRI will be performed at inclusion. The mean vertical displacement of each pelvic organ (vaginal wall, cervix, uterosacral ligaments, utero-tubal junction) will be measured at 6-month intervals and at the first visit in the control group. It will be measured using MRI at inclusion and dynamic MRI which means that the participant will have to perform the same physical gesture, a simple thrust effort, so that the pelvic organ moves, without any external force, to make it move. The hypothesis is that endometriotic lesions will be detected on the image more frequently at the push thrust effort.

Inclusion Criteria:
patients referred for suspected pelvic endometriosis requiring pelvic MRI
Female, nulliparous
patient with signed written consent
patient with health insurance
patient willing to comply with all study procedures and duration

The purpose of the Childhood Live Attenuated Influenza Vaccination (LAIV) vaccine is to protect children against influenza A and B. It works by stimulating the immune system to make protective antibodies (raised after vaccination) that react against the flu virus. Influenza viruses are continually developing, and therefore the vaccine is reformulated every year. The study aims to assess the uptake of the influenza vaccine and to identify factors associated with the decision to vaccinate in children aged 2-<18 years. The study will utilise primary care data linked to Hospital Episode Statistics (HES) to examine the use of healthcare resources associated with influenza and its related health outcomes. The study will collect de-identified medical records from CPRD, a national research database of primary care data for 7% of the UK population, and will use these data to identify and follow up individuals who meet the eligibility criteria. The investigators will be provided with access to the anonymised data only. The results of our study will provide valuable information on vaccine hesitancy, uptake and its effect on the health care resources usage among children in England.

This is a pilot pre-post intervention trial. Our objectives are to examine the following: 
- Happiness reported by the students before and after the sessions, as well as twelve weeks later; 
- Acculturation, including the ability in speaking Chinese, interacting with local friends, and watching Chinese TV (report by students). Tang poems, a form of traditional Chinese literature, are being explored as a potential tool promoting happiness among ethnic minority students. Reciting Tang poems in Chinese-speaking setting was popular before the introduction of modern learning, and children could memorize and recite some poems like singing songs without knowing how to read and write. It is still popular today that Chinese kids learn to recite Tang poems, which may contribute to their Chinese cultural identity. The research aims to examine whether similar activities in non-Chinese families and communities may also promote happiness. Chinese children in primary schools normally start to learn Tang poems from grade 1 onward. The students aged from 6 – 9 can enjoy family learning together with parents’ support. This study will focus on the students with ages from 6 to 9 years who are able to communicate in either simple Cantonese or English. The parents will give consent for their children to participate in this study. The recruitment and randomization will be done through the community-based charity organization, Hong Kong Christian Service (HKCS) in a non-randomized way. Participants will attend three weekly sessions of Tang poem classes, each lasting for 1.5 hours, and a final session to showcase their progress in reciting the poems. Informed consent will be obtained from participants before enrollment. The study was approved by the institutional review board of the Research Centre at the Chinese University of Hong Kong (Ref. No. CRE-2020.094). This study was not sponsored or received any funding.

Suicide is the second leading cause of death among youth (aged 13-24). The incidence of suicide among adolescents ages 10-18 has increased by 63% from 2007 to 2018 in the US. Digital tools such as smartphones have the potential to address the critical barriers to screening and monitoring high-risk youth.
The goals of this clinical trial are to develop and test a comprehensive digital platform for use with adolescents and young adults at risk for suicide or at high risk for suicide attempt. The platform integrates smartphone monitoring of ecological momentary assessments (EMAs), and digital self-report assessments to support psychoeducation and skills training using Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT), a treatment with evidence supporting its successful treatment of adolescents with suicidal ideation. The smartphone app called Vira will collect passively-collected data on sleep patterns, activities of daily living (sitting, walking, running) and language patterns that provide risk signatures for increased risk for suicide attempt or relapse to suicidal behaviors, and the frequency of these activities. These patterns are indicative of psychological and behavioral states of adolescents and young adults with suicidal ideation. The smartphone app will prompt them to answer a daily question "How are you feeling today?". The information collected from the smartphone app will be combined with self-report assessments (e.g., Columbia suicide severity ratings scale, scale for suicide ideation, mood and feelings questionnaire, sleep questionnaire, and Pittsburgh sleep questionnaire) in the app to provide practitioners with daily ratings of youths' mental health and mood during their entire treatment. If the digital monitoring of a youth indicates risk for suicidal behavior or imminent relapse to suicidal ideation, a clinician will be notified via a secure email or a message within the app. The therapist will then respond by calling the patient to assess if intervention is required or a face to face or tele-psychology session is scheduled. To summarize, the digital platform allows practitioners to integrate mobile sensing data and self-report assessment data (e.g., Columbia suicide severity ratings scale, scale for suicide ideation, mood and feelings questionnaire, sleep questionnaire, and Pittsburgh sleep questionnaire) into their management of these high-risk young people.
The digital platform can detect the emotional and interpersonal states underlying suicidal ideation and suicide attempt and provides interventional support to patients and therapists alike in preventing suicidal behaviors.

Humans rely on their eyes to help them navigate through the visual environment during the day. The eyes also play a larger role than just visual perception, where the eyes use non-visual light to help entrain or reset the internal clock with its 24-hour circadian rhythms. The internal clock or circadian rhythms controls many functions in our bodies including the release of hormones that help us sleep. The process that the eye uses to extract cues from light is controlled by different types of cells in the retina called intrinsically photosensitive Retinal Ganglion Cells (ipRGC). The purpose of this study is: a) to determine if there are differences in the response of the eyes to light that is not visible depending on the sex of the person, b) to determine how people of different sex and age groups respond to non-visible light and how this response changes with age, and c) to determine how non-visible light affects different people in terms of the timing of the internal clock and the release of hormones. Participants will have light exposure in their eyes during pupillometry measurements and will also undergo circadian timing assessment by exposure to non-visible light using a light box (spectacular device).

Individuals with ADHD often suffer from dysfunctional parenting skills. This can create parent-child relationship problems, resulting in greater child behavior problems and a high risk for poor outcomes and mental health problems in childhood. This is the first parent training program for a Swedish-speaking population that adapts general parent training to children with ADHD, including dysfunctional parenting skills of both parents.
The investigators developed IPSA, a new and brief parent training program for adult ADHD. The program is based on two prior pilot studies that provided positive results.

The purpose of this trial is two-fold; to pilot the feasibility of performing RIC at home for 12 months and to pilot the outcomes assessed in RIC by showing whether RIC could prevent worsening of disability (timed 25-foot walk) at 12 months in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
The specific aims of this trial are: Aim 1: Feasibility: Successful recruitment and retention of study participants for up to 12 months RIC will be performed at home by participants on a daily basis. We plan to enroll 10 participants. If more than 4 (of 10) participants can be recruited and retain for up to 12 months, the trial will be deemed feasible. Aim 2: Primary endpoint RIC is expected to prevent disability worsening as assessed by the timed 25-foot walk, in a pilot open-label manner. Specifically, the investigators hypothesize that the rate of disability worsening (defined as a 20% increase in the timed 25-foot walk) will be < 50% in the RIC group compared to an historical control average rate of worsening of 30%. In order to rule out a treatment benefit of RIC with a probability of 80%, while using a one-tailed significance level of α = 0.05, enrolling 10 participants will be sufficient. The sample size was calculated using the MINIMUM software, which takes into account the number of stages (2) and the probability of an unexpected treatment benefit in each stage (-1 for conservative estimation).
RIC is a promising therapy for people with MS. There is no established therapy for progressive MS forms, such as Primary Progressive MS (PPMS) and Secondary Progressive MS (SPMS) and therefore the investigators consider a conservative design, with an early stopping rule, to be appropriate.
If the investigators find no effect of RIC on MS progression, the trial will be stopped to avoid further RIC treatment in all other patients. If the investigators find some effect of RIC on progression (i.e., less than the 30% disability worsening expected to occur), the trial will be continued with an additional 11 patients with a 3-fold greater recruitment duration.
RIC is a safe therapy that has been tested in people with acute ischemic stroke. RIC has shown benefits in several clinical conditions, such as cardiovascular diseases, vascular dementia, and stroke. Although the rationale for the use of RIC in autoimmune diseases such as MS is compelling, this is the first study testing the hypothesis directly in MS. RIC has potential for people with multiple sclerosis, such as PPMS and SPMS, thus it is important to test this therapy in these populations.

Alcoholic hepatitis (AH) can lead to cirrhosis and may result in the need for liver transplantation. Current treatment for severe AH is corticosteroid treatment for 28 days, with or without addition of pentoxifylline. However, approximately 50% of patients do not respond to steroids and die or undergo liver transplantation. Early prediction of treatment failure would help to select those patients who would benefit from immediate liver transplantation at day 7 after diagnostic. Despite the use of Maddrey's Discriminant Function (MDF), prediction of prognosis is still poor and therefore there is a need for additional predictive markers.

The purpose of this randomized control trial is to compare two different intervention models (functional task training group- walking on flat surfaces and ramps and functional therapy program group- goal directed training) to evaluate their effect on gross motor function, range of motion on, and balance in cerebral palsy children with hemiplagic cerebral palsy. The study will include hemiplagic cerebral palsy patients with GMFCS level (Gross Motor Function Classification System) between 1-11. Patients will be assigned randomly to the intervention model and their gross motor function, range of motion and balance will be assessed via GMFM-88 (Gross Motor Function Measure scale), Pediatric Balance Scale and goniometre. All data analysis will be done on a PC with IBM Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS) version 29 (Armonk,New York: IBM Corp., 2017). The hypothesis of the study is to compare the two interventions with respect to their effectiveness in gross motor function, range of motion and balance in children with cerebral palsy. A total of 20 participants will be included in the study for each study arm for a total of 40 participants. Both interventions will last eight weeks (a total of 24 treatment sessions) in the form of 3 days a week and 50 minutes sessions one on one session. The outcome measure will be assessed in the last session of each group. Comparison between two groups will be done with respect to the changes in Gross Motor Function Measure score, Pediatric Balance Scale and Goniometre measurement in both groups.

A retrospective observation on tetralogy of fallot (ToF) primary repair in National Cardiovascular Center Harapan Kita, which was done from January 2020 until December 2022. Blood cell and differential count must be tested no later than 14 days before the operation. The number of days of the most recent blood test, leukocyte count, percentage neutrophil, percentage and absolute lymphocyte count, thrombocyte count, derived variables such as neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), absolute lymphocyte count (ALC), and thrombocyte-lymphocyte ratio (TLR), cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB), CPB time, aortic cross-clamp (AOX) time, postoperative mortality, the rates of additional or corrective surgeries, hospital length of stay, and postoperative length of stay were studied. ToF primary repair was associated with reduced survival odds (P=0.01) for patients with higher NLR levels. However, the higher TLR levels were significantly associated with increased postoperative mortality (P=0.04) and reoperation rates (P=0.001). High ALC levels were associated with reduced postoperative mortality (P=0.01) and complications (P=0.04), shorter hospital length of stay (P=0.001), and shorter postoperative length of stay (P=0.001). ToF primary repair was the best procedure for patients with lower NLR levels and ALC levels.

How does capillary blood sampling compare to conventional blood sampling for the detection of early chronic autoimmune disease, such as type 1 diabetes?
This paper compares capillary blood sampling using capillary blood sampling devices with conventional venous blood sampling for the early detection of type 1 diabetes and describes the diagnostic characteristics of some autoantibodies for early detection of type 1 diabetes. After 2 years, 450 patients underwent both conventional and capillary blood sampling. The prevalence of positive anti-GAD and anti-islet cell (ICA) antibody results was similar with capillary and conventional blood samples, thus providing an alternative to conventional blood sampling for the detection of early chronic autoimmune disease.
Capillary blood sampling provides a faster and easier way to obtain blood samples compared to conventional blood sampling. Capillary blood sampling is a noninvasive, simple technique that involves the quick acquisition of capillary blood with the use of lancet, a device to pierce the skin and to draw the blood into a container. Blood samples are collected through capillary blood sampling devices from capillaries, small blood vessels that branch off from arteries and veins, and then transferred in tubes via a syringe. This simple technique allows a quick recovery from the site of the sample, reduces pain and reduces the risk of infection at the puncture site.
Conventional venous blood sampling, on the other hand, is associated with a higher risk of bacterial infections, bruises or bleeding, fainting, dehydration and discomfort. Thus, it's necessary the acquisition of at least 3 blood samples by venous canulation (4.5 mL each) and the separation of plasma, serum, blood cells and other blood components, and so on, which could be an additional source of pain and discomfort for the patient.
In conclusion capillary blood sampling is an effective way to detect autoantibodies and other key laboratory parameters, in addition to providing patient safety. This data support those from previous studies, and they all suggest that the availability of capillary sampling may improve the efficiency of preclinical detection for type 1 diabetes. With the development of more sophisticated tools and reagents, in the future, it will possibly be possible to use capillary blood sampling to achieve a complete clinical evaluation for patients at risk of these disorders. Mobile technology has become the most widespread technology globally and has recently become ubiquitous in most of our social interactions (Park et al., 2019). According to the Global Web Index Report, global smartphone usage has reached 64% in 2020 and adults are spending more than two and half hours on their mobile phones every day (Global Web Index, 2020). Breastfeeding is an essential infant feeding practice and has been shown to yield many positive effects for babies who are exclusively breastfed. As a result, breastfeeding promotion and initiation have been an important global health challenge in recent years. However, breastfeeding mothers' smartphone usage and the impact of this usage on breastfeeding and mother-infant interaction remains a critical unanswered area. The current study is in line with our research center's interest in the study of brain mechanisms related to addiction, risk-taking in addiction and compulsive behaviors, and we would like to focus on compulsive/addictive behavior of breastfeeding mothers towards their smartphones. Therefore, the main aim of the current study is to examine the mechanisms of brain activity, physiology and attention toward the infant while being exposed to the cues of their smartphones during breastfeeding.

Photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) is a non-invasive, energy-based drug free modality that has been widely used in the treatment of musculoskeletal conditions in the last decade. The device, LightForce Therapy®, emits light in the visible and near infrared spectrum of light which increases tissue oxygenation and stimulates repair processes which improve tissue health. The proposed study is designed as a single-blinded randomized controlled trial, to assess the efficacy of PBMT in the management of Plantar Fasciitis (PF). The study will recruit 90 participants from the active-duty military population aged 18-54, with an index episode of PF and pain >= 3 on an 11-point numeric rating scale (NRS) who are seen and/or treated in the Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation (PM&R), at Madigan Army Medical Center. Participants will also be enrolled in a concurrent interventional, observational behavioral study which will provide them with a standard care behavioral protocol including stretching and cryotherapy. Those enrolled in the observational study will be randomized to receive either active PBM treatment or placebo sham treatment for the active-duty military participants. The active treatment condition will receive active PBM treatment for 3 consecutive weeks for a total of 9 treatments, while the sham treatment condition will receive sham PBM treatment. For both conditions, the treatment sessions will take approximately 5-10 minutes to administer. The goal of this protocol is to evaluate the potential efficacy of using PBM for patients reporting symptoms of PF.

Brain networks rely on synchronisation of neuronal activity to operate properly. However, the brain is a complex organ that is not uniform. The structure of the brain varies in fine detail across the entire brain (centimeter-scale resolution) and can have many different manifestations of pathology, and these manifestations can be associated with differences in how neurons operate and interact in specific brain regions (millimeter-scale resolution) and within specific functional brain networks (micrometer-scale). Consequently, characterising the fine-scale structure and function of the brain using advanced neuroimaging techniques may bring a revolution in research on many brain disorders.
In this study, participants will be imaged using cutting-edge devices called simultaneous electroencephalography/functional magnetic resonance imaging (EEG/fMRI) at ultra-high magnetic fields (7T). We will record detailed brain activity through the use of these devices in healthy participants and in participants who suffer from essential tremor, psychosis or epilepsy. The detailed and fine-scale brain information will be used to advance our understanding of the brain, particularly in understanding the mechanisms underlying the aforementioned disorders.

The study aimed to investigate the effect of weight loss on serum hepcidin, iron status, inflammation, and oxidative stress in men and women with obesity and iron deficiency. In phase I, a cross-sectional study was conducted to compare the levels of these variables between two groups of women and men with obesity, and to correlate them with iron deficiency. In phase II, a randomized clinical trial with a dietary intervention was conducted to assess the impact of weight loss on serum hepcidin, iron status, inflammatory, and oxidative stress markers in men and women with obesity and iron deficiency. Pregnant women in need for maternal and/or fetal monitoring are hospitalized at the obstetric high care (OHC) of Máxima Medical Center (MMC). They are monitored for up to three times a day with conventional cardiotocography (CTG). In the meantime they reside at the OHC, but the status of the fetus and uterine activity (UA) is not monitored. Nemo Healthcare developed a wireless abdominal electrode patch for measuring fetal heart rate (FHR) and UA: The Nemo Fetal Monitoring System (NFMS). Previous research on non-invasive electrophysiological CTG (eCTG) has yielded promising results in monitoring FHR and UA both during pregnancy and labor. With the use of eCTG technology, safe continuous 24/7 monitoring is possible, which is not possible with conventional CTG. The investigators hypothesize that by introducing continuous antepartum eCTG monitoring perinatal and maternal outcomes will improve. The investigators aim to include 1911 pregnant women ≥18 years old with a singleton pregnancy between 23+0 and 32+0 weeks of gestation requiring hospitalization on the OHC for maternal or fetal surveillance (including 1400 historical controls). Additional objectives: The collected NFMS and demographic data will be used to develop and verify a mathematical model for the prediction of time until (preterm) birth, which may be used in clinical practice to reduce unnecessary OHC admissions and facilitate a better timing of interventions. Furthermore, data collected in this study (NFMS, accelerometric, annotated ultrasound) will be used for the development and verification of a mathematical model for the automated detection of fetal movements in NFMS data. This latter model might provide new opportunities in non-invasive monitoring of fetal health.

Severe and/or recurrent infectious diseases remain a significant burden on human health and are often accompanied by multiple morbidities, and in some cases, death. While advances in modern medicine have dramatically increased the chances of survival for young and immunocompetent patients, they are often accompanied by permanent sequelae. Infectious diseases are characterized by a particularly high heterogeneity of their etiology, their susceptibility genes, their pathophysiology and their prognostic, making it difficult to develop treatments or to follow patients in homogeneous groups. This makes it difficult for scientific research to address the problem of susceptibility of certain patients or to propose specific therapeutic strategies. Genetic predisposition can influence susceptibility to infections by modifying the response of the immune system, the pathophysiology of the disease (bacterial virulence) or the course of the disease. Our aim is to use modern genomics tools to identify chromosomal regions and mutations associated with severe and/or recurrent infectious diseases, with a focus on rare but fatal pathologies. To carry out this work, we plan to recruit a cohort of patients with rare and severe infectious diseases, whose precise diagnosis has previously been established by a multidisciplinary specialized panel of experts. In order to identify common genetic factors between different pathologies, we want to use methods of population genetics. The analysis of the genome of the index case and their relatives will indeed allow us to precisely estimate the proportion of the genome shared between patient relatives, thus identifying the genomic regions that have the most chance of carrying genetic loci. Associated with this, we plan to conduct an exome sequencing project within large families and/or multi-cases. These two approaches should identify chromosomal regions of potential interest in the study of infectious pathologies. If a mutation associated with severe and/or recurrent infectious diseases, either in the proband or in his relatives, is identified, we will seek to demonstrate its pathogenic nature in infectious diseases models or functional assays on lymphocytes from patients. In parallel, epidemiological data should allow us to identify new risk situations for each severe or recurrent infectious disease. In order to carry out a large field work as close as possible and within the deadlines of the disease, we have set up a network of expertise and patient support throughout the French territory, associated with a research platform specializing in medical genetics, cellular and molecular immunology and bioinformatics, and with a platform dedicated to molecular biology (sequencing and microarrays). This organization and the methodology of the project should allow us to characterize the genetics and epidemiology for each severe infectious disease studied and to identify candidate genes. A better understanding of the links between genotype and infectious pathologies will contribute to identifying more specific diagnostics, preventing or reducing recurrence in these pathologies, and, as a consequence, improving patient care.

In patients with rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD) who undergo primary repair with or without scleral buckle (SB), the current standard treatment in most centers is the use of a tamponading gas (gastricretin or sulfur hexafluoride [SF6]). This study is designed to evaluate whether the use of a gas tamponade influences in any way the RRD outcome with respect to recurrence and visual acuity.
Specifically, we aim to compare three approaches to treat RRD: 
a. Pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) as primary repair with or without SB (PPV/P) and SF6 as tamponading gas.
b. PPV/P and perfluoropropane (C3F8) as tamponading gas.
c. PPV/P and scleral buckle/C3F8 as tamponading gas.
Inclusion criteria
Men and Women ≥18 years old.
Subjects for whom a surgical intervention with PPV/SB with or without gas tamponade is possible.
Written informed consent.
Exclusion criteria
Proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) grade ≥C2.
Chronic RRD with duration >3 months.
Pregnancy.
Traumatic RRD or RRD secondary to intraocular surgery.
Epiretinal membrane (EM) grade ≥3.
Uncontrolled glaucoma.
Hemophilia.

Primary and secondary outcome measure:
Primary Outcome Measure: Single surgery anatomic success defined as freedom from recurrent RRD. The primary endpoint for this measure will be anatomic success at the final 1 year follow-up visit.
Secondary Outcome Measure: Pinhole visual acuity, best-corrected visual acuity, time to next operation of the fellow eye, RRD recurrence (both within the first year after treatment and subsequently within the 12-month follow-up period), severity of complications, quality of life questionnaire (with scores based on the Rand-12 questionnaire) to evaluate the functional impact of the disease and treatment.

For more information about the study, please visit the research registry web site. Once you sign up on this web-site, you will have access to more information and the full study documents.
If you are interested in participating in our study, please contact us for further details.

Background: To evaluate the differential effects of 0.25%, 0.5% and 1% ropivacaine on the onset time and duration of ultrasound-guided ankle blocks in patients having forefoot surgery for anesthesia and postoperative analgesia.
Hypothesis: The use of 1% ropivacaine for ultrasound guided ankle blocks will result in a significantly faster onset time and a longer sensory block duration, and thus analgesia, compared to the use of 0.25% and 0.5% ropivacaine in patients having forefoot surgery.
Method: A prospective, randomized, triple-blinded, parallel-group interventional study. Study participants will be randomized in triplicate to: 0.25% ropivacaine group, 0.5% ropivacaine group, and 1% ropivacaine group. In each group the nerves of the ankle will be infiltrated with a total of 15 ml of ropivacaine, 6 ml for the tibial nerve, 3 ml for the deep peroneal nerve, and 2 ml each for the superficial peroneal nerve, saphenous nerve, and sural nerve. The injections will be performed by the same physician using ultrasound guidance. After surgery, the participants will be discharged to their home with a patient controlled anesthesia (PCA) pump containing normal saline preloaded to provide analgesia for the first 24 hours after surgery. The primary outcome is the difference in the duration of the sensory blocks. The secondary outcomes are the difference in onset time of the sensory block, the postoperative pain scores and the opioid consumption.

The exercise snacking consists of an exercise bout that includes the performance of 5 movements and each movement is performed for one minute repeatedly at least 3 times a week. It aims to improve the health of participants who regularly engage in physical exercise and also aims to provide a form of low intensity physical exercise that does not require a high maintenance of effort and time investment, potentially increasing adherence to exercise compared to traditional exercise programs. The exercise snacking aims to prevent the regression of health-related outcomes from physical exercise by allowing participants to perform a brief bout of physical exercise whenever they can fit it into their schedule, with an emphasis on improving strength, balance, and physical function. The Tai-chi snacking is a modified version of Tai chi by shortening the exercise into 1-minute movements and performing it for 3 times a week.

Lumbosacral spine surgeries under GA are commonly performed. Perioperative pain following spine surgeries not only contributes to significant morbidities but also hampers early mobilization. Perioperative opioids, though relieve pain but hampers consciousness, increase PONV and delays mobilization. Caudal analgesia can be effectively given preemptively to alleviate pain and facilitate early mobilization.
Caudal epidural block places the needle through the sacral hiatus into the epidural space to deliver medications. It can be performed as ultrasound guided procedure with very high successful rates. Single shot caudal block with local anesthetic provides analgesia for 2-4 hours but this can be further prolonged by adding adjuvants like opioids, steroids, ketamine, alpha 2 agonists, adrenaline etc. Ropivacaine is a long-acting amide local anesthetic agent which is less lipophilic, less cardiac and central nervous system toxicity with similar duration of analgesia, has lesser motor blockade and facilitates earlier mobilization than bupivacaine. This study will evaluate the role of pre-emptive caudal epidural analgesia for postoperative pain relief in lumbosacral surgeries and to compare the effect of adding dexamethasone to ropivacaine with respect to quality of analgesia, duration of analgesia, hemodynamic effects and associated side effects. Caudal dexamethasone prolongs the analgesic duration of the ropivacaine. Other names: Postoperative analgesia using Caudal block. To evaluate whether addition of dexamethasone prolongs analgesic duration in caudal ropivacaine in lumbosacral surgeries compared to caudal ropivacaine alone. To determine the complications associated with caudal dexamethasone.

Pediatric injuries account for more than 300,000 deaths and 6 million injuries worldwide among children under 18 years of age. This represents a significant global child health issue, and is prevalent in Sub-Saharan Africa. The Pediatric-Killed for Injury Related Deaths (P-KIDs) study aims to reduce delays in care and improve outcomes for injured children, including deaths. The study will be implemented in Northern Tanzania - Kilimanjaro Region, which has a high burden of accidents among children under 18 years of age. In the P-KIDs study, the investigators aim to conduct research to identify the determinants of care-seeking behavior for injured children by family caregivers and to assess barriers that contribute to time to care. The study has two components. In Aim 1, the investigators will conduct formative research to inform development of the P-KIDs CARE intervention. In Aim 2, the investigators will use this formative data to develop the P-KIDs CARE intervention during a 2-day intervention development workshop with an interdisciplinary study team. The investigators will then perform a pre-implementation assessment and refinement by convening focus group discussions with healthcare providers and a community-engaged panel. This step will enable us to obtain feedback and refine the intervention. In Aim 3, the investigators will pilot the intervention in 2 study facilities in the Kilimanjaro Region. The investigators expect to enroll approximately 10 total healthcare providers across the 2 study facilities. The investigators anticipate 100 total pediatric injury patients across the 2 study facilities. The investigators will conduct post-surveys and exit interviews for healthcare providers using the intervention, assessing implementation outcomes including feasibility, healthcare provider acceptability, and fidelity. The investigators will also conduct interviews with family members of 12 patients referred to KCMC and 12 patients not referred, assessing acceptability and satisfaction with the disposition decision. The investigators anticipate recruitment of approximately 155 participants across the study facilities.
