Background: Chronic low back pain (CLBP) and stress urinary incontinence (SUI) are prevalent conditions across multiple populations, including women. To date, most studies of conservative treatment options do not consider the concomitant existence of pelvic floor and spinal disorders. Additionally, the combination of postural re-education and conventional pelvic floor physiotherapy treatment approach on musculoskeletal disorders has been rarely investigated. Therefore, an aim of the present prospective trial is to consider concomitant CLBP and SUI and to evaluate if the combination of postural re-education and pelvic floor rehabilitation should be beneficial for improvement of SUI symptoms and lumbo-pelvic pain in these patients. Methods and analysis: This study will be performed as a single-center, prospective randomized clinical trial. Sixty inactive women, aged between 18 - 75 years, with moderate to severe SUI and chronic low back pain referred to the pelvic floor physiotherapy unit of Clinic S. Giovanni Battista will be assigned to two groups: the intervention group will undergo a combination of pelvic floor and postural rehabilitation treatment; the control group will undergo only pelvic floor rehabilitation treatment. Both groups will undertake a treatment program for ten one-hour weekly sessions within two weeks. Primary outcome measures will be change in the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF) scores for frequency, severity of urinary incontinence, and impact of symptoms on quality of life; secondary outcome measures will be change in pain visual analog scale scores for pelvic floor symptoms, Modified Oxford Scale scores for muscle strength, and the Oswestry low back pain questionnaire. Statistical analyses will be conducted using multiple imputation due to multiple missing data in the primary outcome measures. Ethics and dissemination: This study was approved by the responsible ethical committee (Comitato Etico Interaziendale, Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria Policlinico of Modena, ID: 389/2019).

<|assistant|>
The administration of intravenous anesthetics in the elderly population requires adequate titration to avoid deleterious effects derived from overdosing or underdosing. Older patients show greater sensitivity to similar doses of propofol compared to younger patients. In addition, there is extensive interindividual variability among older patients, which would also explain the different responses to the same dose of drugs. This variability would be secondary to differences in comorbidities and physiological age, in contrast to chronological age, which would not explain the differences found in response to anesthetics in these patients. One way in which an attempt has been made to make the doses of anesthetics in different patients comparable is the use of models that predict what infusion rate is required to maintain a given concentration at the site of drug action. The relationship between a propofol effect site concentration (Ce) with a given effect can be represented by pharmacodynamic (PD) models. Recently, Eleveld et al. created a pharmacokinetic-pharmacodynamic (PKPD) model for the administration of intravenous propofol in a population of wide ages, including neonates to older patients. However, the pharmacodynamic parameter used in this model was the BIS index, which has been questioned for its use in older adults. In addition, the creation of this PD model only included 3 patients older than 70 years, so the underrepresentation of this age group in the construction of the model could affect its performance, making it even more difficult to correctly predict the effect in this population. Anesthetic drugs exert their desired hypnotic effect on the brain. Brain electrical activity can be monitored non-invasively by recording electrical potential on the cranial surface using electrodes. The electroencephalographic (EEG) changes observed with the administration of anesthetics are usually systematic across different patients. These have been described and have been used to identify different phases of anesthetic depth or hypnosis. In addition, the representation of the EEG signal by means of a spectrogram has facilitated the incorporation of this information into commercial EEG monitors that previously only included highly processed indices such as the BIS. Within the EEG patterns of the spectrogram described for anesthetic maintenance with propofol, the alpha (8-12 Hz) and delta (1-4 Hz) oscillations stand out. However, the power of alpha oscillations decreases with age and with other changes that are associated with age, such as decreased cognitive ability, increased comorbidities and brain vulnerability. Therefore, guiding our administration of propofol based on obtaining a pattern of alpha predominance appears to be difficult in this aged population. The general objective of this work is to build a PKPD model that uses the pharmacokinetic parameters of the Eleveld model and new pharmacodynamic parameters derived from the frontal EEG in a population older than 65 years. Our hypothesis is that the Eleveld PKPD model, modified with this new pharmacodynamic parameter, will predict better the hypnotic effect of propofol than the original Eleveld PKPD model, in adult patients older than 65 years. The creation of a PKPD model of propofol for the population over 65 years of age would allow a better titration of this drug to avoid possible deleterious effects secondary to its under or overdosage.

Introduction

Elective patients with an infected bile duct caused by common bile duct (CBD) stones, benign or malignant distal biliary obstruction or distal stent dysfunction (only stents in situ for a minimum of 30 days) will be allocated to an intervention group (antibiodic stewardship) or a comparator group (standard antibiotic therapy).
Patients with acute cholangitis (ACC) are recommended to receive appropriate antibiotic treatment (ABT) until resolution of ACC (TG18 2018). Currently the international Tokyo Guidelines 2018 (TG18) recommend 4 to 7 days of ABT after source control. The national SWAB guideline of 2020 suggests a course of one to 3 days after biliary drainage. There is no randomized study to guide for the duration of ABT for ACC.
Our recent retrospective study in the Netherlands showed that a short course of ABT seems safe and more evidence is available showing that other bacterial infections, including abdominal and bloodstream infections, can be treated with a short antibiotic course than previously assumed. Hence, the hypothesis is that a very short-course of ABT for ACC is non-inferior to a course of 4 to 7 days after adequate biliary drainage.
Methods

This study is designed as a multicenter non-inferiority randomized controlled trial. Patients will be randomly assigned to the intervention group (one day of antibiotic therapy after ERCP) or the comparator group (4 to 7 days of antibiotic therapy after ERCP).

Inclusion and exclusion criteria

Inclusion criteria are acute cholangitis (TG18 2018) due to:
- CBD stones: common bile duct stones
- Benign or malignant distal biliary obstruction and/or distal biliary stent dysfunction (only stents in situ for a minimum of 30 days)

The exclusion criteria are:
- No informed consent
- Other aetiologies of acute cholangitis
- Concomitant pancreatitis
- Concomitant cholecystitis
- Liver abscess
- An additional infectious diagnosis (e.g. other abdominal infections)
- Admission on an Intensive Care Unit (ICU) at time of randomisation
- Patients receiving maintenance antimicrobial therapy
- Patients on immunosuppressive therapy
- Patient with neutropenia (<1 x 103/µL)

Design

In this multicenter non-inferiority randomized controlled trial, patients will be randomly assigned to the intervention group or the comparator group (1:1 ratio). The first stratum is based on the hospital of treatment (15 hospitals in the Netherlands). The second stratum is based on the severity of ACC, defined by the presence of fever, chills and/or leucocytosis. In patients with ACC, we will measure fever and leucocytosis prior to randomisation. If fever and/or leucocytosis are present, it will be considered as severe ACC.
The study is designed as a non-inferiority study and the non-inferiority margin is assumed to be 10 percent (10%). The study will be statistically powered to include a total of 320 patients, with 160 patients in each arm. The primary outcome of the study is clinical cure rate, defined as absence of fever and/or shaking chills and improvement/resolution of initial presenting symptoms (including abdominal pain). This will be measured by phone contact or hospital admission (if the patient has to be re-admitted) at day 14 after ERCP. Clinical relapse within 90 days after ERCP will be defined as the (initial or subsequent) initiation of new antibiotic therapy for recurrent cholangitis or infection in the hepatic-pancreatic-biliary region and/or any other subsequent infection possibly related to the initial episode of cholangitis. Secondary outcome measures include the all-cause 90-day mortality, clinical relapse within 30 days, duration of hospital stay, rate of subsequent infections and rate of other adverse drug events. Cost effectiveness will also be studied.

Ethics and dissemination

Institutional Board approval has been obtained by each participating hospital (Zuyderland, Elker lieken/

Low-dose external beam radiotherapy (LD-EBRT) for heel spurs (HSS, plantar fasciitis) provides effective pain relief. The current standard of treatment at Masaryk Memorial Cancer Institute Brno (MMCI) involves 6 fractions of 1 Gray (Gy) administered twice weekly, resulting in a total dose of 6 Gy. While effective, this standard regimen is challenging for many patients to comply with, especially when there is no improvement in symptoms in the first week, which is very common. It also requires a significant time commitment for patients, radiotherapy staff, and physicians, and it entails a certain risk of long-term late toxicity. One-day irradiation (a single fraction) may be a more efficient method of delivering LD-EBRT for HSS. This investigation aims to test the hypothesis that single-fraction radiotherapy provides equivalent pain relief and quality of life to standard fractionated radiotherapy while being considerably less inconvenient. The primary goal of this research is to determine whether one-day irradiation (a single fraction) is non-inferior to fractionated radiotherapy over a three-month period in terms of pain relief for HSS patients. There will be a secondary comparison of different single-fractions radiotherapy.

Over a 12-month period, we will compare the effectiveness between two conservative treatments for overweight or obese people with CLBP: 1) blended rehabilitation (the combination of PNE and CTET), and 2) blended rehabilitation including weight reduction on pain, pain interference, function, weight loss, pain cognitions, body composition and energy balance-related behavior. Secondary, we will examine the economic impact and clinical effectiveness of combining lifestyle changes (diet and behavior/exercise) with physiotherapy for a total of 18 treatment sessions in people with chronic low back pain (with and without overweight/obesity) in secondary healthcare. For this purpose, we will recruit a total of 500 people, and conduct randomized controlled trial (RCT).
The primary aim of this study is to investigate the clinical effectiveness of a weight reduction program on pain reduction in overweight or obese people with chronic low back pain. There is a need for further research, as blended rehabilitation is a promising strategy for CLBP treatment, however, no studies were conducted to study this intervention in overweight or obese people. A systematic review showed that physical activity for weight loss improves pain outcomes in overweight or obese people with chronic pain. However, in the clinical setting, no studies have studied the effectiveness of an integrative intervention (physiotherapy) including weight reduction in overweight or obese people with chronic low back pain. By targeting the biopsychosocial aspects of pain complaints in combination with a weight reduction program, we expect superior outcomes after 18 weeks (i.e. in the long-term) in people suffering from chronic low back pain with and without overweight/obesity. This will be measured using a 0-10 numerical rating scale.

Secondary aims of the study include examining the clinical effectiveness of a weight reduction program in reducing pain interference, function, back/abdominal body composition (anthropometric measurements and body composition analysis), pain cognitions and energy balance-related behavior (measured using accelerometry) in overweight or obese people with chronic low back pain. We will also conduct qualitative interviews with 15 participants in each study arm to understand their experiences throughout the intervention (i.e. semi-structured interview using an interview guide). We want to provide a better understanding of the participant's experiences during the physiotherapy intervention, with and without weight reduction, including experiences with pain, fear beliefs, physical exercise, body mass/shape, and the process of change. Finally, we will examine the health economic impact of combining lifestyle changes (diet and behavior/exercise) with physiotherapy in overweight or obese people with chronic low back pain, including a cost-effectiveness analysis of the added value (in terms of health effects and cost) of the integrated intervention and the associated costs per patient.

The clinical relevance of this study is to determine whether single versus double pyloromyotomy during G-POEM improves clinical outcomes in the treatment of refractory and severe gastroparesis. G-POEM is an upcoming therapeutic modality for a growing condition without any cure. G-POEM allows direct visualization of the upper stomach, and can directly address the cause of the disease. If we can offer patients less invasive and less expensive technique for refractory and severe gastroparesis, it will have tremendous impact on the cost of care as well as patient experience. The primary measure of clinical success will define whether the treatment is improving the symptoms of the disease in the participants. It is measured by the mean values of symptoms (nausea and vomiting, post-prandial fullness, early satiety), and other sub-scales of GCSI. This measure gives us the indication of the patient clinical benefit after the procedure. GCSI is a validated score to measure symptoms of gastroparesis. The GCSI score will be measured before and after G-POEM at our institution. The second measure will be technical success rate. This measure is crucial to assess the feasibility and safety of using G-POEM for refractory and severe gastroparesis. A successful G-POEM procedure is the main determinant of patients' clinical outcome. Finally, we will monitor any clinical complications such as pneumoperitoneum, perforation, gastric bleeding or infection. Recurrence of symptoms will be recorded as well to assess the long-term sustainability of treatment benefit. This study will provide evidence-based data and allow patients to make informed decisions on their treatment options for refractory and severe gastroparesis.

The prevalence of female nutritional anemia in Hong Kong is 30%. It is reported that the main cause of iron deficiency anemia is poor dietary balance, which is not always caused by iron deficiency in most cases. Based on research, SOD (Superoxide dismutase), a natural antioxidant, can reduce oxidative stress and inhibit free radicals. If SOD increases the level of iron in the body, it may help to relieve anemia in women.
EZYdrink Minayo Yeast Drink has been formulated to meet the dietary needs of anemic women. In the ingredients, in addition to erythritol, jujube juice concentrate, and wolfberry juice concentrate, it is also rich in SOD with an iron content of 13mg.
Aim of study: Study the efficacy of EZYdrink Minayo Yeast Drink in improving iron deficiency anemia, skin condition, and Qi-blood deficiency syndrome in female population, and assess the change of serum ferritin level, hemoglobin level, and other biochemical indexes after 4 weeks of intervention.
In this single group, open-label study, female subjects aged 18-35 with hemoglobin concentration < 110g/L will consume one piece of Minayo per day for 4 consecutive weeks. The changes of biochemical indexes, hemoglobin level, serum ferritin level, and skin condition will be evaluated.

The purpose of this study is to examine the effects of acute hypoxia and single-dose transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation (tSCS) on respiratory cortical and spinal drive, upper extremity cortical and spinal drive, airway occlusion pressure, forced vital capacity, and upper extremity hand grip strength in persons with chronic spinal cord injury (CSCI).
Transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation is a simple treatment approach which has been tested in people with CSCI to enhance muscle response to neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES). The investigators predict that the combination of acute hypoxia and simultaneous spinal cord stimulation (SHSSCS) will produce greater neuromuscular response in ventilation, diaphragm function, hand grip strength, and muscle function. Hypoxia alone will enhance respiratory cortical and spinal drive, while the SHSSCS will enhance upper extremity cortical and spinal drive.
Inclusion and exclusion criteria need to be carefully considered to recruit a relatively homogenous population of chronic spinal cord-injured participants, since prior spinal cord injuries or surgeries may affect muscle function and responsiveness to electrical stimulation of the spinal cord, while certain medical conditions (e.g., uncontrolled cardiovascular disease) can affect the response to acute hypoxia or tSCS.
Primary study outcomes will assess changes in respiratory cortical and spinal drive, upper extremity cortical and spinal drive, airway occlusion pressure (P0.1), forced vital capacity, and maximum respiratory volitional force production. A total of 120 adults (aged 18 to 65 years) with chronic spinal cord injury (CSCI, >2 years; AIS C, D, or E) will be recruited. Outcomes will be measured prior to the main study treatments as well as once at the end of the study. Participants will undergo 3 different interventions (Acute Intermittent Hypoxia, transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation, sham for AIH and tSCS) in a random order, with each of the treatments followed by measurement of the corresponding outcome.

The following outcome measures will be assessed on the day of each intervention test.
a. Change in Respiratory cortical and spinal drive in minutes of intervention
b. Change in Upper extremity cortical and spinal drive in minutes of intervention
c. Change in Maximum respiratory voluntary force production in minutes of intervention
d. Change in Airway occlusion pressure (P0.1) in minutes of intervention
e. Change in Forced vital capacity in minutes of intervention
f. Change in Upper extremity functional assessment in minutes of intervention

The investigators plan to recruit 80 adult patients and randomized them in a 2x2 factorial design into one of the four groups in 1:1:1:1 ratio (20 patients per group) for one of two choices of anesthetic maintenance agents and vasopressors. This is a prospective randomized controlled study that will last one hour prior to the induction of anesthesia (time 0) and the last 3 hours (210-240) of surgery. The investigators will compare 2 types of anesthetic agents (propofol and sevoflurane) and 2 types of vasopressors (phenylephrine and ephedrine) to identify which combination is the best choice. Study participants will have the trNIRS/DCS device applied to monitor CBF and CMRO2 changes during surgery in addition to standard anesthesia monitoring devices. The investigators hypothesize that the magnitude of the effects and their associations with outcome variables will differ depending on the type of anesthetic agent, the type of vasopressor, and the interactions between the two groups.

The national cohort on imprinting disorders and their metabolic consequences (RADICO-IDMet) has several objectives. First, this cohort has to describe the clinical characteristics of each imprinting disorder (ID) for adult and pediatric patient as well as their phenotype, to describe the underlying genetic and / or cytogenetic anomalies and to study metabolic consequences of these syndromes such as obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease (CVD), metabolic syndrome. This will be done through questionnaires (medical-family and life-style questionnaire, quality of life questionnaire) and in-hospital measurements (blood test, bone test, heart and lungs ultrasound and electrocardiogram, dental X-ray, neuro-imagery).
The second step of the cohort is to follow-up patients presenting with metabolic abnormalities (MA), which includes :
- an exploration protocol focusing on MA (blood test, heart and lungs ultrasound, cardiac and respiratory functional tests, dental X-ray)
- an exploration protocol focusing on central nervous system involvement of the subjects if needed
- the exploration protocol of the metabolic phenotype (blood test, bone test, heart and lungs ultrasound and electrocardiogram, dental X-ray, CT, MRI, myocardial perfusion scan)
Third, this cohort has to follow ID patients for a period of 10 years to describe late clinical presentations of IDs, to follow up metabolic complications of IDs and to analyze the risk for the patients.

The secondary objective is to compare the radiological signs of healing by the different implants at the end of the study and the impact of the two interventions on radiological signs of healing (consolidation) and bone regeneration, quality of life and pain.
Inclusion criteria: Patient with written consent Patient ≥18 years of age with a diagnosis of humeral shaft fracture (all types in the AO classification) requiring surgical treatment with intramedullary nailing Exclusion criteria: Person not affiliated to national health insurance Patient unable to attend all study visits Patient with a pathologic fracture Patient with a post-traumatic brachial plexus injury at the time of inclusion Patient under court protection, guardianship or legal guardianship Pregnant, parturient or breastfeeding woman Patient admitted for revision surgery of a humerus fracture (insufficient healing or complication) Patient with an acute or chronic, unstable or poorly controlled disease that may interfere with the evaluation of the study objective, as determined by the investigator.
Each patient included will receive questionnaires and a CT scan within the limits of the national social security ceilings for the patient's care.

No new or additional procedure is expected for patients and the data used in this study will be those that are used for their care as part of routine care. There may be some additional costs not billed to the patient (eg, additional X-rays or use of the clinical outcome questionnaire). Information will be collected on medical records.

This is a first-person perspective story from the movie Into The Wild (2007), about a young college graduate named Christopher McCandless, who leaves his old life behind and hits the road.

This is an incredible true story, from the start, where you are transported to a college campus graduation reception, filled with proud and loving parents, as they hug their successful graduates. It is obvious that the family of the protagonist, Christopher McCandless (played by Emile Hirsch), is happy and proud of his academic achievements.

The story is about the journey of discovery that Christopher embarks on once he decides to break his ties with his successful but loveless life. The story starts with Christopher McCandless, who is a highly idealistic person; he is not satisfied with his job at a bookstore, his university education, and his family.

After graduation, Christopher leaves his family and his old life behind and heads towards the wild north. The movie makes a great start and you feel the excitement for the future of the central character. He starts packing as soon as he gets home, and you can see him trying to live a stress free life.

His first obstacle is that he has no knowledge of what to do and where to go. A helpful hitchhiking driver provides him with the inspiration he needs; he hands him a hand drawn map of the north, and that is when Christopher decides that the wild is worth exploring.

The next part of the movie takes you into a life on the road. Christopher uses the name Alex and hitchhikes along his way to Alaska. He has taken nothing but some food, books, and clothes and is determined not to take his parents money or use any kind of technology.

The movie gets you into the shoes of Christopher McCandless. He meets a lot of characters and learns a lot of things from them. The people he encounters are so true to themselves that it is obvious he is trying to find a new identity.

Into the Wild is a story of one mans discovery of his true identity. The movie's cinematography is incredible and you feel like you are inside the movie. The story tells of Christopher McCandless's life in the wilderness, including the struggle to survive, and his eventual fate at the hands of the Alaskan wild.

The movie is a story about self-discovery and living life as you want. It is a highly inspiring movie, and one that you will not forget for a long time.

The movie is so inspiring that I was motivated to explore the story of Christopher McCandless myself. Even though the movie gives you a good idea of the true story behind Christopher McCandless, you still want to know more about him.

I strongly recommend this movie to everyone, and not just for its inspiring story, but for the fact that it is one of the few movies that touches your heart. You get to know so much about the human spirit and the true value of life.

After completing this movie, I was inspired to live life with true passion. You should not only dream about it, but you should also live it. Life is short and it is never too late to take a chance and live your dreams.

The impact of COVID-19 to patients undergoing cancer treatment and their subsequent rehabilitation remain ill-defined. Patients receiving pre-operative chemotherapy, whilst a crucial part of their treatment are particularly vulnerable. As a result, many services have been affected resulting in a further reduction in their already limited capacity. The use of technology to support patients through this difficult period is a rapidly expanding field which may support the management of pre-operative complications during chemotherapy treatment.
It is hypothesised that monitoring heart rate remotely will not require the need for patients to attend hospital and will provide real-time objective data which can be used to inform future interventions. By monitoring heartrate, a patient's activity can be objectively assessed, reducing uncertainty in the evaluation of exercise adherence and intensity resulting in a potentially more accurate and individualised assessment.
To support this approach the following technology will be considered:
1. Heart rate trackers - to provide patients with access to remote heartrate monitoring in the home.
2. EHealth - to assist patients in tracking their exercise adherence to their prescribed activity levels.
3. Wearable activity trackers - to augment the use of a heart rate tracker and provide an increased understanding of daily exercise levels.
The goal is to assess if the use of these technologies increases the intensity of activity achieved by patients in a prehabilitation/pre-operative setting with an ultimate aim of being able to provide similar support to those undergoing radiotherapy on both an in-patient and out-patient basis. The impact of a remotely monitored, pre-operative exercise programme using heart rate trackers on patient's physical performance, compliance and adherence, recovery and satisfaction will be measured. This data will provide valuable information guiding the development of a future, remote prehabilitation programme. This development will be supported by a framework of user experience considerations which are often ignored at the expense of technical development.

Study Objectives:
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the sociodemographic characteristics, personality traits, and patterns of substance abuse among patients with substance use disorder attending addiction treatment unit.
The hypothesis of this study is to determine the following:
Sociodemographic and personal (e.g., personality) factors may influence the course of addiction and the choice of substance of abuse.
Personality Traits:
Personality traits are believed to influence the development and maintenance of SUD. Patients with SUD might show certain personality characteristics that predispose them to substance abuse as they increase the intensity of drug related cues with repeated drug exposure.
Theoretical models of personality may provide an explanation of different personality characteristics that might interact with addiction. Previous studies have identified the following common personality traits among drug abusers:
- Borderline and antisocial.
- Sensation-seeking.
- Impulsivity.
- Risk propensity.
- Low self-efficacy.
These characteristics may interact with drug-related cues and promote substance use.
Study Arms and Intervention/Treatment: The study is an observational, case series study. Data will be gathered through interviews and medical investigations. All admitted patients to the Addiction management unit during the study period will be asked to participate in the study. Data will be collected during admission before the initiation of detoxification therapy.

Background: 
Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (iCCA) is an aggressive malignancy that is not readily suitable for resection with curative intent. The majority of patients have advanced or metastatic disease at the time of diagnosis, and there are few or no known therapies to effectively treat this disease with significant activity. Tremelimumab and durvalumab are novel immunotherapies that have shown promising results in other solid tumors and are currently in clinical trials for the treatment of iCCA. Preclinical evidence suggests these immunotherapies can have a potent synergistic effect on iCCA treatment. 
The goal of this protocol is to evaluate if durvalumab combined with gemcitabine/cisplatin given prior to potentially curative treatment of iCCA improves rate of conversion from unresectable to resectable disease as well as the effectiveness of these therapies in reducing the risk of recurrence. 
Inclusion in this clinical trial allows subjects to receive neoadjuvant durvalumab and tremelimumab in combination with a standard chemotherapy regimen of gemcitabine/cisplatin prior to (if needed) definitive surgery for unresectable iCCA. All subjects, with exception of poor performing intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (> 30% of tumor is in extrahepatic site or the whole tumor are large nodular masses), will be evaluated by multidisciplinary tumor boards to confirm preoperatively that they have an unresectable intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma. 
Methods: Eligible patients will undergo CT scan with and without contrast for localization of lesions at baseline and after cycle four of treatment with gemcitabine/cisplatin 21 days prior to the first infusion of durvalumab with tremelimumab. Subjects who require surgical resection will undergo imaging every 2-3 months, starting after cycle four of neoadjuvant treatment and continuing through the 6 to 9 months post surgical resection until disease progression. 
Subjects without measurable disease but with unresectable clinical disease will undergo physical examination and blood draw for tumor evaluation every 2-3 months, starting after cycle four of treatment and continuing 36 months after the initiation of durvalumab with tremelimumab. 
Upon confirmation of the rate of conversion from unresectable to resectable tumor and if deemed safe, the treatment could then be made available to more patients with the potential for cure. At the end of treatment, subjects will be offered follow-up at months 3 6, 9, 12, 18 and 24 per follow-up plan in the current protocol to monitor the development of recurrence through physical examination and blood work.

Cards: The clinical need for 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging in cardiac sarcoidosis: Macrophage infiltration and inflammatory heart diseases
Objective(s): • Characterizing 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT findings in sarcoidosis patients compared with other causes of inflamed hearts using PET/CT imaging with a somatostatin-based tracer, and using myocardial radionuclide uptake values and a comprehensive clinical score in the evaluation of the patients.
Background: Cardiac involvement is considered a serious condition and a frequent cause of death in patients with sarcoidosis. 18F-FDG PET/CT is currently used as part of the diagnostic criteria for cardiac sarcoidosis, but FDG displays limitations in the evaluation of cardiac sarcoidosis because of the high physiological uptake of FDG in normal cardiac muscle. Elaborate preparations are required for patients including either a low-carbohydrate diet followed by long fasting or an intravenous loading with heparin to reach low enough glucose levels before FDG-PET. In heparin loading, the rare adverse effect of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia should be considered. Therefore, it is of interest to find a PET/CT tracer that displays high sensitivity and specificity without requiring thorough patient preparation and minimizing any adverse effects. A potential tracer is the human somatostatin receptor 2-binding tracer 64Cu-DOTATATE, which is routinely used for the diagnosis and monitoring of treatment response in patients with neuroendocrine tumors. 64Cu-DOTATATE has been used for the detection of breast cancer and neuroendocrine tumors, where somatostatin receptors are expressed on the tumor cell surface. Macrophages and various other monocyte-derived inflammatory cells are present in sarcoidosis granulomas and express somatostatin receptors on their surface. Because of this reason, the use of a somatostatin-based tracer might provide important clinical information.
Study rationale and significance: The hypothesis is that 64Cu-DOTATATE will detect a macrophage infiltrate in the sarcoidosis patients, while the uptake will be low or nonexistent in the healthy control group and in patients with myocarditis. It is important to differentiate between these two causes of inflamed heart tissue, as treatment of the patients is distinct. 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging provides important information about the disease activity and distribution in the heart, and thereby provides important treatment-decision. Finally, 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT is more easily performed than 18F-FDG PET/CT, as the preparation and the scan itself are less demanding. This implies a less stressful scan procedure for the patients.
Study design: The study is a single-center prospective cohort study, and the study population consists of 1) patients referred to our center for suspected or verified cardiac sarcoidosis (group A) 2) patients with known cardiac sarcoidosis (group B), 3) patients with clinically suspected or verified acute lymphocytic myocarditis (group C), and 4) patients with a neuroendocrine tumor who underwent 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT as part of their clinical diagnostic work-up or follow-up (the control group). All patients will have a 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT scan in addition to routine clinical procedures. The time perspective for each participant is 24 months.
Methodology: 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT scans are performed in all groups. Further, a comprehensive clinical evaluation is performed, including echocardiography and a battery of blood tests. Myocardial uptake of the imaging agent is determined by using standard uptake values (SUV) and by visual assessment of standardized PET/CT images. A battery of blood tests are performed to detect markers of inflammation and sarcoidosis in the blood. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a debilitating disease responsible for almost 15% of all hospital deaths. In ARDS, lung function is severely impaired, leading to hypoxemia (decreased oxygenation). In an attempt to improve oxygenation, intensive care units have traditionally been using an aggressive strategy of sedation and mechanical ventilation. However, both sedation and mechanical ventilation are risk factors for the progression of ARDS and for subsequent mortality. The administration of sedatives may indeed depress the respiratory center, leading to a reduction in ventilation that may increase the risk of developing ARDS. Meanwhile, mechanical ventilation is associated with lung hyperinflation and collapse, both of which can worsen the pulmonary status. The search for a better strategy is therefore warranted. However, an alternative to the standard intravenous strategy has eluded clinicians and researchers. Indeed, there is a lack of evidence supporting any particular approach.
Sevoflurane is a commonly-used anesthetic that may be administered to the patient in a non-invasive or invasive (tracheal) way through a specific non-rebreathing device that enables both oxygenation and sedation (Sedana Medical, Danderyd, Sweden). Among many advantages, inhaled sedation is characterized by a precise adjustment of sedation depth according to its effect upon the level of consciousness (Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale®, Appendix A). However, despite its use in anesthesia and its well-established pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamics properties, there is a dearth of data regarding the effect of inhaled sedation with sevoflurane on the course of ARDS (its incidence and severity, as judged by the development of clinically-defined ARDS and the clinical outcome).
To address this knowledge gap, the investigators designed a prospective, randomized, controlled, parallel-group clinical trial focusing on patients admitted to the ICU and at risk of developing ARDS. The investigators will compare the effects of inhaled sedation with sevoflurane and current intravenous sedation strategy on the incidence and severity of ARDS, as defined by either the Berlin criteria or the investigator’s criteria (Lung Injury Scale, Appendix B). The investigators will also assess the clinical outcome in both arms.

The rotator cuff is a complex tendon structure which enables shoulder movement. The rotator cuff is one of the most common sites of shoulder tendon pathology. Shoulder pain is a high burden of disease and the most frequent cause of work disability. Shoulder pathology is caused by chronic, progressive overload (such as repetitive use and overstrain), sudden muscle or tendon fatigue leading to degenerative changes, and traumatic causes. The rotator cuff is particularly affected by tendinosis, tears, arthritis, and osteoarthritis. The prevalence of shoulder injury is estimated to be 10 -15%. Most of them are degenerative injuries. Most of the people with rotator cuff injury suffer no significant disability as a result, but if the injury affects the rotator cuff extensively and is accompanied by a tear, disability is severe, and the pain can be very bad. If the tear is accompanied especially by a large defect, this usually leads to arthroscopic rotator cuff surgery. A tear that has a defect size of at least around 3 cm is called a massive rotator cuff tear. Massive tendon tears are a challenge to treatment. Treatment with arthroscopic partial repair using the intact LHBB tendon has been introduced to treat the massive tear. With this procedure we aim not only to replace the intra-tear fatty infiltration with viable tendon matrix but also to reconstruct the torn tendon structure anatomically.
The primary aim is to evaluate the functional, radiological, and physiological outcomes of different treatment strategies for massive rotator cuff tears.

The IRIS program aims to address the gaps in the treatment of injection-related infections for people who inject drugs (PWID). This is an ambitious interventional, patient-oriented, mixed methods, longitudinal, single group assignment intervention study designed to optimize treatment in individuals who present with injection-related infections. The study is the first of its kind and is aimed at supporting and engaging PWID in integrated care pathways. The novel integrated model of care that the IRIS program offers, may provide better outcomes for PWID with injection-related infections.

Background: Adverse events following immunization (AEFI) are a concern after influenza vaccine administration. There is currently a gap in our understanding of the optimal platform for conducting surveillance for AEFIs after influenza vaccine administration. Researchers at the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) developed an AEFI surveillance tool, named CANVAS, which can be accessed either through a secure platform (WEB) or through a mobile application (APP).
Objective: Compare the ability of the web-based surveillance tool (WEB) and the mobile application (APP) to promote AEFI reporting in order to determine if it is more effective to use one over the other.
Methods: This will be a randomized open-label superiority trial. Participants will be recruited through a public vaccination clinic, and randomized to WEB, or APP. Using the web-based CANVAS, participants will be notified of the survey (either through email or push notification) at two weeks post immunization. One week after, participants will be notified of any unsolicited adverse events detected by the investigator team.
Expected results: This research will provide insights into the most effective tools to use to promote AEFIs reporting.

The objective of the proposed study is to investigate the relationship between COX-2 gene polymorphisms with peri-implantitis and the detection of pathogenic microbiota and pathogenic molecules associated with peri-implantitis in a cohort of patients with a history of periodontal disease. The aims of the research are to investigate whether the COX-2 gene polymorphisms, pathogenic microbiota, and pathogenic molecules are associated with peri-implantitis and to investigate their association with pathogenic microbiota and molecules (such as aMMP-8) associated with peri-implantitis in a cohort of periodontitis patients with a history of peri-implantitis. The proposed research will have the following structure: 
Inclusion Criteria: The inclusion criteria will consist of 100 patients (60 males and 40 females) of Caucasian origin, aged 30-85 years, willing to participate in the study, and diagnosed with peri-implantitis according to the 2017 Workshop criteria (American Academy of Periodontology Workshop).
Exclusion Criteria: The exclusions criteria will include, current diagnosis of periodontitis in any tooth, pregnancy and smoking status, history of anticoagulant antibiotics therapy in the previous 12 months, diabetes, antibiotic therapy in the previous three months and the inability or unwillingness of the patient to participate in the study.
The reasons for the design of the criteria: The selection of patients with a specific age range is justified on the basis that a healthy young adult patient with a history of periodontitis, who will eventually develop peri-implantitis, will most likely have a genetic makeup with a correlation between cox-2 gene polymorphism and peri-implantitis. This criterion ensures that the study will be focused on patients with a history of periodontitis who are more likely to be relevant to the research question. The exclusion of pregnant women and smokers is necessary to avoid confounding factors in the study results. Anticonvulsants, antiplatelet drugs and antibiotics can affect gene and protein expression, therefore patients who have taken them in the past year will be excluded from the study. A current diagnosis of periodontitis in any tooth will allow us to focus on patients who are more likely to develop peri-implantitis rather than those with healthier periodontium.
Patient Group/Arm: There will be two study participant groups. The first group will be the test group and will consist of patients with diagnosed peri-implantitis, who will be the focus of our research. Peri-implantitis is a major threat to implant survival and is considered a common late complication in clinical routine. The group will consist of 60 patients, half of the sample with implants treated with a 3S+R technique (3-unit bridge, single unit implant supported crown, and a single implant-retained overdenture. Each implant will be evaluated for peri-implantitis and the patients will be asked to provide an informed consent form for participation in genetic analyses. Participants will be requested to follow the home care maintenance recommendations of the study investigator regarding oral hygiene instructions and plaque control.
The second group will be the control group and will include patients who have previously received periodontal treatment and maintain a healthy periodontium. One implant will be selected for further gene, microbiota and molecular analysis. Each patient in the control group will be asked to sign an informed consent form for genetic analysis.
Intervention/Treatment: The intervention/treatment for the control group will involve one saliva DNA test to detect gene polymorphisms of MMP-8. The test will be administered during a visit for non-surgical periodontal therapy and will be performed as described by the manufacturer in the ORALyser User Manual. The test will be carried out by two different operators to verify the accuracy and consistency of the measurements. The test results will be compared with the clinical and radiographic status.

T1: Patients will be recruited in a postgraduate clinic of implantology in Aristotle University of Thessaloniki.
T2: An informed consent form will be signed by the patients who will be tested for peri-implantitis and the patients who will be tested for their saliva polymorphisms.
T3: The test group will provide samples of clinical and radiographic measurements.

Virtual reality, an interactive digital environment, is created in 3D environments using devices such as smartphones, computer systems, consoles, and VR glasses. Virtual Reality (VR) is thought to stimulate certain areas in the brain, where it provides effective pain reduction. In the literature, it has been found that virtual reality has been effective in reducing anxiety levels in patients undergoing various procedures such as chemotherapy, cancer treatment, postoperative pain, and dental treatment. Trigger Point injection therapy, which is frequently applied by orthopedic and rehabilitation physicians for musculoskeletal pain, is considered a standard treatment method. For each patient, trigger point injection causes anxiety and pain due to pain. Patients' anxiety and pain can be reduced using non-pharmacological methods. Virtual Reality, being used widely in healthcare, is stated to be a non-pharmacological method that can be used in this field. In this study, it is aimed to investigate the effect of virtual reality on the pain intensity of patients undergoing trigger point injection, to decrease the anxiety scores of patients applied with trigger point injection and to increase their comfort.

Achalasia is characterized by the failure of esophageal smooth muscle relaxation causing food bolus retention and progressive esophageal dilatation. In 2015, per-oral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) was introduced as a treatment option. During POEM, hemodynamics are commonly unstable, and studies showed that autonomic dysfunction occurred in up to 75% of patients undergoing POEM. However, studies regarding the clinical implications of autonomic dysfunction during POEM are limited. In this study, the aim is to assess the effect of autonomic dysfunction on the hemodynamic instability during POEM in Achalasia patients, which will help in optimizing the perioperative management.

In children, inhaler treatment is one of the common procedures during the emergency period. However, pediatric complaints that require inhaler treatment are still high, and children over the age of 5 and under the age of 2 are frequently referred to the Emergency Service for non-respiratory symptoms. This leads to negative feelings when the child arrives at the hospital, experiences treatment anxiety and refusal. Virtual Reality (VR) glasses, which are a visual aid used widely in children's healthcare, are used in inhaler treatment and can reduce pain during children's inhaler treatment. There are a few publications in the literature showing the benefits of VR glasses for children during treatment. The most frequently reported studies use standard VR glasses to reduce anxiety in children. In pediatric emergency services, it is planned to use VR images created by smartphone applications for the first time on smartphone-integrated VR glasses without using separate VR glasses. In this study, the effects of VR glasses on anxiety, vital signs, and duration of inhaler treatment during inhaler treatment in children were examined with 2 different VR images.

Approximately 20% of children and adolescents in primary care units seek help due to anxiety and depression and need psychological treatment. These symptoms often last for several years, and the symptoms are often combined, causing suffering and problems for the child, his/her family and the society. One way of treating these symptoms are Cognitive Behaviour Therapy (CBT) methods. CBT methods are effective in both short and long term, according to international studies. However, difficulties with access and recruitment in the primary care setting have been reported.
In recent years, treatment-manuals for psychotherapeutic treatment have been developed, offering a structured and transdiagnostic approach to treatment. One of these methods, the Unified Protocol (UP-C/A), was recently evaluated in a treatment study among adolescents and young adults. The results showed the UP-C/A as effective in decreasing symptoms and to be well received by patients as well as their parents. However, there is a need to evaluate this treatment approach among children and their parents. A randomized trial of the Unified protocol for children and adolescents (UP-C/A), in a treatment as usual environment, in primary care clinics, is yet to be conducted. The current study is a clinical open trial to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability and effect of implementing this method in a clinical setting, as well as to prepare for a follow-up study, a randomized controlled trial (RCT), in this setting. The project intends to investigate 40 children and adolescents seeking treatment for anxiety and depression in primary care, together with their parents.
In this open trial, children and adolescents, aged 7-17 years old, with anxiety-related and / or depressive symptoms, and their parents, are offered a transdiagnostic treatment group. They meet for 11 sessions over a period of three months. The treatment is based on the third wave of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), which is called Unified Protocol (UP-C/A). In this treatment method, both child and parents are trained in Emotion-focused coping skills. The treatment group treatment is led by psychologist trained in the UP-C/A and is supervised by two licensed psychologists. The treatment is delivered in 11 face-to-face sessions, divided into child-training group sessions and parent-training group sessions, with some exercises together.
At the beginning of the study, there are two baseline assessments to register symptoms. The children fill out self-ratings, the parents fill out self-ratings, the therapists evaluate the treatment and the child is being evaluated by a psychiatrist. Assessments are made before and after the treatment sessions and at a 6-month follow-up. Children fill out self-ratings, parents fill out self-ratings and the therapists will also be asked to evaluate the treatment. If the project succeeds in recruitment of a sufficient number of participants and if preliminary results are promising, we intend to design a future randomized controlled trial. The results of this open trial will contribute in design of outcome measures, recruitment strategies and the evaluation of costs and resources in a future RCT.

The purpose of this study is primary prevention. The investigators aim to reduce pain in preterm infants during less-invasive-surfactant-administration (LISA) by analgosedation of a pre-emptive or 'prophylactic' nature.
Infants born preterm are a highly vulnerable population as they have an immature nervous system. Pain is a threat and stress to their immune system and can result in chronic neurodevelopmental, physiological and behavioral impairments. Therefore, it is essential to reduce the incidence and intensity of pain and stress in preterm infants.
The investigators hypothesized, based on preliminary results reported in a review regarding the effect of pain on stress parameters and its impact on the developing brain, that the infants receiving analgosedation (pain relief) will experience reduced stress in comparison to non-pain relieved infants. The investigators therefore tested their hypothesis by implementing a randomized, controlled, clinical, multicenter study protocol.
The investigators used non-invasive continuous video recording and skin conductance measurement, a measurement for sympathetic arousal, as pain markers to identify pain and stress. With this information, the investigators plan to assess the hypothesis stated above.
The study population consisted of preterm infants who needed LISA. The investigators assessed the investigational test treatment (pain treatment) in comparison to the standard of care (control) in order to establish the effect of different treatment modalities.
The investigators expect no serious adverse effects to be associated with the study because the investigational test treatment will be started at a low dose and will not be administered in all participants to allow individualized pain management during LISA.
Ultimately, the data acquired from this investigation could potentially be implemented into clinical practice in order to improve pain management not only during LISA but for other invasive and painful interventions in preterm infants.

Background: Many older patients with depression in Africa are undetected and receive no treatment. Risk factors, and barriers to care and treatments include lack of awareness of depression, lack of access to care, poor knowledge of clinicians, poor access to psychotropic medication, and stigma. Evidence of a positive effect of the emhGAP-Age intervention on patients with depressive illness is limited to the UK or the US. There is no reported attempt to implement the trial model in Africa. Our research aims to adapt an evidence-based, home-delivered stepped-care depression treatment; the emhGAP-Age intervention, for the low and middle income countries including Nigeria.
Objective: A feasibility cluster randomised controlled trial with a two-arm design will be conducted in a purposive sample of Nigerian primary care centres (PCCs) located in four South-West states in Nigeria. It will assess the acceptability (of emhGAP-Age by the people who use the services), recruitment rate, retention rate, and trial completion to inform the design of a full trial. This trial will focus on the older population, 60 years and above.
Participants: Patients aged 60 years and over with probable major depressive disorder (mMDD) who attend primary health care centres in South-West Nigeria with mental health conditions and older adults who attend for routine primary care for other health problems and present with symptoms of depression. In each study centre 600 older adults will be screened to identify 40 with probable mMDD.
Design: An exploratory feasibility cluster randomised controlled trial will be conducted. A purposive sample of 6 PCCs will be randomly allocated to the intervention group (IG) or to a placebo comparator group (CG). In each study centre 600 older adults will be screened to identify 40 with probable mMDD.
Intervention: Adapted emhGAP-Age intervention: a problem-solving treatment for depressive illness (based on the emhGAP-Age intervention delivered in UK to older patients with depression) modified for Nigerian population, will be delivered on a one-to-one basis by trained lay health workers. Support and ongoing supervision of lay providers will be provided. Participants will be offered regular follow up within a supportive environment.
Reasoning: The study will assess the acceptability, recruitment rate, retention rate, and trial completion to inform the design of a full trial. The proposed adaptation of the emhGAP-Age intervention for the Nigerian context can provide a feasible, culturally acceptable, and affordable treatment option for a significant proportion of older people with depression in Nigeria.

Inclusion criteria: Inclusion Criteria:
Age ≥ 60 years - There are two groups. Those aged 60 years and above, and older adults (60 years and above), who attend for routine primary care for other health problems with symptoms of depression.
PHQ-9 score of ≥11 during routine consultation - Patients aged 60 years and over with probable major depressive disorder (mMDD) who attend primary health care centres in South-West Nigeria with mental health conditions and older adults (60 years and above), who attend for routine primary care for other health problems with symptoms of depression.

To be successful, an ACL reconstruction requires a strong incorporation of the tendon to the bone within or at the margin of the tunnel, but the tunnel itself is at risk of widening, therefore compromising the tendon attachment. The tunnel widening is mainly due to non-physiologic tissue formation at the bone-graft interface as fibrous tissue (mainly periosteal membrane) and/or subchondral bone cysts can form around the tendon aperture sites. This results in decreased bone-graft biomechanical anchor of the graft to the bone and increased risk of graft pullout. A composite (moldavite and demineralized bone matrices mixed with autologous PrP) obtained from bone tissue debris gathered from tunnel drilling during surgery could be used with the aim that the application of this mixed bone tissue would create a biomechanical bone environment and an appropriate space for the application of the autograft and promote optimal bone-graft integration.
The primary objective is to evaluate whether the procedure of augmented ACL integration results in less tibial tunnel widening compared to the same surgery without this treatment measured by CT and MRI.

Preoxygenation with HFNO has been described previously in elective surgeries. Its superiority over conventional face-mask preoxygenation is clear. Background: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), an acquired disorder, is caused by a mutation in the PIG-A gene, leading to complement activation and eventual hemolysis. PNH has a high mortality rate due to complications such as renal insufficiency, thrombosis, and heart failure. However, the introduction of eculizumab, a monoclonal antibody, has dramatically improved outcomes in PNH patients and has become a highly effective treatment over the past decade. Eculizumab blocks complement component C5, a critical component of the complement cascade.
In the United States, the incidence and prevalence of PNH have been historically underestimated. Thus, in 2012, an NIH-sponsored prospective, multicenter study of subjects with a history highly suggestive of PNH but without laboratory confirmation (called the 2012 NIH PNH Screening Registry), was conducted, and a subsequent analysis of the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 2007-2010 found rates of PNH as high as 1:500. Additionally, since most U.S. residents have undergone testing for other genetic disorders, it is likely many U.S. residents with undiagnosed PNH exist, particularly in areas with a significant population of African American men, who make up approximately one-third of adult patients with PNH.
Based on these data, and with the approval of the NIH, the PAROXISMAL NOCTURAL Hemoglobinuria (PNH) PATHWAY to SIGNIFICANT HEALING (PATHWAY 1) pilot Study, was launched to:1) Diagnose PNH (defined as an increased percentage of NHS RBC+ PNH clone size ≥15%; increased percentage of NHS RBC+ clone size for all PNH patients); 2) Follow over time an increased PNH clone size in newly diagnosed subjects; and 3) Follow up PNH patients on treatment to see if their PNH clone size changes over time while on therapy.
Prior eculizumab clinical trials demonstrated efficacy in stabilizing LDH over time in subjects treated with eculizumab who were randomized to 6-month intervals of treatment.
Regardless, due to the large number of subjects with PNH already in the study or being identified by other investigators not part of the study, subjects in PATHWAY 1 who require treatment for PNH cannot be discontinued from eculizumab at any point but will be kept on therapy until they become no longer responsive to eculizumab.
Currently, eculizumab is the only treatment for PNH and while eculizumab prevents ongoing hemolysis, it does not reverse PNH-associated disease. If eculizumab is stopped, LDH levels rise, with the potential for a recurrence of acute complications such as renal failure, requiring re-initiation of eculizumab.
PURPOSE: While the long term efficacy of extended interval dosing and the impact on clinical outcomes are unknown, the investigator believes that such a treatment approach may help preserve access to eculizumab for newly diagnosed subjects and other subjects treated off label with eculizumab. However, the investigator cannot be sure of this.
This study will help us answer the following questions:
Can we stabilize LDH in subjects whose PNH clone size stabilizes with extended dosing intervals?
Can we maintain or improve quality of life, fatigue, hemoglobin, physical function, and overall health status in subjects with stable PNH clone size treated with extended dosing intervals?
To address these questions, the investigators will perform a retrospective review of subjects within the PAROXISMAL NOCTURAL Hemoglobinuria (PNH) Pathway to Significant Healing (PATHWAY 1) pilot Study who are or were receiving eculizumab to determine whether their LDH levels are stable. Secondary objectives will collect retrospective data for the same subjects on quality of life, fatigue, hemoglobin, physical function, and overall health status as assessed by the subject questionnaire administered to them as part of their routine follow-up.

This will be a 24-week prospective study that will incorporate user base data of WayBetter Inc.'s app, WayBetter, to examine user mHealth app engagement. The primary objective of this study is to examine predictors (i.e., socio-demographics, past health behaviours, psychological determinants, app engagement metrics) of (a) initial six-month subscription and b) subscription renewal rates at six months for the WayBetter app. The secondary objective is to characterize WayBetter app engagement over the first 24 weeks of app use. Our study sample will consist of approximately 400 adult users (aged ≥18 years old), who are new WayBetter app users (who have engaged in a 7-day free trial). As users may have varying registration dates, the data collected will only include the first 24 weeks of an individual's interaction with the platform. The engagement metrics will include; 1) App opens per week, 2) Date of Joining First Game, 3) Game Adherence, 4) Number of games started and won, 5) Non-usage attrition and 6) Re-regagement. We hypothesize that (1) previous physical activity levels, (2) health literacy, (3) personality traits, (4) impulsiveness and (5) perceived self-efficacy to change health behaviours will differ between users who sign up for the 6-month WayBetter subscription, users who renewed WayBetter subscription at six months, and users that subscribed to a new app after their free trial expired; and that (6) significant associations will exist between the predictors and the engagement metrics 1-6. 
The primary outcomes of this study are rates of initial six-month subscription and subscription renewal rates at six months for the WayBetter app. User specific metrics that will be examined are; demographic information and past health behaviours, psychological determinants (i.e., risk taking traits, healthy behaviour self-efficacy, personality traits) and app engagement metrics (i.e., app opens per week, date of joining first game, game adherence, number of games started and won, non-usage attrition and re-engagement). Multivariate analysis will be used to examine associations between variables and correlations between the engagement metrics.

This randomized controlled experimental study was conducted to determine the effect of swaddling and inhaling breast milk odour on the pain and comfort during the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter in term infants in the neonatal intensive care unit. Infants in the 1st experimental group (Swaddling) were swaddled, the infants in the 2nd experimental group (Inhaling mother's breast milk odor) were made to inhale their mothers' breast milk odor and the infants in the 3rd experimental group (both swaddled and made to inhale mother's breast milk odor) were both swaddled and made to inhale mother's breast milk odor. No procedure was applied to the infants in the control group. The Neonatal Infant Pain Scale (NIPS) and the Newborn Comfort Behavior Scale were evaluated by the researcher before and during the procedure, and 5 minutes after the infants were taken to the incubator. The pain and comfort levels of the infants in the experimental and control groups were found to be higher in the control group compared to the other two experimental groups (Swaddling and Inhaling mother's breast milk odor). The Neonatal Infant Pain Scale (NIPS) and the Newborn Comfort Behavior Scale revealed that infants experienced less pain and discomfort when they were both swaddled and made to inhale mother's breast milk odor. Therefore, these two methods can be applied to term infants for the management of pain and discomfort.

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is a common mental disorder in the adult population, with a lifetime prevalence of 19.9% on the basis of epidemiological survey data, and the incidence of the disease is on the rise. Patients with GAD often experience symptoms such as excessive anxiety, muscle tension, fatigue, insomnia, irritability, poor appetite, and concentration difficulty, which seriously affect their quality of life and even increase the risk of cardiovascular and other physical diseases. The first-line therapy for patients with GAD is to take selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or benzodiazepines. However, SSRI-based medication can take several weeks to take effect and often results in unwanted side effects such as decreased libido, gastrointestinal symptoms, weight gain, and insomnia. In addition, the long-term use of benzodiazepines is often associated with the risk of drug dependence, so the treatment is not satisfactory. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop new intervention models that can effectively relieve the symptoms of GAD in a shorter period of time with fewer side effects. Transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation (tVNS) has emerged as a new therapy for various neurological and psychiatric diseases (including treatment of depression, anxiety, and epilepsy). The specific mechanism of tVNS is still unclear at present, and it is commonly believed that tVNS can promote cortical excitation and inhibition imbalance, improve cerebral blood flow and metabolism, and regulate the function of various brain regions through increasing the activity of the vagus nerve and enhancing the cholinergic system. However, there are currently few studies on the combined use of transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation and medication for the treatment of anxiety disorders, and no studies have compared the outcomes of transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation combined with benzodiazepines or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors in GAD patients. Therefore, in this study, the investigators hope to explore the feasibility and efficacy of benzodiazepine or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors combined with transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation for the treatment of GAD.

Lacrimal drainage obstruction usually manifests as epiphora with or without recurrent infections of mucopurulent discharge. Dacryoendoscopy is an advanced technique of lacrimal drainage system examination which combined the advantages of endoscopy and radiography. In the last five years, it has been increasingly used in dacryologic surgery. Dacryoendoscopic-assisted laser dacryoplasty with silicone intubation was widely accepted for management of lacrimal drainage obstruction, particularly for the patients who are ineligible for the traditional surgery. However, the success rates vary between 51% and 90% as reported by Chinese and Korean literatures. We have noticed that the success rate of DLDI is associated with the sites of obstruction, stringency of dacryoendoscopy-assisted laser dacryoplasty, patient selection, and surgical technique. Because of a wide range of success rates among reported studies and with a view to evaluating success rates of DLDI for patients in China, we planned to conduct the retrospective study. One hundred seventy-five patients who underwent laser dacryoplasty via DLDI with a follow-up period of >6 months were recruited. This paper reports the preliminary results of this trial for patients with a median follow-up period of 13 months. The cumulative success rate for DLDI in our retrospective analysis was 82.7% at the 2-year follow-up using the Kaplan-Meier method. The success rate was 80.7% for group A, 79.8% for group B, and 87.9% for group C.

This pilot study is the first step in the development of a vascular access management algorithm in patients requiring multiple peripheral venous catheters (PVCs) or a difficult PVC. It proposes to validate the usefulness of implementing a catheter placement algorithm, composed of a scoring system (i.e., the Difficult Intravenous Access Scale (VAD) score) and a new graded decision tree for management, to facilitate venous access, decrease the time for management of vascular access difficulties and improve the patients' comfort during care.
It is important to note that the aim of this study does not include comparing the results after the use of the vascular access difficulties score and the algorithm to routine practices, nor to any other interventions, but rather to describe the impact of the innovative tools on the management of vascular access difficulties to the best of the patient's condition and comfort.
The study is planned over a 15-month period, and will follow a mixed (quantitative and qualitative) research methodology; a quasi-experimental, before-and-after study, in the form of a three-phase data collection process. The study will take place with a multidisciplinary team of investigators (nurses and physicians) and will involve data collection and analysis activities (data collection, statistical analysis, analysis of the data collected during the interviews, production of reports and scientific articles).
This study will be carried out in the resuscitation departments of two different hospitals: a university center and a general hospital, specialized in emergency medicine. To this aim, a working group of health professionals will co-construct the criteria for inclusion and allocation of professional categories (nurses, specialized nurses, physicians). It will also co-construct the assessment scale used to evaluate the difficulty of PVC insertion as well as the decision support tool (graduated management tool) to be used during peripheral venous catheterization.
There is currently an overall lack of standard recommendations for evaluating vascular access difficulties in hospitalized patients. Thus, the main goal of this pilot study is to evaluate practices relative to vascular access management in adults. This phase aims to describe the initial situation, the usual practices and the reasons for the use of PVC in the target resuscitation departments and the usual techniques used during PVC insertion. It will also describe the pain felt by patients and operators' professional behaviors.
The second phase is planned to occur 4 months after the first phase and will be focused upon evaluating the impact of implementing the vascular access difficulties score on the management of vascular access difficulties as well as operators' professional practices.
The third phase is planned to coincide with the second phase, and will aim to evaluate the impact of the new algorithm (i.e., the full algorithm composed of the VAD score and the new decision support tool for management) on the management of vascular access difficulties and on patients' comfort.
By analyzing the collected data, an algorithm for vascular access management will be constructed and scientific articles and reports will be produced to disseminate the results to clinicians and other health professionals. This study could also help to optimize the care given to hospitalized patients, to better understand patient pain and to improve the experience of care in a comprehensive approach that takes into account clinical, ethical, and economic aspects. The results from this study could contribute to the building of a body of knowledge and to the implementation of practices that adhere to patients' conditions, respect and preserve their comfort and dignity during care, and provide them with an experience that fosters hope and resilience.

Non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) incidence and morbidity rates are high in older patients. Surgery is the standard of care. About 5 to 10% of NMSC present high-risk clinico-pathologic features that can increase risk of local recurrence (LR). Adjuvant radiation therapy (ART) is often discussed regarding the risk of local recurrence. Despite the lack of high level evidence, ART is indicated in patients according to unfavorable prognostic factors. ART benefit is generally questioned in regard to the potential degradation of the patient's quality of life (QoL). Currently there is no prospective trial or recommendations that take into account geriatric patients' evaluation and profiles during the management of NMSC. In addition, there is no data that could help to define the subgroup of elderly patients who will benefit from ART in tumors with unfavorable prognostic factors. In terms of ART, multiple fractionation schedules are available, ranging from standard fractionation (45-60Gy in 5-6 weeks) to the extreme hypofractionation delivering 16-18Gy in one fraction. In routine practice, HF is mainly preferred in elderly patients for more convenience by reducing the number of transports and increase health related quality of life (HRQoL). However, there is no data on the fragility profiles of these patients, nor validating any HF schedule in terms of efficacy, acute toxicity, cosmetic results, and impact on HRQoL. Hypothesis/Objective Main Objective: To evaluate the comparative efficacy of two modalities of Radiotherapy over surgery alone on local tumor control in older patients with Non Melanoma Skin Cancer (NMSC) In current practice, adjuvant radiotherapy is discussed regarding the risk of local recurrence as determined by the existence (or not) of unfavorable prognostic factors. The proposed study will include R0-high risk of CBC and CEC of the skin in elderly patients. There is no risk regarding the design of the trial as the last will respond to two important unknown questions regarding the utility of RT and its fractionation in this population. Moreover, it is an excellent opportunity to collect prospectively geriatric evaluation and HRQoL data that are lacking in the literature for skin cancers. No constraints are seen neither in the design, nor in the potential recruitments. Primary endpoint: Local tumor control at 3-year follow-up in a time-to-event analysis Method This is a multicenter, randomized, open-labeled, comparative 3 arms phase III trial. After inclusion of patient aged ≥ 70 years with performance status OMS 0-3 who had completed surgery (R0) for SCC and BCC with at least one unfavorable prognostic factor, all patientsst will have G8 score and a Geriatric Core Data Set (G CODE) evaluation. Performance of a complete oncogeriatric evaluation and its modalities will be left to the discretion of the investigator. The patients will be randomized in 3 arms with stratification by center, time from surgery to wound healing and perineural invasion. Arm A: Surgery alone Arm B: Surgery + Moderate HF 45Gy in 15 fractions, 3 fractions per week over 5 weeks to the operative bed. Arm C: Surgery + Extreme HF : 30Gy in 5 fractions of 6Gy, 1 fraction per week, over 5 weeks to the operative bed.

Approximately 70,000 Veterans reach age 75 each year and over the next two decades, the number of Veterans reaching age 75 is expected to exceed 120,000/year. Colorectal cancer (CRC) risk is higher among older adults: 92% of the more than 300,000 new cases of CRC diagnosed each year are diagnosed among those 75 and older. As a result, older adults are also disproportionately affected by CRC screening complications such as perforation, hemorrhage, and death. There is significant controversy regarding whether colorectal cancer screening improves survival in older adults. While population-level guidelines recommend screening, there is no conclusive evidence that CRC screening in older adults reduces colon cancer deaths. The investigators propose to study colorectal cancer risk after age 75 in a cohort of older adults with vs. without history of polypectomy prior to age 75 (SurvOlderAdults cohort) to determine clinical importance of surveillance colonoscopy risk in older adults with prior polypectomy, and identify the population which can benefit most from surveillance using a case-cohort design (SurvOlderAdults case-cohort). Lastly, utilizing qualitative research on surveillance in older adults, the investigators will convene an expert panel to obtain stakeholder perspectives for informing future implementation of surveillance among older adults (SurvOlderAdults stakeholder panel). This will advance quantitative and qualitative knowledge regarding colorectal cancer risk and screening in older adults, and optimize the use of healthcare resources to mitigate complications and improve survival.
