Background: Recent data suggest that losartan treatment might block activation of the Nerve Growth Factor (NGF) in rats receiving Taxane. The aim of this Phase II randomized study is to evaluate its efficacy in the prevention of paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy (PIPN) in patients undergoing adjuvant or neo adjuvant chemotherapy for breast cancer. Methods: All breast cancer patients receiving paclitaxel (80 mg/m2) will be offered inclusion in this study and enrolled following written informed consent. In a randomized design, patients will be assigned to 2 different study arms; one group (control arm) will receive the standard treatment for PIPN based on vitamins use, and the other group (losartan arm) will receive the standard treatment plus daily administration of losartan (50 mg) starting one week prior to paclitaxel on day 1 of each Taxane course (for those receiving 3 weekly doses of paclitaxel 175 mg/m2 in combination with 5FU 500 mg/m2 or Docetaxel 75 mg/m2, this regimen will be administered every 21 days). Assessment of the development of PIPN will be based on NCI Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE v3.0). Neuropathy grade and functional assessment of quality of life will be evaluated using FACT/GOG-NTX. Blood sample will be collected at baseline for biomarkers level. The study will continue until 12 patients are recruited. At that point, the accrual will be terminated and an interim analysis of the results will be performed. Enrollment will be terminated if patients in the control arm develop more than 2 grade 2 and/or 1 grade 3 PIPN.

AA can be divided into severe AA (SAA) and non-severe AA (NSAA), according to the severity of the disease. For SAA patients, guideline recommended ciclosporin A (CsA) + anti-thymocyte immunoglobulin (ATG) + thrombopoietin receptor agonist (TPO-RA) as the first-line therapy. Our study of 30 cases showed that for SAA patients who were intolerant to ATG, CsA+ eltrombopag (EPAG) had similar efficacy to CsA+ATG+EPAG. However, the adverse effects such as hepatotoxicity and gasrointestinal disorder limit its application in elderly SAA. Compared with EPAG, AVA has no hepatotoxicity and less other adverse effects, but the efficacy is not well defined in SAA. The action mechanism of AVA and EPAG is different. And the metabolic level of the elderly is not the same as that of younger patients. Thus, we wondered whether CsA+AVA had similar efficacy to CsA+ATG+AVA in the elderly SAA patients. Therefore, this is a prospective, randomized, controlled, open-label study, aiming to study the clinical value of CsA+AVA in preventing relapse and long-term prognosis of AA in elderly patients.

The purpose of this 2 part sequential study is to assess the performance of 89Zr-panitumumab PET/CT in evaluation of response and monitoring for recurrence in patients with HNSCC. The hypothesis of this study is that 89Zr-panitumab PET/CT can accurately diagnose occult (i.e., indeterminate) metastases in subjects with HNSCC on first line CT and/or 18F-FDG-PET/CT. The sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab for detecting head and neck cancer lesions on PET/CT compared to gold standard imaging will be compared. Additionally, PET/CT using 89Zr-panitumumab will be compared to current standard of care imaging (i.e., CT and/or 18F-FDG PET/CT). Finally, time and use of resources required for treatment decisions will be estimated by patients, treating physicians, and clinics using different imaging modalties.
In part 1, 20 participants will be enrolled to assess safety and tolerability. Participants will receive single dose of unlabeled panitumumab followed by 89Zr-panitumumab on day 0 and 140 microCuries 89Zr-panitumumab on day 30. PET/CT imaging will be obtained on days 3, 5, 7, 14, 21, 28, 35, 42, and 49. Patients will return for additional PET/CTs at months 6, 7, 8, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24 and 36.
The primary objective of part 1 is to determine the toxicity profile of unlabeled Panitumumab and 89Zr-panitumumab using PET/CT in HNSCC patients. The secondary objective of part 1 is to assess the imaging properties of 89Zr-panitumumab after the first dose of 140 microCuries and evaluate immunogenicity of Panitumumab.
Part 2 (expansion phase): 100 participants who do not progress after Part 1 will receive a single dose of unlabeled panitumumab on day 0 and 140 microCuries 89Zr-panitumumab on day 365. A follow up PET/CT will be conducted at 13.5 months.
The primary objective of Part 2 is to compare 140 microCuries of 89Zr-panitumumab to current standard of care imaging modalities, including CT and/or 18F-FDG PET/CT. The secondary objective of Part 2 is to assess the impact of 89Zr-panitumumab PET/CT on treatment decisions among subjects with indeterminate lesions and determine the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab.
In Part 1, an initial cohort of 10 participants will be enrolled sequentially to first establish the preliminary safety profile of 89Zr-panitumab. The decision to continue enrollment of additional patients will be guided by preliminary Safety and Tolerability results, with at least two participants receiving 89Zr-panitumumab without experiencing Dose Limiting Toxicity. 
Enrolled participants will undergo the 89Zr-panitumumab PET/CT scan, and the results of the PET/CT scan will be used for dose modification/escalation guidelines. The study will be terminated if the 89Zr-panitumumab PET/CT scan results in adverse events.

Bug and Vector Borner Diseases (VBBD) have been described as the neglected group of the neglected diseases. Despite major progresses in the fight against severe VBD diseases, such as malaria, visceral leishmaniasis or lymphatic filariasis, and the fact that VBVDs kill almost 700,000 people annually and affects billions more people around the world, these diseases have not received the attention from the scientific and funding communities as the top diseases (e.g., diarrheal diseases, HIV/AIDS). The huge scale up of long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLIN) has led to a major reduction in malaria burden in many sub-Saharan African (SSA) countries. This progress is threatened by the wide scale selection of insecticide resistant malaria vectors. Furthermore, a recent WHO report showed that LLIN use in SSA only reached 53%, and that this coverage dropped from 61% in 2014 to 47% in 2018, raising concerns for the coverage impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.
To fight this pandemic the World Health Organization (WHO) has put in place several policies aimed at supporting countries during the pandemic. This includes the development and implementation of a global COVID-19 strategy for VBD that will help countries to adapt and mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, maintain coverage of core VBVD and malaria interventions. WHO has also recently published updated VBVD and malaria guidelines (2019), including the recommendation to use a new generation of nets with a mixture of chemical insecticides with different modes of action (pyrethroids α-cypermethrin, chlorfenapyr). This new generation of nets can also be used to target insecticide resistant vectors.
The overall goal of this 5-year study is to compare the performance of new generation nets using mixtures of two different chemicals to the performance of LLINs with classic pyrethroids, in terms of effectiveness to control malaria and its transmission in a highly transmitting, pyrethroid resistant malaria environment in Southern Bouakey, Ivory Coast. This will provide guidance to WHO and endemic country programmes in determining which novel LLIN to select for scale up in a context prone to pyrethroid resistance.
This study will be conducted over a 12-month period, in 33 rural villages of Lac district (Côte d'Ivoire), with a total population of 20,000 people, following a clustered randomised (CRT) design. The study will compare two LLINs containing a synergistic with the pyrethroids (Veeralin Nets) or another compound (Interceptor G2) that is not a synergist, with a standard nets containing pyrethroids only, for their efficacy in reducing malaria cases in children aged between 6-months to 9-years, malaria infection prevalence using Rapid diagnostic test (RDT) among all ages. The second outcome will be the insecticide resistance intensity (measured using WHO bottle assay). Entomological outcomes will be assessed using the current WHO guidelines including the following parameters: vector density, sporozoite rate, vector bionomics and survival.
This study will be one of the first studies in SSA to evaluate the performance of a novel insecticide on pyrethroid resistant vectors, and how this novel approach impacts on key entomological and malariological indexes with the ultimate goal to better control malaria in SSA. It will also provide WHO technical advisory and country programmes with additional scientific evidence and technical guidance to effectively promote the implementation of this novel technology. The findings of this study will also provide WHO with scientific evidence required to update the WHO guidelines for vector control. This study, which will be the first of its kind conducted at local level, will impact on a broad range of stakeholders including national programme managers, international vector control project managers, donors (e.g., PMI, European Union, Gates Foundation) and NGOs (e.g., Vestergaard, Sumitomo, Sharda, Net-Freedom, etc…) who are all pushing for a transition towards a broader spectrum of insecticides in order to tackle the emergence of new insecticide resistant vector populations.

Background: The incidence of prostate cancer continues to increase with 35,000 newly diagnosed cases recorded in the UK in 2013 alone. Over 10,000 UK males died from the disease in 2013. If diagnosed at an early stage, the chances of getting cured is more than 90%, through removal of the prostate (known as radical prostatectomy), or through radiotherapy. Both treatment options are associated with life-changing quality of life impacts, and survivors will be forever dealing with changes to sexual, bowel and bladder function, which are challenging to manage and can have significant impact on their well being, work and social life. Radiotherapy is the preferred treatment option in most cases to preserve sexual function and quality of life, rather than risking surgical complications. However standard radiotherapy treatment requires on average 5 weeks of treatment giving 39 x 2Gy fractions, or for low-risk disease this number can be reduced to 8 fractions (38 x 2Gy) and 5 fractions (35 x 2Gy). Even at these lower doses the treatment can cause urinary and bowel side effects, sometimes with permanent consequences. New radiotherapy techniques have enabled more precise treatment aiming to avoid any normal tissues and deliver higher doses directly to the tumour in fewer fractions. This means that 5 x 7Gy fractions (35 x 7Gy) and less commonly 4 x 9Gy fractions (36 x 9Gy) can be used. These new techniques are also known as hypofractionation. The latest techniques also use image guidance to ensure that the tumour is treated with the most accurate precision. Current conventional radiotherapy machines require a special scanner to be able to track the prostate during the treatment. This is done using small electronic markers inserted into the prostate tissue which are only visible when imaged with the specialist scanner. However one major draw back is that the prostate moves within the body due to rectal gas or urinary bladder filling between the time of the planning CT scan and the time of the actual radiotherapy treatment. This is particularly true with the 3-5 x 2.5-3Gy fraction schedules that are currently considered too aggressive, as the prostate movements are much greater than for the lower fraction radiotherapy schedules. If the prostate moves more than 2-3mm during the treatment it can cause a severe complication known as rectal toxicity. Prostate motion due to bladder filling can also lead to overdosing of an area of the prostate, potentially worsening the side effects for bladder function. The purpose of this study is to develop a new system that measures precisely the real-time movement of the prostate inside the body and corrects for this by moving the radiotherapy beam to prevent overdose to the bladder and ensuring that the prostate is always correctly positioned for the treatment. The new system will also allow for the delivery of more precise radiotherapy to the prostate while minimizing bowel and urinary side effects.
Objectives: The primary purpose of this study is treatment and to prove the therapeutic ability of 3 fractions of prostate SBRT (Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy). The secondary purposes are the study of radiation side effects and patient experience.
Primary goal: Our main study goal is to treat 40 patients with 3 fractions of prostate SBRT (Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy). We aim to show that 3 fractions of SBRT can be performed without severe urinary or bowel side effects, while also giving a dose of radiation therapy high enough to cure the cancer. We also aim to minimize the risk of long-standing side effects to the bowel, bladder and erectile function in addition to treating the cancer.
Secondary goals: We also aim to study patient experience and quality of life, assessed using various standardised questionnaires, in order to understand the impact on men who undergo prostate SBRT. We will also assess the immediate side effects of the radiotherapy using objective side effect assessment. This is important in determining how safe and effective prostate SBRT with 3 fractions is in routine clinical practice.
Methodology: This is an international phase II clinical trial. Patients with low and favorable intermediate risk prostate cancer who are already in routine clinical follow up will be offered the opportunity to participate in a study called the PRECISION study. The patient will be taken through an information sheet in the outpatients clinic before deciding to take part and will have ample opportunity to understand the requirements and benefits of participating in a trial. Overall, the goal of this study was to determine the influence of using low-level laser (LLLT) during mini-implant-assisted intrusion of maxillary anterior teeth on root resorption. The hypothesis was that the low-power density laser device reduces the extent of root resorption in Class II patients who are receiving orthodontic treatment for deep overbite through the application of mini-implants over the upper incisors.
The data collected from this project is promising and indicated that the LLLT application was associated with a reduction in OIIRR, although further studies are needed to obtain more reliable results. Objective: To examine whether the Cawthorne Cooksey exercises increase balance and quality of life in children with hearing deficits. Hypotheses: Hypothesis 1 : Cawthorne Cooksey exercises increase balance ability in children with hearing deficits. Hypothesis 2: Cawthorne Cooksey exercises improve the quality of life in children with hearing deficits. Methods:  In the first study step, descriptive and comparative statistical methods were used to determine the balance levels, quality of life statuses and demographic characteristics of the participants. Then, 30 participants were randomly assigned to a control group (10) and two experimental groups: group 1 (10) performing the Cawthorne Cooksey exercises on the Swiss ball, and group 2 (10) performing the Cawthorne Cooksey exercises without Swiss ball. Both groups participated in training with Cawthorne Cooksey exercises 5 days a week, an hour a day, for six weeks. A total of 6 weeks of measurements was made before and after the training period. The Pediatric Berg Balance Scale and Four-Step Square Test results were used to analyze the changes in balance. The CHOICES-22 and Children's Hearing Care Assessment Short Form scales were used to analyze the changes in quality of life. The age, education status, sex, hearing impairment etiology and duration, vestibular impairment, auditory impairment, other neurological or orthopedic disease and medication status, were recorded as demographic characteristics and their changes. Statistical: Kolmogorov-Smirnov test was used for normal distribution of the study variables. In the analysis between the groups, Student t-test was used for parametric measurements, and Mann Whitney U test was used for nonparametric measurements. Wilcoxon signed-rank test was used for within-group changes, and to compare the pre and post training values.
Participants with hearing deficits between the ages of 7 and 12. Pediatric Berg Balance Scale (pedBB); Children's Hearing Care Assessment Parent Questionnaire; The Four-Step Square Test, the Turkish Standards Authority for Children and Adolescents Pediatric Functional Activity Scale (TFAS). This study will not be conducted outside the province.

Research question: What is the psychological impact on women with GTN who have completed chemotherapy treatment? Objectives: Gaining insight into the emotional impact of diagnosis and treatment experienced by women following the completion of treatment Ascertaining if health professionals are providing adequate psychological support Identifying sources of support that patients accessed post completion of treatment Identifying potential areas of improvement in the follow up support for future patients. Abstract: Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia is highly curative but can have psychological consequences for women due to the nature of the diagnosis. Little is known about the psychological impact of diagnosis and treatment experienced by women following completion of treatment. As the specialist centre for GTN in the North of the UK, it is important to understand the experiences and care needs of our patients. The aim of the study is to explore women's experiences following treatment, how they managed any negative impacts and investigate if there is gap in the follow up support provided to patients after treatment. The study aims to have 20 participants who received chemotherapy. Semi-structured telephone interviews will be conducted; each interview will be digitally recorded and transcribed verbatim. Thematic analysis will be used to generate in depth descriptions of the patients experiences. The findings will enable health care professionals working closely with this unique group of patients to gain some understanding of the patient perspective; recommendations will be made to improve the support and provision of care these patients receive after their treatment has completed. Aim: The aim of the study is to explore the experiences of women with GTN following completion of chemotherapy Plan of investigation: Methodology A cross-sectional retrospective study of a sample of 20 women who completed single agent or multi agent chemotherapy: between 6 weeks and 24 months post treatment involving a semi structured telephone interview. This is felt to be appropriate as this topic has received very little research attention for this rare disease and the study aims to capture the patients' own descriptions of their symptoms and experiences. The timeline will capture different perspectives from the varying treatments that patients received, this may provide valuablet insight into patient experiences during different time points. Telephone interviews will be conducted to gain insight into the patient's experiences. The rationale for using the telephone method is based on the geographical location of our patients. It is not feasible for the investigators to travel to individual homes to conduct the interviews or ask patients to travel. This method has the advantage in that it is relatively inexpensive. The telephone interview offers a robust method of eliciting information from patients about the quality of their care which could help to design improved services. The telephone interviews were designed following discussions with the clinical team and with the aim of answering the research question. Setting All interviews will be recorded via telephone and take place at Weston Park Hospital. The principal investigator will be responsible for negotiating dates and times of the interview and contacting the participants the day before to ensure they are still available for the scheduled interview. The principal investigator will ensure a designated quiet room is available for the interviews without any interruptions. Each interview will be digitally recorded and transcribed verbatim using an external company- Lawson Hardwick Limited 1st class secretarial services. An hour will be allocated for each interview. Sample A patient sample of 20 is proposed for the study. These are all the patients who meet the inclusion criteria below and are thus eligible for the study. These patients will be contacted via telephone by the principal investigator to inform them of the study and invite participation. A proposal of 20 is sufficient to generate data to address the central questions and furthermore, this sample size is adequate because the intention is to gain insight into the experiences of patients' perceptions about their psychological experiences post chemotherapy. Criteria for inclusion: Treated with chemotherapy for a GTN diagnosis Completed treatment between 6 weeks and 24 months Are able to provide informed consent Have no cognitive impairment as judged by the treating clinician Criteria for exclusion Treatment received less than 6 weeks ago Treatment received more than 24 months ago Non-English speaking Recruitment Each of the participants will receive a written information leaflet via email with the details of the nature of study and a written consent form for them to return back. However outputs from this study include increasing knowledge and insight into: patients' experiences of their psychological experiences post chemotherapy patients' perspective of the support received after their treatment potential areas of improvements in care Analysis Thematic analysis will be used to generate in depth descriptions of the patients experiences. Fracture of the distal radius has been reported to be the most common wrist fracture. An open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation of the displaced distal radius fracture is considered to be the gold standard treatment for these patients. However, open wedge corrective osteotomy of the distal radius often leads to a gap in the distal fragment. Furthermore, a decrease in the distal fragment may be more common. In addition, there are numerous studies demonstrating that open wedge corrective osteotomy of the distal radius results in a reduction of the width of the ulna. Open wedge corrective osteotomy with bone grafting of the iliac crest is suggested to avoid the widening of the distal fragment.
There is limited evidence about the effect of bone grafting in open wedge corrective osteotomy of the distal radius. The aim of this study is to evaluate and compare the complication rates, time to complete bone healing, subjective functional outcomes, objective functional outcomes, cost effectiveness and Quality of life of patients with symptomatic distal radial malunion receiving bone grafting compared to those receiving no bone grafting during an operation with open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation to the ulna bone on the basis of published and unpublished studies.
The current trial is designed as a prospective multi-centre randomised controlled trial and is undertaken at 10 different medical facilities. 74 patients will be included in the study. In one group of the study, the bone defect in the distal radius will be filled with autologous bone from the iliac crest during the primary operation. The other group will consist of patients who will not receive any additional bone graft from iliac.
The primary outcome of the trial will be an absolute reduction in the rate of complications and non-unions when the open wedge corrective osteotomy with bone grafting from the iliac crest is made. Further outcomes will include quality of life measured with the EQ-5D-5L questionnaire for up to one year after surgery and time to complete bone healing for up to one year after surgery.

Introduction
-----------------
Chronic non-specific neck pain (NSNCP) is a prevalent and disabling musculoskeletal health and work problem. Despite effective treatments, such as exercise, education, and manual therapy, there are several problems regarding their implementation. In particular, a majority of patients (30-70%) with chronic NSNCP do not consult healthcare providers or do not follow the treatment recommendations. For this reason, patients' preferences and lifestyles are often not taken into account and treatment non-compliance may hamper the effectiveness of rehabilitation. These gaps have to be addressed in order to offer optimized patient management, minimize healthcare costs and increase the chances of recovery. In this regard, new strategies such as tele-rehabilitation seem to be promising, especially in the context of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic.
In recent years, virtual reality (VR) have been used in the rehabilitation of patients with various health problems, such as stroke, arthritis, cardiovascular diseases, acute pain and post-traumatic stress disorder. In the field of musculoskeletal disorders, VR have several advantages such as the possibility to perform exercises in a virtual environment, the possibility to make exercises with a lot of repetition and immediate feedback to the patient, the possibility to adapt the exercises to the individual needs and abilities of patients, and the possibility to train in a safe and controlled environment. Despite their benefits, there are still no VR systems for chronic NSNCP that take into account therapeutic education and acceptability. The purpose of the present study is to assess the feasibility, acceptability and usability of a tele-rehabilitation consisting of VR exercises and therapeutic education. The investigators will conduct a pilot study before conducting a randomized clinical trial.
Methods
-----------------
Ethics
-----------------
The study was approved by the local institutional review board (University Hospitals of Strasbourg, France, H 2201309). Since this is a feasibility study, the study was conducted without the signature of an informed consent.
Design
-----------------
This pilot study will be conducted according to a single-arm protocol in a 6-weeks period. After the inclusion visit, patients will receive a brochure on the use of VR for pain and will be instructed on how to perform the virtual reality exercises. These exercises will be based on the principles of gradual exposure, cognitive restructuring and attention diversion. Patients will receive 5 VR sessions per week, for 20 minutes each session, using the Pico G2 4K headset. The Virtual Reality exercises will target different aspects of NSNCP, such as pain, stiffness, and activities of daily living. Patients will also receive 1 teleconsultation session via Skype with a physiotherapist (15 minutes). During this session, the physiotherapist will discuss the information provided in the educational brochures. The number of sessions will be fixed to 5 to allow a maximum number of sessions while ensuring that patients have sufficient time for social and professional activities.
Participants
-----------------
Patients will be included if they provide a written informed consent, are 18 years or older, have a diagnosis of chronic NSNCP (defined as having persisting neck pain for more than 3 months), are fluent in French, and are able to use the Pico G2 4K. Patients will be excluded if they have an exclusion criterion such as osteoarthritis or a specific somatic cause of neck pain, a tumor/cancer, a fracture, a trauma, an inflammatory disease, an infection, a compression or a lesion of the spinal cord, a surgery of the cervical spine, a recent stroke (within the last 3 months), a vascular pathology, a neurological pathology, a ligamentous lesion of the upper cervical spine, a congenital disease of the cervical spine, chronic diffuse pain, or a visual or cognitive impairment that interferes with the understanding or performance of the virtual reality exercises.
Before starting the virtual reality exercises, all patients will receive an individualized education with an adapted brochure. This educational brochure will be based on the general principles of pain, the persistence of pain, tips for managing chronic non-specific neck pain, and the use of virtual reality in the rehabilitation of chronic non-specific neck pain. During the 6 weeks of intervention, educational and therapeutic sessions (at 7 days and at 4 weeks) will be provided by Skype video call or on telephone, according to the patients

Liver transplantation can completely cure liver cancer, but there are too few donor livers, and the condition for enrolling patients with HCC is not uniform, which means that many patients may not have access to transplantation. In addition, patients with liver cirrhosis and HCC are often considered a contraindication for liver transplantation, and the shortage of suitable liver donors leads to a large number of unresectable liver cancer patients. Now the latest left hemiliver donor liver transplantation, sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT) can obtain an adult donor liver, expand the donor pool for liver transplantation, and avoid the disadvantages of liver transplantation. The purpose of this study is to explore the safety and effectiveness of SALT and to establish the survival curves of OS and DFS in follow-up patients to assess the safety and effectiveness of SALT in patients with cirrhosis and HCC.

The purpose of this research is to evaluate the validity and reliability of a new, portable dexterity measurement tool. This tool is an automated system that will measure the force exerted by the patient's thumb and index finger as they play a simple game. It takes less than 10 minutes to administer the game.
The researchers are also interested in the change in dexterity over time in patients with degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) due to a herniated disc in the neck compressing the spinal cord. Dexterity is a common symptom in patients with myelopathy. By establishing the validity of this novel research tool, it is hoped that the tool can be used to track changes in dexterity in patients with spinal cord disease over time. This tool might help us understand how dexterity changes over time and how well it correlates with other assessments of changes in strength, sensation, and function. This will help researchers understand both the natural disease course in patients with myelopathy, as well as the effectiveness of various treatments for myelopathy. Moreover, because this tool is portable and does not require a skilled examiner to administer the measurement, researchers feel that this tool could easily be used to help guide treatment decisions for individual patients.

Patients with myelopathy experience a range of symptoms such as weakness, numbness, and difficulty with coordination. Myelopathy may cause progressive weakness and difficulty with movement as well. The most common symptoms are generally associated with the hand and fingers. Dextroous movements may be slow, shaky, or incoordinated. This game requires the use of the index and thumb of each hand to play. The researchers expect that this game system will specifically evaluate movement and strength in the distal part of the upper extremity.

Nipple discharge is a relatively common clinical problem, and in most cases non-cancerous. The vast majority of it can be diagnosed safely by careful clinical evaluation and non-invasive diagnostic methods. However, there are still some studies, showing that as much as half of the discharging ducts can not be traced, particularly in ductus lactifer in the area of the areola, and for this reason, traditional needle puncture has a poor sensitivity for this disorder. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the usefulness of delayed imaging of contrast-enhanced spectral mammography (CESM) in assessing pathological nipple discharge.

In the past two decades, the survival of heart transplantation (HTx) has been improving due to better medical and surgical treatments. Despite the fact of good graft function, patients still face many unfavorable long-term complications such as cardiac allograft vasculopathy (CAV), chronic rejection, and myocarditis. In recent years, post-heart transplant organ rejection and long-term survival were mainly associated with dyslipidemias. The aim of this prospective study was to verify the link between dyslipidemias and graft rejection. Sixty patients who had recently donated and received heart transplantation were monitored for 4 years. The patients were divided into two groups: Group 1 included 28 patients with good post-transplant function (G/P-); and group II included 29 patients without graft function (G/P+). Blood lipid measurements (TG, TC, HDL-C, LDL-C, ApoB) was obtained and compared both at baseline and at end of the follow-up between groups. The ejection fraction (EF), a non-invasive indicator of cardiac function, as well as left ventricular (LV) mass and volumes were evaluated both at baseline and end of the follow-up. Patients and donors' demographics were similar in the two groups. The results showed no statistically significant difference in the blood lipid and lipoprotein parameters studied between groups at the beginning of the study. However, after 4-year follow-up, in the patients with good post-transplant function, TG was reduced from 1.53 ± 0.68 mmol/L at baseline to 1.17 ± 0.56 mmol/L. In contrast, TC and LDL-C concentrations remained unchanged, 4.75 ± 2.43 vs 5.12 ± 2.74 mmol/L, respectively. In the graft function impaired patients, dyslipidemias and especially postprandial hypertriglyceridemia were clearly observed after 4 years, characterized by a sharp increase in TG from 1.22 ± 0.66 mmol/L at baseline to 1.76 ± 0.86 mmol/L (P<0.01), without a significant change in the rest of the lipid/lipoprotein parameters studied. A significant increase in the cardiac left ventricular mass index was observed in the group with impaired graft function, rising from 76.19 ± 29.84 to 86.97 ± 30.64 g/m2 (P<0.01). Multivariate regression analysis shows that graft function impairment is associated with a significant increase in post-heparin triglycerides (P<0.001) LVMI (P<0.05), and a significant decrease in post-heparin HDL-C (P<0.05) compared to the group with good graft function. Moreover, univariate regression analysis shows that the risk factors of hypertriglyceridemias after heart transplantation is associated with a high BMI, male sex, the lack of per-operative lipid-lowering therapy, graft function impairment and higher post-heart transplantation lipoprotein(a) concentration, with an odds ratio (OR) of 9.96, 8.27, 10.77, 24.78 and 3.14 respectively for risk factors. Therefore there is a strong association between post-heart transplantation post-prandial hypertriglyceridemia and graft function impairment. As the study duration will extended, it will help us to better understand how dyslipidemias affect heart transplants.

Women with stress urinary incontinence, predominantly caused by weak pelvic floor muscles, have limited treatment options. In particular, effective in-person pelvic floor physical therapy is difficult, limited and expensive to access. Many women will delay seeking care for years and are usually forced to try and do unsupervised pelvic floor exercises on their own. Virtual pelvic floor physical therapy has been developed and provides a form of biofeedback to assist with strengthening pelvic floor muscles. This study will determine the effectiveness of the product, Pelex Upp, which uses biofeedback to improve pelvic floor muscles strength. Women with stress urinary incontinence will be randomized to use an FDA approved pelvic floor trainer for four weeks and/or receive virtual pelvic floor physical therapy from trained physiotherapists to improve strength of pelvic floor muscles. All participants will fill out questionnaires before and after treatment to answer the study's main question: Are women who use a biofeedback-guided pelvic floor trainer plus virtual pelvic floor physical therapy more likely to see improvement in stress urinary incontinence symptoms compared to women who just use a pelvic floor trainer for four weeks or women who just undergo virtual pelvic floor physical therapy for four weeks?

The proposed study, guided by MOST, evaluates the role of three evidence-based strategies that may improve attendance to the Community Wise (CW) intervention and increase its effectiveness at reducing Alcohol and Substance Misuse (ASM) in a population affected by poverty and inequitable access to health resources. CW is a treatment program for alcohol and substance misuse that was originally developed for previously incarcerated individuals. The primary aim of CW is to reduce substance misuse behavior. Preliminary work has shown CW effectiveness in decreasing alcohol and substance misuse in a population affected by poverty and inequitable access to health resources. Despite strong interest across multiple states, only nine individuals have participated in an effectiveness trial. Unfortunately, attendance across the 15 intervention sessions was low (only 15% of participants attended 50% of the sessions). Low attendance was attributed to the intervention's closed group format, the study's randomization strategy, and instability of the study's population (homelessness, poverty). Specifically, participants were recruited from social service agencies, which resulted in individuals without substance misuse concerns joining the study as well. To remedy the low attendance problem, we will conduct a 23 full factorial experiment to examine the interactive effects of recruitment and incentivization, as well as group participation format, on intervention attendance. This study is important as it will inform the optimization of the CW intervention, to maximize its effectiveness in helping marginalized communities address chronic ASM.

hemorrhoids are a common condition affecting the anal canal and may vary from little bulges to large, prolapsing hemorrhoids. Hemorrhoids are classified as internal (protruding above dentate line) or external (outside the anus). This condition is common, affects men and women of all ages, and its prevalence increases with age. Symptoms of hemorrhoids include bleeding and pain may accompany. Pain after hemorrhoidectomy is common, and most patients have some element of post-hemorrhoidectomy pain.
botulinum toxins (BoNT) can be used for hemorrhoidal diseases, as it works by relaxing the internal anal sphincter. In addition, pain after hemorrhoidectomy is probably caused by an increase in activity of internal anal sphincter, due to the release of a hyperalgesic substance in the area of injury. Several studies have demonstrated that botox injection may increase urinary continence in patients with urinary incontinence and may improve post-hemorrhoidectomy pain.
This study aims to compare the effect of a single dose of botox and internal sphincterotomy in the control of pain after hemorrhoidectomy, with the aim of comparing the analgesic effect of these two methods.
For this reason, the investigators intend to conduct a prospective, randomized study with 2 groups to compare the effect of Botox and internal sphincterotomy in post-hemorrhoidectomy pain. We hypothesize that the pain in the first few weeks after hemorrhoidectomy will be less in the group undergoing botox injection or surgery compared to the group undergoing only hemorrhoidectomy. The investigators aim to demonstrate the effectiveness of these techniques in pain control after hemorrhoidectomy while minimizing post-hemorrhoidectomy pain. The main objective of this study is to compare the analgesic efficacy between hemorrhoidectomy alone, hemorrhoidectomy + internal sphincterotomy and hemorrhoidectomy + botox injection in post hemorrhoidectomy pain. The investigators aim to demonstrate the effectiveness of these techniques in controlling pain after hemorrhoidectomy..

Background: Previous clinical studies have shown that 10%-30% of patients with colorectal liver metastases develop a recurrence within five years after curative local treatment. In the absence of effective adjuvant therapy, the recurrence rate of patients with colorectal liver metastases is still very high after curative local treatment. Based on the above reasons, this study aims to investigate the clinical effect and safety of fruquintinib in colorectal cancer patients with no evidence of disease(NED) after local treatment and adjuvant chemotherapy.
Objective: Study the clinical effect and safety of fruquintinib maintenance treatment in patients with colorectal liver metastases who achieved NED after adjuvant chemotherapy.
Methodology: This is a prospective, single-arm, phase II study aimed at exploring the clinical efficacy and safety of fruquintinib as maintenance therapy for advanced CRC patients who achieve NED after adjuvant chemotherapy.

Veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and comorbid traumatic brain injury (mTBI) are less responsive to current psychotherapeutic and medications treatments. Methylphenidate (MPH), a psychostimulant with neurobiological mechanisms that differ from those of current PTSD treatment options, has been shown to improve cognitive function and mood in studies of individuals with ADHD and moderate and severe traumatic brain injury. In a small pilot study of the efficacy of MPH for subjective cognitive impairment (SCI) associated with PTSD and/or mTBI, members of the research team found that MPH resulted in not only a significant improvement in subjective and objective measures of cognitive functioning, but also a significant decrease in symptoms of both depression and PTSD. Based on this promising pilot study, the current trial, to be completed in two VA hospitals serving Veterans with PTSD and neurocognitive complaints, will assess the efficacy of MPH compared to placebo (PBO) for reducing PTSD and neurocognitive symptoms in participants with PTSD and without TBI. Additionally, the investigators will assess the impact of MPH compared to PBO on neurocognitive functioning and the impact of mTBI on treatment response to MPH for the treatment of PTSD.

Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) is a syndrome characterized by recurrent abdominal pain accompanied by abdominal discomfort, changes in bowel habits, and abdominal bloating. It is a common condition, affecting approximately 10% of the population in Korea, and its chronic gastrointestinal symptoms significantly impact patients' daily life and quality of life. Factors such as changes in the intestinal microbiota and the intestinal ecosystem are crucial in its etiology. Modern individuals, who are often exposed to numerous stressors, frequently experience persistent intestinal hypersensitivity and inflammation. Foods that are not well digested and fermented in the intestines, producing a significant amount of gas - such as those rich in seasonings, dairy products, caffeine, and alcohol - are known to trigger symptoms. Therefore, it is suggested that a controlled environment like a Temple Stay, which provides both dietary regulation and stress control, could lead to meaningful symptom improvement. However, there is currently a lack of objective scientific research on this. Our research team hypothesizes that a Temple Stay experience of more than a week could consistently change the microbiome and stabilize psychosocial factors. This might control chronic intestinal inflammation and hypersensitivity, leading to subjective symptom improvement and enhanced treatment satisfaction for patients. Through this study, we aim to validate the hypothesis that the dietary changes in a Temple Stay environment will drastically alter patients' dietary intake, enrich the composition of the gut microbiome, and consequently reduce the symptoms of IBS, thereby improving the quality of life.
The official title of this study is "Temple Stay Improves Intestinal Microbiome Profile in Patients With Irritable Bowel Syndrome". The intervention/treatment includes both monk patients and ordinary patients staying in a temple as a control. The study is an observational study and the phase is not specified.
Monk patients staying in a temple over seven days will keep a detailed diary of their lifestyle, intake of dietary supplements, medication, and stool. They will also provide blood and fecal samples for the purpose of the survey, in addition to completing various questionnaires regarding stress, stress control, and lifestyle, among others. Data will also be collected based on a comparison to ordinary patients staying in a modern facility of the same nature as the retreat of monk practitioners.
Through this research, our goal is to confirm the effects of a temple stay - that is, dietary control and stress reduction - on intestinal inflammation and overall health improvement for patients with IBS.

The goal of the study is to assess asthma patients' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons as well as prescribers' willingness to prescribe for environmental reasons, at the patient's request. The study will also be assessing patient awareness of the climate impact of inhalers and the importance they attribute to this issue as well as other issues (cost and ease of use).

Eligible participants include English-speaking asthma patients (18 years of age or older) who have experienced no exacerbations of asthma in the last month and are followed in the chest clinic at the Montreal Chest Institute or the Montreal General Hospital. These participants will be randomized to either receive a low impact educational intervention or to receive standard care.

The educational intervention will involve giving the participant an infographic about the climate impact of inhalers, a letter explaining the option of changing inhalers, and a pre-filled prescription for a different inhaler (Bricanyl Turbuhaler) if they are interested in making a change for environmental reasons. The control group will receive standard care only.

Patients' awareness and perceptions of the climate impact of inhalers will be assessed at baseline using a questionnaire. The same questionnaire will be administered three months later to assess changes in attitudes and knowledge. The physicians who supervise the participants will also be included in the study and will be assessed on their perceptions of the climate impact of inhalers and their willingness to prescribe differently for environmental reasons.

The overall aim of the Validation of Hybrid Sleeve Gastroplasty trial is to evaluate the durability and efficacy of a new laparoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (LSG) device, Apollo's ESG System, which is designed to be used in laparoscopic sleeve gastroplasty surgery. The investigators also propose to investigate the association of the ESG System with decreasing blood pressure, decreasing hemoglobin A1C (HbA1C), and improving quality of life (QOL).
To achieve this aim, the investigators propose to enroll 90 subjects, randomized in a 1:1 fashion to hybrid or traditional ESG, who will be followed for 12 months. A second cohort of 50 subjects will be enrolled to provide a pool of subjects available to provide additional follow-up and to augment the primary safety and efficacy arms with larger sample sizes and a longer duration of follow-up, to meet target sample sizes for long-term follow-up.
There will be 4 data-gathering visits in this trial: baseline visit, 6-week visit, 6-month visit, and 12-month visit. Subjects in both arms will undergo ESG procedures under general anesthesia in an outpatient setting and will be followed for 12 months. All subjects will be contacted by phone for quality-of-life assessments at 3- and 9-month intervals, to assess health status and other secondary outcomes. After the 12-month visit, subjects will continue to be followed via telephone-only contacts (performed by study staff) on a monthly basis.
Study Endpoints:
Primary Outcomes:
- The primary outcomes are durability of plications and endoscopic sutures on repeat endoscopy at 6 months, in the two randomized arms.
Secondary Outcomes:
All subjects will undergo Quality of Life (QOL) assessments using the validated Short Form Health Survey (SF-36) Questionnaire, the validated Impact of Weight on Quality of Life-Lite (IWQOL-Lite) Questionnaire, and the validated Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) Questionnaire. Subjects will have an additional QOL assessment performed by telephone call at 3 and 9 months. Weight loss will be assessed using percent total body weight loss (%TBWL) and percent excess weight loss (%EWL) as per standard Bariatric practice. The duration of follow-up postoperatively for patients is 12 months.
The investigators hypothesize that the use of the ESG System will prove to be:
1. As safe and tolerable as standard ESG procedures, as per the US FDA clearance for the ESG System.
2. Efficacious in producing clinically significant weight loss, as evidenced by at least 10kg of excess weight loss in at least 75% of the ESG System Hybrid patients at 6 months, and comparable improvements in blood pressure and HbA1C levels by 6 months.
3. Associated with an immediate positive impact on co-morbid conditions and patient-reported outcomes, as evidenced by changes in subject-reported quality of life on QOL questionnaires and changes in hemoglobin A1C (HbA1c) levels by 6 months.

In COPD patients, dyspnea, fatigue, and sleep disturbances are common symptoms. Dyspnea and fatigue are two symptoms experienced by over 90% of COPD patients and cause quality of life problems, decrease the distance of the patients when walking and also cause a decrease in the activity of the patients. These symptoms not only affect the activities of the patients, but also cause a decrease in their quality of life and increase the fatigue of the patients.
According to the literature, in COPD patients, dyspnea, fatigue, and sleep disturbance are common symptoms. It was stated that these symptoms negatively affect the functional and quality of life status of the patients. These symptoms not only decrease the activity of the patients, but also cause a decrease in the activity of the patients. It is stated that when relaxation exercises are applied, it may be positive in terms of decreasing these symptoms. Dyspnea and fatigue are two symptoms experienced by over 90% of COPD patients. In COPD patients, dyspnea, fatigue, and sleep disturbances are common symptoms.
Purpose: To investigate the effect of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) and Breathing deep (WB) exercises training on dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of sleep in patients diagnosed with COPD.
Study Population and Design: It will be a single group assignment and randomized controlled clinical trial. Eight weeks 170-person outpatient clinic volunteer patients with mild to moderate COPD who meet the inclusion criteria will be included in the study. In the random assignment process, half of the group will comprise relaxation exercises and the other half will be given breathing deep exercises training.
Intervention/Treatment: The PMR exercise, which includes the systematic relaxation of the main muscle groups of the body aimed at physical and psychological relaxation, was applied twice a day, every weekday, for eight weeks. PMR exercises and training on the application of these exercises were given to the patients individually by face-to-face interview method. During the training process, Muscle Relaxation Exercises Practice Guide and Relaxation Exercises Audio Recordings, which were prepared by the researcher and included relaxation exercises, were used. Voice recordings were uploaded to each patient's mobile phone so that they could continue the application at home. The steps of the relaxation exercises were explained to the patient by the researcher and he was shown exactly how to do the exercises.
All patients will have the same exercise at the same frequency. Intervention/Treatment will be applied for 8 weeks. The patients, who will form the study group after random assignment, will be given PMR exercises training. Deep Breath exercises training was given to the patients in this group individually by face-to-face interview. During the application, the importance of deep and comfortable breathing was explained and correct breathing technique was taught. Informing and application training took an average of 20-25 minutes for each patient. The patients were told to do the 10-minute application at home 3 times a day for 8 weeks. They were called once a week and asked whether they continued the practice and whether they had any difficulties during the exercises.

Introduction:
Functional assessments (such as fractional flow reserve (FFR) or coronary flow reserve (CFR)) are currently the gold standard for guiding revascularization decisions. However, these indices are less accurate at lower grade stenosis (< 70%). Coronary intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) and coronary ultrasound flow ratio (UFR) are promising functional indices applicable to a larger range of coronary stenosis, and their ability to predict the need for revascularization in intermediate coronary lesions has been investigated intensively. However, there is currently no head-to-head comparison of the diagnostic performances of these two techniques.
Objective:
The study intends to compare the diagnostic performance of UFR as measured by an IVUS pullback vs. a pressure wire in determining the presence of functionally-significant coronary stenosis based on flow-limiting FFR stenoses < 50%, and provide cut-offs of pressure (UFR) and IVUS (FFR) for predicting functional significance of coronary stenosis.
Hypothesis:
The ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) has a better diagnostic accuracy for prediction of a flow-limiting stenosis than FFR.
Methods:
In this multicenter, prospective, non-randomized study, consecutive patients undergoing FFR due to intermediate coronary lesions will be included. A pressure wire-based FFR will be performed, followed by an IVUS pull-back. The UFR will also be calculated by using the IVUS pull-back. The primary endpoint will be a comparison of the diagnostic accuracies of UFR between pressure-FFR and IVUS-FFR to predict stenoses with FFR < 0.80 at individual patient and lesion levels. Additionally, the diagnostic accuracy of UFR to predict stenoses with FFR < 0.80 at individual vessel-level and the relationship between UFR and physiological parameters will also be analyzed.
Discussion:
This study may further provide a clinical cut-off of pressure and IVUS parameters for prediction of a flow-limiting stenosis and guide the revascularization decision. The result of this study is expected to have significant implications for diagnosing and treating coronary artery disease.

Burnout, defined as an exhaustion that is difficult to recover, is one of the most common adverse responses of caregivers to nursing work. The Chinese Balint (CB) method, which originated in China, is a working form that focuses on the professional doctor-patient relationship, and its effect on the work status of caregivers has not been well studied.
This randomized, controlled, single-group assignment trial aims to assess and compare the effect of CB activities for Chinese nurse leaders with no participation in CB activities (non-CB). A total of 125 Chinese nurse leaders with burnout symptoms were recruited in the study and allocated into the experimental or non-intervention groups. MBI-HSS, GSES and EKR scale were conducted to evaluate their burnout and self-efficacy.
The results of the study will provide valuable evidence on the effect of Balint group activities on burnout and self-efficacy of Chinese nurse leaders.

Study Overview
=================
Detailed Description
-----------------
Background Long COVID is the persistent presence of symptoms and/or health effects beyond three months after the diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection. Post-acute COVID-19 or prolonged fatigue is one of the predominant subgroups of Long COVID and it is estimated to affect 10-20% of patients who have recovered from SARS-CoV-2 infection. Post-acute COVID-19 has also been reported to be associated with cognitive impairments, and the prevalence of cognitive impairments in patients with prolonged fatigue subgroups was found to be 25%, which can have significant implications on one's daily functioning and quality of life. Several studies have demonstrated that non-pharmacological treatments, such as aerobic exercise training, have shown improved cognitive function and quality of life in patients with Long COVID. Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM)-based non-pharmacological interventions have also been found to improve cognitive function and fatigue in people with mild cognitive impairment. In addition, TCM-based acupuncture has shown promising effects on mood disturbance and various symptoms in anxiety and depression, postoperative pain, and chronic insomnia. However, the effects of TCM-based acupuncture, lifestyle modification, and combined acupuncture and lifestyle modification on cognitive impairments in people with Long COVID has not been evaluated. Objectives The aim of this study is to assess the effectiveness of TCM-based acupuncture + lifestyle modification, TCM-based lifestyle modification alone, and acupuncture alone on cognitive function, health-related quality of life, fatigue, and psychological distress in patients with Long COVID. Methods First, a meta-systemic evaluation of currently available RCTs on the management of Long COVID will be conducted. Second, the investigators will conduct a modified Delphi method to systematically examine the prevalence and nature of cognitive impairments in Asian patients with Long COVID. Third, the investigators will conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT) comparing the effectiveness of TCM-based acupuncture+ lifestyle modification, TCM-based lifestyle modification alone, and acupuncture alone on the management of patients with Long COVID. In this RCT, up to 192 patients with Long COVID will be recruited and randomly assigned to the following three treatment conditions: 1. Experimental: acupuncture only; 2. Experimental: lifestyle modification only; and 3. Experimental: acupuncture plus lifestyle modification. The assessment of primary and secondary outcome measures will be conducted before and after the interventions using standardized scales and tests. The investigators will aim to recruit 64 participants for each treatment condition, and the interventions of these conditions will be conducted over 8 weeks.

Official Title
-----------------
Testing Non-pharmacological TCM-based Interventions for Cognitive Impairment in People With Long COVID Symptoms: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Conditions
-----------------
Long Covid19

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Behavioral: Acupuncture and TCM-based lifestyle management

Exclusion Criteria: Having any severe cognitive impairment, mood disorder, or anxiety disorder before SARS-CoV-2 infection. Having any current psychiatric disorders that require taking medication. Having any current medical conditions that could interfere with cognitive functions. Having epilepsy or any other unstable medical conditions. Having alcoholism or drug abuse within the past 1 year. Having bleeding tendency. Having severe needle phobia. Having heart pacemaker or other electronic devices implanted in the body. Currently participating in another research studies or clinical trials.

Breast cancer is one of the most common cancers among women. The detection of symptoms at an early stage, the reduction of risk factors in order not to develop cancer, the use of preventive measures against cancer and the early diagnosis and treatment of cancer are important in reducing morbidity and mortality from cancer. The aim of studies in this field is usually to improve early diagnosis. Breast cancer awareness training is an important factor in reducing morbidity and mortality from breast cancer by identifying breast cancer and having early diagnosis. In the breast cancer education process, after the awareness education given to the individuals, it is thought to have a supportive effect in terms of early diagnosis and healthy lifestyle behaviors by providing follow-up and counseling to the individuals. There is a lack of research literature in the literature on the effect of counselling and follow-up after breast cancer education on the risks factor, modifiable and non-modifiable, and the risk behaviors of breast cancer in terms of early diagnosis and healthy lifestyle behaviors. Although there are many studies on breast cancer education, there is no study that examines the effect of counseling and follow-up after breast cancer education on the risks factor and breast cancer risk behaviors in the literature. There is only one study in the literature on early diagnosis behaviors and healthy lifestyle behaviors in breast cancer education. The aim of this study to investigate the effect of counseling and follow-up after breast cancer education on early diagnosis behaviors and healthy lifestyle behaviors in terms of the modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors of breast cancer. In this study, breast self-examination, clinical breast examination, mammography, routine medical check-up and healthy lifestyle behaviors in terms of health responsibility, physical activity, nutrition, spiritual development, interpersonal relationships and stress management behaviors will be examined in individuals who will continue with counseling and follow-up after breast cancer eduation. The effect of counseling and follow-up after breast cancer education on the risk behaviors of breast cancer will be revealed in the study and the knowledge and application level of the individuals participating in the study will be revealed. This information will be very useful in the determination of nursing interventions for the healthy life of individuals in breast cancer education programs.

Chronic pain (CP) has long been known as a major health concern, impacting psychological health, functioning, and quality of life by influencing daily activities and overall life perception. However, it is a challenging health problem with complex pathways that make it hard to properly diagnose and find the appropriate treatments. While the general population is affected by pain, the elderly or those with underlying pathology or chronic disease are more sensitive to acute, subacute, or chronic pain. This means that CP is a multifaceted manifestation and a condition that requires multiple perspectives to fully understand. The complexity of CP and the lack of information on the best approach in managing chronic pain is challenging and leads to dissatisfaction among patients and medical professionals, in particular given the lack of objective parameters that can capture the complexity of CP and its evolution over time. Today, the standard treatment of CP is based on non-pharmacological approaches, with a variety of therapeutic interventions focused on non-specific physical activity, rehabilitation, physiotherapy, and medications to address specific pain symptoms. However, these treatment modalities have variable effects on CP symptoms and often show limited effectiveness.
The use of wearable digital sensors for pain management in both controlled and uncontrolled environments have recently increased and are becoming more frequent in research and clinical practice. Wearable sensors (temperature, pressure, acceleration, heart rate variability, gait, posture, electroencephalogram, electrodermal activity) provide the opportunity to monitor pain through objective evidence and provide medical professionals with quantitative data to better understand CP and the effectiveness of therapeutic interventions. These data have a unique opportunity to uncover the nature of physical pain and its correlation with psychological and emotional factors, but until now no such solution is available. In this context, the investigator intends to develop a novel pain assessment for CP patients through the use of wearable sensing technology and Artificial Intelligence tools.
The pAIn-sense project aims at the introduction of a novel, Artificial Intelligence (AI)-based technology for the monitoring and treatment of chronic pain, providing multidisciplinary real-life data about pain physiology and psychology while quantifying its correlation with treatment outcomes and efficacy. The overarching goal is to improve the quality of life for patients suffering from chronic pain, by providing real-life quantitative data about their pain experience that could foster medical treatments, optimize their outcomes and prevent further complications. To obtain that, the investigator will recruit chronic pain patients and monitor their pain, movement, sleep, stress, fatigue, drugs intake levels, as well as questionnaires and other psychological assessments, such as sleep quality, level of pain efficacy, pain catastrophizing, treatment expectation, and health status. Data will be collected during typical daily activities without requiring the patients to change their usual life habits. Through a rigorous analytical model, based on advanced artificial intelligence techniques, data will be integrated and used to characterize the nature of pain: physical, mental or both. The investigator will compare treatment outcomes with the type of pain identified.

This study will prospectively validate, implement in real-time, and assess the performance of an electronic health record (EHR)-based cancer prediction model for pancreatic cancer (PDAC). The investigators hypothesize that their EHR-based PDAC risk-prediction model will exhibit high performance and can be implemented in a clinically actionable fashion to direct and optimize screening for pancreatic cancer in the general community.
As in prior work, the investigators will apply two machine learning models, a neural network (PrismNN) and a logistic regression (PrismLR), that will use routinely collected EHR data to stratify individuals from the general population into PDAC risk groups. The risk models will operate using a "tiered system" approach to direct both screening intervention with biomarker testing for those medium-risk and screening intervention with either close monitoring or direct biopsy for high-risk individuals. This project will implement data-driven, predictive decision-making capabilities in the general population that could potentially optimize risk-based screening by providing objective guidance on who should be screened and when such measures should take place, based on population-specific risk as indicated by the predictive models. The ability of the PrismNN and PrismLR to correctly identify subjects at risk will be assessed by ROC calculations (including calibration of the estimates), PPV, and sensitivity. Tumor stage at diagnosis will be described.
For the prospective, biomedically blinded validation study, using the EHR-based risk prediction models (PrismNN and PrismLR) to prospectively predict subjects at risk for PDAC, as well as assessing their ability to predict clinical outcomes such as tumor stage at diagnosis will be prospectively validated. For the validation studies, the same 2 risk models (PrismNN and PrismLR) as previously described will be applied. Model development and validation will be performed using 4 HCOs, with the prospective validation for risk prediction at a separate HCO (TrialNetX). All 4 HCOs will contribute to the implementation and assessment of the risk-based screening program by the use of a "tiered system" for screening intervention with routine biochemical monitoring, and for those at higher risk, either advanced medical imaging, or direct biopsy as risk increases. We will recruit 44 organizations (i.e., HCOs) to participate in this study, and we plan to enroll 1.8 million individuals in the validation cohort of this study. Validation of the EHR-based models will be performed using the prospective cohort. Outcomes measured in the entire cohort will include age, sex, race, tumor stage at diagnosis, and screening and outcome information (see Outcome Measures). Only participants with new cases of PDAC, after the study was declared officially open in 2020, will have PDAC outcome data recorded and collected, as determined by review of their medical records. The primary purpose or intervention/treatment is diagnostic; patient data are only used for statistical modeling to determine a risk score.
Inclusion criteria: Inclusion Criteria: Inclusion Criteria:
Male or female between the ages of 40 and 100, inclusive.
2 or more clinic encounters within the past year to one of the HCOs, after January 1st, 2020 (declaration open date).

Exclusion Criteria:
Personal history of PDAC or current PDAC
Ages under 40 (below 18) years.

Accepts Healthy Volunteers: No

The purpose of this study is to examine whether a novel drug called 18F-PF-06445974 can be used accurately to quantify PDE4B in the human brain and to determine whether PDE4B is reduced in the brains of individuals with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), using PET scans. The investigators hope to learn whether the loss of PDE4B helps to account for the reduction of brain chemistry associated with depression. This study will take place at the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) in Bethesda, Maryland.
Study participants between 18 and 70 years of age, with and without Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), are eligible for this study. Healthy volunteer subjects will be enrolled from the Clinical Core of the NIMH Intramural Research Program (IRP), Intramural Research Facility Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience Branch. Participants with suspected MDD will be recruited through the NIH Clinical Center and through the NIMH Treatment, Outcomes, Access and Networks Center (TOAN Center). In order to join the study, participants must have symptoms of depression.
The study will require several visits to the hospital. At the first visit, up to 100 milliliters (1/2 cup) of blood will be collected for routine tests and for tests to be used to determine the amount of PDE4B produced by the participant's liver and kidneys. Participants will also be asked to complete a questionnaire concerning mental health and to have a short interview with a study clinical staff to discuss concerns about PET imaging. The study will conduct a brain MRI and a blood test to check hormone levels to see if they have been altered because of pregnancy. During the MRI, the participant will lie down, be asked to take off their glasses or contact lenses if possible, and have their head secured in a plastic ring with straps. A small, round magnet inside the scanner will cause a loud noise during imaging as the participant's blood vessels move slightly. Pills containing 18F-PF-06445974 will be given by mouth, after which a PET imaging procedure will be performed. The procedure involves lying on the back for 1-2 hours while images are taken using the PET scanner. For this examination, the participant's head will be positioned using a light, plastic frame that is tightened with elastic bands. Subjects will be given one or more more IV injections of 18F-PF-06445974 for a total dose of up to 24 millicuries (mCi). Pill-cam radio-transmission device (RC-6) will be used to confirm when the last administration of 18F-PF-06445974 occurs. PET imaging will be performed during 31 frames for 7 minutes duration each, on up to 10 occasions over about 2 hours.

Knee osteoarthritis (OA) is a very common disease with increasing number of patients as population ages. OA of the knee is defined as a progressive, degenerative condition which primarily affects the articular surface of the knee joint and occurs in patients over the age of 50 years. OA can significantly impact the quality of life of the patient and is therefore associated with high socio-economic burden. The development and progression of the disease may depend on the weight-bearing load on the knee joint which has not been well elucidated yet. Moreover, the exact role of knee joint flexion in osteoarthritis is still unknown.
Medial knee osteoarthritis is the most common subtype and results in a narrower joint space in the medial compartment as compared to the lateral compartment. Most studies have focussed on the medial compartment, which can lead to an incomplete view of the disease process. The assessment of the joint space in the lateral compartment, however, is highly relevant as the medial and lateral compartments of the knee are interdependent and can affect each other.
Our hypothesis is that: (1) the medial joint space will be narrower than the lateral joint space in symptomatic knees and (2) intra-articular joint space changes in the weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing knee will be greater in the medial joint space than in the lateral joint space.
The objective of this study is therefore to evaluate inter- and intra-compartmental differences in joint space width of the medial and lateral compartments of symptomatic knees in weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing conditions (1), both in OA grade 2 and 2-3. Furthermore, we will evaluate the intra-articular joint space changes in weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing conditions of the medial and lateral compartments (2). Additionally, the intra-articular joint space changes in knee flexion (2) will be evaluated.
We will test the hypothesis of interest that (1) in symptomatic knees the medial joint space will be narrower than the lateral joint space, both in OA grade 2 and 2-3, and (2) the intra-articular joint space changes in the weight-bearing knee position will be greater in the medial joint space than in the lateral joint space.

Swallowing dysfunction is a frequent complication in patients with PD and can ultimately lead to complications of aspiration pneumonia which contributes to mortality and morbidity in PD. Despite these risks, swallowing therapy currently lacks options for accountability, adherence and skill based exercises. This study will test the effectiveness of a novel at-home surface electromyography (sEMG) biofeedback app to improve swallowing safety and efficiency in patients with PD by providing personalized strength targets and skill-based exercises. An FDA approved office-based tool will be translated to a consumer-friendly tool at a fraction of the cost to improve accessibility and adherence. This project will not only improve the management of dysphagia in PD but also provide a practical tool that has the potential to reduce healthcare costs for this population. Aim 1: To determine if at-home biofeedback using the i-BiSSkApp improves swallowing swallowing safety and efficiency compared to traditional swallowing therapy in patients with PD. Primary Outcome Measures: a) Penetration Aspiration Scale (PAS) score, b) Total pharyngeal residue, and c) Eating Assessment Tool - 10 (EAT-10) will be compared between the group receiving biofeedback exercises using the i-BiSSkApp and the group receiving traditional swallowing therapy with a 4-week baseline period, 6-week of therapy and a 3-week maintenance phase (i.e. total intervention of 12 weeks). Secondary Outcome Measures: a) Penetration Aspiration Scale (PAS) score. Time Frame: We anticipate completion of the project within 24 months.

GLOBE-HPV is a survey study to explore the burden of infection with high-risk human papillomaviruses (HR HPV) in lower socioeconomic status populations in South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. GLOBE-HPV will measure HPV prevalence (point prevalence) and incidence (≥6-month persistent HPV) in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia, using a multi-country protocol for data collection, processing and interpretation. Two separate approaches will be implemented to estimate prevalence and incidence respectively. General principles of survey design and methodology will be described in the global master protocol. Multi-stage cluster random sampling or another applicable sampling strategy will be applied to ensure representativeness.

The surveys will rely on urine sampling as the primary study arm. Urine samples will be collected for HPV testing, along with data on demographics, socioeconomic status, sexual and reproductive history, attitudes towards and awareness and uptake of cervical cancer screening and HPV vaccination, and potential risk factors for HPV infection and cervical cancer. Multi-stage cluster random sampling or another applicable sampling strategy will be applied to ensure representativeness. Urine samples will be collected for HPV testing, along with data on demographics, socioeconomic status, sexual and reproductive history, attitudes towards and awareness and uptake of cervical cancer screening and HPV vaccination, and potential risk factors for HPV infection and cervical cancer.

In selected countries, urine and self-collected vaginal swabs (SCVS) will be collected at the first visit to determine the comparability of HPV genotyping results from both sample types. For all the other visits, only SCVS will be collected. Data on demographics, socioeconomic status, sexual and reproductive history, cervical screening, HPV vaccination, and other potential risk factors will be collected using standardized questionnaires.

There will be qualitative sub-studies in 5 countries (Bangladesh, Nepal, Pakistan, Sierra Leone, DR Congo) following and drawing on findings from the cross-sectional surveys (CSS), focusing on girls and women of different age strata as well as community members (including boys and men) and key informants in the health care system in each study site.

The study will be implemented in 2 rounds. Cross-sectional surveys (CSS) and Qualitative sub-studies (QSS) will be conducted in Round 1. In the following year (Round 2), cross-sectional surveys and longitudinal studies (LS) will be conducted in selected sub-Saharan countries. The following countries will be included in the LS study: Bangladesh, Sierra Leone, Tanzania, and DR Congo. In each country, approximately 600-1300 menstruating/menstruated (in the past 12 months) women aged between 15-35 years old will be enrolled in the LS studies. In selected 3 countries, approximately 288-384 women aged between 15-35 years old will be enrolled in the LS studies, with a maximum of 24 months observation period. The study will be implemented from 2021 to 2024.

Heart failure (HF) is a common diagnosis in primary care, but the incidence of HF is poorly defined mainly due to the lack of standardized and cost-effective methods to detect new cases. A novel predictive model based on a range of read codes and routine clinical practice data will be developed and validated. Primary purpose of the study would be hypothesis generating through an observational cohort design. Patients registering with CPRD are deemed to have consented to be included in the register when their records are entered for research. This study is approved by the Independent Scientific Advisory Committee of the CPRD and is therefore exempt from the provisions of the 2003 Mental Capacity Act and no individual consent will be sought.
