The objective of this randomized study is to evaluate the impact on sexual function of a recommended period of time after hysterectomy before resuming sexual activity. Our hypothesis is that patients who delay resumption of sexual intercourse will have a higher FSFI® score (sexual function inventory) compared to those who resume sexual intercourse earlier. To this end, we plan to include 400 patients (n = 200 in each group) who will answer the FSFI® questionnaire before surgery and then at 3 months. This 18-item questionnaire assesses various aspects of female sexual function, including desire, arousal, lubrication, orgasm, satisfaction, and the absence of pain. The questionnaire results are expressed as a single score, the total score (0 to 36) and a domain score, from 2 to 6. The domain scores are weighted averages of the items contained in each one. To analyze the FSFI® score and the correlation with the recommendation, the two groups of women will thus be compared. This difference will be considered as clinically relevant if it is greater than 4. At 1 year after the hysterectomy, a second survey will be sent to the patients in order to collect socio-demographic, past medical history, postoperative complications, and date of resumption of sexual intercourse. The postoperative complications studied include dyspareunia, spontaneous pain outside of sexual intercourse, metrorrhagia, infection, and vaginal fundal suture release. We expect the data to be analyzed starting in June 2022.

<|assistant|>
Age-Related Sarcopenia (muscle wasting in older individuals) results in many health problems including reduced lifespan, falls, fractures, loss of independence and quality of life (Stark, 2004; Meredith, 2008). In addition, the decline in muscle function in older men and women, has been attributed to deficiency in testosterone (Wu et al., 2008). Testosterone deficiency, which affects more than 20% of older men, has been recently classified as a ‘metabolic disease’ (Morley, 2011). Testosterone deficiency in men has been reported to impair skeletal muscle mass and muscle performance (Bhasin, 2012). However, the effect of testosterone replacement in older men on muscle size and muscle performance have been inconsistent and difficult to evaluate as most studies have included men with age-related sarcopenia (Matsumoto, 2008). Furthermore, only few studies have evaluated the combined effects of exercise and testosterone replacement on skeletal muscle (Kerksick, 2004).
Exercise training is a potent stimulus for increasing skeletal muscle mass and function (Macpherson et al., 2007; Dreyer, 2008) but previous studies of resistance exercise in older men have observed that the muscle performance or skeletal muscle mass in older men improves or does not change, indicating an absence of adaptability (King, 2008; Hedman, 2009). The lack of adaptability to exercise in older men has been associated with a lack of testosterone (Kerksick, 2004). Therefore, the aim of this study is to investigate whether testosterone supplementation and exercise training would increase the skeletal muscle mass and muscle performance in older men.
In the present study, a randomized controlled, parallel, double-blind, placebo-controlled, cross-over trial in 36 healthy, eugonadal men aged 60 to 75 years, with relatively low serum testosterone levels, will be performed. The main objectives of this study are to investigate whether testosterone supplementation and structured resistance exercise training lead to: 1) increased skeletal muscle mass and muscle force, 2) increased number of myonuclei in skeletal muscle, and 3) increased muscle protein synthesis after an acute resistance exercise bout. The skeletal muscle adaptations related to the combined intervention will be investigated by measuring the following; muscle size, cross-sectional area of muscle fibres, DNA methylation and gene expression in skeletal muscle and blood.

Argentine and international studies have recently recorded higher incidence of dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) cases. The increase in DHF is partially associated with the introduction of new viral genotypes and / or new vectors responsible for virus transmission in countries where dengue has been present for years. Due to these factors, new epidemiological situations are generated worldwide. In Argentina the increase of dengue cases is linked to the reactivation of previously existing circulating viral serotypes. The study of antibody prevalence among the population allows us to estimate the level of exposure to the virus and the level of acquired immunity to guide control procedures against DHF in the Metropolitan Area of Buenos Aires (MAB) and its surroundings. The presence of flaviviruses other than dengue has also been described in the last few years. Studies in MAB did not detect significant transmission of flaviviruses other than dengue, but there is no information to know whether antibodies to these viruses would be present in the population. The main objective of the project is to estimate the seroprevalence of antibodies to dengue fever (DF) and the prevalence of other flaviviruses circulating in people living in the MAB. The population to be studied (age ≥18) includes persons who are most exposed to the arboviral threat due to the type of activities they carry out (domestic workers, construction workers, workers of markets, etc.) and others who are in more stable situations but have a greater chance of developing severe forms of the disease because of their age, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, etc.

Education has a powerful effect upon physical and mental health for children and adults alike. Many schools in poor countries have large classes and few resources with which to provide education. You can help poor children succeed by donating to one of the hundreds of schools and educational organizations working to give kids an education in struggling communities. Many of these organizations are involved in sponsorships or international adoption programs. These programs allow you to support the education of your sponsored child through correspondence and gifts that you send or donations that you give directly to the school. Even modest financial contributions can make a huge difference in the lives of children. For example, only $35 per year can cover tuition, textbooks and uniforms allowing a student to complete four years of high school in Uganda. You also may be able to donate school supplies, computers, or other necessary resources to poor schools. Donations in the forms of in-kind support are especially valuable to schools in areas with limited infrastructure. You also may be able to contribute to specific educational programs, such as those for children with disabilities or those living in remote areas. Such programs help to ensure that no child is denied access to an education because of their gender, economic status, race, or geographical location. Whatever the program to which you choose to donate, you will be making a positive impact on children's lives and providing them with the tools they need to make significant contributions to their world. You can donate to many school-based programs through organizations such as UNICEF, Save the Children, DonorsChoose.org, and Room to Read. There are also education-based programs outside of schools that provide access to education for poor people in countries all over the world. Some nonprofit organizations, such as Libraries Without Borders and Books for Africa, provide libraries, books, and other learning tools to improve literacy and provide access to education. Donating to these nonprofits will not only provide education to children but also will support adult learning, which is a critical step toward breaking the poverty cycle. Many schools and organizations that provide education to poor children will accept monetary donations, but they also are in need of volunteers. If you have the time and skills necessary to teach English, perform administrative duties, or support other educational projects, consider volunteering in person or online. When you donate to schools and educational organizations, you are helping to transform the lives of the children and creating a brighter future for all.

The investigators seek to better predict the risk for developing Type 2 Diabetes in prediabetes and understand their differences by measuring and profiling how the different factors interact to affect glucose control after eating. The study will include individuals with prediabetes or diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes to test different dietary and exercise mitigators before a glucose challenge. Participants will be monitored using continuous glucose monitors, fitbit devices, and food logs. Phantom limb pain (PLP), the awareness of painful sensations in the missing limb, affects 60-80% of amputees. Evidence show that the amputation causes long-lasting remodeling in the sensorimotor cortex, leading to changes in neural activity that contribute to the experience of pain. The goal of the current research is to determine if sensory brain activity associated with the amputated limb can be improved by providing operant conditioning feedback.
Using operant conditioning, participants with PLP will receive real-time feedback based on their sensorimotor brain response to peripheral stimulation. The participant's activity will be recorded using non-invasive electroencephalography (EEG). Following operant conditioning, the investigators expect an increase in the amplitude and a decrease in the latency of brain response in the contralateral sensorimotor cortex. The study will also evaluate the impact of the operant conditioning on pain intensity, quality of life, and disability associated with PLP. A control group will receive stimulation without feedback. This study will provide evidence on the effectiveness of this novel approach to retrain the brain responses associated with PLP..

This retrospective study used electronic chart records to review patients with axillary venous thromboembolism at Shangyu People's hospital from October 1, 2006, to April 30, 2019. A total of 147 patients with axillary venous thromboembolism were enrolled. Among different age groups, we found the group of 20-45 years was the most vulnerable. We found that, compared with other trauma patients, axillary vein thrombosis and thromboembolism in patients with axillary venous thromboembolism had different characteristics in thromboembolism type and imaging display. The thrombus of axillary vein can not be observed by ultrasonography only in a few cases, and its accuracy rate is far lower than that of trunk veins such as internal jugular vein, subclavian vein, axillary vein and inferior vena cava. There is significant difference in the accuracy rate of ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization between experienced and novice clinicians. Puncture of axillary vein is the most important factor for successful CVC insertion in experienced clinicians. Ultrasonic and puncture operation skills of novice clinicians need to be improved. Puncture of axillary vein can not avoid puncture complications, such as thromboembolism and pneumothorax, the former needs to be evaluated regularly, and the puncture site needs to be evaluated in time after operation. And ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization may increase the length of ICU stay for trauma patients. Axillary vein catheterization is a reliable way to monitor central venous pressure and improve fluid status assessment in trauma patients in ICU. The advantages of axillary vein catheterization are its safety and effectiveness. However, the thromboembolism rate associated with indwelling catheter can be reduced through the use of anticoagulant therapy and active lower limb motion during bed rest.

Multiple myeloma (MM) is a plasma cell disorder characterized by clonal plasma cells that accumulate within the bone marrow affecting bone metabolism, immune system function and blood cell production. A common feature of plasma cell disorders is that plasma cells make monoclonal antibodies that do not function properly; one approach to treating these disorders has been to develop antibodies (called "anticancer antibodies") that help the immune system target and kill plasma cells. More recently, therapeutic antibodies have been engineered in the laboratory to be very potent and target specific molecules, such as a molecule called B-cell maturation antigen (BCMA). A drug called belantamab mafodotin, called "anti-BCMA" or "BCMA-directed CAR T cell", was recently approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and European Medicines Agency (EMA) for the treatment of patients with relapsed (return) or refractory (non-responsive) multiple myeloma after receiving prior therapies. While anti-BCMA therapy can induce remarkable anti-myeloma efficacy, a large percentage of patients receiving these agents experience rapid disease progression. Therefore, there is a need to explore new treatment options. Cevostamab is a bispecific antibody that consists of an anti-BCMA antibody and another antibody that binds to a specific receptor called FcgammaRI on immune cells. Cevostamab was initially tested in patients with non-Hodgkin lymphoma and resulted in significant immune activation (called �cytokine release syndrome” or �CRS”) in a large proportion of patients. The investigators therefore conducted a smaller trial in patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma after prior therapy with BCMA-targeted therapy to determine the safe dose of cevostamab. The purpose of this trial is to determine the safety and anti-myeloma effectiveness of cevostamab in subjects with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma who have received BCMA-targeted therapy.

This is a randomized control trial with three study groups. The first study group consists of 20 subjects will undergo the cavitation sonication (CUS) only. The second study group consists of 20 subjects will undergo the US imaging guided core muscles exercise only (RUSI guided core muscle exercise). The third study group consists of 15 subjects will undergo combination of CUS sonication and US imaging guided RUSI guided core muscles exercise (combination of cavitation and RUSI). The primary outcome measures will be the diaphragm excursion, transverse abdominis contraction ratio, visceral fat thickness and waist circumference measured by ultrasound imaging at the start and end of the 5 weeks. The secondary outcome measures will be the BMI, fat mass and muscle mass assessed by bioelectrical impedance analysis before and after the intervention.

The aim of this single-center pilot study is to evaluate whether the extent of atrial fibrosis as measured by late gadolinium enhancement on cardiac magnetic resonance imaging may be prognostic of AF in a population with stroke without other known causes for stroke.
This prospective monocentric pilot study will include 60 patients hospitalized for ischemic stroke of undetermined cause and with indication for long-term monitoring for stroke of unknown origin within 3 months of stroke.
The primary objective is to study the predictive value of the extent of atrial fibrosis measured by MRI with the implantable loop monitor.
Secondary objectives are: to calculate the AF incidence in these cases of "stroke of unknown origin" (without another obvious cause), to study the feasibility of obtaining additional information to identify causes, to study the safety of the MRI test in patients with a history of ischemic stroke and to explore possible link between the extent of atrial fibrosis and the risk profile of the patients.
Patients will receive an exploratory MRI assessment (at least a cine magnetic resonance and a cardiac magnetic resonance) with or without contrast in the 2nd month for stroke causes search, and during the same exploratory MRI, they will receive a cardiac magnetic resonance with contrast agent for evaluating atrial fibrosis.
Patients will undergo an implantable loop monitor implantation at 3 months. A 3-year long-term follow-up will be carried out with a specific protocol including remote cardiac monitoring, stroke relapse and death record.
Participants will be followed up at 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, 2 years and 3 years after inclusion. If the exploratory MRI results in the identification of a cardioembolic cause of the stroke, the patient will be withdrawn from the study and will be referred to the appropriate department of the hospital.

The primary endpoint is objective tumor response, which is defined as the proportion of subjects with best response of complete response (CR) or partial response (PR) per independent central review (ICR) according to Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) 1.1. The secondary endpoints include the objective response rate (ORR) for 3 subgroups of the HR+/HER2- population defined by subtype I,II, or III, according to PAM50 analysis, as well as progression-free survival (PFS) using Kaplan-Meier method. Additionally, the study will assess safety using CTCAE (version 5.0) to calculate safety parameters, including the number of participants experiencing adverse events (AEs). Lastly, biomarker analyses, including TILs, PD-L1, p-S6, p-mTOR, p-4EBP, and T cell subsets, will be conducted.

There is robust evidence for a beneficial effect of induced therapeutic hypothermia (ITH) in the setting of out of hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) and in a patient population that have suffered prolonged ischaemic times before reaching hospital. 
Despite the increasing number of PCI centers performing PCI in patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), there are no conclusive data on the effect of induced therapeutic hyperthermia (ITH) in the same setting. 
The aim of this study is to evaluate the safety and feasibility of implementing a trans-coronary cooling and dilution (TCD) strategy using a simple approach to cool and dilute the coronary artery during primary PCI in patients with acute STEMI. 
This single centre prospective randomized controlled trial will be conducted in patients with acute STEMI undergoing primary PCI.

Overweight and obesity are associated with greater risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD) in breast cancer survivors (BCS). This study will use a prospective, three-arm single institution RCT to evaluate the effectiveness of a tailored, culturally adapted, and telemedicine-delivered weight loss intervention designed to reduce cardiometabolic risk in Latina BCS. Specifically, the investigators hypothesize that BCS who receive a comprehensive three-month weight loss program including both educational and behavioral components will be more likely to achieve clinically meaningful weight loss at month 12 relative to BCS who receive a comprehensive three-month weight loss program consisting only of educational components or a comprehensive four-month weight loss program including both educational and behavioral components along with individualized health coaching sessions and home-delivered groceries. All patients undergo laboratory, anthropometric, and lifestyle assessments at baseline and at month 12. Weight loss status at baseline dictates participant re-randomization into one of four embedded EAI's at month 4. The data analytic plan includes a mixed-model intent-to-treat analysis, assessing EAI effectiveness across and within treatment arms using a doubly robust estimator model. This study will be the first to evaluate the role of tailored interventions and telemedicine in the weight loss of BCS as a means to decreasing cardiometabolic risk, as well as assess whether the observed EAI effects on weight, waist circumference (WC), blood pressure (BP), glucose, and serum lipids are moderated, mediated, or conditional by demographic, cardiovascular, metabolic, and cancer-treatment-related characteristics.

Background; ⁊Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) are a rare type of tumors, affecting mostly the gut, pancreas or bronchi. NETs can be locally advanced or have metastasized to organs such as the liver or bone when treated for the first time. Treatments include local operations (e.g. surgery, radiofrequency ablation or external radiotherapy) and systemic treatment with Somatostatin analogues (SSA) or peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT). 
Several guidelines advise not to interrupt SSAs upon progression with the primary aim of tumor control. However, there is so far no evidence to support stopping or continuing SSA treatments, nor has its clinical benefit been established. This study is aimed at investigating the benefit of SSA withdrawal in terms of progression (no progression versus progression) as well as time to tumor deterioration in patients who have progressed on first-line SSA therapy and the impact of such clinical decisions on patients' life in terms of quality of life. Additionally, the cost effectiveness of these approaches will be analyzed. 
Participants; ⁊All patients with local advanced or metastatic, non-functional, well-differentiated, World Health Organisation 2019 grade 1-2 GEP NETs that have progressed after first-line SSA treatment will be considered. Participants are enrolled in substudies with the following treatments: PRRT substudy (participants will receive PRRT with Lutetium (177Lu) oxodotreotide in the second-line), targeted therapy substudy (these participants will receive either sunitinib or everolimus), both given on their first-line therapy, or no treatment after withdrawal of SSA due to progression following the first-line therapy. Patients in the 4 arms can be switched between both arms. 
Outcomes will be assessed by questionnaires on quality of life, clinical tumor assessments and progression (according to RECIST 1.1) by means of imaging techniques performed every 10 weeks over a 1.5 year period. After 1.5 years, the patients enter an observation phase for 5 years. A health technology assessment (HTA) will be conducted from a societal perspective.

Primary dysmenorrhea is a highly prevalent gynaecological condition affecting the reproductive age group of girls around the world. It is caused due to an increase in the levels of prostaglandins leading to excessive uterine contractions which in turn lead to pain. The current literature suggests that exercises like dynamic core stabilizing exercises (DCSE) and stretching exercises play an important role in the management of primary dysmenorrhea. The aim of this study was to determine the effectiveness in symptom reduction and quality of life (QoL) by comparing the effect of Dynamic core stabilizing exercises (DCSE) and stretching exercises on primary dysmenorrhea.
                Female students (18-25 years) were included after obtaining their written informed consent. The sample size was taken after considering several factors. They were randomly assigned to experimental and control group. The control group was taught stretching exercises for 8 weeks. Experimental group received core stabilizing exercises for 8 weeks. The effectiveness of both the groups were assessed using WaLIDD (working ability, Location, Intensity, Days, Dysmenorrhea) score, side bridge, McGill quality of life.
                Out of 40 patients were selected, 20 in the experimental group and 20 control group completed 8 weeks of intervention and assessments.
                Both the groups reported a significant improvement in the WaLIDD (working ability, Location, Intensity, Days, Dysmenorrhea) score and also in the quality of life scale. However, the extent of improvement in the experimental group, which were given core stabilizing exercises was more than the stretching group.
                Dynamic core stabilizing exercises are highly effective in the management of primary dysmenorrhea. By providing the core with stability the pressure experienced by the uterus is reduced and the quality of life of the girls is improved. It takes a shorter time for girls to recover and resume their normal activities and thus plays an important role in the management of primary dysmenorrhea.
                The limitations of the study are that the study included only one center, the number of cases taken into the study was too small and the number of controls in the control group was less. But they were enough to assess the effectiveness of the experimental groups.
                Future recommendations include conducting studies with a larger sample size and including a larger number of controls.

Background: Arterial hypotension during general anesthesia is associated with postoperative complications. The current safety margin for blood pressure varies from 40 to 50% of the value measured before anesthesia, depending on the available evidence. In particular, recent large observational studies have reported that a decrease in blood pressure to 30% of its value before anesthesia is associated with high mortality in patients aged 60 years or older. It has also been reported that in patients with cardiac risk factors, the brain blood flow autoregulation capacity is much lower, making cerebral organs more vulnerable to arterial hypotension. It is also known that the reduction in perfusion pressure is associated with a decrease in brain oxygenation but the individual sensitivity of the brain to hypotension is poorly understood.
Study Objective: The aim of this prospective observational study is to measure the non-invasively, quickly and reliably the variations of cerebral perfusion in patients under general anesthesia during controlled variations to adjust blood pressure under the current safety margin. The level of mean cerebral artery blood flow velocity will be assessed by transcranial Doppler in a simple and accurate way. The goal of the study is to identify a significant linear relationship between changes in cerebral blood flow velocity (CMRO2) and changes in the 95% spectral frequency front (SEF95) during the changes in mean arterial pressure (MAP).
Study Design: This study, classified as "Cohort Study" according to the Helsinki Declaration, has a transversal and monocentric nature. Patients over 18 years old are included at any time in the operating room for surgery requiring full anesthesia during the perioperative period. All patients included are informed about the research protocol and must have given their express and informed consent to the processing of their medical data. The investigating physician is not involved in the data analysis or reporting of the results, and therefore he will not be influenced by knowledge acquired from the results. Data analysis is performed by an independant researcher with no knowledge of the patient's name or data and of the patient's evolution during the operation. The investigating physician is not informed of the results of the study, and they therefore have no influence on blood pressure optimization strategies.

Inclusion Criteria:
Patient of legal age (≥ 18 years)
Eligible for scheduled surgery at Lariboisière Hospital
Informed patient who has expressed no objection to participating in this research

Small Cell Lung Cancer accounts for approximately 15% of all lung cancers. Because lung cancer is often not discovered until it has spread, or metastasized, the standard first-line treatment for this disease is a combination of chemotherapy and immunotherapy. The standard treatment for this disease currently consists of immunotherapy with Atezolizumab (Tecentriq) and chemotherapy with carboplatin plus etoposide or cisplatin plus etoposide. While the current combination (immunotherapy with Atezolizumab combined with chemotherapy) is effective and increases the overall survival, the side effects can be substantial and sometimes patients do not respond. It is important to identify patients who are not likely to benefit from this treatment. There are several biomarkers that are used to evaluate the efficacy of immunotherapy such as programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1), tumor mutational burden (TMB), and circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) . Minimal residual disease (MRD) is the presence of tumor cells following treatment that are no longer visible by conventional imaging techniques. MRD testing could help us identify treatment response earlier, which may lead to targeted adjustment of the treatment and can improve the outcome of patients. However, MRD testing is not routinely used currently in clinical practice and it is not known whether MRD testing can directly assist with patient response to immunotherapy and chemotherapy, and whether it can be used to identify early predictors of treatment failure and early adjustment of treatment plan. The investigators designed this study to obtain MRD information during the treatment course of patients with extensive small cell lung cancer treated with IMCG-1E1C in clinical practice and explore its value in predicting treatment outcomes at different time points during the treatment course. Also, the investigators hope to establish a long-term MRD data registry of patients receiving IMCG-1E1C as part of this study to validate the ability of post-treatment MRD status in predicting treatment outcomes and overall survival of patients in real-world practice. This study will include patients with extensive small cell lung cancer treated by Serplulimab (IMCG-1E1C) in First-line treatment in clinical practice according to routine clinical practice in real-world data. The study arms for this study include upfront Serplulimab plus chemotherapy, with MRD testing before treatment, after 2 cycles of treatment, after 6 cycles of treatment, 6 months after the end of chemotherapy, and 1 year after the end of chemotherapy.

The purpose of this study is to verify if a nasally-administered spray of the hormone oxytocin helps children and youngsters with autism feel more connected with others by improving their social behavior and reducing their repetitive behavior. It is a double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study in which 20 male and female youth age 12-20 with autism, a confirmed diagnosis and relatively low symptoms of social impairment and/or repetitive behavior, will be given nasal spray (24 IU of oxytocin) or placebo twice daily for a total of 4 weeks, while their behavior and physiology will be studied.
Autism is mainly characterized by social impairment, but there is large variation in autism with respect to clinical severity. Some individuals with autism have a good social contact and functioning in daily life. Other individuals experience problems related to social reciprocity, often accompanied by repetitive behavior. Oxytocin has been suggested to enhance social behavior and reduce repetitive behavior, and it is known to facilitate social contact or bonding. By administering oxytocin nasal spray to individuals within this subgroup of youth, it is believed that oxytocin can improve social behavior and reduce behavior that might interfer with functioning or participation in social activities.
The project will assess the efficacy of 24IU oxytocin nasal spray versus placebo twice daily after a four week administration period. It will be a double-blind, cross-over study where participants will be assigned to 1 of 2 possible sequences of being treated with active oxytocin nasal spray and placebo for 2 weeks each. The sequence will be randomized. Both participants and observers will be blinded regarding the content of each nasal spray administered. During the experiment, a diary will be maintained to track symptoms and side effects every hour for 2 weeks. Parents (or legal guardians) to administer the nasal spray will receive training before the start of the study. Oxytocin nasal spray will be administered by these parents before bedtime on weekdays and at any time two hours after the last intakes. During the weekends, treatment will be administered a.m. and p.m. at any time. Each day, the participants will receive 2 doses. The first dose will be before bedtime and the second will be at least two hours afterwards on weekdays, and at any time two hours after the last intakes on weekends. The total number of nasal sprays used will be accounted for.
A battery of tests will evaluate the efficacy of the oxytocin nasal spray. A set of computerized tests will be performed twice each week for two weeks on separate days. Some of the tests will be performed before and after the administration of 24IU oxytocin nasal spray. In addition to these tests, one task will be performed once, 24 hours after participants have administered 24IU oxytocin nasal spray. One of the computer tasks is a behavioral task for social and emotion recognition. Here, participants will view pictures of people and animals during the study. Their response will be measured and coded and recorded. Another computer task is a repetitive behavior task which will last 20-30 minutes and is probabilistic and rewarding in nature. Some other tests will be repeated at week 4, after the completion of oxytocin or placebo administration.

The purpose of this study is to compare the severity or the clinical condition of the abdomen of newborns born prematurely in term of their digestive development, their weight gain or their clinical course through blinded evaluations carried out by professionals at the time of their daily care of newborns at the maternity hospital of the University Hospital of Clermont Ferrand.
The hypothesis to be validated is that it is possible to quantify and qualify abdominal condition with a clinical evaluation scale of abdominal condition specific to the preterm, the ECAP scale. This validated scale will help the care givers to assess the abdominal condition of the preterm.
In order to establish this scale, the investigators have created it using three points that correspond to three clinical situations :
- inactive abdomen, that is to say, a flaccid abdomen: score 0 of the ECAP scale.
- The moderate abdomen, that is to say, a slightly tense abdomen: score 1 of the ECAP scale.
- The tense abdomen, that is to say, a tense abdomen: score 2 of the ECAP scale.
This scale is the object of two types of trials, feasibility and validity, in 3 phases: collection of clinical data, creation of a scale specific to preterm, validation of the scale.
The assessment of the abdominal condition will be carried out by the physician, the physiotherapist and the nurse, blindly and by the same sequence: each will carry out the blinded evaluation at the day of consultation and within two days, the patient being evaluated by the 3 professionals. Each assessment will be carried out within a maximum time window of 30 minutes, the patient being considered as having stable abdominal condition. These assessments and the clinical data will be stored and analyzed by statisticians.
The clinical data collected are : age, weight, length, head circumference, gestational age, maternal age, APGAR score, birth mode (instrumental or not), need for supplemental oxygen, presence of enteral nutrition, presence of intravenous nutrition, use of diuretics , pain medication, mechanical ventilation, sedative, presence of feeding syndrome, occurrence of abdominal massage, analgesia for abdominal massage and indication of abdominal massage on ECAP scale. The clinical data will be compared with the blinded evaluation by each evaluator.
The clinical data collected over time allow an analysis by time to predict the abdominal condition at birth from the factors of the mother's state, the newborn's state. The results will be the basis for a prognostic score for the preterm at birth based on the ECAP scale.
The validation of the score is carried out by the comparison between the scores of the different evaluators of the same patient and allows to have a good inter-evaluator reliability. It will give a range for the value of a healthy abdomen on a preterm born. The results of the ECAP scale will also be compared with the results of the daily evaluation carried out by the medical and paramedical teams.
In addition, this scale will be used as an outcome in a multi-centre clinical trial, to show the efficiency of abdominal massage on enteral weight progression and on the time spent in the neonatal intensive care unit for preterm newborns with enteral feeding syndrome.
It is important to evaluate the impact of this scale in daily practice of neonatal care and in research for premature newborns. If it is validated, it will constitute a simple tool to quantify and qualify an abdominal condition of newborns which varies greatly between different professionals in view of their daily practice. Validated at the University Hospital Center of Clermont- Ferrand, it will allow its use in all neonatal units and will be a tool to improve the care of preterm newborn infants in the field of gastrointestinal or respiratory diseases where abdominal issues are a significant problem impacting on newborn quality of life, long term outcome and healthcare costs.

Introduction: Chronic pain is widespread, costly, and associated with disrupted lives, impaired function, and diminished quality of life. People with chronic pain often lack effective pain relief and experience disparities in pain care. Many are underserved and lack access to skilled, compassionate providers. A significant need exists for people with chronic pain to receive educational content about effective pain management strategies. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the use of the Empowered Relief (ER) educational program delivered by Nurses as a method for addressing these needs.
Study Design: Randomized controlled trial with two experimental conditions: ER and a Wait-List Control (WL). The primary aims of the study are to compare the effect of ER on self-reported pain intensity and pain-related fear compared to a wait-list control (WL) among adults with persistent pain.
Participants and Intervention: ER is an online 2-hour interactive psycho-educational pain skills training that teaches participants how to use the principles of mindfulness and behavioral activation to promote self-sufficiency and well-being when pain is unpredictable and variable. An important component of ER is to address the relationship between pain and psychological factors. ER emphasizes the promotion of skill acquisition, confidence, self-efficacy, and hope. This intervention has previously been found to be successful in improving pain outcomes.
WL participants will not receive any educational intervention at randomization and will serve as a control group at the time of assessment. When the ER participants receive their class, the WL-participants will be invited to be randomized to receive ER.
Feasibility and Patient Acceptability of ER will be qualitatively analyzed using descriptions of participant experiences to assess barriers to intervention delivery and explore facilitators for future scaling up of training and study recruitment across various settings to include a broad range of patient participants.

Chronic musculoskeletal pain can be a significant limitation for patients' health, affecting their mood, daily routine, and sleep patterns. In a recent study, patients found it more difficult to choose and understand certain pain intensity rating scales. In addition, some patients reported worrying about whether their pain intensity ratings communicated the correct number, which could result in unnecessary healthcare visits. The goals of this study are to decrease patients' mental effort when choosing and understanding pain intensity ratings, and increase confidence in pain intensity ratings. Before investigating these goals, we will assess the mental effort required from patients and nurses to choose and understand the rating scales as part of the baseline measurements of the study. This information will inform future efforts to improve rating scales. We will develop a survey that investigates mental effort required from patients and nurses to select or understand chronic pain rating scales. The survey will include the following rating scale characteristics: worst pain you can think of versus worst pain you have ever felt, one vs. multiple body areas, one vs. average pain intensity rating across specified time periods. We will pilot test the survey among 15 nurses to determine the length of time needed for completion and identify issues with survey readability prior to administering the survey to participants. We will test mental effort and confidence in fictional pain intensity ratings in an exploratory fashion without testing the hypotheses described for the primary purposes below.

A mobile-app for alcohol use disorders (AUD) will be evaluated for its effectiveness by comparing it to usual care medical management with naltrexone. The app, in combination with mobile coaching from a licensed counselor, aims to reduce alcohol consumption in individuals with AUD by providing therapy techniques in the form of cognitive-behavioral content in short video format. After successful enrollment in the program, participants will undergo a medical assessment to determine eligibility for medication, and pharmacotherapy will be integrated into the app for consistent delivery of naltrexone treatment. The mobile coach, who is part of a telemedicine clinic within the study, will provide additional therapeutic support and assess participants' readiness to change before each pharmacotherapy dosing to ensure compliance. Participants will be compared to a control group that will receive usual medical care while undergoing weekly coaching sessions with a licensed counselor. Both groups will participate in a follow-up assessment at 6-months post-treatment entry. The primary outcome measure will be the change in past 30-day alcohol use, with additional measures including self-report measures of alcohol severity (i.e., Severity of Alcohol Dependence Questionnaire-Revised, Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test), quality of life (i.e. World Health Organization Quality of Life-Abbreviated Scale), perceived stress and anxiety, and health satisfaction and health literacy. A cost-effectiveness analysis will also be performed.

The Seven trial is a national, multicenter, phase 2 randomized controlled trial. It is hypothesized that the Seven trial will reduce the incidence and progression of breast cancer and deaths from the disease in a population where screening is currently offered to women over the age of 40.
Study participants will be randomly assigned into three groups:
1. Breast screening by digital mammography (including a local biopsy if needed) at intervals of 1 to 2 years.
2. Breast screening by breast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and digital mammography (including a local biopsy if needed) at 1 to 2 year intervals.
3. Breast screening by breast ultrasound only for women with denser breast tissue (including a local biopsy if needed) at intervals of 1 to 2 years.
Participants who have a breast cancer detected during the screening phase of the study will have treatment as part of their usual care.
A woman of at least 40 years of age may self-refer to the study or may be referred by her general practitioner (family doctor), Breast Care Nurse, or Breast Screening Unit. The screening for women who enrol in the trial will take place in selected Breast Screening Units in Ireland. If women are unsure whether they wish to continue to participate, they may withdraw at any time during the study. 
Participant information leaflets and consent forms are available in different formats.
Please see the original trial documentation for further details.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the clinical pregnancy rate of embryo transfer in natural vs substituted cycles using frozen embryos. 
Patients included in the study will either have done a frozen embryo transfer in natural or substituted cycle. 
Clinical pregnancy is defined as the presence of at least one intrauterine gestational sac with fetal heart activity on ultrasound. 
The embryos used for the transfer were frozen after in-vitro fertilization (IVF) or intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI). One embryo or maximum 2 embryos will be transferred at each attempt. 
Adequate endometrial thickness is considered important for embryo implantation, and a thickness of more than 7mm is necessary according to our clinical practice guidelines. 
The outcome of this study will be the evaluation of the clinical pregnancy rate of embryo transfer in natural vs substituted cycles.

Sepsis-induced vascular endothelial injury is caused by multiple factors. Numerous studies have found a variety of proteins that inhibit pro-inflammatory cytokine release, maintain endothelial cell function, and are involved in vascular leakage and vascular endothelial dysfunction. In recent years, the Gasdermin D pore formation plays an important role in endothelial cell death. The DDX17 is a multi-function protein involved in RNA modification, and plays an important role in modulating the inflammatory response in the host. This study will use a variety of methods to measure the plasma level of DDX17 and the vascular endothelial injury in sepsis patients. It will explore the correlation between them, and verify the potential mechanism by which DDX17 regulates the Gasdermin D pore formation, the vascular endothelial barrier and the septic tissue permeability through RNA modification.

Glioblastoma (GBM) is a highly malignant, primary brain tumor and is resistant to standard treatment regimens, including surgical resection, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and TTFields therapy. The Stupp Protocol, consisting of fractionated focal irradiation given daily fractions of 2 Gy for 6 weeks, plus concomitant daily temozolomide, followed by six cycles of adjuvant TMZ, has been adopted as the standard of care for patients with ndGBMs since 2005. However, there have been no other treatment modalities except for TTFields that have brought survival benefits for ndGBM patients during the past decades. Due to the expensive price of TTFields therapy, the Stupp Protocol is still regarded as the first-line and the most widely-adopted treatment option for ndGBM patients worldwide. Elemene, a Chinese anti-tumor medicine extracted from the plant Curcuma Wenyujin, has been isolated as a monomeric drug and has a broad-spectrum anti-tumor effect in various cancers, such as lung cancer, breast carcinoma, leukemia, and ovarian cancer. In recent years, the application of Elemene in GBMs has shown survival benefits with acceptable toxicity. The aim of this multi-center, phase II, randomized, controlled clinical trial is to test the safety and efficacy of Elemene plus Stupp Protocol compared with Stupp Protocol alone for ndGBM patients. Based on previous clinical data on the efficacy and safety of Elemene in GBM patients, the investigators suggest adding Elemene to the daily regimen of the standard Stupp Protocol.

The study, in part funded by the Italian Ministry of Health, will enroll 55 patients and last for 12 months. Each patient's PaO2/FiO2 ratio will be measured while on mechanical ventilation; only those with a ratio of less than 200 may be eligible if, before the study, they also satisfy all the necessary criteria. Eligible patients will undergo a protocol of measurements in two different body positions. Both the supine and the prone positions will be studied with all the variables investigated only once in a given body position, and measurements will not be repeated in the second position. The supine body position measurement will last about 30 minutes and will include standard mechanical ventilation with high PEEP pressure, lung mechanics assessments, and end-expiratory lung impedance computed tomography scans with two levels of PEEP. Following the supine measurements, the patients will be placed in the prone position for one hour, with measurements performed after this brief intervention. This will help determine the effects of changes in lung positioning on arterial gases and lung mechanics. It is hypothesised that prone positioning will increase the PaO2/FiO2 ratio by 5%, meaning that patients may not need invasive mechanical ventilation. On the other hand, if no difference in PaO2/FiO2 is obtained, they may be unable to breathe spontaneously. It is speculated that patients with ALI/ARDS may be a candidate for prone positioning if they exhibit an insufficient response to conventional mechanical ventilation. This study will provide guidance on whether prone positioning could be used in critically ill patients with ALI/ARDS, while ensuring patient safety throughout the monitoring and interventions.

                H1 : The postoperative pain level of the patients in the intervention group is lower than that of the patients in the control group.
                H2 : The level of fear of postoperative pain of the patients in the intervention group is lower than that of the patients in the control group.
                The first point of the study; "To determine the effect of preoperative patient education given to patients on pain tolerance".
                The second point of the study; "To determine the effect of preoperative patient education given to patients on the fear of postoperative pain".
                The third point of the study; "To determine the effect of preoperative patient education given to patients on patient satisfaction".
                It was aimed to reveal the effect of preoperative education on patient management after discharge.
                Significant reduction in pain levels and fear of pain in patients who underwent preoperative patient education reduces the need for analgesic treatments and reduces surgical risks caused by postoperative pain.                 It has been stated in the reviews that patients' fear of pain reduces their adherence to the treatment in postoperative follow-up. As a result, the frequency of the need for inpatient treatment is increased.

                It was aimed at reducing the frequency of the need for inpatient treatment.

<|assistant|> Background: Women who use opioids during pregnancy are at significantly higher risk of negative pregnancy outcomes compared to individuals with no opioid use. Buprenorphine, a partial opioid agonist used for the treatment of opioid use disorder (OU), has been shown to successfully reduce incidence of neonatal withdrawal syndrome (NWS). In addition to its anti-withdrawal effects, buprenorphine has been shown to reduce the frequency of illicit opioid use and decrease the incidence of opioid overdose. Despite these benefits, patients continue to avoid or abandon treatment with buprenorphine, often due to its displeasing withdrawal symptoms during induction. Objective: To evaluate the use of a transdermal buprenorphine patch for the induction of buprenorphine in pregnant OU patients with and without prior history of precipitated withdrawal. Design: Individuals with a history of precipitated withdrawal are randomized prior to buprenorphine induction to receive either the buprenorphine transdermal patch for a two day period with dosing every 12 hours x 3 days, or a placebo patch that will also be applied for 2 days. The main objective of this research work is to demonstrate that functional arteriovenous scintigraphy is a non-invasive method that allows quantitative evaluation of a vascular compression of the thoracic outlet and allows better diagnosis and management of a possible upper limb vascular compression.

Secondary Objective: Demonstrate the feasibility of functional arteriovenous scintigraphy at the thoracic outlet level.

Study Population: 19 healthy volunteers and 69 patients referred to the outpatient diagnosis clinic (CHR-Tours) for the diagnosis of a possible upper limb vascular compression. Among them, 23 presented a clinical and/or imaging diagnosis of arterial vascular compression (TOS type I) and 46 have clinical and/or imaging diagnoses of arterial and/or venous vascular compression (type II TOS).

Study protocol:
The protocol used is based on three arms.
1. Patients who came for the diagnosis of TOS (19 healthy volunteers and 69 patients referred to the clinic of consultation for the diagnosis of a possible upper limb vascular compression.),
- for whom a bloodless arteriography is performed as part of the diagnosis.

2. for whom a dynamic scintigraphy using an arteriovenous injection technique (the arm to compress is the one with the vascular compression).
- for whom a functional scintigraphy at the level of the TAC (Transcutaneous Oximetry of the Capillary) is performed.

3. for whom a transcutaneous oximetry of the two upper limbs is performed during passive shoulder abduction and during the execution of compression.

Study phase : Phase 4

Background and rationale Chronic pancreatitis is an inherently complex disease requiring coordinated, multidisciplinary care. Patients suffer from constant, distressing, adverse symptoms including abdominal pain, steatorrhoea, bloating, wind, cramping, and fatigue - making it difficult to eat a normal or sufficient diet. They develop vitamin deficiencies, osteoporosis, and a difficult-to-manage diabetes subgroup (type 3c diabetes). There is no effective medical/surgical treatment, and the disease is progressive and incurable. The mainstay of treatment is diet, supplementation, and pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy- which helps patients to digest and absorb their food, alleviating symptoms somewhat. Contrary to perceptions, half of patients (or fewer) have an alcohol related aetiology. The investigators run several out-patient clinics for chronic pancreatitis including medical-led, nurse-specialist led, and type 3c diabetes clinics. A nurse specialist deal with 3-5 crisis phonically daily, each lasting up to 30mins. Patients have frequent urgent clinic attendance, A&E, and hospital admissions.

What is the intervention?
A steering group designed and developed the SmartCP mobile phone app during 2022 with the support of a government innovation grant. SmartCP consists of a symptom tracker, diet/physical activity log, alert system for escalating symptoms, quality of life assessment, red-flag alerts for diabetes/pancreatic cancer, educational content, push notifications and messaging function. Overall aim of the study To conduct a study to determine if SmartCP is feasible in the management patients with chronic pancreatitis, complementing current specialist clinical care. Design A single-arm, unblinded, feasibility study, with an uncontrolled, within-group baseline and post-intervention (16-week) design, with an embedded quantitative and qualitative process evaluation. Participants will receive the intervention for 16 weeks, supplementing usual clinical practice.

We aimed to determine the incidence of anal fissure among COVID-19 survivors and risk factors that may be associated with its development.
Study Design: A single center retrospective cross-sectional study was conducted over three months period from the start of September 2020 to the end of November 2020 on COVID-19 patients who were diagnosed to have anal fissure at Mansoura university isolation Hospital. Data from 350 patients, 176 patients were reached via telephone to asked whether they had experienced anal pain or not was collected. Among 176 patients, 115 suffered from anal pain and were asked to come to the clinic to investigate the diagnosis and the risk factors that may be associated with its development. We found that 40% were men and 60% were women. The mean age was (40.44+/-8.88) and the mean duration of symptom was (9.61+/-6.2) days. Fissure was of type 1 in 60% and type 2 in 40% of patients with no differences statistically. Risk factors that were associated with development of anal fissure among this group were; Females gender [p=0.001] , patients with co-morbidities (Cardiac, renal and other associated diseases) [p=0.01] , the mean duration of symptom [p=0.001] , the period from isolation till developed fissure was (10.3+/-4.8) days. Conclusion: We found that anal fissure may occur in COVID-19 survivors and the risk factors were females gender , patients with co-morbidities and prolonged intestinal symptoms. So that this issue should be taken in to consideration in the follow up of Covid-19 patients. ( 2021).

To collect high quality data on the model of care ARRC, the study aims to establish a registry to measure the primary outcome Days at Home after Surgery (DAH) and related aspects. Additionally, the study will measure in-hospital complications, mortality and cost-effectiveness of the model compared to usual ward care. ARRC has been shown to produce improved patient outcomes, hospital utilisation, and costs of care. By collecting data on this model, the study hopes to provide a robust mechanism to maintain and improve outcomes, benchmark models across institutions and generate and test hypotheses as to how improvements are achieved. To achieve these objectives, patients undergoing surgery at Royal Adelaide Hospital will be included in the registry if they meet the eligibility criteria consisting of scheduled for elective or unplanned surgery, expected to stay at least one night at hospital, and with a 30-day mortality risk of 0.5-8% as assessed by the US National Safety and Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP). Patients being transferred to the ICU, or scheduled for cardiac surgery, will not be included in the registry. The main outcome is the number of Days at Home after Surgery (DAH) within 90 days after surgery. Secondary outcomes include rates of in-hospital complications, mortality, and cost-effectiveness. Data will be collected from patients' medical records as part of routine care, including demographics, surgery details, recovery room pathway, and hospital and follow-up outcomes. By collecting this data, the registry hopes to provide robust and ongoing evidence of the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the ARRC model of care.

This research study aims to evaluate effectiveness and implementation of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) among mobile men (men who have sex with men and whose partners may be infected with HIV) in South Africa and Uganda at the end of 6 month recruitment. There are still many individuals in these areas who are at risk of acquiring HIV infection. If we can learn how to deliver PrEP among mobile men, we may be able to further increase the acceptance and uptake of PrEP by men across Africa where there are high rates of infection.
The study will be testing different forms of PrEP (daily, on demand, and long-acting) to determine which ones men chose and for how long they would use them. The research team will also learn how the health system can work together with men to maximise their chances of taking PrEP in a way that stops HIV transmission.
All men who are found to be HIV negative will be invited to take part in the study, including men who are HIV positive. There is no cost to participating in the study and participation is voluntary. Men will be asked to be involved in the study for at least 18 months to 2 years.

This study is designed to assess the effectiveness and feasibility of a non-invasive gentle intervention known as Osteopathic Manipulative Treatment (OMT) on the neurodevelopment of very preterm (very low birth weight -VLBW)borns.
Pregnant women at risk of giving birth to a preterm baby at less than 34 weeks of gestation will be invited to participate in this study when attending routine prenatal care in the Prenatal Center of the Clinica Ospedaliero Universitaria Policlinico, Modena.
Preterm babies will be eligible for entry to the study once they are stable and able to breathe on their own for more than 72 hours.
Families will be asked to participate in the study and if they agree, informed consent will be obtained before any procedures. After discharge (around day 42 of gestational age), babies will be invited to enroll in the experimental phase and undergo a series of 6 osteopathic-manipulative treatments, starting around week 42+6 and repeated every five days up to week 47+6. The treatments are conducted while the babies are lying on their back and are non-invasive, gentle and soothing.
The study will take place in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit at Policlinico in Modena. Preterm babies will be treated by a team consisting of a Consultant in Pediatrics, an Osteopathic Manipulative Treatment Practitioner and Nursing Staff. The treatment protocol will be applied in all 3 arms, with treatment sessions lasting approximately 20 minutes. Parents will remain in the NICU while their baby is being treated. The same members of the study team will perform all the treatments.
Each preterm baby will be enrolled in one of the 3 study arms after baseline measurements (t1): Active Comparator (Afective Touch), Placebo Comparator (Static touch) or Experimental Comparator (Therapeutic Touch, Osteopathic Manipulative Treatment. For each arm, pre-post changes from baseline in BOLD levels among different brain areas will be tested.
The same 1H NMR measurements (as an adjuvant technique to fMRI) will be taken pre and post treatments to identify pre and post treatment changes in brain connectivity and urinary metabolites. To measure brain connectivity, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans are conducted before and after the OMT intervention to see changes in blood flow in certain areas of the brain.

This protocol is the result of an ongoing collaboration with advocates and people with sickle cell disease (SCD) to create a treatment that could improve the quality and quantity of life of children and adults with SCD. The study was proposed with the aim of improving the current standard of care for adults and children with SCD. This protocol is the first study to ever combine alemtuzumab, TBI, sirolimus, and filgrastim activated stem cells with a monoclonal antibody targeting CD123(briquilimab) and a monoclonal antibody targeting CD22(abatacept). This combination, never before used, has the potential to achieve better disease control with fewer transplant related complications. 
Additionally, the investigators are performing research (gene therapy) research on cells collected from participants in this study. This research has several goals. First, to determine the optimal conditions for gene delivery; second, to understand the natural history of SCD and other medical conditions in study participants; and third, to learn more about the participants' immune systems and whether this combination therapy can reprogram their immune system and reduce reliance on frequent blood transfusions - a necessary treatment for SCD but which has long-term complications. The investigators believe that the combination of a less intense transplant combined with a research component provides the participant with the best opportunity of a more stable clinical course with less dependence upon transfusion.

Studies have shown that single nucleotide gene polymorphism (SNPs) in the gene of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) contribute to the severity of allergic rhinitis. On the contrary, BDNF polymorphism have not been linked to peripheral sensitization in allergic rhinitis. As our previous finding, we showed that the frequency of the BDNF CC genotype was 94.0 % (n=45) in our group of allergic patients with the CC genotype had significantly higher symptom assessment scores, and the BDNF CC genotype was associated with more frequent symptoms. It is noteworthy to say that the symptoms were scored on the same 5 day diary as the assessment of nasal symptoms and olfaction.
In addition, peripheral inflammation was demonstrated in patients with allergic rhinitis in previous studies in the form of increased levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Our recent data have shown that allergen exposure, which can trigger inflammation through several mechanisms, leads to an increase in the gene expression of the BDNF gene in nasal mucosa. Thus, allergen exposure and inflammation might enhance the activity of nasal BDNF in patients with allergic rhinitis. The activity of BDNF protein causes the sensitization of peripheral nerves in allergic rhinitis, and it might have a vital role in the symptoms of allergic rhinitis.

Mindfulness-Based Interventions (MBI) are a type of meditation-based intervention that have shown efficacy in improving well-being in a variety of populations, and in various domains including stress reduction, quality of life, emotion regulation, and cognitive processes. There is evidence that mindfulness-based interventions promote wellness and resilience in healthy populations. However, most MBI research focused on young adults rather than older adults. Even though there is also evidence that mindfulness is an effective intervention also for this population, there is still a lack of studies investigating the effects of mindfulness in older adults.
In contrast to standard cognitive interventions, MBI does not emphasize cognitive improvements (i.e., memory, attention) but rather the promotion of well-being and resilience. MBI is also associated with changes in cortical function as assessed by event-related potential (ERP) and electroencephalography (EEG). However, a study on the impact of MBI on emotional regulation and on brain activity of older adults is lacking.
Thus, the goal of this study is to investigate the effect of MBI intervention in enhancing EEG activity associated with cognitive and psychophysiological well-being in older subjects and to examine correlations between different variables (cognitive, psychophysiological, and personality measures) with EEG activity. Specifically, this study aims to test the following hypothesis: 1) MBI intervention will enhance well-being and cognitive resilience as measured by EEG activity in older adults 2) personality traits might influence the effects of MBI 3) mindfulness and cortical activity will be related to cognitive and psychophysiological measures.

Mycoplasma genitalium (MG) is a sexually transmitted bacterial infection increasingly recognized as a cause of sexually transmitted disease (STD). It is a common cause of urethritis, cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease in women, with possible long term sequelae such as infertility and pelvic pain. MG infection is one of the causes implicated in recurrent urethritis in men. MG infection has also been implicated in the recent decline in the effectiveness of certain antibiotics used to treat other STDs.
MG infection is highly associated with other major STDs and viral or bacterial resistance mutations. MG is increasing in prevalence and is now recognized as the second most common bacterium causing sexually transmitted urethritis in men, with infection rates reaching 20% among men who have sex with men (MSM). However, the high prevalence of MG infection, along with other major STDs, has not been reported in Hong Kong, and studies on STDs are rare in Hong Kong. The prevalence of MG infection is unknown in different populations in Hong Kong.
As the prevalence of MG infection in the general population is high in MSM, heterosexual men who have sex with males, and in viral suppression, and as MG is frequently associated with other major STDs, such as Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) and Neisseria gonorrhoeae (NG) infection, the clinical implications of MG infection warrant clinical attention and investigation. MG treatment is also becoming increasingly challenging due to the emergence of antimicrobial resistance in certain cases. Although there are some studies on MG infection in Europe and North America, there is no study reporting the prevalence of MG infection in Asia. This study intends to fill the gap of data from Asia.
In this study, we aim to explore the prevalence of MG infection along with CT and NG infection in different populations in Hong Kong, which also allows better understanding of the prevalence of MG infection, treatment patterns and antimicrobial resistance patterns.
Hypothesis:
The aims of this study are:
1. To study the prevalence of MG infection and associated antibiotic resistance mutations in different populations
2. To evaluate potential risk factor for MG infection among different populations
3. To evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of self-sampling STD testing kits in the general male population, particularly for HIV-infected persons.

Background: Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide and the leading cause of cancer-related death in women. Hormone receptor (HR)-positive breast cancer refers to tumors that express estrogen receptors (ER) and/or progesterone receptors (PR), with or without overexpression of the HER2 receptor (c-erbB2 (HER2/neu)). Hormone-therapy (HT) is the mainstay of treatment for patients with HR-positive breast cancer. Due to the lack of available data on HR-positive and HER2-negative advanced breast cancer (ABC) patients after CDK4/6 inhibitors failure, it remains unclear whether combination chemotherapy can improve the progression-free survival (PFS) of HR-positive and HER2-negative ABC patients after CDK4/6 inhibitor failure. In the DAWNA study, the investigators hypothesized that the combination of CDK4/6 inhibitors with endocrine therapy would lead to better PFS than endocrine therapy alone in first-line therapy or after endocrine therapy failure. However, there is no standardized treatment following CDK4/6 inhibitor failure. The objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of dalpiciclib in combination with physician-selected endocrine therapy for second-line treatment compared to chemotherapy in ABC patients with HR-positive and HER2-negative who failed the use of CDK4/6 inhibitors.

Methods: This is a single-arm, prospective, open-label, phase-II clinical study. It is a non-randomized trial with the aim to investigate the efficacy of dalpiciclib (a CDK4/6 inhibitor) in combination with physician-selected endocrine therapy in patients with HR-positive and HER2-negative recurrent/metastatic breast cancer (R/M) who failed the use of CDK4/6 inhibitors. The study population will be recruited at Nanfang Hospital of Southern Medical University, Guangzhou, China. A total of 50 female, HR-positive, and HER2-negative R/M breast cancer patients will be treated with the planned combination treatment of the combination of dalpiciclib with physician-selected endocrine therapy. In addition, 18F-fluoroestradiol (FES) positron emission tomography-computed tomography (PET/CT) will be used to assess ER positive sites of disease in patients. All patients will receive FDS PET/CT scans for screening and every 3 months for disease assessment. PFS, objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and overall survival (OS) will be evaluated for efficacy. Adverse events of both the drugs will be collected, and the safety of the combination treatment will be evaluated throughout the study period.

Official Title: An Exploratory Study on Predicting the Efficacy of Dalpiciclib in Combination With Endocrine Therapy for HR-Positive and HER2-Negative Recurrent/Metastatic Breast Cancer Patients After CDK4/6 Inhibitor Treatment Failure Using 18F-Fes PET/CT

Conditions: Advanced Breast Cancer

Intervention / Treatment:
* Drug: The combination of Dalpiciclib with physician-selected endocrine therapy
* Drug: Chemotherapy selected by the physician


Participation Criteria: 
Eligibility Criteria:
Hematology, blood pressure, blood chemistry, etc., should be normal 
Patient agrees to take effective contraceptive measures during the study period, pregnancy and lactation are forbidden, and not receiving breast cancer surgery or radiation therapy during the study period

Older adults are less physically active than the average adult, which puts them at risk for chronic diseases and cognitive decline. Monetary incentives have been used to increase physical activity, but have mixed results. In this study, we aim to evaluate the impact of alternative incentives on physical activity (step count) of older adults. Half the participants will earn monetary incentives and meal donations on their behalf for each day they meet a daily step goal, for up to 5 days a week. The investigators will track their step count using the Fitbit device for 8 weeks.

<|assistant|> Newborns in low income countries (LICs) suffer a higher burden of complications than newborns in high income settings. Despite a number of technological interventions, newborn mortality in Kenya remains unacceptably high at 8.7 per 1000 live births. We propose the use of neoGuard - a wireless vital signs monitor designed to increase the accuracy of newborn monitoring in LICs. NeoGuard measures the pulse rate, respiratory rate, blood oxygen saturation and temperature of newborns automatically and continuously. It was developed by the team at Neopenda, PBC (Chicago, Illinois) and is now available as a regulated medical product in Kenya. Our hypothesis is that neoGuard will enhance detection and management of physiological changes, which will result in cost savings for the hospital, better newborn health results, and improved care of sick newborns. The study will take place in the MTRH NICU and neonatal ward in Kenya. We plan to enroll 400 newborns at high risk for complications over 18 months. Enrolled patients will be assigned to receive either neoGuard or standard-of-care monitoring, depending on the sub-unit of the NICU to which they are admitted. We will collect daily data on clinical outcomes (e.g., complications, interventions, treatments), clinical pathways (e.g. duration of hospital stay, intensive care admission rates), and the cost of newborn care. Additionally, the feasibility of using neoGuard, the acceptability/usability of the device, and health economics outcomes (e.g. incremental cost-effectiveness) will be studied. Our primary aim is to describe the effectiveness of neoGuard in detecting physiological changes among high-risk newborns using a user-friendly, continuous vital signs monitoring system. The secondary aim is to evaluate the clinical impact of neoGuard in terms of patient complications, in-hospital mortality, as well as the total cost of care in the MTRH NICU and neonatal ward. Official Title ----------------- Evaluating the Clinical Impact and Cost-effectiveness of a Wireless Vital Signs Monitor for Hospitalized Newborns in Kenya Conditions ----------------- Newborn Complication, Newborn, Morbidity Intervention / Treatment ----------------- * Device: neoGuard vital signs monitor Participation Criteria ================= Eligibility Criteria ----------------- Inclusion Criteria: Must be admitted to one of the subunits assigned to receive the intervention (i.e., APU category A or B, the HDU-1 or HDU-2) The newborn's parent/guardian must provide informed consent to use the neoGuard system on their newborn. Exclusion Criteria: Assessed to have congenital anomalies that are incompatible with life Receiving palliative care Patients undergoing phototherapy Those with open head injuries/lacerations Those receiving treatment that might interfere with application of the neoGuard device Ages Eligible for Study ----------------- Minimum Age: 0 Days Maximum Age: 28 Days Sexes Eligible for Study ----------------- All Accepts Healthy Volunteers ----------------- No Study Plan ================= How is the study designed? ----------------- Arms and Interventions | Participant Group/Arm | Intervention/Treatment | | --- | --- | | Intervention Group
The intervention group consists of patients admitted to the 4 neonatal subunits where neoGuard was installed: the preterm units (category A and category B), and the high dependence units (HDU-1 and HDU-2). | Device: neoGuard vital signs monitor
* The neoGuard device is a 4-in-1 wearable vital signs monitor developed by Neopenda, PBC (Chicago, Illinois). The system is designed to continuously measure temperature, pulse rate (PR), respiratory rate (RR) and blood oxygen saturation (SpO2). It contains two non-invasive sensors: an optical reflectance pulse oximeter and a digital temperature sensor. These sensors measure signals from the surface of the patient's skin, and algorithms within the device calculate the pulse rate, respiratory rate, SpO2 and temperature.
