Among soft tissue sarcomas, the most frequent is extremity soft tissue sarcoma, for which several retrospective studies, based on clinical or pathological features, have shown that radiation therapy (RT) significantly improves local control, especially in tumors larger than 5 cm. This is also the case for trunk soft tissue sarcomas, which are rarer, for which the literature is limited but suggests improved local control by RT. Thus, the benefit of RT in soft tissue sarcomas has been proven for anatomopathological tumors large than 5 centimeters, whatever the site of the tumor (proximal muscles), regardless of surgery or not. This benefit remains to be demonstrated in small or intermediate size tumors. The rarity of soft tissue sarcomas limits access to this radical treatment for many patients.
Sarcoma of extremities and trunk are nowadays considered as "highly treatable diseases". Treatments are thus adapted to the patient's physical performance and age, especially for the oldest or the most fragile ones. Thus, the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines for soft tissue sarcomas now provide specific recommendations for patients aged 70 years or more. This is also true for patients with limited physical performance. A recent multi-institutional French study confirmed the safety of RT in patients over the age of 70 with extremity soft tissue sarcomas, with a survival in elderly patients comparable to younger patients. Furthermore, RT seems to be safe for elderly and fragile populations.
In order for RT to be systematically proposed for patients over 70 or limited physical performance, the dose of RT used to date has been adapted in a phase II study, increasing the dose on a proton beam for an initial period of 30 Gy in 5 fractions, then completing RT at 40 Gy in 15 fractions. This adaptation of treatment allowed reducing the duration of RT from 5 weeks to 2,5, which appears acceptable for the older patients.
The purpose of this multicenter study is to analyze the initial response to induction chemotherapy and its predictive value on the effectiveness of subsequent irradiation.
HYPOTHESES:
The primary objective is to determine the rate of patients free of immediate surgical complication of irradiation, defined by the Clavien-Dindo classification, grade 3 to 5, in patients over 65 years or limited physical performance, treated with hypofractionated RT (30 Gy in 5 fractions) for extremity or trunk soft tissue sarcoma with good general health.
The secondary objectives are to:
- Determine the rate of patients in complete remission (pCR), the rate of patients with residual tissue, and evaluate the local control rate and the overall mortality rate at 2 years in patients over 65 years of age or limited physical performance who have undergone neoadjuvant hypofractionated radiotherapy (30 Gy in 5 fractions);
- Determine the rate of patients free of immediate surgical complications defined by Clavien-Dindo score, grade 3 to 5, in patients over 65 years or limited physical performance who will receive surgical and postoperative hypofractionated radiation therapy (40 Gy in 15 fractions);
- Determine the incidence rate of postoperative complications defined by the Clavien-Dindo score assessed 1 month after surgery and at 3 months and 6 months post-surgery; then at 3 years;
- Determine the incidence of late radiation therapy side effects in patients over 65 years of age or limited physical performance within 6 months after neo-adjuvant and adjuvant hypofractionated RT: overall toxicity, wound disruption, wound healing time, wound diseases, quality of life, patient's physical performance, and survival;
- Determine the rate of patients with persistent local disease (disease free survival within 3 years) and overall survival in patients over 65 or limited physical performance.
METHODS:
- Multi-centric open and non-comparative trial (phases 1, 2). The protocol aims to recruit 154 patients, 77 in each phase.
- Inclusion of patients with a histological-verified soft tissue sarcoma (proximal and/or distal muscle sarcomas) over 65 years or presenting a limited physical performance who will receive hypofractionated RT for small or intermediate size tumors (less than 10 cm).

The most common site involved in the study of head and neck cancer (HNCs) is the oral cavity. The second most common type is the oropharynx, which is followed by the hypopharynx, nasopharynx, and the larynx. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), tobacco is responsible for 65% of HNCs, while alcohol consumption or use of smokeless tobacco is responsible for 10%. The human immunodeficiency viruses (HIV) are responsible for 16% of HNCs. According to the Globocan study, the incidence of HNCs in South Asia is 14.6/100 lakh population. There is limited data available in regards to HNCs in Nepal, and as we have a paucity of data regarding head and neck cancers, this study was performed to know the profile of patients, age-wise distribution of HNCs, tumor subsites, lymph nodal involvement, histopathology, TNM staging, and treatment modalities of HNCs in Army Hospital of Nepal.

The study will enroll 1,150 children at-risk for OSA, aged 2 to 13 years, across 8 primary care clinics. 698 children screen positive for OSA and will receive the intervention (information about OSA and the recommendation to discuss this with the provider at the visit). The purpose of this study is to assess the real world impact of Upadacitinib in CD patients in clinical practice. The study will prospectively enroll adult patients with moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease and then follow them for a duration of 52 weeks.
Outcome measures includes:
1. The speed of onset of treatment effect at the individual patient level as assessed by daily Crohn's Disease- Patient Reported Outcome (CR-PRO), a primary clinically relevant endpoint evaluated in randomized trials in clinical development.
2. The sustainability of treatment response at the subject level as assessed by the physician clinical remission at end of induction therapy for Upadacitinib and Crohn's Disease Activity Index (CDAI) response.
The design of this study will allow the examination of upadacitinib's onset of anti-inflammatory action and clinical benefits at the individual patient level early in treatment. This may help to expedite the evaluation of upadacitinib's benefit profile. At the same time, physicians, patients and caregivers will be able to observe how patients respond to Upadacitinib over time, including both short and long-term benefits, allowing the evaluation of a comprehensive benefit-risk profile.

These activities will take approximately 20 minutes to complete.

Trauma is one of the main causes of death in the industrial nations Germany and Switzerland. In 2015, about 7% of deaths were due to trauma. In Switzerland, 6,600 were killed and 188,000 victims were injured in 2012, 18% of which suffered severe injuries that caused long-term disability. Of the 80,000 injured per year, 25,000 people die due to their injuries and one of three patients suffer from long-term physical, psychological or social consequences.
Surgery in the vascular trauma area is in the forefront of therapy. A vascular trauma is defined as a traumatic injury of the arteries, veins, nerves and other blood vessels and includes a wide range of surgical interventions, ranging from simple hemostasis to complex vascular reconstructions including grafting or the use of stents.
In patients with post-traumatic sequelae, therapy is often necessary in the long-term, such as repeated operations, amputations or other interventions. These interventions can be costly for patients and health insurers, as re-interventions are often associated with a longer hospital stay, a higher number of days of absence and higher costs for health systems. However, there are no studies to evaluate the costs in patients after vascular trauma.
The aim of the study is to gather information to identify predictors of long-term functional limitations and vascular-related complications such as bleeding or thrombosis, to identify predictors of long-term functional limitations and vascular-related complications, and to evaluate the costs incurred by these complications. The information obtained will guide in the future the development of early preventive interventions or the treatment of patients as well as the development of cost-effective strategies. The study is a prospective and multicenter nation-wide registry. All patients who have suffered vascular injury in trauma, have an isolated vascular injury and who are undergoing surgery or other intervention will be asked to participate in the registry. Data is collected at three time points during the first year after trauma (3, 6 and 12 months after the trauma). The registry is performed in conjunction with the vascular trauma congresses in Basel. An annual congress was organized and held in 2013, 2014 and 2016 in Basel. In the future, the number of annual meetings will be expanded. The collection of data will take place in parallel. Vascular trauma is defined as trauma-related damage to the vascular system, including injury to the arteries, veins, blood vessels and the peripheral nerves. The injury may be due to sharp or blunt trauma (e.g. stab or gunshot wound) or other means of injury.
This registry aims to achieve the following:
- To collect extensive demographic, clinical, surgical and cost data in patients with vascular injury after trauma.
- To follow up these patients for at least one year after the trauma.
- To evaluate predictors of long-term functional limitations and vascular - related complications.
- To evaluate the need for re-interventions such as repeated operations etc.
- To determine whether the above factors have an influence on the costs incurred by these complications.
Vascular injury in major trauma is one of the most common surgical therapies. The incidence and extent of traumatic vascular injuries (including the necessary surgical interventions) have been recorded for many years by a number of international registries such as the World Safety Survey for Emergency Care and Transport, the European Trauma Registry and the Swiss Acute Care Survey. However, there is no prospective multicenter registry in patients with traumatic vascular injury. The Swiss Trauma Registry has collected data on blunt abdominal trauma and trauma in children. Thus, an international registry in this field would greatly enhance the knowledge about the effects of vascular trauma and its consequences. The establishment of a Swiss registry would be helpful because it could be linked to other national trauma or vascular registries in order to create a complete image of the problem, and would be compatible with the legal conditions of patient data protection.
The vascular trauma congress is dedicated specifically to traumatic injuries of the vascular system. The congress provides the opportunity to collect important demographic and outcome data from expert centres and physicians. Additionally, in the future more than one or two vascular trauma congresses will be held annually in order to collect more comprehensive data, resulting in more statistical analysis.

- What are the demographic characteristics (

The purpose of this study is to assess the effect of peripheral blood flow restriction (BFR) rehabilitation on the improvement of range of motion, muscle strength, muscle mass and bone density in patients with operatively treated distal radius fractures.

Study Procedure: The study requires two visits per week until the physical therapy program is complete. All participants will undergo the standard rehabilitation program consisting of a hand therapist at Cedars Sinai with the standard protocol for post-operative distal radius fracture rehabilitation that is tailored to the patients individual needs. Additionally, they will complete standardized outcome assessments and questionnaires that measure for pain/symptoms and functional ability pre and post-operatively. The BFR group will, in addition to this standard protocol, undergo BFR therapy following each physical therapy session. BFR therapy will be performed for 20 minutes at the individuals individual limb occlusion pressure during specific exercises.
Subjects will be required to complete questionnaires and undergo standardized outcome assessments on each visit. All assessments will be performed by an independent Physical Therapist on each visit. The baseline assessment will be conducted the day of surgery and will include a DEXA scan to determine bone density and body composition, as well as a full evaluation of forearm girth. They will then receive a follow-up assessment at 1 week, 6 weeks, 12 weeks and will follow the standard post-operative physical therapy protocol.  Measures will be performed at multiple time points over the course of the year long study to ensure no changes in the patients' state occur between measurements.

This 2-arm randomized controlled trial evaluated the effect on office workers using the STAND-BY app. It included 120 office workers recruited from three higher education institutions. Anthropometrics, blood chemistry, sitting time, pain pressure threshold, subjective musculoskeletal symptoms, and the work environment were measured. The office workers had a sitting time greater than two-thirds of their workday (71%), which significantly decreased from 96.2% to 88.3% at the end of the 6-month study (difference: 2.2%, 95%CI: 1.08 to 3.35). There were no important changes on cardiometabolic indicators or musculoskeletal symptoms. Only one third of the participants adhered to the app-based intervention and barriers included: the lack of time, low perceived need, and the low awareness of the program benefits according to the participants. The results of this study suggests that the app-based intervention does not modify most of the observed indicators. The lack of effects could be attributed to the inadequate adherence to the app-based interventions.

<|assistant|> The incidence of acute myocardial infarction (MI): the first major adverse cardiovascular event (MACE) in men and non-obstructive CAD women is between 1 in 6 and 1 in 7 (depending on the definition) over a period of 2 to 3 years, increasing in men with obstructive CAD to 1 in 4 to 1 in 3. However, most patients present without obstructive coronary artery disease (CAD) and the burden of this asymptomatic syndrome is largely underestimated. In 2016, MI incidence was 1.8 per 1000 person-years of follow-up with a 24% (95% CI: 18--30%) increase over the same period. CAD is primarily a chronic, progressive, inflammatory process that is initially driven by risk factors (e.g. hypertension and dyslipidemia), leading to the buildup of large lipid-rich atherosclerotic plaques in the coronary arteries. Once a lesion reaches a critical size and is unstable, it can spontaneously rupture or can be triggered by plaque disruption following a transient increase in coronary artery pressure. Thus, early detection and treatment of patients at high risk of disease progression would improve their prognosis significantly. To date, several approaches have been proposed. These include drug therapy, percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), implantable and non-invasive devices. However, most of these solutions require invasive approaches and have not been validated in prospective, controlled, long-term trials. The primary objective of the present study is to develop an AI-based model for CAD risk stratification. This multimodal diagnostic model will integrate clinical and imaging risk features such as plaque morphology. Pericoronary adipose tissue (PCAT) attenuation, coronary artery topology (e.g. tortuosity, vessel length, cross-sectional area, etc) into a composite biomarker that will be evaluated through an independent follow-up period in a large retrospective cohort. The secondary objective is to provide a platform capable of delivering this software solution to healthcare providers via web interface. The current lack of user-friendly, validated, and externally validated AI-based software solutions is preventing the widespread integration of AI into the clinical workflow, hindering its potential beneficial effects to patients. The retrospective cohort will include 2500 patients who underwent a clinically indicated cCTA examination for CAD evaluation. These patients will be analyzed for the first primary and secondary outcome over a period of 3 years. The prospective cohort will include 500 patients who underwent a clinically indicated cCTA examination for CAD evaluation and will be prospectively followed-up for 3 years. Both cohort will be used for the development of the AI-based risk prediction model. Subsequently, this model will be externally validated using data from the retrospective cohort. Furthermore, the software solution will undergo a pilot test in order to test its usability and reliability before its integration into the clinical workflow by a group of selected healthcare providers. The symptoms of new coronavirus infection often have obvious systemic symptoms, such as fever, cough, expectoration, fatigue, shortness of breath, sore throat, etc. As the new crown epidemic situation has been continuously improving, some patients need to be discharged from the hospital relatively early, and the patients were still in the recovery stage after leaving the hospital. At this stage, physical energy is still scarce, and exercise intolerance is obvious, which seriously affects the quality of life of patients. Therefore, how to effectively delay the symptoms of patients, improve their exercise tolerance and accelerate their body's recovery is the key problem faced by clinical work. To observe the effects of Yupingfeng decoction on relieving the symptoms and promoting the rehabilitation of patients after recovery. It is planned to conduct a systematic and rigorous, high-quality multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial. This study is mainly applied to patients with a good clinical response during recovery, and the researchers hope to provide data support and clinical evidence for the effectiveness and safety of Yupingfeng decoction in patients with novel coronavirus infection in the convalescent period and provide reference for clinical and basic research on the treatment and improvement of novel coronavirus infection with TCM. The research results provide a guarantee for the subsequent clinical application of Yupingfeng decoction. It is hoped that this will be a new attempt and innovation in the treatment and improvement of novel coronavirus infection with TCM.

The fast growth of Decision Neuroscience is contributing to unveil the cognitive processes underlying choices and their neural bases. The results obtained so far show that decision-making involves neural mechanisms underpinning a complex balance between automatic appetitive or aversive drives generated by subcortical structures, and processes of executive control centered in fronto-parietal brain networks. While the role of meso-limbic structures in reinforcement learning have been widely investigated, it is much less clear to what extent are choices shaped by a) individual differences in executive skills; b) contextual factors potentially interfering with such skills, such as knowing that the outcome of those choices will impact only on one's own vs. another's welfare. This a critical gap, since executive abilities are known to decline even in physiological ageing, thus potentially interfering with the quality of choices. On this ground, this single center non-interventional fMRI study aims to provide novel insights into the relationship between executive and decision-making skills, and their possible changes with ageing, in 150 healthy individuals. This goal will be pursued by combining a behavioral assessment of decision-making and executive skills with a multimodal fMRI session including data concerning a) brain activity associated with decision-making and executive functioning in social vs. non-social contexts, b) brain structural morphometry (grey-matter volume/density), and c) brain structural connectivity (diffusion weighted imaging). The behavioral assessment will involve the main metric of decision-making (e.g., risk aversion, loss aversion, delay discounting) and executive functioning (e.g., selective attention and inhibitory control). MRI data will unveil the neural bases of individual differences in decision-making and executive performance in terms of performance-related patterns of brain activity, structure and connectivity. Results will provide an useful baseline for investigating alterations of decision-making and executive functioning, and of their neural bases, in pathological conditions.

The participants will be randomised to one of two groups and provide their consent to be in the study prior to participating. Participants will then undergo the use of the Neutrocheck system, and when completed, will complete a questionnaire to measure user satisfaction.
The intervention of this study will include the measurement of usability and adapting procedures to support ease of use and user satisfaction.

PD is a progressive, complex, and multi-symptom disorder characterized by a combination of motor and non-motor symptoms which includes a triad of symptoms: shaking, slowness and stiffness. The latter is a very problematic symptom and leads to difficulty walking, stiff and rigid muscles, and impaired postural stability. Walking also becomes slow, shuffling and affected by freezing. This difficulty is associated with functional decline, reduction in physical activity, and decreased social participation and physical function. The cost to the Canadian economy is at least $1 billion per year and only 18 % of those who need it are getting it. The aim of this research program is to improve gait and physical function in persons with PD (PwP) through optimization and adoption of technology. The research program is inspired by our findings in previous research studies 66-69. These studies revealed that an intervention based on providing individuals with PD with an auditory-visual device providing real-time feedback regarding their heel strike when walking resulted in improved gait, walking cadence and walking distance. These findings are in keeping with the findings of another study on the same technology in a younger population with multiple sclerosis 70-72. The investigators aim to address issues regarding the use of the Heel2Toe sensor among community dwelling PwP through a three-year mixed methods study.
First, they will determine which PwP will be responsive (user-friendly) and for who, the intervention is a practical fit for their daily routines. Second, they will provide a sensor to all PwP recruited and will examine whether the sensor is safe for home use. Third, the investigators will use a stepped-wedge cluster randomized trial design to answer the question of whether the technology will improve gait performance in PwP and whether the technology will ultimately promote behaviour change and increase physical activity.
The overall purpose of this study is to answer the following three objectives: 1) Identify technical, attitudinal and motivational obstacles and solutions for people with PD for adopting technology to improve gait. Second, whether the Heel2Toe technology improves gait performance in PD. Third, whether the Heel2Toe technology has the potential to promote an increase in physical activity and improved functional capacity in people with PD.
It is proposed that the team will enroll 200 PwP meeting the criteria for technology readiness and having a minimum of some walking capacity to use the Heel2Toe. All participants will be asked to answer one final questionnaire to quantify the impact of participating in the study. They will be given up to $180 in credits. All participants will answer an initial online questionnaire and send a video. Following the receipt of these responses, the persons who have enough walking capacity to use the Heel2Toe will be identified. A total of 10 blocks of 10 will be formed. Within each block, half of the PwP will be randomized to be assigned the Heel2Toe immediately and the other half will be randomized to be assigned the Heel2Toe after a delay of 3-4 weeks. They will all undergo quantitative assessments at baseline, after 3 months, and after 6 months. Additionally, participants who undergo Heel2Toe training will also be randomly assigned to be followed for 12 months to evaluate long-term changes and identify additional benefits of using Heel2Toe.

Intellectual and physical disability are common among children and adolescents in Hong Kong. Around one million people in Hong Kong report some form of disability. Children with intellectual and physical disability may experience challenges in communicating and interacting with peers, leading to long-term psychiatric difficulties including depression, anxiety, loneliness, and psychosocial problems. Laughter brings people more happiness, laughter and joy to help improve health and happiness through promoting better wellness and reducing health costs. The laughter yoga has been proven effective in reducing people's levels of stress, anxiety, depression, loneliness, and strengthening the immune system and keep the mind positive. Therefore, the purpose of a 4-week laughter yoga programme (8 sessions) combined with mindfulness activities is to help adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities bring more happiness, laughter and joy to promote their mental health status. To accomplish this, a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) design will be adopted to study the feasibility of laughter yoga programme in special school adolescents.

Background: 

Cervical cancer screening (Pap test or HPV testing), which assesses the risk of developing cervical cancer, has been widely employed as a prevention strategy. However, uptake of cervical cancer screening is relatively low in South Asian women, even though they are at an increased risk of developing cervical cancer due to their genetic and cultural characteristics. One major barrier is the lack of understanding of screening options. A decision aid in the form of a booklet or a mobile application can aid women in making an informed decision. Our pilot study showed positive effects of decision aids on knowledge about the screening options and risk perceptions. The current trial aims to test the effectiveness of printed and mobile decision aids on the uptake of cervical cancer screening in South Asian women in Hong Kong.

Objectives:

The study aims to test the effectiveness of different forms of decision aids on South Asian women's uptake of cervical cancer screening using the following methods:

i. A pilot randomised controlled trial of the effects of a printed screening decision aid, a mobile screening decision aid and a leaftlet;

ii. A cohort study tracking all the women in the trial to understand the contextual factors that influence cervical testing uptake.

Study design:

In this multicentre pilot randomised controlled trial (Phase 2), 200 South Asian women will be randomly allocated to different groups:

1. Control (leaftlet about healthy living)
2. Experimental A (printed screening decision aid)
3. Experimental B (mobile screening decision aid)

The subjects will be asked to provide personal details, cancer risk perception, and uptake of cervical cancer screening through questionnaires at baseline and two weeks after. The participants will be followed up at three months to track their uptake of cervical cancer screening.

The results of the trial may provide useful information to increase cervical cancer screening rates among South Asian women in Hong Kong. It may also shed light on cultural sensitivities and barriers in different language and cultural groups in the community. 

This study will enhance our understanding of the effectiveness of decision aids in improving the uptake of cervical cancer screening.

The purpose of this study is to investigate the additional effect of Denneroll cervical traction orthodontic traction for forward head posture correction impact on myogenic temporomandibular dysfunction.
In this study, a randomized controlled design will be followed between 2 groups, the first group will undergo conservative management for temporomandibular dysfunction myofascial component including stretching exercise with placebo traction for forward head posture correction, where as the second group will undergo the same conservative management as the first group in addition to Denneroll cervical traction orthodontic traction for forward head posture correction. The primary outcome measures will be TMD symptoms using Fonseca's questionnaire, craniocervical angle measurement and mouth opening measurement assessing TMJ movement, and pain perception using Visual Analog Scale. Evaluations will be carried out for the first group at baseline, third week, and week 7, while the evaluations for the second group at the same time frames will be postponed till the ninth week. The investigators expect that the Denneroll cervical traction orthodontic for the second group will have further effects on temporomandibular dysfunction reducing the disability and its related pain comparing to the group that will have the conservative management only.

This is a comparative efficacy study to determine whether once daily topical Dapsone is non inferior to the two time per day treatment schedule of Clindamycin phospate. Patients will be enrolled after informed consent and medical history, followed by a 2-week washout period. The efficacy of the treatments will be determined by the mean difference of GAGS score before and after the treatment. The purpose of this study is to determine the differences in muscle activation patterns for scapular and rotator cuff muscles in individuals with small, medium, large, and massive rotator cuff tears by measuring the amplitude of these muscles during shoulder flexion, abduction, and external rotation. It is hypothesized that muscle activation patterns of the musculature stabilizing the scapula and rotator cuff will change with tear size, becoming less effective at small t-ears and showing significant differences with increasing tear size. This study will employ scapular electromyography data at 25% effort level to assess muscle activation patterns. This study is a first step in understanding alterations in muscle activation patterns with increasing tear size.

The SENIOR RCT is a multicenter study conducted in two North Italian Scientific Hospitalization and Treatment Institution in Pavia on older malnourished adults (≥ 65 years old). The estimated duration is 24 months, which include 6 months of nutritional intervention and a follow-up after 6 months, with an preferred starting date on January 2024. The primary objective of the SENIOR RCT is the evaluation of the efficacy of a 6 months sustainable nutrition protocol on malnourished older adults participants (diagnosed with the most recent GLIM criteria) in comparison to the hospital standard of care. Therefore, the primary endpoint is the improvement of the nutritional status between pre- and post-intervention between experimental and control group measuring the change of body weight and strength (handgrip). Secondary objectives are the change pre- and post-intervention between experimental and control group for blood biomarkers, dietary habits, quality of life and evaluation of sarcopenia. Secondary endpoints are the change pre- and post-intervention between experimental and control group for blood biomarkers, MEDI-LITE score, SF-12, diet composition, phase angle and gait speed. Participants of this study are older adults over 65 previously enrolled in the SENIOR cross-sectional study and willing to participate to the RCT phase or new enrolled patients from the two hospitals in according to the eligible criteria. Malnutrition will be diagnosed according to GLIM criteria, using Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST) as screening tool. The experimental group at the baseline will receive a nutritional assessment followed by the elaboration of a sustainable and personalized nutritional protocol by qualified dietitians. The intervention will last 6 months with a monthly evaluation of the dietary consumption of the previous 24 hour (recall-24h), followed by a final follow-up after additional 6 months. For both groups at the baseline will be measured blood biomarkers, anthropometric variables, Mediterranean diet adherence, quality of life, strength (handgrip) and locomotion (gait speed). At 3 months weight and strength will be evaluated. At 6- and 12-months baseline measurements will be repeated except for the nutritional assessment. Dietary habits will be evaluated through a Mediterranean diet questionnaire (MEDI-LITE), while quality of life will be measured with Short-Form Health Survey (SF-12) questionnaire. Anthropometric variables include weight, height (knee height and demi-span), waist circumference, and body composition (BIA). In addition, strength (handgrip), Appendicular Skeletal Mass (ASM) and locomotion (gait speed) will be evaluated. Strength (handgrip), Appendicular Skeletal Mass (ASM) and locomotion (gait speed) are necessary to diagnose sarcopenia according to the European Working Group on Sarcopenia in Older People 2 (EWGSOP2) consensus. Malnutrition will be evaluated again at 6 months. Blood analysis will be carried out on a subgroup to evaluate the participants' inflammatory, nutritional and clinical status.

In these studies, our main goal is to determine whether B 3 or B 12 treatment helps to reduce the severity of TBI. The impact of this treatment on cognitive capacity, sensorimotor activity and the staircase test (working and reference memory) will be assessed. A total sample of 300 patients is estimated, the method of evaluation is to recruit children with severe TBI ages 6 to 15 years old. At 3 weeks and a year following the treatment, children will undergo neurobehavioral testing and the gait analysis. Paired t testing will be used to show the mean and standard error of the data when statistically examined.

A post-op adjuvant anti-HRE2 inhibitor, pyrotinib (JW741), is a novel, highly specific, oral, TKI, irreversible, and small molecule drug for inhibition of the HER2/neu receptor. Previous studies had suggested pyrotinib could prolong the disease-free survival (DFS) of TNBC patients in the adjuvant neoadjuvant setting. However, it is unclear about its efficacy and safety when used in primary breast cancer. This is a prospective, long-term follow-up study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of pyrotinib as maintenance treatment against recurrence after adjuvant anti-HRE2 therapy in women with high-risk in early or locally advanced (LA) breast cancer by the primary endpoint, iDFS at year 2. Eligible patients have been previously diagnosed with early or locally advanced stage breast cancer and been treated with standard anti-HER2 treatment. Patients will be treated with pyrotinib 400mg once a day after anti-HER2 (trastuzumab combined with pertuzumab or T-DM1) therapy until occurrence of adverse events intolerable to the patient or disease recurrence, and treatment will be discontinued after enrollment due to death, which may last for up to 2 years. The assessment of adverse events of the pyrotinib after adjuvant anti-HRE2 therapy and its efficacy in clinical application will be observed at the same time.

Objective: The aim of this study is to assess, for the first time, whether there is a difference between consuming pasta at lunch or dinner in terms of sleep quality, anthropometric parameters, cardiovascular risk factors, composition and functionality of the gut microbiota in a sample of normal-weight subjects. Additionally, chronotype (a construct indicating when a subject is most active during the day) will be taken into consideration.

Design details: The experimental study will be a randomised controlled trial and will involve 2 phases of nutritional intervention.

Study population: The sample will consist of 30 male and female subjects aged between 18 and 65 years (n=20 male and female aged between 18 and 45 years, n=10 male and female aged between 45 and 65 years).

Methods: First, subjects will spend a 24-hour measurement period at the Policlinico Gemelli nutrition and diet therapy department. Then, they will be invited to participate in the study. Once the baseline assessment is completed, subjects will be randomised into 2 groups: Group 1 will change their habitual dietary pattern, eating pasta at dinner for 3 months and then switch to consuming pasta at lunch for another 3 months. Group 2 will change their habitual dietary pattern, eating pasta at lunch for 3 months and then switch to consuming pasta at dinner for another 3 months.

The dietary intervention adopted in the experimental groups will be a normo-caloric Mediterranean diet. Calorie intake will be defined on the basis of the individual basal metabolic rate measured by indirect calorimetry and on the calculation of the participant's calorie intake extrapolated from a 3-day food diary. Calorie intake will be distributed as 20% calories at breakfast, 5% calories in the mid-morning snack, 40% calories at lunch, 5% calories in the mid-afternoon snack, and 30% calories at dinner.

Assessments regarding sleep quality (actigraphy), anthropometric parameters, cardiovascular risk factors, composition, and functionality of the gut microbiota will be conducted during the 7-month study period. Furthermore, dietary intake will be registered through 3-day food diary.

Background: Multiple myeloma (MM) is an incurable malignancy of plasma cells that leads to destructive bone lesions, renal damage, anemia, and hypercalcemia. MM is the second most common hematologic malignancy. The American Cancer Society estimates that annually over 34,000 new cases of MM will occur in the U.S. and over 12,000 deaths due to MM in 2022. Overall survival (OS) has improved significantly over the past 20 years with the development of proteasome inhibitors (PIs), immunomodulatory agents (IMiDs) and anti-CD38 monoclonal antibodies. However, despite these advances, patients ultimately succumb to their disease. With multiple lines of efficacious therapies, the correct early identification of relapsed disease is important to trigger initiation of a new line of therapy. Limitations in conventional imaging highlight a need for molecular imaging agents with better sensitivity for detecting and measuring tumor burden to improve staging and treatment selection for patients with MM and plasma cell dyscrasias. 18F-fluciclovine is a radionuclide approved by the FDA for evaluating suspected prostate cancer recurrence but has shown additional ability in detecting MM lesions. Objective: To determine the concordance between 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT in participants with multiple myeloma Eligibility: Participants >= 18 years old Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Performance score of 0 to 2 Participants must have a documented diagnosis of MM defined by the International Myeloma Working Group (IMWG) Criteria Participants fit criteria for one of the following categories: Newly diagnosed multiple myeloma (NDMM) without previous treatment (or within the first 3 cycles of front-line treatment) Relapsed and/or Refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM) with at least 1 prior line of therapy Design: This is an open-label, single center phase 2 study evaluating 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT imaging in up to 55 participants with multiple myeloma. Participants will be enrolled into one of two cohorts based on disease status; newly diagnosed multiple myeloma (NDMM) participants will be enrolled into Cohort 1 and relapsed refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM) participants will be enrolled into Cohort 2. All subjects will undergo an 18F-fluciclovine injection followed by a static whole-body PET/CT at three time points: Timepoint #1, Timepoint #2 (after induction treatment for NDMM or at 6 months for RRMM) and Timepoint #3 (at progression or at 5 years). Results will be compared to 18F-FDG PET/CT imaging at those same timepoints.

Background: Micro-invasive breast cancer (MIBC) is defined as infiltration of less than 1 mm. Its prognosis is poorer than DCIS. Invasive breast cancer is an incompletely differentiated, invasive tumor, and its prognosis is not as good as in situ breast cancer, even after breast-conserving surgery. HER2 gene amplification is a marker that determines the effect of treatment in breast cancer. A variety of studies have shown that HER2 overexpression is a very important marker for early breast cancer and is associated with poor prognosis.
Hypothesis: Compared with capecitabine alone, adding Pyrotinib to capecitabine can improve the invasive disease-free survival rate in patients with Her2-positive, microinvasive breast cancer. Based on the above hypothesis, the investigators propose the following scheme:
Allocation: The study will be randomized into three arms: no intervention group, single chemotherapy drug group, and combination chemotherapy drug group, and follow-up results were compared.
Intervention/Treatment: patients in the no intervention group and the single chemotherapy drug group do not receive any additional treatment after surgery (no adjuvant treatment), and patients in the combination drug group receive Pyrotinib and Capecitabine in combination. 
Finally, the main purpose of this prospective multicenter study is to observe the therapeutic effect of pyrotinib combined with capecitabine in improving the invasive disease-free survival rate of Her2-positive, microinvasive breast cancer patients.
This work is funded by grants from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 8175029 and 8205037), Youth Foundation of Science and Technology Department of Shanxi, China in recent three years (No. 6026); Key Research and Development Projects in Shanxi Province (No. 201803D03-4).

Paradoxical vocal fold motion (PVFM) is a disorder in which there are sudden, temporary breath holdings that occur during breathing but with vocal fold closure. Treatment options include various behavioral therapies, but they have not been widely studied. To guide future research and treatment development, the investigators plan to conduct a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) to compare the effects of video biofeedback and laryngeal control therapy (LCT) in improving PVFM outcomes at 1 month. The primary endpoint will be the change in Dyspnea Index score before treatment and one month after treatment. Patients will also complete surveys to assess their expectations of treatment, reasons for treatment, perceived benefits of treatment, and their symptoms 3 months after treatment. They hypothesize that no clinically meaningful difference will be detected between video biofeedback and LCT. This will help inform the design of a larger RCT comparing these two treatments.

The aims of this study will be to determine an intervention of multiple modifiable elements to promote sleep quality in critically ill patients and to evaluate the effect of these measures on sleep and sleep disorders. The investigators will conduct a cross-sectional study of patient sleep quality, a survey on perceptions among family members of sleep parameters, the incidence of associated delirium, and its duration. The investigators will then develop a Multidisciplinary Team Protocol to improve sleep quality in critically ill patients, after which a second study will be conducted to evaluate the perceptions of staff regarding this protocol and the knowledge among the multidisciplinary team of sleep disorders in critically ill patients. Finally, the investigators will conduct follow-up studies of the patients after their discharge from the ICU to assess the association of sleep quality with quality of life and risk associated with other outcomes.

Melissa Officianlis L. is a plant belonging to the Lamiaceae family known for its beneficial properties. This plant has been used since ancient times to treat various disorders, especially those related to anxiety and sleep quality. M. officinalis contains several phytochemicals, such as phenolic acids, flavonoids, terpenoids, and many others, which form the basis of its pharmacological activities. The plant exhibits antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antispasmodic, antimicrobial, and neuroprotective effects. Widely used since ancient times, M. officinalis has also been studied clinically, demonstrating interesting beneficial properties in the treatment of various conditions, including anxiety, sleep disorders, palpitations, hypertension, and depression. Nutraceuticals could be an alternative option to prescription drugs for alleviating symptoms associated with mild anxiety and insomnia. M. officinalis has been shown to be a stress-reducing and anxiolytic agent; in a study [Cases et al., 2011] conducted on subjects with mild to moderate anxiety and sleep disorders, M. officinalis extract reduced anxiety manifestations by 18%, improved anxiety-related symptoms by 15%, and reduced insomnia by 42%. Among the subjects who benefited from M. officinalis extract, 70% experienced a significant reduction in anxiety and 85% in insomnia. However, a limitation of the study was the absence of a control group, thus requiring a randomized controlled study with a placebo group. In light of the above, the aim of the current study is to further investigate the beneficial effects of a formulated M. officinalis extract in phytosome form (Phytosome®). The phytosome technology utilizes phospholipids derived from sunflowers as an element capable of modulating the absorption kinetics of plant-derived molecules, with the intention of optimizing the product's efficacy with the lowest effective dosage. The phytosome technology represents a potentially useful approach in optimizing the administration of M. officinalis extract, applicable to the described literature-based applications. Phytosome® is composed of a dry extract of Berberis aristata root (550mg/cpr), complexed with phospholipids (soy lecithin), Pisum sativa proteins, and proanthocyanidin oligomers from Vitis vinifera. The Melissa Phytosome-based product used has been registered with the Italian Ministry of Health. The specific application of interest is the induction and enhancement of physiological sleep dynamics. The data will be recorded by the Garmin Connect application (Garmin Ltd), which monitors sleep duration in different phases and allows for data extraction. The devices will be provided to the participants by the recruiting center for the duration of the entire study (6 weeks; 5 weeks of study plus 1 week of training). The device enables the extraction of sleep phase durations for each subject at the end of the study [Burgett et al., 2019]. The CGI-I assesses the overall improvement of a subject's symptoms compared to baseline, with scores ranging from 1 (''very much improved'') to 7 (''very much worse''). The goal of this study is to examine the effectiveness of Social Engage, a novel behavioral intervention, in increasing social connection of adults who are lonely. Social Engage is a 10 week, 10 session, individually delivered intervention to promote social connection and prevent suicide in older adults who live in senior living communities, are lonely, and have at least one suicide ideation in the last month. The intervention was designed to overcome barriers to increasing social connection and focuses on changing social goals, changing activity selection, and changing self-perception. In R33, we will examine the efficacy of the intervention in increasing social connection. The intervention will be integrated with smartphone technology to allow objective measurement of behavioral change over time. The R61 phase is a single-arm trial of S-ENG plus eCAU (n=30) with 1 week of smartphone-based target assessment at baseline, 8-weeks and 16-weeks. Participants are 30 adults age 60 and older who report clinically significant loneliness and suicide ideation and reside in a senior living community (SLC). We will use ambulatory assessment via smartphones, including both active self-report (ecological momentary assessment, EMA) and passive sensing (audio recordings & GPS) to comprehensively assess indices of social connection. Subjects will complete EMA recordings using a smartphone daily following 3 personally-selected times for prompts (to enhance recall and ease of completion of assessments) for 10-days prior to starting study interventions, beginning the day after the baseline visit. Each EMA instance takes approximately 2-5 minutes to complete. EMA will be integrated with other smartphone technology to passively capture social behavior. The Electronically Activated Recorder (EAR) will passively measure social behavior (i.e., conversation frequency, duration, and valence). GPS- will track time outside the home. Subjects will be given a study smartphone designed for older adults to use during assessment periods. All subjects who successfully complete the smartphone assessment protocol at baseline will be assigned to S-ENG. S-ENG involves 10 individual coaching sessions over (up to) 4 months. S-ENG is a stepped, modular intervention that addresses barriers to action plan implementation and challenges in processing positive outcomes when exposed to socially rewarding activities. Psychoeducational materials address the importance of social connection. Subjects complete a values clarification exercise on aspects of connection most important to participants to inform personalized activities most likely to impact loneliness. Coaches are instructed to focus action plans on activities that foster social connection. The follow-up assessments at 8- and 16-weeks include baseline measures and smartphone measures.

To evaluate the safety and tolerability of treatment with transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% (Gel sachet 1.5mg/ day and 2.0mg/ day) against oral dose of estradiol (2mg/ day) in women with Primary Ovarian Insufficiency.
An official approval has been given to recruit 46 participants eligible to participate in the study. All women with primary ovarian insufficiency on standard dose estradiol hormone replacement therapy (ET/p) were invited to the study. The study will include the participants with estradiol level of < 150 pmol/l as assessed in peripheral blood.
Women with Karyotypically normal POI will be selected from among those with Karyotypically normal POI, diagnosed before the age of 40. All participants should have used standard-dose estradiol HRT (Estradiol 2 mg+ Dydrogesterone 10 mg) for at least the last 12 months. Participants should have signed the informed consent before inclusion in the study. Subjects with significant health problems affecting the somatic status or having an expected influence on the study results will be excluded.
The study is a phase III interventional clinical trial designed as a multicenter, randomized, non-blinded, parallel group study with three stage randomization to increase dose strength of Estradiol - from 1.5 mg/day to 2.0 mg/day. In each study center, women will be treated with two different doses of transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% (Gel sachet 1.5mg/ day and 2.0mg/ day) against the background Estradiol 2 mg/ day as oral therapy. The order of dosing during the first stage of the study (1.5 mg/ day and 2.0mg/ day) will be randomized in a 1:4 ratio (1.5mg/day:3 participants, 2.0mg/day:12 participants). The treatment will be conducted in 3 stages for 12 months.
Efficacy of treatment will be evaluated as a change in levels of the individual symptoms (hot flushes, vaginal dryness, depression, sleep disorders, sexual disorders and skin irritation), quality of life, sexual function, estradiol and testosterone level as well as the impact of medication on bone mineral density.
The primary outcome of the study will be the severity of estrogen deficiency symptoms evaluated by the Green scale questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures include SF-36, MENQOL questionnaire and the influence of medication on bone mineral density according to Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DXA). The evaluation will be made initially and after 3 months against the background of HRT.

Over 90% of the world's population is exposed to low levels of sunshine on a daily basis, resulting in low vitamin D levels. While the best source of vitamin D is sun exposure, some populations are at great risk for insufficient or even deficient vitamin D levels from the limited sun exposure they receive. It has long been known that vitamin D supplementation is linked to better health outcomes (e.g., lower risk for cardiovascular disease, respiratory infections, and osteoporosis), but a common challenge with increasing vitamin D intake is to achieve sufficient dosing without experiencing any side-effects. Some studies suggest that supplementation should aim to maintain serum 25(OH)D levels within the range of 50-100 ng/mL while avoiding overdosing beyond this range. However, achieving the right dosage level of vitamin D supplementation is difficult, as recommended doses vary across different guidelines and clinical trials while most studies did not measure vitamin D at the time of blood draw. In order to better understand the metabolic pathways of supplemental doses of vitamin D and identify the best way to supplement vitamin D while ensuring an appropriate dosage is achieved, the investigators propose to measure participants' blood levels of vitamin D before and after vitamin D supplementation (from baseline to the end of the intervention) together with the study team's own pharmacokinetic studies. The investigators will compare blood levels of vitamin D (calculated as serum 25(OH)D) with the daily supplementation dose in order to determine the correct dosing strategy to achieve the targeted range of 50-100 ng/mL.

Vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) represent a significant health burden. One of the key determinants of the VCID is obesity-related endothelial dysfunction that is characterized by reduction of nitric oxide (NO)-dependent vasodilation, which is critical in ensuring optimal blood flow to the brain and other organs. Urolithin A (UA), a secondary metabolite of dietary polyphenols, has been reported to improve endothelial function and increase cerebral blood flow in animal and cell models without affecting peripheral blood pressure. The investigators aim to test whether UA supplementation (30 days) would improve endothelial function, cerebral blood flow regulation, and selected serum indicators of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function in middle-aged adults with obesity (54 +/- 20 years old) in randomized double-masked placebo-controlled study. The investigators expect that UA supplementation in middle-aged adults with obesity will improve endothelial function, cerebral blood flow regulation, and selected serum indicators of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function, and that this will be accompanied by a reduction of blood pressure and vascular stiffness.

Background: The direct consequences of total laryngectomy are multiple: loss of phonation (voice) and need to learn to speak again through speech therapy; Disappearance of oral-nasal breathing (and therefore loss of smell, or even taste); Disappearance of the capacity of the effort with closed glottis (used in the acts of daily life: defecation, sexual act in men, etc.); Impairment of body image and often self-esteem.
Objective: The aim of the study is twofold: to study, quantitatively and qualitatively, the impact of total laryngectomy on the body image of patients in the follow-up and to evaluate the benefit of the self-help workshops for patients.
Methods: 
The study will last two years, with inclusion in January 2020. Fifty patients will be included after they have completed all the care required for their pathology. Each patient will participate in a cycle of four sessions, over four months. Each will be carried out with five patients, in order to facilitate exchanges. The aim is to organize eight groups, each completing a cycle. This will allow to include about 40 patients in the study.
The sessions will follow a similar structure for each meeting in the cycle. The content will be similar for all the groups. There will be a first meeting to get to know each other, a second meeting to present the association of voice mutilated, a third meeting to listen to a resource patient and a fourth meeting to evaluate patient satisfaction.
To assess the benefit of these meetings, a global quality of life questionnaire (WHOQOL-BREF) and an ENT-specific questionnaire (EORTC QLQH&n43) should be completed during the first meeting and withdrawn beforehand. The patient can participate in the sessions only if the questionnaires are collected. Patients who cannot participate in exchange groups for geographical or personal reasons will constitute the control group. This group will also complete the two questionnaires four months apart.
The number of patients registered and the participation rate in each session will be evaluated. Quality of life questionnaires (WHOQOL-BREF and EORTC QLQH&n43) will be analyzed after inclusion (T0) and after the sessions (T1). The data will be analyzed using t, McNemar, Wilcoxon non-parametric tests or non-parametric Mann-Whitney tests when necessary.
The analysis will be done according to an intention-to-treat principle.
The rate of loss to follow-up will be noted.
Expected results of the research: Exchanging on these daily-life troubles and fears that are sometimes taboo can promote better acceptance of the body, and the body image changes resulting from total laryngectomy.

The MS-DETECT trial is a prospective, open label, multicenter, single-arm, non-interventional study to assess the usefulness of the MSCopilot® Detect digital test-based application to detect early disability progression and measure disability changes in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis at early disease stages (Expanded Disability Status Scale [EDSS] <5.5).
The primary objectives of this observational trial are to (1) evaluate the ability of MSCopilot® Detect individual and/or composite scores (i.e., the change from baseline of the sum of the absolute differences between the current score or score change and the previous) to predict disability worsening and (2) to measure disability progression in patients with RRMS and assess the reproducibility, reliability, validity and safety of these individual and/or composite scores. The secondary objectives will be to assess the association between individual and/or composite scores with the clinical scores, the change of fatigue, of health quality of life, of the patient and physician satisfaction and of the mobile application's usability.

The PCOS Challenge Study is a registry aimed at collecting data on the experiences of individuals with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) for use in future research to create a profile of the syndrome. Participants will complete online surveys detailing various aspects of their health and wellbeing. The goal is to better understand the symptoms and experiences of people with PCOS in order to improve diagnosis, treatment, and overall care for this condition. This registry is part of a larger research initiative, the PCOS Challenge, which is focused on improving the care of PCOS patients through a range of approaches, including education, community support, and advocacy.

Low molecular weight heparins (LMWHs) as preventive treatment against deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and embolism in patients with a high-risk of bleeding are often used. Although LMWHs are considered safe drugs, there are reports suggesting that their use is linked to a higher risk of death or bleeding requiring transfusions. This study is designed as a cluster-randomized, open trial comparing the safety and effect of two different LMWHs. All patients with indication for LMWHs are included. Each patient is only allocated to receive one of the two types of LMWHs. The study compares 65.000 patients receiving either dalteparin or tinzaparin and will follow the patients for 30, 90 and 365 days. The primary outcome is to compare the risk of bleeding requiring blood transfusion or mortality during hospitalization. Secondary outcomes will evaluate the risk of hospital stay, all-cause mortality and bleeding during hospitalization, the risk of death from any cause, DVT and PEs within 30, 90 and 365 days, incidence of HIT, liver failure and any type of bleeding during follow-up.
It is anticipated that the clinical trial will provide valuable knowledge of the safety of different LMWH-treatments. These findings may contribute to a more informed decision of which LMWH to use in patients with indication for LMWH.

Acquired brain injury (ABI) is a main cause of morbidity and mortality, especially in older people. These people suffer high levels of disability, functional loss, loss of independence, mortality, and reduced quality of life. Moreover, muscle weakness, mainly respiratory muscle weakness, occurs mainly when respiratory training is not applied. Furthermore, they also experience low levels of activity. However, the improvement through respiratory muscle training (RMT) and physical exercise is unclear. Thus, the purpose of this study is to investigate the effect of RMT on respiratory muscle strength (RMS) and function of older people suffering from ABI and living in the nursing home.
Method. This is an intervention study where adult patients with ABI from nursing homes were randomly allocated into two groups: intervention group (group A): Inspiratory Muscle Training (IMT), and control group (Group B): Expiratory Muscle Training (PEMT). Both groups will maintain the intervention during 8 weeks and 5 days a week. All measures and assessments will take place in the nursing home.
Results. Significant differences in RMS between groups A and B. These differences were due to the increase in inspiratory muscle strength in group A compared to its resting values.

The ASARD-TMA project is an artificial Intelligence-based system designed to speed up the diagnosis and treatment of thrombotic microangiopathies in the Emergency Department. In this study, a predictive model based on clinical and laboratory data will be built to identify patients with a high probability of having a thrombotic microangiopathy, allowing early initiation of treatment and reducing the length of hospital stay and the mortality rate in these patients.

Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) rely on others to dispense clean water, and current methods of dispensing using hydration packs and straws can create unsanitary conditions and are unfeasible for those with upper extremity paralysis. 5-level, functional independence using a 10 point measure for individuals with SCI is proposed. This measure is being tested in individuals with high-level SCI (quadriplegic) using the Access-H20 fountain faucet to control water dispensing using eye gaze, voice, and motion sensors. The goal for the subject-user is to complete the three functions of the Access-H2O faucet: 1) Drink water from the faucet, 2) rinse mouth, and 3) rinse face, using motion, voice, or eye gaze commands to dispense the desired amount and temperature of water. The faucet features have been pre-programmed to activate the desired features of the faucet. The faucet has incorporated electromechanical controls and software programs that adjust spray outlets, spray angles, and water temperatures. Once activated, the camera and other sensors can track movement of the hands or arms from the shoulder joint and determine the angle for delivery of water into subject's mouth, onto a clean piece of tissue to remove dirt from the face or onto the brush to clean the face, depending on the subject's ability to engage the task. The functional independence scores for drinking, rinsing, and grooming using the Access-H20 faucet have been determined to test the device feasibility and the percentage of individuals at a respective functional independence level for a particular task, such as drinking, rinsing, and grooming. These scores will be compared to those at a normal healthy level (i.e. no disability) in order to determine the effectiveness of the Access-H20 faucet in reducing the level of disability and dependence for individuals living with SCI.

The objective of this cluster-randomized controlled trial is to analyze the effect of an intermittent teaching unit during compulsory Physical Education lessons on students' motivation, intentions and habitual physical activity. It is proposed to use activity wristbands (FitBit Zip) to evaluate the students' daily physical activity. An intent-to-treat analytical model using a multilevel mixed-model will be used to analyze the data. Students (N=1,225) in seventh, eighth, ninth and tenth grades of secondary education of 19 public schools will be randomly assigned into two conditions (intermittent and control group) matched for gender, body mass index (BMI) and Physical Education program. A total of 42 Physical Education classes will be included in this study. The intermittent group students will be trained on the use of the activity wristbands to perform a daily self-monitoring of PA. The control group students will wear physical activity activity wristbands but will not be trained on its use. Both groups will be evaluated by a standardized test including questionnaires measuring students' motivation, autonomous motivation, self-determined motivation, intention to be physically active, perceived autonomy support from Physical Education teachers, and basic psychological needs in Physical Education. Moreover, students' habitual physical activity will be measured with a physical activity questionnaire and objectively with activity wristbands. The results will be corroborated 6 weeks after intervention completion.

The prevalence of autonomic nervous system dysfunction including orthostatic intolerance (OI) is as high as 6% in the general population and can be even higher among patients with chronic diseases. OI is a multi-organ disorder and is characterised by a reduction in the functional reserve of the cardiovascular system, caused by the inability to increase blood flow to the peripheral arteries, including hands, during orthostatic changes in body position, induced by a reduction in blood volume in the lower part of the body. This causes a failure in blood flow to the heart and vital organs. However, the current gold standard method used for evaluating autonomic nervous system function is subjective to several factors, such as the lack of a consistent methodology and the inability to reliably measure the autonomic response in a continuous, non-invasive, and patient-friendly mode.
The aim of this study is to evaluate the accuracy of Autonomic Function Testing with the Task Force® CORE and Task Force® CARDIO, compared to the gold standard indirect technique using blood pressure cuffs (blood pressure recording from two fingers) and assessed via ECG (heart rate and cardiac output). Task Force® CORE and CARDIO allow in-clinic accurate and non-invasive measurements of cardiac parameters. The assessment includes beat-to-beat blood pressure parameters and cardiac parameters, including heart rate and cardiac output. The blood pressure recording is taken from two fingers, and the heart rate assessment is performed using a five-lead electrocardiogram (ECG). ECG is used for the analysis of cardiac parameters. Additionally, beat detection is performed, using a dedicated algorithm. A continuous non-invasive beat-to-beat blood pressure and 5 lead ECG monitoring allows for heart rate and cardiac output evaluation in the beat-by-beat mode.
The present study will include 20 healthy volunteers and 33 patients with OI without other comorbidities. The subjects will be asked to take part in the following tests and assessments:
Supine Baseline Blood Pressure Measurement: The reference device will measure the absolute blood pressure variables [systolic, diastolic and mean pressure in mmHg (millimetres of mercury)] using two blood pressure recording devices from the two middle fingers, according to ISO 81064. Blood pressure will be recorded for 5 minutes.
Supine Non-invasive Blood Pressure Measurement: The investigational device will measure the absolute blood pressure variables [systolic, diastolic and mean pressure in mmHg (millimetres of mercury)] using 2 non-invasive blood pressure recording devices from the two middle fingers in continuous mode for 5 minutes.
Supine Heart Rate and Cardiac Output Measurement: The reference device will measure the absolute heart rate (bpm [beats per minute)] and cardiac output(in l/min) using the 5 lead ECG in continuous mode. 5 lead ECG is the standard for assessing heart rate and cardiac output. The absolute values for HR and CO will be recorded for 5 minutes.
Patient Examination and Study Procedures: 
Patients will be examined under standard conditions in the cardiology outpatient clinic in the Supine position and in a Head-up tilt position in a 20 ° position for 10 minutes. Each examination and measurement will be conducted by a medical technician who is not blinded for the device used, and the procedure is the same for both devices. During the examination, measurements will be conducted continuously within a period of 15 minutes (Supine Base Line) of supine position. The Head-up tilt table test will be performed for 10 minutes. In the end, the heart rate and blood pressure measurements will be performed in a supine resting position during 5 minutes. Blood pressure will be recorded with the reference device for blood pressure recording from fingers. Simultaneously, heart rate (5 lead ECG) will be recorded for 5 minutes.

The mental health of youth is an important public health concern. Compared to other age groups, youth have the highest percentage of individuals with disorders, with approximately 75% of mental health disorders first appearing by age 18. Despite their prevalence, there is a critical mismatch between student mental health needs and available mental health services in Ontario. This mismatch is primarily driven by limited public funding and a shortage of clinicians who can provide evidence-based interventions for students with mental health disorders. This issue is particularly acute in smaller, rural communities, such as Kingston, Frontenac, Lennox & Addington, as they lack local mental health resources, and students have greater difficulty accessing such services that are located in larger cities.
The proposed regional mental healthcare hub (hub) will target a broad population of students in the KFL&A community. The initiative will provide equitable, efficacious, and cost-effective AI-driven online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific (e.g., MDD, GAD, SAD) online cognitive behavioural therapy (e-CBT) programs. Our research team is strongly experienced in designing effective online psychoeducation and e-CBT programs for various mental health conditions in diverse populations. Therefore, being as effective as in-person methods of healthcare delivery, it is hypothesized that our online interventions disseminated via a robust implementation science and community collaboration strategy will be a feasible, cost-effective, and pragmatic solution to address accessibility issues with post-secondary student mental healthcare.
The proposed mental health hub will offer a comprehensive care model using a stepped-care approach. Its implementation will be guided by a rigorous approach involving seven aims divided into three phases (pre-adoption, delivery, and post-adoption phases). (1) Pre-adoption phase: will assess post-secondary students' current mental health landscape through surveys and focus groups (Aim 1). This information will be used to develop a 6-week online psychoeducation (Aim 2) and 12-week diagnosis-specific e-CBT (Aim 3) programs. The psychoeducation program will be followed by 6 months of AI-assisted journaling exercises to monitor the student's mental health and determine whether they would benefit from stepping up their care to receive the diagnosis-specific e-CBT program. The diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs will be adapted from prior clinically validated and diagnosis-specific psychotherapy modules developed by the lab. Four diagnosis-specific modules will support the most common mental health disorders in students (GAD, SAD, MDD, and ADHD), as indicated by previous studies. Both programs will be delivered through the Online Psychotherapy Tool (OPTT) - a secure cloud-based platform co-developed by the PI that offers online mental health interventions.
(2) Delivery phase: will determine the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the online psychoeducation (Aim 4) and diagnosis-specific e-CBT (Aim 5) programs by comparing them to treatment as usual.
(3) Post-adoption phase: will use the collected data and feedback to monitor the success and fidelity of the programs. The data will be used to build capacity and scale the project to other municipalities.

Background: Cutaneous warts are common, benign, hyperproliferative epidermal lesions caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infections. The incidence of warts is up to 12% in the general population, with school children and young adults being the most common demographic.
Objective: The main objective of this study is to create a baseline understanding of the efficacy of combination treatment of AV2 (0.10% carvone, 0.012% eugenol, 0.037% geraniol and 0.046% nerolidol) with salicylic acid (24% w/v) treatment on persistent warts compared to standard salicylic acid treatment alone.
Design: 100 patients with persistent warts (one index wart and 2-10 additional satellites) will be enrolled and their warts will be photographed before assignment to the randomized treatment arms at baseline. The baseline data will be analyzed to determine the genotype-specific distribution of wart-associated HPV types in a Belgian population (according to the age, wart location, postal code, etc.); to investigate whether mucosal HPV types are more prevalent in cutaneous warts.
Efficacy: 50 patients will receive AV2-SA treatment and 50 patients will receive salicylic acid alone. Assessments will be performed monthly: 4-weekly for the first month and twice monthly thereafter. After 12 weeks, patients will be asked to stop treatment completely while the warts will be left to assess the long-term effect of a 12-week treatment. At weeks 14, 16 and 18 follow-up photographs will be taken. After 6 months, a second treatment period will be requested to evaluate the recurrence rate.
At these follow-up moments, all lesions in the treated area will be assessed and the index wart (or remaining fragment of an original lesion) will be identified. Cure rates will be based on the status of the index wart (complete or partial cure).
Adverse events will be assessed using an adapted short version of the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE).
Conclusion: This study will demonstrate whether a combination of carvone (AV2) and salicylic acid in a single treatment, at home and easily accessible, will result in a higher cure rate and a lower recurrence rate compared to standard salicylic acid therapy for persistent warts. Since salicylic acid alone has limited efficacy and a high recurrence rate (45%), this combination treatment is likely to become a more effective first-line therapy for those patients for whom currently available treatment options fail.

The present study aimed to compare the efficacy of letrozole with that of standard treatment methotrexate in women with ectopic pregnancy and the safety in terms of side effects and complications during and after treatment.
In recent decades, the treatment of ectopic pregnancy has been a major focus of research in both developed and developing countries. Standard treatment for uncomplicated ectopic pregnancy is usually medical. Among existing medications, methotrexate is the safest, most effective and most commonly used drug. But several side effects have been reported on the use of methotrexate such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, liver toxicity, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and even mortality. Letrozole is a new treatment for ectopic pregnancy.
In this study, about 75 women diagnosed with ectopic pregnancy who are referred to the Obstetrics and Gynecology Center of Valiasr Hospital are included in the study. Demographic information including both gynecological and obstetrical data is collected. Ectopic ectopic pregnancy is confirmed by transvaginal ultrasound. The patients are randomly allocated to three groups. The first group will receive a single dose of methotrexate (50 mg/m2).The second group will receive letrozole within a 10-day period (2.5 mg twice a day). The third group will receive letrozole in a 5-day period three times a day. The efficacy of treatment regimens will be calculated with the help of the rate of β-hcg decline.
In conclusion, letrozole can be a good alternative to methotrexate in the management of uncomplicated ectopic pregnancy. In this way, physicians gain the possibility of using other drugs that may cause less side effects in pregnant women and can be used for years.
Letrozole and Methotrexate in Ectopic Pregnancy
Letrozole is a new treatment for ectopic pregnancy.
Ectopic pregnancy remains a significant medical problem of pregnancy-related morbidity. Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, is a new effective treatment option for ectopic pregnancy.
The use of letrozole in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy is safe and has no significant side effects. Letrozole eliminates pregnancy hormone in an easier and faster way, and the success rate is faster than methotrexate. Letrozole is effective not only in the treatment of unruptured ectopic pregnancy but also in ectopic pregnancy with rupture and hemodynamic instability. Letrozole can also be effective in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy with ovarian mass.
In conclusion, letrozole can be a good alternative to methotrexate in the management of uncomplicated ectopic pregnancy. In this way, physicians may gain the possibility of using other drugs that may cause less side effects in pregnant women and that can be used for years. Letrozole treatment is costly. In this study, it is cheaper than methotrexate treatment. Therefore, this study has clinical implications for the treatment of ectopic pregnancy.
How does the treatment with letrozole compare to the standard treatment of methotrexate in the management of ectopic pregnancy?

ASD closure in cases with severe pulmonary hypertension presents a clinical challenge. Incomplete treatment of ASD is associated with increased mortality. Small LV (left ventricular diameters less than 48 mm - 2D-image) is an adverse prognostic indicator of ASD. While the optimal treatment of ASD patients with pulmonary hypertension is unclear, evidence from registries suggest that closure may result in less disease progression and lower mortality. The risk of pulmonary hypertensive crisis after complete closure is however high. To minimize this, the use of fenestrated patch was advocated to create volume backup and improve forward flow. This study evaluates whether there are differences on echocardiography parameters between a group of ASD patients with small LV before treatment, who have undergone surgical closure with fenestrated compared to non- fenestrated patch.
