Background: Papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) is the most frequent type of thyroid cancer. The majority of PTC patients have good prognosis but 5-15% develop a progressive form of the disease. Although molecular alterations such as BRAF and RAS point mutations, RET/PTC3 and PAX8/PPARγ transcriptional fusions have been identified, further genetic and/or epigenetic events might be involved in the progression of PTC.

Objectives: Our hypothesis is that oxidative stress might play a role in the progression of PTC, by inducing mitochondrial gene transcription via an epigenetic mechanism involving the TERT promoter. TERT is a transcription factor, whose expression is essential for telomere maintenance; however, it can localize either to the nucleus or to the mitochondrial matrix. The aim of this project is to characterize the mitochondrial properties of PTC by measuring H2O2 generation, reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels and TERT nuclear to mitochondrial translocation in patient tissues and in vitro cell lines. Moreover, the impact of an oxidative status on TERT localization and on gene expression will be further investigated. Finally, we aim to study the therapeutic resistance of BRAF inhibitors that target mitochondrial pathways, to decipher the role of TERT and the mitochondrial energy production in tumor cells.

Study population: PTC patients will be enrolled in different centers for this study. They will undergo surgery for PTC and/or post-operative radiotherapy. Tissue samples will be collected at the moment of thyroidectomy. The number of subjects is 250, for which RNA, RNA-seq and DNA will be analyzed. In addition, 150 subjects will be recruited in dedicated cohorts to be used for the specific aim. For this, an additional 100 tumor and cancer-free tissues from the first cohort will be used to measure H2O2 generation, TERT nuclear localization, TERT and OXPHOS mRNA expression.

This is a phase III prospective multi-centre open label two-arm randomised controlled trial with an internal pilot and masked outcome assessments. Babies who are born at or after 36 weeks of gestation requiring prolonged resuscitation at birth (defined as continued resuscitation at 10 minutes after birth or 10-minute Apgar score less than 6) or those with severe birth acidosis and admitted to the neonatal unit will be screened for eligibility. All babies undergoing whole-body hypothermia will be cooled to 33.5±0.5°C for 72 hours using a servo-controlled cooling machine. Babies randomised to normothermia will be kept in neutral thermal environment for 80 hours.
The follow up assessment will be done for the recruited babies at 24 (±2) months of age by a central team of 2 to 3 examiners, masked to the allocation. The assessment will be carried out using the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development IV. In addition, all infants will have a detailed neurological examination, including Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) for cerebral palsy, vision, and hearing assessment. Babies who die (the mortality rate is expected to be less than 1% in mild HIE) or who cannot be assessed with the Bayley-IV due to severe disability will be allocated a Cognitive Scale Composite score one point below the basal test score (i.e., score of 54) similar to the previous whole-body hypothermia trials. In all infants, PARCA-R (online or face to face) will be completed by the parents immediately prior to the Bayley IV assessments and CBCL (face to face only). The follow up visit will be scheduled in close consultation with the parents, either at the local hospital or at home.

=================
Eligibility Criteria
-----------------
All babies born at or after 36 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1800g or more with birth acidosis or requiring resuscitation at birth will be screened for eligibility. Parents will be approached for consent if the baby meets all the three (A + B + C) criteria below: A. Evidence of intra-partum hypoxia-ischemia defined as any of - (i) Apgar score of <6 at 10 minutes after birth; (ii) continued need for resuscitation, including endotracheal or mask ventilation, at 10 minutes after birth; (iii) severe birth acidosis defined as any occurrence of pH <7.00 or a Base deficit >16mmol/l in any cord or baby gas sample within 60 minutes of birth. B. Evidence of mild hypoxic ischaemic encephalopathy defined as - two or more abnormal findings in any of the six categories of the modified Sarnat examination (level of consciousness, spontaneous activity, posture, tone, primitive reflexes, and autonomic nervous system) but not meeting the diagnosis of moderate or severe hypoxic ischaemic encephalopathy on a standardised examination performed by a certified examiner between 1 to 6 hours of age. C. Normal amplitude on aEEG performed for at least 30 minutes between 1 to 6 hours of age. Normal amplitude will be defined as upper margin of the aEEG activity more than 10 microvolts and the lower margin more than 5 microvolts on a single channel aEEG.

Pancreatic malignant neoplasms (PDAC) are very aggressive and therapy-resistant cancers. This makes patients with advanced PDAC have a very poor prognosis despite aggressive treatment, even though the therapeutic outcome of PDAC is still improving. It is widely accepted that immunotherapy is a promising strategy to overcome the poor outcomes of PDAC. However, there is no FDA-approved immunotherapeutic agent that has proven clinical efficacy in PDAC.
The investigators have developed the first generation of autologous T cell therapy based on neoantigens (pTNT). This investigational treatment (iCureTM) was not successful in treating PDAC, in part because the repertoire of tumor neoantigens is very heterogenous and may vary in different PDAC patients. In addition, the treatment's efficacy also may vary depending on tumor microenvironment composition in which the tumor resides. 
Therefore, this project aims to develop a second generation of autologous T cell-based therapy using neoantigens specific for each patient (pTTL), i.e. "personalized tumor-trained lymphocytes". This therapy has the potential to overcome resistance to pTNT.

<|assistant|> Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory disease of unknown etiology, presenting with non-caseating granulomas in various organs. Intrathoracic manifestations of the disease, including enlarged lymph nodes, are frequently found on chest imaging. The clinical course of sarcoidosis is often unpredictable. Some patients will improve spontaneously, some will worsen and experience severe shortness of breath because of pulmonary fibrosis, while others will develop disabling extra-thoracic arthropathy. Sarcoidosis is diagnosed on the basis of clinical, histopathological and radiological findings. In some cases, it is necessary to rule out other granulomatous diseases such as tuberculosis. The current diagnostic criteria for sarcoidosis lack validity, although there is some recent evidence suggesting that various imaging (chest imaging) and blood based (e.g. serum concentrations of CC chemokine ligand 18 (CCL18), monokine induced by interferon-γ (CXCL9)) but also pulmonary function tests and high-resolution computed tomography scans are of diagnostic and prognostic value. Other inflammatory markers (e.g. serum concentrations of TNF-related apoptosis inducing ligand (TRAIL)), interleukin-1 (IL1), interleukin-6 (IL6), interleukin-8 (IL8) and interleukin-10 (IL10) were suggested to be more specific to distinguish between tuberculosis and sarcoidosis. There are reports on increased circulating levels of serum amyloid A (SAA) in patients with sarcoidosis but its diagnostic value has not been confirmed in a large cohort. The investigators hypothesize that SAA levels are increased in patients with sarcoidosis and correlate with disease activity, extent of the disease and correlate with other biomarkers of inflammation and pulmonary damage. The investigator also hypothesizes that the serum levels of SAA may correlate to extent of disease on high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scans and extent of disease on Pulmonary function tests. Objective: SAA level in serum samples at diagnosis of intrathoracic sarcoidosis can be evaluated as a part of the differential diagnosis of granulomatous disease. Exclusion Criteria: Individuals with granulomatous disease that could not be unequivocally diagnosed as sarcoidosis were excluded, as well as patients with possible confounding other known systemic inflammatory illnesses, acute infection, patients on immunosuppressive drugs or immunotherapy and patients with active cancer. Early in vitro culture of pre-implantation embryos generates an altered endometrial environment which can lead to pregnancy failure. In parallel with improving developmental capacity of embryos, there is an urgent clinical need for simple cost-effective modifications to current practice which can improve the implantation of embryos. It has been shown that the pre-implantation culture of embryos on a small volume of culture medium with the patient's serum (blank culture) prior to transfer could improve implantation of embryos in IVF cycles. However to date, this technique have not been considered applicable in frozen embryo cycle.
In the context of frozen embryo cycles, the objective of this study is to determine whether a simple procedure (small volume of blank culture medium pre-transfer) can improve implantation of embryos during transfer of a single thawed embryo.
This is an open, multi-centre randomized controlled trial.
All women undergoing frozen embryo transfer (FET) will be approached for the study and will be randomized to receive either a single transfer on day of progesterone only medication (P), or a transfer carried out 72 hours previously with a small volume of blank culture medium and a second transfer on progesterone only.
Primary outcome is the pregnancy rate per woman at 12 weeks of amenorrhea. Secondary outcomes are: the rate of biochemical pregnancies, clinical pregnancies, ectopic pregnancies, miscarriages, live births.
Treatment costs and resource utilization will also be evaluated through a cost-utility analysis.

The study aims to collect the clinical data and blood samples of patients, follow up the efficacy and prognosis of patients with immunotherapy after collecting baseline information, and build a database of clinical data, blood samples and questionnaire evaluation information of patients. It is planned to collect and evaluate the health status of the patients before and after immunotherapy, and analyze the factors influencing the efficacy and prognosis of immunotherapy to provide more effective and personalized treatment strategies for patients.
The study is a non-interventional retrospective study, and data observation is the main approach. The cohort of patients will be followed up in 3 stages, with 2 years of observation. During this period, the investigator will follow up on the patients according to the schedule designed in the research plan, collect data related to the patients during this period, and record the information in the patients' electronic medical files. The main research content is mainly concentrated on the collection of clinical information and blood samples before and after immunotherapy, the evaluation of health status, and follow-up of efficacy and prognosis.
The investigators will collect the clinical profile of the patients, laboratory profiles and outcome measures of health status before and after immunotherapy. The investigators will follow up the patients after randomization by outpatient, telephone and web. The relevant data of the patients will be recorded every 3 months throughout the process of treatment, and the data will be collected by the investigators' visit or phone call. It is planned to collect the results of patients' disease progression-free survival and overall survival every 3 months for two years after enrollment. The investigators may collect more detailed information according to the needs of the project. The information collected includes the patient's demographic character, diagnosis of disease, treatment history, quality of life questionnaire, laboratory examination, the use of other drugs and complementary health services, information on disease progression and the cause of death due to the reasons of death, medical treatment changes, etc.

Study Overview
=============
Detailed Description
-----------------
Aim: The study was planned to examine the effect of acupressure on back pain in the late postpartum period after cesarean section. Hypothesis(s): H0: Acupressure application applied to puerperant women who had a cesarean delivery in the late postpartum period has no effect on reducing the level of back pain. H1: Acupressure application applied to puerperant women who had cesarean delivery in the late postpartum period reduces the level of back pain. Type of Research: This study was designed as a randomized controlled experimental study. Research population: The population of the research will consist of participants who have had cesarean section, who have back pain, who are in the late postpartum 1st week and 4th week, and who are registered to family medicine units in a Family Health Center. It was calculated according to the research conducted by Akgün and Boz to determine the sample size in the study. The sample size of the study was calculated using the G*Power 3.1.9.2 program and the mean, standard deviation values and effect size of the back pain variable in the related article (Akgün & Boz, 2020) were taken into account. The effect size was calculated as 1.025136 by using the mean and standard deviation values of the related article. The minimum number of individuals to be included in the sample of the study to be done was calculated by taking G*Power 3.1.9.2 and effect size: 1.025136, α= 0.05, power: 0.90, and the sample size was determined as 23 in the acupressure group and 23 in the control group. Background: Septic Shock and Systemic Inflammatory Reaction Syndrome (SIRS) are closely related clinical syndromes. It is common to see overlap of these two terms in clinical practice. They are both important clinical states for the health of patients. The initial prognosis of septic shock and SIRS is poor. Approximately 80% of mortality due to septic shock occurs within 8 hours. SIRS is a condition in which the immune system of an individual goes into overdrive, resulting in inflammation that can be harmful. This inflammation is a body's response to an infection or injury. Sepsis is a more severe form of SIRS.
Objective: The aim of the study is to investigate the effects of Paroxetine on the expression of the Serotonin transporter (SERT), and also, on the improvement of the cardiovascular function of adult patients with septic shock, with hemodynamic instability, and associated SIRS, who are using noradrenaline. SIRS is a clinical condition in which the immune system of an individual goes into overdrive and produces inflammation. This inflammation can be harmful. The study will be randomized, in which patients will be randomly assigned to receive Paroxetine or Placebo. In both groups, participants will receive vasopressors (including norepinephrine) for hemodynamic support.
Method: To evaluate the effects of Paroxetine on the expression of Serotonin, Transporter (SERT) mRNA level in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) and cardiovascular function during septic shock, we will do a randomized, placebo-controlled, open-label trial.
Participants: We will participate adult patients with septic shock and hemodynamic instability.
Intervention: All participants who agree to participate in the trial will sign the informed consent and will be randomized into two groups. Both patient groups will receive a dose of intravenous paroxetine 40mg/days (1440 mg total dose) during 5 days or placebo.
Reasoning: Serotonin metabolism is related to immune system response to infection. Studies show the use of serotonin inhibitors in patients with sepsis to reduce the production of inflammatory markers. The serotonin transporter (SERT), which is expressed in neutrophils, is an important participant in this process. It is suspected that the increase in SERT in the context of septic shock is associated with an increase in inflammatory markers. SERT is regulated by the interaction between inflammatory mediators and microRNAs. Paroxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), can interfere with the normal functioning of SERT and can potentially improve clinical outcomes in patients with septic shock and cardiovascular instability.

This is the RCP2 (Patient Depression Treatment in Primary Care) study. Its main objective is to evaluate the impact of a paramedical education program on the maintenance of continuous antidepressant treatment in patients with a depressive episode of moderate intensity.
The study is a single-centered randomized controlled trial. It includes patient recruitment over a period of 9 months by 9 family doctors. The inclusion of eligible patients will be randomized according to a computerized randomisation program provided by the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The inclusion criteria are: patient older than 18 years with a depressive episode of moderate intensity according to the DSM-V criterion, with a prescription for an antidepressant started less than 2 months before inclusion in the study, whose state of health is compatible with follow-up by his general practitioner, with Internet access at home (computer) and able to use the digital platform.
The exclusion criteria are: patients who are unable to complete self-questionnaires (language barrier, etc.), patients who have already undergone a psycho-education or therapeutic patient education program in depression, patients whose state of health requires follow-up by a psychiatrist.
The study includes two study arms:
- The experimental group, which will consist of patients who will be offered a psycho-educative program for a depressive episode by a registered nurse of the Community Health Center.
- The control group, which will include patients who will receive their usual care from their GP.
All patients who are recruited for the study will complete questionnaires (online).

Narcolepsy is a debilitating, lifelong neurological condition characterised by excessive daytime sleepiness, with episodes of 'sleep attack'; cataplexy- where some people experience sudden muscle weakness that affects speech, limbs or neck and can present when emotionally triggered; and REM-sleep-onset parasomnias. Narcolepsy with sleep attacks usually presents after puberty. Cataplexy can present at any age. The prevalence is reported to be between 50-200 cases per 100,000 people. This study aims to diagnose Narcolepsy in participants with excessive daytime sleepiness and associated symptoms. The study aims to achieve the following:
Assess the ability of continuous 'home' EEG to more accurately diagnose Narcolepsy compared to current ICSD-3 gold standard clinical diagnostic testing with polysomnography and multiple sleep latency tests in inpatients.
Examine if EEG results can predict an accurate response to Narcolepsy treatment.
The objective of the study is to provide data to a National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) grant application which will support a larger study, called the PREVENT trial.

Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and subjective cognitive decline (SCD) are prodromal manifestations of Alzheimer's Disease. Brain hypometabolism is a biomarker of Alzheimer's disease, but brain hypoperfusion using pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling (pCASL) could be an alternative. The investigators aim to assess the clinical utility of pCASL in predicting progression to dementia. Using a cohort of 150 patients, the investigators will perform a multivariate analysis to find specific brain regions correlating with pCASL profiles and cerebro-spinal fluid (CSF) amyloid beta (Aβ), phosphorylated tau (p-tau) and total tau (t-tau).

The purpose of a randomised controlled trial is to objectively compare the clinical and functional outcomes of a combined surgical wires plus STERNFIX™ (intervention group) technique and traditional wires only technique (control group) when closing median sternotomy. The study also aims to provide evidence to improve patient care.

<|assistant|> Background: Young people tend to spend most of their time in sitting position while studying and using the electronic devices. Prolonged sitting is associated with musculoskeletal dysfunction including low back pain (LBP). This may be explained by the prolonged sitting time, next to reduced level of physical activity. Physiotherapists recommend many different sitting positions to prevent and treat negative effects of prolonged sitting. However, there is debate regarding what is an optimal sitting posture. The current energy crisis, exacerbated by the war in Ukraine, is causing e-learning back to educational institutions. However this change in learning methods is associated with musculoskeletal dysfunction including low back pain. Research aim: The aim of this study is to evaluate the effect of active break on reduce LBP and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting in young people with LBP. Methods: This will be a randomized controlled study with pre and post-intervention assessment. The participants will be recruited from students. Participants were randomly assigned to the intervention group consisting of an active break (n = 25) or the control group (n = 25). The group with an active break with postural change from sitting to standing will be recommended to take an active break for every 30 minutes of sitting. The primary outcome will be average pain intensity (Visual Analogue Scale, VAS), disability measured using the Oswestry Disability Index and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting (Borg scale) and The Global Perceived Effect (7-point Likert scale). Secondary outcome will Post-Intervention Questionnaire (5-item self-completed questionnaire). Vaginal dryness, mucosal pallor, vaginal bleeding and an increased risk of infections are common problems that affect women in the reproductive and postmenopausal age group. These problems are also associated with negative effects on quality of life. These changes depend on a decrease in the concentration of sex hormones, especially oestrogen. The decline in oestrogen levels in the vagina results in the depletion of the lactobacilli component and the consequent increase in susceptibility to pathogens. Tocopherol is a fat-soluble vitamin that contributes to pH acidification in the vaginal environment, making it inhospitable to pathogens. In addition, recent data indicate its antibacterial action in conditions of bacterial infection. The aim of the study will be to assess the effectiveness of an oestrogenic and protective role of topical vaginal tocopherol in reducing the signs and symptoms associated with hormonal depletion. These outcomes include vaginal pH (reducing pH to 4.5), vaginal dryness (reducing vaginal dryness by at least 2 points), vaginal mucosal integrity (restoring the microcirculation of the vaginal mucosa), vaginal mucosal pallor (improving mucosal vascularization and blood supply). The study will also verify if the treatment restores the lactobacilli flora to grades ≥ 3 and reduces the Whiff test sensitivity and the total score of the microbiological assessment of the vaginal mucosa by 50%. Furthermore, the study will evaluate the presence of adverse events associated with the application of tocopherol. At the end of the study, the data will be analyzed and the clinical effectiveness of the treatment will be verified in terms of the percentage of responders.

A randomized, double-blind, active-placebo controlled phase II study will be conducted to determine the effect of moderate-to-high doses of LSD on well-being in patients with end-stage illness. The study will be a three-phase study with pre- and post-randomization measurement of subjective, objective, and biological data. Up to 140 patients with a life expectancy between 12 to 24 months, age between 25 and 75 years, and suffering from end-stage illness and psychological/existential maladjustment and/or anxiety, pain, demoralization and/or depression, and fear of death will be included in the study. After a two-week observation period, eligible patients are assigned to treatment or control groups in a randomized way. After pre-randomization measurements, patients in the treatment group receive 100 µg of LSD on two consecutive days in a standardized out-patient setting. Control group patients receive 25 µg of LSD the first and 25 µg the second day, respectively. If the first sessions are well tolerated, patients of the treatment group are administered two doses of 200 µg on day 2 and 3 (second intervention). Patients of the control group receive a second dose of 25 µg on day 2 (second intervention). Safety and efficacy are measured over 11 weeks (3 months). Safety is measured in terms of side-effects and blood levels of LSD, heart rate, blood pressure, and body temperature. Efficacy is measured as changes in subjective assessments and objective measurements of psychosocial data and quality of life. Results of a similar study in cancer patients yielded clinically meaningful and statistically significant results for most measurements. In this study an even larger effect is expected.

Inclusion Criteria:
Age between 25 and 75 years. A clinical diagnosis of end-stage illness with a life expectancy between 12 to 24 months. Suffering from psychological/existential maladjustment and/or anxiety, pain, demoralization and/or depression, and fear of death. Informed consent and willingness to adhere to study procedures.

Pregnancy is a critical period for maternal-fetal health. Although perinatal interventions are effective at improving maternal-fetal outcomes, they are often underutilized. Evidence suggests that maternal decision-making during pregnancy is an important contributing factor to the uptake of perinatal interventions. 
In Canada, access to prenatal care is increasing and high-quality prenatal care is widely available. To promote maternal decision-making that improves perinatal outcomes, text messaging is a promising, low-cost tool for women who may benefit from evidence-based prenatal information and support. 
Pregnancy is a period of dynamic health, including increased maternal knowledge and engagement in healthy behaviours. Teaching behaviourally via text messaging is one promising method for supporting maternal decision-making and promoting healthy behaviours. By providing women with mobile access to maternal health education, tools, and support, SmartMom aims to improve maternal and newborn health for a range of Canadian women. 
The purpose of this trial is to evaluate the impact of the SmartMom text messaging program on maternal weight gain during pregnancy, maternal attendance at prenatal care appointments, uptake and adherence to recommended health interventions and screenings in pregnancy, uptake and adherence to care for maternal and newborn health, maternal health outcomes (including rates of depression, anxiety, and postpartum depressive symptoms), rates of breastfeeding initiation and duration, and rates of gestational diabetes, preterm birth (<37 weeks gestation), stillbirth, and small for gestational age (SGA) birth. 
The primary hypothesis is that participation in the SmartMom mobile intervention arm will result in more participants meeting recommended amounts of weight gain and attendance at prenatal care appointments compared to participants receiving the control messages. Secondary hypotheses include: 1) Maternal engagement in recommended health behaviours will be higher in the intervention group, 2) Postpartum depression, anxiety, and related symptoms will be lower in the intervention group, 3) Maternal and newborn health outcomes will be improved in the intervention group, and 4) Breastfeeding initiation and duration will be improved in the intervention group.

Official Title
-----------------
Teaching by Texting to Promote Health Behaviours in Pregnancy

Conditions
-----------------
Pregnancy

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Behavioral: SmartMom text messaging
* Behavioral: Control text messaging


Participation Criteria
=================
Eligibility Criteria
-----------------
Inclusion Criteria: pregnant person at 15 weeks gestation or earlier singleton pregnancy can read and understand English at grade 8 level and comfortable completing online surveys live in Canada (excluding British Columbia where SmartMom has been piloted) Exclusion Criteria: health conditions existing prior to pregnancy that require individualized care (e.g. hypertension, cardiac disease, diabetes) previously had a baby with the SmartMom program
